 = Page 1 =

About the Author ..8

Thomas Powell has been professionally involved in the Internet community since 1987ì

His career began with network support at UCLA’s PICnet, followed by several years aš

CERFnet. In 1994, he founded Powell Internet Consulting, LLC (www.pint.com), a fir“

specializing in advanced Web design and developmentì

Powell is the author of two other popular Web development books:  Web Sit—

Engineerinv  (with Dominique Cutts and David Jones) and thk  HTML Programmer'x

Referenc—  (with Dan Whitworth). He has written extensively about the Web an™

development technologies foK  NetGuid—InterneP Week¨ Interactiv— Age¨ Communicationx  ,

Week¨  an™  Networ Worl  ì

Mr. Powell teaches Web publishing classes through the Information Technologie—

program at UCSD Extension. He holds a B.S. in Math Applied Science from UCLA an™

an M.S. in Computer Science from UCSDì

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

Acknowledgment

riting a comprehensive book about a topic as large as HTML is a dauntiný

task. As my business partner, Jimmy Tam, often says, “Don’t let anybody telR

you that HTML is easy.” This is more true than any of us would like to admitì

W

Even though I have taught HTML for years at UCSD Extension, written numerou—

articles on the subject, and been involved in the construction of dozens of corporatk

sites, I am just as guilty as anybody else of underestimating the details an™

complexities of the language when you get beyond layout. The specifications aren’š

perfect, documentation varies between browser vendors, and there is a great deal o“

misconception and oral history floating around the Web. Worst of all, it’s ¾

continuously moving target. The HTML 4.0 specification represents a significanš

change in the flavor of HTML from previous versions. With the potential rise of a neu

form of HTML in light of XML, more changes are in the offing. I and many others trie™

as hard as we could to clarify everything to the best of our understanding. I would likk

to thank those who made the extra effort to try to make this more than just anotheK

HTML bookì

First I would like to thank all of the staff members at PINT who put up with theiK

grumpy boss and his big book project. PINT’s editor, writer, and overall HTML expert,

Dan Whitworth, was indispensable and did a great job of fixing what I thought werk

complete sentences, as well as putting everything else together. Other PINT staf“

xi¨

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 19 =

x¨  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

members, including Jimmy Tam, Francesca Weisser, Nikos Ioannou, Eric Raether,

Rob McFarlane, Mark Robertson, Cory Ducker, Keith Mar, and many others, alway—

helped keep things running smoothly enough so I could have a few minutes to work

in peaceì

Megg Bonar at Osborne/McGra“Hill, who graciously allowed me to write thi—

book and this new edition, provided the appropriate motivation to keep thing—

running. Stephane Thomas made sure all the manuscript was in order, an™

Emily Rader made sure everything was edited and put together properly. TechnicaR

editor Alan Herrick, as well as the original technical editor, MegaZone, made sure tf

keep our HTML code to spec as much as possibleì

My family and friends, particularly my sister Diana Powell, provided moraR

support as well as a few chili dog deliveries that ensured eventual completion of thi—

project. Special thanks to my good friends at Datanet in Mexico City (particularl_

Tony Rihan) who have always shown support and friendship when I have needed itì

Last but not least, the staff and students at UCSD Extension deserve thanks for giviný

me the wonderful opportunity to teach HTML and Web publishing for the past fouK

years. The feedback from students has much to do with any improvements in thi—

new editionì

Thomas A. PowelR

 = Page 20 =

Prefacf

itting down to write the new edition of this book shows just how fast things movk

in Internet time. Since the first edition was published, HTML 4 has become ¾

standard, Dynamic HTML (DHTML) has started to take hold, and style sheets ark

S

reasonably well supported by both of the major browsers. The Web is getting eve-

more complex. Vestigial elements of the past, such as proprietary HTML tags, ark

disappearing rapidly. And finally, we are beginning to realize the immense scope o“

the implications of the Extensible Markup Language (XML)ì

Despite these rapid changes, many people seem to believe that the future of HTML

is dire. At the time of the first edition, many pundits had already predicted that thk

need for intimate knowledge of HTML would soon disappear. This doesn’t see“

ridiculous when you consider WYSIWYG editors such as Microsoft’s FrontPage. Thesk

tools provide the illusion that we are a mere draanÙdrop away from creating ¾

“killer” Web site. Eventually we will get there; but, for the moment, things are ofte-

complex. WYSIWYG tools may be useful in a limited fashion, but the instability o“

HTML and the lack of control over layout still requires a great deal of custom codingì

If anything, authoring Web pages is becominý  mor—  complex, not lessì

HTML provides the framework for all Web pages and will continue to be a-

important technology for at least the next few years. Fortunately, for now, learning thk

basics of HTML isn’t difficult. If you arm yourself with a good informational tool, yo¾

xxX

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 21 =

xxiX  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

can produce decent HTML code relatively quickly. As a teacher of Web publishiný

classes at the University of California at San Diego Extension, I know that after only ¾

few classes some students can produce very nice Web pages. On the other hand,

mastering HTML is still a daunting task. Errors creep into pages, particularly acros—

browsers, and new elements are invented all the time. Coding techniques have becomk

very important. Furthermore, the latest version of HTML represents a serious increask

in the number of attributes available for modifying HTML elementsì

This book attempts to incorporate the ideas of HTML 4, Netscape, Microsoft, an™

even WebTV, along with new technologies that affect HTML, such as Cascading Stylk

Sheets (CSS), DHTML, and XML. Don’t forget that there is more to making Web page—

than HTML. I’ll hint at that where I can; but, rather than try to talk about everythiný

related to Web design, I want to do one thing the best I can: cover HTML. This book

isn’t meant to bk  only  about learning HTML. I want this to be a book you can comk

back to if you forget an element’s syntax or just want to look something up. I want it tf

be current and cover Netscape, Microsoft, WebTV, and any other important HTML

viewing platform. I want it to show the relationship of HTML to emerging technologie—

such as style sheets and present the open issues facing HTML. I would even like it tf

stimulate some thought about your authoring techniques. If I’ve done a good job, thi—

book will be true to its name—¾  complet—  referenceì

Thomas A. PowelR

tpowell@pint.co“

January, 199Ð

Chapte7  

Introduction to HTMP



Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 25 =

  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

ypertext Markup Language (HTML) is the text markup language currentl_

used on the World Wide Web. If you have ever written a school report oK

business memo, you have encountered text markup. Your documents probabl_

õ

came back to you covered in red ink, courtesy of your teacher or boss. The symbols an™

acronyms used in those editorial markups suggested changes for you to interpret oK

implement (see Figure —1). In that scenario, markup is separate from the actual contenš

of your document. When you create a document with a word processing program,

such as Microsoft Word or WordPerfect, the program uses markup language tf

indicate the structure and formatting of that electronic document. What you see o-

your screen looks like a page of formatted text; the rest is done “behind the scenes.”

HTML is the noâskbehinÙth[scenes markup language that is used to tell WeD

browsers how to display Web pagesì

Basic HTML Concept“

In the case of HTML, markup commands applied to your We~based content tell thk

browser software the structure of the document and, when appropriate, how you wanš

the content to be displayed. For example, if you want to display a section of text i-

boldface, you surround the corresponding text with the boldface markup tags,  <B

an™  </B  , as shown here:

<BL  This is important text<  </BL

When the browser reads a document that has HTML markup in it, it determine—

how to render it onscreen by considering the HTML elements embedded within thk

document (see Figure —2). Be aware that browsers don’t always render things in thk

way that you think they will. This is due partially to the design of HTML and partiall_

to the differences in the variety of Web browsers currently in useì

Figurs 1-18  Interpretation of an essay with editorial marku—

 = Page 26 =

ChapteX 1  Introductio‘ tW HTMP  

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Figurs 1-28  Interpretation of a Web page with HTML marku—

An HTML document is simply a text file that contains the information you want tf

publish. It also contains embedded instructions, calle™  elementx  , that indicate how ¾

Web browser should structure or present the document. In the following listing, thk

HTML elements are highlighted in a bold font. The elements are explained in greateK

detail later in this chapter in the section “Overview of HTML Markup.”

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Big Company's Big Home Pag4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  Big Company, Inc<  </H1L

<PL  Welcome to Big Company, Inc.–your best source for HTML examples<

We do examples right!  </PL

 = Page 27 =

‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<ULL

<LI><A HREF="new.htm"L  What's New  </AL

<LI><A HREF="products.htm"L  Product?  </AL

<LI><A HREF="contact.htm"L  ContacM  </AL

</ULL

<HRL

<ADDRESSL  E-mail:

<A HREF="mailto:webmaster@bigcompany.com"L

webmaster@bigcompany.co—  </AL

</ADDRESSL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

As this listing demonstrates, HTML elements generally consist of a pair of angl[

bracketed tags surrounding some text. Thk  end tav  (  </TAG  ) is just like thk  start tav

(  <TAG  ), except that it has a slash ( ) in it, as shown here:  

Start taý

<TAGL

..<

Content that the tag pair affect?

..<

End taý

</TAGL

The HTML elements may indicate the meaning of the enclosed information (foK

example, a citation) or how the text should be rendered (for example, in italics). Give-

the following HTML code,

<IL  This is interesting<  </IL

a Web browser should render the phrase “This is interesting” in italicsì

HTML elements normally consist of a pair of tags that enclose some textual contenš

or other HTML elements. However, some elements, such as the horizontal rule tag,

<HR  , do not have a corresponding end tag; that is, they don’t actually “contain”

anythingì Thesk element— ark terme™  empty  elementsì Thk en™ taý foK somk element— i—

optional, sf a- elemenš ma_ appeaK tf bk empty, eve- thoug— iš isn’t, becausk it— en™ taý

i— missingì FoK example, wit— thk paragrap— element, , thk en™ taý ma_ bk omittedì  <P

However, foK suc— elements, thk WeD browseK actuall_ infer— thk presenck o“ thk en™ tagì

FoK clarity’— sakk an™ tf protecš youK page— againsš futurk change— tf thk HTML

specification, usiný thk en™ taý foK a- elemenš i— alway— ¾ goo™ idea, i“ onk i— definedì

 = Page 28 =

ChapteX 1  Introductio‘ tW HTMP  

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

HTML: A Structured Languags

As the preceding discussion indicates, HTML tags have a wel_defined syntax an™

HTML document— havk ¾ formaR structureì Thk Worl™ Widk WeD Consortiu“ (W3C),

aš http://www.w3.org, i— thk primar_ organizatio- thaš attempt— tf standardizk

HTML (a— welR a— man_ otheK technologie— use™ o- thk Web)ì Tf providk ¾ standard,

thk W3C “usš carefull_ specif_ alR aspect— o“ thk technologyì I- thk cask o“ HTML,

thi— mean— precisel_ defininý thk element— i- thk languageì Thk W3C —a— define™

HTML a— a- applicatio- o“ thk  Standar Generalize Markup Languag— (SGML)  .§ -

short, SGML i— ¾ languagk use™ tf defink otheK language— b_ specifyiný thk allowe™

documenš structurk i- thk for“ o“ ¾  documenP typ— definitioc (DTD)—  ¾ documenš šhaš

indicate— thk syntax thaš ca- bk use™ foK elementsì

From the DTD, a basic template can be derived for an HTML document. First,

you indicate the particular variant of HTML that you are using. As you’ll learn later,

numerous versions of HTML exist, and thus you must make sure to author youK

documents with the HTML standard (or nonstandard) that makes the most sense foK

your user baseì

To indicate the particular variant of HTML that you are using, you need to specif_

the particular DTD to which the HTML file conforms. To accomplish this, all HTML

files should begin with ¾  <!DOCTYPE  indicator. Unfortunately,  <!DOCTYPE  i—

rarely used correctly, and HTML’s relationship to SGML is not well understood b_

many HTML authors. Furthermore, most browsers don’t seem to care whether ¾

document type is indicated. The benefits of using thk  <!DOCTYPE  statement ark

discussed in Chapter 3ì

While all proper HTML files should begin with ¾  <!DOCTYPE  declaration, this i—

generally omitted. Instead, most HTML files begin with thk  <HTML  element, whic—

indicates that the content of the file includes markup. This is an essential element thaš

should not be omittedì

The file should end with thk  <HTML  element’s end tag,  </HTML  . Within thk

<HTML  element are two primary sections—the head and the body. Occasionally,

special framing documents contain a head and a frameset. The concept of frames i—

discussed in depth in Chapter 8ì

Thk head, whic— i— enclose™ withi- thk  <HEAD  elemenš (consistiný o“ thk  <HEAD

an™  </HEAD  tags), include— supplementar_ informatio- abouš thk document, suc— a—

thk titlk o“ thk document, whic— mosš browser— displa_ i- ¾ titlk baK aš thk to5 o“ thk

browseK windowì Thk titlk i— indicate™ betwee- thk  <TITLE  an™  </TITLE  tagsì Thk

documenš titlk i— require™ undeK thk currenš HTML specificationì Whilk somk browser—

ma_ noš requirk thk inclusio- o“ thk  <TITLE  element, yo¾ shoul™ alway— includk it—foK

correctness, book marking, an™ thk sakk f“ goo™ HTML styleì

Thk informatio- i- thk hea™ o“ a- HTML documenš i— ver_ important, becausk iš

i— use™ tf describk oK augmenš thk contenš o“ thk documentì Thk hea™ o“ a- HTML

documenš i— likk thk fronš matteK oK coveK pagk o“ ¾ documentì I- man_ cases, thk

informatio- containe™ withi- thk  <HEAD  elemenš i— informatio- abouš information,

 = Page 29 =

8  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

whic— i— generall_ referre™ tf a—  meta-informatioc  ì Thi— i— ¾ ver_ importanš an™ ofte™

overlooke™ aspecš o“ HTML documentsì Searc— engines, suc— a— Lyco— an™ HotBot, usk

metDinformatio- tf index WeD pagesì Beside— metDinformation, thk  <HEAD  elemenš

ca- includk authoK contacš information, scripts, stylk sheets, an™ commentsì

The body, which is enclosed betwee-  <BODY  an™  </BODY  tags, contains thk

actual content and the appropriate markup tags needed to render the page. A basi´

HTML template is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Document Title Goes Her4  </TITLEL

...Other supplementary information goes here...<

</HEADL

<BODYL

...Document content and markup go here...<

</BODYL

</HTMLL

In the preceding template, the HTML 4 document type indicator is used. Other HTM?

standard conformance indicators are also possible, as discussed in Chapter 3.

Some of the most common elements used in HTML documents are listed here:

  Thk  <HTML <HEAD  ,  , an™  <BODY  tag pairs are used to structure thk

documentì

  Thk  <TITLE  an™  </TITLE  tag pair specifies the title of the documentì

  Thk  <H1  an™  </H1  header tag pair creates a headlineì

  Thk  <HR  element, which has no end tag, inserts a horizontal rule, or bar,

across the screenì

  Thk  <P  an™  </P  paragraph tag pair indicates a paragraph of textì

Now that you have a template, take a look at the following sample HTML

document, which uses these seven elements:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

 = Page 30 =

ChapteX 1  Introductio‘ tW HTMP  9

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

<TITLEL  HTML First Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<HEADL

<H1L  Welcome to HTML  </H1L

<HRL

<PL  This really isn’t so hard!  </PL

<PL  You can put in lots of text if you want to. In fact, yo‚

could keep on typing and make up more sentences and continu4

on and on<  </PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

If you are using a word processing program, you can type the example and save iš

with a filename, such as first.htm or first.html. For a browser to read your file properly,

it must end in either the .htm or .html extension. If you don’t save your file with thk

appropriate extension, the browser won’t attempt to interpret the HTML markupì

When this happens, the codes appear in the browser window as shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  HTML First Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<TITLEL  Welcome to HTML  </H1L

<HRL

<PL  This really isn’t so hard!  </PL

<PL  You can put in lots of text if you want to. In fact, yo‚

could keep on typing and make up more sentences and continu4

on and on<  </PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 31 =

10  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

FX( thix quic example¨ us— ‘ simpl— text-editinv tool¨ such ax Notepa ic Windowx

95/NT¨ SimpleTexP oc th— Macintosh¨ o( v— —c UNæ. Whil— such simpl— programx may

cXP v—ve you all the features that you want, you’ll avoid accidentally saving the file ic

the wrong format, possibly with a .txt extension, or even saving it in a proprietary wor

processing format that the browser cannot read.

After you save the example file on your system, use your browser to open it b_

using the Open, Open Page, or Open File command. After your browser reads the file,

it should render a page like the one shown in Figure —3ì

I“ youK pagk doe— noš displa_ properly, revieu youK filk tf makk surk thaš yo¾ type™

thk pagk correctlyì I“ yo¾ fin™ ¾ mistakk an™ makk ¾ changk tf thk file, savk thk file, gf

backtf youK browser, an™ clickthk Reloa™ oK Refres— buttonì Keepiný thk browseK an™

texš editoK ope- simultaneousl_ i— ¾ goo™ idea, tf avoi™ constantl_ reopeniný onk oK thk

otherì Onck yo¾ geš thk haný o“ HTML design, you’lR sek that, aš thi— rau level, iš i— muc—

likk thk edit, compile, an™ ru- cyclk sf familiaK tf programmersì Thi— manuaR proces—

probabl_ isn’š thk wa_ thaš yo¾ wanš tf develo5 WeD pages, becausk iš ca- bk tedious,

erroK prone, an™ noš helpfuR whe- thinkiný o“ visuaR designì FoK illustrativk purposes,

however, iš work— fineì

Based on this simple example, you might guess that learning HTML is merely ¾

matter of learning the multitude of markup tags, such a—  <B  , that specify the formaš

and structure of documents to browsers. While that is true in some sense, such ¾

Figurs 1-38  An HTML Web page displayed in a browse

 = Page 32 =

ChapteX 1  Introductio‘ tW HTMP  1h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

simplistic approach is like trying to learn print publishing by understanding only thk

various commands available in Microsoft Word, while disregarding paper types,

document structure, and issues of style. In addition to learning the various marku5

tags, you need to consider the intent of HTML, its purpose, and the medium in whic—

HTML is used—the World Wide Webì

Overview of HTML Markup

A markup language such as HTML is simply a collection of codes—  elementx  in thi—

case— that are used to indicate the structure and format of a document. The codes havk

meaning that is interpreted by a formatting program, often a Web browser, whic—

renders the document. Elements in HTML consist of alphanumeric tags within anglk

brackets. These tags usually come in pairs, but exceptions do exist. The following tablk

shows a few HTML elements:

Start Tag  End Tag  Descriptio

<H1  </H1  The most important headlink

<B  </B  Bold texš

<CITE  </CITE  A citatio-

<P  </P  (optional)  A paragraph of texš

<HR  Nonk  A horizontal rulk

The alphanumeric tags are cas[insensitive, which means that as far as WeD

browsers are concerned,  <H1  is equivalent tf  <h1  , an™  <cite  is equivalent tf

<CiTe  . For stylistic reasons, however, you should use case consistentlyì

Using all uppercase elements makes distinguishing markup from document contenP

easier. For future compatibility with)ML, which is case-sensitive, lowercase might b—

preferable. For more on)ML, see Chapter 17. Many HTML editing tools provid—

tag-coloring features that make maintaining documents with complex tagginv

structures easier.

HTML elements often have attributes that affect the rendering of the element’—

content by modifying the function of the element. Attributes are very common wit—

complex elements such a—  <IMG  , which specifies an image to load into a Web pageì

The name and location of the particular image are set via thk  SR‚  attribute, whic—

indicates the “source” of the image fileì  <IMG SRC="logo.gif"  tells the browser tf

display the file called logo.gif. An element may have many attributes with quote™

values that are separated by one space, as shown here:

<IMG SRC="logo.gif" ALT="Big Company Logo" HEIGHT="100" WIDTH=00"L

 = Page 33 =

1p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Attribut— valuex shoul b— enclose withic doubl— quotes. Many browserx allow yo¤ tX

us— singl— quotex o( nX quotex aP all¨ particularly fo( valuex thaP consisP o ‘ singl— word.

Situationx alsX exisP ic which singl— quotex may b— use withic attribut— values. Thix occurx

whec JavaScripP ix used¨ o( whec th— valu— o th— attribut— includex special characters¨ such

ax spacex o( punctuation. Attributex ar— discusse ic mor— detail ic Chapte( 3.

Althoug— HTML element— suc— a—  <IMG  aren’š cas[sensitive, thk content— o“

attribute— ofte- ark cas[sensitiveì FoK example,  <IM… SRC="logo.gif"  isn’š necessaril_

equivalenš tf  <IM… SRC="LOGO.GIF"  , becausk thk  SR‚  valuk follow— casiný rule—

specifi´ tf thk attributeì Wit— regar™ tf filenames, somk operatiný system— ark cas[

sensitive; foK example, LOGO.GIF doesn’š necessaril_ specif_ thk samk filk a— logo.gifì

HTML files generally aren’t sensitive to spacing. Browsers tend to collapse multiplk

spaces or tabs into a single space. For example,

<BL  This is a test<  </BL

displays the same way in a browser as does the following:

<BL  This    is      :

test<  </BL

Spaces, tabs, and returns collapse when HTML files are displayed in a browser,

unless they are included within elements, such as the preformatted elemenš  <PRE  ì

Because HTML allows judicious spacing, you should space out content with whitk

space for easy reading of the source document, particularly by separating markup fro“

content. Additional spacing does not affect the browser’s rendering of the documentì

In the future, when tools generate the majority of HTML, spacing and tagging stylex

may not be as big of an issue; but, until people stop editing HTML files directly¨

formatting your documents for human reading is wise.

Another aspect of HTML elements i—  nesting¨  which means that HTML elements ca-

surround each other. If you have some text that you want to make bold and italic, yo¾

can apply both thk  <B  and thk  <I  elements to the text, as shown in the followiný

illustration. In this example, the tags are nested and do not crossì

The idea of crossing tags is shown here:

 = Page 34 =

ChapteX 1  Introductio‘ tW HTMP  1

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

You can always determine whether tags cross, by connecting arcs from start tag tf

end tag, to see whether the arcs cross each otherì

The preceding is only a brief introduction to some of the “rules” that HTML

documents tend to follow. Unfortunately, the benefit of following the rules isn’t alway—

apparent to new Web developers, because most browsers don’t strictly enforce thk

standards. For example, although the nesting rule agrees with the formal definition o“

HTML, most browsers have no problem with crossed tags, or even with tags beiný

used totally improperly. The reason for the browsers’ laxity in enforcement is actuall_

very logical: a browser would display nonstop error messages if it displayed a messagk

every time that it encountered a slightly miscoded Web page! Nevertheless, don’t usk

the browsers’ laxity in enforcing HTML’s “rules” as an excuse to misuse HTML oK

sloppily code a page. Standards impose specific structural requirements on documents,

and as the Web becomes increasingly more complicated and technologies such as thk

Extensible Markup Language (XML) are adopted, following the standards may becomk

much more importantì

Unfortunately, many document authors are unfamiliar with standards. Thus, the_

might not pay attention to the structure, because they don’t understand the philosoph_

of HTML; or, they may think of HTML as a physical pag[description language, suc—

as PostScript, rather than a logical, structur[oriented markup language. Browser—

don’t discourage this view, and may even encourage the physical viewì

Logical and Physical HTM¤

No introduction to HTML would be complete without a discussion of the logicaR

versus physical markup battle at the heart of HTMLì  Physical HTM?  refers to usiný

HTML to make pages look a particular way;  logical HTM?  refers to using HTML tf

specify the structure of a document, and using another technology, such as cascadiný

style sheets (see Chapter 10), to designate the look of the pageì

Mosš peoplk ark alread_ ver_ familiaK wit— physicaR documenš design, becausk the_

normall_ usk WYSIWYG (  whaP yo¤ se— ix whaP yo¤ geP  ) texš editors, suc— a— Microsofš Wordì

Whe- Wor™ user— wanš tf makk somethiný bold, the_ simpl_ selecš thk appropriatk

button, an™ thk texš i— madk boldì I- HTML, yo¾ ca- makk somethiný bol™ simpl_ b_

enclosiný iš withi- thk  <B  an™  </B  tags, a— show- here:

<BL  This is important<  </BL

This can easily lead people to believe that HTML is nothing more than a simplk

formatting language. WYSIWYG HTML editors (such as Microsoft FrontPage) alsf

reinforce this view; but as page designers try to use HTML in this simplistic fashion,

sooner or later they must face the fact that HTML i—  noP  a physical pag[descriptio-

language. Page authors can’t seem to make the pages look exactly the way they want;

and when they can, doing so often requires heavy use o“  <TABLE  tags, giant images,

and even trick HTML. Other technologies, such as style sheets, may provide a betteK

solution for formatting text than a slew of inconsistently supported tricks an™

proprietary HTML elementsì

 = Page 35 =

1  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

According to many experts, HTML was not designed to provide most of thk

document layout features people have come to expect, and it shouldn’t be used for thaš

5urposeì Instead, HTML shoul™ bk use™ a— ¾ logical, oK generalized, marku5 languagk

thaš define— ¾ document’— structure, noš it— appearanceì FoK example, instea™ o“ defininý

thk introductio- o“ ¾ documenš wit— ¾ particulaK margin, font, an™ size, HTML jusš label—

iš a— a- introductio- sectio- an™ let— anotheK system, suc— a— Cascadiný Stylk Sheets,

determink thk appropriatk presentationì I- thk cask o“ HTML, thk browseK oK ¾ stylk

sheeš ha— thk finaR sa_ o- hou ¾ documenš looksì

HTML already contains many logical elements. An example of a logical element i—

<STRONG  , which indicates something of importance, as shown here:

<STRONGL  This is important<  </STRONGL

Thk  <STRONG  element says nothing about how the phrase “This is important” wilR

actually appear, although it will probably be rendered in bold. While most of thk

logical elements are relatively underutilized, others, such as headings (  <H1  throug—

<H6  ) and paragraphs, are used regularlyì

The benefits of logical elements may not be obvious to those comfortable wit—

physical markup. To understand the benefits, it’s important to realize that on the Web,

many browsers render things differently. In addition, predicting what the viewiný

environment will be is difficult. What browser does the user have? What is his or heK

monitor’s screen resolution? Does the user even have a screen? Considering thk

extremk o“ thk useK haviný nf scree- aš all, hou woul™ ¾ speakiný browseK rendeK thk

<BOLD  element? Whaš abouš thk  <STRONG  element? Texš tagge™ wit—  <STRONG

might be read in a firm voice, but boldfaced text doesn’t have a meaning outside thk

visual realmì

Many realistic examples exist of the power of logical elements. Consider thk

multinational or multilingual aspects of the Web. In some countries, the date is writte-

with the day first, followed by the month and year. In the United States, the datk

generally is written with the month first, and then the day and year. A  <DATE

element, if it existed, could tag the information and let the browser localize it for thk

appropriate viewing environment. Another example is the problem of screen sizes that,

theoretically, could be reduced by logical structuring concepts. For example, logicaR

elements could allow for different renderings based on the screen size of the computeK

running the browser. This would allow the creation of documents that look good o-

laptop screens as well as on large workstation monitors. In short, separation of thk

logical structure from the physical presentation allows multiple physical displays to bk

applied to the same content. This is a powerful idea that, unfortunately, is rarely take-

advantage ofì

Whether you subscribe to the physical or logical viewpoint, HTML is not purely ¾

physicaR logical language, yet. In other words, currently used HTML elements comk  o(

in both flavors: physical and logical. Elements that specify fonts, type sizes, type styles,

 = Page 36 =

ChapteX 1  Introductio‘ tW HTMP  1

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

and so on, are physical. Elements that specify content or importance, such a—  <CITE

an™  <H1  , and let the browser decide how to do things are logical. A quick look aš

Web pages across the Internet suggests that logical elements often go unused, becausk

Web developers want more layout control than raw HTML provides, and style sheet—

are relatively new and still buggy. Furthermore, many designers just don’t think in thk

manner required for logical markup, and WYSIWYG page editors generally don’š

encourage such thinkingì

So, likk [š fK not, tf achievk thk look thaš the_ want, pagk designer— wilR probabl_

continuk tf abusk elements, suc— a—  <TABLE  an™  <FRAME  , an™ usk trick— šf

implemenš layout— i- thk wa_ thaš the_ wanš themì Thi— i— thk strugglk thaš currentl_

exist— betwee- whaš peoplk wanš ouš o“ HTML an™ whaš HTML actuall_ providesì Wit—

thk risk o“ HTML 4 an™ Cascadiný Stylk Sheets, thi— strugglk ma_ eventuall_ gf away;

buš thk uptakk [— stilR slow, an™ million— o“ document— wilR continuk tf bk authore™ wit—

nf concepš o“ logicaR structuringì WeD pagk developmenš continue— tf providk a-

interestiný stud_ o“ thk differenck betwee- whaš theorist— sa_ an™ whaš peoplk wantì

What HTML Is No

HTML [— ¾ powerfuR technology, buš man_ misconception— exisš abouš itì Understandiný

whaš HTML i—  noP  wilR certainl_ hel5 pagk developer— avoi™ commo- “istakesì

HTML Is Not a xSIxG Design Languags

HTML isn’t a specific, scree™ or printe§precise formatting language like PostScriptì

Many people struggle with HTML on a daily basis, trying to create perfect layouts b_

using HTML elements inappropriately or by using images to make up for HTML’s lack

of scree™ and fonâhandling features. Other technologies, such as style sheets, are faK

better than HTML for handling presentation issuesì

HTML Is Not a Programming Languags

Many people think that making HTML pages is similar to programming. However,

HTML is unlike programming in that it does not specify logic. It specifies the structurk

and often the layout of a document. With the introduction of scripting languages suc—

as JavaScript, however, the concept of dynamic HTML (DHTML) is becoming mork

and more popular and is used to create highly interactive Web pages. Simply put,

DHTML provides scripting languages with the capability to modify HTML element—

and their content before, and possibly after, the page has been loadedì

DHTML blurs the lines between HTML as a layout language and HTML as ¾

programming environment. However, the line should be distinct, because HTML isn’š

a programming language. Heavily intermixing code with HTML markup in the ad ho´

manner that many DHTML authors do is far worse than trying to use HTML as ¾

WYSIWYG markup language. Programming logic can be cleanly separated in HTML

in the form of script code, as discussed in Chapters 13 and 14. Unfortunately, if thi—

separation isn’t heeded, the page maintenance nightmare that results from tightl_

 = Page 37 =

1‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

binding programming logic to content will dwarf the problems caused by misuse o“

HTML code for presentation purposesì

HTML Is Not Truly StandardizedYe

Although the W3C defines the HTML specification, in practical terms browser vendor—

and users often define their own, de facto standards or decide what aspects of thk

standards they support. While this may sound like heresy, it is true. Until recently,

when a new browser supporting a new feature was released, many companies an™

individuals would rush to use it, regardless of whether the feature was included in thk

W3C HTML standard. Today, rather than adopting new tags as often as in the past, thk

tags already defined in the specification are being consistently supportedì

Presently, nf singlk browseK support— alR HTML 4 features, whic— i— unfortunate,

becausk thk browser— themselves—quirk— an™ all—ark currentl_ considere™ thk finaR

arbiter— o“ thk meaniný o“ HTML element— (a— faK a— en™ user— ark concerned)ì I- thi—

sense, HTML resemble— Englishì Neu element— an™ technologie— ark thk “slang” o“

HTML: the_ ma_ noš bk correct; buš eventually, man_ slaný term— becomk a- accepte™

parš o“ thk languageì Man_ way— exisš tf “speak” HTML, buš thk ke_ issuk i— whetheK thk

browseK understand— thk markup, jusš a— thk ke_ issuk i- Englis— i— whetheK onk perso-

understand— anotheK person’— slangì Hopefully, browser— wilR sto5 beiný sf varie™ i-

theiK interpretatio- o“ certai- element— an™ wilR begi- tf offeK fulR supporš o“ standards,

suc— a— HTML 4ì Buš foK now, thk practick o“ buildiný page— aroun™ “commo- HTML”

usagk ma_ bk mork appropriatk tha- implementiný standar™ HTML usageì

HTML Is Not Extensibls

Some people feel that changing HTML is easy as long as the language is simple enoug—

for browser vendors and standards groups to determine new elements easily. A loný

battle has been waged to implement features correctly. Truly extensible marku5

environments (such as SGML and XML), in conjunction with style sheets, allow user—

to invent elements and renderings for those elements without compromising thk

experience for other users. This is currently impossible with HTMLì

HTML Is Not Complets

HTML is not finished. The language does not provide all the facilities that it should,

even as a logical markup language. However, work is presently focused o-

implementing the current HTML standards under a new language, called Extensiblk

Markup Language (XML). Future versions of HTML will almost certainly be defined a—

a subset of XML. Theoretically, this is a wise decision, but the ubiquitous nature o“

HTML and its huge installed base suggest that considering how to extend HTML or filR

in its small gaps is an incredibly important task. The W3C’s current HTML  Activity

StatemenP  can be found on its Web site (http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/Activity.html)ì

 = Page 38 =

ChapteX 1  Introductio‘ tW HTMP  1

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

HTML Is Not AllYou Need to Know ts

CreateGood Web Page“

Whereas HTML is the basis for Web pages, you need to know a lot more than HTML tf

build useful Web pages (unless the page is very simple). Document design, graphi´

design, and even programming often are necessary to create sophisticated Web pagesì

HTML serves as the foundation environment for all of these tasks, and a completk

understanding of HTML technology can only aid document authorsì

HTML’s lack of support for certain features leads to a general problem with hou

people use the language. Much of the tension surrounding HTML and HTML’s abusk

stem from the “logical versus physical markup” debate (discussed earlier in thi—

chapter in the section “Logical and Physical HTML”) and the desire for absolutk

positioning of text and graphics within Web pages. These themes recur throughouš

this bookì

Summar

HTML is neither a programming language nor a physical pag[description language. Iš

is a markup language that combines physical and logical structuring ideas. Elements—

in the form of tags, such a—  <B  an™  </B  —are embedded within text documents tf

indicate to browsers how to render pages. The rules for HTML are fairly simple, buš

these rules are not strictly enforced. Browsers are still the final arbiters of page layoutì

The rapid development of HTML and the laxity of its use have created a great deaR

of misunderstanding about how to use the language. This is due in part to the chaoti´

nature of the Web publishing environment and in part to HTML’s inability to addres—

all the needs of its users. Currently, HTML does not provide all the features necessar_

to build modern Web pages, nor should it. Developers need to use other technologie—

properly, such as scripting and style sheets, to build complete Web pages. In this sense,

HTML will continue to be the bedrock upon which the information superhighway i—

builtì

Chapter 3 will return to the specifics of HTML; but, first, Chapter 2 takes a look aš

the history of Web publishing and how HTML fits into the Web development processì

 = Page 41 =

20  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

ne of the problems with discussing the creation of Web pages is that mastery o“

HTML is often mistakenly equated with mastery of the process of Web desig-

and publishing. HTML is only one part of the process. Graphic design an™

O

programming technologies are also important aspects of the process. “Web publishing”

is a more appropriate term to describe the overall process of planning and puttiný

together a Web site, particularly when some degree of forethought, skill, and artistry i—

employed. Knowledge of HTML alone does not provide all the facilities required tf

make appealing, usable Web sites. Before you get too caught up in the details o“

markup tags, you need to understand the Web process and how HTML works in thaš

processì

What IsGood Web Design?

Before you read about the process of building Web pages, this section helps yo¾

define your goal clearly. What, exactly, is good Web design? Some people discus—

whaš  isn’P  good Web design (www.webpagesthatsuck.com), but this really doesn’š

demonstrate how to create good Web sites. Others like to discuss aesthetics and layouš

(www.highfive.com). This may be appropriate on a superficial level, but beauty i—

often in the eye of the beholder. Looks aren’t everything. Function is important, too,

and some people even claim that the answer to what constitutes good Web design i—

purely a matter of function. If it isn’t usable (www.useit.com), then it isn’š

reasonable—but function without motivating form is boringì

Some talk too much about success, citing numerous visitors as true validation of ¾

site’s design. This assumes that the Web is primarily about popularity. Who cares hou

many visitors come to a page, unless it has some benefit? Think about quality an™

success. If serving the most burgers says anything about making good hamburgers,

then McDonald’s makes the world’s best hamburger. This kind of logic gets people i-

trouble on the Web all the time. Consider whether economically successful or trend_

Web pages are well designed. Characterizing good Web design is not easy, especiall_

because it depends largely on your target audienceì

Most Web discussions lose sight of the big picture, placing too much emphasis o-

how pages look, and not enough emphasis on their content, purpose, functionality, oK

the user’s experience. Web design is not just graphic design. Web desig-  includex

graphic design. Other important aspects of the Web design process may include suc—

areas as the following:

  Artistic style, color theory, typography, and other visual concern—

  Information design, which specifies how information should bk

organized and linke™

  Hypertext theor_

  Technical writiný

 = Page 42 =

ChapteX 2  Web Publishin‚  2h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

  System desig-

  Programminý

  Network and server desig-

  Business issues and project managemenš

Obviously, many disciplines are part of Web design. The first requirement,

however, is a clear understanding of the site’s ultimate purpose. The goal of a WeD

designer is to produce a usable and appealing visual design for a software system, i-

the form of a Web site that helps a user fulfill some goal. In other words, the goal is tf

develop a site that can be delivered to the user in a satisfactory manner, be interprete™

correctly by the user, and induce the desired outcome. Web design should bk

concerned not only with the aesthetic qualities of a Web site, but also with the user’—

overall experience in the context of a specific task or problem. The focus is on hou

something can be done, not just on how it looksì

It is easy to throw out expressions like “perception is reality” or “content is king” a—

arguments for or against focusing on the visual nature of the Web. However, the realit_

is a balance between these extreme points of view. If you skimp on graphics, the sitk

may seem boring. If you provide a wonderful interface, but skimp on content, the useK

may leave to find a site with more information. If you forget to debug, you may sen™

thk useK angril_ away, faciný erroK dialoý boxesì Remember: experienck i— vitalì Alway—

´f-sider what feeling the user will take away after visiting your site. A sense o“

accomplishment? Frustration? Understanding? Disgust?

The best approach to Web design is a holistic one, in which content, presentation,

and interactivity work in harmonyì

So, hou ca- yo¾ makk ¾ WeD sitk thaš i— bot— functionaR an™ visuall_ appealing,

withouš exceediný thk constraint— o“ thk Interneš an™ WeD technologies? Focusiný o- thk

technolog_ an™ the- decoratiný ¾ WeD pagk lead— tf thk dreade™ “Christma— tree” design,

show- [- Figurk 2-1ì Puttiný ¾ pagk togetheK wit— HTML an™ the- spruciný iš u5 wit— ¾

feu colore™ balls, ¾ rainbo“coloK bar, an™ animate™ cli5 arš doesn’š helpì Thk pagk look—

slappe™ together, an™ thk graphic— providk littlk mork tha- extr¾ ey[catchiný glitzì I- thi—

case, thk backgroun™ plai- interfere— wit— thk user’— abilit_ tf rea™ thk textì

On the other hand, focusing too much on the visual aspects leads to onlink

brochures with slo“downloading, ful_screen images. Everything is created wit—

graphic composition tools, such as Photoshop, which provide nearly absolute layouš

control, but result in huge files. Text on such a page can’t be changed without a graphi´

designer, let alone be indexed by a Web search engine. This design also excludes thosk

who surf with images turned off, use a text browser, or are disabled and simply can’š

see your images. Even worse, the site may not scale on a higuresolution monitor,

causing it to be so small that it’s unreadable. The ful_scree™image design style, show-

in Figure 2-2, may produce nic[looking pages, but it tends to relegate Web sites tf

fancy digital brochures. Many large sites fall into this trap because they never test theiK

pages over a dia_in link. A page that seems to work well over the local etherneš

 = Page 43 =

2p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 2-18  “Christmas tree” desig—

network may take ages to load over a 56Kbps modem connection. The averagk

modem user still connects at that speed (or a lower speed), and most user—

are not willing to wait forever for your page to load before they give up and movk

on to les-bandwidtuintensive sitesì

an™ whaš it— ultimatk goal— ark befork diviný intf HTML codiný seem— obvious, buš iš isn’š

graphicsì Aš thk otheK extreme, designer— ma_ rui- thk sitk jusš b_ thinkiný mork abouš thk

useK interfack tha- abouš whaš i— actuall_ deliveredì Creatiný WeD site— require— ¾ process,

noš a- a™ ho´ decisio- tf focu— mork o- visual— oK mork o- contentì

The Process of Web Publishing

Planning, organizing, and visualizing Web sites and pages may be more importanš

than knowing HTML. Unfortunately, these are very difficult things to teach and tend tf

be learned only by experience. The biggest mistake in Web development is not haviný

a clear goal for a Web site. Even if the site is launched on time and under budget, hou

can you understand whether you did a good job if you had no goal in the first place?

Often goals are vague. Initially, many corporate Web site projects were fueled b_

 = Page 45 =

2  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

FUD—fear, uncertainty, and doubt. With the hype surrounding the Web, it wa—

important to get on the Web before the competition. If the competition was alread_

online, having a Web site appeared even more crucial to corporate success. This is ¾

dangerous situation to be in. Even if budget is not an issue, the benefit of the site wilR

eventually be questioned. Web professionals may find their jobs on the line. Thus, thk

first step in the Web publishing process is defining the purpose of a siteì

Determining Purposs

Findiný ¾ purposk foK ¾ WeD sitk isn’š necessaril_ ver_ hardì Thk WeD ca- bk ver_ useful,

an™ man_ commo- reason— exisš tf puš u5 ¾ WeD site, ¾ feu o“ whic— ark liste™ here:

  Commerck

  Entertainmenš

  Informatio-

  Marketiný

  Personal pleasurk

  Presenck

  Promotio-

  Research and educatio-

  Technical supporš

One problem with Web sites is that they may have multiple purposes. A corporatk

Web site may include demands for marketing, public relations, investor relations,

technical support, commerce, and human resource services such as job recruitingì

Trying to meet all of these needs while thinking about the Web site as one entity can bk

difficult. Much like a larg[scale software system with many functions, a Web site wit—

many different goals probably should be broken into modules, or subprojects, thaš

constitute parts of a larger whole. This leads to the idea of ¾  microsit—  —a very specifi´

subsite that is part of a larger site and that may be built separately. Microsites have thk

advantage of allowing the focus, look, or technology of a portion of a site to changk

without having to change the site as a wholeì

No matter how the site is structured, keeping it cohesive and logical is importantì

For example, establishing a consistent look and feel for the site as a whole is stilR

important, regardless of the multitude of functions. People should feel comfortablk

moving from your support pages to your marketing pages to your employment pagesì

A consistent user interface breeds familiarity and generates a united front. The useK

doesn’t need to know that the site is constructed in modules. An inconsistent interfack

can lead to a user becoming lost and confused while exploring. It helps to have onk

 = Page 46 =

ChapteX 2  Web Publishin‚  2

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

person (or at least a small group) designated as the overall decision maker on a WeD

project. The Webmaster, or more appropriately terme™  Webmanage(  , coordinates thk

work efforts and helps keep the project on track. The Webmanager’s role is basicall_

the same as a project manager on a large software project. Without such carefuR

management, a Web site with many goals may quickly become a mess, built tf

satisfy the needs and desires of its builders rather than its viewersì

Who Is the Audience?

Of course, just having a purpose for a site isn’t enough: you need to consider a site’—

audience. Notice how often sites reflect the organizational structure of a compan_

rather than the needs of the customer. The goal is always to keep the user at the centeK

of the discussion. Before building a site, make sure to answer some simple audienck

questions:

  Are the users coming from within your organization, or from outside?

  Are they young or old?

  What language do they speak?

  When do they visit the site?

  What technologies do they support?

  What browsers do they use?

Figuring out an audience doesn’t have to be that hard, but don’t assume that youK

audience is too large. People from South America or the Sudan can visit your WeD

page—but do they? Should they? It is important to be realistic about the audience o“

the Web. The Web has millions of users, but they aren’t all going to visit a particulaK

Web site. If they did, things probably wouldn’t work well. When the idea of a site’—

audience is discussed, don’t think in terms of a nameless, faceless John Q. Cybercitize-

with a modem and an America Online account. When thinking about users, try to geš

as specific as possible, and even ask users, if possibleì

I“ yo¾ alread_ havk ¾ sitk seš up, yo¾ havk ¾ uealt— o“ informatio- abouš youK

users—youK serveK logsì Log— ca- telR yo¾ quitk ¾ biš abouš youK useK baseì Dependiný o-

thk serveK an™ it— configuration, yo¾ ca- lear- thk timk f“ da_ thaš yo¾ geš thk mosš hits,

thk page— visite™ thk most, thk browser— an™ version— beiný used, thk domain— youK visitor—

comk from, an™ eve- thk page— thaš referre™ visitor— tf youK siteì Fro“ thk logs, yo¾ ca-

eve- infeK connectio- speeds, base™ o- deliver_ timk betwee- pagesì I“ yo¾ df noš havk ¾

serveK runniný yet, begi- wit— youK besš estimatk o“ thk kind— o“ visitor— yo¾ expectì Onck

thk sitk i— running, checkthk log— againsš youK estimates—yo¾ ma_ fin™ thaš youK audienck

i— differenš tha- yo¾ expectedì A- importanš poinš i- WeD desig- i— thaš yo¾ musš bk

williný tf revisk youK designs, eve- goiný a— faK a— throwiný awa_ youK favoritk ideas, i“

the_ df noš fiš wit— youK actuaR audienceì

 = Page 47 =

2‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Who Will Pay for It?

Sites cost money to produce, so they generally have to produce some benefit tf

continue. While people do put up sites for personal enjoyment, even this type o“

site has limits in terms of an individual’s investment of time and money. It is ver_

important to understand the business model of the site. Only a year or two ago, man_

corporate Web budgets were not always the first concern, due to the novelty of thk

technology. Today, however, Web sites often have to prove that they’re “worth it.” Thk

money has to come from somewhereì

A site’s creator could pay for everything, but that probably isn’t reasonable unles—

the Web site is for pure enjoyment or is nonprofit. Typically, some funds have to bk

collected, probably indirectly, to support the site. For example, while a promotional sitk

for a movie may not directly collect revenues, it can influence the audience and havk

some impact on the success or failure of the film. Interestingly, many Web sites ark

nearly as indirect as a movie promotion site. Measuring the direct benefit of haviný

such sites can be very difficult. More directly measurable sites are those on which lead—

are collected or goods are sold. Some value can be put on these transactions, and a-

understanding of the benefit of the site can be determinedì

HardeK tf track, buš nf les— valuable, ark WeD site— foK customeK servick an™ supportì

Placiný producš informatio- oK manual— online, oK postiný URL— foK Frequentl_ Aske™

Question— (FAQs) list— o- youK products, enable— youK customer— tf answeK man_ o“ theiK

ow- questionsì Noš onl_ ca- thi— directl_ reduck thk loa™ o- youK customeK servick an™

supporš organizations, iš alsf foster— goo™ wilR amoný youK customeK baseì Whe- ¾

customeK i— shoppiný around, thk vendoK whf “ake— iš easiesš foK the“ tf obtai- thk

informatio- the_ ark lookiný foK tend— tf havk a- immediatk advantageì

Another possible business model for a Web site is to have viewers pay, as in ¾

subscription model. This model’s problem is that viewers must be given a convinciný

reason to pay for the information or service available at the Web site. Making a WeD

site valuable to a user is tricky, especially considering that value often is bot—

psychological and real. When looking at the value of the information available in a-

encyclopedia, think about its form. If the encyclopedia’s information is in book form,

the cost might be as high as $1,000. Put the same information on a CD-ROM, and see i“

the information can be sold for the same cost. What if the same information is on a WeD

site? On a CD-ROM, the information probably can be sold for $50 to $100. On a WeD

site, it goes for even less, particularly if the user only wants to buy a specific piece o“

informationì

User— ofte- plack mork valuk o- thk  delivery  o“ ¾ goo™ oK servick tha- o- thk goo™

itselfì ConsideK software, foK whic— thk desig- an™ productio- o“ packaginý ofte- cost—

mork tha- reproduciný thk softwark itselfì Thk botto“ link i— thaš packaginý doe— countì

Iš i— nf wondeK thaš user— ofte- mistakenl_ overvaluk thk graphi´ aspecš o“ ¾ siteì

As information services become more pervasive, consumers will probably begin to valu—

content on the Internet, despite its lack of tangibility.

 = Page 48 =

ChapteX 2  Web Publishin‚  2

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Another business model involves getting someone other than the owner or thk

intended audience of the site to pay. This model typically comes in the form of a-

advertisindriven site. However, what is interesting about advertising is that a good i—

actually being sold—the audience. Advertisers are interested in reaching a particulaK

audience and are willing to pay for an advertisement based on the effectiveness of thaš

ad reaching the intended audience. The question is, how can an audience be attracted,

measured, and then sold to the advertisers? The obvious approach is to provide somk

reason for an audience to come to a Web site and identify themselves. This is ver_

difficult. Furthermore, the audience must be accurately measured, so that advertiser—

have a way to compare audience size from one site to the next and know how to spen™

their advertising dollars. People often discuss the number of visitors to their site as a-

indication of value to an advertiser. The advertisers, however, may not care about thk

number of visitors, unless those visitors are in their target audienceì

Regardless of who is paying for the site, some understanding of the costs an™

benefits of the site is necessary. How much does each visitor actually cost, and whaš

benefit does he or she produce? Understand that the number of visitors doesn’t count,

even when using the advertising model. The value of the site transcends this figurk

and addresses the effectiveness of the visitation. In other words, many visits don’š

necessarily mean success. Having many visitors to an online store who nonetheles—

make few purchases may mean huge losses, particularly if it costs more to reach eac—

visitor. Even the form of the Web site may affect the cost. For example, because thk

amount of data delivered from a Web site is generally related directly to the site’—

variable costs, sending video costs more than sending regular HTML text. High cost—

for Web site development isn’t always bad, particularly if it produces a big payoffì

Goals must be set to measure success and understand how to budget Web sitesì

DefiningGoal“

A goal for a site is not the same as its purpose. A  purpos—  gives a general idea of whaš

the site is for, whereas ¾  goal  is very specific. A goal can help define how much shoul™

be spent, but goals must be measurable. What is a measurable goal of the site? Selliný  x

dollars worth of product directly via the Web site is a measurable goal, as is selliný  x

dollars of product or service indirectly through leads. Reaching a certain usage leveR

per day, week, or month can be a goal. So is lowering the number of incoming technicaR

support phone calls by a certain amount. Many ways exist to measure the success oK

failure of a Web project, but measurements generally come in two categories: soft an™

hard. Hard measurements are those that are easily measured, such as the numbeK

of visitors per day. Soft measurements are a little less clear. For example, with ¾

promotional site for a movie, it might be difficult to understand whether the site ha™

any effect on the box office salesì

Why are measurements so important? From a manager’s perspective, measur[

ments can be used to determine how much to spend. If a Web site’s goal is to produck

$10,000 of new sales, then spending $500,000 on the site is not acceptable, unless thk

 = Page 49 =

28  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

site has some other nonmeasurable value that can make up the other $490,000. Whilk

this seems like common sense, a clear return on investment or cost benefit is seldo“

determined for corporate Web sites. Soft measurements can make things difficult,

because the effect the Web site may have is unclear. In the advertising industry,

certain rules of thumb apply, such as spending ten percent of overall sales o-

advertising. A percentage of that would obviously go toward a Web site. Due tf

the hype surrounding the Web, very little business sense is exhibited toward WeD

development. Even if sites were considered as little more than online brochures, iš

is obvious that the more brochures printed on paper, the more expensive. The mork

pages, the more expensive. The more complicated, the more expensive. Web site—

are the same wayì

Both on paper and on the Web, economies of scale do reduce the per-unit cost; but a poinP

of diminishing returns still exists. Web sites often have diminishing returns that ar—

ignored. For example, the expense of making a site engineered perfectly for every

situation and every browser provides only a little more benefit than one engineered fo(

most users, from a financial point of view. Interestingly, Web experts tend to geP

somewhat religious on the point of how a site should be implemented. However, in th—

face of managerial and financial realities, things can’t always be done perfectly.

Defining Scops

After you define a site’s goals, you need to define what is necessary to reach youK

goals. You might call thi—  defining scop—  . One thing to remember, though—scope equal—

money. Because of the flexible nature of the Web, many developers want to add a—

much as possible to the Web site. However, more isn’t always better. The more that i—

added to the Web site, the more it costs. Furthermore, having too much informatio-

makes finding essential information difficultì

To think about scope, return to one of the first steps in the process. What is thk

main purpose of the site? Shouldn’t the information of the site reflect this purpose?

Looking at the Web, this doesn’t always seem to be the case. Have you ever gone to ¾

site and not understood its point?

Finding the essentials of a Web site might not be easy, particularly if it has man_

purposes or many parties involved in its development. One approach is to have ¾

brainstorming session, in which users provide ideas. Each idea is then written down o-

a 3×5 card. After all the cards have been created, ask the users to sort the cards intf

piles. First, sort the cards into similar piles to see how things are related. Next, sort thk

piles in order of importance. What is important can eventually be distilled out of thk

cards. Remember to cut down the number of cards, to make people focus on what i—

truly importantì

Instead of coming up with ideas of what should go into a site to meet a particulaK

goal or goals, you may be tempted to take existing materials, such as marketing pieces,

and convert them to the Web. Unfortunately, creating the content of the site base™

 = Page 50 =

ChapteX 2  Web Publishin‚  29

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

solely on text and pictures from manuals, brochures, and other support material—

rarely works. Migrating text from print to the Web is troublesome, because the medi¾

are so different. Reading onscreen has been proven to be much slower than readiný

from paper. In practice, people tend not to read information online carefully. They ten™

to scan it quickly and then print what they need. In this sense, writing for paper tend—

to go against screen reading. Think about newspaper or TV news stories: the mai-

point is stated first and then discussed. This goes against the slow buildup of man_

paper documents, which carefully spell out a point. With visitors skimming the site,

key bullet points tend to be read while detailed information is skipped. The main thiný

is to keep the points obvious and simple. Even if information is presented well, pooK

organization can ruin all the hard work in preparing the information. If a viewer can’š

find the information, who cares how great it looks or how well it reads?

Organization of Informatio

Organizing the information at a Web site is often just as important as the informatio-

itself. If visitors to a Web site can’t find what they are looking for, they may geš

frustrated and leave. Organizing information is a matter of grouping similar items i-

the same place. The carÙsorting discussion in the previous section helps define whaš

items should go togetherì

Tree Structurs

Sitk designer— ofte- usk ¾  tre— structur—  oK hierarch_ foK theiK sites, a— show- i- Figurk 2-3ì

Figurs 2-38  A typical Web site tree diagra‘

 = Page 51 =

30  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

While the tree structure seems the most appropriate choice for Web sites, you stilR

need to decide how many choices should be at the top level, and how wide versus hou

deep the tree should be. If too many choices are at the top level, the structure is flat an™

may be confusing. Forcing people farther down the tree can be frustrating, because iš

requires them to keep moving, level by level, to find the appropriate information. Thk

depth versus breadth issue is illustrated in Figure 2-4ì

From the initial studies on hypertext, the following are the three “golden rules”:

  Hypertext is a body of information organized into numerous fragments. B_

definition, most Web sites—unless they are a single page—should fit this ruleì

  These fragments relate to each other somehow. If the site doesn’t have a cleaK

goal, the relationship between pages might not be obviousì

  The user needs only a small fraction of the information presented at any timeì

Sites that are too flat and provide all the choices all the time confuse the user b_

presenting too many choices. How many choices are okay? Studies suggest that thk

optimal number of choices is between five and nine, because users can retain thk

choices in shorâterm memory fairly easily. Too many choices make the selectio-

process suboptimal, and the user may focus on extremes, such as the first item, lasš

item, or center item. Too few choices may indicate that you are creating a needles—

layer; a long sequence of pages with only two choices on each may simply slow thing—

down. Combining some of those choices on fewer pages might be better. Structuriný

the site appropriately may help improve a user’s interaction with informationì

Unfortunately, sometimes the hierarchy is considered the only structure appropriatk

for a Web siteì

Figurs 2-48  Depth versus breadth in a tree structurP

 = Page 52 =

ChapteX 2  Web Publishin‚  3h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Pure Linear Structurs

We~based information doesn’t necessarily have to be structured in the form of a treeì

Sometimes, ¾  pure linea(  organization, with one page after another, makes sense. A slidk

show, tour, or presentation probably should be in the form of a linear progressionì

(At one level, because of the browser’s Back button, linear Web sites are alway—

bidirectional as well.) The basic idea of a linear structure is shown in Figure 2-5ì

Linear Structure with Alternative“

Another approach might be ¾  linear progression with alternativex  : a series of yes and nf

questions that eventually lead to the next question in the sequence. An effectivk

application of the linear with alternatives structure comes in the form of an AIDS

awareness site that discusses risk factors in a yes and no question fashion, buš

eventually leads to the next risk category, regardless of the choice. This gives the site ¾

false sense of interactivity, which engages the viewer more than a pure linear structureì

The linear form with alternatives is shown in Figure 2-6ì

Linear Structure with Option“

Another form of organization is thk  linear with optionx  structure. This structure, show-

in Figure 2-7, is good for a set of information that is sometimes optional. For example,

in many surveys, the survey taker is asked to skip a set of questions, depending on hi—

or her answer. A Web form of such a survey would be a perfect candidate for lineaK

with options, because it allows the reader to skip over questions that are not relevant,

while still preserving the general path of the informationì

Linear Structure with Side Trip“

Thk  linear with side tripx  structure is perfect for a body of information that may havk

useful supplementary information. For example, a linear Web presentation abouš

flowers may lead to a side trip about beekeeping that the user can view, but lateK

return to the main discussion, as shown in Figure 2-8. This form of site provide—

diversion while still preserving the path. Linear with side trips is a form of trek

structure—just turn the structure on its side. When used with linear content, iš

warrants its own discussionì

Figurs 2-58  Pure linear organizatio—

 = Page 53 =

Grid-Style Structurs

One uncommon form of structuring information, at least on the Web, is thk  grid styl—  ì

The grid style has a great degree of spatial organization, as do many of the lineaK

forms. The grid provides a sense of up, down, left, and right. Because of its regulaK

structure, the grid form is good for related items and organization, such as items thaš

might be found in a catalog. Imagine the columns of the grid being associated with ¾

particular product line, and the nodes representing the products in that particulaK

product line. Moving across columns might be like moving among equivalent product—

between product lines. The basic idea of the grid is shown in Figure 2-9ì

The tree structure or hierarchy is much less structured than the grid. A narrou

hierarchy provides few choices for the user, but requires many clicks to get to thk

destination. On the other hand, the wide hierarchy provides many choices, so iš

requires fewer clicks to get to the destination information, assuming the user make—

the correct decisions. This is the same discussion illustrated earlier in Figure 2-4. Bot—

forms of the tree provide some spatial organization, but there is a question of hou

much. The wider the tree, the less structured the informationì

Mixed Hierarch

To balance the problems of hierarchies, many developers consider a mixed form. Thk

idea of skips ahead or alternatives was previously discussed in relationship to thk

linear structure. How about adding a skip ahead to a tree structure? A special link fro“

the top of the tree could lead directly to an important piece of information. This often i—

seen in Web sites in which a special button on the home page links directly to the frek

download or another important item. Deeper in the site, it may be useful to providk

a catalog, so the grid structure makes sense. Perhaps in another part of the site, ¾

presentation should be used, so the linear style makes sense. Most complex Web site—

are actually mixed hierarchies, as shown in Figure 2-10ì

Figurs 2-98  Grid structurP

 = Page 55 =

3  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 2-108  An example of mixed hierarchV

Pure Web Structurs

The problem with the mixed hierarchy is that it can easily degrade into the pure WeD

form, which is a tangled mess of links in which the organization is unclear. All sense o“

spatiality is lost in the pure Web form. The only navigational sense is “signpost based,”

whereby the viewer recognizes landmarks in the site, such as the home page. Thk

benefit of the pure Web form is obvious if the user is familiar with the data, becausk

navigating among items that are fully connected is easy. However, the organizatio-

may be so unclear that the confusion factor drives users away. An example of a purk

Web structure is shown in Figure 2-11ì

Balancing Linear and Web Information Structure“

Whe- organiziný information, thk ai“ i— tf achievk ¾ balanck betwee- predictabilit_ an™

expressivenessì Althoug— thk WeD for“ ma_ Dk ver_ expressive, iš ma_ Dk completel_

unpredictablk a— faK a— thk useK i— concernedì O- thk otheK hand, thk lineaK for“ i— ver_

predictable, buš noš terribl_ expressiveì Thk balanck o“ thesk form— [— show- [- Figurk 2-12ì

temptationì Whe- yo¾ ark addiný ¾ link , askyoursel“ “Doe— thi— linkad™ valuk tf thk

audience?” I“ thk answeK i— “No,” the- thk linki— inappropriateì Ever_ linki— a- invitatio-
