Determining the Site Pla

AfteK yo¾ determink thk purpose, content, an™ structurk o“ thk site, yo¾ ca- develo5 ¾ planì

Thk pla- shoul™ consisš o“ ¾ timk line, ¾ documenš thaš describe— whaš i— neede™ an™ hou

thk sitk wilR bk puš together, an™ ¾ flou charš o“ thk site, a— show- [- Figurk 2-13ì

For small projects, this formality might be overkill. On larger projects, however,

approaching the task without a sense of where the project is going is foolish. If the sitk

Figurs 2-138  Sample Web project document9

 = Page 58 =

ChapteX 2  Web Publishin‚  3

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

is developed commercially, such planning is mandatory. Without a sense of what goe—

into the site, how can a vendor price the site? People often ask Web developers hou

much a site costs, but this depends on the size, scope, and technology that goes into thk

site, among other factors. A company with a comprehensive site plan can send thk

project out for bids. Without a plan, comparing proposals from competing firm—

provides little information of value. Notice that, up until this point, no specifi´

discussion of what the site will look like or how it works has been addressed. Thesk

tasks are part of the implementation phaseì

Implementatio

Readers might assume that the implementation phase of the Web publishing proces—

is the most difficult; but, depending on how well the site was planned, it may bk

very straightforward. With a clear plan in hand, a site can be built very quicklyì

When the various parts of the site are well defined, many people can work on thk

site simultaneously. Even so, the implementation phase of a Web project does involvk

potential problemsì

Gathering and Creating the Conten

One of the first signs of trouble is when content isn’t ready for the Web, or you havk

too much content. When planning a Web site, people often provide ideas for thing—

that would be nice to put in, with no consideration of the cost. Information can bk

formatted quickly—but if the information doesn’t exist, formatting can’t take placeì

While this sounds like common sense, it is probably the seconÙmost common proble“

on the Web, beyond purposeì

Just ask yourself what “under construction” means. Why do so many sites havk

many choices, but 90 percent of the pages are “under construction”? Wouldn’t thesk

sites be better if only the working areas were available? This highlights the problem o“

not having the content ready. The cost of developing the content often outweighs thk

cost of preparing it for the Web. A good plan pares the site down to what it should df

and considers the cost of creating the content. Without content, the site goes nowhereì

Navigation buttons and yello“anÙblack animated pictures of men digging up ¾

road don’t make a good site. The client’s inability to produce content on time cause—

commercial Web design projects to be late more often than does the firm’s inability tf

finish the technology or graphics in a timely mannerì

While we’re on the subject, don’t place “under construction” images on your pagesì

All Web sites are either under construction or stagnant. If an area of the site isn’t read_

for visitors, don’t place the links to that area online yet. If users are unaware that a-

area exists, they won’t be disappointed that it isn’t ready. Finding a link to somethiný

you need, only to discover that it is “under construction” is highly frustratingì

 = Page 59 =

38  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Visual Desig

After you have the content in hand, you can produce the visual design. Why can’š

visual design come before content generation? One simple reason: the visual style o“

the site should reflect the content of the site. Until the content is close to being finished,

any developed visual style can only provide decoration. It won’t add any real valuk

to the content. Consider product literature on a Web site. What happens if the visuaR

design is developed first, in a very corporate style, but the copy is written in a sarcastic,

unprofessional tone? The site won’t make much senseì

Visuals should be discussed early to set the tone of the site, but the specifics o“

exactly what shade of red to use or what size an image should be must wait until thk

implementation phase. The visual design phase generally requires that paper design—

first be explored. Then, image composites can be created by using a tool such as Adobk

Photoshop. The choice of a particular look and feel depends on the purpose of the site,

the look and feel of related materials, technological considerations such as downloa™

time, and personal tasteì

Another reason not to approach visual design too early in the development proces—

is that the goals of the site may change. It is very frustrating to put together a visuaR

design that is based on having five choices on the home page, only to have the numbeK

of sections increased to eight later on. Although accounting for changes that occur lateK

in a project is impossible, by not developing graphics and navigation until after thk

structure and content of the site is set, you usually can avoid a great deal of reworkì

Graphi´ designer— ark generall_ thk besš peoplk tf approac— tf makk ¾ gooÙlookiný

siteì Unfortunately, designer— ofte- attempš tf imitatk directl_ thk existiný prinš materialsì

Thi— doesn’š alway— workwellì Subtlk texture— wilR bk losš onscreen, complex gradient— wilR

translatk intf larg[byte–size™ images, an™ bleed— generall_ won’š workì

Often, the best approach is to keep the spirit of existing materials and fit them tf

suit the needs of the Web. This doesn’t give Web designers license to reinvent thk

corporate look and feel, but it does enable them to modify an approach so that iš

creates a visually stimulating page that downloads quickly. This balance betwee-

visual appeal and download speed—combined with the imprecise layout afforded b_

HTML and unpredictable viewing environments—is what makes Web design sf

challenging. The best Web designers know enough about Web technology to work

within its constraints. Web designers with graphics backgrounds occasionall_

undervalue the sense of organization that may have been applied to a site, and want tf

move sections around. Be careful not to let the visual designer disrupt labeling an™

organization schemes based on his or her personal tasteì

Technology Desig

FaK tof man_ WeD site— ark develope™ a— glorifie™ brochure— wit— biý picturesì However, thk

besš moder- site— ofte-  dX  somethiný an™ ark mork likk softwark tha- printe™ documentsì

Man_ site— providk searchiný features, an™ somk site— enablk user— tf purchask product— oK

eve- pla_ gamesì Ver_ advance™ site— automaticall_ configurk themselve— accordiný tf thk

visitor’— preference— oK browseK typeì

 = Page 60 =

ChapteX 2  Web Publishin‚  39

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

After adding technology—such as a database, interactive forms, or programme™

objects like Java applets—to the mixture, the Web becomes more like software and les—

like print media. In this sense, some effort must be made to select the appropriatk

technology for the job and to integrate the look and content properly. As sites becomk

more complex, appearance will still be important, but much of the effort will go intf

the technology. The shift from a page paradigm of Web sites to a program paradig“

is fast becoming a reality. How programming ideas relate to HTML, the core WeD

technology, is discussed in depth starting in Chapter 12ì

Producing the HTM¤

While visuals and technical elements are very important to Web design, the hearš

of nearly every modern Web page is still HTML. Although it is possible to use a-

embedded media type to build a complex Web page that consists of a single HTML

element, such a—  <EMBED SRC="bigbinary.dcr" HEIGHT="200"  WIDTH="500"  ,

HTML is still required. In the strictest sense, all Web pages must contai-  som—  HTML,

regardless of whether the focus and content are in an embedded binary objectì

A— discusse™ i- ChapteK 1, HTML i— ¾ texš marku5 languagk thaš i— use™ tf describk thk

structurk o“ ¾ pageì UntiR recently, HTML wa— alsf use™ tf describk thk appearanck o“ thk

pageì Thi— i— nf longeK thk preferre™ wa_ šf ™f thingsì Presentatio- shoul™ bk lefš tf stylk

sheets, a— discusse™ i- ChapteK 10, buš thaš isn’š hou mosš page— havk bee- create™ tf dateì

HTML ofte- serve— a— thk bridgk betwee- thk contenš o“ ¾ pagk an™ thk interactivk object—

(suc— a— script— an™ programme™ objects) thaš ma_ alsf bk parš o“ thk WeD siteì

In many ways, HTML provides the framework on which a Web page is built. Thk

images, text content, and programming are equally important, but HTML is necessar_

to bring it all together. Because of this, some people view putting together a Web sitk

as being similar to putting together a puzzle—just assemble the pieces. This analog_

would be appropriate if the puzzle had to be designed and the pieces had to be created,

broken apart, and then put back together. Given the pieces of a site, how can HTML bk

used to create the pages?

The creation of an HTML document for publishing on the Web is as simple as usiný

the text editor of your choice (vi, Microsoft Word, Notepad, and so on) to insert intf

the text the markup tags that indicate the format and links. Or, you could use ¾

conversion program that converts files into HTML automatically. For example, you ca-

quickly convert Word 97 files or Rich Text Format (RTF) documents into HTML. Thk

conversion program preserves paragraphs, character formatting, and so on. However,

the translated file may have to be checked and cleaned up. Furthermore, the translatio-

program may not add links and other items that are necessary for Web publishing, i“

they weren’t indicated in the original documentì

Today, HTML editors are commonplace. Some editors for Windows, such a—

HoTMetaL Pro (http://www.softquad.com), HomeSite (http://www.allaire.com), an™

Hot Dog (http://www.sausage.com), show the insertion of the actual HTML tags intf

the document directly. Some of these tools are very simple tainsertion programs,

while others are sophisticated markup tools that are similar to programmers’ editiný

tools, such as Allaire’s HomeSite, shown in Figure 2-14ì

 = Page 61 =

40  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 2-148  Allaire’s HomeSite 4.0

Other editing environments provide WYSIWYG (what you see is what you get)

editing of pages, which keeps the HTML tags hidden behind the scenes. Thesk

products include Netscape Composer (http://www.netscape.com), GoLivk

CyberStudio (http://www.golive.com), and Microsoft FrontPage (http://wwwì

microsoft.com/frontpage). Traditional WYSIWYG desktop publishing tools, such a—

PageMaker, QuarkXPress, and Microsoft Word, also now support automatic HTML

outputì

Choosing the right Web tool for the job is not easy. In many cases, HTML tool—

are useful only to get a “first cut” of an HTML document. Manual editing of a WeD

document may still be necessary, to create superior hypermedia documents using thk

latest HTML features. Furthermore, HTML tools tend to take a “on[pag[aâDtime”

view of the world. In the case of larg[scale sites, it might be better to create a templatk

of a standard page and flow content into it directly. Table 2-1 compares the pros an™

cons of using particular methods to create Web pagesì

The tool that you use to compose your HTML is a matter of both taste an™

applicability. In some cases, a WYSIWYG editor provides a good enough solution,

particularly considering the ease with which the page can be created. For situations i-

which tight control is demanded, a tagging editor may be in order. If a quick changk

to fix a typo is all that is needed, then a text editor works just fine. A large volume o“

files might warrant a translation tool. In practicality, no single tool fits all jobs. Don’š

dismiss WYSIWYG tools for editors because they are easy. Many large Web firms stilR

generate Web pages by hand, though the pages are populated automatically with ¾

database. Just remember that creation of the HTML is only part of the jobì

Testing

After you create a site or page, you must test it. Testing, in the basic sense, require—

checking the page under a particular set of browsers to see whether it looks properì

Unfortunately, Web page authors often mistakenly assume that if a page looks fink

under their own browsers, then it will look fine under other browsers. The same pagk

under WebTV and Netscape Navigator might appear very different. So, on whic—

 = Page 64 =

ChapteX 2  Web Publishin‚  4

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

browsers should the site look perfect? This gets back to the issue of audience. If thk

primary audience is AOL users, then obviously the site should be heavily tested undeK

such conditions. The idea is to make sure that you don’t lock out people from viewiný

your siteì

Unfortunately, somk õTML pundit— takk thk ide¾ o“ “audience” tf a- extremeì “Thk

sitk shoul™ bk availablk tf everyone” i— theiK rallyiný cryì Whilk thi— i— truk i- theory, i-

reality, limite™ budget— ofte- makk thi— ideaR difficult, give- otheK projecš goalsì Thk sa™

facš i— thaš thk WeD isn’š nearl_ a— ope- a— peoplk likk šf thinkì Man_ site— don’š work welR

undeK certai- browsers, particularl_ mork esoteri´ browser— oK thosk madk foK user— wit—

accessibilit_ issues, suc— a— blin™ usersì However, ¾ littlk efforš ca- gf ¾ loný wa_ šf

improvk ¾ site, suc— a— usiný alternativk texš foK browser— thaš can’š rendeK image— oK

ensuriný thaš thk sitk work— undeK thk mork commo- browsersì

Getting past the basics can be difficult, though. For example, testing a site foK

compatibility with all browsers is one problem. HTML theory says that if a pagk

conforms to standard HTML, it works. But browsers don’t always work properly an™

don’t always conform to HTML standards. Even among the same brand of browser,

“slight problems” creep in that can cause huge problems. For example, undeK

Netscape 3, each platform (Macintosh, Windows, and UNIX) has a different margi-

offset. For designers attempting to place an image on a background, these difference—

are infuriating, as shown in Figure 2-17ì

Testiný i— ¾ biý issue, particularl_ a— thk paradig“ move— closeK tf ¾ programminý

oneì UndeK ¾ truk programminý paradigm, slopp_ codiný an™ lax testing—whic—

previousl_ ma_ havk resulte™ i- a- odÙlookiný page, ¾ broke- link, fK ¾ strangel_

colore™ image—ma_ resulš i- ¾ user’— syste“ crashingì Makiný surk thaš ¾ complex

pagk work— undeK alR situation— ca- bk ver_ difficultì Eve- i“ thk worl™ onl_ consiste™

o“ twf browsers, hou man_ permutation— exist? FoK example, Netscapk NavigatoK ha—

generation— 1ì,2 ì ,3 ì ,4 ì , an™ 4.5, eac— o“ whic— i— availablk o- threk majoK platform—  x  x  x  x  x

(Mac, UNIX, an™ Windows), a— welR a— numerou— bet¾ versionsì An™ thi— doesn’š eve-

takk intf accounš ¾ “professional” oK Gol™ edition, thk numerou— otheK port— (suc— a— thk

onk foK OS/2), oK foreig™languagk versionsì AlR o“ thesk permutation— ma_ havk subtlk

differencesì Now, ad™ i- Interneš Explorer, wit— 2ì,3 ì ,4 ì , an™ 5ì generation— o- Mac,  x  x  x  x

Windows, an™ UNIX, an™ yo¾ fin™ thaš literall_ dozen— o“ tesš possibilitie— existì

In most cases, things aren’t so bad, but you can learn some real lessons fro“

browser testing. A simple JavaScript program works fine on Netscape 3 undeK

Windows, but crashes the Macintosh every time. The UNIX version doesn’t eve-

support the calls used, while Internet Explorer 3 works fine, but under a new beta,

exhibits strange behavior. These are just a few examples of real problemsì

Browser and system testing isn’t the end of testing. User testing is probably thk

most important part of testing a site. Do the users know what to do? Do they like thk

site? Getting some users to evaluate a site and make suggestions for improvements i—

probably the single mosâimportant thing that a site developer can do. A site may see“

okay to its developers, but they are too close to it to know what’s wrong. Customer—

are rarely as familiar with a product line as the people selling it, so it is no wonder the_

don’t know that part number XG5Lslash6 is the “Super Widget.” Having the site looke™

 = Page 65 =

4  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 2-178  An example of a margin problem under Netscape 3

over by a variety of people removes many embarrassing gaffes. The good thing abouš

the Web is that, unlike print, it is easy to fix. This shouldn’t be used as an excuse tf

put up subpar work first and plan to fix it later; but, instead, it should be viewed as a-

acknowledgment of the medium’s flexibility and the reality that sites change over timeì

Maintenancs

Sites are born, live, and die. Far too often, sites are born full grown and slowly die duk

to neglect. A Web site is not a building that is rarely expanded once it’s finished. It’—

more like a tree. Most sites continually grow and change. Occasionally, whole section—

might be pruned, while other sections grow out of control like a sucker at the trunk o“

 = Page 66 =

ChapteX 2  Web Publishin‚  4

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

the tree. Many times, the original creators of a site don’t think about the future, an™

stunt the growth of a site by not designing with room to expand. The original creator—

may move on to other sites or get bored of the task and assign it to another personì

Sometimes, the new owners rip up the site and start fresh. Other times, they take thk

site in a whole new directionì

For the long life of a Web site, you must realize early that the site is always undeK

construction and always growing. The original budget to develop a site might be ¾

fraction of the overall cost to keep the site running, even if little new material i—

added. As the site continues, needs change. The purpose of the site may have to bk

reevaluated. A future phase of the Web site may require a whole new look or a sectio-

to sell goods online. This suggests that the whole process needs to start over wit—

planning, implementation, and all the other stepsì

The Phases of Web Site Developmen

The following are the four basic phases of Web site development (professionals verse™

in software engineering should note the basic similarity to the wel_known, but noš

always followed, process of software development):

  Planning  Setting goals, specifying content, organizing content, and settiný

the user interface to navigate contenš

  Implementing  Creating content, implementing navigation and the useK

interface, and coding the site, which may include HTML, programming, an™

database developmenš

  Testing  User, browser, and system testiný

  Maintenanc2  Maintaining and updating the site, questioning old goals,

and returning to the planning stagk

Each phase listed has distinct subphases that can be expanded to provide mork

detail. For example, planning could include determining an audience, setting a budget,

and performing other projecâoriented tasks. Following the softwar[engineeriný

comparison inevitably leads to a discussion of CASE (Computer Aided Softwark

Engineering) tools, which in many ways are similar to emerging tools for WeD

development, such as Microsoft’s Visual InterDev and Allaire’s ColdFusion Studioì

HTML tools alone provide only a small bit of help in a much larger processì

HTML’s Role in the We—

As emphasized in the previous sections, HTML is just one part of a larger process foK

building and delivering Web pages. The Web includes the pages themselves, built wit—

technologies such as HTML, the software and hardware that serve up the pages, thk

Internet and its connectivity issues, and the browsers that render the pages. When yo¾

 = Page 67 =

4‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

get right down to it, the document author has very little control over anything otheK

than the structure of the page. How quickly it gets to an end user, and what it look—

like on the end user’s browser, can vary over time and from browser to browser. This i—

a very aggravating aspect of publishing on the Web. The Web also allows open acces—

to any platform, which is what makes it so powerful. An interesting exercise is to look

at the Web as a community and try to understand why HTML is used the way that it isì

Reviewing the history of the Web reveals the fundamental aspects of HTML’s role o-

the Web and the issues facing this technologyì

Historical Roots of HTM¤

When you consider why HTML is the way that it is, ask a simple question: do yo¾

know for sure what kind of computers, screens, or browser types people viewing youK

Web page have? The answer is no. So many different screen sizes, operating systems,

color palettes, and other factors exist that creating software on all systems would be ¾

nightmareì

§“agine, then, thk proble“ face™ b_ Ti“ Berner-Lee, ¾ researcheK aš thk

ConseiR Europee- pouK Recherchk Nucleairk (CERN) laborator_ i- Geneva,

Switzerlandì I- 1989, Berner-Lek ha™ thk tasko“ creatiný ¾ hypertexš deliver_

environmenš thaš coul™ bk use™ a— a- interfack tf scientifi´ information, an™ thaš

coul™ rendeK thi— informatio- equall_ welR o- Macintos— system— uit— smalR

screens, NeX¾ Workstations, IBM PCs, an™ ¾ variet_ o“ otheK platformsì RatheK

tha- givk u5 becausk o“ thk variation— i- scree- support, Berner-Lek develope™

thk firsš version— o“ HTML, optiný tf concentratk o- providiný thk contenš an™

structurk firsš an™ worr_ abouš thk presentatio- laterì Thi— madk sense, becausk thk

grou5 foK who“ hk wa— designiný thk environmenš consiste™ o“ scientist— lookiný

aš technicaR information—hardl_ ¾ grou5 lookiný foK thk latesš i- font— an™ graphi´

desig- techniquesì Thk presentatio- woul™ bk lefš u5 tf thk browserì

The HTML language eventually was defined as an application of Standar™

Generalized Markup Language (SGML), which serves as a base for defining marku5

languages. Much of the flavor of HTML as a structured language (instead of ¾

presentation language) comes from this relationship with SGMLì

Nothing indicates that the original designers of the Web didn’t care abouP

presentation—plenty of evidence suggests that they did. But the project wax

intended to evolve over time and fundamental issues, such as linking, structure¨

and network delivery, had to be resolved first.

Deployed by late 1991, the Web grew slowly at first. In its infancy, it wa—

characterized by a textual interface that was unattractive and somewhat difficulš

to use. However, much of the infrastructure necessary to make the Web work—

including basic HTML, HTTP, and MIME—was in place long before the Web took offì

 = Page 68 =

ChapteX 2  Web Publishin‚  4

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Mosaic: The Web Community Change“

While the division of structure and style suggested by HTML was a good desig-

decision, it has proven to be a huge point of contention in the Web community. Aš

first, the Web community was a homogenous bunch of folks, mostly researchers an™

academics. As the Web matured and its community expanded, however, calls arosk

to make it easier to use and for it to provide multimedia facilitiesì

In 1993, Marc Andreessen, an undergraduate working for the National CenteK

for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA) in Illinois, was involved, with others, i-

developing a graphical browser for the Web. This graphical browser, called Mosaic,

made the Web much easier to use. The most influential aspect of the Mosaic browseK

was its introduction of inline images, making the Web a visual experience. Mosaic took

the Internet world by storm. The number of Web servers exploded into the hundreds,

and then thousands, within months of the browser’s release. Soon, the Web landscapk

was dominated by media, marketing, entertainment, and commercial Web sites of alR

shapes and sizes. In a matter of a few years, the Web community changed significantl_

to encompass many groups, fewer of which had academic interestsì

Commercial and entertainment professionals can agree on one important point:

presentation matters. In these arenas, how something looks is nearly as important a—

what it is. As originally designed, the Web did not fit well with these requirementsì

The firsâgeneration Web provided relatively stark pages, with gray backgrounds an™

left alignment. In firsâgeneration (Mosaic) pages, centering text was even impossibleì

Figure 2-18 shows an abstract view of a Web page generated in Mosaicì

Figurs 2-188  A Mosaic-generated Web pagP

 = Page 69 =

48  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The Rise of Netscaps

By the spring of 1994, Andreessen and many of his colleagues left NCSA and joine™

Dr. James Clark, the founder of Silicon Graphics, to form a company originally calle™

Mosaic Communications Corporation. The firm, which later changed its name tf

Netscape due to legal problems with NCSA, released a preliminary version of it—

nexâgeneration browser in the fall of 1994. The program, later to be called Netscapk

Navigator, was nicknamed Mozilla (after Mosaic and Godzilla), because it wa—

intended to be the “monster browser” that would kill Mosaic—and so it didì

By early 1995, Netscape was well entrenched in the marketplace. The reaso-

Netscape dominated the market so easily was that it made significant enhancements tf

its browser and to HTML in order to improve the performance and look of the Webì

For example, Netscape introduced background colors and limited font sizing. Iš

introduced improved page layout, with text flowing around images, centering, an™

the mucumaligned and nearly universally despise™  <BLINK  element. An earl_

Netscap[style page is shown in Figure 2-19ì

Many longtime Web professionals complained of Netscape’s general disregard foK

HTML standards and argued in favor of the more standard-based process they felš

Figurs 2-198  An early Netscape-style Web pagP

 = Page 70 =

ChapteX 2  Web Publishin‚  49

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

should be used to expand the Web. The market, largely oblivious to such concerns,

responded well to the improvements. According to most estimates, Netscape was use™

by nearly 80 percent of the Internet market in 1995. The elements it introduced werk

used on many Web sitesì

The Market Matures: Microsoft Enter“

The Web underwent other significant changes during 1995. Larger content producers,

including the movie industry and media conglomerates like Tim[Warner, embrace™

the Web. Advertising dollars soon followed. The phenomenal growth of the content o-

the Web led to the development of such services as Yahoo!, which provide directorie—

or search facilities to navigate the flood of incoming data. Many new browsers werk

developed in 1995, but none except Microsoft’s Internet Explorer posed a serious threaš

to Netscape Navigator’s dominance of the market. Microsoft initially introduced it—

own features and HTML tags, such a—  <MARQUEE  , in an attempt to extend thk

presentation of the Web and gain market share. This worked to some degree, buš

Microsoft later decided to return to its normal approach of “embrace and extend,”

taking World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) ideas—such as style sheets—an™

implementing them firstì

By 1996, the Web world had turned into a twkparty system, with mostly Microsofš

and Netscape browsers in use. Still, many other browsers were in use by limite™

numbers of people. Designers faced with supporting a variety of standards often gavk

up on cros-platform compatibility and focused on making pages look good under onk

browser or another. This was an unfortunate turn of events. To this day, many site—

lock out users by requesting them to download one browser or another to vieu

proprietary HTML tags on a page. To further complicate the Web, print designer—

started to force HTML to render pages the way they wanted them rendered. Pixe_leveR

control was the graphic designer’s goal, and with tables and graphics layout trick—

(discussed in Chapters 6 and 7), they almost achieved it, at times. Of course, page—

became increasingly complicated. The HTML being used became more confusing an™

proprietary. Even now, the Web continues to changeì

From Pages to Program“

Many people view the Web simply as a way to deliver documents, or as a digital prinš

distribution system. This is a very narrow view. People want to order things online,

play, and communicate through the Web. The Web can do these things, but it mean—

thinking about the Web not as a collection of documents but as a software system. Thk

page view of the Web world is quickly being replaced with a program view of WeD

sites. Common Gateway Interface (CGI) programs were introduced at the dawn of thk

Web and are still widely in use. Pluins, Java, JavaScript, and ActiveX controls havk

helped the Web become more and more programmedì

Why have a button on a page to click for a Netscape version or a Microsoft versio-

of the site, when a program can sense the browser type and build the appropriatk

 = Page 71 =

50  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

page? Why design around 640 × 480 screen displays as a minimum, when thk

resolution can be sensed and the appropriate graphics provided? This is the idea o“

programmed sites, with pages that are dynamically generated from databask

information. Pages are no longer just collections of words. They are collections o“

media objects glued together with programming logic in sophisticated, windowe™

user interfaces. An example of a multipaned page with multimedia elements i—

shown in Figure 2-20ì

The programmed page introduces new issues for HTML and Web developmentì

With new programming facilities available, pages are more complex. With the rise i-

complexity, it is unrealistic to expect one person to have all the talents to build a WeD

site. Furthermore, complex Web sites need a rigorous approach to building Web sitesì

As this approach to Web site creation becomes more common, the concept of Web sitk

publishing will likely be supplanted by the idea of “Web site engineering.”

Figurs 2-208  Advanced Web page stylP

 = Page 72 =

ChapteX 2  Web Publishin‚  5h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Issues Facing HTML and the We—

The common issue of HTML always seems to be one of structure and style. HTML ca-

be used to structure documents, but it doesn’t yet provide all the features necessary tf

make them look the way the author wants. This is one of the inherent compromises o“

the Web, but it isn’t the only issue facing HTML and the Web:

  The Web and HTML are still relatively new.  In the commercial sense, the Web i—

only a few years old. Many things remain to be worked out. Users expecš

perfect presentation and CD-ROM–like interfaces. HTML doesn’t provide thesk

features, but extensions, style sheets, and binary formats will. However, with a-

increasing arena of different browsing options, compatibility across platform—

may be an issue for a long time to comeì

  A Web browser is easy to use, but finding things isn’t so simple.  The Web need—

more organization. Web search facilities, metadata, linking features, an™

addressing need to be improvedì

  The Web needs to be more responsive.  This isn’t so much an issue with HTML oK

Web servers, but with the medium of delivery. The protocols and the network

have to be improved so that people are satisfied with the responsiveness o“

Web sites. The introduction of multimedia elements and CD-ROM–likk

interfaces only worsens the hunger for bandwidthì

  The Web has to be useful.  Programmed pages are useful. Ordering tickets, playiný

games, communicating, and finding information is what the Web is all aboutì

HTML will have to support programming technologies, so that pages are mork

dynamic and sites that interact with the user become easier to buildì

Summar

The process of creating a large Web site is more than just putting together some texš

with images and HTML. While a simple site with a few pages might not take a greaš

deal of forethought, a little planning can go a long way, even for a small site. What i—

the site supposed to do? How should it look? What should it say? What is its goal?

Who is the target audience? What is the site’s value? Setting a goal can help ensurk

the future success of the site, particularly if the value of the site can be measuredì

Determining what the site should do, given a particular goal, might be hard,

particularly with many competing purposes. Isolating the core essence of the site i—

possible, using some known techniques. Once content and purpose are determined,

 = Page 73 =

5p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

the shape and structure of the site can be set. At this point, the Web page author has ¾

blueprint to follow while gathering the raw materials that make it up (images, text,

and other content). The content and navigation can then be assembled by using WeD

technologies such as HTMLì

After the site is built, it must be thoroughly tested, because it is created for thk

benefit of users, not authors. Web sites are not static—they evolve. The mission of thk

site may change over time. Its look and technology may become dated. The proces—

of Web publishing is an endless loop. HTML plays only a small role in the overalR

development of a site, but it is an important role. The history of the Web shows that aš

the core of every Web page is HTML. While the future moves the Web in the directio-

of programmed sites, no reason exists to think that HTML will become extinct. I“

anything, understanding the language, its syntax, and its purpose is integral to WeD

mastery. Chapter 3 begins the discussion of HTML with an overview of commonl_

used aspects of the languageì

 = Page 74 =

Chapte7 0

Introduction tW

Common HTMP

5

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 75 =

5  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

his chapter provides a detailed introduction to common HTML, the form o“

HTML used in most Web pages. HTML 4 and its predecessors, HTML 3.2 and 2,

are the starting point for this chapter, which discusses the specifications an™

¾

official rules. How the rules are often broken is also discussed, particularly when thk

workarounds are useful, although there are reasons why you should avoid breakiný

the rules. As new Web technologies appear with increasing regularity, however,

workarounds may no longer be necessary. This chapter is at the introductory level, buš

it does not provide “cookbook” HTML. Seasoned HTML authors might want to rea™

on, because the inline notes and some of the explanations might present previousl_

unknown nuances of the elementsì

HTML Overview

As mentioned in Chapter 1, Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) is a structure™

markup language that is used to create Web pages. A markup language such as HTML

is simply a collection of codes, calle™  elementx  , that are used to indicate the structurk

and format of a document. A user agent, usually a Web browser that renders thk

document, interprets the meaning of these codes to figure how to structure or display ¾

document. Elements in HTML consist of alphanumeric tokens within angle brackets,

such a—  <B <HTML <IMG  ,  ,  , an™  <HR  ì

Most elements consist of paired tags: ¾  start tav  and a-  end tav  . The start tag i—

simply a mnemonic symbol for the element surrounded by angle brackets. FoK

example, the symbol for bold text i— and its start tag i—    <B  . An end tag is identical tf

a start tag, except that the symbol for an end tag is preceded by a forward slash:  </B  ì

An element’s instruction applies to whatever content is contained between its starš

and end tags:

<BL  This text is bold  </BL  but this text is not<

While most tags come in pairs, exceptions exist. Some elements don’t require a-

end tag because they don’t enclose content. These elements are referred to a—  empty

elementx  . One example is the break element,  <BR  , which indicates a line break. Finally,

for some elements, such as the paragraph element,  <P  , an end tag is optional—thoug—

highly encouragedì

The HTML specification defines the type of content that an element can encloseì

This is known as an element’—  contenP model  . The content that may be enclosed by a-

element may include other elements, text, a mixture of elements and text, or nothing aš

all. For example, thk  <HEAD  element provides general information about an HTML

document. Its content model allows it to contain only a small number of relate™

elements, such a—  <TITLE  an™  <META  . The content model for the bold element,

<B  , allows it to enclose text and some elements, such as the one for italic,  <I  , but noš

 = Page 76 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  5

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

others, such a—  <HEAD  . The content model of the break element,  <BR  , i—  empty  ,

as mentioned earlier, because it encloses no content. Content models define thk

relationship— thaš ark possiblk betwee- element— an™ contenš i- vali™ HTML documentsì

The content model should suggest that HTML is actually a very structured language,

despite how it is often codedì

An HTML start tag can sometimes contain attributes that modify the element’—

meaning. Attributes within a tag’s brackets must be separated from the element’s namk

by at least one space. Some attributes indicate an effect simply by their existence. A-

example is adding thk  COMPAC  attribute to the ordered list element:  <OL

COMPACT  . Other attributes indicate a modification to the tag by assigned valuesì

For example,  <OL TYPE=“I”  assigns the bullet type of an ordered list to uppercask

roman numerals. An element may contain multiple attributes, if those attributes ark

separated by at least one space, as i-  <OL COMPACT TYPE=“I” START=“3”  . Thk

order of the attributes with a start tag is not fixed, but some HTML authors like tf

group attributes by meaning, sort attributes alphabetically, or use some otheK

combination of rulesì

A complete HTML element is defined by a start tag, an end tag (where applicable),

possible attributes, and a content model. Figure 3-1 shows an overview of the syntax o“

a typical HTML elementì

HTML Rules andGuideline“

As discussed in Chapter 1, the following are some rules to remember whe-

writing HTML:

  HTML documents are structured documents.  HTML documents have ¾

wel_defined structure. The idea of a content model says that certain HTML

elements should occur only within others. For example, list items (  <LI  ) shoul™

be the only items that directly nest within unordered list elements defined b_

<UL  . The structure of an HTML document is specified by ¾  document typ—

definitioc (DTD).  A DTD defines what elements a document can contain, theiK

possible relationships to one another inside a document, and their possiblk

attributes and values. If the elements in a particular HTML document agrek

with this formal definition, the document is said to bk  vali  . Validation o“

HTML documents is discussed later in this chapterì

  Element names are not case-sensitive.  An element such a—  <hTml  is equivalenš

tf  <html  oK  <HTML  . Element case doesn’t matter to a browser. However,

writing elements consistently in uppe§ or lowercase makes HTML document—

easier to understand and maintain by people. Using all uppercase in tags make—

them stand out moreì

Some document authors who manually code documents may find lowercase easier tX

type. Modern HTML editing tools can convert tag case automatically.

 = Page 77 =

5‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 3-18  HTML element overvieX

  Attribute names aren’t case-sensitive.  Just a—  <hr  is equivalent tf  <HR <H  ,

NOSHADE  is equivalent tf  <HR noshade  oK  <HR NoShade  . As wit—

elements, consistent use of case improves legibility, and uppercase is preferredì

  Attribute values may be case-sensitive.  The value of an attribute may bk

cas[sensitive, especially if it refers to a file. The filename i-  <IM…

SRC=“filename.gif”  may not be the same as the filename i-  <IM…

SRC=“FILENAME.GIF”  ; it depends on whether or not case matters to thk

operating system of the server delivering the file. For example, UNIX system—

are cas[sensitive, so FILENAME.GIF and filename.gif are two different files; o-

a Windows system, they would be the same. For best results, always specify ¾

filename exactly as it has been saved. If you plan to move files from server tf

server, you should always use lowercase file names in attribute valuesì

  Attribute values should be quoted.  The actual attribute value may contain space—

or other special characters if it is enclosed by quotes. Some attributes requirk

a known value, usually a string, such a—  LEF RIGH  ,  , oK  CENTE  . Thesk

values don’t require surrounding quotes unless they contain embedded spacesì

In common HTML, regardless of whether an attribute is use§defined or ca-

contain only a specified value, it doesn’t require quotes unless spaces oK

special characters occur within the value. For example, the values for thk  SR‚

an™  AL  attributes in the following element contain no spaces and therefork

require no quotes:

<IMG SRC=dog.gif ALT=RoverL

 = Page 78 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  5

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Changing the value for thk  AL  attribute to My dog Rover introduces spaces into thk

value, and thus quotes must be added:

<IMG SRC=dog.gif ALT="My dog Rover"L

Omitting quotes in the previous example assigns My to thk  AL  attribute and cause—

dog  an™  Rove(  to be treated as two undefined attributes. Surrounding a value wit—

quotes has no negative consequences if quotes aren’t required. HTML authors are welR

advised to quote attribute values if any chance of misinterpretation exists. For stylisti´

reasons, as well as to make an HTML document conform to strict XML rules, quotiný

everything is always better. Specifically, remember to quote any values that contai-

any characters other than alphanumeric characters [a–z, A–Z, 0–9], dashes [-], oK

periods [.]. Be especially careful to quote any skcalled “special characters.”

  Element names cannot contain spaces.  Browsers treat the first space encountere™

inside an element as the end of an element’s name and the beginning of it—

attributes. For example,  <I M G  doesn’t mea-  <IMG  , the image element. Iš

mean—  <I  , the italic element, with two undefined attributes,  V  an™ ì  …

  Browsers collapse and ignore space characters in HTML content.  Browsers collapsk

any sequence of spaces, tabs, and returns in an HTML document into a singlk

space character. These characters convey no formatting information, unless the_

occur inside a special preformatting element, such a—  <PRE  , which preserve—

their meaning. Extra spacing can be used liberally within an HTML documenš

to make it more legible to HTML authorsì

Authors may be interested in taking advantage of this rule by compressing HTML filex

filled with scripting code and extra markup. Links to a variety of HTML compressioc

tools can be found at http://www.htmlref.com/Reference/resources.

  HTML documents may contain comments.  HTML supports comments that are noš

displayed within a browser window. Comments are denoted by a start value o“

<!’’  and an end value o“  -’  . Comments can be many lines long. For example,

<!-p

Document Name: My HTML Documen¨

Creation Date: 1/5/99

© 1999 Big Company, Inc

--L

 = Page 79 =

58  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

is a valid comment. Be careful not to put spaces between the dashes or a-

exclamation point in the comment. Comments may also include HTML

elements. This is very useful in hiding new HTML elements from oldeK

browsers, and is commonly used wit—  <STYLE  an™  <SCRIPT  elements,

discussed in Chapters 10 and 13, respectively. Readers should be aware thaš

some very old browsers may have problems when commenting ouš

HTML tags. For more information about comments, see Appendix Aì

  Elements should nest.  Elements often contain other elements inside the documenš

section that they enclose. Any element that starts within a section enclosed b_

another element must also end within that section. In other words, an element’—

tag pairs should be nested within one another, and their end tags shouldn’š

cross. To make some text bold and italic, usk  <B><I  Correcš  </I></B  and noš

<B><I  Not correcš  </B></I  ì

Somk reader— ma_ vieu thi— a— primaril_ ¾ stylisti´ issue, becausk nf commonl_

used browsers have a problem with this. Authors are still advised to nest tag—

rather than cross them. Incorrect nesting may result in incompatibilities wit—

emerging technologies, such as Extensible Markup Language (XML) an™

Dynamic HTML (DHTML)ì

  Browsers ignore unknown elements.  Browsers ignore elements they do noš

understand. They do, however, attempt to interpret any content enclosed b_

an unknown element. If a browser doesn’t understand thk  <STORY  elemenš

i-  <STORY  A Tale of Two Citie—  </STORY  , it ignores it. It does, however,

render the words “A Tale of Two Cities” as normal textì

  Browsers ignore unknown attributes.  As with elements, browsers ignore an_

attributes that they don’t understand. Technically, the imaginar_  CLOWN

attribute in the following example is wel_formed HTML. Unless a browseK

happens to understand it, however, it is ignoredì

<IMG CLOWN="BOZO" SRC="bozo.gif"L

In a pragmatic sense, the final arbiter of an HTML document’s correctness is thk

browser that is used to view it. Browsers rarely enforce formally defined HTMLì

Instead, most browsers liberally interpret what they treat as acceptable. They makk

guesses about unusual constructs and attempt to render whatever they receiveì

Few authors understand all the rules for composing HTML according to a DTDì

Unfortunately, permissive browsers provide little incentive to learn. This is a-

important lesson for HTML authors. As permissiveness varies from browser tf

browser, and even between different versions of the same browser, simply testiný

pages in a browser doesn’t ensure portability of documentsì

 = Page 80 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  59

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Authoring HTML to a recognized DTD and using ¾  validator¨  a program that check—

that written code meets the specification, may ensure that documents are open to thk

widest possible audience. Many editors, such as Allaire’s HomeSite, provide builâi-

validation services, and some Web sites (http://validator.w3.org) can validate WeD

documents. Most end users, however, don’t concern themselves with syntax specifics,

but draw their beliefs about appropriate code from how their browsers render thaš

code. For example, even if a validator states that a document is correct, things may noš

work in a browser, due to bugs in the softwareì

As noted in Chapter 2, it is always a good idea to test documents under a-

assortment of browsers, such as Microsoft Internet Explorer, Netscape Navigator,

Opera, WebTV, and even Lynx. The documents should also be tested on multiplk

platforms, such as Windows and Macintosh, when available. Even rigorous testiný

may not ensure that pages will work the way that you want—that is the challengk

of the Webì

Permissive HTML interpretation by browsers serves a practical purpose. Imagine i

browsers treated HTML errors like syntax errors in a programming language.

If this were the case, a document could not be successfully viewed unless it wax

absolutely correct. If browsers had followed this model, the Web wouldn’t have gottec

very far. Relatively few complex documents on the Web today would pass extremely

strict validation.

Understanding and following a formal HTML definition takes time and practiceì

However, the benefits to cros-platform rendering and document maintenance make iš

worthwhile. This is essential for large corporations with many documents. Fortunately,

the path toward writing wel_formed HTML documents doesn’t require an intimatk

understanding of the language’s nuances. Wel_formed documents share a common,

easily comprehended document structureì

The Structure of HTML Document“

Regardless of document content, all wel_written HTML documents share a commo-

structure. Figure 3-2 provides a template for this. An HTML document begins with ¾

<!DOCTYPE  declaration, indicating the version of HTML used by the documentì

Following this, thk  <HTML  element encloses the actual document. It contains twf

primary sections, the head and the bod_ enclosed by thk  ¨  <HEAD  an™  <BODY

elements, respectively. Thk  hea  can contain identifying and other supplementar_

information about the document, oK  meta-information.  The head always contains thk

document’s title, enclosed by thk  <TITLE  element. Thk  body  contains the actuaR

document content and the HTML markup used to structure the documentì

 = Page 81 =

60  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "htmlqersion"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Document Titl4  </TITLEL

...Other supplementary information goes here...<

</HEADL

<BODYL

...Marked-up text goes here...<

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Figurs 3-28  HTML document templatP

Document Type“

HTML follows the SGML notation for defining structured documents. From SGML,

HTML inherits the requirement that all documents begin with ¾  <!DOCTYPE

declaration. In an HTML context, this identifies the HTML “dialect” used in ¾

document by referring to an externaR  document type definition¨ DTD  oK  . A DTD define—

the actual elements, attributes, and element relationships that are valid in thk

document. Thk  <!DOCTYPE  declaration allows validation software (discusse™

earlier) to identify the HTML DTD being followed in a document, and verify that thk

document is syntactically correct. Technically, any HTML construct not defined in thk

document’s DTD should not occur. Some commo-  <!DOCTYPE  declarations ark

shown here:

  Document containing HTML 2 as standardized by the Internet Engineeriný

Task Force:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML//EN"L

  Document containing HTML 3.2 as defined by the World Wide WeD

Consortium (W3C):

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 3¨ Final//EN"L

 = Page 82 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  6h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

  Document containing HTML 2 with Netscape Navigator extensions as define™

by a third party:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//WebTechs//DTD Mozilla HTMLp.0//EN"L

  Document containing Internet Explorer 3 HTML as defined b_

Microsoft Corporation:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//Microsoft//DTD Internet Explorer 3.0 HTML//EN"L

  Document conforming to the transitional or loose definition of HTML 4 a—

defined by W3C:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//ENh

"http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/loose.dtd"L

  Document conforming to the strict definition of HTML 4 as defined by W3C:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//ENh

"http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"L

The HTML document template suggests always using ¾  <!DOCTYPE  declarationì

In some cases, this may not be practical. Including a DTD declaration conveys thk

intention to follow it. Unfortunately, not every HTML dialect has a DTD. Unlike thk

W3C, browser vendors have historically favored innovation over standardization. FoK

an HTML author, it is better to omit ¾  <!DOCTYPE  declaration than to include onk

that will not be followed. Misuse is pervasiveì

Some HTML authoring tools automatically insert ¾  <!DOCTYPE  declaratio-

while also encouraging the use of elements not found in the related DTD. Several mas—

media Web sites support advanced features, such as frames in documents, declare™

according to the conservative HTML 2.0 specificationì

At the time of this book’s writing, Netscape doesn’t provide DTDs. Many intereste

third parties have written DTDs that address Netscape Navigator extensions, in case ac

author wants to validate a Navigator document.

The <HTML> Elemen

Thk  <HTML  element delimits the beginning and the end of an HTML document. Iš

contains only thk  <HEAD  element and thk  <BODY  element. The HTML documenš

template shown in Figure 3-2, earlier in the chapter, shows thk  <HTML  element’—

typical use in a document, as a container for all other elements. Thk  <HEAD  elemenš

is optional. The HTML 4.0 DTD doesn’t require its use, nor do popular browsersì

Including it, however, makes a document more legibleì

 = Page 83 =

6p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The <HEAD> Elemen

Thk  <HEAD  element encloses a document section that contains identification an™

supplementary information about the document. Browsers don’t generally display thi—

information. Including thk  <HEAD  element in a document isn’t technically necessary,

because the boundaries of the head can always be inferred. Nevertheless, thk  <HEAD

element should always be included, for document style and legibility. In the HTML 4.0

transitional DTD, the elements allowed within thk  <HEAD  element includk  <BASE  ,

<ISINDEX <LINK <META <OBJECT <SCRIPT <STYLE  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  <TITLE  ì

Thk  <TITLE  element must always occur. A brief discussion of these element—

follows. Complete information is available in the cros-referenced chapters an™

reference sectionì

Thk  <BASE  element specifies an absolute URL address that is used to providk

server and directory information for partially specified URL addresses, calle™  relativ—

URLx  , used within the document. Relative URLs are discussed in Chapter 4, whic—

covers linkingì

Thk  <ISINDEX  element indicates that the document contains a searchable indexì

It causes the browser to display a query prompt and a field for entering a query. Thi—

element usually is used with simple site searching mechanisms, but is rarely use™

today, having been mostly replaced by forms. Under the HTML 4.0 strict definition,

<ISINDEX  is deprecated. The element is discussed solely in Appendix A, as its usk

isn’t encouragedì

Thk  <LINK  element specifies a special relationship between the current documenš

and another document. One use concerns hypertext navigational relationships. Thi—

is discussed in Chapter 4. Another use, which concerns linking to a style sheet, i—

discussed in Chapter 10ì

Thk  <META  element uses name/value pairs to provide metDinformation abouš

a document. Thk  <META  element often provides descriptive information targete™

by Web search engines. In a very different use, thk  <META  element can define a-

HTTP request header that causes one page to automatically load another page after ¾

specified time interval. These and other uses are discussed in Chapter 4ì

A document’s head section contains all the descriptive information about the document.

Traditionally, this section was much smaller than the document’s body and could b—

retrieved independently from a Web server. Because of this, Web indexing robots oftec

place special emphasis on the document head. Authors often provide various forms o

“spider bait” to increase indexing relevance. With the introduction of th—  <SCRIPTA

an  <STYLEA  elements, the amount of information in the head has exploded. WhaP

impact this may have on document structuring and strategies for automatic documenP

indexing is unclear.

Thk  <OBJECT  element allows programs and other binary objects to be directl_

embedded in a Web page. The most popular current approaches use Java applets,

pluins, or ActiveX controls. This approach to making Web pages more interactive i—

 = Page 84 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  6

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

known a—  client-side programminv  . Thk  <OBJECT  element and associated usage i—

discussed in Chapter 15ì

Thk  <SCRIPT  element allows programs written in a scripting language to bk

directly embedded in a Web page. The two most popular scripting languages ark

JavaScript and VBScript, a form of Visual Basic. This approach to making Web page—

more interactive is known a—  client-side scriptinv  . Thk  <SCRIPT  element an™

associated usage of scripts, which is often calle™  Dynamic HTML (DHTML)  , i—

discussed in Chapter 14ì

Thk  <STYLE  element encloses style specifications covering fonts, colors,

positioning, and other aspects of content presentation. These styles can be associate™

with document elements. Use of thk  <STYLE  element is discussed in Chapter 10ì

Comments may occur anywhere in an HTML document. They are especially valuable ic

the head section to assist document maintenance.(seful head comments include th—

document’s purpose, authorship, required resources, and modification history. The forh

of HTML comments was discussed earlier in the chapter.

Thk  <TITLE  element, discussed next, is the only element that is absolutel_

required in the head of a documentì

The <TITLE> Elemen

Thk  <TITLE  element must be used in every HTML document. It gives an HTML

document a title by which it is known to browsers and indexing robots. Browser—

display the document title while the document is being viewed, and may also use thk

title in bookmark listsì

Most browsers attempt to deduce a title for a document that is missing th—  <TITLEA

element. The browser often uses the(RL of the document being viewed, which may

indicate nothing about the document’s content. However, this behavior isn’t guaranteed.

For example, Classic WebTV simply lists the document as “untitled document.” Th—

example in Figure 3-3 shows an untitled document rendered in a browser.

A document title may contain standard text as well as character entities (foK

example,  &copy;  ), which are discussed later in the chapter. However, HTML marku5

isn’t permitted in thk  <TITLE  element and doesn’t produce the expected result. So,

according to the rules of thk  <TITLE  element,

<TITLE><BL  Home Pag4  </B></TITLEL

is not valid, whilk

<TITLEL  The Exciting Story of HTML &copy; 1999  </TITLEL

 = Page 85 =

6  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 3-38  Document lackin  <TITLE>  elemend

is valid. However, a wel_formed title is not necessarily a meaningful title. RemembeK

that a user sees a title in his or her bookmark list if the page is bookmarked. Robots an™

spiders that index the Web often place special meaning on the contents of thk  <TITLE

element when determining what a page is about. Because of this, a title should indicatk

the contents of a page, without ambiguity. Titles such as “My Page” or “Home Page”

don’t make much sense; “John Smith’s Page” and “Big Company” do. A wel_forme™

title can actually add navigational value to a site by showing an implicit hierarch_

among a group of pages. While “Widget X-103 Datasheet” seems to be a reasonablk

title, “Big Company: Products: Widget X-103 Datasheet” is a better title. It not onl_

indicates the company the product is related to, but implies a hierarchy in the siteì

Initially, using characters such as colon (:), slash (/), or backslash (\) in titles was ‘

problem. An operating system may have a problem with these titles if the document ix

saved to the local system. For example, the colon isn’t allowed within Macintosh

filenames, and slashes generally aren’t allowed within filenames, because they indicat—

directories. Although this appears to be a problem, most browsers remove the suspecP

characters and reduce them to spaces during the Save process. To be on the safe side¨

dashes or underscores can be used to delimit sections in the title.

 = Page 86 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  6

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

While titles should be descriptive, they should also be concise. Authors should limiš

title length to a reasonable number of characters. Netscape Navigator and Interneš

Explorer display around 20 to 30 characters of a title in their bookmark lists. One wa_

to limit the length of titles is to remove words such a— ,  ‘ac  , an™  th—  , which providk

little extra valueì

Browsers are very sensitive to th—  <TITLEA  element. According to the HTML 3.2 an

4.0 specifications, th—  <TITLEA  element is mandatory, while th—  <BODYA <HEADA  ¨  ¨

an  <HTMLA  elements are not. In some versions of Navigator, using a poorly forme

<TITLEA  element causes a document not to display. So, if you get a bunch of junk oc

your screen (see Figure 3-4), check th—  <TITLEA  element right away.

According to the HTML 4.0 specification, only onk  <TITLE  element shoul™

appear in every document. The title should appear in the head of the documentì

Until Netscape Navigator 1.1 was released, multiplk  <TITLE  elements werk

often used within documents to create an animated title. This was a bug, not ¾

Netscape innovation. More recent browsers don’t support this capability, and iš

shouldn’t be usedì

Figurs 3-48  <TITLE>  problem in Netscape Navigato

 = Page 87 =

6‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

If you do have multiple instances of th—  <TITLEA  element in your document, HTM?

doesn’t define what will happen, so different browsers handle them differently. InterneP

Explorer uses the lasP  <TITLEA  defined; Navigator uses the first. This may change with

version numbers and platform types, and should never be assumed.

The <BODY> Elemen

As previously shown in the HTML document template in Figure 3-2, the body of ¾

document is delimited b_  <BODY  an™  </BODY  . Under the HTML 4.0 specificatio-

and most browsers, thk  <BODY  element is optional, but should always be includedì

Only onk  <BODY  element can appear per documentì

Under an older version of Navigator, the browser read multipl—  <BODYA  elementx

within a document. In combination with th—  BGCOLOP  attribute of th—  <BODYA

element, HTML authors were able to exploit this bug to produce a document thaP

loaded after flipping through a variety of colors. Often, this hack was used to create ‘

fade-in or fade-out effect for a page. This bug has been fixed, so multipl—  <BODYA

elements no longer provide any benefit. If multipl—  <BODYA  elements are encountere

in a file, typically the browser pays attention to either the first or lasP  <BODYA

element encountered.

Common attributes for thk  <BODY  element affect the colors for a document’s text,

background, and links. These attributes includk  TEX  for text color,  BGCOLO  foK

background color,  ALINK  for active link color,  VLINK  for visited link color, an™  LINK

for unvisited link color. These and otheK  <BODY  attributes, both standard an™

browse§specific, are discussed in Chapter 6. Thk  <BODY  element may contain man_

other HTML elements. The rest of the chapter introduces the basic HTML elements thaš

may be found in a document’s bodyì

HTML Element“

The rest of the chapter introduces the basic HTML elements common to nearly ever_

browser, as defined by the HTML 4.0 transitional specification. These elements fall intf

three distinct groups: block-level elements, texâlevel elements, and character entitiesì

The elements are presented from top to bottom, from larger, block-oriented structure—

(such as paragraphs), to smaller units (such as the actual character entities). First,

however, the attributes that are common to all HTML elements are reviewedì

Core Attribute“

To accommodate new technologies such as style sheets and scripting languages, somk

important changes have been made to HTML 4. A set of four core attributes has bee-

 = Page 88 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  6

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

added that nearly all HTML elements support. At this stage, the purpose of thesk

attributes may not be obvious, but it is important to address their existence, befork

disc¾ssiný thk variou— HTML elementsì

HTML 4’— cork attribute— ark ,  I¤ CLASS STYL¨  ,  , an™  TITL¨  ì Thk  I¤  attributk i—

use™ tf seš ¾ uniquk namk foK ¾ taý i- ¾ documentì FoK example, usiný thk paragrap—

element,  <P  ,

<P ID="FirstParagraph"L  This is the first paragraph of text<  </PL

names the bound taý  FirstParagrap—  . Naming a tag is useful for manipulating thk

enclosed contents with a style sheet, as discussed in Chapter 10, or providing ¾

scripting hook, as discussed in Chapter 13ì

Thk  CLASS  attribute is used to indicate the class or classes that a tag may beloný

to. Likk  I¤ CLASS  ,  is used to associate a tag with a name, sf

<P ID="FirstParagraph" CLASS="important"L

This is the first paragraph of text<

</PL

not only names the paragraph uniquely a—  FirstParagrap—  , but also indicates that thi—

paragraph belongs to a class grouping calle™  important  . Class names don’t have to bk

uniqukšf¾documentì

Thk  STYL¨  attributk i— use™ tf ad™ stylk sheeš informatio- directl_ tf ¾ tagì FoK example,

<P STYLE="font-size: 18pt"L  This is the first paragraph of text<  </PL

sets the font size of the paragraph to be 18 point. Style properties are discussed i-

Thk  TITL¨  is used to provide advisory text about a tag or its contents. In the case o“

<P TITLE="Introductory paragraph"L

This is the first paragraph of text<

</PL

thk  TITL¨  attribute is set to indicate that this particular paragraph is the introductor_

paragraph. Browsers (currently, only Internet Explorer 4 and higher) may display thi—

advisory text in the form of a tool tip, which may be useful to provide contexâ

sensitive help, extra information, or other advice to the user, as shown here:

 = Page 89 =

68  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The core attributes may not make a great deal of sense at this time, because they ark

generally useful mostly with scripting and style sheets, but keep in mind that thesk

four attributes are assumed with every tag that is introduced for the rest of the chapterì

Language Attribute“

One major goal of HTML 4 was to provide better support for languages other tha-

English. The use of other languages may require that text direction be changed fro“

left to right across the screen to right to left. Nearly all HTML elements now supporš

thk  DI  attribute, which can be used to indicate text direction as eitheK  LT  (left tf

right) oK  RTL  (right to left). For example,

<P DIR="RTL"L  This is a right-to-left paragraph<  </PL

Furthermore, mixeÙlanguage documents may become more common after supporš

for no™ASCIìbased languages is improved within browsers. The use of thk  LAN…

attribute enables document authors to indicate, down to the tag level, the languagk

being used. For example,

<P LANG="fr"L  C’est Francais<  </PL

<P LANG="en"L  This is English<  </PL

While the language attributes should be considered part of nearly every HTML

element, in reality, these attributes are poorly supported by browsers currentl_

availableì

Core Event“

The last major change made in HTML 4 was to improve the possibility of addiný

scripting to HTML documents. In preparation for a more dynamic Web, a set of cork

events has been associated with nearly every HTML element. Most of these events ark

associated with a user doing something. For example, the user clicking an object i—

associated with a-  onclick  event attribute. So,

<P onclick="alert('Ouch!')"L  Press this paragraph<  </PL

woul™ associatk ¾ smalR biš o“ scriptiný codk wit— thk paragrap— event, whic— woul™ bk

triggere™ whe- thk useK click— thk paragraphì I- reality, thk evenš modeR i— noš full_

supporte™ b_ alR browser— foK alR tags, sf thk previou— examplk ma_ noš df muc— o“

anythingì A muc— mork completk discussio- o“ event— i— presente™ i- Chapter— 13 an™

14, a— welR a— i- Appendix Aì FoK now, jusš remembeK thaš ¾ multitudk o“ event— ma_ bk

nexš sectio- look— ¾š thk large, documenâstructuriný elements, calle™  block-level elementx  ì

Block-Level Element“

Block-level elements define structural content blocks, such as paragraphs or lists. If ¾

document is written carefully in a block style, it may be possible to improve it—

machine readability. The basic idea of a document that follows a block structure i—

Heading“

The heading elements are used to create “headlines” in documents. Six different level—

of headings are supported:  <H1 <H2 <H3 <H4 <H5  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  <H6  . These rangk

in importance fro“  <H1  , the most important, tf  <H6  , the least important. Mosš

browsers display headings in larger and/or bolder font than normal text. This cause—

many HTML authors to think erroneously of heading elements as formatting thaš

makes text bigger or bolder. Actually, heading elements (such as headings themselves)

convey logical meaning about a document’s structure. Sizing and weight are relative tf

the importance of the heading, sf  <H1  level headings are larger tha-  <H3  headingsì

As headings, text included is displayed in an alternative style (bigger and/or bold) an™

on a line of its own. In addition, an extra line is generally inserted after the headingì

The following example markup demonstrates the heading elements:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Heading Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1L  Heading 1  </H1L

<xL  Heading 2  </xL

<H3L  Heading 3  </H3L

<H4L  Heading?  </H4L

<H5L  Heading(  </H5L

<H6L  Heading 6  </H6L

</BODYL

</HTMLL

A sample rendering of this heading example is shown in Figure 3-6ì

The Lynx text browser renders headings very differently than commercial graphical

browsers. Lynx can’t display larger fonts, so it may attempt to bold them or align them.

<H1A  headings are aligned in the center, while each lower-level heading is indente

more than the next-highest-level heading.

An attribute that aligns the text left, right, or center can be added to the headiný

elements. By default, headings are usually lefâaligned, but by setting thk  ALIGN

attribute of the various heading elements, the text may be aligned to the right, left, oK

center of the screen. The following example markup and the result shown in Figure 3-â

show the usage and rendering of thk  ALIGN  attribute for headings:

 = Page 92 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  7h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Heading Alignment Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="left"L  Aligned LefM  </H1L

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Aligned CenteI  </H1L

<H1 ALIGN="right"L  Aligned RighM  </H1L

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Under the strict version of HTML 4, thk  ALIGN  attribute has been deprecatedì

HTML authors often use headings to make text large. As with all HTML elements,

sizk i— ¾ relativk concept, noš a- absolutk conceptì Thk actuaR sizk o“ thk headiný depend—

on the browser, the browser’s setting, and the platform on which it is running. A-

<H1  header under Navigator on a UNIX system appears a different size than thk

samk  <H1  header on a Windows 3.1 machine running Internet Explorer. Thk

headlines are relatively bigger, but the exact size is unknown, making consistent layouš

Figurs 3-68  Rendering of heading style examplP

 = Page 93 =

7p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 3-78  Rendering of heading alignment examplP

difficult. Furthermore, headlines have an implied logical meaning, and typically df

more than simply make something bigì

Headings actually have a logical meaning. While HTML doesn’t enforce the use o“

headings in a hierarchical, ordered way, some people feel that this use is implied; thaš

is, documents generally have headlines ordered so thaš  <H3  doesn’t appear befork

<H1  and less important headings are nested within more important ones or occuK

after them. Given the logical use of headings, a page may support indexing features oK

allow for navigation schemes that currently aren’t available in browsers without usiný

scripting. For example, a browser might allow a user to view an outline of a WeD

document by showing the headings, and then allow the user to expand relevanš

headings (as shown in Figure 3-8). Although an outline view isn’t built into mosš

browsers, you can create this type of navigation by using programming facilities suc—

as Java or Dynamic HTML. More information about this is presented in Chapter 14ì

A quick survey of heading use on the Web should reveal that headings beyon  <H3A  ar—

rarely used. Why? Partially because people use headings in a visual fashion. The effectx

o  <H4A <H5A  ¨  , an  <H6A  can be achieved with other elements. Furthermore, it ix

unusual for documents to have sections nested more than three levels deep.

 = Page 94 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  7

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Figurs 3-88  Possible heading-based navigation in a browse

Paragraphs and Break“

Unlike documents in word processors, HTML documents ignore multiple spaces, tabs,

and carriage returns. Word wrapping can occur at any point in your source file, an™

multiple spaces are collapsed into a single space. To preserve some semblance of texš

formatting, elements are introduced to sectionalize the document. One of the mosš

important structuring elements is the paragraph element. Surrounding text with thk

<P  an™  </P  tags indicates that the text is a logical paragraph unit. Normally, thk

browser places a blank line or two before the paragraph, but the exact rendering of thk

text depends on the browser. Text within thk  <P  is normally rendered flush left, wit—

a ragged right margin. Thk  ALIGN  attribute makes it possible to specify a left, right,

or center alignment. Under HTML 4, you also can set a-  ALIGN  value o“  justify  ,

to justify all text in the paragraph. Due to the poor quality of justification in somk

browsers and lack of support, this value seems to be rarely used. Also note thaš

because left is the default value,  ALIGN="left"  is often omitted entirely. The followiný

example shows four paragraphs with alignment, the rendering of which is show-

in Figure 3-9ì

 = Page 95 =

7  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Paragraph Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<PL  This is the first paragraph in the example about the P tag<

There really isn't much to say here<  </PL

<P ALIGN="center"L  This is the second paragraph. Again, more o¨

the same. This time the paragraph is aligned in the center. Thi?

might not be such a good idea as it makes the text hard tB

read<  </PL

<P ALIGN="right"L  Here the paragraph is aligned to the right<

Right-aligned text is also troublesome to read. The rest of th4

text of this paragraph is of little importance<  </PL

<P ALIGN="justify"L  Under HTMLY.0-compliant browsers, you ar4

able to justify text. As you may notice, the way browsers tend tB

justify text is sometimes imprecise. Furthermore, not all browser?

support this attribute value<  </PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Because thk  <P  element generally causes a blank line, some HTML author—

attempt to insert blank lines into a document by using multiplk  <P  elements. Thi—

rarely results in the desired outcome. The browser collapses empt_  <P  elements,

because they represent logical text units, not physical formattingì

Many WYSIWYG HTML editors and some page authors try to get around th—

collapsing paragraph problem by using a nonbreaking space character within ‘

paragraph, to keep the element from collapsing, as shown her—  <PA  &nbsp;  </PA  . Thix

approach isn’t recommended, because it doesn’t reduce markup used and it furthe(

obscures the meaning of the document.

To insert returns or blank lines in a document, thk  <BR  element must be used. Thk

<BR  element is a texâlevel element that inserts a single carriage return or break intf

a document. It contains no content and has no end tag. The one attribute commonl_

used wit—  <BR  i—  CLEA  . This attribute allow—  <BR  to affect how text flows aroun™

 = Page 96 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  7

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Figurs 3-98  Rendering of the paragraph examplP

images or embedded objects. The use o“  <BR  in this fashion is discussed in Chapter 5ì

Because of its relationship with thk  <P  element, the basic use o“  <BR  must bk

presented here. The following code fragment shows hou  <BR  might be used bot—

within and outside paragraphs. An example screen rendering is shown in Figure 3-10ì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Break Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<PL  This is the first paragraph<  <BRL

Not much to say here<

</PL

 = Page 97 =

7‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<BR><BR><BRL

<PL  This is the second paragraph. Notice all the extra space betweeY

these paragraphs. That's from the BR tags<  </PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Figurs 3-108  Rendering oS  <BR>  examplP

 = Page 98 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  7

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

The following code fragment shows thaš  <P  an™  <BR  are not equivalent, despitk

their physical rendering similarities (screen renderings appear in Figure 3-11):

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Break Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<PL  This is the first paragraph<  <BRL

Not much to say here, either<

</PL

<P><P><PL

<PL  This is the second paragraph. Notice that the three P tags ar4

treated as empty paragraphs and ignored<  </PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Users looking for blank lines have to insert multipl—  <BRA  elements into thei(

document. A singl—  <BRA  element merely goes to the next line rather than insertinv

a blank line.

<CENTER> as a Block Elemen

In the original HTML 2–based browsers, centering text was impossible. One of thk

major additions introduced by Netscape was thk  <CENTER  element. HTML 3.2

adopted this element because of its widespread use. To center text or embedded object—

(such as images), simply enclose the content withi-  <CENTER  an™  </CENTER  . I-

this sense,  <CENTER  appears to be a texâformatting style element, but under thk

HTML 3.2 and transitional 4.0 specifications (and beyond),  <CENTER  is defined as a-

alias for a block-level structuring element. Under the HTML 4.0 DTD,  <CENTER  i—

 = Page 99 =

78  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 3-118  Screen rendering oS  <P>  examplP

simply an alias foK  <DIV ALIGN=“CENTE  and is treated exactly the same wayì

Thk  <CENTER  element is unlikely to go away, considering its simplicity an™

widespread use. But according to specifications, two preferred ways exist to centeK

content: thk  <DIV  element with ¾  cente(  alignment attribute, or thk  ALIGN  attributk

used in conjunction with some elementsì

Division“

Thk  <DIV  element is used to structure HTML documents into unique sections oK

divisions. Adding thk  ALIGN  attribute enables you to align a portion of the documenš

to the left, right, or center. By default, content within thk  <DIV  element is lefâalignedì

Divisions are also useful when used in conjunction with style sheets (see Chapter 10)ì

The following example shows the use o“  <CENTER  an™  <DIV  (Figure 3-12 show—

their screen rendering):

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

</HEADL
