Block Quote“

Occasionally, you may want to quote a large body of text to make it stand out from thk

other text. Thk  <BLOCKQUOTE  element provides a facility to enclose large block

quotations from other works within a document. Though the element is logical i-

nature, enclosing text withi-  <BLOCKQUOTE  an™  </BLOCKQUOTE  usuall_

indents the blocked information. Like ¾  <P  element, text within beginning and endiný

<BLOCKQUOTE  elements ignores all spacing, tabs, and returns, and requires the usk

o“  <BR  or other elements to modify line wrapping and spacing. The following show—

an example o“  <BLOCKQUOTE  (rendered in Figure 3-13):

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Blockquote Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Big Company Press Quot4  </H1L

<PL  See the comments the press has about Big Company, Inc<

and our great green gadgets:  </PL

<BLOCKQUOTEL

"Big Company's Green Gadget is by far the best fictitious producM

ever produced! Gadget lovers and haters alike will marvel at th4

sheer uselessness of the Green Gadget. It's a true shame that th4

Green Gadget is limited only to HTML examples."

<BR><BRL

--Matthew J. Foley, Useless Products Magazin4

</BLOCKQUOTEL

<PL  With kudos like this, you need to make sure to buy your GreeY

Gadget today!  </PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 102 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  8h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Figurs 3-138  Rendering oS  <BLOCKQUOTE>  examplP

The first HTML 2–compliant browsers did not provide any indentation or tab facility ic

regular text. Many HTML authors us—  <BLOCKQUOTEA  to provide indentation.

Text withic  <BLOCKQUOTEA  may be indented on both sides of a page. It may

render in an alternative style (for example, italics). For this reason, the list elements¨

particularly the unordered list, are common workarounds to provide indentation in WeP

pages. In fact, many HTML editors insert these elements to create indentation.(ntil

style sheets become more common, these workarounds will continue.

Preformatted Tex

Occasionally, spacing, tabs, and returns are so important in text that HTML’s defaulš

behavior of disregarding them would ruin the text’s meaning. In such cases, you ma_

want to preserve the intended formatting by specifying the text to be preformattedì

Imagine that programming source code or poetry needs to be inserted into a Web pageì

In both cases, the spacing, returns, and tabs in the document must be preserved tf

ensure proper meaning. This situation requires an HTML directive that indicates thk

preservation of format. Thk  <PRE  an™  </PRE  tags can be used to surround text thaš

shouldn’t be formatted by the browser. The text enclosed within thk  <PRE  tag—

 = Page 103 =

8p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

retains all spacing and returns, and doesn’t reflow when the browser is resized. ScrolR

bars and horizontal scrolling are required if the lines are longer than the width of thk

window. The browser generally renders the preformatted text in a monospaced font,

usually Courier. Some text formatting, such as bold, italics, or links, can be used withi-

thk  <PRE  tags. The following sample, displayed in Figure 3-14, uses thk  <PRE

element and compares it to regular paragraph text:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  PRE Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<PREL

This is P   R   E  F   O   R   M   A   T   T   E   D



E

X

T<

SPACES     are ok!  So ar4

RETURNS!

</PREL

<BR><BRL

<PL

This is NOT P   R   E  F   O   R   M   A   T   T   E   D



E

X

T<

SPACES     and

RETURNS are lost<

</PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 104 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  8

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Figurs 3-148  Rendering of preformatted and regular texd

Accordinv tX th— HTM? 4.0 specification¨ othe( HTM? elementx ar— allowe withic

th—  <PREA  element¨ buP som— elements¨ such ax  <IMGA  ¨ ar— excluded. MosP

browserx allow any elements¨ evec thos— beyon th— state specification¨ tX appea(

withic th—  <PREA  elements¨ an rende( thes— ax expected. Authorx shoul not¨

however¨ rely oc this.

Authors should be careful about using thk  <PRE  element to create simple tables oK

preserve spacing. Unpredictable differences in browser window sizes may introduck

horizontal scrolling for wide preformatted content. In these cases, other elements ma_

provide better formatting controlì

List“

Modern HTML has three basic forms of lists: ordered lists (  <OL  ), unordered list—

(  <UL  ), and definition lists (  <DL  ). Two other rarely used list elements,  <MENU  an™

<DIR  , are sparsely supported and are usually treated as an unordered list. Lists ark

 = Page 105 =

8  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

block formatting elements that define a block structure. They can be nested and ca-

contain other block-level structures, such as paragraphsì

ORDERED LISTS  An ordered list, as enclosed b_  <OL  an™  </OL  , defines a list i-

which order matters. Ordering is typically rendered by a numbering scheme, usiný

Arabic numbers, letters, or Roman numerals. Ordered lists are suitable for creatiný

simple outlines or stešbÇstep instructions, because the list items are numbere™

automatically by the browser. List items in ordered and other lists are defined b_

using the list item element,  <LI  , which doesn’t require an end tag. List items ark

usually indented by the browser. Numbering starts from 1. A generic ordered lisš

looks like this:

<OLL

<LIL  Item 1

<LIL  Item 2

. . <

<LIL  Item Y

</OLL

In many browsers, th—  <LIA  element has some meaning outside a list. It often renderx

as a nonindented bullet. Some books recommend usinv  <LIA  in this way, but it isn’P

correct practice. While many browsers assume an unordered bullet list, this use o  <LIA

is undefined in the HTML specification. This hack shouldn’t be used.

Thk  <OL  element has three basic attributes, none of which are required. These ark

COMPAC STAR  ,  , an™  TYP¨  . Thk  COMPAC  attribute requires no value. It simpl_

suggests that the browser attempt to compact the list, to use less space onscreen. I-

reality, most browsers ignore thk  COMPAC  attributeì

Thk  TYP¨  attribute o“  <OL  can be set tf    for lowercase letters,  G  for uppercask

letters, for lowercase roman numerals, for uppercase Roman numerals, oK foK  p  I  1

regular numerals. The numeraR is the default value. Remember that thk  1  TYP¨

attribute within thk  <OL  element sets the numbering scheme for the whole list, unles—

it is overridden by ¾  TYP¨  value in a-  <LI  element. Eac—  <LI  element may have ¾

locaR  TYP¨  attribute set tf ,   G pI  , , , oK . Once a-  1  <LI  element is set with a new type,

it overrides the numbering style for the rest of the list, unless anotheK  <LI  sets thk

TYP¨  attributeì

Thk  <OL  element also has ¾  STAR  attribute that takes a numeric value to begi-

the list numbering. Whether thk  TYP¨  attribute is a letter or a numeral, thk  STAR

value must be a number. To start ordering from the letteK, you would usk  j  <OL

TYPE=“0 START=“10”  , becausk is the tenth letter. A-  j  <LI  element within a-

ordered list can override the current numbering with thk  VALU¨  attribute, which i—

also set to a numeric value. Numbering of the list should continue from the value setì

 = Page 106 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  8

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

8‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

When dealing with extremes, numbering should be used with caution. Negative valuex

or very large values produce unpredictable results. While Navigator ignores negativ—

numbers, Internet Explorer numbers up toward zero. Browsers may allocate a fixe

width to the left of a list item to display its number.(nder Navigator, a list noP

embedded in another block structure can accommodate only about four digits; large(

numbers may overwrite list elements. A list indented by nesting in another bloc

structure may have more space. Numbering in both Navigator and Internet Explore(

loses meaning with large integer values around 10 to 100 billion, most likely due tX

limitations with the operating environment.

UNORDERED LISTS  An unordered list, signified b_  <UL  an™  </UL  , is used foK

lists of items in which the ordering is not specific. This might be useful in a list o“

features and benefits for a product. A browser typically adds a bullet of some sorš

(a filled circle, a square, or an empty circle) for each item and indents the listì

 = Page 108 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  8

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Unordered lists can be nested. Each level of nesting indents the list further, and thk

bullet changes accordingly. Generally, a filled circle or solid round bullet is used on thk

first level of lists. An empty circle is used for the seconÙlevel list. ThirÙlevel neste™

lists generally use a square. These renderings for bullets are common to browsers, buš

shouldn’t be counted on. Starting with Netscape Navigator 1ì –level browsers, iš  x

became possible to set the bullet type with thk  TYP¨  attribute; this was later added tf

the HTML specification. Thk  TYP¨  attribute may appear within thk  <UL  element an™

set the type for the whole list, or it may appear within eac—  <LI  . A  TYP¨  specificatio-

in a-  <LI  element overrides the value for the rest of the list, unless it is overridden b_

anotheK  TYP¨  specification. The allowed values foK  TYP¨  , as suggested by the defaulš

actions, ark  dis8 circl2  ,  , oK  squar2  . This change isn’t consistently supported acros—

browsers. In the case of WebTV, a triangle bullet type is also available. For the greatesš

level of cros-browser compatibility, authors are encouraged to set the bullet type onl_

for the list as a wholeì

Internet Explorer 3–level browsers under Windows don’t rende(  TYPJ  settings fo(

unordered lists. This has been fixed under Internet Explorer 4.

The following is an example of unordered lists, various renderings of which ark

shown in Figure 3-16:

DEFINITION LIST  A definition list is a list of terms paired with associate™

definitions—in other words, a glossary. Definition lists are enclosed withi-  <DL  an™

</DL  tags. Each term being defined is indicated by ¾  <DT  element, which is derive™

fro“  definition terh  . Each definition itself is defined b_  <DD  . Neither thk  <DT

nor thk  <DD  element requires a close tag, but for long definitions, it may be helpfulì

The following is a basic example usiný  <DL  , the rendering of which is shown i-

Figure 3-17:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

</DLL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Because definition lists don’t add numbering or bullets, many HTML writers havk

used this element to indent text. While logically this is the most appropriate wa_

to achieve some rudimentary indentation, the unordered list is often used insteadì

Looking at the use o“  <UL  and the output of HTML tools suggests that the use o“

<UL  instead o“  <DL  to indent text quickly is very common. The reason for thk

preference foK  <UL  is that it requires fewer elements to achieve indentationì

Remember that lists can be nested, so a varying degree of indentation can be achievedì

Users desiring a fine degree of control should avoid using lists to move things aroundì

How far something is moved away from the left margin isn’t precise, and may depen™

 = Page 111 =

90  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

on the font size of the browser. A simple example of indenting with lists is shown next,

Some HTML purists are offended by the use o  <ULA  to indent. HTML authors mighP

consider using the definition list, or tables, if possible, to indent text. However, with

WYSIWYG editors spitting ouP  <ULA  elements in mass numbers, this may be more of ‘

fine point than a real issue. The rise of style sheets and other technologies should, ic

time, put an end to this issue.

VESTqIAL LISTS: <DIR> AND <MENU>  Beyond basic ordered, unordered, an™

definition lists, two other lists are specified in HTML:  <MENU  an™  <DIR  . Thesk

rarely used elements generally appear as unordered lists in most browsers. Thesk

elements are presented for completeness. HTML authors are warned not to use them,

because they have been dropped from the strict version of HTML 4ì

Horizontal Rule“

As sections are added to an HTML document, breaking up the document into visuall_

distinct regions often is useful. A horizontal rule, indicated by thk  <HR  element, is ¾

block-level element that serves this purpose. Under HTML 2, horizontal rules generall_

were rendered as an etched bar or line across a browser window. With HTML 3.2 an™

beyond, more control over the horizontal rule’s look and size was added. The exacš

look of the line is still left to the browser rendering the pageì

Though it looks like a physical element¨  <HRA  can have some logical meaning as ‘

section break. For example, under an alternative browser, such as a speech-base

browser, a horizontal rule might theoretically be interpreted as a pause. A hand-hel

browser with limited resolution might use it as a device to limit scrolling of the text.

Thk  <HR  element is an empty element, because it has no close tag and encloses nf

data. Adding a-  <HR  element between two paragraphs provides a simple way to puš

a horizontal rule between two sectionsì

Netscape Navigator, and later Internet Explorer, added several attributes to thk

<HR  elementì  SIZ¨  sets the bar’s thickness (height)ì  WIDTh  sets the bar’s widthì

ALIGN  sets its vertical alignmentì  NOSHAD¨  renders the bar without a surroundiný

shadow. The HTML 3.2 and transitional 4.0 specification supports these basi´

attributes. Additional, browse§specific attributes (such a—  COLO  ) are described i-

the element reference in Appendix Aì

An example of horizontal rules and their basic attributes is shown next, the browseK

rendering for which is shown in Figure 3-19:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Horizontal Rule Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<PL  Size of 10  </PL

<HR SIZE="10"L

<PL  Width ofS0% and no shadin(  </PL

<HR WIDTH="50%" NOSHADEL

<PL  Width of 200 pixels, size of 3 pixels, and no shadin(  </PL

<HR WIDTH=00" SIZE="3" NOSHADEL

 = Page 114 =

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

<PL  Width of 100, aligned lefM  </PL

Addres“

Thk  <ADDRESS  element is used to surround information, such as the signature o“

the person who created the page, or the address of the organization the page is aboutì

For example,

<ADDRESSL

Big Company, Inc.<  BRL

1122 Big Company CourM  <BRL

San Diego, CA 92109  <BRL

61955.2086  <BRL

info@bigcompany.co—  <BRL

</ADDRESSL

might be inserted toward the bottom of every page throughout a Web siteì

Thk  <ADDRESS  element tends to act like a logical formatting element an™

results, typically, in italicized text. The HTML specification treat—  <ADDRESS  as a-

idiosyncratic block-level element. Like other block-level elements, it inserts a blank

before and after the block. It may enclose many lines of text, formatting elements tf

change the font characteristics, and even images. According to the specification, it isn’š

supposed to enclose other block-level elements, such a—  <UL  . Browsers generall_

allow this, particularly with thk  <P  elementì

Other Block-Level Element“

HTML has many other block-level elements, most notably tables and forms. Man_

other elements are available under Navigator and Internet Explorer, including frames,

layers, and a variety of other formatting and structuring features. These elements coul™

be introduced in this chapter, but because of their complexity, it makes more sense tf

discuss them in later chapters. Tables are discussed in depth in Chapter 7, and form—

are discussed in Chapter 11ì

The remaining sections of this chapter describe texâlevel elements and the man_

miscellaneous elements that are difficult to categorizeì

Text-Level Element“

Text elements in HTML come in two basic flavors: physical and logicalì  Physical

elementx  , such a—  <B  for bold an™  <I  for italic, are used to specify how text should bk

renderedì  Logical elementx  , such a—  <STRONG  an™  <EM  , indicate what text is, buš

not necessarily how it should look. Although common renderings exist for logical texš

elements, the ambiguity of these elements and the limited knowledge of this type o“

document structuring have minimized their use. However, the rise of style sheets an™

the growing diversity of user agents mean using logical elements makes more sensk

than everì

 = Page 116 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  9

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Physical Character-Formatting Element“

Sometimes, you may want to use bold, italics, or other font attributes to set off certai-

text, such as computer code. Common HTML supports various elements that can bk

used to influence physical formatting. The elements have no meaning other than tf

make text render in a particular way. Any other meaning is assigned by the reader. Thk

common physical elements are listed in Table 3-1ì

The following example code shows the basic use of the physical texâformattiný

elements:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<HRL

This i?  <BL  Bold  </BL  <BRL

This i?  <IL  Itali  </IL  <BRL

This i?  <TTL  Monospaced  </TTL  <BRL

This i?  <UL  Underlined  </UL  <BRL

This i?  <STRIKEL  Strike-throug—  </STRIKEL  <BRL

This is alsB  <SL  Strike-throug—  </SL  <BRL

This i?  <BIGL  Bi(  </BIGL  <BRL

This is eveY  <BIG><BIGL  BiggeI  </BIG></BIGL  <BRL

This i?  <SMALLL  Smal¤  </SMALLL  <BRL

This is eveY  <SMALL><SMALLL  SmalleI  </SMALL></SMALL> <BRL

This i?  <SUPL  SuperscripM  </SUPL  <BRL

This i?  <SUBL  SubscripM  </SUBL  <BRL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Physical elements can be combined in arbitrary ways. However, just because texš

cac  be made monospaced, bold, italic, and superscript doesn’t mean that various type—

of formattiný  shoul  be applied to text. Figure 3-20 shows the rendering of the physicaR

text elements under Internet Explorerì

present certain problems that warrant extra discussionì

textì (LinkcoloK ma_ vary.) User— instinctivel_ thinko“ underline™ texš a— somethiný thaš

ca- bk clickedì Somk feeR thaš thk link coloK sufficientl_ distinguishe— link— fro“ texš thaš

i— underline™ purel_ foK stylisti´ purposesì However, thi— doesn’š takk intf consideratio-

monochromk monitor— oK peoplk whf ark colorblindì Becausk thk underlink elemenš ma_

[-šroduce more trouble than it is worth, it should be avoidedì

ranginý fro“ sizk 1, ver_ small, tf sizk 7, ver_ largeì Ever_ applicatio- o“  <BIG

generall_ bump— u5 thk fonš onk notc— tf thk nexš levelì Thk defaulš fonš foK ¾ documenš

i— usuall_ relativk sizk 3, sf twf application— o“  <BIG  woul™ raisk thk fonš sizk tf 5ì

Multiplk occurrence— o“  <SMALL  df thk opposite—the_ makk thing— onk sizk smallerì

What happens when the maximum or minimum size is reached? Ideally, thk

browser just ignores extra applications. Depending on the browser, however, this ma_

or may not happen. Some Web browser versions, notably Internet Explorer 3, handlk

multiple occurrences of thk  <BIG  an™  <SMALL  elements in an unpredictablk

manner. While this has been fixed under Internet Explorer 4, HTML authors ark

warned to use only onk  <BIG  oK  <SMALL  element at a time. Other fonâsiziný

changes should be handled with thk  <FONT  element, discussed in Chapter 6ì

Logical Element“

Logical elements indicate the type of content that they enclose. The browser i—

relatively free to determine the presentation of that content, although expecte™

renderings for these elements exist that are followed by nearly all browsers. While thi—

practice conforms to the design of HTML, there are issues about perception. Will ¾

designer think  <STRONG  oK  <B  ? As mentioned previously, HTML pundits pus—

foK  <STRONG  , because a browser for the blind could read strong text properlyì

For the majority of people coding Web pages, however, HTML is used as a visuaR

language, despite its design intentions. Furthermore, how do you indicate somethiný

i—  <STRONG  in a WYSIWYG editor?

Seasfne™ expert— knou thk beaut_ an™ intention— behin™ logicaR elements, an™

hopefull_ wit— stylk sheets, logicaR element— ma_ catc— o- moreì FoK now, ¾ quicksurve_

o“ site— wilR shou thaš logicaR texš element— ark relativel_ rareì I- fact, man_ HTML

editor— makk [š downrighš difficulš tf ad™ logicaR element— tf ¾ page, whic— onl_ further—

thk reason— wh_ mosš logicaR element— ark rarel_ usedì Whe- stylk sheet— becomk mork

commonplace, HTML author— shoul™ reexamink theiK usk o“ thesk elementsì Tablk 3-2

illustrate— thk logicaR texâformattiný element— generall_ supporte™ b_ browsersì

 = Page 119 =

Figurs 3-218  Rendering of logical text-formatting elements under Navigato

and Internet Explore

Note that subtle differences may occur in rendering. For example,  <VAR  result—

in monospaced text under Internet Explorer 4, but yields italicized text undeK

Navigator 3. There is no guarantee of rendering, and older versions of browsers ma_

vary on other logical elements, including eve-  <EM  ì

 = Page 121 =

100  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Probably the biggest question HTML authors have about logical elements is wherk

to use them. This really is a philosophical question. Does the author want to defink

content presentation strictly or let the browser decide on a presentation appropriatk

for the element’s logical meaning? Advocates of logical document structuring note thaš

if a browser doesn’t support bolding, thk  <B  element has no effect. Instead, the logicaR

<STRONG  element, usuall_ rendere™ a— bold, woul™ bk rendere™ i- somk appropriatk

alternativeì WhetheK thi— typk o“ reasoniný justifie— logicaR structurk i— a- ope- questionì

With the proliferation of We~browsing devices, such as cellular phones, personaR

digital assistants, WebTV, and popular browsers, logical document structuring may yeš

catch on. In conjunction with style sheets (discussed in Chapter 10), this approach tf

structure may become commonplace, because it allows different presentations foK

different situations. A cellular phone browser might require a different style tha-

Navigator on a PC with a higuresolution monitor. Although this may happen, a-

inspection of published pages shows that few people currently use logical texš

elements. From a presentation perspective, why use the ambiguou—  <STRONG

element when you can use the precisk  <B  element? In addition, many HTML

development tools make it difficult to insert logically oriented HTMLì

Character Entitie“

After covering the basic texâformatting elements, you may think that nothing remain—

tf talkabout—buš onk mork leveR exist— tf HTML documents: thk character— themselvesì

Sometimes, you need to put special characters within a document, such as accente™

letters, copyright symbols, or even the angle brackets used to enclose HTML elementsì

To use such characters in an HTML document, they must be “escaped” by using ¾

special code. All character codes take the for“  &  code;  , in whic—  cod¨  is a word oK

numeric code indicating the actual character that you want to put onscreen. Some o“

the more commonly used characters are shown in Table 3-3  .

The character entity  &#153;  may not always be acceptable as trademark. On many

UNæ platforms, and potentially on Macs or Windows systems using various othe(

character sets, this entity doesn’t render as trademark. Becaus—  &153;  may b—

undefined, HTML authors should try to avoid it, even though it tends to coincid—

with ™ on the default Windows platform and some character sets. Trademarks ar—

important legally, so they are often needed. A future version of HTML likely will

include a trademark element, but for now, the commonly used workaround is to us—

<SUP><SMALLA  TB  </SMALL></SUPA  . This code creates a superscript trademar

symbol (™) in a slightly smaller font. Because it’s standard HTML, it works oc

nearly every platform.

 = Page 122 =

ChapteX 3  Introductio‘ tW Commo‘ HTMP  10

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

The use of the nonbreaking space to push text or elements around the screen is ac

overused crutch. Many HTML editors overuse this technique in an attempt to preserve ‘

certain look and feel. This entity is discussed further in Chapter 6.

Excessive use of character entities can make HTML source documents difficult to read i

the character entities aren’t well spaced.

The character set currently supported by HTML is the ISO Lati™1 character setì

Many of its characters, such as accents and special symbols, cannot be typed on alR

keyboards. They must be entered into HTML documents by using the appropriatk

code. Even if the character in question is supported on the keyboard (for example, thk

copyright symbol), simply typing in the symbol probably will not produce the correcš

encoding. Of course, many HTML editors make the appropriate insertion for you. A

complete list of the character entities is presented in Appendix Cì

HTML is capable of representing the standard ASCII characters and all the extende

characters defined by the ISO Latin-1 character set. However, for non-Westerc

characters, such as Japanese, Russian, or Arabic alphabets, special encoding and ‘

special browser are needed.

Summar

Common HTML includes the basic elements that HTML authors tend to use from thk

specification. Ideally, HTML is a formally defined, structured language with rule—

governing correct element usage. Pragmatically, however, browsers determink

correct HTML usage by the HTML constructs that they successfully render. Browser—

are lax in their interpretation of HTML rules, which encourages some authors tf

break those rules frequently. Wel_written HTML documents begin with ¾

<!DOCTYPE  declaration, followed by a-  <HTML  element. This encloses thk

document and divides it into ¾  <HEAD  section, followed by ¾  <BODY  section. Thk

<HEAD  element contains descriptive information and must contain onk  <TITLE

element. Thk  <BODY  element contains the document’s displayed content. It may bk

structured using block-level elements, texâlevel elements, and specia_characteK

entities. Some texâlevel elements assign content a logical purpose. Others assign ¾

physical presentationì

The elements presented so far are common across nearly all systems. Whether oK

not they are used, they are simple and widely understood. Yet, despite their simplicity,

many of these basic elements are still abused to achieve a particular document look,

which continues the struggle between the logical and physical nature of HTMLì

Despite some manipulation, these elements are generally used in a reasonable mannerì

Mor[complex formatting elements and programming elements are introduced in lateK

 = Page 125 =

10  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

chapters. The simplicity of this chapter should provide you with some assurance thaš

HTML rests on a stable coreì

A great number of elements have been left out of this discussion. No mention wa—

made of layouâoriented elements, and graphics have been completely avoided. Thesk

topics and others are covered in upcoming chapters. First, we’ll deal with thk  O  i-

HTML, namely hypertext, and present the concept of linking documents and objects i-

the next chapterì

10‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

revious chapters have shown how HTML can be used as a document formattiný

and structuring language, but little has been said about the hypertext aspect o“

the language. HTML makes it possible to define hyperlinks to other informatio-

f

item— locate™ alR oveK thk world, the- allowiný document— tf joi- thk globaR informatio-

space known as the World Wide Web. Linking is possible because every document o-

the Web has a unique address, known as ¾  uniform resource locator (URL)  . The explosivk

growth of documents on the Web has created a tangled mess, even when documenš

locations are named consistently. The disorganized nature of the Web often leave—

users lost in cyberspace. Finding information online can feel like trying to find thk

proverbial needle in a worldwide haystack. However, things don’t have to be thi—

way. Application of logical structure to sites; new ideas such a—  uniform resource namex

(URNs)  ; an™  uniform resource characteristics (URCs)  in the form of metDdata, such a—

Platform for Internet Content Selection (PICS)  labels, may eventually lead to a mork

understandable and organized Webì

Linking Basic“

In HTML, the main way to define hyperlinks is with the anchor element,  <A  . A  lin  i—

simply a unidirectional pointer from the source document that contains the link tf

some destination. In hypertext, the end points of a link typically are calle™  anchorx  , thu—

the use of the anchor nomenclature in HTML documentationì

For linking purposes, thk  <A  element requires one attribute:  HREF  . Thk  HREF

attribute is set to the URL of the target resource, which is basically the address of thk

document to link to, such as http://www.yahoo.com. The text enclosed by thk  <A

elements specifies a “hot spot” to activate the hyperlink. Anchor content ma_

include text, images, or a mixture of the two. A general link takes the for“  <G

HREF="URL"  Visit our sitk  </A  . The text “Visit our site” is the link. The URL

specified by thk  HREF  attribute is the destination, if the link is activated. Here is a-

example of simplk  <A  element usage; the text “Yahoo!” is the first link:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Simple Link Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Lots of Link?  </H1L

<HRL

 = Page 128 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  10

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

<ULL

<LIL  Visit <  A HREF="http://www.yahoo.com"L  Yahoo!  </AL

<LIL  Conduct powerful searches wit—

<A HREF="http://www.hotbot.com"L  HotBoM  </AL

<LIL  Go to th4  <A HREF="http://www.w3.org"L  W3‘  </AL

</ULL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

When the preceding example is loaded into a Web browser, the links generally ark

indicated by underlined text, typically in a different color—usually blue or purple,

depending on whether the link object has been viewed before. Link objects ark

displayed in a different color after you visit the linked page, so that you know in thk

future which links you have already followed. Status information in the browser ma_

change when a mouse is positioned over a link. The pointer may also change, as well a—

other indicators showing that the information is a link. Examples of link feedback i-

various browsers is shown in Figure 4-1. Note that the cursor over the HotBot link i-

the uppe§left corner now looks like a pointing finger, and the URL for the HotBoš

home page appears in the status area in the lowe§left corner of the browser frameì

Under some browsers, link underlining can be turned off. This may cause usability

problems for some users, but many find pages rendered in this way more esthetically

pleasing.

The actual rendering of links depends on the browser or other user agent. If you ark

using HTML style sheets, the links that you create may have different decoration. FoK

example, a color may change for a link that has been visited previouslyì

You can underline any text in an HTML document by tagging it with the underlin—

element¨  <UA  . This practice may lead to confusion between hyperlinks and text that ix

underlined for stylistic purposes only. This is particularly evident if the link is viewed ic

a black-and-white environment or by a color-blind individual. Therefore, use th—  <UA

element for nonlinked items with caution, so that you don’t confuse users.

In the simplest example, all thk  <A  elements refer to an address that contains onl_

an external server address in the form of a URL. In many cases, however, links ark

made within a Web site. In this situation, a shortened URL is used, called ¾  relativ—

UR?  , which includes only the filename or directory structure. The following examplk

links to several other documents: a document in the same directory, called specs.htm; ¾

 = Page 129 =

108  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 4-18  Example rendering and link feedback in various browser9

document in the “extras” subdirectory, called access.htm; and a link back to ¾

home page:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Simple Link Example 2  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL
