These basic examples show that the use of links, at least within text, is simpleì

Specifying the destination URL may not be so obvious. HTML authors often ark

tempted to use only very simple relative URLs, such as a filename, or fully qualifie™

URLs, but without a sense of what URLs really can provide. Later in this chapter, thk

discussion returns to the HTML syntax for forming links. First, take a closer look aš

URLs, because thoroughly understanding URLs is quite important for forming linksì

What Are URLs?

A URL is a uniform way to refer to objects and services on the Internet. Even novick

users should be familiar with typing a URL, such as http://www.yahoo.com/, in ¾

browser dialog box to get to a Web site. Internet users use URLs to invoke otheK

Internet services, such as transferring files via FTP or sending [mail. HTML author—

use URLs in their documents to define hyperlinks to other Web documents. Despite it—

potentially confusing collection of slashes and colons, the URL syntax is designed tf

provide a clear, simple notation that people can easily understand. The designer—

intended URLs to be useful as information for books, business cards, and even thk

backs of paper napkins, not just computers, in that they are easily transmittable i-

forms outside the Internet. Some people might counter that saying http:// or www alR

the time is troublesome. The following concepts will help you to understand the majoK

components of a URL addressì

Some people call(RLx  universaR  resource locators. Except for a historical reference tX

universal resource locator—  in documentation from a few years ago, the currenP

standard wording ix  unifor“  resource locator.

 = Page 131 =

110  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Basic Concept“

To find any arbitrary object on the Internet, you need to find out the followiný

information:

1ì First, you need to locate and access the machine on the Internet (or intranet) o-

which the object resides. Locating the site might be a matter of specifying it—

domain name or IP address, while accessing the machine might be a matter o“

providing a username and passwordì

2ì After you access the machine, you need to determine the name of the desire™

file, where the file is located, and what protocol will be used to retrieve thk

information or access the objectì

The URL describes where something is and how it will be retrieved. Thk  how  i—

specified by the protocol (for example, HTTP). Thk  wher—  is specified by the machink

name, the directory name, and the filename. Slashes and other characters are used tf

separate the parts of the address into machin[readable pieces. The basic structure o“

the URL is shown here:

protocol  ://  site addresx directory filenam—  /  /

The next several sections look at the individual pieces of a URL in significant detailì

Site Addres“

Every Web document exists on some server computer somewhere on the globaR

Internet or within a private intranet. The first step in finding a document is to identif_

its server. The most convenient way to do this on a TCP/IKbased network is with ¾

symbolic name, called ¾  domain nam—  . On the Internet at large, a fully qualified domai-

name (FQDN) typically consists of a machine name, followed by a domain name. FoK

example, www.microsoft.com specifies a machine name™  www  in the microsoft.co“

domain. On an intranet, however, things may be a little different, because you ca-

avoid using a domain name. For example, a machine name of h§server may be all thaš

you need to access the human resources server within your company’s intranetì

A machine name indicates the local, intra-organizational name for the actual server. A

machine name can be just about any name, because machine naming has no mandate

rules. Conventions exist, however, for identifying servers that provide common InterneP

resources. Servers for Web documents usually begin with the www prefix. However¨

many local machines have names similar to the user’s own name (for example, jsmith)¨

his or her favorite cartoon character (for example, homer), or even an esoteric machin—

name (for example, dell-p6-200-a12). Machine naming conventions are importanP

because they allow users to form(RLs without explicitly spelling them out. A user whX

understands domain names and machine naming conventions should be able to guesx

that Toyota’s Web server is http://www.toyota.com/.

 = Page 132 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  11h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

The other part of most site addresses, the domain name, is fairly regular. Within thk

United States, a domain name consists of the actual domain or organization name,

followed by a period, and then a domain type. An example is sun.com. The domai-

itself is sun, which represents Sun Microsystems. The sun domain exists within thk

commercial zone, because of Sun’s corporate status, so it ends with the domain type o“

coh  . In the U.S., most domain identifiers currently use a thre[character code thaš

indicates the type of organization that owns the server. The most common codes ark

coh  for commercial,  gov  for government,  orv  for nonprofit organization,  ed¤  foK

educational institution,  neP  for network, an™  mil  for military. Recently, some debate ha—

occurred regarding the extent of the domain name space. Soon, a variety of neu

domain endings may be added, such a—  firh weP  ,  , an™  noh  . Table 4-1 sets forth a basi´

listing of U.S. domain typesì

Domain space beyond the United States is somewhat more complicated. An FQDN,

including a country code, is generally written as follows:

machine nam—domain nam—domain typ—country cod—  ì  ì  ì

Zone identifiers outside the U.S. use a twkcharacter code to indicate the countr_

hosting the server. These includk  c‘  for Canada,  mx  for Mexico, an™ for Japan. Withi-  jp

each country, the local naming authorities may create domain types at their ow-

discretion, but these domain types can’t correspond to American extensions. FoK

Domain Typs  Domain Descriptio  Exampls

co“  Commercial entities and individual—  apple.co“

neš  Networks and network provider—  cerf.neš

orý  Nonprofit and other organization—  greenpeace.orý

ed¾  Fou§year colleges and universitie—  ucla.ed¾

go~  United States federal governmenš  whitehouse.go~

agencie—

miR  United States federal governmenš  nosc.miR

military entitie—

u—  Used for a variety of organizations an™co.sa™diego.ca.u—

individuals, including K through 12

education, libraries, and city an™

county government—

Tabls 4-18  Domain Types in the United State9

 = Page 133 =

11p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

example, www.sony.co.jp specifies a Web server for Sony in thk  cX  zone of Japan. I-

this case,  cX  , rather tha-  coh  , indicates a commercial venture. In the United Kingdom,

the educational domain space has a different name,  a  . Oxford University’s Web serveK

is www.ox.ac.uk, whereby ac indicate—  academic¨  compared to the U.Sì  ed¤  extension foK

educatioc  . Despite a flattening of geographical name use for large, multinationaR

companies (such as Sony), regional naming differences are very much alive. Web pagk

authors linking to no™native domains are encouraged to understand the naminý

conventions of those environments. One special tošlevel domain,  inP  , is reserved foK

organizations established by international treaties between governments, such as thk

European Union (eu.int). Tošlevel domains, such a—  coh neP  ,  , and any upcoming neu

domains, may not necessarily correspond to a particular geographic areaì

Symbolic names make it convenient for people to refer to Internet servers. A server’s real

address is itx Internet Protocol (IP) numeric address. Every accessible server on th—

Internet has a unique IP address by which it can be located using the TCP/IP protocol.

An IP address is a numeric string that consists of four numbers between 0 and 255¨

separated by periods (for example, 213.6.17.34). This number may then correspond to ‘

domain name, such as www.bigcompany.com. Note that a server’s symbolic name musP

be translated, o( resolved¨ into an IP address before it can be used to locate a server. Ac

Internet service known ax Domain Name Service (DNS) automatically performs thix

translation. You can use an IP address instead of a symbolic name to specify an InterneP

server, but doing so gives up mnemonic convenience. In some cases, using an IP addresx

may be necessary because, although every server has an IP address, not all servers hav—

symbolic names.

Investigating all aspects of the domain name structure is beyond the scope of thi—

book. However, it should be noted that domain name formats and the domain namk

lookup service are very critical to the operation of the Web. If the domain name serveK

is unavailable, it is impossible to access a Web server. To learn more about machink

and domain names, explore the following Web sites:

  http://rs.internic.net/r-internic.htmR

  http://www.iana.orý

  http://www.gtlÙmou.orý

Domaic namex ar— noP case-sensitive. Fo( example¨ yo¤ coul writ— www.BigCompany.coh

or www.BIGCOMPANY.com. A browser should handle both properly. Case is typically

changed for marketing or branding purposes. Directory values following the domaic

name may be case-sensitive, depending on the operating system that the Web server ix

running on. For example,(Næ systems are case-sensitive, while Windows machinex

ar— not. Troubl— cac aris— i casinv ix use randomly. Ax ‘ rul— o thumb¨ keep everythinv

in lowercase, or consistently use uppercase for just the first letters in directoriex

and filenames.

 = Page 134 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  11

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

AfteK yo¾ specif_ thk machine, eitheK b_ it— domai- namk oK it— If address, yo¾ ma_

nee™ tf specif_ thk particulaK director_ o- thk particulaK machine, a— describe™ nextì

Director

Servers may contain hundreds, if not thousands, of files. For practical use, files need tf

be organized into manageable units, analogous to the manila folders traditionally use™

to organize paper documents. This unit is known as ¾  file directory.  After you know o-

which server a document resides, the next step toward identifying its location is tf

specify the directory that contains the file. Just as one manila folder can contain otheK

folders, directories can contain other directories. Directories contain other directories i-

a nested, hierarchical structure that resembles the branches of a tree. The directory thaš

contains all others is known as thk  root directory  . Taken together, all the directories an™

files form a file tree, oK  file systeh  . A file is located in a file system by specifying it—

directory path  . This is the nested list of all directories that contain the file—from thk

most general, the root directory—to the most specific. Similar to the UNIX operatiný

system, directories hosted on Web servers are separated by forward slashes (/) ratheK

than backslashes (\), as in DOS. Figure 4-2 shows a sample file tree for a Web site,

where directories are organized within (or above and below) one another. For example,

the directory calle™  specia“  is within thk  product—  directory, which is within the rooš

directory, a— indicate™ b_ thk forwar™ slashì Thk fulR pat— shoul™ bk writte- a— /products/

special/ tf indicatk thaš  specia“  i— a- actuaR directory, noš ¾ filk i- thk  product—  directoryì

When linking to other files, you may need to refer to a directory above the currenš

directory, or to the current directory itself. In the scheme presented, ./ means thk

current directory, while ../ means one directory up in the hierarchy. A document i-

thk  specia“  directory with a link path of ../ will link up to thk  product—  directoryì

Figurs 4-28  Sample file treP

 = Page 135 =

11  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Directory names may follow conventions specific to an operating system, includinv

being case-sensitive. Authors are cautioned to look carefully at directory casing.

Furthermore, directories may follow popular usage conventions (for example, tmp), o(

they may be arbitrary.(sually, directory names reflect aspects of media types, subjecP

matter, or access privileges of their content. For example, a directory called “images”

might be the name of a directory containing images.

Filenams

After you specify the server and directory path for a document, the next step towar™

locating it is to specify its filename. This step typically has two parts: a filename,

followed by a standard file extension. Filenames can be any names that are applicablk

under the server’s operating system. Special characters such as spaces, colons, an™

slashes might play havoc if used in names of We~available files. A file name™

test:1.htm would present problems on a Macintosh system, whereas test/1.htm mighš

be legal on a Macintosh but problematic on a PC or UNIX machineì

A dot separates the filename and thk  extensioc  , which is a code, usually three letters,

that identifies the type of information contained in the file. For example, HTML sourck

files have an .htm oK .html extension. JPEG images have a .jpg extension. A file’—

extension is critically important for Web applications, because it usually is the onl_

indication of the information type that a file contains. A Web server reads a filk

extension and uses it to determine which headers, in the form of a MIME typk

(discussed in Chapter 16), to attach to a file when delivering it to a browser. If filk

extensions are omitted or misused, the file may be interpreted incorrectly. Whe-

browsers read files directly, they also look at file extensions to determine how to rendeK

the file. If the extension is missing or incorrect, a file generally will not be properl_

displayed in a Web browserì

While many operating systems support four or more letters for file extensions, using ‘

three-letter extension (.htm) versus a four-letter extension (.html) ensures thaP

cross-platform incompatibilities are minimized. Spaces, uppercasing, and special

characters should also be avoided, to provide the greatest flexibility. Authors and userx

should particularly be aware of case sensitivity in filenames and directory names.

Protocol

It may seem that nothing more is needed to locate a document than its server,

directory, and filename. However, one component is missing—the protocol. Thk

Internet supports a standard set of resources, each with its own associated protocol. A

protocol  is the structured discussion that computers follow to negotiate resourc[

specific services. For example, the protocol that makes the Web possible is thk

Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP). When you click a hyperlink in a Web document,

 = Page 136 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  11

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

your browser uses the HTTP protocol to contact a Web server and retrieve thk

appropriate documentì

Although HTTP stands fo( Hypertext Transfer Protocol, it doesn’t specify how a file ix

transported from a server to a browser, only how the discussion between the server an

browser will take place to get the file. The actual transport of files is usually up to ‘

lower-layer network protocol, such as the Transmission Control Protocol (TCP). On th—

Internet, the combination of TCP and IP makes raw communication possible. Although

a subtle point, many Web professionals are unaware of lower-level protocols below

application protocols, such as HTTP, which are part of(RLs.

Although less frequently used than HTTP and TCP/IP, several other protocols ark

important to HTML authors, because they can be invoked by hyperlinks. Here ark

some examples:

Protocol  Descriptio

Filk  Enables a hyperlink to access a file on the locaR

file syste“

File Transfer Protocol (FTP)  Enables a hyperlink to download files fro“

remote system—

GopheK  Enables a hyperlink to access a Gopher serveK

mailtf  Calls thk  Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP)  , thk

Internet mail protocol, and enables a hyperlink tf

send an addressed [mail messagk

Network News Transporš  Enables a hyperlink to access a USENE¾

Protocol (NNTP)  news articlk

new—  Enables a hyperlink to access a USENE¾

newsgrou5

telneš  Enables a hyperlink to open a telnet sessio-

on a remote hosš

These are the common protocols, but a variety of new protocols and URL forms ark

being debated all the time. Someday, such things as LDAP (Lightweight Director_

Access Protocol), IRC (Internet Relay Chat), phone, fax, and eve- TV might be used tf

reference how data should be accessed. More about the future of URLs and otheK

naming ideas is discussed toward the end of this chapterì

Beyond the protocol, server address, directory, and filename, URLs often include ¾

username and password, port number, and sometimes a fragment identifier. Somk

 = Page 137 =

11‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

URLs, such as mailto, might even contain a different form of information altogether,

such as an [mail address rather than a server or filenameì

User and Passwor

FTP and telnet are protocols foK  authenticated servicex  . Authenticated services ma_

assume access by authorized users, and the protocols may require a username an™

password as parameters. A username and password precede a server name, like this:

usernam—passwor server-addresx  :  @  . The password may be optional or unspecified in thk

URL, making the form simpl_  usernam— server-addresx  @  ì

HTML authors are warned not to include password information in(RLs, because th—

information will be readily viewable in a Web page or within the browser’s(RL box.

Por

Although the situation is rare, the communication port number used in a URL also ca-

be specified. Browsers speaking a particular protocol communicate with server—

through entry points, known a—  ports¨  which generally are identified by numeri´

addresses. Associated with each protocol is a default port number. For example, a-

HTTP request defaults to port number 80. A server administrator can configure ¾

server to handle protocol requests at ports other than the default numbers. Usually,

this occurs for experimental or secure applications. In these cases, the intended porš

must be explicitly addressed in a URL. To specify a port number, place it after thk

server address, separated by a colon: for example,  site-addresx  :8080. Web administrator—

are forewarned not to change port numbers arbitrarily, because it confuses users an™

may result in them having difficulty accessing a site, particularly if access comes fro“

behind a firewall. In short, users coming from sites with wel_defined security policie—

may not be set up to access sites running on nonstandard port numbersì

Some Web development systems may require users to log in on nonstandard ports. A

common example is an Administrator that needs to access a nonstandard port tX

configure a Web server using a Web browser.

Fragmen

After a user specifies a file, the user may want to go directly to a particular point in thk

file. Because you can set up named links under HTML, you can provide links directl_

to different points in a file. To jump to a particular named link, the URL must includk

the link name, preceded by a pound symbol ( ), which indicates that the value is ¾  #

fragment identifier. To specify a point called “contents” in a file called test.htm, yo¾

would use test.htm#contents. Elsewhere in the file, the fragment name would be seš

using a named anchor, such a—  <A NAME="contents"></A  . This will be discusse™

later in the chapterì

 = Page 138 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  11

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Encoding

When writing the components of a URL, take care that they are written using only thk

displayable characters in the US-ASCII character set. Even when using character—

within this basic keyboard character range, you will find certain unsafe characters, oK

reserved characters that may have special meaning within the context of a URL or thk

operating system on which the resource is found. If any unsafe, reserved, oK

nonprintable characters occur in a URL, they must be encoded in a special formì

Failure to encode these characters may lead to errorsì

The form of encoding consists of a percent sign and two hexadecimal digit—

corresponding to the value of the character in the ASCII character set. Within man_

intranet environments, filenames often include use§friendly names, such as “firsš

quarter earnings 1997.doc.” Such names contain unsafe characters. If this file were tf

live on a departmental Web server, it would have a URL with a file portion o“

first%20quarter%20earnings%201997.doc. Notice how the spaces have been mapped tf

%20  values—the hex value of the space character in ASCII. Other characters that wilR

be troublesome in URLs include the slash character ( ), which encodes a—    %2F  , thk

question mark, which maps tf  %3F  , and the percent itself, which encodes a—  %25  . Onl_

alphanumeric values and some special characters ($  ?  _ . + ! * ‘), including parentheses,

may be used in a URL. Other characters should be encoded. In general, speciaR

characters such as accents, spaces, and some punctuation marks have to be encodedì

HTML authors are encouraged to name files with encoding in mind, so that encodiný

can be avoided whenever possible. Table 4-2 shows the reserved and potentiall_

dangerous characters for URLsì

Characte5  Encoding Valus

Spack  %20

/  %2F

?  %3F

:  %3G

;  %3

&  %26

@  %40

=  %3¤

Tabls 4-28  Common Character EncodingXalue9

 = Page 139 =

118  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Characte5  Encoding Valus

#  %23

%  %25

>  %3¨

<  %3‚

{  %7

}  %7¤

[  %5

]  %5¤

"  %22

`  %27

‘  %60

^^  %5¨

~  %7¨

\  %5‚

|  %7‚

Tabls 4-28  Common Character EncodingXalue9  (continued)

Many of the characters in Table 4-2 don’t have to be encoded; but encoding a characte(

never causes problems, so when in doubt, encode it.

With this brief discussion of all the various components coming to a close, the nexš

section presents a formula for creating URLs, as well as some examplesì

Formula for a UR¤

All URLs share the same basic syntax: a protocol name, followed by a colon, followe™

by a protoco_specific resource description:

protocol_nam4 resource_descriptioY  :

Beyond this basic syntax, enough variation exists between protocol specifics foK

each to merit a separate discussionì

 = Page 140 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  119

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

HTTV

A minimal HTTP URL simply gives a server name. It provides no directory or filk

information. A minimal HTTP formula commonly occurs for corporate addresses use™

in advertising:

  Formul  http://  serveI  /

  Exampl2  http://www.bigcompany.com/

A minimal HTTP URL implicitly requests the home directory of a Web site. Eve-

when a trailing slash isn’t used, it is assumed and added either by the user agent or thk

Web server, making an address such as http://www.bigcompany.com becomk

http://www.bigcompany.com/. By default, requesting a directory often results in thk

server returning a default file from the directory, termed thk  index fil—  . Usually, index

files are named index.htm or default.htm (or index.html and default.html,

respectively), depending on the server software being used. This is only a convention;

Web administrators are free to name default index files whatever they likeì

Interestingly, many people put special importance on the minimal HTTP URL for“

when, like all other fil[retrieval URLs, this form simply specifies a particular director_

or default index file to return, although this isn’t always explicitly written outì

Some sites are now renaming their systems so that the use of www is optional. Fo(

example, http://pint.com/ is the same as http://www.pint.com. Although browsers oftec

provide similar shorthand functionality, users should be careful not to assume such

forms are valid. For example, in some browsers, typing bigcompany by itself may resolv—

to http://www.bigcompany.com. This is a browser usability improvement and can’t b—

used as a(RL in an HTML document. Because of misunderstandings with(RLs, sit—

managers are encouraged to add as many variable forms as possible, so that the sit—

works regardless of browser improvements or slight mistakes in linking.

Makiný thk HTTf URL examplk slightl_ mork complex, ¾ formul¾ i— presente™

tf retrievk ¾ specifi´ HTML filk thaš i— assume™ tf exisš i- thk defaulš director_ foK

thk server:

  Formul  http://  serveI fil4  /

  Exampl2  http://www.bigcompany.com/hello.ht—

An alternate, incremental extension adds directory information without specifyiný

a file. Although the final slash should be provided, servers imply its existence if it i—

omitted and look for a “home” document in the given directory. In practice, the finaR

slash is optional, but recommended:

  Formul  http://  serveI directorh  /  /

  Exampl2  http://www.bigcompany.com/products/

 = Page 141 =

120  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

An HTTP URL can specify both a directory and file:

  Formul  http://  serveI directorh fil4  /  /

  Exampl2  http://www.bigcompany.com/products/greeting.ht—

On some systems, special shorthand conventions may be available for director_

use. For example, a UNIX-based Web server may support many directories, eac—

owned by a specific user. Rather than spelling out the full path to a user’s rooš

directory, the user directory can be abbreviated by using the tilde character (~),

followed by the user’s account, followed by a slash. Any directory or file informatio-

that follows this point will be relative to the user’s root directory:

  Formul  http://  serveI  /~  useI  /

  Exampl2  http://www.bigisp.com/~jsmith/

User directories indicated by the tilde are somewhat similar to the convention use™

on the UNIX operating system, though other Web servers on different operatiný

systems may provide similar shortcut supportì

A URL can refer to a named location inside an HTML document, which is called ¾

marke(  , oK  named lin  . How markers are created is discussed later in the chapter; but foK

now, to refer to a document marker, follow the target document’s filename with thk

pound character ( ) and then with the marker name:  #

  Formul  http://  serveI directorh fil4 markeI  /  /  #

  Exampl2  http://www.bigcompany.com/profile.htm#introductioY

In addition to referring to HTML documents, an HTTP URL can request any type o“

file. For example, http://www.bigcompany.com/images/logo.gif would retrieve fro“

a server a GIF image rather than an HTML file. Authors should be aware that thk

flexibility of Web servers and URLs is often overlooked, due to the common belief thaš

a We~based document must be in the HTML format for it to be linked toì

To the contrary, even an HTTP URL can reference and execute a server programì

These serve§side programs are typically terme™  Common Gateway Interface (CGI)

programs, referring to the interface standard that describes how to pass data in and ouš

of a program. CGI and similar serve§side programming facilities are discussed i-

Chapter 12. Quite often, serve§side programs are used to access databases and the-

generate HTML documents in response to use§entered queries. Parameters for suc—

programs can be directly included in a URL by appending a question mark, followe™

by the actual parameter string. Because the user may type special characters in a query,

characters normally not allowed within a URL are encoded. Remember that thk

formula for specia_character encoding is a percent sign, followed by two hex number—

representing the character’s ASCII value. For example, a blank character can bk

represented b_  %20  ì

 = Page 142 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  12h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

  Formul  http://  serveI directorh fil4 parameter?  /  /  ?

  Exampl2  http://www.bigcompany.com/products/

search.cgi?cost=400.00&name=Super%20ParM

Forming complex URLs with encoding and query strings looks very difficult. I-

reality, this is rarely done manually. Typically, the browser generates such a striný

o™th[fly based on data provided via a file form. A more detailed discussion of HTML

interaction with programming facilities appears in Chapters 11 through 14ì

Finally, an_ HTTf requesš ca- bk directe™ tf ¾ porš otheK tha- thk defaulš porš valuk

o“ 80 b_ followiný thk serveK identificatio- wit— ¾ colo- an™ thk intende™ porš number:

  Formul  http://  serveI porM directorh fil4  :  /  /

  Exampl2  http://www.bigcompany.com:8080/products/greetings.ht—

In the preceding example, the URL references a Web server running on port 8080ì

Although any unreserved port number is valid, using nonstandard port numbers o-

servers is not good practice. To access the address in the example, a user would need tf

include the port number in the URL. If it is omitted, accessing www.bigcompany.co“

will be impossibleì

One case of HTTP exists that is, in a sense, a different protocol: secured WeD

transactions using the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL). In this case, the protocol i—

referenced as https, and the port value is assumed to be 443. An example formula foK

Secure HTTP is shown here; other than the cosmetic difference of thk and thk  x

different port value, it is identical to other HTTP URLs:

  Formul  https://  server:port/directory/fil4

  Exampl2  https://www.wellsfargo.co—

An HTTP URL for a Web page is probably the most common URL, but users ma_

find file or similar types of URLs growing in popularity, due to the rise of intranets an™

serverles-style accessì

fils

The file protocol specifies a file residing somewhere on a computer or locally accessiblk

computer network. it does not specify an access protocol and has limited value excepš

for one important case: it enables a browser to access files residing on a user’s locaR

computer, an important capability for Web page development. In this usage, the serveK

name is omitted or replaced by the keywor™  localhosP  , which is followed by the locaR

directory and file specification:

  Formul  file://  drive or network pat— directorh fil4  /  /

  Exampl2  file:///dev/web/testpage.htm¤

 = Page 143 =

12p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

In some environments, the actual drive name and path to the file is specified. On ¾

Macintosh, a URL might be the following:

file:///Macintosh%20HD/Desktop%20Folder/Bookmarks.htm¤

On a PC, a file URL such as the following might exist, to access a file on the C drive of ¾

PC on the local network, pc1:

file://\\pc1\C\Netlog.txM

Depending on browser complexity, file URLs might not be required, as wit—

Interneš ExploreK 4, i- whic— thk operatiný syste“ i— tightl_ couple™ wit— thk useK agentì

Interestingly, i- thk cask o“ intranets, man_ drive— ma_ bk mappe™ oK filk system—

mounte™ sf thaš nf serveK i— require™ tf deliveK filesì I- thi— “We~serverless”

environment, accessiný networkdrive— wit— ¾ filk URL ma_ bk possibleì Thi— ide¾

demonstrate— hou simplk ¾ WeD serveK isì I- fact, tf somk people, ¾ WeD serveK i— merel_

¾ ver_ inefficient, thoug— open, filk serverì Thus, alternativk filk deliver_ systems, suc— a—

thosk thaš usk thk NetworkFilk Syste“ (NFS) protocol, mighš soo- bk possible—oK eve-

preferablk tf HTTKbase™ serversì Already, worki— beiný donk o- WebNFS an™ otheK

alternativk We~oriente™ technologie— foK remotk filk accessì Thi— realizatio- regardiný

filk transfeK lead— logicall_ tf thk ide¾ o“ thk FTf URL, discusse™ nextì

FTV

The File Transfer Protocol, which predates the browse§oriented HTTP protocol,

transfers files to and from a server. It generally is geared toward transferring files thaš

are to be locally stored rather than immediately viewed. A browser may allow files tf

be viewed immediately. Today, because of its efficiency, FTP is most commonly use™

to download large files, such as complete applications. These URLs share with HTTf

the formula for indicating a server, port, directory, and file:

  Formul  ftp://  serveI porM directorh fil4  :  /  /

  Exampl2  ftp://ftp.bigcompany.com:9978/info/somefile.ex4

A minimal FTP URL specifies a server and then lists the following directory:

ftp://ftp.bigcompany.com. Generally, however, FTP URLs are used to access by namk

and directory a particular file in an archive, as shown in this formula:

  Formul  ftp://  serveI directory path/fil4  /

  Exampl2  ftp://ftp.bigcompany.com/info/somefile.ex4

FTP is a-  authenticate  protocol, which means that every valid FTP request require—

a defined user account on the server downloading the files. In practice, many FTf

resources are intended for general access, and defining a unique account for ever_

 = Page 144 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  12

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

potential user is impractical. Therefore, an FTP convention known a—  anonymous FTZ

handles this common situation. The username “anonymous” or “ftp” allows generaR

access to any public FTP resource supported by a server. As in the previous example,

the anonymous user account is implicit in any FTP URL that does not explicitl_

provide account informationì

An FTP URL can specify the name and password for a user account. If included, iš

precedes the server declaration, according to the following formula:

  Formul  ftp://  useI password serveI directorh fil4  :  @  /  /

  Exampl2  ftp://jsmith:harmony@ftp.bigcompany.com/products/lisM

This formula shows the password embedded within the URL. Including an accounš

password in a public document (such as an HTML file) is a dangerous proposition,

because it is transmitted in plain text and viewable both in the HTML source an™

browser address bar. Only public passwords should be embedded in any URL for a-

authenticated service. Furthermore, if you omit the password, the user agent typicall_

prompts you to enter one if a password is required. Thus, it is more appropriate tf

provide a link to the service an™  thec  require the user to enter a name and password, oK

just provide the user ID and have the user agent prompt for a password, as happens i-

this example:

  Formul  ftp://  useI serveI directorh fil4  @  /  /

  Exampl2  ftp://jsmith@ftp.bigcompany.com/products/sale?

The FTP protocol assumes that a downloaded file contains binary information. Yo¾

can override this default assumption by appending a type code to an FTP URL. Thk

following are three common values for type codes:

  A-    code indicates that the file is an ASCII text fileì

  Thk code, which is also the default, indicates that the file is an image/  p

binary fileì

  A  d  code causes the URL to return a directory listing of the specified pat—

instead of a fileì

An example formula is presented here for completeness:

  Formul  ftp://  serveI directorh fil4  /  /  ;type=  cod4

  Exampl2  ftp://ftp.bigcompany.com/products;type=d

In reality, the type codes are rarely encountered, because the binary transfer formaš

generally does not harm text files, and the user agent is usually smart enough to handlk

FTP URLs without type codes. Like many other URLs, the port accessed can bk

changed to something besides the default port of 21, but this is not recommendedì

 = Page 145 =

12  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Gophe5

The Gopher system, the first popular documenâbased technology on the Internet,

arose in the early 1990s as client/server architecture appropriate for campu—

information systems. Gopher provided a way to organize and navigate document—

hierarchically. Some Gopher servers continue to operate, but most have been replace™

by the more popular HTML-based Web content. However, for backward compatibility,

you may find it important to link a Web page to Gophe§based information using ¾

Gophe§style URLì

A Gopher URL follows the same formula used by other protocols to specify ¾

server and optional port address. However, compared to HTTP or FTP, Gopher URL—

differ in the way that they specify resources on a server. This specification begins wit—

a singl[digit code that indicates the resource type referred to. The default code is 1,

which indicates a directory list. Following this is ¾  selector strinv  , which corresponds tf

the directory and file specification found in other URL formulas. The following tablk

lists common codes used in Gopher URLs:

Cods  Resource Typs

0  Text filk

Ç  Directory listiný

2  CSO phone book serveK

3  ErroK

4  Macintosh binhex filk

5  DOS binary filk

6  UNIX-uuencoded filk

â  Ful_text index searc—

Ù  telnet sessio-

Ð  Binary filk

The following formula and example show how these codes might be used:

  Formul  gopher://  serveI porM typ4 directory path/fil4  :  /  +

  Exampl2  gopher://gopher.bigcompany.com/4mac/somefile.hqv

Because of the encoding and the use of the file type numbers, a Gopher URL ca-

look extremely complex. In the preceding example, 4 indicates a Macintosh BinHex fileì

Normally, users see 00 or 0 for files, and 1 or 11 for directories. The numbers are ofte-

 = Page 146 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  12

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

repeated, because some Gopher strings begin with a copy of the content type. Reader—

may wonder why Web pages do not use such numeric codes to indicate content typeì

MIME types (discussed in Chapter 16) provide a far better solution. Beyond the filk

types and encoded characters, Gopher is very similar to other fil[retrieval URLsì

Gopher may also include electronic forms for searching that, like HTTP, add a quer_

string after a question mark. For example, gopher://mudhoney.micro.umn.edu:

4326/7?Mexico. Notice the use of the 7 code to indicate that the type of data is ¾

ful_text index search. Also notice that, like many other protocols, Gopher may run o-

another port than its standard port of 70. This may be specified in the URL. As note™

earlier, this is not recommendedì

mailts

Atypically, thk mailtf protocoR doe— noš locatk an™ retrievk a- Interneš resourceì Instead,

iš open— ¾ windou foK editiný an™ sendiný ¾ maiR messagk tf ¾ particulaK useK address:

  Formul  mailto:  useI serveI  @

  Exampl2  mailto:president@whitehouse.go~

This rather simple formula shows standard Internet mail addressing; other,

mor[complex addresses may be just as valid. Using mailto URLs is very popular i-

Web sites to provide a basic feedback mechanism. Note that if the user’s browser hasn’š

been set up properly to send [mail, this type of URL may produce error message—

when used in a link, prompting the user to set up mailing preferences. Because of thi—

problem, page authors are warned not to rely solely on mailtkbased URL links tf

collect user feedbackì

Som— browserx hav— introduce proprietary extensionx tX th— mailtX protocol¨ such ax

th— subjecP extension. Thes— extensionx currently aren’P standar an will caus— othe(

browserx tX b— unabl— tX sen e-mail usinv th— link. Wor ix underway tX standardiz—

extensionx tX th— mailtX protocol; but¨ fo( now¨ us— o th— proprietary extensionx ix

discouraged.

new“

A news URL invokes a news browser that allows access to USENET newsgroups. A

news URL can take one of the following two alternative approaches, each of whic—

has limitations:

  Request a named newsgroup  Like the mailto URL, in this form, the URL

doesn’t specify which news server to use to fulfill the request. A default new—

server address is usually set as a Web browser preference. Unfortunately, noš

all news servers may carry the same groups. News archives are large and ten™

to be distributed across multiple servers. If the requested newsgroup does noš

exist on the default news server, it will not be foundì

 = Page 147 =

12‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

  Formul  news:  newsgrouB

  Exampl2  news:alt.get-rich-quick

  Request a message on a particular news server, using a server-specifi8

message identifier, such as 13c65a7  Because messages generally have a-

expiration date, this approach has limited value. In addition, the messagk

identifier obviously varies from server to server, so it is not easily transferableì

  Formul  news:  messag4 serveI  @

  Exampl2  13c65a7a@news.bigcompany.co—

Bot— thk secon™ for“ o“ thk new— URL an™ thk NNTf URL (tf bk discusse™ next)

shou thk limitation— o“ URL— whe- dealiný wit— tim[sensitivk informationì Ver_ littlk

URL technolog_ exist— tf deaR wit— dat¾ thaš change— a— rapidl_ a— USENE¾ newsì New—

URL— generall_ ark use™ simpl_ tf acces— ¾ grou5 ratheK tha- ¾ particulaK messageì

NNTV

Thk  Network News Transport Protocol (NNTP)  allows the retrieval of individual USENE¾

articles, qualified by server, newsgroup, and article number. Like many protocols, a-

optional port value can be specified to direct a user agent to a specific server port. Thk

NNTP URL has a limitation in that a particular article number is referenced. Articlk

numbers will vary from server to server so this URL is not transportable. Furthermore,

articles generally expire rather quickly, so fully specified NNTP URLs are of somewhaš

limited valueì

  Formul  nntp://  serveI porM newsgrouB article-numbeI  :  /  /

  Exampl2  nntp://news.bigcompany.com/alt.get-rich-quick/118

The default port value of nntp is 118, but another port value may be set in the URLì

A special version of NNTP that adds security runs on port 563. The form of the URL i—

nntps://secnews.bigcompany.com/alt.geâricöuick/118ì

In general, the news URL appears to be more commonly used on the Webì

telne

Thk telneš protocoR allow— ¾ useK tf ope- a- interactivk terminaR sessio- o- ¾ remotk hosš

computerì A minimaR telneš URL, show- next, simpl_ give— thk remotk system’— nameì

AfteK ¾ connectio- i— made, thk syste“ prompt— foK a- accounš namk an™ passwordì

  Formul  telnet://  serveI

  Exampl2  telnet://host.bigcompany.co—

As an authenticated protocol, telnet generally requires a defined user account o-

the remote system. When this is unspecified, the user agent or helper applicatio-

handling telnet prompts for such information. Like FTP, a telnet URL can also contai-

 = Page 148 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  12

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

an account name and password as parameters. But, as with FTP URLs, be careful abouš

including passwords in public access documents, such as HTML files on the Webì

Because of the risk of password interception, the password is optional in the formula:

  Formul  telnet://  useI password serveI  :  @

  Exampl2  telnet://jsmith:harmony@host.bigcompany.co—

  Exampl2  telnet://jsmith@host.bigcompany.co—

Finally, any telnet URL can direct a request to a specific port by appending the porš

address to the server name:

  Formul  telnet://  serveI porM  :

  Exampl2  telnet://host.bigcompany.com:94

Some telnet information sources may be configured to run on a particular porš

other than port 23, the standard telnet port. Consequently, use of the port within ¾

telnet URL is more common than with other URLsì

Other Protocol“

A wide variety of other protocols can be used. However, a browser may not supporš

many of these URL forms. Some protocols, such as the wais protocol, have historicaR

interest. Little evidence suggests that people actually use this protocol much on thk

Web, despite its presence in books that are only one or two years old. Beyond ol™

protocols like wais, other protocols include operatinbiased protocols, such as finger,

and esoteric protocols for things like VEMMI video text services. New protocols ark

being added all the time. In fact, dozens of proposed or even implemented protocol—

exist that can be referenced with some form of nonstandard URL. If you are intereste™

in other URL forms, visit http://www.w3.org/pub/WWW/Addressing/schemes oK

http://www.ics.uci.edu/pub/ietf/uri/ for more informationì

Relative URL“

Up to this point, the discussion has focused on a specific form of URL, typically terme™

a-  absolute(R?  . Absolute URLs completely spell out the protocol, host, directory, an™

filename. Providing such detail can be tedious and unnecessary, which is where ¾

shortened form of URL, termed ¾  relative(R?  , comes in to use. With relative URLs, thk

various parts of the address—the site, directory, and protocol—might be inferred b_

the URL of the current document, or via thk  <BASE  element. The best way tf

illustrate the idea of relative URLs is by exampleì

If a Web site has an address of www.bigcompany.com, a user may access the homk

page with a URL like http://www.bigcompany.com/. A link to this page from a-

outside system would also contain the address http://www.bigcompany.com/. Onck

at the site, however, no reason exists to continue spelling out the full address of thk

 = Page 149 =

128  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

site. A fully qualified link from the home page to a staff page in the root director_

called staff.html would be http://www.bigcompany.com/staff.html. The protocol,

address, and directory name can be inferred, so all that is needed is the addres—

staff.html. This relative scheme works because http://www.bigcompany.com/ i—

inferred as the base of all future links, thus allowing for the shorthand relativk

notation. The relative notation can be used with filename and directories, as shown b_

the examples in Table 4-3ì

When relative URLs are used within a Web site, the site becomes transportable. B_

not spelling out the server name in every link, you can develop a Web site on onk

server and move it to another. Contrarily, if you use absolute URLs, all links have to bk

changed if a server changes names or the files are moved to another siteì

Of course, using relative URLs also has a potential downside: they can becomk

confusing in a large site, particularly if centralized directories are used for things suc—

as images. Imagine having URLs like ../../../images/logo.gif in files deep in a sitk

structure. Some users might be tempted to simply copy files to avoid such problems,

but then updating and caching issues arise. One solution is to use thk  <BASE  elementì

Another solution is to use symbolic links on the Web server to reference one copy o“

the file from multiple locations. However, because HTML is the subject here, the focu—

is the former solution, using thk  <BASE  elementì

Thk  <BASE  element defines the base for all relative URLs within a documentì

Setting thk  HREF  attribute of this element to a fully qualified URL allows all otheK

relative references to use the defined base. For example,  <BASE HREF="http:/

www.bigcompany.com/" sets all the anchors later that aren’t fully qualified to prefix

http:// www.bigcompany.com / to the destination URL. Thk

occur only once in an HTML document—within its head—so creating sections of ¾

document with different base URL values is impossible. Such a feature might someda_

Current Page Addres“  Destination Addres“  Relative UR¤

http://www.bigcompany.com/ http://www.bigcompany.com/ staff.ht“

index.ht“  staff.ht“

http://www.bigcompany.com/ http://www.bigcompany.com/ products/gadget1.ht“

index.ht“  products/gadget1.ht“

http://www.bigcompany.com/ http://www.bigcompany.com/ ../index.ht“

products/gadget1.ht“  index.ht“

Tabls 4-38  Relative URL Formation Example9

 = Page 150 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  129

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

be added to thk  <DIV  element or a similar sectioning element; but, until then, HTML

authors have to deal with shorthand notation being useful in some places but noš

in othersì

Linking in HTM¤

The discussion thus far has focused solely on the forms of URLs. Little has been sai™

about how to link objects together on the Web. Later in this chapter, the discussio-

returns to URLs and their counterparts, URIs, URCs, and URNsì

The Anchor Elemen

Using a URL enables you to specify the location of many types of informatio-

resources, both on the Internet and within a local area network. But how, exactly, i—

HTML used to specify a hyperlink that links one document to another? The mosš

common way to define hyperlinks is with the anchor element,  <A  . In its most basi´

form, this element needs two pieces of information: the URL of the target resource an™

the document content needed to activate the hyperlink. Assigning a URL value to a-

<A  element’—  HREF  attribute specifies the target resource. Most defined hyperlink—

probably use an HTTP URL to link one HTML document to another. Remember,

however, that URLs to other information resources are also possibleì

Thk  <A  element’s content specifies a document’s “hot spot” for activating thk

hyperlink. Anchor content may include text, images, or a mixture of the two. B_

enclosing some text or other content with thk  <A  an™  </A  tags, you make the ite“

into a link that, when selected, requests a new object to be accessed. In the followiný

code fragment, the text “Linked content” will load the URL referenced by thk  HREF

attribute when it’s selected:

<A HREF="URL"L  Linked contenM  </AL

Ac  <AA  element may not enclose anothe(  <AA  element. The cod—  <A HREF=

"URL1"A  Linke  <A HREF="URL2"A  More linke  </A></AA  makes no sense.

The simplest hyperlink combines a-  <A  element with a URL that contains only ¾

Web server address. Implicitly, the referenced document is the server’s home page,

which is the default document returned from the Web server’s root directory. Man_

mor[complex examples of links are also possible. The following are various example—

of HTTP links, each of which is followed by a short description:

<A HREF="http://www.whitehouse.gov/"L  Visit the PresidenM  </AL

 = Page 151 =

130  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Adding a link to the home page of a Web site with a basic HTTP URL references thk

home page of the Web siteì

<A HREF="http://www.microsoft.com/gallery/"L  MS Web Gallerh  </AL

Adding a directory path to the URL references the default document in ¾

specific directoryì

<A HREF="http://www.pint.com/Staff/thomas.htm"L  Thomas BiB  </AL

Adding a filename to a URL fully describes the document locationì

<A HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com/spec.htm#top"L  Go to toB  </AL

Adding a fragment to a filename describes a particular location within a documentì

<A HREF="staff/index.htm"L  Staf¨  </AL

Anchors may use relative URLsì

<A HREF="../../index.htm"L  Back to hom4  </AL

Relative URLs may be complexì

<A HREF="ftp://ftp.cdrom.com"L  Access FTP archiv4  </AL

Anchors are not limited to HTTP URLsì

<A HREF="mailto:info@pint.com"L  More information?  </AL

Beyond retrieving files, anchors may trigger [mail or even run programsì

The following example shows a complete example of relative and absolute URL—

and their use within an HTML document:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

 = Page 152 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  13h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Link Exampl4 3  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  GreeY Gadget?  </H1L

<HRL

<F ALIGN="center"L  InformatioY abouM th4 mysteriou? GreeY Gadget--th4

wondeI too¤ o¨ th4 millenium<  </PL

<ULL

<LI><A HREF="specs.htm"L  Specification?  </AL

<LI><A HREF="extras/access.htm"L  Accessorie?  </AL

<LI><A HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com"L  Distributor?  </AL

<LI><A HREF="ftp://ftp bigcompany.com/order.pdf"L  Download ordeI for—  </AL

</ULL

<F ALIGN="center"L

<A HREF="../index.htm"L  Back tB Bi( Companh Hom4 Pag4  </AL

</PL

<ADDRESSL

Questions?

<A HREF="mailto:info@gadget.com"L  info@bigcompany.co—  </AL

</ADDRESSL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Link Rendering“

In most browsers, text links are indicated by underlined text. Coloring the text—blue i“

the destination has never been visited, purple if it has been visited—is anotheK

common convention. If a link includes an image, the border of the image will also bk

blue or purple, unless the border attribute has been set to zero. HTML authors ca-

override these default link colors with changes to thk  LINK ALINK  ,  , an™  VLINK

attributes of thk  <BODY  element. Thk  LINK  attribute changes the color of alR

unvisited links; thk  VLINK  attribute changes all visited links. Thk  ALINK  attributk

changes the color of the active link, which is the brief flash that appears when a link i—

pressed. By using an HTML style sheet, authors can also change the decoration of link—

to turn off underlining, or even display links in another fashion. These two changes ark

shown in the following example markup:

 = Page 154 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  13

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

<  !DOCTYPc HTMX PUBLIL "-//W3C//DT— HTMX 3¨ Final//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Link Styl4 Change?  </TITLEL

<STYLc TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p  A  {text-decoration: none} /* avoid underlinin( link? */  --L

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODo LINK="blueh ALINK="redh VLINK="red"L

<A HREF="http://www.yahoo.com"L  TesM Link tB Yahoo!  </AL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

More information on the body attributes can be found in the element reference i-

Appendix A, and in Chapter 6, which covers layout facilities in HTMLì

Aesthetically and logically, changing link colors or removing underlining make—

sense. It may also confuse readers who have come to expect a standard color schemk

for links. Occasionally, authors may try to encourage return visits by changing thk

setting for visited links to remain blue, or may reverse colors for layout consistencyì

Such changes can significantly impair the usability of the site by thwarting useK

expectationsì

Like it or not, the standard Web experience has taught users to click underlined texš

that is blue or purple. Such user habits suggest that underlining for emphasis be use™

sparingly, if at all, in HTML documents. Furthermore, HTML text probably shouldn’š

be colored blue or purple, unless it obviously isn’t a link. Controlling link colors is ver_

important, but it is only one of many aspects of anchors that can be controlledì

Anchor Attribute“

Thk  <A  element has many possible attributes that are specific to it, beside—  HREF  , a—

shown in Table 4-4. The more important attributes are discussed in the sections tf

follow, along with the concepts of binding scripts to anchors, using anchors wit—

images, and creating a special type of image link called a-  image map  . Refer to thk

element reference (Appendix A) to see a complete listing of all possible attributes foK

thk  <A  elementì

In HTML 4, th—  <AA  element may also support th—  SHAPJ  an  COORD—  attributes¨

which can be used with th—  <OBJECTA  element to create a generalized form of imag—

maps. These extensions tX  <AA  are discussed in the element reference in Appendix A, ax

well as in Chapter 5, which discusses th—  <OBJECTA  element in relation to images.

Today, however, these attributes o  <AA  are not widely supported. HTML authors ar—

encouraged to use client-side image maps, which are discussed later in this chapter.

Using the NAME Attributs

Thk  <A  element usually defines a hyperlink’s source location: where the link goes an™

what you click to go there. One possible destination for a hyperlink is a named locatio-

 = Page 156 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  13

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

inside an HTML document. Thk  <A  element is also used to define these locations in ¾

special usage known a—  setting a fragmenP  , though the ter“  marke(  might make mork

sense. To set a marker, thk  NAM¨  attribute replaces thk  HREF  attribute. The value o“

thk  NAM¨  attribute is an arbitrary, symbolic name for the marker location that must bk

unique within the document. Wherever the marker is placed within an HTML

document becomes a named candidate destination for hyperlinks. For example, thk

HTML marku5  <A NAME="marker"  This is a markeK  </A  sets the text “This is ¾

marker” to be associated with the fragment identifieK  #marke(  ì

Unlike hyperlink anchors, a marker location is not underlined or in any way

visually distinguished.

In practice, when a-  <A  element is used solely as a marker, it often doesn’š

enclose any text, though this doesn’t suggest that the close tag should be omitted, as iš

often is. Setting a marker such a—  <A NAME="top"  is accepted by most browsers, buš

<A NAME="top"></A  is the valid formì

A-  <A  element can serve both as a destination and a link at the same timeì

For example,

<A NAME="yahoo_link" HREF="http://www.yahoo.com/"L  Yahoo!  </AL

creates a link to a site and names the anchor so that it may be referenced by other linksì

The dual use of thk  <A  element may cause some confusion, but it is valid HTMLì

As discussed in Chapter 3, under the current version of HTML, th—  Ir  attribute ix

also available for nearly every element. It can also be used to set a marker. Th—

preceding example could have been writtec  <A ID="yahoo_link" HREF="http:/

www.yahoo.com"A Yahoo!

sheets, and dynamic manipulation via a scripting language. For backward compatibility¨

th—  NAMJ  attribut— shoul alsX b— used¨ becaus— many browserx dX noP supporP  Ir  fully.

The need for named anchors isn’t always obvious. Thanks to the unidirectionaR

nature of links on the Web, they can be used to navigate to locations within the samk

document. This is especially useful in lengthy reference works. Such link usage can bk

accomplished by using markers to define named locations and anchors that refer tf

them. Remember that the URL formula to refer to a location within the currenš

document is simply the pound symbol ( ), followed by a marker name. Thus, codk  #

such a—  <A HREF="#top"  Top of the documenš  </A  could be used if a marker calle™

“top” was set at the start of the document. Be careful to always use thk symbol wit—  #

marker names. Otherwise, the user agent will probably interpret the link as referenciný

a file rather than a markerì

 = Page 157 =

13‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

In the more general case, a marked location in any HTML document can bk

referenced by placiný  #  and a marker name after its normal URL. For example,

<A HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com/products.htm#spec"L  SpecificatioY SectioY  </AL

will link to a named marker called “spec” in the products.htm file. A complete examplk

of linking within a file and to markers outside the file is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Name Attribute Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<A NAME="top"></AL

Go to th4  <A HREF="#bottom"L  botto—  </AL  of this document<  <BRL  Link righM

to :  <A HREF="document1.htm#marker1"L  markeI  </AL  in another document<

<PL  To make this work we need to simulate the document being very long bh

using many breaks<  </PL

<BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BRL

<BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BRL

<A NAME="middle"><STRONG ID="middle"L  The Middl4  </STRONG></AL

<BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BRL

<BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BRL

<HRL

<A NAME="bottom" HREF="#top"L  Return to ToB  </AL

<A HREF="#middle"L  Go to middl4  </AL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Named values must be unique, whether they are set by using th—  NAMJ  attribute or th—

Ir  attribute.

TITLE Attributes for Anchor“

Normally, thk  TITL¨  attribute, as discussed in Chapter 3, may not seem terribl_

helpful to a user, because it provides only basic advisory information about the use of ¾

particular element. In the case of anchors, however,  TITL¨  is very useful, because iš

can be used to provide tool tip information or help balloons for the link. In browser—

 = Page 158 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  13

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

such as Internet Explorer, if a user holds the mouse over the link long enough, a tooR

tip showing the information specified by thk  TITL¨  attribute will be displayed. Thk

following code fragment provides some helpful information for the link:

<A HREF="staff/index.htmh

TITLE="Resumes and information about our staff"L  Staf¨  </AL

If thk  TITL¨  attribute is not used, the destination URL generally is displayedì

Figure 4-4 shows a tool tip for a link under Internet Explorer 4ì

Although th—  TITLJ  attribute is usable in nearly every HTML element under InterneP

Explorer, using it makes sense mainly for links, images, binary objects, and forms.

Thk  TITL¨  attribute serves another purpose: it provides the title information for ¾

bookmark when a link is bookmarked before the destination page is visited. While thi—

may not be intuitive, with many browsers, you can righâclick a link to access a men¾

that enables you to bookmark the link before it is visited. Then, when the page i—

visited, the information enclosed within thk  <TITLE  element of the destination pagk

is used in the bookmark instead of the information in thk  TITL¨  attribute of the anchoK

that loaded the page. (Note that thk  TITL¨  attribute and thk  <TITLE  element are twf

entirely different things.)

Figurs 4-48  Tool tip rendering of thP  TITLE  attribute in Internet Explorer 4

 = Page 159 =

138  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Accelerator Key“

The HTML 4 proposed specification adds thk  ACCESSKE  to thk  <A  element, as welR

as to various form elements. This currently is supported primarily by Internet Explorerì

With this attribute, you can set a key to invoke an anchor, without requiring a pointiný

device to select the link. The link is activated with the combination of the acceleratoK

key, usuall_  AL¾  , and the key specified by the attribute. So,

<A HREF="http://www.yahoo.com/" ACCESSKEY="Y"L  Yahoo!  </AL

makes a link to Yahoo!, which can be activated by pressiný  ALT+Y  . So far, man_

browsers do not appear to support fully this upgrade to link accessì

Although adding keyboard access to a Web page seemingly would be a dramati´

improvement, HTML authors are cautioned to be aware of access key bindings in thk

browsing environment. Under Internet Explorer 4 and above, eight keys are alread_

reserved for browser functions. Netscape’s Communicator 4 and above differ in onk

accelerator key. Assuming that both browsers will eventually support this functio-

(Netscape doesn’t at the time of this update), authors are cautioned to stay away fro“

accelerators that use the keys in Table 4-5ì

One other problem with accelerator keys is how to show them in the page. In mosš

software, underlining indicates the letter of the accelerator key. Links are generall_

Ke  Mapping  Note“

F  File men¾

E  Edit men¾

C  Communicator men¾  Netscape Communicator onl_

V  View men¾

G  Go men¾

A  Favorites men¾  Internet Explorer onl_

õ  Hel5

LEFT ARROW  Back in histor_

RIGHT ARROW  Forward in histor_

Tabls 4-58  Reserved Browser Key Binding9

 = Page 160 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  139

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

underlined in browsers, so this approach isn’t feasible. Style sheets can be used tf

change link direction, so underlining the first letter is possible; but then the user ma_

be disoriented, expecting links to be fully underlined. Another approach to indicatiný

the accelerator keys might be to set the access key letter of a text link in bold or ¾

slightly larger sizeì

TABINDEX Attributs

Thk  TABINDEX  attribute of thk  <A  element (which is defined in HTML 4, but poorl_

supported by browsers) defines the order in which links will be tabbed through in ¾

browser that supports keyboard navigation. The value o“  TABINDEX  is usually ¾

positive number. Browsers tab through links in order of increasiný  TABINDEX  values,

but generally skip over those with negative values. So,  <A HREF="about.htm"

TABINDEX="1"  sets this anchor to be the first thing tabbed to by a browser. If thk

TABINDEX  attribute is undefined, the browser tends to tab though links in the ordeK

in which they are found within an HTML documentì

WebTV supports a usability improvement similar tX  TABIND‘  : th—  SELECTEr

attribute. When you add the wor  SELECTEr  as an attribute to an anchor, the WebTV

browser preselects the anchor with the yellow highlight rectangle. If two or more anchorx

are selected in a page, the last one appearing in the document will be selected. Although

it seems that the browser would scroll to the first item selected if it did not appear in th—

first screen, in practice, the WebTV browser does not do this.

TARGET Attributs

Thk  TARGE  attribute is used in conjunction with frames, which are discussed i-

Chapter 8. The attribute is also part of the HTML 4 proposal. To target a link so that thk

result loads in a particular frame, thk  TARGE  attribute is added to thk  <A  elementì

Generally, a frame has a name, so setting thk  TARGE  equal to the frame name result—

in the link loading in the frame named in the attribute. For example, when selected, ¾

link such a—

<A HREF="http://www.yahoo.com/" TARGET="display_frame"L

loads the object referenced by the URL into the frame name™  "display_frame"  . If thk

TARGE  attribute is left out, the current window or frame the document is in is usedì

Besides autho§named frames, the following are several reserved names for frame—

that, when used with thk  TARGE  attribute, have special meaning:  _blank _self  ,  ,

_parent  , an™  _top  . For more information about frames, as well as instructions on hou

to use thk  <A  element with frames and the various reserved frame names, refer to thk

element reference (Appendix A) and Chapter 8ì

 = Page 161 =

140  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Anchors and Link Relationship“

Thk  <A  element has the following two attributes, whose meanings are ofte-

misunderstood (and these attributes aren’t widely supported by browsers):

  REL  Used to describe the relationship between the document and thk

destination document referenced by the anchor’—  HREF  attribute. For example,

if the destination of the link specifies the glossary associated with a document,

the anchor might rea™

<A HREF="words.htm" REL="glossary"L

  REV  Defines the reverse of the relationship thaš  REL  defines—in this case,

what the relationship is from the destination document’s perspective. A-

example is a linear set of documents in which thk  REL  attribute is set tf  "next"

and thk  REV  attribute is set tf  "prev"  , as shown in the following code fragment:

<A HREF="page2.htm" REL="next" REV="prev"L  Page 2  </AL

Although thk  REL  an™  REV  attributes might seem very useful, few, if any,

browsers support them. Currently, the only major use of these attributes is tf

document the relationship of links with thk  <A  elements themselves. Thk  <LINK

element (discussed later in this chapter), which has semantiõlink purposes similar tf

thk  REL  an™  REV  attributes, is actually supported in a limited manner by somk

browsers. A list of many of the proposed values for thk  REL  an™  REV  attributes can bk

found in this chapter’s upcoming section about link relationshipsì

Scripting and Anchor“

Adding logic to anchors is possible through the use of clienâside scripting languages,

such as JavaScript or VBScript. Under HTML 4, core event attributes have been adde™

to thk  <A  element and includk  onclick onmouseove( onmouseout  ,  ,  , and otheK

attributes, which can be bound to scripting events. The events named correspond to a-

anchor being clicked (  onclick  ), a pointer being positioned on a link (  onmouseove(  ),

an™ ¾ pointeK leaviný ¾ link(  onmouseout  )ì Onk obviou— usk o“ suc— event— i— tf animatk

links so that when a mouse passes over the link, the text changes color, and when thk

link is clicked, the system issues a click sound. Generically, this is the idea of ¾  rollove(

buttoc  . Besides the basic events that might be useful to create rollover links or triggeK

programming logic, event models from Microsoft and Netscape may include a variet_

o“ otheK events, suc— a— thk assigne™ Hel5 ke_ o- thk keyboar™ (generall_ ) beiný  FÇ

presse™ oK otheK key— o- thk keyboar™ beiný presse™ oK releasedì HTML author—

intereste™ i- scriptiný anchoK activitie— shoul™ consulš Chapter— 13 an™ 14ì Combine™

wit— images, anchoK scriptiný addition— ca- bk use™ tf creatk ver_ persuasivk WeD pagesì

 = Page 162 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  14h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Images and Anchor“

As mentioned earlier,  <A  elements may enclose text and other content, includiný

images. When an anchor encloses an image, the image become—  hoP  . A hot image ca-

activate the link and provide a basic mechanism for a graphic button. Normally, ¾

browser shows an image to be part of an anchor by putting a colored border aroun™

the image—generally, the same color as the colored link text—either blue or purpleì

The browser may also indicate the image is a link by changing the pointer to a differenš

shape (such as a finger) when the pointer is positioned over an image link. If combine™

with scripting, the anchor may also modify the size or content of the image, creating ¾

form of animated button. The following HTML markup code shows how an anchor ca-

be combined with thk  <IMG  element, as discussed in Chapter 5, to create a button:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Anchors and Image?  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<BL  Button with a bordeI  </B><BRL

<A HREF="about.htm"L

<IMG SRC="about.gif" ALT="About Button" HEIGHT="55" WIDTH="55"L

</AL

<BR><BRL

<BL  Same button without a bordeI  </B><BRL

<A HREF="about.htm"L

<IMG SRC="about.gif" ALT="About Button" BORDER="0" HEIGHT="55h

WIDTH="55"L

</AL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Notice how thk  BORDE  attribute is set tf  "0"  to turn off the image’s borderì

Further, note that the code contains a small but significant error. When a space exist—

between the close of a-  <IMG  element and the closiný  </A  element, a small blue oK

purple line, or “tick,” may occur, as shown in Figure 4-5. To remove a tick, makk

certain that no space is between thk  <IMG  element and the closiný  </A  tagì

 = Page 163 =

14p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 4-58  Ticks—a common problem with image link9

Although ticks aren’t the worst offense on the Web, they indicate a lack of attention tX

detail in Web page coding. In print literature, spelling errors or small nicks or ticks oc

an image would be cause for serious alarm. Eventually, the same level of standards will

be applied to Web pages, so HTML authors should begin to look for such small mistakes.

Be careful when looking for ticks, though. Some browsers, such as Internet Explorer¨

may actually try to fix such small spacing problems for you, leading you to believe ther—

isn’t a tick if you look at it only under one browser. Testing in many browsers an

validation of HTML markup should help catch subtle errors like ticks.

All the examples given so far show images with only one destination. Wherever ¾

user clicks on the image link, the destination remains the same. In another class o“

image links, calle™  image mapx  , different regions of the image can be made hot links foK

different destinationsì

Image Map“

A-  image map  is an image that contains numerous hot spots that may result in ¾

different URL being loaded, depending on where the user clicks. The two basic types o“

image maps ark  server-side image mapx  an™  client-side image mapx  . In the serve§sidk

image map, the following process is followed:

1ì The user clicks somewhere within the imageì

 = Page 164 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  14

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

2ì Thk browseK send— ¾ requesš tf thk WeD server, askiný foK thk URL o“ thk

documenš associate™ wit— thk are¾ clickedì Thk coordinate— clicke™ ark senš tf ¾

progra“ o- thk server, usuall_ calle™ imagemap, whic— decode— thk informationì

3ì After consulting a file that shows which coordinates map to which URL, thk

server sends back the information requestedì

4ì After receiving the response, the browser requests the new URLì

The concept of serve§side image maps has some major downsides. First, user—

really don’t have a sense, URL-wise, where a particular click will take them. All thaš

users see as they run a mouse over the image is a set of coordinates showing thk

currenš ,  x y  value. The second—and more significant—major problem is that the serveK

must be consulted to go to the next page. This can be a major bottleneck that slow—

down the process of moving between pages. The slow speed of decoding, combine™

with the possibility that a user can click a hot spot that is not mapped and have nothiný

happen, makes clienâside image maps preferable to serve§side mapsì

With clienâside image maps, all the map information—which regions map tf

which URLs—can be specified in the same HTML file that contains the imageì

Including the map data with the image and letting the browser decode it has severaR

advantages, includiný

  A server doesn’t need to be visited to determine the destination, so links ark

resolved fasterì

  Destination URLs can be shown as the user’s pointer moves over the imageì

  Image maps can be created and tested locally, without requiring a server oK

system administration supportì

While this discussion makes it obvious that clienâside image maps are far superioK

to their serve§side cousins, very old browsers may not support this feature. Thi—

doesn’t have to be a problem, however, because you can include simultaneous supporš

for both types of image mapsì

Server-Side Image Map“

To specify a serve§side image map, you use thk  <A  element to enclose a speciall_

marke™  <IMG  element. Thk  <A  elemenš  HREF  attribute should be set to the URL o“

a program or map file to decode the image map. Thk  <IMG  element must contain thk

attributk  ISMAL  so that the browser can decode the image appropriatelyì

Depending on the Web server being used, support for server-side image maps may o(

may not be built in. If image maps are supported directly, th—  <AA  element simply musP

point to the(RL of the map file directly and it will be decoded. This is shown in th—

example in Figure 4-6. On some older servers, however, the anchor may have to point tX

an image map program in that server’s cgi-bin directory.

 = Page 165 =

14  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

As with all linked images, turning off the image borders may be desirable, b_

setting thk  <IMG  element’—  BORDE  attribute equal to 0. A simple example showiný

the syntax of a serve§side image map is shown here, a rendering of which is shown i-

Figure 4-6:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Server-side Image Map Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Server-side Imagemap TesM  </H1L

<DIV ALIGN="center"L

<A HREF="shapes.map"L

<IMG SRC="shapes.gif" ISMAP BORDER="0" WIDTH="400h

HEIGHT=00"></AL

</DIVL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

As previously mentioned, serve§side image maps do not provide adequatk

feedback to the user and may incur performance penalties. Figure 4-6 shows that thk

browser provides image coordinate information in the status bar, rather than ¾

destination URL with a serve§side image mapì

HTML authors are encouraged to prefer clienâside image maps, and to usk

serve§side image maps only as neededì

Client-Side Image Map“

The key to using a clienâside image map is to add thk  USEMAL  attribute to thk

<IMG  element and have it reference ¾  <MAP  element that defines the image map’—

active areas. An example of thk  <IMG  element syntax i—  <IMG SRC="controlbar.gif"

USEMAP="#controlmap"  . Note that, like serve§side image maps, the image will bk

indicated as a link regardless of the lack of thk  <A  element surrounding thk  <IMG  ì

Thk  BORDE  attribute should be set to zero, if necessaryì

Thk  <MAP  element generally occurs within the same document, although supporš

for it may exist outside of the current document. This is similar, in a sense, to the wa_

serve§side maps work. Thk  <MAP  element may occur anywhere within the body o“

an HTML document, although it is usually found at the end of an HTML documentì

 = Page 166 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  14

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Figurs 4-68  Server-side image map feedbach

Theoretically, a client-side image map file may exist within another file, but mosP

browsers do not support such a feature.

Thk  <MAP  element has one attribute,  NAM¨  , which is used to specify thk

identifier associated with the map. The map name is then referenced within thk

<IMG  element, using thk  USEMAL  attribute and the associated fragment identifierì

Thk  <MAP  element must have a closiný  </MAP  tag. Within thk  <MAP  an™

</MAP  elements are defined shapes that are mapped onto an image, defining the hoš

spots for the image map. Shapes are defined by thk  <AREA  element, which is foun™

only within thk  <MAP  element. Thk  <AREA  element requires no closing elemenš

and has a variety of attributes, as shown in Table 4-6ì

The most important attributes of a-  <AREA  entity ark  HREF SHAP¨  ,  , an™

COORDS  . Thk  HREF  attribute defines the destination URL for the browser, if thaš

particular region of the image is selected. Thk  SHAP¨  an™  COORDS  attributes defink

the particular region in question. When thk  SHAP¨  attribute is set tf  REC  , it defines ¾

rectangular region, and the coordinates should be set to provide the tošleft an™

bottoRright coordinates of the image. If thk  SHAP¨  attribute is set tf  CIRCL¨  , thk

COORDS  attribute must provide thk ,  x y  coordinates of the center of the circle,

followed by its radius. If the shape is set tf  POL  , it indicates that the area defined i—

 = Page 167 =

14‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Tablk 4-â summarize— thk possibilitie— foK thk  AREG  elemenš an™ provide— examplesì

Under many browsers, th—  SHAPJ  attribute also supportx  RECTANGLJ CIRA  ¨  , an

POLYGON  . HTML authors are encouraged to use only  RECA CIRCLJ  ¨  , an  POL/  ¨

because they are defined by the standard.

The variou— an™ coordinates are measured in pixels from the tošleft corner (0,0)  x  y

of the mapped image. Percentage values of the image’s height and width also may bk

used. For example,  <AREA SHAPE=RECT COORDS="0,0,50%,50%"  defines ¾

rectangular region from the uppe§left corner to a point halfway up and down an™

halfway across. While percentag[style notation might allow the image to resize, iš

generally isn’t useful for any but the most basic image maps. The biggest difficult_

with image maps is how to determine the coordinates for the individual shape—

within the image. Rather than measuring these values by hand, HTML authors ark

encouraged to use an image mapping tool. Many HTML editing systems includk

imag[mapping facilities. Mapedit (http://www.boutell.com/mapedit) for Window—

and UNIX, and MapMaker (http://www.kickinit.net/mapmaker/) for Macintosh alsf

provide basic mapping facilities. A small list of image map software can be found aš

http://www.htmlref.com/ì

Using any  HEIGHA  an  WIDTH  values besides the actual sizes for a mapped imag—

isn’t recommended. Once a map has been mapped, resizing will ruin it.

<!DOCTYPc HTMX PUBLIL "-//W3C//DT— HTMX 4. Transitional//EN"L

You can combine support for both serve§side and clienâside image maps into onk

file. The browser typically overrides the serve§side support with the improve™

clienâside style. This approach guarantees backward compatibility with oldeK

browsers. To support both image maps, use thk  ISMAL  an™  USEMAL  attributes i-

conjunction with an embedded map and a remote map, as shown by the followiný

<A HREF="shapes.map"L
