HEIGHT=00"></AL

Image Map Attribute“

Clienâside image maps have a variety of attributes that can be used with thk  <AREA

element. Serve§side image maps have no attributes other than those normall_

associated with thk  <IMG  element, such a—  BORDE  . The important attributes ark

discussed here, as well as the issues of adding scripting facilities to image mapsì

TARGET

Thk  <AREA  element for clienâside image maps has been extended to support ¾

TARGE  attribute, much like the addition to thk  <A  element. Thk  TARGE  valuk

 = Page 171 =

150  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

should be set to the name of a frame or window. Generally, a frame has a name, sf

settiný  TARGE  to the frame name results in the link loading in the frame named i-

the attribute. When selected, a link such a—

<AREA SHAPE="RECTh COORDS="0,0,50%, 50%h HREF="http://www.yahoo.comh

TARGET="display_frame"L

loads the page referenced by the URL set b_  HREF  into the frame that is name™

"display_frame"  . If thk  TARGE  attribute is omitted, the current window or framk

that the document is in is used. Besides autho§named frames, the following are severaR

reserved names for frames that, when used with thk  TARGE  attribute, have speciaR

meaning:  _blank _self _parent  ,  ,  , an™  _top  . For more information about frames, as welR

as instructions for how thk  <AREA  element is used with frames and the variou—

reserved frame names, refer to the element reference (Appendix A) and Chapter 8ì

NOHREF

Thk  NOHREF  attribute appears to have little use, but it can be used to set a region i-

the map that does nothing when clicked. This might be useful when attempting to cut ¾

hole in something. For example, an image of a donut might make a great image map,

particularly if the hole in the middle of the donut isn’t an active, clickable area. Thk

NOHREF  attribute makes this simple. Just define a large click region for the wholk

image and then declare the middle of the image nonclickable with thk  NOHREF

attribute. An example of this is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  NOHREF Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<IMG SRC="donut.gif" WIDTH="300" HEIGHT="300" BORDER="0h

ALT="Donut Widget" USEMAP="#donut"L

<MAP NAME="donut"L

<AREA SHAPE="circle" COORDS="150,150,81" NOHREFL

<AREA SHAPE="circle" COORDS="150,150,146" HREF="donut.htm"L

<AREA SHAPE="default" NOHREFL

</MAPL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 172 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  15h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

When this code is rendered under Netscape, the hand cursor, indicating a clickablk

area, disappears when it passes over the nonclickable area; under Internet Explorer, thk

cursor appears the same, but the area still isn’t clickableì

Given thaš  NOHREF  creates an inactive region that sits on top of another, whaš

happens when one region overlaps another? According to the specification, if two oK

more regions overlap, the region defined first within thk  <MAP  element take—

precedence over subsequent regions. This rule implies thaš  <AREA  elements with thk

NOHREF  attribute should be placed befork  <AREA  elements that are active, so thaš

clicking thk  <AREA  element with thk  NOHREF  attribute doesn’t take the user to ¾

new URL as a result of a previously placed, overlapping activk  <AREA  elementì

ALT and TITLE

Image maps have some major drawbacks, even in their clienâside aspect, wit—

texâbased browsers. Thk  AL  attribute can be used, as shown in the previou—

examples, and should provide text labels that are displayed in the status line when thk

pointer passes over the hot spots. Although thk  TITL¨  attribute can be added to alR

elements and can provide a function similar tf  AL  in graphical browsers, in practice,

browsers seem to pick u5  AL  befork  TITL¨  . To be on the safe side, you can use bot—

attributes simultaneously. One unfortunate problem with thk  AL  attribute an™

clienâside image maps is that nongraphical browsers don’t always pick up thk  AL

attributes and build meaningful renderings. Instead of a set of links, the viewer mighš

only see a cryptic message, as shown in Figure 4-8ì

HTML authors are encouraged to provide secondary navigation that mirrors thk

choices available in the image map. This secondary navigation should consist of texš

links located below the image, which makes the site accessible for nongraphical useK

agents and may improve the site’s usability. Users on slow connections may opt tf

select text links before the image is completely downloaded. An example of text link—

in conjunction with an image map is shown in Figure 4-9. Also, when using serve§sidk

image maps, you can make the inactive, or default, area link to a new page thaš

contains a text menu of the choices provided via the image map. In this way, a useK

who selects thk  ISMAL  provided by an older browser receives the menu, not the mapì

Discussion of the design and navigation issues surrounding image maps is left tf

books that focus on site design. When possible, HTML authors should avoid relyiný

too heavily on singl[image–style image maps for navigation purposesì

TABINDEX

Under the HTML 4 proposed specification, you can use thk  TABINDEX  attribute o“

thk  <AREA  element to define the order in which hot spots in a clienâside image ma5

are tabbed through in a browser that supports keyboard navigation. The value o“

TABINDEX  typically is a positive number. A browser tabs through links in order o“

 = Page 173 =

15p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 4-88  Nonmeaningful image map rendering9

increasiný  TABINDEX  values, but generally skips over those with negative values. So,

the following line sets this anchor to be the first thing tabbed to:

<AREA SHAPE="RECTh COORDS="0,0,50%,50%h HREF="http://www.yahoo.com/h

TABINDEX="1"L

 = Page 174 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  15

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Figurs 4-98  Image map with secondary text navigatio—

If thk  TABINDEX  attribute is undefined, the browser tends to tab though links i-

the order in which they are found within an HTML document. Currently, browseK

support o“  TABINDEX  within image maps is sparseì

SCRIPTING

As already noted, you can add logic to image maps with clienâside scriptiný

languages, such as JavaScript or VBScript. Three extensions to thk  <AREA

element—  onclick onmouseove(  ,  , an™  onmouseout  —can be bound to scriptiný

events that provide feedback when a mouse passes over a link. This is the rollover ide¾

discussed earlier. However, thk  <AREA  element is less flexible than using anchor—

in conjunction with single images, because replacing only a portion of the imagk

o™th[fly is impossible. Most rollove§style Web interfaces do not use image maps,

but rely instead on images cut up and pieced together to resemble an image mapì

 = Page 175 =

15  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Semantic Linking with the <LINK> Elemen

Syntactically, a link to another document created by an anchor says nothing about thk

relationship between the current document and the object being pointed to. You ca-

use thk  TITL¨  attribute to provide a hint or advisory information about the link, sf

that the viewer of a page may associate meaning with a link. The linked image or texš

might also give some clue about what happens when the link is selected, but in HTML

itself, links lack any semantic meaning. Thk  <LINK  element, however, does provide ¾

way to define the relationship between linked objects. The concept of thk  <LINK

element is that a document may have predefined relationships that can be specified,

and that some of these relationships might be useful to a browser when offeriný

navigation choices, rendering a page, or preparing a page to be printed. Althoug—

<LINK  has been around for several years, until recently, few browsers havk

supporte™  <LINK  in any way. With the rise of style sheets, scripting, and proprietar_

extensions,  <LINK  is finally being supported by browsers, at least in a limite™

mannerì

Thk  <LINK  element is found in the head of an HTML document, where it ma_

occur more than once. The two most important attributes of the element ark  HREF  an™

REL  . Like thk  HREF  attribute for thk  <A  element, thk  HREF  attribute foK  <LINK

specifies the URL of another document, whilk  REL  specifies the relationship with thaš

document. The value o“  REL  is often called thk  link typ—  . The basic syntax of thk

<LINK  element i—  <LINK HREF="URL" REL="relationship"  . Under HTML 4,

<LINK  also supports a reverse semantic relationship, indicated by thk  REV  attribute,

as well as thk  TITL¨  attribute, which can be used to set advisory information for thk

link. The most mysterious aspect of thk  <LINK  element is the value of thk  REL  an™

REV  attributesì

Link Relationships in Detail

Like thk  REL  attribute for thk  <A  element, thk  REL  attribute foK  <LINK  defines thk

relationship between the current document and the linked object. The value of thk  REL

attribute is simply a text value, which can be anything the author desires. However, ¾

browser might interpret standardized relationships in a particular way. For example, ¾

browser might provide special icons or navigation features when the meaning of a link

is understood. Currently, no standard set of document relationship values exists, buš

the HTML 4 specification lists some proposed relationship values, as shown in Tablk

4-8. Note that these values are not cas[sensitiveì

Beyon™ thk HTML 4 propose™ relationships, variou— otheK relationship— ark beiný

discussedì I- fact, HTML author— ca- makk ¾5 theiK ow- relationship— i“ the_ desire, buš

shoul™ bk carefuR tf avoi™ usiný  PREV  oK  NEX  a—  REL  oK  REV  values, becausk the_

ten™ tf hol™ speciaR meaniný foK browsersì Tablk 4-Ð show— somk propose™valuesì  REL

The most interesting of the proposed relationships are those that are actuall_

supported by a browser. Otherwise, they serve as little more than comments to ¾

document’s reader about the meaning of a linkì

 = Page 176 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  15

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

REL Valus  Explanatio  Exampls

ALTERNAT¨  The link references an alter™  <LINK HREF="frenchintro.htm"

ative version of the documenš  REL="ALTERNATE"

that the link is in. This may be ¾  LANG="fr"

translated version of thk

document, as suggested by thk

LAN…  attributeì

that serves as an appendix for ¾  REL="APPENDIX"

document or siteì

BOOKMARK  The link references a documenš  <LINK HREF="index.htm"

that serves as a bookmark; thk  REL="BOOKMARK"

TITL¨  attribute may be used tf  TITLE="homepage"

name the bookmarkì

CHAPTE  The link references a documenš  <LINK HREF="Ch01.htm"

that is a chapter in a site oK  REL="CHAPTER"

collection of documentsì

CONTENTS  Thk linkreference— ¾ documenš  <LINK HREF="toc.htm"

thaš serve— a— ¾ tablk o“ contents,  REL="CONTENTS"

mosš likel_ foK thk site, thoug— iš

mighš bk foK thk documentì Thk

meaniný i— unclearì

INDEX  The link references a pagk  <LINK HREF="docindex.htm"

that provides an index for thk  REL="INDEX"

current documentì

GLOSSAR  The link references a documenš  <LINK HREF="glossary.htm"

that provides a glossary o“  REL="GLOSSARY"

terms for the current documentì

COPYRIGH  The link references a page thaš  <LINK HREF="copyright.htm"

contains a copyright statemenš  REL="COPYRIGHT"

for the current documentì

NEX  The link references the nexš  <LINK HREF="page2.htm"

document to visit in a lineaK  REL="NEXT"

collection of documents. Iš

can be used, for example, tf

“pr[fetch” the next page, a—

in the WebTV browsersì

WebTV Support for <LINK>

The only fairly common browser to supporš  <LINK  is WebTV. In the WebTV

environment,  <LINK  is used to improve performance. If thk  REL  attribute is set wit—

the value o“  next  and a-  HREF  is specified, the browser will “prefetch” the page i-

question. If the content of the next page is stored in a memory cache, the page load—

much faster than if the page has to be requested from the server. If a WebTV user i—

being presented a brief set of pages in a linear fashion, like a slid[show or tour, thk

next page could be preloaded with thk  <LINK  element. For example,  <LINK

REL="next" HREF="second.htm"  loads the next page, called second.htm, in advanceì

This technique assumes that the user is going to a predictable next page. This may noš

be easy to determine for all possible Web site organizationsì

HTML authors not using WebTV who are interested in prefetching pages can us—

Microsoft’s preloader ActivN control. Images also can be prefetched by setting both

thei(  HEIGHA  an  WIDTH  attributes to 1:  <IMG SRC="image_on_nextpage.gif"

HEIGHT="1" WIDTH="1"A  . This technique loads an image into the page, but th—

image appears as a barely perceptible dot. Then, when the next page loads, the image will

have been precached by the browser. Combined with a scripting language, the loading o

images can be handled after the current page has loaded, by using th—  onloa  evenP

attribute for th—  <BODYA  element.

<LINK> and Style Sheet“

A variety of attributes are defined for thk  <LINK  element, includiný  TYP¨ MEDIG  ,  ,

an™  TARGE  . These new attributes are already supported in browsers such as Interneš

Explorer and Netscape for handling style sheets. Thk  <LINK  element allows a stylk

sheet for a document to be referenced from a separate file. If the markup codk  <LINK

REL="stylesheet" HREF="corpstyle.css"  is inserted in the head of an HTML

document, it associates the style sheet corpstyle.css with the current document. Thk

REL  value o“  STYLESHEE  indicates the relationshipì

Thk  ALTERNATE STYLESHEE  relationship, which would allow users to pick

from a variety of styles, has also been suggested. To define several alternative styles,

thk  TITL¨  attribute must be set to group elements belonging to the same style. AlR

members of the same style must have exactly the same value foK  TITL¨  . For example,

the following fragment defines a standard style called basestyle.css, while twf

alternative styles, titled 640by480 and 1024by768, have been added; these refer to stylk

sheets to improve layout at various screen resolutions:

<LINK REL="alternate stylesheet" TITLE="640by480h

HREF="small-1.css"L

<LINK REL="alternate stylesheet" TITLE="640by480h

HREF="small¤.css"L

<LINK REL="alternate stylesheet" TITLE="1—4by768" HREF="big.css"L

<LINK REL="stylesheet" HREF="basestyle.css"L

 = Page 182 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  16h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

A Web browser should provide a method for users to view and pick from the list o“

alternative styles, where thk  TITL¨  attribute might be used to name each choiceì

Currently, this alternative choice for style sheets is not supported by any populaK

browserì

Because the potential exists for many different kinds of linked objects, thk  TYP¨

attribute was added to thk  <LINK  element to indicate the data type of the relate™

objectì  TYP¨  can be especially helpful when used to indicate the type of style sheeš

being used, because many style sheet technologies currently existì  TYP¨  is used b_

browsers to indicate the type of the linked style, as in this example:

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="corpstyle.css" TYPE="text/css"L

For style sheets,  TYP¨  usually takes a MIME type, which indicates the format of thk

style sheet being linked toì

Thk  MEDIG  attribute is another new attribute for thk  <LINK  element, but it isn’š

widely supported. For style sheets, this attribute would indicate what type of medi¾

the style sheet should be used with. The same document could thus reference one stylk

when it is viewed on a computer screen and a different style sheet when it is printedì

This would allow a different style for printing versus screen. The browser is the-

responsible for filtering out those style sheets that aren’t appropriate for the currenš

environment. The following code fragment shows an example of this idea:

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" MEDIA="PRINT" HREF="corp-print.css"L

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" MEDIA="SCREEN" HREF="corp-screen.css"L

A variety of values have been proposed for thk  MEDIG  attribute, includiný  PRIN  ,

PROJECTION SCREEN BRAILL¨ AURAL  ,  ,  ,  , an™  ALL  . When not specified,  ALL

would be the default type, suggesting that the style be used in all output environmentsì

Meta-Informatio

MetDinformatio- i— simpl_ informatio- abouš informationì Informatio- o- thk WeD

ofte- involve— man_ piece— o“ associated, descriptivk informatio- thaš isn’š alway—

explicitl_ represente™ i- thk resourck itselfì Example— o“ metDinformatio- includk thk

creatoK o“ ¾ document, thk document’— subject, thk publisher, thk creatio- date, an™ eve-

thk titleì Whe- use™ properly, descriptivk metDinformatio- ha— man_ benefitsì Iš ca-

makk informatio- easieK tf locate, b_ providiný searc— engine— wit— mor[detaile™

indexiný information, ratk informatio- tf protecš minor— fro“ viewiný certai- content,

an™ ¾ variet_ o“ otheK thingsì A— alread_ discussed, metDinformatio- i— relate™ tf

linking, becausk iš help— providk meaniný foK ¾ document’— rolk i- ¾ globaR oK locaR

informatio- spaceì MetDinformatio- ca- alsf providk roo“ foK miscellaneou—

informatio- relate™ tf thk documentì HTML’— primar_ supporš foK metDinformatio- i—

throug— thk  <META  element, whic— allow— author— tf ad™ arbitrar_ form— o“ metadataì

 = Page 183 =

16p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<META> and the NAME Attributs

A  <META  element that uses thk  NAM¨  attribute is the easiest to understand. Thk

NAM¨  attribute specifies the type of information. Thk  CONTEN  attribute is set to thk

content of the metDinformation itself. For example,

<META NAME="FÆorite Sandwich" CONTENT="Turkey and Swiss"L

defines metDinformation indicating the document author’s favorite lunch. Whilk

metDdata can be inserted into a document and list characteristics limited only by a-

author’s imagination, some wel_understood values exist that have meaning for WeD

search tools, such as AltaVista, HotBot, and Infoseek. Many search robots understan™

thk  AUTHO DESCRIPTION  ,  , an™  KEYWORDS  values for thk  NAM¨  attributeì

By setting thk  NAM¨  an™  CONTEN  attributes, HTML authors can add met“

information to the head of their documents and improve the indexing of their page—

by Web search robots. The following code sets the description of a Web page for ¾

fictitious company that makes Green Gadgets:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Bi( Company Inc< Hom4 Pag4  </TITLEL

<META NAME="AUTHORh CONTENT="Big Company, Inc."L

<META NAME="DESCRIPTIONh CONTENT="#1 vendo of Gree Gadgets."L

<META NAME="KEYWORDSh CONTENT="Big, Company, Gadgets, Green, Sa Diego"L

</HEADL

<BODYL

..<

</BODYL

</HTMLL

As this example demonstrates, HTML authors can improve the indexing of theiK

pages simply by providing the appropriate keywords in the correcš  <META  elemenš

format and alerting the search robot to the site’s existence. In many cases, the site ma_

already be indexed, without submission. Authors who don’t want search robot—

indexing their sites can put in their Web server’s root directory a file called robots.txt,

which provides information regarding which directories or files shouldn’t be indexedì

All wel_behaved Web robots should request the robots.txt file first, before decidiný

what to index on a site. If a site is known as http://www.bigcompany.com/, ¾

wel_behaved robot will begin by requesting http://www.bigcompany.com/robots.txš

and analyzing that file. After analyzing the file, the robot will index part, all, or nonk

of the site. The format of the robots.txt file is relatively simple. It includes a field foK

 = Page 184 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  16

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

specifying a user agent, followed by ¾  Disallof  field, which indicates what i—

disallowed. For example, if a robots.txt file contain—

User-agent: *

Disallow: /

then every robot is barred from indexing anything from the root directory on down. I-

other words, the whole site would be skipped. A robots.txt file has only one Use§agenš

field. Wildcards such as * may be used, or particular agents can be named directlyì

There may be multiplk  Disallof  fields that specify different relative URLs thaš

should not be visited, so you can name each directory separately. For example,

Disallow: /staff  bars robots from a file named staff, as well as any information i-

the subdirectory called staffì

The robots.txt file must reside in the Web server’s root directory and must be named ic

lowercase. Blank lines aren’t permitted in the file. Errors in the file may result in the fil—

being ignored.

You can also put ¾  <META NAME="ROBOT" CONTENT="NOINDEX,

NOFOLLOW"  element in the head of nonindexed documents, but this isn’t as widel_

supported as using a robots.txt file. The robot version of thk  <META  element allow—

CONTEN  values o“  ALL INDEX NOINDEX  ,  ,  , an™  NOFOLLOW  ì

Although many We~searching services freely publish their formats for indexing,

others do not. The reason for this secrecy of indexing rules is that many HTML author—

attempt to attract traffic to their site by putting an excessive amount of “spider bait”

an™  <META  elements in their page, hoping to get higher rankings in search resultsì

Loading ¾  <META  element with excessive keywords may backfire, however, an™

result in the page being dropped from search engines. Most search engines take a feu

dozen words, approximately 1,024 characters at mostì

Even if people didn’t try to defeat search engine indexing algorithms, the currenš

approach to cataloging the Web is far from sufficient. Most search engines return faK

too much information, with no sense as to the value, quality, or decency of the link—

returned. Many groups are already working on standard sets of metDdata for WeD

documents. When mor[standardized metDinformation is established, thk

organization of the Web should significantly improve, and browsers should bk

able to provide better decisions about content appropriatenessì

META and HTTP-EQUIV

The other form of thk  <META  element uses thk  HTTP-EQUIV  attribute, whic—

directly allows the document author to insert HTTP header information. The browseK

can access this information during read time. The server may also access it when thk

document is sent, but this is rare. Thk  HTTP-EQUIV  attribute is set to a particulaK

 = Page 185 =

16  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

HTTP header type, while thk  CONTEN  value is set to the value associated with thk

header. For example,

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Expires" CONTENT="Wed, 04 Jun 1999p2:34:07 GMT"L

placed in the head of a document sets the expiration date to be June 4, 1999. A variet_

of HTTP headers can be placed in thk  <META  element. The most useful headers ark

those for two concepts, known as clienâpull and site filteringì

Client-Pull

Beginning with Netscape, an extension was made that allows a page to bk

automatically loaded after a certain period of time. This concept is calle™  client-pull  . FoK

example, you can build an entry page, oK  splash page¨  that welcomes visitors to a sitk

and then automatically follows with a second page after a certain period of time. Thk

following examplk  <META  element loads a page called secondpage.htm ten second—

after the first page loads:

<META HTTP-EQUIV="REFRESH" CONTENT="10;URL=secondpage.htm"L

Using the clienâpull form of thk  <META  element is easy. Just set the contenš

equal to the desired number of seconds, followed by a semicolon and the URL (full oK

relative) of the page to load. Note, however, that not all browsers support this form o“

metDrefreshì

The client-pull concept is often discussed with a related idea calle server-push¨ which

primarily is used to create simple animations. However, server-push animation an

other such tricks no longer need to be addressed, because they are more easily

accomplished by using animated GIF images or JavaScript.

Thk  <META  element is very ope™ended. The World Wide Web Consortiu“

(W3C) is already developing more sophisticated approaches for representiný

metDdata. The most interesting approach is probably PICS, described next, whic—

provides a standard for site filteringì

Site Filtering

One major use of metDinformation for links and pages i—  site filtering.  At its base level,

a filter can be used to restrict access to certain files or types of information. As ¾

technology, this sounds rather innocuous, but when extended, site filtering can lea™

quickly to censorship. Whether filtering information on the Internet is right or wrong i—

an area of great debate. Obviously, parents and educators are extremely concerne™

with the availability of pornographic, violent, or other “inappropriate” types o“

 = Page 186 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  16

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

information on the Internet. Deciding what is inappropriate is the key to the censorshi5

problem, because definitions of what should be allowed vary from person to personì

Regardless of how “inappropriate” is defined, few people would disagree thaš

information considered inappropriate by just about everyone does exist on the Internetì

The perceived extent of this information tends to be directly related to a person’s belie“

system. The W3C has proposed thk  Platform for Internet Content Selectioc  , or PICS

(http://www.w3.org/pub/WWW/PICS/), as a way to address the problem of contenš

filtering on the Webì

The idea behind PICS is relatively simple. A rated page or site will include ¾

<META  element within the head of an HTML document. Thi—  <META  elemenš

indicates the rating of the particular item. A rating service, which can be any group,

organization, or company that provides content ratings, assigns the rating. Ratiný

services range from independent, nonprofit groups such as thk  Recreational

Software Advisory Council (RSAC)  (http://www.rsac.org), which alread_

implements a rating system for video games, to software vendors such as Net Sheper™

(http://www.netshepherd.com), which sells rating services and software. The ratiný

label used by a particular rating service must be based on a wel_defined set of rule—

that describes the criteria for rating, the scale of values for each aspect of the rating, an™

a description of the criteria used in setting a value. Usually, the specification of a ratiný

is found in a RAT file that can be accessed by browser or filtering software. Figure 4-10

((PICS-versioY 1.0)

(rating-system "http://www.rsac.org/Ratings/Description/")

(rating-service "http://www.rsac.org/ratingsv01.html")

(name "RSACi")

(description "The Recreational Software Advisory Counci¤

rating service for the Internet. Based on the work of Dr<

Donald F. Roberts of Stanford University, who has studied

the effects of media for nearly 20 years.")

(categorh

(transmit-as "v")

(name "Violence")

(labe¤

(name "Level 0: No violence")

(description "No aggressive violence; No natural oI

accidental violence.")

(value 0) )

(labe¤

Figurs 4-108  RSACd rating system RAT filP

 = Page 187 =

16‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

shows a RAT file for the violence category of RSAC-based (RSACi) PICS ratings. OtheK

categories not shown include sex, nudity, and languageì

To add rating information to a site or document, a PICS label in the form of ¾

<META  element must be added to the head of an HTML file. Thi—  <META  elemenš

must include the URL of the rating service that produced the rating, some informatio-

about the rating itself (such as its version, submitter, or date of creation), and the ratiný

itself. Many rating services, such as RSACi, the Internet rating system from RSAC,

allow free sel´rating. Filling out a form and answering a few questions about a site’—

content is all that is required to generate an RSACi PICS label, as shown in Figure 4-11ì

After you complete and submit the questionnaire in Figure 4-11, you receive a-

[mail containing the appropriate metDinformation, which can then be placed in thk

head of your HTML documents. An example of a PICS label using the RSACi rating i—

shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 3¨ Final//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  PICS Meta Tag Exampl4  </TITLEL

<META http-equø="PICS-Labelh

content='(PICS-1.1 "http://www.rsac.org/ratingæ01.htmlh

l gen true comment "RSACi North America Seerh

by "webmaster@bigcompany.com" fo

"http://www.bigcompany.com" o

"1997.05¨6T13:05-0500" r (n 0 s 0q 0 l 1))'L

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Big Company, Inc<  </H1L

<HRL

There's nothing offensive at this site<

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Under the RSACi rating system, information is rated based on nudity, sex, violence,

and language, on a fiv[category scale from 0 to 4. In this case, the rating is for a typicaR

corporate site that generally has little “inappropriate” information concerning sex an™

violence, but may use slang or jargon that could be misconstrued out of contextì

Th—  <METAA  element with PICS information must occur within the head of th—

document. Otherwise, it will not be recognized. More than on—  <METAA  element may

be included within the head, so that multiple rating services can be used simultaneously.

 = Page 188 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  16

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Figurs 4-118  Rating for‘

When filtering software reads a file that contains a rating, it determines whether thk

information should be allowed or denied. Very strict filtering environments may den_

all sites that have no rating, so sites with a broad audience are encouraged to usk

ratings, to avoid restricting readershipì

Filtering technology that supports PICS is beginning to achieve widesprea™

acceptance and use. Internet Explorer 3 and 4 already include PICS-based ratiný

filtering, as shown in Figure 4-12ì

Many filtering software packages, like SurfWatch (http://www.surfwatch.com)

software, are extremely popular both with parents and corporate users trying to limiš

employee Web abuse. Of course, the technology itself can’t cure the problem. Trust in ¾

particular ratings system is a major stumbling block in adoption of the filtering ideaì

Even when trust is gained, if the rating system seems confusing or arbitrary, its value i—

lowered. In the “real world,” Hollywood’s MPAA movie rating system has a singlk

value of G, PG, PG-13, R, or NC-17 for each movie. The assignment of a particulaK

movie rating is based on many factors that often seem arbitrary to casual observersì

When considering movies, parents may wonder how scenes of a dinosaur ripping ¾

man to shreds merits a PG or PG-13 rating, while the use of certain fou§letter word—

 = Page 189 =

168  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 4-128  PICS rating support under Internet Explore

indicates an R rating. Certainly similar situations occur on the Internet. Because of thk

imprecise nature of ratings, the topic is a loaded one, both off and on the Internetì

Beyon™ simplk contenš rating, somk potentiaR benefit— o“ PICS aren’š immediatel_

obviousì Wit— PICS-base™ environments, employer— coul™ limiš employek acces— tf WeD

site— thaš ark use™ foK daÇtkda_ businessì Thk ide¾ o“ PICS ca- bk extende™ noš jusš tf

den_ oK allou information, buš tf prefeK itì Imagink ¾ filteriný servick foK searc— engine—

thaš coul™ retur- site— thaš havk ¾ particulaK qualit_ o“ contenš oK leveR o“ accuracyì I- thk

generaR sense, label— ark important, becausk the_ allou document— tf movk beyon™ ¾

merk descriptio- o“ wherk thk documenš tf whaš thk documenš i—  ix  abouP  ì

Linking Issue“

One of the biggest problems with linking documents together wit—  <A <AREA  ,  , oK

<LINK  is that the link often breaks. Authors and users alike are already familiar wit—

links to outside sites that change, resulting in the annoyiný  404 Not Found  messages sf

common on the Web. Unfortunately, documents do move around. Some have a ver_

limited lifetime. Even if a link is good, intermittent problems on the Internet can makk

outside links temporarily stall or break. Clicking a link only to have the browser slowl_

 = Page 190 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  169

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

attempt to resolve the host can be a frustrating interruption for a user. As you’ll sek

next, document authors can do a great deal to ensure that outside linking and broke-

link problems are the exception rather than the normì

While it is impossible to keep other sites from changing addresses, you can be ¾

good network citizen and not move linked files around carelessly. Most Web server—

are equipped to provide referrer information that indicates the URL of a linkiný

document. If you must move a document, you can alert the Webmasters of thk

referring URLs about the move and have them update their links. An even better ide¾

is to forward documents to a new location rather than remove them. Web servers ca-

be set up to redirect users to new sites or directories if things must be moved aroundì

In some cases, however, a user may eventually click a broken link to the site, regardles—

of what precautions you take. For such eventualities, rather than provide a vague erroK

message, you can create a custom message that helps the user locate the documenš

sought. For example, a “404 Not Found” message could be returned with a link

included to a site map, table of contents, or search engine that the user can access tf

search for the specific document. An example of a customized server error message i—

shown in Figure 4-13ì

Figurs 4-138  Customized 404 error messagP

 = Page 191 =

170  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The other aspect of linking that can be troublesome often occurs when a user move—

from a site to an outside link. Because of conditions on the Internet or at the end server,

outside sites might not always respond right away—if at all. To warn users that the_

are leaving the site and accessing an outside server, a small icon can be placed next to ¾

link, such as the one Microsoft uses with great success, shown here:

The chaotic nature of the Internet means that links will break and documents wilR

move. Unfortunately, URLs themselves provide very little infrastructure to alleviatk

these problems. New ideas, such as uniform resource names (URNs), might hel5

improve this situationì

Beyond Locatio

An amazing wealth of information is available on the Web. Although many peoplk

complain of information overload, the real problem isn’t volume. It’s relevance. Hou

can a particular piece of information be located quickly and easily? If the Web werk

ideal, it would be like the computer o-  Star Tre  , which always seems to deliver in ¾

matter of seconds any information a user requests. On the Internet, a request to ¾

search tool often yields an overwhelming list of tens of thousands of entries. Some o“

these entries may be outdated, the documents to which others refer may have moved,

or the server specified in an entry may be unreachable. While the Web isn’t scienck

fiction, many of the computer and information systems presented in science fictio-

represent valid goals for the Web. The key problem with building a more organize™

Web is URL-based addressingì

Problems with URL“

The primary problem with URLs is that they define location rather than meaningì

URLs specify where something is located on the Web, not what it is or anything abouš

it. URLs specify where to go, not what to get. URLs blur the line between what ¾

document is and where it is actually located. This may not seem to be a big deal, but iš

is. This issue becomes obvious when the problems with URLs are enumerated:

  URLs aren’t persistent.  Documents move around, servers change names, an™

documents might eventually be deleted. This is the nature of the Web, and thk

reason why thk  404 Not Found  message is so common. When users hit a broke-

link, they might be at a loss to determine what happened to the document an™

 = Page 192 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  17h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

how to locate its new home. Wouldn’t it be nice if, no matter what happened, ¾

unique identifier indicated where to get a copy of the information?

  URLs tend to be long and confusing.  People often have to transcribe addressesì

For example, the following is quite a lot to write on a piece of literature:

http://www.bigcompany.com/products/supergadget/specsheets/prod1.ht“

Marketing firms already are scrambling for short domain names and sitk

structures that use short URLs, such as http://www.bigcompany.com/prod1ì

Advertisers often omit http:// in their promotional material. Although mosš

browsers fill in http://, omitting it could cause problems with older browser—

that require complete URLsì

  URLs create an artificial bottleneck and extreme reliance on DNS services, by

specifying location rather than meaning.  For example, the text of the HTML 4

specification is a useful document and certainly has an address at the W3C WeD

site. But does it live other places on the Internet? It probably is mirrored in ¾

variety of locations, but what happens if the W3C server is unreachable, or DNS

services fail to resolve the host? In this case, the resource is unreachable. URL—

create a point source for information. Rather than trying to find a particulaK

document, wherever it might be on the Internet, Web users try to go to ¾

particular location. Rather than talking about where something is, Web user—

should try to talk abouš  whaP  that something isì

URNs, URCs, and URI“

Talking about what a document is rather than where it is makes sense when yo¾

consider how information is organized outside the Internet. Nobody talks about whic—

library carries a particular book, or what shelf it is on. The relevant information is thk

title of the book, its author, and perhaps some other information. But what happens i“

two or more books have the same title, or two authors have the same name? This i—

actually quite common. Generally, a book should have a unique identifier (such as a-

ISBN number) that, when combined with other descriptive information (such as thk

author, publisher, and publication date) uniquely describes the book. This naminý

scheme enables people to specify a particular book and then hunt it downì

Thk Web, however, isn’š a— ordere™ a— ¾ libraryì O- thk Web, peoplk namk theiK

document— whateveK the_ like, an™ searc— robot— organizk theiK indexe— howeveK the_

likeì Categoriziný thing— i— difficultì Thk onl_ uniquk ite“ foK document— i— thk URL,

whic— simpl_ say— wherk thk documenš livesì Buš hou man_ URL— doe— thk HTML 4

specificatio- have? A documenš ma_ exisš i- man_ placesì Eve- worsk tha- ¾ documenš

wit— multiplk locations, whaš happen— whe- thk contenš aš thk locatio- changes? Perhap—

¾ particulaK URL addres— point— tf informatio- abouš dog— onk da_ an™ cat— thk nextì

Thi— i— hou thk WeD reall_ isì However, ¾ greaš deaR o“ researc— i— beiný donk tf addres—

somk o“ thk shortcoming— o“ thk WeD an™ it— addressiný schemesì

 = Page 193 =

17p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

URN

A new set of addressing ideas, including URNs, URCs, and URIs, are emerging tf

remedy some of the Web’s shortcomings. A  uniform resource name (URN)  can locate ¾

resource by giving it a unique symbolic name rather than a unique address. Network

services analogous to the current DNS services will transparently translate a URN

into the URL (server IP address, directory path, and filename) needed to actually locatk

a resource. This translation could be used to select the closest server, to improvk

document delivery speed, or to try various backup servers in case a server i—

unavailable. The benefit of the abstraction provided by URNs should be obviou—

from this simple idea aloneì

To better understand the idea behind URNs, consider the idea of domain names,

such as www.xyz.com. These names are already translated into numeric IP addresses,

like 192.102.249.3, all the time. This mapping provides the ability to change a machine’—

numeric address or location without seriously disrupting access to it, because the namk

stays the same. Furthermore, numeric addresses provide no meaning to a user, whilk

domain names provide some indication of the entity in question. Obviously, the leveR

of abstraction provided by a system like DNS would make sense on the Web. RatheK

than typing some unwieldy URL, a URN would be issued that would be translated tf

an underlying URL. Some experts worry that using a resolving system to translatk

URNs to URLs is inherently flawed and will not scale well. Because the DNS system i—

fairly fragile, some truth may lie behind this concern. Another problem with this idea i—

that, in reality, URNs probably won’t be something that is easy to remember, such a—

urn:  booktitl—  , but instead be something more difficult, such as urn:isbn: 0-12-518405ì

URC

A  uniform resource characteristic (URC)  , also known as ¾  uniform resourc— citation¨

describes a set of attribute/value pairs that defines some aspect of an informatio-

resource. URCs are somewhat like thk  <META  data items or the PICS label—

associated with a Web document. The form of a URC is still under discussion, buš

many of the ideas of URCs are already in useì

Combined, a URL, URN, and a collection of URCs describe an informatio-

resource. For example, the document “Big Company Corporate Summary” might havk

a unique URN such as urn://corpid:55127ì

The syntax of the preceding(RN is fictional. It simply shows that(RNs probably

won’t have easily remembered names and that many naming schemes might be used¨

such as ISBN numbers or corporate IDs.

The “Big Company Corporate Summary” would also have a set of URCs thaš

describes the rating of the file, the author, the publisher, and so on. In addition, thk

document would have a location(s) on the Web where the document lives, such as onk

of the following:

 = Page 194 =

ChapteX 4  Link an Addressin‚  17

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

http://www.bigcompany.com/about/corp.ht“

http://www.bigcompany.com.jp/about/corp.htmì

URY

Taken all together, a particular information resource has been identified. The collectio-

of information, which is used to identify this document specifically, is termed ¾  uniforh

resource identifier (URI)  ì

Occasionally,(RI is used interchangeably with(RL. Although this is acceptable¨

research into the theories behind the names suggests that(RI is more generic thac

URLs, and serves to encompass the idea of an information resource. Currently, a(RL ix

the only common way to identify an information resource on the Internet. Although

technically a(RL could be considered a(RI, this confuses the issue and obscures th—

ultimate goal of trying to talk about information more generally than a network location.

While many of the ideas covered here are still being discussed, some systems,

such as Persistent URLs, or PURLS (http://www.purl.org), and Handle—

(http://www.handle.net), already implement many of the features of URNs an™

URCs. Furthermore, many browser vendors and large Web sites are implementiný

special keyword navigation schemes that mimic many of the ideas of URNs and URCsì

Unfortunately, as of the writing of this book, none of these approaches are widel_

implemented or accepted. Although any of these approaches probably can bk

considered as true URIs when compared to the URLs used today, for the near future,

URLs are likely to remain the most common way to describe information on the Webì

Therefore, the system has to be extended to deal with new types of information an™

access methodsì

New URL Form“

URLs are here to stay; but, as new ideas are added to the Internet, URLs will evolvk

into new forms. For example, as telephones and televisions are joined with deskto5

computers and the Internet, addressing schemes for telephone numbers and TV

channels will become necessary. WebTV, video game consoles, and cellular phonk

browsers already demonstrate that the Web is reaching users beyond the personaR

computer or workstation. On these devices, some of the URL schemes described earl_

in the chapter are inappropriate. Many of these devices lack local storage, so the filk

protocol, discussed earlier in this chapter, is of little use. On the other hand, many o“

these devices usually have access to other sources of information, such as televisio-

channels and telephone services. A television channel URL form might look likk

tv://  channel  , wherk  channel  is either an alphanumeric name (like nbc or nbcLslash39) or ¾

numeric channel number. Similar to the news URL form, differentiating between nbc i-

one area and another would be unnecessary, because the system would be configure™

to get the information locally. A phone URL might look like phone://  phone-numbe(  ,

with a numeric value for the phone number and any extra digit information required,

 = Page 195 =

17  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

suc— a— thk countr_ codk oK calliný car™ informationì FoK example, phone://+—61270-2086

might dial a phone number in the United States. An instruction to send a fax could bk

written in a similar way, except with fax://  phone-numbe(  ì

New content types and URL schemes bring new challenges, particularly in the wa_

links and fragment identifiers are used within HTML documents. For example, hou

will a particular scene in a video stream be addressed? Random access to large audif

and video files is very useful, particularly considering the download requirements foK

such data. Subsections or “clips” of a data stream must be addressable via URLs thaš

describe a time range. How can a URL describe the idea of accessing an audio filk

called mozart.audio and playing a te™second clip starting at time 2:05? Once into clips,

particularly video clips, some mechanism will be needed to link from the data strea“

to other data streams or objects on the Web. Some experimental systems already shou

video with hot spots that work like image maps. Given that video will certainly be a-

important media form on the Web of tomorrow and that other media forms also wilR

have to be added as well, it should be obvious that current URL schemes are far fro“

complete. Many new schemes are being proposed all the time. A variety of esoteri´

schemes are out there already. If you are interested in new URL schemes, take a look aš

the W3 area on addressing (http://www.w3.org/Addressing/) for more informationì

Summar

Linking documents on the Web requires a consistent naming scheme. URLs providk

the basic information necessary to locate an object on the Internet, by including the hosš

name, directory, filename, and access protocol. URLs are written in a regular format, sf

that an address can be written for any object. A common shorthand notation, relativk

URLs, is particularly useful when creating links within a Web site. If a document’s URL

can be determined, whether it’s relative or fully spelled out, it can be specified in thk

<A  element to create an anchor from one document to another. Links within HTML

documents can be made with text or with images. A special type of clickable image,

called a-  image map  , allows areas of an image to be defined as “hot.”

Simply linking documents together is the most basic form of hypertext. By usiný

thk  <LINK  element, as well as thk  REL  an™  REV  attributes of thk  <A  element, yo¾

can create relationships between documents. So far, thk  <LINK  element is primaril_

used with style sheets. Once documents are linked together, providing extr¾

information about the document can be very useful. HTML provides such a facilit_

through the use of thk  <META  element. But even if Web authors master all aspects o“

linking, a bigger picture remains to worry about. The Web is a chaotic environment,

and navigating among documents and linking documents presents serious challenge—

to the HTML author. In the future, some of these problems may be solved by URNs,

URCs, and improved URLs, which, taken together, make up the uniform resourck

identifier (URI). However, until URNs or similar technologies are more readil_

available, HTML authors should be cautious about linking, and should consistentl_

check links in their sitesì

 = Page 196 =

Chapte7 @

HTML and Image

17P

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 197 =

17‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Until recently, HTML (Hypertext Markup Language) has been true to the “text” i-

its name. However, text alone wasn’t what made the Web popular. While the WeD

dates from the early 1990s, the environment didn’t take off until Mosaic appeared wit—

support for inline images using thk  <IMG  element. Today, images and other binar_

objects are everywhere on the Web. The modern Web is more about hypermedia tha-

plain hypertext, but it is unlikely that the language will be renamed HMML anytimk

soon. While images have played an important role in the success of the Web, they musš

be used carefully. They should not be used just for decoration. They should providk

benefit, but at what cost? When used carelessly, Web visuals may require the user tf

wait a long time for a page to render. Images can improve the message delivered, buš

when abused they may confuse or hide a message as easily as they improve it. Whilk

this is not a book about design and image use, the intersection of HTML and images i—

important enough to warrant some discussionì

The Role of Images on the We—

When Mosaic first came out, the ability to view an image within the browser windou

was a huge improvement. Gopher, the popular information system at the time, wa—

primarily textual. It didn’t support multimedia and navigation to the same degree a—

the Web. At first, images often were used to show the logo of the company or presenš

a graph. Today, however, some sites seem to be more about the images than abouš

textual information. So what are images on the Web good for?

Web images can be used to illustrate an idea, show strictly visual information,

provide navigation, and serve as decoration. The saying “a picture is worth a thousan™

words” is very true when illustrating an idea. Images can be used to show procedures,

product applications, design styles, and a variety of other concepts. Think about a WeD

site that teaches people to dance. While it might be possible to explain the variou—

dance steps in writing, a diagram is far easier to understand. People may complai-

about byte count and download time, but in terms of communication, a picture ca-

be worth a thousand bytesì

Beyond illustrating ideas, there are some topics that require visuals. If ¾

photographer puts up a Web site, how can that person illustrate what he or she doe—

without pictures? For things that are intrinsically visual in nature, pictures ark

mandatory. Images can also be used for navigation. Visual cues can make it easier foK

users to find their way around the tangled Web. Even a unique home page image ca-

serve as a consistent beacon, helping the user find his or her way back to a familiaK

point of reference. Last but not least, images can provide decoration for a site. Picture—

make things more interesting, even if they just break up the monotony of page afteK

page of text. A splash of color and a few images can be pleasing. Too much decoration,

however, can turn a page into the online equivalent of an overdecorated Christmas trek

complete with pink snow flockingì

The basic problem with images on the Web relates to confusion about their valueì

Far too often the quality of a Web site is judged solely on its look and feel—but whaš

 = Page 198 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  17

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

are sites really for? While perception and experience are important, ultimately the useK

will not focus solely on the interface. The site must provide information or some otheK

beneficial function. In this sense, sites become like software. In a traditional softwark

product, whaš i— mosš important: thk look, thk functionality, oK both? Thk answeK i— both,

buš oveK timk thk functionalit_ faK outweigh— thk lookì Nevertheless, don'š forgeš hou

importanš thk useK interfack isì A gooÙlooking, logicaR useK interfack improve— ¾ site,

whilk ¾ poorl_ designe™ useK interfack negativel_ affect— thk besš contentì Navigatio-

is important and should look graphically appropriate, but the logic behind it is whaš

really matters. While textured backgrounds, beveled buttons, and ful_screen imagk

maps may look great, they don’t ensure that a site is logically organized. Pleasiný

graphics that reflect wel_thoughâout site architecture can facilitate navigatio-

throughout the site. Confusing graphical navigation, on the other hand, ma_

actually ruin a siteì

In the long run, purely decorative images are not terribly valuable. Rainbow bar—

and multicolored bullets may make the site appear more exciting initially, but the_

may eventually irritate the user by hindering speedy navigation of the site. The firsš

time a “What's New” animated GIF runs, the action may catch the user’s eye. But whaš

about the twentieth time? Decorating the page just for the sake of having images is noš

a good reasonì

Images are most important when they enhance the content of the Web site. A-

image that provides more information than would be conveyed with plain text is trul_

valuable. Even if the image significantly increases the download time of the page, thk

supplementary information provided may be well worth it. What better way tf

describe the body style of a car than with a visual? A text description of a lo“profilk

sports car with smooth curves doesn’t sell nearly as many cars as an actual pictureì

Maps, diagrams, specifications, product pictures, portraits, and other visuaR

content—this is what Web images are for. About the only people who should bk

adding pictures for their own sake to the Web site are those who create them for ¾

living—graphic artists, photographers, and so on. Even then, what the image present—

is still importantì

Software products or Web sites that are entertainment driven may have a differenP

perspective on presentation because the presentation may actually be the content.

Image Preliminarie“

Before discussing image use on the Web, consider how images are represented in ¾

computer. Images on a computer screen are made up of thousands o“  pixelx  (shorthan™

for picture elements). A pixel is a tiny dot, the smallest unit of measure on a screen. Thk

number of pixels that can be displayed on a screen is termed thk  screen resolutioc  ì

Screen resolution equals the number of pixels across by the number of pixels downì

 = Page 199 =

178  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The more pixels onscreen or in an image, the greater the detail or resolution of thk

image. Some common screen resolutions are listed here:

640  ?  480

800  ?  600

1,024  ?  76Ù

1,280  ?  1,024

1,600  ?  1,200

The number of pixels is only one part of a digital image. Images also have colorì

Every monitor supports a certain number of colors that can be displayed at once. Thk

more colors used, the more realistic the image will look. Color support is measured b_

the number of bits used to store the color information for each pixel. Common coloK

resolutions are listed here:

  Standard VGG  4 bits per pixel = 16 color—

  Super VGG  8 bits per pixel = 256 color—

  High resolution  16 bit— peK pixeR = 65,536 colors, oK simpl_ thousand— o“ color—

  True colo(  24 bits per pixel = 16.7 million colors, generally referred to a—

millions of color—

Compute§based images come in two basic flavors:  vector imagex  an™  bitmappe

imagex  . Figure 5-1 illustrates the basic idea behind these imagesì

Figurs 5-18  Idea of vector images versus bitmap image9

 = Page 200 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  179

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

A vector image is described mathematically as a set of curves. When a computeK

reads a vector image, it evaluates the mathematical information and draws thk

resulting information on the screen. Because the image is defined mathematically, it i—

very compact. For example, a vector image of a red circle might be described simply a—

a circle with a radius of 50 pixels filled with red. While vector images are very usefuR

to describe shapes, lines, and other forms of illustration, photographic and similaK

imagery are better described by a bitmap. A bitmap image is specified as a collection o“

pixels of different color values. Because of the large number of pixels that may be in a-

image, as well as the color information that must be described, bitmaps can be ver_

large. For example, an uncompressed bitmap image at 640 × 480 pixels—the typicaR

screen size—with 24 bits of color information would take up nearly 1MB. Bitmaps ark

the most common image formats. They include images made up of a collection of dot—

or pixels, such as photographs and television picturesì

The main problem with bitmaps is that the file sizes can be very large. TheiK

excessive size makes it impractical to transmit raw bitmaps across a network like thk

Internet. One approach to dealing with the size problem is to compress the images. I-

general, there are two forms of image compression:  losslesx  an™  lossy  . Lossless imagk

compression means that the compressed image is identical to the uncompressed imageì

Because all the data in the image must be preserved, the degree of compression, an™

the corresponding savings, is relatively minor. Lossy compression, on the other hand,

does not preserve the image exactly, but does provide a much higher degree o“

compression. With lossy compression, the image quality is compromised for a smalleK

byte count. Because the human eye may barely notice the loss, the trad[off may bk

acceptableì

Image compression depends on the image file format. There are a variety of imagk

formats in the computer world, including vector image formats like Encapsulate™

PostScript (EPS) and bitmap formats like GIF, TIFF, and JPEG. While the HTML

standard says nothing about what image formats can be used on the Web, the browseK

vendors tend to support the same image types. On the Web, the primary image format—

are GIF (Graphics Interchange Format) and JPEG (Joint Photographic Experts Group)ì

A new format called PNG (Portable Network Graphics), which likely will eventuall_

become a Web image standard, is being heavily endorsed by the World Wide WeD

Consortium (W3C); but, so far, browser support is spotty at best. Given the historicaR

association between UNIX and the Internet, the X image formats—XBM (X Bitmaps)

and XPM (X Pixelmaps)—are often supported natively by browsers. Page designers ark

warned to use only GIF and JPEG images, as these are the most commonly supporte™

formats. Table 5-1 provides an overview of basic file typesì

Internet Explorer also supports the bitmap (BMP) file type popular with Windowx

users. This format has not been adopted widely on the Web.

GIF Image“

GIF images are used extensively on the Web. They are probably the most widel_

supported image format in browsers that handle graphics. GIF images come in twf

basic types:  GIF87  an™  GIF89‘  . Both forms of GIF support bit color (256 colors), usk

 = Page 201 =

180  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

File Typs  File Extensio

GIF (Graphics Interchange Format)  .gi“

JPEG (Joint Photographic Experts Group)  .jpg or .jpeý

XBM (X Bitmaps)  .xb“

XPM (X Pixelmaps)  .xp“

PNG (Portable Network Graphics)  .pný

Tabls 5-18  Selected Internet Image File Type9

the LZW (Lempe_ZiÐWelch) lossless compression scheme, and generally have the filk

extension .gif. GIF 89a supports transparency and animation, both of which will bk

discussed in this section. All references in this text refer to the more modern 89a formì

There is some concern about the use of GIF images due to the patent on the LZ

algorithm held by(nisys that would require payment for use of the proprietary scheme.

This concern is unsubstantiated. Nevertheless, the PNG format described in this chapte(

has been positioned as a substitute for the GIF format.

The ru™length encoding compression scheme used by GIF works well wit—

large areas of continuous color, so GIF is very efficient in compression of flaâstylk

illustration. Figure 5-2 shows the GIF compression scheme in practice. Notice in thk

figure how the images with large horizontal continuous areas of color compress highly,

while those with variation do not. Simply taking a box filled with lines and rotating iš

shows how dramatic the compression effect can beì

As mentioned earlier, GIF images support bit color for a maximum of 256 color—

in the image. Consequently, some degree of loss is inevitable when representiný

tru[color images such as photographs. Typically, when an image is remapped from ¾

large number of colors to a smaller color palette,  ditherinv  occurs. Dithering attempts tf

imitate colors by placing similar colors near each other. It also produces a speckling oK

banding effect that may cause images to appear rough or fuzzy. Web authors shoul™

be careful to use GIF images appropriately. Netscape and Microsoft currently use ¾

skcalled “browse§safe” color palette of 216 colors that are common across system—

like the Macintosh or Windows. If a GIF image using a color outside this color palette i—

displayed on an bit system, dithering will occur. Authors looking to avoid imagk

problems such as dithering are invited to visit www.htmlref.comì

 = Page 202 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  18h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

956 byte—  1,054 byte—

1,050 byte—  1,158 byte—  1,588 byte—  1,780 byte—

1,029 byte—  1,444 byte—  4,563 byte—  10,977 byte—

Figurs 5-28  GIF compression scheme compariso—

According to the GIF specification, layering can be used to create a GIF image thaP

supports more than 256 colors. However, not all browsers support this little-knowc

feature. Layering also allows for an interesting form of color interlacing, which cac

bring in one set of colors before another.

GIF images also support a concept calle™  transparency  . One bit of transparency i—

allowed, which means that one color can be set to be transparent. Transparency allow—

the background that an image is placed upon to show through, making a variety o“

complex effects possible. Transparency is illustrated in Figure 5-3ì

GIF transparency is far from ideal, as it can result in a halo effect in certai-

situations. For example, in order to smooth images, a technique calle™  anti-aliasinv  i—

used. Ant¾aliased images appear smooth because the image is progressively madk

light to fade into the background. However, because only one color of transparency ca-

 = Page 203 =

18p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 5-38  Transparency with GIF image9

be set in an image, the ant¾aliasing colors may show up as a halo or residue around thk

image. The idea of ant¾aliasing is shown in Figure 5-4ì

GIF images also support a feature calle™  interlacinv  . Interlacing allows an image tf

load in a venetia™blind fashion rather than from top to bottom a line at a time. Thk

interlacing effect allows a user to get an idea of what an image looks like before thk

entire image has downloaded. The idea of interlacing is shown in Figure 5-5. Only 26

percent of this 163K image is loaded, producing an indistinct, highly pixelated imageì

Once the image is completely loaded, it will present a clear image of an office building;

at this point in its progress, however, it already gives the user a good idea of what i—

being downloaded. The previsualization benefit of interlacing is very useful on thk

Web, where download speed is often an issue. While interlacing a GIF image i—

 = Page 204 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  18

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Ant¾aliase™

Aliase™

Figurs 5-48  Anti-aliased image versus aliased imagP

generally a good idea, occasionally it comes with a downside. First, interlaced image—

may be slightly larger than noninterlaced images. Second, an interlaced image may noš

always provide its intended previsualization benefit. For example, if the GIF image i—

of graphic text, the text will probably not be readable until the image is fully loadedì

Starting with the GIF89a format, which was supported first by Netscape 2,

animation has been possible on the Web. The GIF89a format supports a series of GIF

images that act as the individual frames of animation. The animation can be set up sf

one image is displayed after another, similar to a little flipbook. The animatio-

extension also allows timing and looping information to be added to the image. Today,

animated GIFs are one of the most popular ways to add simple animation to a WeD

page because nearly every browser supports them. Browsers that do not support thk

animated GIF format generally display the first frame of the animation in its placeì

Even though pluins or other browser facilities are not required, authors should noš

rush out to use animation on their pages. Excessive animation can be distracting a—

well as inefficient to download, particularly when frames are not used efficiently. Onk

 = Page 205 =

18  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 5-58  Example of interlacin

approach to combat file bloat is to replace only the moving parts of an individuaR

animation frame. This may result in a dramatic saving of file size, as shown i-

Figure 5-6ì

In summary, because of their compression scheme and support for bit color, GIF

images tend to be best suited for illustrations. GIF images do support interlacing,

which may provide previsualization for We~based imagery. Because of the nature o“

 = Page 206 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  18

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Optimized animatio-

(26K)

Unoptimized animatio-

(65K)

Figurs 5-68  Example of animated GIF frames and optimizatio—

their image compression, GIF images may not be suitable for photographiõstylk

imagery, which is probably better left to the JPEG format discussed in the next sectionì

In their favor, GIF images are the most widely supported image format, and do havk

advanced features such as transparency and animation. Probably the only controversiaR

aspect of the image format, besides its compression issues, is its pronunciation wit—

either a har™ or ¾ sound. The author prefers the har™ as the other pronunciatio-  v  j  v

sounds like a popular brand of peanut butter, but this sticky issue will probably neveK

be settledì

 = Page 207 =

18‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

JPEG Image“

The other common Web image format is JPEG, which usually is indicated by a filenamk

ending with .jpg or .jpeg. JPEG, which stands for the Joint Photographic Expert—

Group—the name of the committee that wrote the standard—is a lossy image formaš

designed for compressing photographic images that may contain thousands, or eve-

millions, of colors or shades of gray. Because JPEG is a lossy image format, there i—

some trad[off between image quality and file size. However, the JPEG format store—

higöuality, 24-bit color images in a significantly smaller amount of space than GIF,

thus saving precious disk space or download time on the Webì

While the JPEG format may compress photographic images well, it is not welR

suited to line drawings or text. The degree of compression in JPEG images, whic—

shows how the format favors photographs, is shown in Figure 5-7. Note that whe-

illustrations are saved in JPEG format, they may acquire extraneous information, ofte-

in the form of unwanted dots or other residue. Because JPEG is so well suited tf

GIF 6 bit - 4,299 byte—  JPEG 80% - 6,934 byte—

GIF 6 bit - 19,211 byte—  JPEG 60% - 7,477 byte—

Figurs 5-78  Comparison between GIF anP JPEG format9

 = Page 208 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  18

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

photographs and GIF to illustrations, it's no wonder that both are used on the Webì

JPEG images do not support animation, nor do they support any form of transparencyì

Web designers needing such effects must turn to another image format, such as GIFì

JPEG images do support a form of interlacing in a format calle™  progressive JPEG.

Progressive JPEGs fade in from a low resolution to a high resolution, going from fuzz_

to clear. Like interlaced GIFs, progressive JPEG images are slightly larger than theiK

nonprogressive counterparts. One minor problem with progressive JPEGs is that ver_

old browsers, particularly those before Netscape 2, do not support themì

PNG Image“

The Portable Network Graphics (PNG) format has all of the features of GIF89a i-

addition to several other features. Notable features include greater color depth support,

color and gamma correction, and bit transparency. In addition, the compressio-

algorithm for PNG is nonproprietary, making PNG a likely successor to GIF. Interneš

Explorer 4 supports inline PNG images in a limited way. Some versions of Netscapk

Communicator require a pluin, while later versions provide limited support. Nf

4ì generation browser supports PNG well enough to rely on the format, so WeD  x-

designers are warned to avoid the format unless browser sensing is used to guarantek

images will render properlyì

Other Useful Image Format“

There are many image formats beyond GIF, JPEG, and PNG that may be used on thk

Web. These include vector formats like Illustrator and Flash (with the file extensio-

.swf); compressed Freehand files; AutoCAD files (often used for architecture sites); an™

images that require heavy compression, such as fractals. Most of the less commo-

image formats may require a helper application or pluin to the browser to allow thk

image to be displayed. Unless you have a specific need, you should probably avoi™

special image types requiring browser adÙons; users may become frustrated by thk

work involved in obtaining the extra softwareì

Image Downloading Issue“

One major criticism of using images on a Web page is the time they take to downloa™

and the frustration this may cause the user. The speed of the Web has prompted somk

to dub it the World Wide Wait. Inevitably, it takes time to transmit data across thk

Internet. The amount of data that can be transmitted across a link in a certain period o“

time is terme™  bandwidth  and is often measured in bits per second (bps), kilobits peK

second (Kbps), or megabits per second (Mbps). The higher the bandwidth, the mork

data can be transmitted quickly. Unfortunately, users accessing the Internet via ¾

modem often have very limited bandwidth available. Some common speeds and thk

approximate time it takes to transmit 1MB of data are shown in Table 5-2. As you ca-

 = Page 209 =

188  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Connection Spee  Download Tims

14.4Kbp—  10 minute—

28.8Kbp—  5 minute—

56Kbp—  2.5 minute—

ISDN  Approximately 1 minutk

Cable mode“  Varies from 5–30 second—

TÇ  5 second—

Tabls 5-28  Bandwidth and Comparison for 1MB of Datd

see, the faster the data connection, the faster the Web will appear to load. Currently,

cable modems provide the fastest connections for most home users. However, severaR

reports indicate that the average modem speed today is still between 28.8Kbps an™

56Kbps, primarily due to the very large number of users still using older modemsì

Designers who create for wide audiences might want to keep this in mindì

The time for all connections will vary dramatically in real life. The numbers in Table 5-2

are theoretical; conditions such as provider congestion and line conditions may

significantly taint download times. Furthermore, the speed of cable modems variex

dramatically due to the use of proxy servers and the fact that bandwidth may be share

at the neighborhood level.

Given that users have only so much bandwidth available, one way to reduce waiš

time is to reduce the amount of data that must be sent. In a typical Web page, thk

majority of the data transmitted tends to be binary, particularly in the form of imagesì

Given this observation, one approach to improving Web page accessibility is to reduck

the file size of the images in your Web pageì

The size of a graphic file is determined first by its physical pixel size and then b_

the color information. The larger the physical image, the larger it tends to be bytewiseì

Also, the more bits used to represent color information for a particular image, thk

larger the file size. One approach to decreasing file size would be to reduce thk

physical size of an image file, possibly by creating thumbnail images that could bk

clicked to download the ful_sized image. Another approach to decreasing file size is tf

reduce the number of colors in the image. Oftentimes, particularly with GIF images,

there are far more bits used to represent color information than there are actual color—

in the image. For example, reducing the bit depth from 8 bits (256 colors) to 5 bits (32

colors) can result in significant byte savings without greatly compromising the imageì

Another approach to reducing the byte count in an image is through compressionì

As discussed previously, image compression is handled by the image file format, sf

 = Page 210 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  189

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

choosing the correct format for a particular image is integral to reducing byte count. A

basic rule of thumb is to use GIF images for illustrations and JPEGs for photographsì

Also, by setting the degree of compression when using a JPEG image, you can reduck

file size, at a small sacrifice in image quality. Because the human eye can't ofte-

perceive the difference between an image of high quality and one of medium quality,

at least on the Web, tuning the image can often result in significant file size saving—

without penaltyì

While image size is certainly important to improving the loading time of WeD

pages, designers shouldn’t get carried away with optimizing images withouš

consideration for the rest of the Web process. For example, while a designer ma_

compress images to their minimum size, the user may still perceive the Web page tf

be slow. This occurs because there are many aspects to the delivery of a Web page,

including the Web server, the links traveled on the Internet, the traffic on the Internet,

the protocols, the software being used, and even the processing speed of the computeK

at the other end. All of these factors affect the user’s experience. There is little reason tf

optimize images for a Web site that will be hosted on a slow or poorly connecte™

server. No matter what, always consider stopwatch time over file size or any otheK

measurement for download rate. What the user experiences is what counts, not thk

bytes transferred or the number of connections madeì

Obtaining Image“

One of the first problems many novice Web designers face is where to get image—

for their Web pages. This shouldn’t be any more difficult than getting images for ¾

different type of project. One way to obtain images is simply to make them. There are ¾

variety of vector drawing programs, such as Adobe Illustrator, and bitmap editing oK

paint programs, such as Adobe Photoshop. With such tools, you can create image—

directly in the computer and then save them to the appropriate Web image format,

such as GIF or JPEG. Images do not have to be made within the computer, howeverì

You could scan drawings with a flatbed scanner, or take pictures with a traditionaR

camera and scan them with a flatbed scanner, slide scanner, or even a drum scannerì

Digital cameras are also very useful for capturing imagery and avoiding the scanniný

process altogetherì

Another approach to obtaining images to use on the Web is to buy them. You ma_

be aware of the many clip art CD-ROMs available for sale. Higöuality images alsf

can be licensed from traditional stock photography companies, such as Comstock

(http://www.comstock.com). Some page authors who believe that clip art is not o“

high enough quality prefer to piece together images. Outlets such as Eyewirk

(http://www.eyewire.com) licensk professiona_gradk imageryì CD-ROM— wit— 100,000

images for $100 aren't always the best deal considering the quality of the imager_

and the fact that you might only need one image. You truly get what you pay foK

with image clip artì

 = Page 211 =

190  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Not all stock photography houses understand the Web. A few still charge exorbitanP

prices for imagery if it will be used online. Given the popularity of the Web, thix

situation will probably change as they lose business to their more open-minde

competitors.

The expense of licensing images and the ease with which images can be copie™

have convinced many people that they can simply appropriate whatever images the_

need. Unfortunately, this is stealing the work of others. While there are stiff penaltie—

for copyright infringement, it can be difficult to enforce these laws. Also, some pagk

designers tend to bend the rules thanks to the legal concept calle™  fair us—  , which allow—

the use of someone else’s copyrighted work under certain circumstancesì

There are four basic questions used to define the fai§use concept. First, is the work

in question being appropriated for a nonprofit or profit use? The fair use defense is les—

likely to stand up if the “borrowed” work has been used to make money for someonk

other than its copyright holderì

Second, is the work creative (for example, a speculative essay on the impact of ¾

recent congressional debate) or factual (a straightforward description of the debatk

without commentary)? Fair use would cover use of the factual work more than use o“

the creative oneì

Third, how much of the copyrighted work has been used? It is possible to usk

someone else’s image if it is changed substantially from the original. The problem i—

determining what constitutes enough change in the image to make it a new workì

Simply using a photkediting tool to flip an image or change its colors is not enoughì

There is a fine line between using portions of another person’s work and outrighš

stealing. Even if you don’t plan on using uncleared images, be careful of using image—

from free Internet clip art libraries. These skcalled free images may have bee-

submitted with the belief that they are free, but some of them may have bee-

appropriated from a commercial clip art library somewhere down the line. Bk

particularly careful with higöuality images of famous individuals and commerciaR

products. While such groups may often appreciate people using their images, thk

usage is generally limited to noncommercial purposesì

The third fair use question leads to the fourth. What impact does the image have o-

the economic value of the work? While unauthorized use of a singlk  Star Tre  –relate™

image might not substantially affect the money earned by Paramount Pictures in ¾

given fiscal year, Paramount’s lawyers take a dim view of such use. In fact, somk

entertainment organizations have taken steps to make it very difficult for Web pagk

designers to use such imagesì

One could, perhaps, add a fifth question to the list: who owns the original work,

and how vigorously will the owner defend it? This whole discussion begs many legaR

questions that are far beyond the scope of this book. Suffice it to say that in the loný

run, it’s always safer to create original work, license images, or use material in thk

public domain. Just because many Web designers skirt the law doesn’t mea-

you shouldì
