 = Page 212 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  19h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

HTML Image Basic“

To insert an image into a Web page, use thk  <IMG  element and set thk  SR‚  attributk

of the element equal to the URL of the image. As discussed in Chapter 4, the form o“

the URL may be either an absolute URL or a relative URL. Most likely, the imagk

element will use a relative URL to an image found locally. To insert a GIF image calle™

logo.gif residing in the same directory as the current document, usk

<IMG SRC="logo.gif"L

Of course, an absolute URL could also be used to reference an image on anotheK

server, for examplk

<IMG SRC="http://www.bigcompany.com/images/logo.gif"L

Using an external URL is not advised since images may move and cause the page tf

load at an uneven paceì

The SRC attribute must be included. Otherwise, browsers that support images may

display a placeholder or broken image icon.

To set up a simple example, first create a directory to hold your images. It is usuall_

a good idea to store all your image media in a directory name™  imagex  . This will hel5

you keep your site contents organized as you build the Web site. Now place a GIF

format image named photo.gif in that directory. To retrieve an image off the Internet,

you can simply righâclick with your mouse on an image and save the file to youK

directory. Macintosh users will have to hold the mouse button down on an image tf

access the menu for saving the image. Once you have a GIF image, you should be ablk

to use a short piece of HTML markup to experiment with the use o“  <IMG  ,¾ —

shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Image Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<x ALIGN="CENTER"L  Image Exampl4  </xL

<IMG SRC="images/photo.gif" WIDTH=34" HEIGHT="150" BORDER="0"L

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 213 =

19p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

A possible rendering of the image example is shown in Figure 5-8ì

UndeK thk originaR HTML 2.0 specification, beside—  SR‚  , therk werk onl_ threk otheK

attribute— tf thk  <IMG  element:  ISMAL ALIGN  ,  , an™  AL  ì LateK on, Netscapk an™

Microsofš adde™ numerou— attributes, man_ o“ whic— havk bee- incorporate™ intf thk

HTML 4.0 specificatio- thaš i— currentl_ i- progressì Thk nexš feu section— coveK thk basi´

attributesì A mork completk rundow- o“ thk imagk option— availablk wilR followì

ALT Attributs

Thk  AL  attribute was set to provide alternative text for user agents that do not displa_

images, or for graphical browsers when the user has turned image rendering off. Thk

AL  attribute’s value may display in place of the image, or be used as a tool tip oK

placeholder for information in imag[based browsers. Thk  AL  attribute's value i—

typically enclosed in double quotes and may include spaces and other charactersì

Figurs 5-88  Possible rendering of a simplP  <IMG>  examplP

 = Page 214 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  19

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

However, any HTML markup found in thk  AL  element will be rendered as plain textì

If the option to display images is turned off, the browser will display the alternativk

text, as shown in Figure 5-9ì

Many modern graphical browsers will also display thk  AL  text as the tool tip foK

the image once the pointer is positioned over the image for a period of time, as show-

in Figure 5-10. A browser may also show thk  AL  text as images load, giving the useK

something to read as the page rendersì

While some sources suggest thaš  AL  text be limited to 1,024 characters, there is nf

limit to the text that may theoretically be used. However, anything more than a feu

hundred characters may become unwieldy. Furthermore, some browsers, includiný

some versions of Netscape 4, do not handle long tool tips properly and may not wra5

the descriptive textì

Figurs 5-98  Alternative text renderin

 = Page 215 =

19  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 5-108  Tool tip rendering for ALT texd

The Importance of ALT

It is easy to forget that many different types of browsers can be used to access the Webì

While much of the world may access a page via Netscape or Microsoft products, whaš

about everyone else out there? There are many people who have access to the WeD

from a texâonly environment. Figure 5-11 shows the same page two ways: undeK

Netscape with the image turned on and as rendered under Lynxì

In addition to those who choose to access the Web via a texâonly environment,

some visually impaired people may require a different type of browser. Blind peoplk

might access the Web using a text mode browser fed into a speaking machine or usiný

 = Page 216 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  19

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Figurs 5-118  Graphical browser versus text-only browse

a browser such as pwWebSpeak (http://www.prodworks.com), which can integratk

with a voice synthesizer. Other users may access the Web via a telephone or otheK

automated system just for ease of use or quick information. Already, systems like thk

We~o™Call Voice Browser (http://www.netphonic.com) can be used to providk

automated phone access to Web sites. Imagine a situation in which an automate™

 = Page 217 =

19‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

telephone system to access the Web read, “Press 1 for corporate information, press 2 foK

product information.” Finally, what about robots that come through and index a WeD

site for relevant information? The contents of images provide no information to indexì

In all of these cases—the text mode browser, the automated Web access system, an™

the site indexing robots—images don't mean much. In these cases, thk  AL  attributk

can be very valuableì

Setting thk  AL  attribute to provide alternative information for an image can solvk

many accessibility problems, but simply setting alternative text is not adequate. Thk

biggest problem with alternative text is that it often does not really provide any benefitì

Imagine a company logo on a page for a company called Big Company. Should thk

AL  text be set to something likk  "Logo of Big Company, Inc."  ? Imagine a perso-

hearing this read out loud. Doesn‘t jusš  "Big Company, Inc."  make more sense?

AL  text for pictures of things may prove even more cryptic. A picture of thk

corporate office wit—  AL  text set to read "Picture of Corporate Office" is not terribl_

explanatory. A more detailed description such as "A picture of the exterior of the Biý

Company Corporate office—a thre[story building with beacuflavored architecturk

surrounded by large trees" is much more useful. In this case, there is some added valuk

even for the sighted user. A general rule is that if an image conveys information, thk

AL  text should convey the same information; and, if an image is simply decoration,

you can set thk  AL  text to nothing:  ALT=" "  ì

Last is the famous case of the bullet item. Many users add small red or blue circle—

or bullets to their pages. In many cases, thk  AL  text for these objects is set to bk

"bullet"  . Now think about the aggravation of seeing the wor™  bulleP  over and oveK

again on a page, not to mention hearing it read aloud. Maybe putting an asterisk woul™

be more appropriate foK  AL  text in this instanceì

While a lot of people might argue that the Web wasn’t popular until graphics werk

integrated or that the Web is inherently a visual medium, the value of textual contenš

on the Web is indisputable. Consequently, it should be made as accessible as possibleì

There is no arguing that a picture may be worth a thousand words; but if that is thk

case, why not provide a few words in exchange?

Image Alignmen

Probably the first thing a user wants to do after he or she is able to put an image in ¾

Web page is to figure out how to position it on the page. Under the HTML 2.0

standard, there was very little that allowed the user to format image layout on a pageì

Initially, thk  ALIGN  attribute could be set to a value o“  TOL BOTTOV  ,  , oK  MIDDL¨  ì

When an image was included within a block structure of text, the next line of texš

would be aligned at the top, middle, or bottom of the image, depending on the valuk

of thk  ALIGN  attribute. If the attribute wasn't set, it would default to the bottom. Thk

example that follows illustrates basic image alignment as first defined in HTML 2. Thk

rendering of the image alignment example is shown in Figure 5-12ì

 = Page 218 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  19

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Basic Image AlignmenM  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<P><IMG SRC="images/aligntest1.gif" ALIGN="TOP" BORDER="1"L

This text should be aligned at the top of the image<  </PL

<P><IMG SRC="images/aligntest1.gif" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="1"L

This text should be aligned at the middle of the image<  </PL

<P><IMG SRC="images/aligntest1.gif" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="1"L

This text should be aligned at the bottom of the image<  </PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Figurs 5-128  Image alignment renderin

 = Page 219 =

198  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

One of the problems with initial image alignment in early HTML was that the texš

really didn’t flow around the image. In fact, only one line of text was aligned next tf

the image, which meant the inline images had to be very small or the layout looke™

somewhat strange, as shown in Figure 5-13ì

Netscape introduced thk  LEF  an™  RIGH  values foK  ALIGN  , which allowed texš

to flow around the image. When setting an image element likk  <IMG SRC="logo.gif"

ALIGN="LEFT"  , the image is aligned to the left and the text flows around to thk

right. Correspondingly, when you are using markup likk  <IMG SRC="logo.gif"

ALIGN="RIGHT"  , the image is aligned to the right and the text flows around to thk

left. It is even possible to flow the text between two objects if things are done carefullyì

Figurs 5-138  Poor text flow under HTM¤

 = Page 220 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  199

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

The HTML presented here shows how thk  ALIGN  attribute would be used to flow texš

around images. The rendering of this example is shown in Figure 5-14ì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Improved Text Flow  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<IMG SRC="images/redsquare.gif" ALIGN="LEFT"L

The top image has its ALIGN attribute set to "left," so the texM

flows around it to the right. The top image has its ALIGN attribut4

set to "left," so the text flows around it to the right. The toB

image has its ALIGN attribute set to "left," so the text flow?

around it to the right<

<BR CLEAR="LEFT"><BR><BRL

<IMG SRC="images/redsquare.gif" ALIGN="right"L

The top image has its ALIGN attribute set to "right," so the texM

flows around it to the left. The top image has its ALIGN attribut4

set to "right," so the text flows around it to the left. The toB

image has its ALIGN attribute set to "right," so the text flow?

around it to the left<

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Notice in this example that there is a special attribute of thk  <BR  element. This i—

necessary to force the text to flow properly and will be discussed shortly. However,

there are still some aspects of thk  ALIGN  attribute that should be discussed. There i—

some confusion regarding the use of the valuk  CENTE  with thk  ALIGN  attribute foK

thk  <IMG  element. Typically, this attribute value acts the same as thk  MIDDL¨  valuk

and should be avoided. To actually center an image in the middle of the screen require—

enclosing the image withi-  <P ALIGN="CENTER" <DIV ALIGN="CENTER"  ,  , or ¾

plai-  <CENTER  elementì

Netscape and Microsoft also support four other values foK  ALIGN TEXTOL  :  ,

BASELIN¨ ABSMIDDL¨  ,  , an™  ABSBOTTOV  . All these attributes should be avoide™

in most cases, since they may not be supported identically across browsers and are noš

 = Page 221 =

200  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 5-148  Rendering of improved text flow examplP

yet part of any standards. Positioning is handled more precisely by technologies likk

style sheets, which are discussed in Chapter 10. The basic meaning of these attributk

values is discussed hereì

Setting thk  ALIGN  attribute tf  TEXTTOL  aligns the top of an image with the top o“

the tallest character in the current line; this attribute works erratically under variou—

browsers. Thk  BASELIN¨  value aligns the bottom of an image with the baseline of thk

text in the current line. (The baseline is the unseen line that all the characters sit on.)

ABSMIDDL¨  aligns the middle of an image with the middle of the text in the currenš

line, which means in the actual middle of the characters themselves. The valuk

ABSBOTTOV  aligns the bottom of an image with the bottom of the lowest item in thk

current line of text, including descender characters, such as lowercask an™ , that gf  y  v

below the baseline. Unlikk  ABSBOTTOV BASELIN¨  ,  does not include the descender—

in a character. For example, in a lowercask , the lower half of the letter will sit belou  v

the baselineì

HSPACE and VSPACE

Just floating an image and allowing text to wrap around it may not be adequate. Therk

is also the issue of how to position the image more precisely with the text and makk

 = Page 222 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  20h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

sure that text breaks where it ought to. Initially introduced by Netscape and madk

official in HTML 3.2, thk  HSPAC¨  an™  VSPAC¨  attributes can be used to introduck

“runaround” or buffer space around an inland image. Thk  HSPAC¨  attribute is used tf

insert a buffer of horizontal space on the left and right of an image, while thk  VSPAC¨

attribute is used to insert a buffer of vertical space in between the top and bottom of thk

image and other objects. The value of both attributes should be a positive number o“

pixels. While under some browsers it may be possible to set the attribute values tf

percentage values, this is inadvisable, because very high values may produce strangk

results. However, the most problematic aspect of thk  HSPAC¨  an™  VSPAC¨  attribute—

is the amount of buffer space that occurs on both sides of the image. Take a look at thk

HTML markup shown here to see hou  HSPAC¨  an™  VSPAC¨  work. Figure 5-15

displays a possible browser rendering of the example codeì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<PL  The image below has it?  <TT><BL  &lt;HSPACE&gt;  </B></TTL  and

<TT><BL  &lt;VSPACE&gt;  </B></TTL  attributes set toS0 pixels, so th4

text will flow around it at a distance ofS0 pixels. The rest o¨

this text is dummy text. If it said anything interesting you would

It turns out that in the future, by using style sheets (discussed in Chapter 10), iš

may be possible to avoid these somewhat imprecise layout features altogether. Thk

HSPAC¨  an™  VSPAC¨  attributes have been very useful, albeit occasionally abused b_

Web designers. How these attributes can be used in conjunction with the skcalle™

invisiblk  pixel gi  to force layouts will be discussed in Chapter 6ì

Extensions to <BR>

In flowing text around an image, there may be a situation in which the designer want—

to clear the text flow around the image. For example, creating an image with a captio-

like the one shown in Figure 5-16 might be problematic because the text may reflowì

To deal with such problems, a new attribute calle™  CLEA  was added to thk  <BR

element; this extension is now part of the HTML standard. Thk  CLEA  attribute ca-

be set tf  LEF RIGH ALL  ,  ,  , oK  NON¨  and will clear the gutter around an inlink

object like an image. For example, imagine the fragmenš  <IMG SRC="photo. gif"

 = Page 224 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  20

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Figurs 5-168  Image with misaligned captio—

ALIGN="LEFT"  with text wrapping around it. I“  <BR CLEAR="LEFT"  is include™

in the text and the wrapped text is still wrapping around the image, the text will bk

cleared to pass the image. Thk  CLEAR="RIGHT"  attribute tf  <BR  works for texš

flowing around righâaligned images. Of course, setting the attribute tf  NON¨  make—

the element act as it normally would and is implied when using thk  <BR  by itself. A-

example of the use of this attribute is shown here; a rendering appears in Figure 5-17ì

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

HEqHT and WIDTH

Thk  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  attributes of thk  <IMG  element, introduced in HTML 3.2,

are used to set the dimensions of an image. The value for these attributes is either ¾

positive pixel value or a percentage value from 1 to 100 percent. While an image ca-

be stretched or shrunk with this attribute, the main purpose is actually to reserve spack

for images that are being downloaded. As pages are requested by a browser, eac—

individual image is requested separately. However, the browser can't lay out parts o“

the page, including text, until the space that the image takes up is determined. Thi—

may mean waiting for the image to download completely. By telling the browser thk

height and width of the image, the browser can go ahead and reserve space with ¾

bounding box into which the image will load. Setting the height and width thus allow—

a browser to download and lay out text quickly while the images are still loadingì

For an image called test.gif that has a height of 10 and width of 150, usk  <IM…

SRC="test.gif" HEIGHT="10" WIDTH="150"  . The improvement in usability wit—

thk  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  attributes for images is significant, and they should alway—

be includedì

Many people wonder what the measurements of a particular image are.(sing Netscape¨

it is possible to view the dimensions quite easily. First, load the image into the browse(

by itself without any accompanying HTML. Now look at the title bar of the browser¨

which should display the dimensions. Also, using the option to view documenP

information for the image within the browser should reveal the dimensions.

Beyond the prelayout advantages, thk  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  attributes can alsf

be used to size images. This is rarely a good idea, as the image may end up beiný

distorted. One way to avoid distortion is to shrink images in a proportional mannerì

However, if the image is to be made smaller, it is a better idea to size the imagk

appropriately in a graphics program. Shrinking the image with thk  HEIGH  an™

WIDTh  attributes does not affect the file size, while resizing the image beforehan™

will shrink the file and hence reduce the download time. Another use o“  HEIGH

an™  WIDTh  sizing might be to increase the size of a simple image. For example,

imagine an image of a single green pixel, and set the height and width alike:  <IM…

SRC="greenpixel.gif" HEIGHT="100" WIDTH="100"  . The resulting image is a largk

green box with very little download penalty. A few sites even use thk  HEIGH  an™

WIDTh  attributes with percentage values like 100 percent to create interesting effect—

such as ful_screen images or vertical or horizontal color barsì

One other interesting use of thk  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  attributes would be to hel5

preload images. With the desire for fasâloading pages, preloading can be used tf

create the illusion of a quick download. Imagine that during the idle time on a page,

the images on the next page are being downloaded so that they are precached whe-

the user goes to the next page. A significant perceived performance improvement i—

achieved. One way to perform this prefetching is by putting an image that will appeaK

later on the current page wit—  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  both set tf . In this case, thk  1

 = Page 227 =

20‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

image won't really be visible but will be fully loaded into the browser’s cache. Onck

the user visits the next page, the image can be fetched off the local disk an™

displayed quicklyì

One potential problem with this approach is that the browser doesn’t load image—

at the same rate or in the same order. Because of this, some logic should be added tf

the page so that the image to preload only loads after the page has finished. AnotheK

issue occurs if the user chooses a page that doesn’t use the prefetched image. Becausk

of these potential problems, a linear order of pages is probably the only structure thaš

can benefit from this trickì

LOWSRC

Another potential speed improvement introduced by Netscape and still not part of thk

HTML 4.0 standard is thk  LOWSR‚  attribute. Thk  LOWSR‚  attribute should be set tf

the URL of an image to load in first, before the skcalled high source image indicate™

by thk  SR‚  attribute. In this sense, the attribute can be set to the address of ¾

lo“resolution or black-anÙwhite file, which can be downloaded first and the-

followed by a higuresolution file. For example,

<IMG SRC="hi-res-photo.gif" LOWSRC="bw-photo.gif" HEIGHT="100h

WIDTH="100" ALT="Outside of building photograph"L

Thk  LOWSR‚  attribute can provide significant usability improvement when largk

ful_screen images must be usedì

One interesting aspect of thk  LOWSR‚  attribute is that the browser tends to use thk

image dimensions of thk  LOWSR‚  file to reserve space within the Web page if thk

HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  attributes are not set. Because of this, some strange distortio-

could happen if the higuresolution image is not the same size as the lo“resolutio-

image. This problem actually occurs under versions of Netscapeì

Another interesting aspect of thk  LOWSR‚  attribute is the possibility for simplk

animation. For example, thk  LOWSR‚  attribute could be set to a picture of a close™

book and the regulaK  SR‚  attribute set to a picture of an open book. When loaded,

it appears as a small twkframe animation. However, this method of animation i—

very simplistic and lacks timing; so while it might look good on a relatively slou

connection, the effect may be lost over a T1 connection where the images load rapidlyì

For animation, an animated GIF should be used, as discussed earlier in the chapterì

Animated GIFs require no special syntax and may be used for eitheK  SR‚  oK  LOWSR‚  ì

If more complex animation is required, using a-  <EMBED  oK  <OBJECT  element tf

reference a Flash file might be called for, as discussed in Chapter 9ì

These are only the most basic attributes for thk  <IMG  element. A mork

complete listing o“  <IMG  element attributes can be found in the element referenck

in Appendix Aì

 = Page 228 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  20

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

Images as Button“

One of the most important aspects of images, as discussed in Chapter 4, is how the_

can be combined with thk  <A  element to create buttons. To make an imagk

“pressable,” simply enclose it within an anchorì

<A HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com"><IMG SRC="logo.gif"></AL

When the page is rendered in the browser, clicking on the image will take the useK

to the anchor destination specified. Generally, to indicate that an image is pressable,

the browser will put a border around the image and provide some feedback to the useK

when the cursor or pointing device is over the hot area, such as turning the pointer to ¾

finger or highlighting the text. For some basic feedback types, note the example i-

Figure 5-18, which shows a border, finger pointer, and URL destination, all indicatiný

that the image is pressableì

Figurs 5-188  Image as link feedbach

 = Page 229 =

208  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

One issue that may be troublesome for page designers is the border that appear—

around the image when it is made pressable. It is possible to turn this border off b_

setting thk  BORDE  attribute of the image equal tf . For example,  0

<A HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com"><IMG SRC="logo.gifh

BORDER="0"></AL

Of course, without the border it might be difficult to determine which images on ¾

page are links and which are not. This can cause users to play a little game of findiný

the active click region by running the mouse all over the screen. One way to avoid suc—

usability problems is to provide visual cues in images that are made pressable. Thesk

might include embossing, beveling, or drop shadows. Examples of such buttons ark

shown in Figure 5-19ì

While from a design perspective some of the effects, particularly drop shadows, ark

a little overused, there are tangible benefits to adding feedback information to butto-

graphics. Another approach to providing feedback about what images are clickable i—

to animate the buttons. Using a very simple piece of JavaScript, it is possible to animatk

a button so that when a mouse passes over an image it comes alive. A brief discussio-

about how HTML pages can be made more dynamic using a scripting language likk

JavaScript can be found in Chapters 13 and 14ì

Figurs 5-198  Sample button styles for usability improvemend

 = Page 230 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  209

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

One no™butto™oriented use of thk  BORDE  attribute is to put a simple strokk

around an image. Many times people will use a graphics tool to create a frame on a-

image, but thk  BORDE  attribute is a bandwidtucheap way to get much of the samk

effect. Try setting thk  BORDE  attribute equal to a positive value on a nonclickablk

image—for example,  <IMG SRC="portrait.gif" BORDER="5"  . This little changk

provides an easy way to frame an image and might even lend itself to interestiný

design ideasì

Image Map“

Another form of clickable images, discussed previously in Chapter 4, is the idea of a-

image map. An image map is a large image that contains numerous hot spots that ca-

be selected, sending the user to a different anchor destination. There are two basi´

forms of image maps:  server sid—  an™  client sid—  . In the serve§side image map, the useK

clicks on an image but the server must decode where the user clicked before thk

destination page (if any) is loaded. With clienâside image maps, all of the ma5

information—which regions map to which URLs—can be specified in the same HTML

file that contains the image. Including the map data with the image and letting thk

browser decode it has several advantages, includiný

1ì There is no need to visit a server to determine the destination, so links ark

resolved fasterì

2ì Destination URLs can be shown in the status box as the user’s pointer move—

over the imageì

3ì Image maps can be created and tested locally, without requiring a server oK

system administration supportì

4ì Clienâside image maps can be created so that they present an alternativk

text menu to users of texâonly browsersì

While this discussion makes it obvious that clienâside image maps are far superioK

to their serve§side cousins, very old browsers may not support this feature. This doe—

not have to be a problem, since it is possible to include support for both types of imagk

maps at onceì

Server-Side Image Map“

To specify a serve§side image map, thk  <A  element is used to enclose a speciall_

marke™  <IMG  element. Thk  <A  element’—  HREF  attribute should be set to the URL

of the program or map file to decode the image map. Thk  <IMG  element musš

contain the attributk  ISMAL  so the browser can decode the image appropriately. A—

with all linked images, it may be desirable to turn the image borders off by settiný

thk  <IMG  element’—  BORDE  attribute equal tf . As mentioned in Chapter 4,  0

 = Page 231 =

210  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

serve§side image maps do not provide adequate feedback to the user because the_

show coordinates and may incur performance penalties. HTML authors ark

encouraged to use clienâside image mapsì

Client-Side Image Map“

The key to using a clienâside map is to add thk  USEMAL  attribute to thk  <IMG

element and have it reference ¾  <MAP  element that defines the image map's activk

areas. An example of thk  <IMG  element syntax i—  <IMG SRC="controlbar.gif"

USEMAP="#controlmap"  . Note that, like serve§side image maps, the image will bk

indicated as a link regardless of the lack of thk  <A  element surrounding thk  <IMG  ì

Thk  BORDE  attribute should be set tf  0  if necessaryì

Thk  <MAP  element generally occurs within the same document, though supporš

for it outside of the current document is sparse at best. This is similar, in a sense, tf

the way serve§side maps work. Thk  <MAP  element may occur anywhere withi-

the body of an HTML document, though it is usually found at the end of an HTML

documentì

Thk  <MAP  element has one attribute,  NAM¨  , which is used to specify thk

identifier associated with the map. The map name is then referenced within thk

<IMG  element using thk  USEMAL  attribute and the associated fragment identifierì

Thk  <MAP  element must have a closiný  </MAP  element. Within thk  <MAP  an™

</MAP  tags are defined “shapes” that are mapped onto an image and define the hoš

spots for the image map. Shapes are defined by thk  <AREA  element, which is foun™

only within thk  <MAP  element. The format of the mapping tags is discussed i-

Chapter 4. However, memorizing or creating clienâ or serve§side image maps b_

hand is not advised. Page designers should be able to find tools to automate thk

creation of image hot spots. A popular tool for doing this is MapEdit, which can bk

retrieved from http://www.boutell.com/mapeditì

It is possible to combine support for both serve§side and clienâside image map—

into one file. The browser will typically override the serve§side support with thk

improved clienâside style. This approach will guarantee backward compatibilit_

with older browsers. To support both, use thk  ISMAL  an™  USEMAL  attributes i-

conjunction with an embedded map and a remote map, as shown in the followiný

code fragment:

<A HREF="shapes.map"L

<IMG SRC="shapes.gif" USEMAP="#shapes" BORDER="0" ISMAP WIDTH="400h

HEIGHT=00"></AL

Clienâside image maps have a variety of attributes that can be used with thk

<AREA  element. Serve§side image maps really have no attributes other than thosk

normally associated with thk  <IMG  element, such a—  BORDE  . The importanš

 = Page 232 =

ChapteX 5  HTMP an Image  21h

WE/ AND HTM¤ BASICS

attributes supported in HTML 3.2 and 4 are discussed in Chapter 4, as well as in thk

element reference in Appendix Aì

Advanced Image Considerations: Scripting,

Style, and <OBJECT>

While most of the basic uses of images have been discussed, there are some issues thaš

should be mentioned for later discussion. First, because an image may be referenced b_

a style sheet or by a scripting environment, it may be very important to provide a namk

or identifier for it. Thk  CLASS I¤  ,  , an™  NAM¨  attributes can be used to provide name—

for images so they can be referenced and manipulated by scripting or style informatio-

that is usually found in the head of the document. Names should be unique and in thk

proper HTML form. Thk  TITL¨  attribute may also be set to provide advisory texš

about what the image is. While with other elements a browser may render thk  TITL¨

information as a tool tip, most browsers appear to use thk  AL  attribute instead, a—

shown earlier in this chapterì

It is possible to include inline scripting or style information directly with an imageì

For example, setting thk  STYL¨  attribute allows an inline style to bind to the particulaK

<IMG  element. Style sheets are discussed in Chapter 10. Furthermore, it is possible tf

have images bound to a particular event using an event attribute such a—  onmouseove(

and tying it to a script. A very simple but motivating use of tying an event with a-

image is to have the image change state depending on the user’s action. The most basi´

use would be to create animated buttons or buttons that make a sound when clicked,

but the possibilities are endless. A more detailed discussion and examples of how tf

bind JavaScript to create animated buttons is presented in Chapter 13ì

The last advanced comment to make about thk  <IMG  element is that undeK

HTML 4 it is supposed to be possible to include images using thk  <OBJECT  elementì

For example,

<OBJECT DATA="images/logo.gif"L  Picture of the Big Companh

buildin(  </OBJECTL

Similar to thk  <IMG  tag, thk  DATG  attribute is set to the URL of the include™

image while the alternative rendering is placed within thk  <OBJECT  elementì

Although this new syntax may create some interesting possibilities, the reality is thaš

browsers currently don’t support this form of image inclusion. This generi´  <OBJECT

tag for image support makes sense given that an image is no different than any otheK

included binary object, but the fact is that until browser vendors implement it properly,

it should be avoided. A more complete discussion of included media objects can bk

found in Chapter 9, as well as in Appendix A, which provides the full syntax of thk

<OBJECT  elementì

 = Page 233 =

21p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Summar

Like them or not, inline images are what helped popularize the Web. However, jusš

because images can be used to improve the look and feel of a Web page doesn’t mea-

that they should be the primary content. While presentation is important to the Web, iš

is still fundamentally about the communication of information, some of which doe—

well in image form and some of which does not. Adding images to a Web page i—

accomplished using thk  <IMG  element, which has numerous attributes. Many o“

the attributes of thk  <IMG  element—includiný  AL HEIGH WIDTh  ,  ,  , an™

LOWSR‚  —are useful in improving the accessibility and usability of Web pagesì

As always, the eternal struggle between nic[looking pages and download timk

continues, and knowledge of HTML features is helpful to combat excessive wait timeì

Many of the other attributes for thk  <IMG  element were developed with layout i-

mind, particularl_  ALIGN  . Images can be used in conjunction with colors to creatk

motivating layouts, including tiled backgrounds. This will be discussed in the nexš

chapter. In the future, style sheets and thk  <OBJECT  element may take over many o“

the duties of thk  <IMG  element and its attributes; but for the moment, the use of thk

latter is very importantì

 = Page 234 =

 = Page 236 =

Chapte7 H

Introduction to Layout

Backgrounds, Colorsp

and Tex@

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 237 =

21‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

eb page designers strive to create attractive Web pages; but, until recently, iš

hasn’t been easy. HTML was not created with design features in mind. Eve-

a simple layout technique like centering text has only been possible for a feu

W

years. Browser vendors have added many HTML attributes and elements in order tf

provide page developers with more control over the look and feel of their pagesì

Standardized elements such a—  <UL  were pressed into service as structuring an™

layout tools. New font facilities have also provided more design capabilities in HTMLì

Despite all these advances, tricks and workarounds are still occasionally required tf

create visually appealing pages. While it’s best to avoid these nonstandard techniques,

they often are a reality of page design—at least until technologies such as style sheet—

become more widely deployed and understoodì

Design Requirement“

In the best of all possible Web worlds, what would the designer want? The Web wa—

created for a cros-platform environment with little support for screen presentation,

but today’s Web requires better positioning control. The ability to design for ever_

platform is the ideal situation, but the reality of designing for a particular audienck

is becoming more accepted. By understanding a user’s environment, the designeK

has more control over presentation. Designers also want more control over font useì

Initially, there was no way to specify what font to use in a document, whether or noš

the user actually had the font. Other complex layout features common to electroni´

composition, such as more complex color control and layers, might also be desirableì

At the very least, pixe_level control and font selection are necessary to bring the WeD

closer to a level equal with print designì

Simpl_ providiný feature— tf allou pixe_leveR placemenš o“ object— an™ texš o- thk

scree- doesn’š makk WeD desig- ¾ straightforwar™ process, an_ mork tha- fonš selectio-

doesì Iš i— stilR difficulš tf understan™ exactl_ whaš kin™ o“ displa_ environmenš thk en™

useK hasì WeD display— rangk fro“ smalR liqui™ crystaR screen— o- cellulaK phone— an™

pockeš organizer— tf 20-inc— monitors, oK largerì Eac— displa_ ma_ havk differenš type—

o“ coloK support, ranginý fro“ fouK shade— o“ gra_ o- ¾ typicaR hanÙhel™ machink tf

million— o“ color— o- ¾ higuen™ graphi´ designer’— systemì Therk ma_ noš eve- bk ¾

scree- aš all, a— i- thk cask o“ voic[base™ browsersì I“ ¾ gues— i— madk abouš whaš scree-

configuratio- thk useK mighš have, oK somk programminý facilitie— ark provide™ tf

determink thk same, ¾ betteK layouš coul™ bk providedì

The challenges of designing for the Web are significant. In the past, they havk

only been exacerbated by the lack of technology and tools, not to mention problem—

associated with bandwidth or usabilityì

 = Page 238 =

ChapteX 6  Introductio‘ tW Layout Backgroundsp Colorsp an Tex@  21

HTML Approach to Web Desig

While HTML was not designed with layout in mind, it has been abused and extende™

to support layout as best it can. Today, there are many elements, both standard an™

nonstandard, that can provide layout control. These include the variou—  ALIGN  value—

foK elements, browse§specifi´ proprietar_ element— likk  <SPACER  an™  <MULTICOL  ,

¾nd tables. This section covers some of the basic HTML elements used to control texš

and screen layoutì

PRESENTATION AND

Text Alignment with Traditional HTML Element“

The first thing to consider in the HTML approach to layout is all the elements an™  LUT

attributes used to position text and objects on a page. Web page designers have loný

tended to abuse elements likk  <UL  to move text around the page, as shown in thk

following exampleì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Unordered List LayouM  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<ULL

This is indented text<

</ULL

<UL><ULL

This text is indented more<

</UL></ULL

<UL><UL><UL><UL><UL><UL><UL><UL><UL><UL><ULL

<UL><UL><UL><UL><ULL

This is indented heavily, but may not produc4

the effect you expect<

</UL></UL></UL></UL></UL></UL></UL></UL></ULL

</UL></UL></UL></UL></UL></UL></ULL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

218  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Many HTML page development tools still use this approach to move things aroun™

the screen. A rendering of formatting using the unordered list element is shown i-

Figure 6-1ì

Another approach to control text layout is the use of thk  <PRE  tag. As discusse™

in Chapter 3, any text enclosed b_  <PRE  preserves returns, tabs, and spaces. Usiný

<PRE  , it is possible to force text to lay out the way the page author requires, eve-

forcing the browser to scroll to the right to read text. Generally speaking, the browseK

changes the typeface of any preformatted text to a fixeÙwidth font such as Courierì

This font change may not be desired. How can spaces be inserted to improve texš

layout without a font change? Using the character entit_  &nbsp;  oK  &160;  should inserš

a nonbreaking space that will not be collapsed by the browser. To enter three space—

between words, usk  &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  . This leads many people to force texš

layout like so:

&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Now we are ten spaces from the left!

While use of this nonbreaking space is somewhat a crutch, it is interesting to notk

how many of these character entities will be entered into a document when using ¾

WYSIWYG page editorì

The <CENTER> Elemen

In the early days of the Web it was difficult, if not impossible, to control screen layoutì

Netscape eventually introduced a few elements and attribute changes useful foK

positioning, including thk  <CENTER  elementì

Thk  <CENTER  element can enclose any form of content, which is then centered i-

the browser window. In early HTML, text could be centered using the following code:

<CENTERL  Welcome to Big Companh  </CENTERL

PRESENTATION AND

<CENTER  can be used around an arbitrary amount of content in many differenš

LUT

forms, including images and text. Use of thk  <CENTER  element is common on thk

Web, and it has been included in the HTML 4 standard. However, the element i—

shorthand foK  <DIV ALIGN="CENTER"  . Later, thk  ALIGN  attribute (discussed i-

the next few paragraphs) was added to many elementsì

Alignment Attribute“

Beyon™  <CENTER  , there are many elements under HTML 3.2 and 4 that support thk

ALIGN  attributeì Thk  <DIV  element, whic— i— use™ tf creatk ¾ divisio- i- ¾ document,

may have thk  ALIGN  attribute set tf  LEF CENTE RIGH  ;  ;  ; or, under 4,  JUSTIF  ì

If thk  ALIGN  attribute is not set, text generally is aligned to the left when languagk

direction is set tf  LT  (left to right) and to the right when the language direction is seš

tf  RTL  (right to left). Until recently, thk  JUSTIF  attribute did not work in mosš

browsers; nou iš i— supporte™ b_ thk latesš version— o“ thk twf majoK browsersì Thk  <P

paragrap— element, thk  <TABLE  element, and the heading—  <H1 <H2 <H3  ,  ,  ,

<H4 <H5  ,  , an™  <H6  also support thk  ALIGN  attribute, with the same basic value—

and meaning. Note that, as discussed in Chapter 5, thk  ALIGN  attribute on thk  <IMG

element serves a different purposeì

Word Hinting with <NOBR> and <WBR>

UndeK man_ currenš browsers, iš i— possiblk tf controR texš layouš beyon™ simplk

alignmentì Becausk fonš sizk an™ browseK width— ma_ bk different, wor™ wrappiný ma_

occuK i- strangk waysì Microsofš an™ Netscape, a— welR a— man_ otheK browsers, supporš

thk  <NOBR  an™  <WBR  element— a— ¾ wa_ tf providk browseK hint— foK texš layoutì

Thk  <NOBR  element makes sure that a line of text does not wrap to the next line,

regardless of browser width. This element is useful for words or phrases that must bk

kept together on one line. If the line of text is long, it may extend beyond the browseK

window, obliging the user to scroll in order to view the unbroken text. A simplk

example of using thk  <NOBR  element is shown here:

<NOBRL  This is a very important long line of text, so it should not b4

allowed to break across two lines<  </NOBRL

 = Page 241 =

220  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

It is possible to use thk  <NOBR  element in conjunction with images, but thk

browser window may need to be scrolled for all the images to be seenì

I- somk cases, thk browseK ma_ attempš tf rescalk thk image— i- ordeK tf fiš the“

alR o- onk lineì I- thk cask o“ WebTV, thk browseK wilR scalk dow- tf 80 percenš o“ thk

image’— originaR sizk befork moviný thk imagk tf thk nexš lineì  <NOBR  act— differentl_

undeK WebTV becausk WebTV doe— noš allou foK an_ horizontaR scrollingì

thk  <NOBR  elementì (  <WBR  i— noš parš o“ thk HTML standard, buš man_ browser—

closiný tagì Here’— ¾ simplk examplk showiný hou iš works:

<NOBRL  This is a very important long line of text that should noM

break across two lines. If the line must be split, it should happeY

her4  <WBRL  and nowhere else<  </NOBRL

Thk  <WBR  element should only exist within ¾  <NOBR  element, although it ma_

work outside of it. This element does not have any major attributes, thoug—  CLASS  ,

I¤ STYL¨  ,  , an™  TITL¨  are typically specified as being allowed with the element. It i—

unlikely that any attribute buš  I¤  would be used; applying a style to ¾  <WBR  elemenš

would have no effect, since it encloses no text. Thk  I¤  attribute could be used tf

manipulate the element, perhaps to remove it using a scripting language. The basi´

point, and a very useful one, of this element, is simply to suggest a line break pointì

Alignment with Image“

As discussed in Chapter 5, under HTML 2 thk  <IMG  element specified thk  ALIGN

attribute with allowed values o“  TOL BOTTOV  ,  , oK  MIDDL¨  . When an image wa—

included within a block structure of text, the next line of text would be aligned at thk

top, middle, or bottom of the image, depending on the value of thk  ALIGN  attribute. I“

the attribute were not set, it would default to the bottomì

Onk proble“ wit— imagk alignmenš i- earl_ HTML wa— thaš thk texš didn’š flou

aroun™ thk imageì Onl_ onk link o“ texš wa— aligne™ nexš tf thk imageì Netscapk introduce™

thk  LEF  an™  RIGH  value— foK  ALIGN  , whic— allowe™ texš tf flou aroun™ thk imageì

Whe- settiný a- imagk elemenš likk  <IM… SRC="logo.gif" ALIGN="LEFT"  , thk imagk

i— aligne™ tf thk lefš an™ thk texš flow— aroun™ tf thk rightì Correspondingly, whe- usiný

codk suc— a—  <IM… SRC="logo.gif" ALIGN="RIGHT"  , thk imagk i— aligne™ aš thk righš

an™ thk texš flow— aroun™ tf thk leftì

BASELIN¨ ABSMIDDL¨  ,  , an™  ABSBOTTOV  . Avoid these attributes in most cases,

While thk  ALIGN  attribute and the extensions tf  <BR  provide some degree o“

page layout control (discussed in Chapter 10), technologies such as style sheets handlk

positioning with greater precision. Until style sheets become more common, there ark

certain instances in which thk  <IMG  element and its attributes (includiný  HSPAC¨  ,

Invisible Images and Layou

Another way to push text around in a layout is by using an image. This approach i—

welR know- šf user— o“ thk deskto5 publishiný progra“ QuarkXPressì Wit— thi— program,

users can create invisible regions and run text around them to achieve specific layouš

effects. This can be done under HTML by using an invisible image in combination wit—

thk  ALIGN HSPAC¨  ,  , an™  VSPAC¨  attributes. Given a transparent —pixel image, thk

designer can perform a variety of interesting tricks. For example, take a clear pixel an™

set thk  HSPAC¨  value tf . Now put this at the front of a paragraph, as shown here:  5

<P><IMG SRC="pixel.gif" HSPACE="5"L  This is the start of a paragraph<  </PL

Given this fragment, the first line of the paragraph is indented 11 pixels (5 pixels o-

either side of the —pixel image). Imagine doing the same thing between lines using thk

VSPAC¨  attribute. By setting thk  VSPAC¨  attribute and using hard carriage returns,

the designer could achieve arbitrary line spacingì

Imagine creating a much larger region with an invisible pixel by setting thk

HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  attributes of thk  <IMG  element and usiný  ALIGN  to flow texš

around the invisible region. For example,  <IMG SRC="pixel.gif" HEIGHT="100"

WIDTH="50" ALIGN="LEFT"  could create a large invisible block to run text aroundì

The pixel trick can be a useful workaround; but, in certain situations, it has it—

drawbacks. One potential use for it is to force line space between lines. For example,

the codk  <IMG SRC="pixel.gif" VSPACE="10"  could allow the designer to creatk

line spacing. Similarly, a designer might decide to use an invisible pixel to create ¾

 = Page 243 =

22p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

paragraph indent using something likk  <IMG SRC="pixel.gif" HSPACE="5"  . Buš

what happens when the page is viewed with the images turned off or the stop button i—

pressed early? The resulting page might look like the one in Figure 6-2ì

Despite their problems, image layout tricks are still very common on the Web. The_

are considered so useful that Netscape introduced a special element calle™  <SPACER

that mimics much of the functionality of invisible imagesì

The <SPACER> Elemen

The proprietar_  <SPACER  element, introduced with Netscape 3, allows users tf

create invisible regions to push text and other objects around the browser screen. I-

many ways, this element is a response to the invisible singl[pixel GIF trick discusse™

in the previous section. Whilk  <SPACER  does an adequate job of reproducing thi—

hack for screen design, its lack of cros-platform support suggests that using thk

singl[pixel image or a style sheet is more appropriateì

<SPACER  is an empty element and is used to insert an invisible region to forck

layout. Its main attribute i—  TYP¨  , which specifies the form of the invisible region a—

HORIZONTAL VERTICAL  ,  , oK  BLOCK  . The other attributes are used to set the sizk

Figurs 6-28  Pixel trick proble‘

 = Page 244 =

ChapteX 6  Introductio‘ tW Layout Backgroundsp Colorsp an Tex@  22

of the spacer. Example code to create a horizontal space of 75 pixels between words i-

a sentence is shown here:

This is the start of the sentenc4  <SPACER ALIGN="LEFTh

TYPE="HORIZONTAL" SIZE="75"L  and this is the end<

As with invisible pixels, it is possible to push lines apart. In the next example, thk

<SPACER  element is set to create a vertical region of 24 pixels to give the appearanck

PRESENTATION AND

of double spacing. Notice how the vertical spacer induces line breaksì

This is line one<  LUT

<SPACER ALIGN="LEFT" TYPE="VERTICAL" SIZE=4"L

This is line two<

Thk  <SPACER  element can only be one type at a time. It is not possible to have ¾

vertical and horizontal spacer. If such functionality is required, use thk  BLOCK  typeì

Thk  <SPACER  element can also be used to flow text around invisible blocks. Thk

following HTML code creates an invisible runaround region 150 pixels high and 100

pixels acrossì

...text..<

<SPACER TYPE="BLOCK" HEIGHT="150" WIDTH="100" ALIGN  ="  LEFT"L

...text..<

Notice how thk  ALIGN  attribute is used just as it would be with an image, with ¾

default alignment value o“  BOTTOV  , and so on. The element could also be combine™

wit—  <B CLEAR="LEFT"  tf avoi™ thk spaciný elemenš affectiný texš thaš ma_ followì

Bk carefuR noš tf makk layout— rel_ o-  <SPACER  , ¾— [š [— ¾ somewhaš al_o§nothiný

element that is completely unsupported beyond Netscape browsers. If it is just hinting,

or providing browser tips, page layout such as line spacing can be used and will safel_

be ignored by other browsers. Invisible images, on the other hand, may show up undeK

texâonly browsers if you do not set thk  AL  text to no value. When using block form—

tf creatk runaroun™ space, thk invisibl[pixeR trickma_ stilR providk ¾ betteK work aroun™

tha-  <SPACER  , becausk iš wilR bk picke™ u5 b_ mosš graphicaR browsersì

Some WYSIWYG editors seem to like to us—  <SPACERA  in conjunction with

table-based layouts. As the tag will probably be deprecated over time, designerx

should avoid its use.

22  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The <MULTICOL> Elemen

Likk  <SPACER  , thk  <MULTICOL  elemenš i— uniquk tf Netscapk browser— startiný

wit— NavigatoK 3ì Thi— elemenš allow— pagk designer— tf specif_ texš i- multiplk columns,

whic— ark rendere™ wit— equaR widthì Thk elemenš i— noš supporte™ i- previou— version—

o“ Netscapk oK Interneš Explorer; iš wilR noš degradk gracefull_ i“ layouš depend— o- itì

The most important attribute of thk  <MULTICOL  element i—  COLS  , which is seš

to the number of text columns to display. The browser should attempt to flow the texš

evenly across columns and make the columns the same height, except for the lasš

column, which may be shorter depending on the amount of text in the columns. Thk

element also supports the attributk  GUTTE  , which is used to specify the gutter spack

between columns in pixels. By default, the gutter width (if unspecified) is 10 pixelsì

The last attribute supported b_  <MULTICOL  i—  WIDTh  , which specifies the widt—

of each column in pixels. All columns are the same width; there is no way to directl_

adjust a particular column’s width. If thk  WIDTh  attribute is not set, its value i—

determined by subtracting from the display width the number of pixels that constitutk

the gutter and then dividing by the number of columns set in thk  COLS  attribute. Thk

syntax is summarized here:

<MULTICOL

COLS="number of columns"

GUTTER="gutter width in pixels or percentage"

WIDTH="column width in pixels or percentage">

Text to put in column for—

</MULTICOL>

An example showing hou  <MULTICOL  can be used is shown here; rendering—

of the example are shown in Figure 6-3. Notice how the layout is not preserved i-

Internet Explorerì

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  MULTICOL Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<MULTICOL COLS=" GUTTER="50" WIDTH="80%"L

for all good men to come to the aid of the country. There's no busines?

LUT

When including other objects within thk  <MULTICOL  element, particularl_

further problem wit—  <MULTICOL  is that it will degrade when too many column—

are set, so try to keep the value foK  COLS  around six or less. An example showing thk

problem of too many columns is shown in Figure 6-5ì

Font“

Besides better support for layout, Web page designers have long desired to be able tf

specify fonts in their documents. HTML 2 only supported two fonts, a proportionaR

font and a fixeÙwidth font. Under browsers such as Netscape and Internet Explorer,

the proportional font was usually Times or Times New Roman, while the fixeÙwidt—

font was Courier. To set text to Courier, page authors would use an element likk  <TT  ì

Otherwise, all text on the page was generally in the proportional font unless it wa—

preformatted with thk  <PRE  element. There was also little control over the size of thk

PRESENTATION AND

font, even in relative terms. The font size of the browser was generally 12 point for thk

variabl[width font and 10 point for the fixeÙwidth font, but end users were free tf

LUT

change font size as they pleasedì

Therk wasn’š muc— controR oveK typograph_ i- earl_ browsersì I- fact, thk onl_ wa_

tf usk ¾ neu fonš oK controR thk precisk layouš o“ texš wa— tf makk [š ¾ graphicì Tf thi—

day, man_ pagk designer— stilR embe™ ¾ greaš deaR o“ texš a— graphic— i- ordeK tf precisel_

controR spaciný an™ tf usk font— thaš thk useK ma_ noš haveì Becausk o“ downloa™ an™

accessibilit_ issues, thi— shoul™ noš bk thk dk factf approac— tf dealiný wit— fontsì

Wit— Netscapk NavigatoK 1.1, iš becamk possiblk tf controR font— ¾ littlk moreì Netscapk

[ntroduce™ thk  <FONT  element, whic— wa— use™ tf specif_ thk sizk and, startiný wit—

NavigatoK 2, coloK o“ texš usiný thk  SIZ¨  an™  COLO  attributesì Microsofš lateK adde™

a- attributk calle™  FAC¨  tf indicatk whic— fonš typk shoul™ bk usedì Bot—  SIZ¨  an™

COLO  werk introduce™ tf thk standar™ i- HTML 3.2ì Today, alR o“ thesk attribute—

ark considere™ parš o“ thk HTML 4 transitionaR standardì However, likk man_ layouš

facilities, thk usk o“ thk  <FONT  elemenš shoul™ bk phase™ ouš i- thk futurk i- favoK

o“ stylk sheetsì

Under HTML 4, it is possible to make a certain portion of text a particular color b_

enclosing it within thk  <FONT  element and setting thk  COLO  attribute equal to ¾

valid color name such a—  red  or an equivalent value such a—  #FF0000  . RGB hexadecimaR

equivalent codes are discussed later in this chapter and are also presented in Appendix

E. So the codk

<FONT COLOR="red"L  This is important<  </FONTL

sets the texš  This is important.  in red. Thk  <FONT  element can contain a great deal o“

text or very little, so it is possible to control the colors of individual letters, though suc—

resulting rainbow effects might be hard on the eyesì

It is also possible to set the relative size of type by setting thk  SIZ¨  attribute of thk

<FONT  element. In a Web page, there are seven relative sizes for text numbered fro“

1  tf , wherk is the smallest text in a document an™ is the largest. To set some texš  7  1  7

into the largest size, usk  <FONT SIZE="7"  This is biý  </FONT  . By default, the typicaR

size of text i— ; this can be overridden with thk  3  <BASEFONT  element, discusse™

later in this chapter in the section “DocumenâWide Font Settings.” If the font size i—

not known but the text should just be made one size bigger, the author can use a-

 = Page 249 =

228  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

alternative sizing value such a—  <FONT SIZE="+1"  instead of specifying the sizk

directly. Thk  +  an™ nomenclature makes it possible to bring the font size up or dow-  –

a specified number of settings. The values for this form of thk  SIZ¨  attribute shoul™

range fro“  +1  tf  +6  an™  –1  tf  –6  . It is not possible to specif_  <FONT SIZE="+10"

because there are only seven sizes. If the increase or decrease goes beyond acceptablk

sizes, the font generally defaults at the largest or smallest size, respectivelyì

Microsoft introduced thk  FAC¨  attribute to thk  <FONT  element that has come tf

be supported by nearly all browsers, as well as the HTML 4.0 specification. Thk  FAC¨

attribute can be set to the name of the font to render the text. So a page designer whf

wants to render a particular phrase in Britannic Bold could use the following code:

<FONT FACE="Britannic Bold"L  This is important<  </FONTL

The browser would then read this HTML fragment and render the text in the differenš

font—but only for users who have the font installed on their systems. This raises a-

interesting problem: what happens if a user doesn’t have the font specified? Using thk

FAC¨  attribute, it is possible to specify a commDdelimited list of fonts to try one b_

one before defaulting to the normal proportional or fixeÙwidth font. The fragmenš

shown here would try first Arial, then Helvetica, and finally a generic san-serif fonš

before giving up and using whatever the current browser font isì

<FONT FACE="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif"L  This should be in a differenM

font<  </FONTL

Whilk iš i— impossiblk tf knou whaš font— user— ma_ havk o- theiK systems, thk

previou— examplk show— hou ¾ littlk guessworkca- bk applie™ tf tak k advantagk o“ thk

FAC¨  attributeì Mosš Macintosh, Windows, an™ UNIX user— havk ¾ standar™ seš o“ fontsì

I“ equivalenš font— ark specified, iš ma_ bk possiblk tf providk similaK pagk rendering—

acros— platformsì Tablk 6-Ç show— somk o“ thk font— thaš ca- bk foun™ o- Macintosh,

Windows, an™ UNIX systemsì Thk tablk doe— noš attempš tf cros-referenck thk fontsì

I- fact, whilk Window— doe— noš alway— havk Helvetica, AriaR i— fairl_ similarì

or commDdelimited list of fontsì  SIZ¨  should be set to a size value betwee-  1  an™ ì  7

Downloadable Font“

While one Microsoft solution to type on the Web attempts to promote a common seš

of faces, it isn’t a very flexible approach outside the Windows world. Though man_

Windows, Macintosh, and UNIX systems have similar fonts, what about when the pagk

author wants to use a customized font? In this case, the page author is forced to creatk

a static image of the font. This could take a great deal of time to download and gives u5

the ability to easily index the text, let alone copy and paste itì

Thk besš solutio- foK font— o- thk WeD uoul™ bk tf comk ¾5 uit— somk cros¾

platfor“ form of font that could be downloaded to the browser o™th[fly. Whilk

thisfsound— eas_ enough, thk proble“ wit— downloadablk font— i— thaš the_ musš Dk

highl_ compact. Page viewers must not be able to steal the font from the page an™

install it on their own machines. Both of the major browser vendors have been workiný

on downloadable fonts. Microsoft’s solution for Web type is called OpenTypk

(http://www.microsoft.com/typography). Netscape’s solution, called Dynamic Fonts,

i— base™ o- TrueDo´ (http://www.truedoc.com)ì Currently, onl_ Netscapk 4 an™ Interneš

 = Page 252 =

ChapteX 6  Introductio‘ tW Layout Backgroundsp Colorsp an Tex@  23h

Explorer 4 and above support downloadable fonts, so be careful not to rely too heavil_

on the font being available or your page layout may fall apartì

Netscape’s Dynamic Font“

To use a dynamic font under Netscape, the page author simply uses thk  FAC¨  attributk

of thk  <FONT  element or a style sheet attribute, as discussed in Chapter 10, to set thk

fonš faceì I“ thk useK doe— noš havk thk fonš installe™ o- thk system, ¾ downloadablk fonš

linked to the page can be fetched and used to render the page. To include a link to ¾

PRESENTATION AND

Netscape font definition file in Portable Font Resource (PFR) format, use thk  <LINK

element by setting thk  REL  attribute tf  fontdef  and thk  SR‚  attribute equal to the URL

LUT

in which the font definition file resides. Thk  <LINK  element must be found withi-

thk  <HEAD  of the document. An example of how this element would be used i—

shown here:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Netscape Font DemB  </TITLEL

<LINK REL="fontdef" SRC="http://www.bigcompany.com/fonts/customfonts.pfr"L

</HEADL

<BODYL

<FONT FACE="newfont"L

Content rendered in the font "newfont," which is part of the .pfr fil4

</FONTL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Note that there may be many fonts in the same font definition file. There is no limiš

to how many fonts can be used on a page. Once the font is accessed, it is used just as i“

it were installed on a user’s system. Two attributes available under Netscape 4 ark

useful when dealing with dynamic fonts. The first extension to thk  <FONT  elemenš

i—  POINT-SIZ¨  , which can be set to the point size of the font. The other extension tf

<FONT  is thk  WEIGH  attribute, which can be set to a value betwee-  100  an™  900

in increments o“  100  . The value of thk  WEIGH  attribute determines the weight oK

boldness of the font. A value o“  100  is the lightest weight, whilk  900  indicates to makk

the font as bold as it can be. If thk  <B  element is used, thk  WEIGH  attribute i—

equivalent tf  900  . If dynamic fonts are to be used, it is more likely that style sheets wilR

be the preferred way to interact with them, rather than these proprietary extensionsì

The only obstacle to using dynamic fonts is that the .pfr file describing the font must bk

created. Otherwise, they are no more troublesome than attempting to guess the font o-

the end user’s system or rasterizing the font into a GIF imageì

 = Page 253 =

23p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

One drawback to the Netscape approach to dynamic fonts is that it may cause screec

flashing in many versions of Netscape. This can be disorienting for the user and hax

somewhat limited the use of this technology.

Microsoft’s Dynamic Font“

Microsoft also provides a way to embed fonts in a Web page. To include a font, yo¾

must first build the page using thk  <FONT  element or style sheet rules that set fonts,

as discussed in Chapter 10. When creating your page, don’t worry about whether oK

noš thk en™ useK ha— thk fonš installed; iš wilR bk downloadedì Next, usk Microsoft’— WeD

Embedding Fonts Tool or a similar facility to analyze the font usage on the page. Thk

program should create an .eot file that contains the embedded fonts. The font usk

information will then be added to the page in the form of CSS (Cascading Style Sheets)

style rules, as shown here:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Microsoft Font TesM  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-–

@font-face {

font-family: Ransom;

font-style: normal;

font-weight: normal;

src: url(fonts/ransom.eot);

}

-–L

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<FONT FACE="Ransom" SIZE="6"L  Example Ransom Note FonM  </FONTL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

A possible rendering of font embedding is shown in Figure 6-7ì

Like the Netscape approach, you must first create a font file and reference it fro“

the file that uses the font. It may be useful to define a fonts directory within your WeD

site to store font files, similar to storing image files for site useì

The use of thk  @font-fac2  acts as a pseudoelement that allows you to bring an_

number of fonts into a page. The form of the font embedding supported by Microsofš

conforms to the initial W3C specification for font embedding. For more information o-

 = Page 254 =

ChapteX 6  Introductio‘ tW Layout Backgroundsp Colorsp an Tex@  23

PRESENTATION AND

LUT

Figurs 6-78  Embedded fonts increase design choice9

embedded fonts under Internet Explorer and links to font file creation tools like WEFR,

see the Microsoft Typography site (http://www.microsoft.com/typography)ì

It is possible to provide both links to both Microsoft and Netscape font technology in th—

same page. This really adds only one line or a few style rules as the rest of the documenP

would continue to use the sam—  <FONT FACE=""A  statements. TrueDoc technology

also supports an ActivN control to allow Internet Explorer users to view their style o

embedded fonts. Given the extra download involved, the double font statement approach

is preferred.

Colors in HTM¤

HTML 4 supports color settings both for text and for the background of the document,

or even individual table cells. With style sheets we will see it is also possible to set bot—

foreground and background color at any time. There are 16 widely known color name—

defined in HTML 4. These names and their associated HEX RGB values are shown i-

Table 6-2ì

To set a particular section of text yellow, simply surround the content wit—  <FON

COLOR="yellow"  an™  </FONT  . Similarly, you can also use the HEX valuk  #FFFF00

for thk  COLO  attributeì

Tabls 6-28  Common HTML 4 Color Names and HEXXalue9

Most browsers should recognize the common color values such a—  whit2 red  ,  , an™

black  and render accordingly. Determining the HTML hexadecimal value for ¾

particular color isn’t difficult when following the basic formula o“  #  RRGGBk  , wherk

RP  equals the hex value for red,  G‘  equals the hex value for green, an™  Bk  equals thk

hex value for blue. If the hex value for all off, or zero, i— , and the hex value for all o-  00

i—  FF  , then the coloK  #FF0000  is red. All the red in the image is turned on in this case. A

value o“  #000000  would be black,  #0000FF  would be blue, and so on. Of course therk

are many colors and hex values, some of which seem to have been invented by thk

browser vendors; these are listed in Appendix E. The problem with using browseK

 = Page 256 =

ChapteX 6  Introductio‘ tW Layout Backgroundsp Colorsp an Tex@  23

vendor–defined colors is that they don’t always do what they are supposed to doì

Under Netscape 4, the color aliceblue doesn’t look very close to the Internet ExploreK

color. Even worse, you can invent your own colors. Try setting the following an™

viewing it under Netscape and Microsoft Internet Explorer:

<BODY BGCOLOR="HTML COLOR NAMES ARE TROUBLESOME"L

This color name is totally invalid, but it still results in a shade of green that is ver_

PRESENTATION AND

distinct in each browser. It is possible to make up colors like chilidog brown or stalk

beer yellow, but this is no more recommended than using the Netscap[defined coloK

Dodgerblue. The hex color values are the preferred way of setting colors, since man_  LUT

nonstandard color names may not be supported correctly across browsersì

Document-Wide Color Attributes for <BODY>

Thk  <BODY  elemenš ha— numerou— attribute— thaš ca- bk use™ tf affecš thk displa_ o“

text, an™ thk coloK o“ linksì Onk o“ thk mosš commonl_ use™  <BODY  elemenš attributes,

oveK thk defaulš gra_ (oK whitk undeK Macintosh) o“ Mosaic, althoug— iš an™ thk otheK

attribute— tf followì Tf creatk ¾ whitk background, thk attributk coul™ bk seš tf  <BOD

BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF"  (hexadecimal) oK simpl_  <BOD BGCOLOR="white"  ì

documentì Thk attributk take— ¾ coloK i- thk for“ o“ eitheK ¾ hex codk oK coloK nameì Sf

Note that the text color can be overridden in the text by applying thk  <FONT

element to selected text with it—  COLO  attribute, as discussed earlier in the chapter i-

the section “Fonts.”

Besides the body text, it is also possible to define the colors of links by setting thk

o“ thk standar™ blueì  ALINK  define— thk coloK o“ thk linka— iš i— beiný click edì Thi— i— ofte-

tof quicktf bk noticed, buš ca- creatk ¾ flas— effect, i“ desiredì FoK ¾ “ork subdue™ WeD

experience, iš mighš bk betteK tf seš thk  ALINK  attributk tf matc— eitheK thk  LINK  attributk

oK thk nexš one,  VLINK VLINK  ì  define— thk coloK o“ ¾ linkafteK iš ha— bee- visited, whic— i—

23‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

purplk undeK man_ useK agentsì Man_ author— wis— tf seš thk valuk o“ thk  VLINK  attributk

tf  red  , uhic— make— sensk give- standar™ coloK interpretationì So, usiný thk lasš attributes,

creatiný ¾ uhitk pagk wit— gree- text, re™ links, an™ fuchsiDcolore™ visite™ link— coul™ bk

accomplishe™ usiný thk codk presente™ here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL
