</HTMLL

User— shoul™ bk forewarne™ noš tf choosk linkcolor— thaš mighš confusk theiK viewersì

For example, reversing link colors so that visited links are blue and nonvisited links ark

red could confuse a user. While it is unlikely that a page author would do such a thing,

it has been seen more than once—particularly in situations in which the look and feel i—

the driving force of the site. Other common problems with link color changes includk

the idea of setting all link values tf  blu2  with the belief that users will revisit section—

thinking they haven’t been there before. While this may make sense from a marketiný

standpoint, the frustration factor due to the lost navigation cues may override an_

potentiaR benefiš fro“ extr¾ visitsì A— thk lasš examplk showed, settiný alR thk linkcolor—

tf  red  could have a similar effect of encouraging users to think they have seen the sitk

alreadyì

Page authors must also be extremely careful when setting text and backgroun™

colors so that readability is preserved. Page designers are often tempted to use lighš

colors on light backgrounds or dark colors on dark backgrounds. For example, a gra_

text on a black background might look cool, but will it look cool on every person’—

monitor? If the gamma value of some other person’s monitor is much different than o-

yours, it may be unreadable. White and black always make a good pairing and red i—

certainl_ usefulì Thk besš combination, i- term— o“ contrast, i— actuall_ yellou an™ black;

but imagine the headache from reading a page that looks like a road sign. Despite thk

high contrast, designers should be careful of white text on a black background whe-

font sizes are very small, particularly on poo§resolution monitorsì

Gamm¾  is a term used to describe the relationship between the input and output for ‘

particular image device. Different monitors have inherently different gamma settings.

As a result, the same image on two different monitors may appear significantly different.

While the gamma of a monitor cannot be changed by the user, monitor settings such ax

contrast, brightness, and color can be adjusted.

 = Page 258 =

ChapteX 6  Introductio‘ tW Layout Backgroundsp Colorsp an Tex@  23

Background Image“

Besides setting background colors, you can also change the appearance of a Web pagk

by setting a background image using thk  BACKGROUN¤  attribute of thk  <BODY

element. The value o“  BACKGROUN¤  should be the URL for a GIF or JPEG file,

usually one in the image directory of the Web site in question (for example,  <BOD

BACKGROUND="images/tile.gif"  ). The value could just as easily include a completk

URL to access an image at another site, but this would be a rather unwieldy approac—

to the task at hand. Images accessed in this fashion repeat, oK  tile¨  in the backgroun™

PRESENTATION AND

of a Web page. This can make or break a Web page design. Imagine someone whf

used thk  BACKGROUN¤  attribute to place a 200 × 300 pixel JPEG of a favorite dog o-

LUT

his or her home page. The dog’s image would repeat, both vertically and horizontally,

in the background of the page. This would make the dog’s owner very happy—an™

make the page very difficult to read. Figure 6-8 shows an example of a bothersomk

repeating backgroundì

In general, complex background images tend to be a poor design decision. Takiný

thk subtlk approac— ca- backfirk a— wellì Somk user— attempš tf creatk ¾ lighš backgroun™

like a texture or watermark thinking that, like paper, it will create a classy effect. Thk

problem with this is that under many monitors, the image may be difficult to make ouš

aš all, oK thk texturk ma_ eve- bluK thk texš o- to5 o“ iš slightlyì A— wit— settiný backgroun™

colors, the most important consideration is the degree of contrast. Always attempt tf

Figurs 6-88  Repeating background imagP

 = Page 259 =

238  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

keep the foreground and background at a high level of contrast so that users can rea™

the information. What good is an impressive layout if nobody can read it?

If a background is desired, imag[manipulation programs such as Photoshop ca-

be used to create seamless background tiles that are more pleasing to the eye and shou

no seam. Figure 6-9 demonstrates the idea of a repeating background tileì

Background images, or tiles, can also be used to create other effects. A single GIF, 5

pixels high and 1,200 pixels wide, could be used to create a useful page layout. The firsš

200 horizontaR pixel— o“ thk GIF coul™ bk black, whilk thk resš coul™ bk whiteì Assuminý

1,200 pixels as the maximum width of a browser, this tile would only repeat vertically,

thus creating the illusion of a twktone background. This has become a very commo-

concept on the Web. Many sites use the lefâhand color for navigation buttons, whilk

the remaining area is used for text, as shown in Figure 6-10. However, to guarantek

that content appears on top of the appropriate section of the background image, yo¾

may be forced to use tables. Make sure to read Chapter 7 thoroughly before trying thi—

style of page designì

Figurs 6-98  Background tiles without visible sea‘

 = Page 260 =

ChapteX 6  Introductio‘ tW Layout Backgroundsp Colorsp an Tex@  239

PRESENTATION AND

LUT

Figurs 6-108  Advanced layout using background tileYhorizontal GIF)

Be very careful when segmenting the screen using a background tile. For example,

many people are tempted to create page layout with vertical sectioning, as shown i-

Figure 6-11. However, there is a problem with this layout. Won’t the black bar repeat?

Quite possibly, because the length of the content is hard to determine. Viewers ma_

find the black bar repeating over and over with content being lost on top. A solutio-

might be to make the background tile very tall. However, this not only increases filk

size, but begs a question of how tall is enough? Because content may vary from pagk

tf pagk an™ increask oK decreask oveK time, determininý thk widt— i— nexš tf impossibleì

It would appear that the same problem would occur with sidebar style tiles. This i—

generally not the case, given that pages usually do not scroll left to right, and monitoK

size— ten™ tf noš excee™ 1,200 pixelsì I- eitheK case, thk proble“ o“ backgroun™ tilk

repeat— is solved with style sheets as they provide a way to set the direction an™

frequency of a tile’s repeat pattern. This is discussed further in Chapter 10. There are ¾

few HTML-specific solutions to these and other background layout problems that ark

touched on briefly hereì

 = Page 261 =

240  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 6-118  Layout using background tileYvertical GIF)

Another problem with background tiles is that some designers try to minimize file siz—

and download time. For example, a designer may make the background images a singl—

pixel tall, which may cause screen painting problems because the background will hav—

to be tiled as many times as the screen is high in pixels. With a slow video card, this may

produce an annoying sweeping effect. To avoid the background painting problem¨

consider balancing physical file size and download size. A background image can b—

5 pixels or taller, depending on how many colors are used. If colors are kept to ‘

minimum, there is no harm in making the image 20 or 30 pixels high.

Internet Explorer Background Attribute“

Internet Explorer supports a few special attributes for thk  <BODY  element that ma_

solve background image and layout problems without resorting to style sheets. Thk

BGPROPERTIES  attribute offers a solution to the problem of scrolling backgroun™

images. At present, however, it is only supported by Internet Explorer 3 and aboveì

Thk  <BODY  element’s attribute and valuk  BGPROPERTIES="fixed"  will, undeK

Internet Explorer, allow text and images to scroll while the background image accesse™

with thk  BACKGROUN¤  attribute remains in place. The only value for this attributk

i—  fixed  ì

 = Page 262 =

ChapteX 6  Introductio‘ tW Layout Backgroundsp Colorsp an Tex@  24h

Thk  <BODY  element also allows the setting of margins; but, so far, this is onl_

realized under Internet Explorer. There are twf  <BODY  attributes that affect margins:

LEFTMARGIN  an™  TOPMARGIN  . Each is set with a number value. For example,

LEFTMARGIN="25"  will create a margin of 25 pixels between the left edge of thk

browser window and its content;  TOPMARGIN="15"  will create a 15-pixel margi-

between the top of the browser window and its content, as well as at the bottom if thk

content extends that farì

While many of the body properties discussed in the last few sections are useful tf

set the color and image attributes of a page, many of them are browse§specific or ark

PRESENTATION AND

deprecated under HTML 4. It is too soon to tell if users will embrace image layout vi¾

style sheets or continue to use the elements previously discussed. For backwarÙ

LUT

compatibility, it may be necessary to use both layout forms for another year or twoì

Summar

While HTML does not provide a great deal of support for layout, it really wasn’t meanš

to. While it is easy to say that people shouldn’t use HTML to lay out pages, the fact i—

that they wanted and needed to. Designers desperately want pixe_level layout controR

of Web pages and support for fonts. The need for improved page design gave rise tf

the occasional abuse of HTML elements, “cheats” like the invisibl[pixel GIF trick, an™

to proprietary elements such a—  <SPACER  . Despite the improvement in layouš

capabilities, font— ark stilR a- ope- issuk i- HTML; but, wit— somk assumption— regardiný

the use of downloadable font technology, font use is becoming a reality on the Webì

Chapter 7 presents tables that make it possible to create fairly precise layouts usiný

HTML. However, later chapters reveal that many of the problems raised in this chapteK

and Chapter 7 will cease once style sheets become more prevalent. Then thk element—

discusse™ i- thi— chapteK ma_ bk eliminate™ oK ma_ retur- tf theiK originaR purposeì

 = Page 263 =

Thispbbintentional8yleftPlank‘

 = Page 264 =

Chapte7 P

Layout with Table

24

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 265 =

24  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

hk  <TABLE  element and its associated elements have become one of the mosš

commonly used means of creating Web page layouts. While positioning throug—

style sheets (Chapter 10) should provide more precise layout capacities, browseK

¾

support is inconsistent, and the issue of backwarÙcompatibility remains a concern. FoK

better or worse, this leaves the table approach to page layout as the only one likely tf

work across multiple browsers. Tables are not limited to layout, however, as the lateK

portions of this chapter will discussì

Introduction to Table“

A table represents information in a tabular way, like a spreadsheet: distributed across ¾

grid of rows and columns. In printed documents, tables commonly serve a subordinatk

function, illustratiný somk poinš describe™ b_ a- accompanyiný textì Table— stilR perfor“

this illustrative function in HTML documents. Because HTML does not offer the samk

layout capacities available to print designers, We~based tables have also become ¾

common way to create document layout and design. But unlike printed tables, HTML

tables can contain information that i—  dynamic¨  or interactive, such as the results of ¾

database query. To address this use, the databinding feature allows an HTML tablk

templatk tf bk directl_ connecte™ wit— ¾ databask sourceì A tablk i— dynamicall_ generate™

using the template and the results of a particular database query. Taken together, thesk

capabilities make tables one of HTML’s most useful and sophisticated resourcesì

Simple Table“

In its simplest form, a table places information inside the cells formed by dividing ¾

rectangle into rows and columns. Most cells contain data. Some cells, usually on thk

table’— to5 oK side, contai- headingsì HTML represent— ¾ basi´ tablk usiný fouK elementsì

I- HTML, ¾ table,  <TABLE  …  </TABLE  , contain— onk oK mork rows,  <TR  …  </TR  ì

Each row contains cells holding a heading,  <TH  …  </TH  , or data,  <TD  …  </TD  ì

The following code example illustrates a basic table. Note that the only attribute use™

in this example i—  BORDE  , which is used to specify a —pixel border so it is clear whaš

thk tablk look— likeì Thk renderiný foK thk simplk tablk undeK variou— browser— i— show-

in Figure Lslash1ì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Simple Table Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<TABLE BORDER="1"L

 = Page 266 =

24‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

This simple table example shows the use of the most basic table elements: headings,

rows, and data cellsì

Again, a table is made up of rows enclosed withi-  <TR  . . ì  </TR  . The numbeK

of rows in the table is determined by the number of occurrences of thk  <TR  elementì

What about columns? Generally, the number of columns in a table is determined by thk

maximum number of data cells indicated b_  <TD  . . ì  </TD  , or headings indicate™

b_  <TH  . . ì  </TH  within the table. It may be useful to hint to the browser at thk

number of columns in the table by setting thk  COLS  attribute, introduced in HTML 4,

for thk  <TABLE  element equal to the number of columns in the table (for example,

<TABLE BORDER="1" COLS="2"  , as in the last example)ì

Thk heading— foK thk tablk ark seš usiný thk  <TH  elementì Generally, thk browseK

render— thk stylk o“ heading— differently, possibl_ centeriný thk content— o“ thk headiný

an™ placiný thk texš i- bol™ typeì Thk actuaR cell— o“ thk tablk ark indicate™ b_ thk  <TD

elementì Bot— thk  <TD  an™  <TH  element— ma_ enclosk a- arbitrar_ amounš o“ dat¾ o“

jusš abouš an_ typeì I- thk previou— example, ¾ fulR paragrap— o“ texš coul™ bk enclose™

i- ¾ tablk celR aloný wit— a- image, lists, an™ linksì Last, thk tablk ma_ havk ¾ captio-

enclose™ withi-  <CAPTION  ..ì  </CAPTION  , whosk content— ark generall_ rendere™

abovk oK belou thk tablk indicatiný whaš thk tablk containsì

The closing tags for thk  <TR <TH  ,  , an™  <TD  tags are optional under the HTML

specification. While this may make for cleane§looking code in your HTML documents,

HTML writers are still encouraged to use the closing tags, as well as indentation. Thi—

will assure that table cells and rows are clearly defined, particularly for nested tables,

and avoid problems with Netscape, which often “breaks” tables that don’t use closiný

tags for these elementsì

ROWSPAN and COLSPAN

While the previous example shows that it is possible to create a simple table with ¾

simple structure, what about when the table cells need to be larger or smaller? Thk

HTML code that follows creates tables that are somewhat more complicated. By addiný

thk  ROWSPAN  an™  COLSPAN  attributes to the table elements, it is possible to creatk

data cells that span a given number of rows or columns. The rendering of this codk

appears in Figure Lslash2ì

<TDL  Element 2  </TDL

</TRL

The basic idea of thk  ROWSPAN  an™  COLSPAN  attributes foK  <TD  an™  <TH  i—

to extend the size of the cells across two or more rows or columns, respectively. To seš

a cell to span three rows, usk  <TD ROWSPAN="3"  ; to set a heading to span twf

columns, usk  <TH COLSPAN="2"  . Setting the value o“  ROWSPAN  to more than thk

number of rows in the table does not extend the size of the table. Browsers should noš

add rows or columns when attributes suggest that there are moreì

Beside— beiný ablk tf spa- row— an™ columns, thk  <TABLE  element, a— welR a— it—

enclose™ element—  <TD <TH  ,  , an™  <CAPTION  , support— ¾ variet_ o“ attribute— foK

alignment, sizing, an™ layoutì Thk followiný examplk show— ¾ mork complex kin™ o“ tableì

The preceding example shows that it is possible to place any form of content in ¾

cell, as well as control the individual size of the cells and the table itself. The logicaR

step is to control page layout by creating a grid with thk  <TABLE  elementì

Tables for Layou

I- themselves, table— df noš see“ thaš interestiný tf man_ peopleì The_ are, however,

¾ ver_ importanš tooR foK HTML pagk layoutì Thk foundatio- o“ graphi´ desig- i— thk

abilit_ tf spatiall_ arrangk visuaR element— i- relatio- tf eac— otherì Table— ca- bk use™

PRESENTATION AND

tf defink ¾ layouš gri™ foK jusš thi— purposeì PrioK tf thk advenš o“ stylk sheet— supportiný

positioning, table— werk thk onl_ reliablk wa_ tf accomplis— thisì The_ remai- thk mosš

LUT

commonl_ use™ techniqueì

The key to using a table in order to create a precise page grid is the use of thk

WIDTh  attribute. Thk  WIDTh  attribute for thk  <TABLE  element specifies the widt—

of a table in pixels, or as percentage value, such a—  80%  . It is also possible to set thk

individual pixel widths of each cell within the table, using ¾  WIDTh  attribute for thk

<TD  oK  <TH  elements. Imagine trying to create a 400-pixel column of text down thk

page with a buffer of 50 pixels on the left and 100 pixels on the right. With oldeK

HTML, this would be literally impossible without making the text a giant image. Wit—

a table, it is easy, as shown by the markup code here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Table LayouM  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<TABLE BORDER="0"L

<TRL

<TD WIDTH="50"><BR></TDL

<TD WIDTH="400"L

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Layout is here!  </H1L

<HRL

<PL  This is a very simple layout that would hav4

been nearly impossible to do without tables<  </PL

</TDL

<TD WIDTH="100">&nbsp;</TDL

</TRL

</TABLEL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

250  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

I- thk precediný code, thk  BORDE  valuk i— seš tf zeroì Thi— attributk isn’š necessary;

if the browser does not see ¾  BORDE  attribute in thk  <TABLE  element, it won’š

draw a border. It may be convenient to keep the attribute in but set to zero, so thk

border can be turned on and off to check to see what is going on with a particulaK

layout. When creating empty table cells, it is a good idea to put a line break  <BR

or a nonbreaking space (  &nbsp;  ) into the cell so it doesn’t collapse verticallyì

Table— mighš alsf bk use™ tf providk mork precisk layouš i- relatio- tf ¾ backgroundì

In HTML documents, tables have many nontraditional uses for graphic design an™

BGCOLO  attribute sets the background color for a table using either a standar™

color name or hexadecimal RGB value. The given value indicates a light pastel yellowì

Figurs 7-38  Rendering of foreground/background layoud

25p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Thk  CELLPADDIN…  attribute sets the distance in pixels between a table cell’s outeK

border and the point at which content begins. Besides “sticky” notes and other form—

of colored tables to draw out information, there are various uses for singl[cell tablesì

When combined with width, this might just be a good way to constrain the text withi-

a pageì

Advanced Layout Using Table“

Creating more sophisticated layouts with tables can be relatively simple. The followiný

code example shows how a table can be used to create a twkcolumn layout with texš

and an image. Text in the code example has been truncated to preserve space. Thk

COLSPAN  attribute is used to create table cell— (  <TD  ) that contain headlines an™

subheaders that run across the width of the entire table. Thk  CELLPADDIN…  attributk

foK  <TABLE  is set tf  10  to prevent the text in the columns from running too closk

together. The rendering of this code is shown in Figure Lslash4ì

<!DOCTYPc HTMX PUBLIL "-//W3C//DT— HTMX 4. Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<TITLEL  2-ColumY DocumenM LayouM wit— Tabl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<TABLc CELLSPACING="0h CELLPADDING="10h BORDER="1h WIDTH="550"L

<TRL

<T— COLSPAN=h ALIGN="center"L

<FON. FACE="Arial Black, Helvetica, Sans-serifh SIZE="+2"L

FEZ: IMPERIAL JEWEL OF MOROCCO  </FONT></TDL

<T— WIDTH="50%h VALIGN="middle"L

<BL  Beyond th4 Bo‚ Jeloud Gate..<  </B></FONT></TDL

It is also possible to apply tables to layout in a more complicated fashion. Layout—

combining text and images can be created using large graphics that incorporate text,

but this approach produces pages that are slow to download. The code example thaš

follows shows a more complicated layout that breaks up an image and reassembles iš

like a jigsaw puzzle, using a table as an invisible “frame” to hold it in place. Note thaš

links have not been applied to the graphic links in this code (for example, widgets.gif)

in order to simplify the code exampleì

When creating a layout like this, it is very important to set thk  CELLPADDIN…

an™  CELLSPACIN…  attributes tf . Table cell widths should correspond to the widt—  0

 = Page 277 =

25‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 7-58  Rendering of layout with “jigsaw” imagP

of the image inside the cell, and the width of the table should be the sum of the cells i-

a table row. It is also important to include thk  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  attributes of thk

images used. Figure Lslash5 shows a browser rendering of this layout, with an overlay tf

show where the image is broken upì

Note that the image consists of GIFs and JPEGs. “Photographic” areas of the imagk

have been saved as JPEGs, while areas with limited color, such as simple text, havk

been saved as GIFs. By saving each area in the appropriate format, it is possible tf

reduce the overall file size and optimize performance. (This is discussed in more detaiR

in Chapter 5.)

Tables in HTML 

So far, the discussion of tables has mentioned five elements:  <TABLE <CAPTION  ,  ,

<TR <TH  ,  , an™  <TD  . These are the most commonly used elements. HTML 4

introduces several new elements that provide increased control over table formatting:

<COL <COLGROUP <THEAD <TFOOT  ,  ,  ,  , an™  <TBODY  . An HTML table a—

defined by the HTML 4.0 specification has the following structure:

  An openiný  <TABLE  elementì

  An optional caption specified b_  <CAPTION  . . ì  </CAPTION  ì

  One or more groups of rows. These may consist of a header section specified b_

<THEAD  , ¾ footeK sectio- specifie™ b_  <TFOOT  , an™ ¾ bod_ sectio- specifie™

 = Page 278 =

ChapteX 7  Layou@ wit— Table  25

b_  <TBODY  . While all these elements are optional, the table must at leasš

contain a series of rows specified b_  <TR  . The rows themselves must contai-

at least one header or data cell, specified b_  <TH  an™  <TD  , respectivelyì

  One or more groups of columns specified b_  <COLGROUP  with individuaR

columns within the group indicated b_  <COL  ì

  A closiný  </TABLE  elementì

The main difference between HTML 4 tables and the more basic table form is thaš

PRESENTATION AND

rows and columns may be grouped together. The advantage to grouping is that iš

conveys structural information about the table that may be useful for rendering thk

table more quickly, or keeping it together when displaying on the screen. For example,  LUT

specifying thk  <THEAD  oK  <TFOOT  may allow a consistent header or footer to bk

use™ acros— largeK table— whe- the_ spa- man_ screen— (oK sheet— o“ papeK whe- printed)ì

The use of these elements is mandatory when working with dynamicall_ populate™

table— thaš incorporatk databindiný a— introduce™ b_ Microsofš an™ discusse™ laterfi-

this chapter. The following example explains the use of the new HTML 4 tablk

elementsì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  HTMLY Table?  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<TABLE BORDER="1" FRAME="BOX" RULES="GROUPS"L

<CAPTIONL  Fun with Food  </CAPTIONL

<COLGROUPL

<COLL

</COLGROUPL

<COLGROUPL

<COL ALIGN="CENTER"L

<COL ALIGN="CHAR" CHAR="."L

</COLGROUPL

<THEADL

<TRL

<TH BGCOLOR="yellow"L  FruiM  </THL

<TH BGCOLOR="yellow"L  ColoI  </THL

<TH BGCOLOR="yellow"L  Cost per pound  </THL

</TRL

</THEADL

 = Page 279 =

258  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<TBODYL

<TRL

<TDL  Grape?  </TDL

Thk firsš thiný tf notick i- thi— codk i— thk usk o“ thk  FRAM¨  an™  RULES  attribute—

foK thk  <TABLE  elementì Thk  FRAM¨  attributk specifie— whic— side— o“ thk framk thaš

surround— thk tablk wilR bk visibleì I- thi— example, thk valuk i— seš tf , whic— mean—  BOX

thaš thk framk aroun™ thk outsidk o“ thk tablk i— onì OtheK value— foK thi— attributk includk

ABOV¨ BELOW HSIDES VSIDES LHS RHS VOI¤  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  BORDE  ì Thk meaniný

o“ alR thesk value— i— discusse™ i- thk tablk syntax section— thaš followì

Do not confuse the idea of thk  FRAM¨  attribute with that o“  RULES  . Thk  RULES

attribute defines the rules that may appear between the actual cells in the table. In thk

example, the value o“  RULES  is set tf  GROUPS  ; this displays lines between the row oK

column groupings of the table. Thk  RULES  attribute also takes a value o“  NON¨  ,

GROUPS ROWS COLS  ,  ,  , an™  ALL  ì

Thk otheK majoK differenck i- thk HTML codk foK thk tablk show- abovk i— thk

inclusio- o“ thk  <THEAD  an™  <TBODY  elementsì  <THEAD  contains the row—

(  <TR  ), headings (  <TH  ), an™ cell— (  <TD  ) thaš makk ¾5 thk hea™ o“ thk tableì Beyon™

 = Page 280 =

ChapteX 7  Layou@ wit— Table  259

organizatio- an™ thk applicatio- o“ styles, thk advantagk o“ groupiný thesk item— [— thaš iš

ma_ Dk possiblk to repeat the elements over multiple pages (under certain browsers)ì

Imagine printing out a large table and having the headers for the rows appear on ever_

page of the printout. This is whaš  <THEAD  may be able to provide. Similarly, thk

<TFOOT  element creates a footer to use in the table, which may also run oveK

multiple pages. Last,  <TBODY  indicates the body of the table, which contains thk

rows and columns that make up the inner part of a table. While there should be onl_

one occurrence o“  <THEAD  an™  <TFOOT  , there may be multiple occurrences o“

<TBODY  . Multiple bodies in a document may seem confusing, but these elements ark

PRESENTATION AND

more for grouping purposes than anything else. When a table is specified withouš

<THEAD <TFOOT  ,  , oK  <TBODY>,  it is assumed to have one body by defaultì

LUT

While tables are becoming more difficult to code, you can take heart from thk

variety of tools that can be used to create them. Most HTML editing tools can easil_

add the elements needed to make tables. This is good, since the combination o“

HTML 4’s new table elements with various proprietary extensions introduced b_

Microsoft, Netscape, and WebTV results in a dizzying array of elements, and attribute—

for the individual table elements. The next few sections specify a complete syntax foK

the various table elementsì

<TABLE> Element“

Every table is defined by thk  <TABLE  element, which must have a correspondiný

</TABLE  element. These elements indicate that the contained content is organize™

into a table with rows and columns as specified by thk  <TR <TD  ,  , an™  <TH

elements. It is also possible to use thk  <CAPTION <COL <COLGROUP  ,  ,  ,

<THEAD <TBODY <TFOOT  ,  ,  , an™  <THEAD  elements to organize a tablk

and apply attributes to numerous columns, rows, and data cells at once. Appendix A

lists the complete syntax for all of these elementsì

Databinding: TablesGenerate

from a Data Sourcs

Tables often contain row after row of identically formatted data that originates in ¾

database. There are two basic methods to create these datDdependent tables. NeitheK

one is ideal:

  If the table data is relatively static, it is common to build a long table by hand oK

with a tool, individually coding each data cellì

  If the table data is dynamic, it is common to generate the entire page containiný

the table using a serve§side CGI (Common Gateway Interface) technologyì

Thk firsš approac— i— difficulš foK a- HTML authorì Thk second, whic— doe— noš reall_

qualif_ a— HTML authoring, usuall_ require— programmingì  Databindinv  i— ¾ technolog_

recentl_ introduce™ b_ Microsofš tf dynamicall_ bin™ HTML element— tf dat¾ cominý

 = Page 281 =

260  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

fro“ a- externaR sourceì Whilk noš technicall_ restricte™ tf HTML tables, iš doe— represenš

¾ simpler, mork powerfuR approac— foK generatiný largk datDdependenš tablesì

In HTML databinding, a data source that provides information is associated with ¾

data consumer that presents it. The data source is a control with some means to acces—

external information that is embedded in an HTML document using thk  <OBJECT

elementì Thi— element, briefl_ introduce™ i- ChapteK 9, i— furtheK explaine™ i- ChapteK 15ì

For now, it will be useful to understand thaš  <OBJECT  adds a small program to thk

page that can be used to access an external data source. The document also contains ¾

dat¾ consumer, a- HTML elemenš thaš use— speciaR attribute— tf askthk ActiveX controR

for data that the element subsequently displays. Data consumers come in two sorts:

those that present single data values, and those that present tabular data. Tables falR

into the latter categoryì

Creating an HTML table using databinding is a very simple process. It is onl_

necessary to define one table row. The rest are generated automatically accordiný

to the template defined by the first row. Think of each row in a tabular data set a—

corresponding to a database record, and each column as corresponding to a databask

fieldì A templatk tablk rou i— define™ i- HTML thaš associate—  <TD  oK  <TH  element—

with field names in the data set. A table will subsequently be generated with one rou

foK eac— recor™ i- thk dat¾ set, an™ wit— celR value— fille™ i- fro“ thk appropriatk recor™

fields. The data source control may support processing capabilities such as sorting oK

filtering the data set. If so, the table can be dynamically regenerated on the client sidk

in response to update information from the data sourceì

For example, a data source may contain a tabular data set for product prick

information. One field may contain the name of the product, another its price. B_

default, a table could present this information sorted alphabetically by product nameì

In response to a button on an HTML page, the data source could sort the data set b_

price. The table that displays the information would be dynamically regenerated. Thk

following is a simple databinding exampleì

An external data file contains two or more columns of commDdelimited data. Thk

first line contains the names of the data set fields corresponding to the columns. Thk

following lines contain the actual data for the appropriate fields. A sample file calle™

alphabet.txt is shown here:

Letter, Thin(

A, Appl4

B, Boh

C, CaM

D, Do(

E, ElephanM

F, Fov

G, Gir¤

H, HaM

 = Page 282 =

ChapteX 7  Layou@ wit— Table  26h

To access the data, an HTML document references an object for a data sourck

control and a related table definition. An example of how this would be accomplishe™

is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Data Binding Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL  PRESENTATION AND

<BODYL

LUT

<OBJECT ID="alphabeth

CLASSID="clsid:333C7BC4-460F-11D0-BC04-0080C7055A83"L

<PARAM NAME="DataURL" VALUE="alphabet.txt"L

<PARAM NAME="UseHeader" VALUE="True"L

</OBJECTL

<TABLE DATASRC="#alphabet" BORDER="1"L

<THEADL

<TR BGCOLOR="yellow"L

<THL  LetteI  </THL

<THL  RemindeI  </THL

</TRL

</THEADL

<TBODYL

<TR ALIGN="center"L

<TD><SPAN DATAFLD="Letter"></SPAN> </TDL

<TD><SPAN DATAFLD="Thing"></SPAN></TDL

</TRL

</TBODYL

</TABLEL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Thi— HTML codk generate— ¾ tablk fro“ thk filk alphabet.txš i- whic— eac— tablk rou

contain— ¾ letteK o“ thk alphabeš an™ thk namk f“ ¾ thiný thaš ca- remin™ thk readeK o“ thaš

letterì Thk renderiný o“ thi— examplk undeK Interneš ExploreK 4 [— show- [- Figurk Lslash6ì

Examine a little more closely the pieces needed to make this databinding examplk

work. First, the data source. This example uses the Tabular Data Control (TDC) object:

an ActiveX control provided by Microsoft and identified by the lengthy class identifierì

This particular control locates and manipulates text data files in a tabular format. OtheK

controls supporting databinding could have been used instead. These might supporš

 = Page 283 =

26p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 7-68  Databinding example under Internet Explorer 4

different data access capabilities such as access to remote relational databases. Thk

Microsoft ActiveX Data Objects control (ADO), however, is a representative exampleì

The TDC supports several parameters of which two are used in this example. Thk

"DataURL"  parameter tells the TDC the name and location of the data file it is to useì

In this case, since only a filename is provided, the TDC looks in the same director_

containing the Web page. By default, the TDC treats every line in a data file as dataì

Thk  "UseHeader"  parameter tells the TDC that the first line in the data file does noš

contain data but rather the names of data fieldsì

As a data consumer, thk  <TABLE  element uses it—  DATASR‚  attribute to connecš

to a data source. Note in the example how this attribute is set to the name of thk

<OBJECT  tag invoking the data source control. The name must be preceded by thk  #

symbol. Thk  <OBJECT  element must declare a name using thk  I¤  attribute in ordeK

to be accessed by a data consumer. In summary, thk  DATASR‚  attribute identifies ¾

data source to be used in generating a tableì

The next step is to associate cells in the template table row with particular fields i-

the data set. This is done using thk  DATAFL¤  attribute of appropriate elements. Iš

contains the name of the field in the data set that its element is to be bound to. If dat¾

set–specific names are not defined, fields can be identified using default positionaR

 = Page 284 =

ChapteX 7  Layou@ wit— Table  26

names such a—  Column1 Column2  ,  , and so on. Thk  <TD  tag, commonly used for celR

data, doe— noš supporš thk  DATAFL¤  attributeì Tf bin™ ¾ fiel™ tf ¾ tablk cell, thk  <TD

tag needs to contain one of the elements that do supporš  DATAFL¤  . The elements thaš

make the most sense in the context of a table ark  <SPAN <DIV <OBJECT  ,  ,  , an™

<IMG  . The latter two tags illustrate that databinding is not confined to textual dataì

For example, a column of images can be created by using a tag declaration such a—

<IMG DATAFLD="Picture"  inside a table cell. Note that the usuaR  SR‚  attribute i—

not required. Instead, thk  DATAFL¤  attribute identifies a field inside the data set thaš

contains a valid image filename, such as mypict.gif, and binds the image to that valueì

PRESENTATION AND

I“ ¾ tablk doe— noš explicitl_ declark headeK oK footeK sectio- elements, the- implicitl_

all table content is in the body section. In static tables, this does not usually have visuaR

LUT

consequences, buš iš doe— i- table— generate™ b_ databindingì AlR bod_ row— ark include™

in the template for table row generation, not just the rows containing databound fieldsì

To prevent header or footer information from being repeated for every row in the table,

it is necessary to enclose it with thk  <THEAD  oK  <TFOOT  element. Thk  <TBODY

element can then be used to signal the beginning of the template to be databoundì

Such a brief example scratches the surface of databinding and merely shows thk

importance of tables in relation to dynamic data. For more information on databinding,

visit Microsoft Sitebuilder, at http://www.microsoft.com/sitebuilder, and the Remotk

Data Service site, at http://www.microsoft.com/data/ado/rds/ì

Summar

The development of tables was the first step toward effective layout of HTML pagesì

Tables provide a useful structure in which to place text and images, but they will likel_

be superceded by positioning with style sheets (discussed in Chapter 10); however, thaš

will have to wait until style sheets are more widely supported by browsers. At thaš

time, tables will continue to be important for use with dynamic data, as discussed i-

the preceding section. Chapter 8 addresses two more options for page layout—frame—

and layers—and weighs the pros and cons of bothì

 = Page 285 =

Thispbbintentional8yleftPlank‘

 = Page 286 =

Chapte7 X

Advanced Layout

Frames and Layer

26P

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 287 =

26‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

ables and the other HTML techniques introduced in Chapters 6 and 7 provide ¾

significant improvement in Web page layout. Many designers want even mork

design facilities, including multiple windows and layers. Such expectations aren’š

¾

unreasonable, because these features are common in design programs and computeK

interfaces. Such power comes at a price, however. Frames and layers may providk

significant layout flexibility, but when misused, these structures can confuse users—oK

even lock them out of your site completelyì

Frame“

A frame™ documenš divide— ¾ browseK windou intf multiplk panes, oK smalleK windou

framesì Eac— framk “a_ contai- ¾ differenš documentì Thk benefit— o“ thi— approac— ark

obviousì User— ca- vieu informatio- i- onk framk uhilk keepiný anotheK framk ope- foK

reference, instea™ o“ moviný backan™ fort— betwee- pagesì Thk content— o“ onk framk ca-

bk manipulated, oK  linke  , šf thk content— o“ anotherì Thi— enable— designer— tf buil™

sophisticate™ interfacesì FoK example, onk framk ca- contai- link— thaš produck ¾ resulš i-

anotheK frameì A- examplk o“ suc— a- interfack i— show- [- Figurk 1ì

Figurs 8-18  Example frame interfacP

 = Page 288 =

ChapteX 8  Advance Layout Frame an Layer  26

Frames offer many possibilities. They can contain tables of contents, site indexes,

and lists of links. Frames offeK  fixed-screen navigatioc  —whereby certain information i—

always at the forefront—and other options not found in the singl[window approachì

However, framed documents can be difficult to deal with. When Netscape 2

introduced the concept of frames, many users were very confused by framed Web sitesì

Frames couldn’t be printed, sites were hard to bookmark, and the Back button o“

browsers didn’t work as expected. Regardless, many site designers, excited by a neu

approach, rushed to develop framed pages. Then, they removed them just as quickly,

due to navigation problems and user complaintsì

PRESENTATION AND

Today, many of the problems associated with frames have been fixed at thk

browser level, and users have become more comfortable understanding and workiný

LUT

with frames. Used properly in the right situation, as discussed in this chapter, frame—

are an important tool in the Web designer’s toolbox. No longer considered proprietar_

browser extensions, frames are included in the HTML 4.0 standardì

Overview of Frame“

A  fram—  i— a- independenš scrolliný region, oK window, o“ ¾ WeD pageì Ever_ WeD

pagk ma_ bk divide™ intf man_ individuaR frames, whic— ca- eve- bk neste™ withi-

otheK framesì Fixe™ scree- size— limiš hou man_ frame— ca- realisticall_ bk use™

simultaneouslyì Eac— framk i- ¾ windou ma_ bk separate™ fro“ thk other— wit— ¾

border; i- thi— way, ¾ frame™ documenš ma_ resemblk ¾ tableì However, frame— aren’š ¾

fanc_ for“ o“ tablesì Eac— separatk framk ma_ contai- ¾ differenš document, indicate™ b_

¾ uniquk URLì Becausk thk document— include™ i- ¾ frame™ regio- ma_ bk muc— largeK

tha- thk roo“ availablk onscreen, eac— framk ma_ providk ¾ scrolR baK oK otheK control—

tf manipulatk thk sizk o“ thk frameì IndividuaR frame— usuall_ ark named, sf thaš the_

ma_ bk reference™ throug— link— fK scripting, allowiný thk content— o“ onk framk tf affecš

thk content— o“ anotherì Thi— referenciný capabilit_ i— ¾ majoK differenck betwee- table—

an™ framesì Frame— providk layouš facilitie— , potentially, navigationì Figurk 2  an

provide— ¾ visuaR overvieu o“ thk component— o“ ¾ frame™ documentì

Simple Frame Exampls

The first point to remember is that a framed document is composed of severaR

documents. To illustrate, a page with two frames actually involves three files:

  The framing document that defines the framing relationshi5

  The file that contains the contents of frame onk

  The file that contains the contents of frame twf

Consider the simple twkframe document shown in Figure 3. The first frame, o-

the left, covers about 20 percent of the screen and contains a table of contents. Thk

larger column on the right, which takes up the other 80 percent of the screen, display—

the actual contents. For the purposes of this example, the left frame is named Controls,

and the right frame is named Displayì

 = Page 289 =

268  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Links control the contenš

Frame 2

of frame 2

Frame Ç

Frame bordeK

Scroll baK

Figurs 8-28  Frame road ma—

To specify the framing document, you need to create a file that uses thk

<FRAMESET  element instead of thk  <BODY  element. Thk  <FRAMESET  elemenš

defines the set of frames that makes up the document. The major attributes for thi—

element are thk  ROWS  oK  COLS  attributes. In this case, two columns take up seš

percentages of the total screen, so the code read—  <FRAMESET COLS="20%, 80%"  ì

Setting up something likk  <FRAMESET ROWS="10%, 80%, 10%"  would be just a—

easy, which sets up three rows across the screenì

Thk  ROWS  an™  COLS  attributes can also be set to pixel values, so thaš

<FRAMESET COLS="200, 400"  defines a column 200 pixels wide, followed by ¾

column 400 pixels wide. Because determining the exact size of the screen is difficult,

setting these attributes to exact values might be dangerous. If absolute pixels are use™

and the screen is larger than the area specified, an empty space appears in the browseK

window. If the screen is smaller than the specified frame values, scrolling may bk

required. Because of this, use absolute pixel values only when they make senseì

 = Page 290 =

ChapteX 8  Advance Layout Frame an Layer  269

PRESENTATION AND

LUT

Figurs 8-38  Visual idea of frame examplP

If you know that the Controls frame contains a graphic that is 150 pixels across,

consider setting the size of the first frame to 175 pixels, to fit the graphic plus somk

white space. If the frame were any smaller than this size, the graphic would be clipped,

so using an absolute pixel value makes sense when you know the size of the contentsì

But what should the size of the other frame be? To simply take up the rest of the scree-

with whatever is left over after 175 pixels, use the wildcard character ( ) to specify usk  *

of the rest of the screen. The code for such a frame set i—  <FRAMESET COLS="175,*"  ì

In summary, thk  ROWS  an™  COLS  attributes may be set to pixels, percentages, or ¾

wildcard value. You may use multiple occurrences of wildcards, and you may mix an™

match values. However, you should stick with all percentages or all pixels, and usk

wildcards only where neededì

After you specify the frame layout with thk  <FRAMESET  element, the content—

of each frame must be specified by using thk  <FRAME  element in the order that thk

frames are defined in thk  ROW  oK  COL  attribute. In the case o“  <FRAMESE

COLS="175, 100, *"  , the contents of the firsš  <FRAME  element encountered ark

loaded in the 175-pixel column, the contents of the secon™  <FRAME  element ark

 = Page 291 =

270  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

loaded in the 100-pixel column, and so on. The primary attribute of thk  <FRAME

element i—  SR‚  , which is set to the URL of the document to load into the frame. Thk

NAM¨  attribute should be set to indicate the name of the frame. Naming of frames i—

important, because it allows each frame to be targeted by links and manipulated b_

scripting languages. A very simple example of a framing document follows:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Frameset//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Simple Frame Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<FRAMESET COLS=50,*"L

<FRAME SRC="fileone.htm" NAME="Controls"L

<FRAME SRC="filetwo.htm" NAME="Display"L

<NOFRAMES><PL  This document uses frames. Please follow this link

to :  <A HREF="noframes.htm"L  noframe?  </AL  version<

</NOFRAMESL

</FRAMESETL

</HTMLL

Thk precediný examplk use— thk  <NOFRAMES  …  </NOFRAMES  elemenš withi-

thk framk setì Thi— elemenš provide— informatio- tf bk displaye™ i- browser— thaš don’š

supporš framesì Althoug— thi— approac— seem— likk ¾ goo™ idea, yo¾ ma_ nee™ tf

maintai- bot— ¾ framk an™ ¾ nkframk versio- o“ ¾ site, tf accommodatk differenš

browsersì Yo¾ alsf nee™ tf defink thk individuaR documents, i- thi— cask fileone.ht“

an™ filetwo.htm, whic— ark loade™ intf thk framesì Fileone.ht“ i— show- here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  File On4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<xL  File 1  </xL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 292 =

ChapteX 8  Advance Layout Frame an Layer  27h

This is the code for filetwo.htm:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  File TwB  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL  PRESENTATION AND

<xL  File 2  </xL

</BODYL

LUT

</HTMLL

Putting all three files in the same directory and loading the framed example into ¾

browser should produce a rendering similar to the one shown in Figure 4ì

Figurs 8-48  Rendering of simple frame examplP

 = Page 293 =

27p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

To summarize, thk  <FRAMESET  an™  <FRAME  elements constitute the HTML

needed for frames. Thk  <FRAMESET  element:

  Enclose— thk  <FRAME  elemenš an™ define— thk structurk o“ thk frame™ documentì

  Must have ¾  </FRAMESET  close tagì

  May be nested within otheK  <FRAMESET  elements, to create a nested framk

structureì

  Should be used in place of thk  <BODY  element in the document that define—

the frame relationships. However, you can provide ¾  <BODY  element afteK

thk  <FRAMESET  in place of thk  <NOFRAMES  element as an alternativk

way to provide information for browsers that do not support framesì

Thk  <FRAME  element, which must occur within thk  <FRAMESET  element, ha—

the following attributes:

  The primary attributes are thk  SR‚  attribute, which indicates the URL of thk

frame content, and thk  NAM¨  attribute, which sets a name for the frame foK

linking and scripting purposesì

  The HTML 4 specification defines thk  FRAMEBORDE MARGINWIDTh  ,  ,

MARGINHEIGH NORESIZ¨  ,  , an™  SCROLLIN…  attributes, which controR

the basic presentation of the specified frameì

  BrowseK vendor— havk specifie™ numerou— addition— tf thk  <FRAME  elemenš tf

controR it— presentatio- an™ providk hook— šf stylk sheet— an™ scriptiný languagesì

The complete syntax for thk  <FRAME  an™  <FRAMESET  elements, as well as ¾

discussion of their attributes, is presented in Appendix Aì

Frame Targeting

When using frames, you often may find that making the links in one frame targeš

another frame is beneficial. This way, when a user clicks a button or activates a link i-

one framed document, the requested page loads in another frame. In the simple framk

example in the preceding section, you might want to have the frame named Control—

target the frame named Display. Link targeting has two steps:

1ì Ensure frame naming by setting thk  NAM¨  attribute in thk  <FRAME  elemenš

to a unique nameì

2ì Usk thk  TARGE  attributk i- thk  <A  elemenš tf seš thk targeš foK thk anchorì FoK

example, ¾ linksuc— a—  <G HREF="http://www.yahoo.com" TARGET="Display"

load— thk sitk specifie™ b_ thk  HREF  intf thk windouf called Display, if such ¾

frame exists. If the target specified by the name doesn’t exist, the link loads oveK

the window it is inì

Some particular values for thk  TARGE  attribute have special meaning, which ark

summarized in Table 1ì

 = Page 294 =

ChapteX 8  Advance Layout Frame an Layer  27

Valus  Meaning

_blank  Load the page into a new, generally unnamed, windowì

_self  Load the page over the current frameì

_parent  Load the link over the parent frameì

_top  Load the link over all the frames in the windowì

PRESENTATION AND

Tabls 8-18  ReserveP  TARGET  Value9

LUT

Thk  _top  value for thk  TARGE  attribute may be useful for “frame busting.” Man_

page authors don’t want their sites to be viewed under a framed environment. Settiný

thk  TARGE  attribute of the links within a site tf  _top  ensures that any frames beiný

used are removed after a link is followedì

Thk  _blank  value foK  TARGE  is also useful, because it opens another window i-

which to display the link. The only problem with this action is that the window ma_

tile directly on top of the previous browser window, and the user may not know thaš

multiple windows are openì

Thk  _parent  value isn’t encountered often, because it is useful only when frame—

are nested to a great degree. Thk  _parent  value enables you to overwrite the parenš

frame that contains the nested frame, without destroying any frames that the parenš

may be nested withinì

Thk  _self  value foK  TARGE  , which loads a page over its current frame, duplicate—

thk typicaR defaulš actio- foK mosš browsersì Iš ma_ bk useful, however, tf accommodatk

browsers whose default actions are set differentlyì

According to the HTML 4 specification, frame names beginning with an underscore ar—

discouraged, because they may be reserved for values such ax  _top  .

The following is an example for the file named fileone.htm. This HTML documenš

uses frame targeting with the names defined in the previous simple frame example:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Framed Document On4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1L  Framed Document On4  </H1L

<HRL

 = Page 295 =

27  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<x ALIGN="center"L  Test Link?  </xL

<ULL

<LI><A HREF="http://www.yahoo.com" TARGET="Display"L

Yahoo in frame named displah  </AL

<LI><A HREF="http://www.hotbot.com" TARGET="_new"L

HotBot in new window  </AL

<LI><A HREF="http://www.infoseek.com" TARGET="_self"L

Infoseek in this fram4  </AL

<LI><A HREF="http://www.excite.com" TARGET="_top"L

Excite over whole window  </AL

</ULL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

When using this example, you should consider naming it fileone.htm and using iP

within a frameset that defines a frame named Display. Otherwise, you may find that th—

browser simply creates a new window or overwrites the current window when the lin

that targets the undefined frame is selected.

The Use of <NOFRAMES>

Thk  <NOFRAMES  element is used to enclose the HTML and text that should bk

displayed when a browser that doesn’t support frames accesses the Web page. Thk

<NOFRAMES  element should be found only within thk  <FRAMESET  elementì

Nevertheless,  <NOFRAMES  is often found directly outside thk  <FRAMESET

element. Because of the permissive nature of browsers, this tends to be interprete™

correctlyì

The contents of thk  <NOFRAMES  element should be correct HTML, potentiall_

including thk  <BODY  element, which can be used as an alternative form for browser—

that don’t support frames. The following example provides the links that occur in thk

Controls frame for browsers that don’t support frames:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Frameset//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Simple Frame Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

 = Page 296 =

ChapteX 8  Advance Layout Frame an Layer  27

<FRAMESET COLS=50,*"L

<FRAME SRC="fileone.htm" NAME="Controls"L

<FRAME SRC="filetwo.htm" NAME="Display"L

<NOFRAMESL

<BL  No Frame NavigatioY  </BL

<BRL  PRESENTATION AND

<A HREF="http://www.yahoo.com"L  YahoB  </AL

<BRL

LUT

<A HREF="http://www.microsoft.com"L  MicrosofM  </AL

<BRL

<A HREF="http://www.netscape.com"L  Netscap4  </AL

</NOFRAMESL

</FRAMESETL

</HTMLL

Notick thaš thk approac— o“ puttiný ¾ secon™ cop_ o“ sitk contenš withi-  <NOFRAMES

make— thk sitk usablk acros— browsers, buš result— i- haviný tf updatk twf copie— o“ thk samk

contentì Becausk o“ thi— difficulty, man_ peoplk simpl_ puš ¾ statemenš i- thk  <NOFRAMES

elemenš thaš indicate— thk sitk require— ¾ fram[supportiný browseK foK viewingì Thi— doesn’š

makk thk sitk ver_ accessible, buš doe— cuš dow- o- contenš duplicationì

Floating Frame“

Up to this point, all the frames shown have been attached to the sides of the browseK

(left, right, top, or bottom). Another form of frame, called ¾  floating fram—  (introduce™

by Microsoft), has been incorporated into the HTML 4 standard. The idea of thk

floating frame is to create an inline framed region, or window, that acts similarly tf

any other embedded object, insofar as text can be flowed around it. An inline frame i—

defined by thk  <IFRAME  element and may occur anywhere within thk  <BODY

element of an HTML document. Compare this to thk  <FRAME  element, which shoul™

occur only within thk  <FRAMESET  element; remember that thk  <FRAMESET

element should preclude thk  <BODY  elementì

The major attributes to set for thk  <IFRAME  element includk  SR‚ HEIGH  ,  , an™

WIDTh  . Thk  SR‚  is set to the URL of the file to load, while thk  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh

are set to either the pixel or percentage value of the screen that the floatinframk

region should consume. Like a-  <IMG  element, floating frames should supporš

ALIGN HSPAC¨  ,  , an™  VSPAC¨  attributes for basic positioning within the flow o“

text. Note that, unlike thk  <FRAME  element, thk  <IFRAME  element comes with ¾

close tagì  <IFRAME  an™  </IFRAME  should contain any HTML markup code an™

 = Page 297 =

27‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

text that is supposed to be displayed in browsers that don’t support floating frames. A

simple example of floating frames is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Frameset//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Floating Frame Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Floating Frame Exampl4  </H1L

<IFRAME NAME="float1" SRC="fileone.htm" WIDTH="350" HEIGHT=00h

ALIGN="LEFT"L

There would be a floating frame here if your browser supported it<

</IFRAMEL

<PL  This is a simple example of how floating frames are used. Notic4

that in many ways the floating frame acts very similar to an inlin4

image. Floating frames act like embedded objects in many ways<  </PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Thk renderiný o“ thi— examplk codk i— show- [- Figurk 5ì Notk hou thk Netscapk

browseK doe— noš supporš thk  <IFRAME  element, buš render— thk enclose™ texš insteadì

The complete syntax foK  <IFRAME  is strikingly similar to thk  <IMG  element, a—

well as to other elements, such a—  <OBJECT  , that are used to insert other forms o“

content inline. Thk  <IFRAME  element, defined under HTML 4, includes many of thk

attributes that are expected. The most important attributes ark  SR‚  , which defines thk

content of the floating frame, an™  NAM¨  , which is used for link targeting. Because thk

floating frame is an inlined object, it also supports thk  ALIGN HEIGH  ,  , an™  WIDTh

attributes, which can be useful for content layout. The complete syntax of thk

<IFRAME  element is provided in Appendix Aì

Using Frame“

One of the biggest problems with frames is that they initially were used simpl_

because they existed. Framed documents can provide considerable benefit, but at ¾

price. A potential benefit of frames is that they allow content to be fixed onscreen. A—

demonstrated in previous examples, one frame may contain a table of contents, whilk

 = Page 298 =

ChapteX 8  Advance Layout Frame an Layer  27

PRESENTATION AND

LUT

Figurs 8-58  Rendering oS  <IFRAME>  examplP

the other frame contains the actual information. Keeping the table of contents onscree-

provides a convenient way to navigate the body of information. Furthermore, if onk

frame has fixed navigation, the user may perceive the Web interface to be mork

responsive, because only part of the screen needs to update between selections. Thk

primary benefit of frames is to present two or more things simultaneously, but thi—

extra window of information has its costs, as explained in the next sectionì

Frame Problem“

Many usability experts, such as Jakob Nielsen (http://www.useit.com), are extremel_

critical of frames. Given the current implementation of frames, and designers whf

don’t understand the potential drawbacks of framed documents, the statement thaš

“frames can give designers more rope to hang themselves with” has some truth to itì

 = Page 299 =

278  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

However, browser vendors are addressing many of the problems of frames. With luck,

designers will learn to use frames only when they provide added benefitì

The problems with frames are numerous, including design issues, navigatio-

confusion, bookmarking problems, loss of URL context, and printing issues. Designer—

may not like frames because they often have borders, which can look strange in ¾

design. However, modern frame implementations allow the designer to turn off framk

borders, so this really isn’t an issue anymore. The only potential design issue is thk

possibility that a framed document may sacrifice valuable screen real estate because o“

scroll bars, which could pose trouble for people with lowe§resolution monitors. Thk

only way to get around this problem is to limit the number of frames used on a pageì

Navigation confusion is still a big issue with frames. Under Netscape 2, the firsš

browser to implement frames, the browser Back button didn’t go back in the framk

history, but instead went back in the page history. Because Netscape 2 and subsequenš

versions of the browser do things differently, some lingering confusion may exist abouš

what “Back” means in a framed environment. Another problem involves the sense o“

what happens when a link is clicked. Unless the framing is kept very simple,

determining which frames will change when a link is clicked may not be obvious tf

users. In some sites, numerous frames are updated simultaneously, which may causk

users to lose their sense of navigation. Even worse, if users want to bookmark thk

current page, they actually have to bookmark the tošlevel entry frame rather than thk

deeper level to which they have progressed. If users bookmark the actual framk

content, they may lose any navigation needed to navigate the site upon returnì

Additional navigational problems include loss of context, because the URL of thk

document tends not to change, which accounts for why bookmarking doesn’t work a—

expected. Many people use URLs as a way to orient themselves at a site; frames give u5

this clue to locationì

Before the release of Internet Explorer 4, printing frames was difficult. Although thk

contents of individual frames could be printed, printing an entire document consistiný

of many frames generally was impossible. The newer versions of the Microsoft browseK

allow complete frame printing, but page authors should understand that content ma_

be clipped. While none of the problems with frames are insurmountable, designer—

should approach the technology with caution, and not just use it to show off theiK

technical prowessì

Layer“

Netscape introduced thk  <LAYER  element starting with the CommunicatoK

(Netscape 4) release of its browser. The layer function enables the page designer tf

define precisely positioned, overlapping layers of transparent or opaque content in ¾

page. Besides being able to stack layers on top of each other to create complex layouts,

authors can bind the layers to code that can move them around or change the order o“

overlap. Scripting combined with absolute positioning can truly make pages mork

 = Page 300 =

ChapteX 8  Advance Layout Frame an Layer  279

dynamic. Although thk  <LAYER  element does sound very useful, page author—

should use positioning with style sheets (discussed in Chapter 10) as the primary wa_

to control page layout absolutely. Thk  <LAYER  element is still relevant to thi—

discussion, however, because some users prefer usiný  <LAYER  in Netscape 4 tf

implement positioned pages, due to bugs with CSS implementation in that iteration o“

the browser. Layers are too Netscap[specific at this point to recommend their use. Thk

W3C doesn’t include layers in the HTML 4 specification, and isn’t considering layer—

for inclusion in future versions. The use of layers (as defined with this proprietar_

HTML element) should be approached with extreme caution. However, you may fin™

PRESENTATION AND

it helpful to know more about layering, so this section provides that informationì

The basic idea of a layer is similar to the idea of a frame, except that layers ma_

LUT

overlap. They generally are defined in the same document, unlike frames, whic—

require multiple documents. A layer defines a region or portion of the browseK

window that can be manipulated, and may overlap other layers. Layers come in twf

basic forms:

  Positioned layer—  Defined by thk  <LAYER  elemenš

  Inflow layer—  Defined by thk  <ILAYER  elemenš

This discussion focuses first on positioned layers, which are slightly easier tf

understandì

Positioned Layer“

To define a section of a document as a layer to position, enclose it withi-  <LAYER

an™  </LAYER  . The layer should be named, just as a frame is named, so that it can bk

manipulated later. To name a layer, set thk  I¤  attribute of the element to a uniquk

identifier. For a positioned layer, specify the upper corner of the layer by setting thk

TOL  an™  LEF  attributes to the pixel coordinates of the uppe§left corner of the layer,

relative to the browser window. You may also want to set thk  WIDTh  an™  HEIGH

attributes of the layer. These take pixel values, so the actual size of the layer can bk

controlled, regardless of its content. A simple example showing how absolutel_

positioned layers work is presented here:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Layer Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Simple Layer Exampl4  </H1L

 = Page 301 =

280  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<LAYER ID="Layer1" TOP="100" LEFT="50" BGCOLOR="lightgreen"L

<xL  This is a layer<  </xL

<ULL

<LIL  This layer is positioned at 100,150<

</ULL

</LAYERL

<LAYER ID="Laye" TOP="180" LEFT=50" BGCOLOR="orange"L

<xL  This is another layer<  </xL

<ULL

<LIL  This layer is positioned at 180,250<

</ULL

</LAYERL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Note that thk  BGCOLO  attribute is used with the layers to show how the layer—

clip each other. The rendering of the layer example is shown in Figure 6. To see hou

this code looks on a browser that does not support layers, see Figure 7ì

Because the position of layers is defined absolutely, you don’t need to define hou

they fall on a page; but it makes sense to define layers in a logical order, based on ¾

lefâtkright, toštkbottom flow of the pageì

For browsers that don’t support layers, thk  <NOLAYER  element may be usefulì

Content placed betwee-  <NOLAYER  an™  </NOLAYER  tags is ignored by a browseK

such as Netscape 4, which understands layers, but renders normally on all otheK

browsers that don’t comprehend layers. Thk  <NOLAYER  element enables you to ad™

extra information to the page, for nonlayering browsers that view your site. Becausk

browsers that don’t understand thk  <LAYER  element will attempt to display thk

contents of thk  <LAYER  element, as shown in Figure 7, you should use thk  SR‚

attribute to include the contents of the layer from another file, as shown here:

<LAYER ID="Layer1" SRC="layercontents.htm" TOP="100" LEFT="100"L

</LAYERL

<NOLAYERL

. . .standard HTML. . <

</NOLAYERL

 = Page 302 =

ChapteX 8  Advance Layout Frame an Layer  28h

PRESENTATION AND

LUT

Figurs 8-68  Rendering of layers under Netscape 4

With this technique, you can use layers without ruining the layout for otheK

browsers. As with frames, this may require keeping two separate forms of the site,

which may be unreasonableì

Inflow Layer“

Inflow layers are different than positioned layers, because inflow layers fall naturall_

within the flow of a document, much as an inlined object is positioned, such as a-

image. To indicate that content is part of an inflow layer, enclose it withi-  <ILAYER

an™  </ILAYER  tags. Unlike positioned layers, where the inflow layer is define™

 = Page 303 =

28p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 8-78  Attempted rendering of layers under Internet Explore

matters, and it affects where the content ends up on the page. Similar to thk  <LAYER

element, a name is probably required for the layer and should be set by using thk  I¤

attribute. You also can set thk  LEF  an™  TOL  values for the layer, but this positions thk

layer relative to the content that the layer is within, not within the uppe§left corner o“

the browser window or enclosing layer. This positioning may be useful to movk

content around by a certain number of pixels, relative to text in the document. A

simple example of inflow layers is shown here:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Inflow Layer Exampl4  </TITLEL

 = Page 304 =

ChapteX 8  Advance Layout Frame an Layer  28

</HEADL

<BODYL

<PL  An inflow layer can be found

<ILAYER ID="Layer1" BGCOLOR="yellow"L

within the flow  </ILAYERL  of text<  </PL

PRESENTATION AND

<PL  Thi?  <ILAYER ID="Laye" BGCOLOR="yellow" LEFT=5"L

is positioned 25 pixels from the lefM  </ILAYERL  of the currenM

LUT

flow of the content<  </PL

<PL  Thi?  <ILAYER ID="Layer3" BGCOLOR="yellow" TOP="15"L

is positioned 15 pixels below  </ILAYERL  the current flow o¨

content<  </PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Thk  BGCOLO  attribute is used again, so that when the example is rendered, thk

location of the layers can be determined. The rendering of this example is shown i-

Figure 8ì Note how the second inflow layer clips the text that follows it. Page author—

must be very careful with layers, because layers will clip other objects onscreen. This i—

their nature, by designì

Interesting Uses of Layer“

Although they are very proprietary, layers can be used to create a variety of interestiný

effects. The next chapter shows how to create similar effects by using style sheets,

which is the preferred way of doing things. One major aspect of layers is that, b_

default, they are transparent, unless the content in the layer covers the layer entirely,

as might happen with a layer’s background image. Because layers are normall_

transparent, you can overlay text on top of images. Before layers evolved, this wa—

difficult to do. (While background images and table cells offered some degree o“

 = Page 305 =

28  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 8-88  Rendering of inflow laye

control, it was very limited; the positioning of text on top of the image was far fro“

precise.) The following example shows how text may be positioned over an image:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Text Over Imag4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<LAYER TOP="100" LEFT="100"L

<IMG SRC="bclogonotext.gif" WIDTH="141" HEIGHT="197" BORDER="0"L

</LAYERL

 = Page 306 =

ChapteX 8  Advance Layout Frame an Layer  28

<LAYER TOP=00" LEFT="40"L

<FONT COLOR="red"L

<xL  Big Company, Inc<  </xL

</FONTL

</LAYERL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

PRESENTATION AND

In case you are skeptical of this newfound ability, a rendering of the example undeK

LUT

Netscape 4 is shown in Figure 9ì

Figurs 8-98  Rendering of text-over-image examplP

 = Page 307 =

28‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Programming Layer“

Layers become very interesting when they are combined with JavaScript. The clippiný

region of a layer can be changed incrementally so that, at first, none of the layer shows,

only to gradually appear in a matter of seconds. This effect is known as ¾  wip—  . Thi—

simple transition effect is an example o“  Dynamic HTML (DHTML)¨  discussed i-

Chapter 14ì The original direction of Netscape’s DHTML focused heavily on layers,

but now the preferred method is to use style sheets, discussed in Chapter 10. FoK

olÙtime’s sake, a layer example that creates a simple wipe is shown here:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Curtain Layer?  </TITLEL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

function wipe(alayer,xinc,inctime,stopwidth)

{

alayer.clip.left += -(xinc/2)

alayer.clip.right += (xinc/2)

if (alayer.clip.width < 0) {lyr.clip.width = 0}

i¨ (((xin < 0) && (alayer.clip.widt— > stopwidth)) || ((xin > 0) &&

(alayer.clip.width < stopwidth)))

{

setTimeout('wipe(document.layers["'+alayer.name+'"]

'+xinc+','+inctime+','+stopwidth+')',inctime)

}

}

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

<BODY BGCOLOR="WHITEh

onLoad="wipe(document.layers['lasthurrah'],¤,10,0)"L

<LAYER NAME="lasthurrah" TOP="100" LEFT="100" BGCOLOR="YELLOW"L

<H1L  Goodbye, cruel world. I am the last layer!  </H1L

</LAYERL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Be careful with this example. It only works in Netscape 4 and above. The line thaš

begins wit—  setTimeout  belongs on one line, regardless of any wrapping in the print.

 = Page 308 =

ChapteX 8  Advance Layout Frame an Layer  28

Summar

Web page layout using HTML tags is not appropriate but, until recently, that was thk

only available layout option. Frames are often used as a layout tool, and while thk

<FRAME  element can afford great power in making sophisticated layouts, it come—

with a great price. Navigation confusion, printing mishaps, and design problems ma_

all result from misuse of frames. However, when frames are used properly (foK

example, to provide a fixed table of contents or navigation aid), they are a valuablk

addition to the page designer’s arsenal. Because of their power and popularity, frame—

PRESENTATION AND

are finally included in the HTML specification (in version 4), so you shouldn’t have tf

worry about their future use. However, more advanced page layout tags that ark

LUT

highly proprietary to Netscape browsers, such as thk  <LAYER  an™  <ILAYER

elements, should be approached with caution. Although these elements can be use™

to create impressive and dynamic layouts, similar effects can be created by usiný

standardized technology—particularly style sheets, which are discussed in Chapter 10ì

 = Page 309 =

Thispbbintentional8yleftPlank‘

 = Page 310 =

Chapte7 ‘

HTML and OtheX

Media Type

28
