 = Page 311 =

290  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

dding images to a Web page is just the tip of the iceberg. Web pages ca-

support a variety of media forms, including animation, sound, video, virtuaR

reality, and other binary forms. Browser vendors have introduced speciaR

A

extensions to handle these new media types, but the lonterm solution is to handle alR

media types in a similar fashion, as plain binary objects. When programming element—

an™ truk interactivit_ ark mixed, thing— ca- becomk eve- mork complicatedì Thi— chapteK

ties up some loose ends regarding binary object support and miscellaneous vendo§

specific elements. It also previews many of the issues that arise during the discussio-

of interactivity on the Webì

HTML and Binary Object“

As discussed in Chapter 5, images are not directly part of HTML. Images are binar_

objects that are included, or pulled into, a Web page. Other objects, such as videos,

animations, sound files, and programs, also can be pulled into Web pages. Initially,

because no way existed to insert inline into a Web page an object such as a video, thk

only option was to link to it. By creating a link to a movie file,  <A HREF= "trailer.avi"

View Movie TraileK  </A  for example, the viewer could click the link and launch ¾

helper application to view the movie. Combining linked data with helper application—

is certainly an easy approach, similar to the way images were supported on the WeD

before Mosaic introduced support for inline imagesì

So, how can objects be inserted and supported inline? Three basic approaches exist:

  Use a pluin and reference the data by using thk  <EMBED  tagì

This is primarily a Netscape approachì

  Use an ActiveX control and reference it with thk  <OBJECT  tagì

This is Microsoft’s approach for adding media elements to a pageì

  Use thk  <APPLET  tag to add multimedia with Javaì

Combining all three approaches may enable you to create a page that works undeK

all conditions. Each approach is briefly considered next, respectively, before discussiný

specific methods of inserting audio, video, and other media formsì

Plug-Ins and <EMBED>

Firsâgeneratio- browser— displaye™ stati´ HTML page— an™ offere™ thk abilit_ tf launc—

helper applications to view different media and file types. Helper applications still ru-

i- separatk window— fro“ thk browser, providiný ¾ nonintegrate™ experienceì I- contrast,

pluin— enablk user— tf experienck contenš suc— a— Shockwavk file— oK QuickTimk “ovie—

directly within a Web page. The pluin HTML syntax developed by Netscape is alsf

supported by Internet Explorerì

 = Page 312 =

ChapteX 9  HTMP an OtheX Medi¨ Type  29h

The pluin approach of extending a browser’s features does have drawbacksì

Users must locate and download pluins, install them, and restart their browsersì

Many users find this rather complicated. Netscape 4 may offer some installatio-

relief with it—  self-installing plug-inx  and other features; but, for now, pluins remai-

troublesome. Furthermore, pluins aren’t available on every machine; a pluin binar_

must be compiled for each particular operating system. Because of this machin[

specific approach, many pluins work only on Windows 95 and Windows NT. A

decreasing number of pluins work on Windows 3.1, Macintosh, or UNIX operatiný

systems. Finally, each pluin installed on a system is a persistent extension to thk

PRESENTATION AND

browser, which means that it needs to be downloaded only once, but takes up memor_

and disk space thereafter. Having more pluins on your system equals increase™

LUT

memory requirements. A Macintosh running ten common pluins may need 20MB

of RAM to operate. Pluins are ¾  fat-clienP approach  : the more functionality added, thk

fatter the client application becomesì

On the upside, Netscape already bundles audio, video, and Flash pluins in thk

browser. Other widely used pluins include Real Audio/Video and Adobe’s Acrobaš

format. Adding support for binary objects (sounds, videos, or multimedia files) is ¾

matter of learning the appropriate syntax for thk  <EMBED  element. In general, thk

<EMBED  element takes a-  SR‚  attribute to specify the URL of the included binar_

objectì  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  attributes often are used to indicate the pixel dimension—

of the included object, if it is visible. To embed a short Audio Video Interleaved (AVI)

format movie called welcome.avi to be viewed by the Netscape LiveVideo pluin, usk

the following HTML fragment:

<EMBED SRC="welcome.Æi" HEIGHT="100" WIDTH="100"L

Beyond this simple example, things get a little more problematic. Other tha-

HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  , common attributes includk  ALIGN HIDDEN I¤ HSPAC¨  ,  ,  ,  ,

PALETT¨ PLUGINSPAG¨ TITL¨  ,  ,  , an™  VSPAC¨  . Some of these attributes, such a—

ALIGN HSPAC¨  ,  , an™  VSPAC¨  , work just like the same attributes for thk  <IMG

element. These elements may not be supported by all pluins. Many other vendo§

defined attributes may also be very important. Pluin vendors are free to define theiK

own attributes, which makes dealing with pluins difficult from a developer’s point o“

view. This chapter discusses builâin Netscape pluins and similar Microsoft featuresì

A more generalized discussion of pluins—how they work and how to deal wit—

them—is presented in Chapter 15ì

<NOEMBED>

One important aspect of pluins is thk  <NOEMBED  element. Some browsers do noš

understand Netscape’s pluin architecture or thk  <EMBED  element. Rather tha-

lock these browsers out of a Web page, thk  <NOEMBED  element enables you tf

 = Page 313 =

29p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

provide some alternative text or marked up content. In the short example presente™

here, an AVI video is embedded in the page. Thk  <NOEMBED  element contains a-

image, which in turn has an alternative text reading set with thk  AL  attribute. Notk

how the example degrades from a very sophisticated setting, all the way down to ¾

texâonly environmentì

<EMBED SRC="welcome.Æi" HEIGHT="100" WIDTH="100"L

<NOEMBEDL

<IMG SRC="welcome.gif" ALT="Welcome to Big Company, Inc."L

</NOEMBEDL

One big problem with thk  <NOEMBED  approach occurs when a browseK

supports pluins but lacks the specific pluin to deal with the included binary objectì

In this case, the user is presented with a broken puzzl[piece or similar icon, and ma_

be directed to a page from which to download the missing pluin. This level of useK

interaction is inappropriate for novice users who do not understand how to downloa™

pluins. A better approach is for the page author to attempt to provide pages thaš

don’t require setup. (Chapter 15 presents more information on the accessibility aspect—

of pluins.)

ActiveX Controls and <OBJECT>

Microsoft’s ActiveX technology is another approach to inserting binary objects (suc—

as movie and audio players) into a Web page. ActiveX controls are small, binar_

components that are downloaded to a user’s system and that can be accessed fro“

within the Web page. Compared to pluins, installation is fairly straightforward foK

the user. It may even be automatic. However, this technology has some security issue—

thaš ca- bk ver_ problematicì Becausk o“ securit_ an™ design, thk ActiveX controR i— ver_

different from pluins or Java, though the basic way to access Microsoft’s form o“

binaries is similar as far as HTML is concernedì

Microsoft uses thk  <OBJECT  element to insert an ActiveX control in a page. Thk

<OBJECT  element acts like thk  <EMBED  element insofar as it has attributes such a—

ALIGN HEIGH  ,  , an™  WIDTh  ì Beyon™ this, thk twf element— ark ver_ differentì Usiný

<OBJECT  with an ActiveX control requires the page author to specify thk  CLASSI¤

value that corresponds to the object to insert. This unique code might be something likk

CLSID:99B42120-6EC7-11CF-A6C7- 00AA00A47DD2  —not exactly easy to rememberì

Furthermore, a variety of data items must be passed to the ActiveX control via thk

<PARAM  element, whic— i— include™ numerou— time— withi- thk  <OBJECT  elementì

Thk  <PARAM  element usually has an attribute calle™  NAM¨  (used to set the name o“

 = Page 314 =

ChapteX 9  HTMP an OtheX Medi¨ Type  29

thk parameter) an™ ¾  VALU¨  parameteK (whic— set— thk valuk o“ thk particulaK argumenš

to the control). For example, the following code fragment is used to insert a simplk

graphicaR label; notick hou thk  FontNam2  i— seš tf  Aria“  b_ usiný thk  <PARAM  element:

<OBJECT ID="IeLabel1" WIDTH="122" HEIGHT="57h

CLASSID="CLSID:99B120-6EC7-11CF-A6C7-00AA00A47D2"L

<PARAM NAME="_ExtentX" VALUE=582"L

<PARAM NAME="_ExtentY" VALUE="1207"L

<PARAM NAME="Caption" VALUE="Test Label"L  PRESENTATION AND

<PARAM NAME="Alignment" VALUE="4"L

<PARAM NAME="Mode" VALUE="1"L

LUT

<PARAM NAME="FontName" VALUE="Arial"L

<PARAM NAME="FontSize" VALUE="12"L

Sorry, you don't have ActiveX support<

</OBJECTL

As this example shows, using thk  <OBJECT  element is less than straightforwardì

Depending on the object being inserted, the parameters may vary widely. Becausk

of this, Microsoft has provided a variety of tools, such as the ControlPa™

(http://www.microsoft.com/workshop/misc/cpad), that can be used to inserš

ActiveX controls into a page and set their parametersì

While ActiveX controls were the first binary forms to use thk  <OBJECT  element,

i- thk future, alR binar_ objects—includiný images—wilR probabl_ usk thi— formì Thk

W3C is attempting to standardize the method for including binary data by adopting ¾

generalized approach of using thk  <OBJECT  element. (This approach is discussed i-

dept— i- ChapteK 15.) FoK thk resš o“ thi— discussion, simpl_ notk thaš becausk thk syntax

of thk  <OBJECT  element is so variable when it is used in this manner, using tools tf

generate the syntax, even to include Microsoft controls, is the best approachì

Java Applet“

New media forms also can be inserted into a Web page by using Sun Microsystems’

Java technology. Java (http://www.javasoft.com) is an attractive, revolutionar_

approach to cros-platform, Interneâbased development. Java promises a platforf

neutral development language that allows programs to be written once and deploye™

on any machine, browser, or operating system that supports the Java virtual machink

(JVM)ì Iš use— smalR Jav¾ programs, calle™  appletx  , thaš werk introduce™ b_ Sun’— HotJav¾

browser. Today, many popular browsers, including Navigator and Internet Explorer,

support Java. When applets are referenced in a Web page by using thk  <APPLET

element, they are downloaded and run directly within a browser to provide neu

functionality or media forms such as animation or videoì

 = Page 315 =

29  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Applets are written in the Java language and compiled to a machin[independenš

byte code that is downloaded automatically to the JavDcapable browser and ru-

within the browser environment. But even with a fast processor, the end system run—

the byte code slowly compared to a natively compiled application, because the JVM

must interpret the byte code. Even with recent JusâI™Time (JIT) compilers in neweK

browsers, Java can’t deliver ideal performance. Even if compilation weren’t an issue,

Java applets currently are not persistent; they must be downloaded for each use. Jav¾

browsers act like thi™client applications: they add code only when they need itì

Security in Java has been a serious concern from the outset. Because programs ark

downloaded and run automatically, a malicious program could be downloaded an™

run without the user being able to stop it. Java applets actually have little access tf

resources outside the browser’s environment. Within Web pages, applets can’t write tf

local disks or perform other harmful functions. This framework has been referred to a—

the “Java Sandbox.” Developers who want to provide Java functions outside thk

sandbox must write Java applications, which run as separate applications fro“

browsers. Other Internet programming technologies (pluins, ActiveX, and so on)

provide little or no safety from damaging programs. Oddly, Java developers ofte-

want to add just these types of unsecure features, as well as powerful features such a—

persistence and interobject communication. Most of the features are already far aloný

in development, and should soon become commonplaceì

As far as HTML is concerned, a Java applet is yet another object to insert into a WeD

page. Rather than using thk  <EMBED  oK  <OBJECT  element, a speciaR  <APPLET

element is used to insert a Java applet. Like thk  <EMBED  element,  <APPLET  wilR

most likely be replaced by thk  <OBJECT  element. You need to know hou  <APPLET

works, in case you need to insert Java media objects, particularly for Netscape supportì

Thk  <APPLET  element specifies the Java applet to run by providing a URL to ¾

class file containing the Java byte code. To set the applet to run, set thk  COD¨  attributk

equal to the URL of the Java class. Thk  CODEBAS¨  attribute can also be used to set ¾

base URL reference for thk  COD¨  attribute. Other basic attributes to thk  <APPLET

element are similar to those foK  <IMG  , such a—  ALIGN HEIGH WIDTh HSPAC¨  ,  ,  ,  ,

VSPAC¨  , an™  AL  . Within thk  <APPLET  an™  </APPLET  elements, the user ca-

specify parameters or arguments to the applet by using thk  <PARAM  element, in ¾

similar fashion to how data is passed to ActiveX controls. Plain text may also appeaK

between thk  <APPLET  an™  </APPLET  elements. Such text can be used to providk

alternative text in situations in which the element is not understood at all. A smalR

example of hou  <APPLET  might be used is shown here:

<APPLET CODE="http://www.bigcompany.com/jÆa/test.class" ALIGN="LEFTh

HEIGHT="100" WIDTH="100" HSPACE="10" VSPACE="10"L

<PARAM NAME="caption"qalue="Hello World"L

</APPLETL

 = Page 316 =

ChapteX 9  HTMP an OtheX Medi¨ Type  29

Depending on the Java applet being accessed, many different parameters may exisš

that can be passed to it. A general discussion of Java applets and how they can be use™

is presented in Chapter 15, so the discussion here is meant to show only that man_

forms of binary formats exist that can be included in Web pagesì

The three elements that are useful for inserting nonimage binary objects ark

<APPLET <EMBED  ,  , an™  <OBJECT  . In most cases, spelling out all the aspects o“

thk  <APPLET  an™  <OBJECT  elements is too tedious, because so many variation—

exist. A few pluins are commonly available within browsers to support media types,

such as audio, video, and VRML. Furthermore, some media forms, such as Acrobat an™

PRESENTATION AND

Flash, are so common that they deserve a brief discussion regarding how they ark

handled within HTML. The rest of the chapter reviews common pluins and control—

LUT

for dealing with audio, video, multimedia, and Acrobat. First, however, take a closeK

look at a media element that defies classification—thk  <MARQUEE  elementì

Media-Like Element: <MARQUEE>

One approach to adding new support for objects is to add new elements and build i-

support to the browser for the object. This approach used to be very popular wit—

browser vendors, and is partially responsible for the proliferation of browse§specifi´

tagsì  <MARQUEE  is one example of a mediDlike tag that is fairly common on thk

Web. Althoug—  <MARQUEE  isn’t an embedded binary object, it tends to act like onk

in its support foK  HSPAC¨ VSPAC¨ HEIGH  ,  ,  , an™  WIDTh  attributes. In thk

proprietary HTML extension wars, Microsoft is the culprit for introducing the dreade™

<MARQUEE  element, which is certainly as annoying a—  <BLINK  . Thanks tf

<MARQUEE  , HTML authors now can create messages that scroll and slide across ¾

viewer’s screen in a variety of different ways. Like Netscape’—  <BLINK  element,

<MARQUEE  degrade— fairl_ welR an™ ca- bk use™ b_ HTML author— whf understan™

the ramifications of using such proprietary tags. However, the bottom line is that, i-

good conscience, authors shouldn’t recommend more than very occasional use of thk

<MARQUEE  elementì

Internet Explorer, as well as WebTV, supports thk  <MARQUEE  element. Thk

element requires a closiný  </MARQUEE  tag. The text included between the tags i—

transformed into a scrolling ticker tape, similar to the one found at Times Square. A

very simple continuous marquee could be set with the following HTML fragment:

<MARQUEEL

Welcome to Big Company, Inc. -- the biggest fake company in the world!

</MARQUEEL

Under Internet Explorer and other browsers that support thk  <MARQUEE

element, the enclosed text scrolls repeatedly from right to left. Under browsers thaš

don’t supporš  <MARQUEE  , the text is displayed simply as plain textì

 = Page 317 =

29‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The following is a more complex example that illustrates some of the more commo-

attributes supported b_  <MARQUEE  ; the rendering is shown Figure 1:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Marquee Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"L

<MARQUEE BGCOLOR="YELLOW" BEHAVIOR="ALTERNATE" DIRECTION="RIGHTh

LOOP="6" SCROLLAMOUNT="1" SCROLLDELAY="40h

TITLE="Silly tags aren't just for Netscape anymore.h

WIDTH="80%"L

Welcome to Big Company, the biggest fake company of them all!

</MARQUEEL

</DIVL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Figurs 9-18  Rendering of thP  <MARQUEE>  example under Internet Explore

 = Page 318 =

ChapteX 9  HTMP an OtheX Medi¨ Type  29

Changing the attributes in this example will adjust the presentation of the marqueeì

FoK example, thk  BEHAVIO  attributk ca- bk seš tf  ALTERNAT¨ SCROLL  ,  ,f K  SLID¨  ì

This attribute determines how the scrolling text behaves. By default, a marquee scroll—

text from left to right, unless thk  DIRECTION  is set. The scrolled text, if it is looped,

must first disappear before reappearing on the other side. When the attribute is set tf

ALTERNAT¨  , the text bounces across the scroll region. When the attribute is set tf

SLID¨  , the text slides into position, based on direction, and stays put once onscreenì

Thk  DIRECTION  attribute is used to set the direction in which the scrolled texš

moves. The allowed values for this attribute ark  DOWN LEF RIGH  ,  ,  , an™  UL  . Usiný

PRESENTATION AND

Dynamic HTML (DHTML) features, you may be able to create interesting effects wit—

<MARQUEE  by modifying thk  DIRECTION  attributeì

LUT

Thk  LOOL  attribute is used to set the number of times that the message loops in thk

scrolR regionì B_ default, unles— thk  BEHAVIO  i— seš tf  SLID¨  , ¾ marquek scroll— foreverì

The value of thk  LOOL  attribute should be a positive integerì

Settiný  SCROLLAMOUN  to a particular number of pixels allows the smoothnes—

of the scroll to be controlled. The value of thk  SCROLLAMOUN  attribute is set to thk

number of pixels between each drawing of the scrolled message in the display areaì

The larger the value in pixels, the jerkier the scrollì

SCROLLDELA  is used to set the number of milliseconds between each renderiný

o“ thk scrolle™ messageì A higheK valuk foK thi— attributk slow— thk scrollingì A reasonablk

valuk foK thi— attributk i— oK greaterì LoweK value— foK  50  SCROLLDELA  ten™ tf produck

marquees that are very difficult to readì

Last, because thk  <MARQUEE  element represents a rectangular region, just likk

a- imagk (or, foK thaš matter, an_ binar_ include™ object), iš ha— attribute— suc— a—  ALIGN  ,

HSPAC¨ VSPAC¨ HEIGH  ,  ,  , an™  WIDTh  ì

Appendix A provides a complete discussion of thk  <MARQUEE  element and it—

numerous attributes. Although thk  <MARQUEE  element is certainly interesting, as ¾

simple form of animated text, it doesn’t hold a candle to more persuasive media form—

such as sound or videoì

Audio Support in Browser“

Few things are as persuasive as sound. Just try watching television with the volumk

muted. It’s not terribly interesting. Sound is a vital element of true multimedia WeD

pages—but how should sound be used? What Web audio technology is appropriate foK

the job? Just adding a MIDI file to a site to provide continuous background sound ma_

turn your page into the online equivalent of an i™store electronic organ demonstrationì

The latest audio technologies on the Internet cover a lot of ground, from traditionaR

downloaÙanÙplay systems in a variety of formats tf  streaming audio¨  which play—

close to real time. Surprisingly, the most advanced technologies, and the most popular,

may not be the best solutionì

 = Page 319 =

298  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Digital Sound Basic“

This section provides a very brief overview of digital sound. Digital sound is measure™

b_ thk frequenc_ o“  samplinv  , fK hou man_ time— thk soun™ i— digitize™ duriný ¾ specifi´

time period. Sampling frequencies are specified in Kilohertz (KHz), which indicate thk

soun™ sampliný ratk peK secondì CD-qualit_ soun™ i— approximatel_ 44.1KHz, oK 44,100

samples every second. For stereo, two channels are required, each at 8 bits; at 16 bit—

per sample, that yields 705,600 bits of data for each second of CD-quality sound. I-

theory, the bits of data on a CD could be delivered over the Internet, creating hig¾

quality music at the end user’s demand. In reality, transmitting this amount of dat¾

would take nearly half a T1 network’s bandwidth. Obviously, this type of bandwidt—

is not available to the average Web user. Another approach must be takenì

One approach is to lower the sampling rate when creating digital sound for WeD

delivery. A sampling rate of 8KHz in mono might produce acceptable playback result—

foK simplk applications, suc— a— speech, particularl_ consideriný thaš playbackhardwark

ffte- consist— o“ ¾ combinatio- o“ ¾ simplk soun™ car™ an™ ¾ smalR speakerì Lo“qualit_

audio requires a mere 64,000 bits of data per second, but the end user still has to wait tf

downloa™ thk soundì FoK mode“ users, eve- i- thk besš o“ conditions, eac— secon™ o“ lo“

qualit_ soun™ take— ¾ feu second— tf bk delivered, makiný continuou— soun™ unrealisticì

Audio File Formats and Compressio

Like graphics files, audio files can be compressed to reduce the amount of data beiný

sent. The software on the serving side compresses the data, which is decompressed an™

played back on the receiving end. The compression/decompression software is know-

together as ¾  code  . Just like image formats, audio compression methods are either loss_

or losslessì  Lossy  data compression doesn’t perfectly represent what was compressed,

but is close enough, given the size savings. Becausk  losslesx  compression technique—

guarantek thaš whaš goe— i- onk en™ come— ouš thk other, mosš technique— can’š compres—

files to any significant degree. Compression always involves a tradeoff between soun™

quality and file size; larger file sizes mean longer download timesì

When dealing with sounds, you don’t really select different forms of compressionì

You select file formats. Many standard file formats are available, as shown in Table 1ì

Downloading and Playing Audis

Early approaches to delivering sound via the Internet followed the “download an™

play” model. In this scenario, users must download sounds completely before they ca-

play them. This takes up valuable hard drive space, even if a user wants to hear onl_

the first few seconds of a file. Sounds must be degraded significantly in this situation,

which may not be acceptable for content that requires flawless playback. Even at ver_

low sampling rates, these sounds must be fairly short to spare impatient users thk

agony of prolonged download times. Download time can be reduced by creatiný

smaller audio files, which only accentuates the drawbacks of this methodì

 = Page 320 =

ChapteX 9  HTMP an OtheX Medi¨ Type  299

File Forma  Descriptio

WAV  Waveform (or simpl_  wav—  ) files are the most common soun™

format on Windows platforms. WAVs can also be played o-

Macs and other systems with player softwareì

AU  Sparõaudio, or ýlaw format, is one of the oldest Interneš

sound formats. A player for nearly every platform is availableì

PRESENTATION AND

AIFF  Audio Interchange File FormaP  is very common on Macs. Widel_

used in multimedia applications, it is not very common on thk

LUT

Webì

MID§  Musical Instrument Digital Interfac—  format is not a digitize™

audio format. It represents notes and other information so thaš

music can be synthesized. MIDI is well supported and files ark

very small, but it is useful for only certain applications due tf

its sound quality when reproduced on PC hardwareì

MPEG  Motion Pictures Experts Group  format is a standard format thaš

has significant compression capabilities. It isn’t as standardize™

as many people might think: it lacks widespread playing an™

encoding acceptance, despite its qualityì

Tabls 9-18  Standard Internet Sound Format9

Using HTML, the simplest way to support the downloaÙanÙplay approach is b_

linking to a sound file and letting another application deal with it, such as a helper oK

pluin. If no helper or pluin is configured, the user is prompted to deal with thk

sound. For example, to link to an audio file in WAV format, insert a link such as this:

<A HREF="starspangled.wÆ"L  Star Spangled Banner (6 second WAV - 900K)  </AL

A good idea with the downloaÙanÙplay approach is to put the decision tf

download the file in the hands of users. Warn them about the file format and size, sf

that the user has some indication of how long download will take. Another helpful biš

of information might be how long the sound is going to beì

FoK downloaÙanÙpla_ delivery, WAV an™ AU ark thk safesš format— foK lo“qualit_

music or speech. MPEG—particularly MPEG level 3 (MP3)—is really the only choick

for higöuality playback. DownloaÙanÙplay–based audio delivery is recommende™

when a quick bit of sound, such as an entrance gong, is required. AU and WAV file—

are supported via helper applications and pluins. They are even supported nativel_

 = Page 321 =

300  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

by some recent Web browsers, including Netscape with its LiveAudio pluin, an™

Microsoft Internet Explorer with its proprietar_  <BGSOUND  tag. Both browsers alsf

support MIDI sound files. However, MIDI files played back via PC sound cards (suc—

as SoundBlaster) often sound like cheap, synthesized music, which is more a reflectio-

of the playback hardware than the protocol itselfì

LiveAudis

Starting with Netscape 3, the LiveAudio pluin was included with the Netscapk

browser. The LiveAudio pluin supports AU, AIFF, WAV, and MIDI sound files i-

the downloaÙanÙplay fashion. Adding support for audio with LiveAudio simpl_

requires using the appropriate form of thk  <EMBED  element to access the LiveAudif

pluin. For example, to set LiveAudio to include a sound called test.wav and a paneR

to control the sound, use the following HTML fragment:

<EMBED SRC="test.wÆ" HEIGHT="60" WIDTH="144"L

Including thk  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  values is important; otherwise, the browseK

may clip the console. The default size for the LiveAudio control is 60 pixels high an™

144 pixels across. Other control styles have different default sizes. If you want to creatk

a background sound for a page, you may find this line more appropriate:

<EMBED SRC="test.wÆ" HIDDEN="TRUE" AUTOSTART="TRUE"L

The LiveAudio pluin has a variety of features that can be controlled wit—

ATTRIBUT¨  settings for thk  <EMBED  element. The syntax for the LiveAudif

pluin is shown here:

<EMBED SRC="URL of sound file to play"

ALIGN="top | bottom | center | baseline | left | right |

texttop | middle | absmiddle | absbottom"

AUTOSTART="true | false"

CONTROLS="consol4 | smallconsol4 | playbuttoY | pausebuttoY |

stopbutton | volumelever"

ENDTIME="minutes:seconds"

HEIGHT="pixels or percentage"

HIDDEN="true | false"

LOOP="true | false | positive integer"

MASTERSOUND

NAME="unique name"

STARTTIME="minutes:seconds"

VOLUME="number from 0 to 100"

WIDTH="pixels or percentage"

>

 = Page 322 =

ChapteX 9  HTMP an OtheX Medi¨ Type  30h

Like thk  <IMG  element, the LiveAudio pluin must have a-  SR‚  attributk

setting. Thk  SR‚  value is a URL to a sound file supported by the pluin. Thesk

formats include AU, AIFF, WAV, and MIDI. Remember to take the same precaution—

for using a complete URL to an outside file, compared to using a locally referenced filk

with a relative URLì

Thk  AUTOSTAR  attributes can take one of two values,  tru2  oK  fals2  . When set tf

tru2  , thk soun™ filk begin— playiný a— soo- a— iš i— downloadedì B_ default, i“ unspecified,

AUTOSTAR  is set tf  fals2  ì

Thk  LOOL  attribute can take one of three values,  tru2 fals2  ,  , or a positive integerì

PRESENTATION AND

Setting the value tf  tru2  loops the sound continuously until the Stop button is pressedì

When combined with thk  AUTOSTAR  attribute, infinite looping could become ver_

LUT

annoying, particularly if the Stop button is unavailable. By default, the value o“  LOOL

is set tf  fals2  . Thk  LOOL  attribute can also be set to a positive integer, which plays thk

sound a specified number of times or until the Stop button is pressedì

Thk  STARTTIM¨  attribute can be set to a time value within a sound file, tf

determine from where to begin playback. For example, to start playback two second—

into the sound, the attribute can be set tf  00:02  ì

Thk  ENDTIM¨  attribute is similar to thk  STARTTIM¨  attribute, but instea™

determines the time value to end playback, and is written in the same wayì

STARTTIMJ  an  ENDTIMJ  provide little benefit without using scripting technology¨

because the whole sound must be downloaded, regardless. Why a user wouldn’t simply

edit a sound to avoid starting and stopping at a certain time index is curious. If th—

controls in the LiveAudio plug-in supported a fast-forward and a reverse feature, thes—

attributes would be far more useful.

Thk  VOLUM¨  attribute can be set to an integer between 0 and 100, wherk sets thk  0

sound to be completely off an™  100  sets it at maximum volume. Values outside thi—

range generally default to the extreme, so a value o“  200  would set the volume tf

maximum. When thk  VOLUM¨  attribute is combined with thk  MASTERVOLUM¨

setting for thk  NAM¨  attribute, you can set volume for other sounds. The defaulš

volume level is the current system volume or, typically, a value o“  50  ì

Thk  WIDTh  attribute sets the width, in pixels, for the audio controls. You shoul™

set this value unless thk  HIDDEN  attribute is used. The width for the default console i—

144 pixels and should be set explicitly. When thk  CONTROLS  attribute is set tf

SMALLCONSOL¨  , thk  WIDTh  attribute should also be set to 144 pixels. If thk

CONTROLS  attribute is set tf  VOLUMELEVE  , thk  WIDTh  attribute should bk

set to 74 pixels; and if thk  CONTROLS  attribute is set to any of the buttons, such a—

PLAYBUTTON  , thk  WIDTh  attribute should be set to 37 pixels. The values for thk

WIDTh  attribute are summarized in Table 2ì

Thk  HEIGH  attribute is used to set the height, in pixels, for the audio controlsì

As with thk  WIDTh  attribute, you should make sure to set this value, unless thk

small console is only 15 pixels high. Each button, such as the Play button, is 22 pixel—

up and down, and the volume lever has a height of 22 pixels. All the suggeste™

HEIGH  values are summarized in Table 2ì

Thk  ALIGN  attribute acts just like thk  ALIGN  attribute for thk  <IMG  elementì

Thk  CONTROLS  attribute sets the type of control objects to include for the sound fileì

By default, the value of thk  CONTROLS  attribute is set tf  CONSOL¨  , which include—

Thk  HIDDEN  value can be set tf  tru2  if the page author wants the audio file to acš

as a background sound. The user can’t control the sound if this attribute is set tf  tru2  ì

Whe-  HIDDEN  is set,  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  attributes are unnecessary. By default,

thk  HIDDEN  attribute is set tf  fals2  ì

Thk  NAM¨  attribute is used to group together a set of individual controls thaš

control one sound. The attribute value must be a unique identifier for all the controlsì

For example, the group could be called SoundGroup1. All thk  <EMBED  element—

that reference the same sound should then have theiK  NAM¨  attribute value set tf

soun™ musš poinš tf ¾ reaR soun™ fileì However, thk otheK occurrence— o“ thk  <EMBED

element within the group need to point only to a dummy sound file, called ¾  stub fil—  i-

the Netscape documentation. The stub file is simply a file that is named appropriatel_

to look like a sound file (for example, stub1.wav). The file itself doesn’t need to contai-

any information, and can be a blank text file, as long as it has the appropriate nameì

This is somewhat of a hack but is required for the LiveAudio pluin to work, becausk

By dividing up the controls, the page author has more possibilities for integratiný

Microsoft’s <SOUND>

Microsoft Internet Explorer 2 and later supports WAV and MIDI files with thk

<BGSOUND  element, which plays a sound in the background after it is loadedì

The user has no control over the volume or the playback of the sound, which can bk

annoying. The element takes a-  SR‚  attribute that is set to the URL of the sound filk

to play. A  LOOL  attribute, which can be set to an integer value indicating how man_

times the sound should play, is also available. Thk  LOOL  attribute can also be set tf

the valuk  infinit2  , to keep playing over and over. A simple example to play a soun™

called test.wav two times under Internet Explorer could be written a—  <BGSOUN¤

SRC="test.wav" LOOP="2"  ì

Cross-Browser Background Sound“

You can include both thk  <BGSOUND  and Netscape LiveAudio syntax in one page,  PRESENTATION AND

as follows:

LUT

<EMBED SRC="test.wÆ" HIDDEN="TRUE" AUTOSTART="true"L

<BGSOUND SRC="test.wÆ" LOOP="L

In this case, Internet Explorer should ignore the first statement, while Netscape shoul™

ignore the second. Note that using JavaScript to control which form is inserted into thk

document is preferable. With both forms of sound support enabled, conflicts can occur,

so page authors are advised to test their documents thoroughlyì

Proprietary Audio Format“

Many proprietary audio formats exist, including RealAudio, ToolVox, TrueSpeech, an™

others. Of these, RealAudio is by far the most popular. But why use RealAudio if audif

is built into the browser? Proprietary audio formats offer one thing that many standar™

digitaR audif format— lack: thk possibilit_ o“  streaminv dat‘  ì A— ¾ rulk o“ thumb, ¾ 28.8Kbp—

mode“ useK receive— approximatel_ 2K o“ dat¾ peK secondì I“ onk secon™ o“ soun™ coul™

bk represente™ i- 2K, an™ thk dat¾ coul™ geš tf thk en™ useK aš ¾ ratk o“ 2K ever_ second,

then the data would effectivel_  streah  , or play in real time. Streaming seems to make ¾

wholk loš o“ senseì Wh_ waiš foK a- hou§loný speec— tf downloa™ befork playiný whe-

you care only about the current second of data being listened to? Streamed data doesn’š

take up hard drive space, and it opens up random access to any position in an audif

file. However, streaming audio has a few potential serious drawbacks. First, tf

compress audio far enough for streaming, you have to sacrifice a certain degree o“

sound quality. Second, the Internet protocols themselves do not readily support thk

requirements of streamingì

Why the Internet and Streaming Don’t Mi¨

As you may know, the Internet is frequently subject to bursts and traffic delays. Herk

are a couple of key points to remember. The TCP/IP protocols used on the Interneš

werk designe™ foK robustnes— an™ scalabilityì Thk Interneš i— ¾ packeâswitche™ network

that breaks up data into little chunks and sends them separately, to be reassembled aš

the other end. Because these packets may be lost along their journies or arrive out o“

order, thk  Transmission Control Protocol (TCP)  guarantees the integrity of the data. Thi—

way, many users can share a fixed circuit that allows for economies of scale. However,

 = Page 327 =

30‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

packeâswitched networks have one serious problem—they can’t guarantee deliver_

time without special modifications. This makes streamed audio, video, and other “reaR

time” applications on packeâswitched networks very difficultì

Packeâswitched networks can be augmented with protocols such a—  Real Tim—

Transport Protocol (RTP)  an™  Resource Reservation Setup Protocol (RSVP)  , which hel5

guarantee delivery times by making a bandwidth reservation, when needed. Thesk

protocols can improve rea_time data delivery, but they are not widely supported yetì

They also raise the question of how to limit reservations, because a user would alway—

want reservations in order to have maximum bandwidth. Some experts argue that onck

šhesk protocol— ark i- place, fek structure— base™ o- bandwidt— wilR becomk commonplaceì

For the moment, this is pure speculation, because the various rea_time protocols ark

still very much in the developmental stages. Another solution to rea_time data on thk

Internet is necessaryì

Onk potentiaR solutio- tf rea_timk dat¾ o- thk Interneš i— reall_ jusš a- assumption—

you hope the end user has the enÙtkend bandwidth to receive the file in real timeì

(Remember the 2K per second rule for 28.8Kbps modems.) If audio compression ca-

geš onk secon™ o“ dat¾ tf fiš withi- thosk ranges, rea_timk dat¾ ca- bk serve™ tf 28.8Kbp—

users—when the assumption holds. When the assumption doesn’t hold, a glitch calle™

¾  drop-ouP  occurs in the audio stream. If too much drošout occurs, the user turns of“

the audio streamì

One way to avoid drošout is tf  buffe(  data. This process gives you a head start b_

preloading a certain amount of data into a buffer, so that rough spots can be overcomeì

A- initiaR bufferiný dela_ o“ 10 oK 15 second— i— acceptablk foK loný audif clips; bufferiný

short sounds is counterproductive. Many Internet audio solutions use a combination o“

intensive compression, buffering, and some level of bandwidth assumption to achievk

streaming. Mor[complex audio solutions use servers to control the process. Bot—

approaches to streaming audio have their pros and consì

RealAudis

The first—and still the most popular—approach to streaming audio was develope™

by RealNetworks. RealAudio (http://www.real.com) uses a special server to sen™

continuous audio data to a browser helper application, Netscape pluin, Shockwavk

Xtra, or ActiveX control. With players available for all major platforms, RealAudio i—

the most common streaming audio format on the Internet. Putting data in RealAudif

format is fairly easy if the files exist in WAV or other common audio formats. Simpl_

use the RealAudio production tools, which can be downloaded from RealNetworks,

and the data is ready to publish. But despite RealAudio’s wide support, it has certai-

drawbacks, which mostly revolve around the use of a special serverì

Server— ca- providk ¾ higheK degrek o“ controlì FoK example, the_ ca- limiš oK controR

the number of audio streams delivered and allow for easy access to specified points i-

an audio stream. With simpler “serverless” audikstreaming solutions, the virtual fasš

forward button provided by random access is sacrificed. Some sophisticated server—

could potentially upgrade data quality as bandwidth becomes available. Les-complex

systems give the same quality of data, regardless of the enÙtkend access speedì

 = Page 328 =

ChapteX 9  HTMP an OtheX Medi¨ Type  30

Serve§based systems are expensive and require computing resources beyond the basi´

WeD serverì RealAudikbase™ streaminý audif server— havk ¾ pe§strea“ cosš foK higuen™

sites that keeps some users from adopting this solution. Fortunately, entrÇleveR

RealAudio systems with a few streams are still free or very inexpensive. Already, man_

organizations are using the RealAudio platform, which is a testament to the quality o“

the systemì

One technical problem with RealAudio that bothers many users is that the server sendx

audio data by using the(ser Datagram Protocol (UDP) rather than the more commoc

PRESENTATION AND

and reliable TCP protocol that is used for standard Internet data transmission.(DP ix

fast and helps provide data to the end user quickly, but lost packets are much mor—

LUT

common with(DP. To get around lost packets, RealAudio data is delivered in ac

interleaved fashion, so that single drop-outs are not noticeable. Although(DP may help

avoid TCP’s link-use problems, when mixed with a firewall, RealAudio’s(DP lin

becomes a liability. Most firewalls filter out(DP, so people accessing the InterneP

through a firewall may find it difficult, if not impossible, to access a(DP-based servic—

such as RealAudio.

From an HTML point of view, using RealAudio is really no different from usiný

LiveAudio or any other pluin. Similar to LiveAudio, thk  SR‚  attribute can be set to ¾

RealAudio file ending in .ram. The appearance of the player, as well as how the soun™

should start, is also configurable using a variety of other attributes. A portion of thk

RealAudio syntax is shown here. Note that this syntax changes rapidly. A-

<OBJECT  -based syntax is also available for Internet Explorer supportì

<EMBED

SRC="URL of RealAudio stream or file"

AUTOSTART="true | false"

CONTROLS="ALL | ControlPanel | InfoVolumePanel | InfoPanel |

StatusBar | PlayButton | StopButton | VolumeSlider |

PositionSlider | PositionField | StatusField"

HEIGHT="pixels or percentage"

NAME="identifier for sound file"

WIDTH="pixels or percentage">

Thk followiný list— an™ describe— thk ke_ attribute— i- thk precediný RealAudif syntax:

  SR‚  Sets the source of the RealAudio clip. Thk  SR‚  should be set to a URL,

which can be in the form of a full URL using the pnm:, file:, or http: protocol; oK

it can be a relative URL to the appropriate file type. This is requiredì

  CONTROLS  Sets the visible control components of the player in a similaK

manner to LiveAudio. The default value i—  ALL  , but the attribute alsf

individually controls the aspect—  ControlPane“ InfoVolumePane“ InfoPane“  ,  ,  ,

StatusBa( PlayButton StopButton VolumeSlide( PositionSlide(  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

PositionField  , an™  StatusField  ì

 = Page 329 =

308  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

  NAM¨  Specifies the identifier associated with the RealAudio pluin and clipì

Thi— valuk ca- the- bk use™ tf referenck an™ controR thk cli5 fro“ Java, JavaScript,

or other programming technologiesì

  HEIGH  Sets the height, in pixels, of the control panel usedì

  WIDTh  Sets the width, in pixels, of the control panel usedì

  AUTOSTAR  Sets whether or not the RealAudio pluin automatically start—

playing once the source data is available. Valid values for this attribute ark  tru2

an™  fals2  ì

Provided that the user has access to the appropriate audio stream, using ¾

proprietary audio technology such as RealAudio is no more difficult than usiný

LiveAudio. For more specific information about how to use RealAudio technology,

see RealNetworks’ Web site (http://www.real.com)ì

Sound Conclusion“

The future of audio on the Internet ultimately lies in integration. People will resisš

downloading dozens of pluins for numerous data formats. They prefer singlk

technologies that integrate into one whole presentation, such as animation or videf

with sound, because the uses of background music on the Internet are limited. Whilk

more advanced technologies such as RealAudio allow simple embedding of URLs an™

otheK form— f“ synchronization, ¾ controlle™ environmenš i— requiredì Wit— programminý

technologies such as JavaScript and Macromedia’s Shockwave or Flash, which havk

streaming audio support, full integration is availableì

Adding sound to a Web site shouldn’t be an infuriating experience for Webmaster—

or Web users. Using a simple downloaÙanÙplay sound format built into a browseK

might be better than streaming data that requires special encoding or download of ¾

special pluin. If streaming is required, RealAudio is probably the best bet (if it’—

affordable). For a complete Web page solution requiring tight integration betwee-

technologies, Shockwave or Flash with streaming audio is the only choice beyond somk

custom integration using programming technologies such as JavaScript. Regardless o“

hou soun™ i— included, don’š expecš CD qualit_ foK Interneâbase™ audioì An™ remember:

a little sound can go a long wayì

Video Suppor

The holy grail of Internet multimedia is certainly higöuality, 30-frame-pe§second,

rea_time video. Many companies are working toward the idea of television on thk

Web, but most of their solutions just don’t work well within the bandwidth limitation—

faced by the average Internet user. Sooner or later, video will be used extensively o-

Web pages—but what Web video technology, if any, is appropriate for the job and hou

can video be accessed via HTML? The latest Internet video technologies range fro“

 = Page 330 =

ChapteX 9  HTMP an OtheX Medi¨ Type  309

lo“quality streaming audio with an occasional picture to traditional downloaÙanÙ

pla_ system— foK ¾ variet_ o“ filk formatsì A— wit— audio, thk mosš populaK technologies—

and the most advanced—may not offer the best solutions for simple Web video needsì

Digital Video Basic“

Digital video is measured by the number of frames per second of video, and by the sizk

an™ resolutio- o“ thesk framesì Thk totaR sizk requiremenš foK videf i— huge, particularl_

[“ yo¾ wanš NTSC (TV-quality) videoì A 640 × 480 imagk wit— 24 bit— o“ dat¾ representatio-

PRESENTATION AND

for color and a frame rate of 30 frames per second takes up a staggering 27MB peK

second—and that’s without sound. Add CD-quality audio (705,600 bits of data for eac—

LUT

second of data) and the file size increases proportionately. In theory, the bits of dat¾

necessary to deliver TV-quality video could be transmitted over the Internet, creatiný

the lonsoughâafter interactive TV. In the real world, transmitting this amount of dat¾

generally isn’t feasible, even after compressionì

One approach to video on the Internet is breathtakingly simple: just don’t do itì

A simple frame of movement every once in a while or a static picture with continuou—

audio can provide the illusion required for simple “talking head” applications. Framk

rates and image size can be reduced enough to make download sizes seem plausible,

but even a simple slide show with audio narration is nearly impossible to do in reaR

time without compressionì

Video File Formats and Compressio

Like audio files, video files can be compressed to reduce the amount of data being sentì

Because of the degree of compression required by video, most video codecs use a loss_

approach that involves a trad[off between picture/sound quality and file size, wit—

larger file sizes obviously resulting in longer download timesì

Three standardized video file formats are used on the Web: AVI, QuickTime,

and MPEG, as summarized in Table 3. The file format usually determines whic—

compression technique is used. However, some file formats, such as QuickTime, allou

different codecs to be selected. In some ways, this makes QuickTime the most flexiblk

video formatì

For downloaÙanÙplay delivery, AVI and QuickTime are the safest formats foK

short video clips. Regardless of length, MPEG is typically the only choice for hig¾

quality playback. AVI and QuickTime files are commonly supported via helpeK

applications. They’re even supported natively by many modern Web browsers i-

a downloaÙanÙplay styleì

Waiting for Vides

As with audio, many online video delivery systems follow the downloaÙanÙpla_

model, whereby users must download video clips completely before they can pla_

 = Page 331 =

310  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Video Forma  Descriptio

AV§  Audio Video Interleave  . The Video for Windows file format foK

digital video and audio is very common and easy to specifyì

A growing number of video files in AVI format are beiný

used on the Internet, but file size of AVI is significant. Bot—

Netscape and Internet Explorer are capable of dealing wit—

AVIs easilyì

MOV  Movi—  . MOV is the extension that indicates the use of Apple’—

(QuickTime)  QuickTime format. Probably the most common digital videf

format, it continues its popularity on the Internet. QuickTimk

has a strong following in the multimedia developmenš

community. Various codecs and technology enhancement—

make QuickTime a strong digital video solution that ma_

work in conjunction with MPEGì

MPEG  Motion Picture Experts Group  video format is generall_

considered the standard format for digital video. Althoug—

compression and image quality of MPEG files are impressive,

this format can be expensive and difficult to work withì

Tabls 9-38  Standard InternetXideo Format9

them. Some Web video solutions enable the user to see the video as it downloads,

despite the slow speed; this allows users to cancel the download before it endsì

Shortening video clips and reducing frame rates help users from giving up duriný

download time, but these techniques may not be acceptable for content that require—

flawless playback. Even at very low frame rates with no audio, video clips that ark

more than a few seconds long tend to exceed the patience of the average user. Wit—

downloaÙanÙplay video, you should stick to common formats (such as AVI,

QuickTime, or MPEG), unless the proprietary format has a wide degree of industr_

acceptance or provides a really motivating feature, such as compression that is hig—

enough to allow streamingì

LiveVides

Netscape’s LiveVideo pluin, which was introduced with Netscape 3, supports AV§

on Windows. The pluin is rather simplistic and doesn’t even include controls tf

show, pause, or rewind a video, let alone any sort of volume control. The user musš

 = Page 332 =

ChapteX 9  HTMP an OtheX Medi¨ Type  31h

click the embedded video to start it, unless the video has an autkplay feature enabledì

The basic syntax for thk  <EMBED  element as related to LiveVideo is shown here:

<EMBED

SRC="URL of video file"

ALIGN="top | bottom | center | baseline | left | right | texttoB

|middle | absmiddle | absbottom"

AUTOSTART="true | false"

HEIGHT="pixels or percentage"

PRESENTATION AND

HSPACE="pixels"

LOOP="true | false"

VSPACE="pixels"

LUT

WIDTH="pixels or percentage">

The following lists and describes the key attributes in the preceding syntax:

  SR‚  Must be set to the URL of a valid AVI fileì

  ALIGN  Acts similarly to the same attribute for thk  <IMG  element an™

accepts the same valuesì

  AUTOSTAR  Can be set tf  tru2  to begin play immediately after the entirk

AVI file downloads. The default i—  fals2  and thus requires the user to click thk

video to begin its playì

  HEIGH  Specifies the pixel height of the video. This attribute also takes ¾

percentage valueì

  HSPAC¨  Creates around an image a horizontal buffer region of a specifie™

number of pixelsì

  LOOL  Can be set tf  tru2  to loop the video continuously (the default i—  fals2  )ì

Currently, no way exists to set the pluin to loop the video a particular numbeK

of times, which seems a likely modification to this attributeì

  VSPAC¨  Can be set to a pixel value to create a vertical buffer area above an™

below the embedded mediaì

  WIDTh  Is set to either a pixel value or a screen percentage to specify thk

width of the embedded AVI fileì

The following is a brief example of how LiveVideo is used to include an AVI videf

in a page; a rendering of the example is shown in Figure 3:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  LiveVideo Rendering Under Netscap4  </TITLEL

 = Page 333 =

31p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 9-38  LivSideo rendering under NetscapP

<BODYL

WIDTH="120" ALIGN="LEFT" HSPACE="15" VSPACE="15"L

</BODYL

</HTMLL

QuickTims

QuickTime videos offer a lot more benefits than simply tending to be smaller than AV§

files. QuickTime is designed to provide the framework for the synchronization of tim[

based data in a variety of formats, including video, sound, MIDI, and even text. A-

interesting aspect of QuickTime is that it can work with different video compressio-

codecs, such as Cinepack, Indeo, MPEG, and even exotic fractal compression codecsì

B_ itself, QuickTimk wit— standar™ Cinepack encodiný lack— thk smalR filk sizk o“ MPEG

or proprietary video files, but the quality of QuickTime files is high. Creating or editiný

QuickTime files is also relatively easy when using tools such as the popular Adobk

Premiere packageì

Starting with Netscape 3, QuickTime is supported in Macintosh and Window—

versions of Netscape. Although the pluin is available on both systems, Window—

 = Page 334 =

ChapteX 9  HTMP an OtheX Medi¨ Type  31

users are required to install QuickTime services for their operating systems. The way tf

include QuickTime media into a Web page is similar to the way in which you includk

LiveVideo support. Keep in mind, however, that QuickTime provides support foK

many forms of media and is really more of a generic media architecture than AVIì

The basic syntax for thk  <EMBED  statement for the Netscape QuickTime plui-

is shown here:

<EMBED

SRC="URL of QuickTime object"

PRESENTATION AND

ALIGN="top | bottom | center | baseline | left |

right | texttop | middle | absmiddle | absbottom"

LUT

AUTOPLAY="true | false"

CACHE="true | false"

CONTROLLER="true | false"

CORRECTION="none | partial | full"   (QuickTime VR Only)

FOV="5.0 to 85.0"                    (QuickTime VR Only)

HEIGHT="pixels or percentage"

HIDDEN

HOTSPOT hotspot-id="URL of page to load"

HREF="URL of page to load"

HSPACE="pixels"

LOOP="true | false | palindrome"

NODE="node number"                   (QuickTime VR Only)

PAN="0.0 to 360.0"                   (QuickTime VR Only)

PLUGINSPAGE="URL of page with plug-in information"

PLAYEVERYFRAME="true | false"

TARGET="valid frame name"

TILT="-42 to"                 (QuickTime VR Only)

VOLUME="0 - 256"

VSPACE="pixels"

WIDTH="pixels or percentage">

The following lists and describes the key attributes in the preceding syntax:

  SR‚  Required, and should be set to the URL of a valid QuickTime fileì

  ALIGN  Acts similarly to same attribute for thk  <IMG  element and accept—

the same valuesì

  AUTOPLA  Can be set tf  tru2  oK  fals2  (default); indicates whether the movik

shoul™ bk playe™ a— soo- a— possibleì Attributk ha— nf meaniný whe- embeddiný

a QuickTime VR (Virtual Reality) fileì

  CACH¨  Can be set tf  tru2  oK  fals2  . Providing the attribute by itself implies ¾

tru2  value. Under Netscape 3 and above, ¾  CACH¨  value o“  tru2  causes thk

browser to treat the information just like other information and keep it in a locaR

disk cache, so that it does not need to be downloaded again. When set tf  fals2  ,

the movie must be downloaded againì

 = Page 335 =

31  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

  CONTROLLE  Can be set tf  tru2  oK  fals2  ; determines whether the movik

controller is visible. The controller provides standard stop, play, pause, rewind,

frame selection, and volume controls. The controller is 24 pixels high, so thk

HEIGH  value should be set to account for this. By default, the value o“

CONTROLLE  generally is set tf  tru2  , unless a QuickTime VR file is beiný

embedded. The QuickTime VR object does not use the same style of controlsì

  CORRECTION  Can be set tf  NON¨ PARTIAL  ,  , oK  FULL  (default); used tf

set the display correction for a QuickTime VR object. Has no meaning beyond ¾

QuickTime VR sceneì

  FOV  Specifies the initial field of view angle for a QuickTime movie. TypicaR

values for this attribute range fro“  5.0  tf  85.0  degrees. Has no meaning outsidk

of QuickTime VR objectsì

  HEIGH  Set like thk  WIDTh  attribute, with a pixel value or percentage. Thk

value specifies thk  HEIGH  of the object and is cropped or expanded in thk

same method a—  WIDTh  . For example, if a supplied height is greater than thk

movie’s height, the movie is centered within this height. If the value is smaller,

the object is cropped. Avoid values o“ oK for thk  0  1  HEIGH  attribute, becausk

they may cause unpredictable results. Be aware that controls for the movie ark

24 pixels high, which must be added to thk  HEIGH  value for the object tf

display properlyì

  HIDDEN  Takes no parameters and its presence determines whether thk

movie should be visible. By default, thk  HIDDEN  value i—  off  . In most cases,

such as embedding a QuickTime video or QuickTime VR object, this is not a-

appropriate attribute to use. However, if a sounÙonly movie is being inserted,

this can provide a background sounÙlike function, assuming thaš  AUTOPLA

has been set tf  tru2  . Thk  HIDDEN  attribute typically sets thk  CONTROLLE

attribute tf  fals2  ; but, to make sure, the attribute can be set directly by thk

page authorì

  HOTSPO  Comes in a strange format. By setting the hot spot identifier to ¾

URL, you can link the hot spot to a Web object. Hot spots in a movie can bk

defined by using a QuickTime VR authoring tool. Attribute makes sense onl_

within a QuickTime panoramaì

  HREF  Indicates the URL of a page to load when the movie is clicked. Thk

meaning of this attribute is somewhat troublesome if thk  CONTROLLE

attribute is set tf  fals2  . The problem revolves around the click having twf

meanings, one to start the movie and the other to go to the page. Page author—

should either use the autoplay feature or provide controls when using thi—

attribute. This attribute is not appropriate when using QuickTime VR object—

that may have included their own hot linksì

  HSPAC¨  Sets the horizontal pixel buffer for the pluin and acts the samk

way as thk  HSPAC¨  attribute for thk  <IMG  elementì

 = Page 336 =

ChapteX 9  HTMP an OtheX Medi¨ Type  31

  LOOL  Indicates whether the movie should play in a looped fashion. Settiný

the attribute tf  tru2  loops the movie until the user stops it. The default value i—

fals2  . When thk  LOOL  value is set tf  PALINDROM¨  , the movie loops back

and forth. Setting this value produces interesting effects with movies and eve-

reverses the soundtrack. This parameter is not appropriate for QuickTime VR

objects, because they have no distinct time orderì

  NOD¨  An optional attribute that has meaning to a multinode QuickTime VR

movie. In many QuickTime VR situations, setting multiple areas or viewpoints,

calle™  nodes¨  is desirable. Setting thk  NOD¨  attribute to the integer value of ¾  PRESENTATION AND

node in the scene loads the movie at the particular scene. This attribute has nf

meaning for no™QuickTime VR objectsì  LUT

  PAN  An optional attribute for QuickTime VR objects; allows the author tf

specify the initial pan angle in degrees. The range for thk  PAN  attribute i—

between 0 and 360 degrees. This attribute has no meaning for other forms o“

QuickTime objectsì

  PLAYEVERYFRAM¨  Can be set to eitheK  tru2  oK  fals2  . When set tf  tru2  ,

instructs the pluin to play every frame, even if it requires the movie to play aš

a slower rate. In some sense, this is appropriate in case the processor drop—

frame— thaš ma_ bk valuableì Settiný thi— valuk tf  tru2  i— noš advisablk foK movie—

with audio tracks; it has the sid[effect of turning off the sound. Furthermore,

this attribute should not be used when embedding QuickTime VR objectsì

  PLUGINSPAG¨  Sets the URL of the page that contains information about thk

required pluin and how it can be downloaded and installed, if it is noš

currently installed. This feature is supported by Netscape; it is also documente™

to work under Internet Explorer. Be careful when using this attribute. Iš

generally should be set to http://quicktime.apple.com, unless speciaR

instructions are included beyond standard QuickTime informationì

  SCAL¨  Takes a value o“  TOFI ASPEC  ,  , or a number corresponding to thk

desired scaling factor, such a—  1.5  . The defaulš  SCAL¨  value i— , which is ¾  1

normally scaled movie. Setting the attribute tf  ASPEC  scales the movie to fiš

the bounding box set by thk  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  attributes. A value o“

TOFI  scales the movie to fit thk  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  attribute, with nf

regard to aspect ratio. Be careful when scaling movies, because it may degradk

the playback performance and image qualityì

  TARGE  Used in conjunction with thk  HREF  attribute to set the name of ¾

frame into which to load the page indicated by thk  HREF  attribute. The normaR

reserved frame names, such as _blank, as well as explicitly named frames ark

availablk a— vali™ targetsì Mork informatio- o- frame— ca- bk foun™ i- ChapteK 8ì

  TIL  Can be set when using QuickTime VR objects to specify the initial tilš

angle (up or down) for the scene. The value of the attribute is specified i-

degrees and typically ranges from aroun™  –42.5  tf  42.5  degrees. The parameteK

has no meaning outside of QuickTime VR objectsì

 = Page 337 =

31‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

  VOLUM¨  Can be set to a value fro“  0  tf  256  . The higher the value, thk

louder the audio track on the QuickTime movie. A value o“ effectively mute—  0

the soundtrack, wherea—  256  sets the volume at the maximum level. If thk

attribute is not set, the default i—  256  . This option does not have meaning wit—

QuickTime VR. This is a newer attribute and will not be supported under oldeK

versions of the QuickTime pluinì

  VSPAC¨  Set to the number of vertical pixels to buffer between the embedde™

object and surrounding content. Used in the same way as the correspondiný

attribute for thk  <IMG  elementì

  WIDTh  Set to a pixel value or percentage. Be aware that the pluin may noš

necessaril_ stretc— thk videf imagk tf takk ¾5 thk spaceì A— mentione™ previously,

setting thk  SCAL¨  attribute tf  ASPEC  scales the movie to fit the boundiný

box set by thk  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  attributes. If the value supplied for thk

object width is smaller than the object’s true width, it is cropped to fit thk

dimensions provided. Thk  WIDTh  value must be set, unless thk  HIDDEN

attribute is used. Be careful when using small widths, such as 0 and 1 pixels,

because this can cause problemsì

The QuickTime pluin for Netscape is quite complex. The following examplk

illustrates only the most basic use of the pluin, a rendering of which is shown i-

Figure 4:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<FONT SIZE="4"L  This example shows a frame from a promotiona¤

clip for QuickTime, as viewed in a Netscape browser<  </FONTL

Microsoft’s ActiveMovis

Microsoft’s media technology comes under many guises, but the main effort is calle™

ActiveMovie.  It provides services for the playback of multimedia streams from local file—

or network-based servers. Specifically, ActiveMovie allows playback of video an™

audio content, compressed in various formats. ActiveMovie supports the followiný

formats:

  MPEG-1 and MPEG-2 (.mpg, .mpeg, .mpv, .mp2, .mpa)

  Audio Video Interleaved (.avi)

  Nonproprietary QuickTime files (.mov)

  Wave (.wav)

  AU (.au, .snd)

  AIFF (.aif, .aiff)

 = Page 339 =

318  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

If QuickTime is already available on a system, ActiveMovie keeps existing relationships.

This is particularly useful because ActiveMovie doesn’t support proprietary QuickTim—

features, such as QuickTime VR. However, you may find that ActiveMovie (as well ax

other video technologies) occasionally overrides existing file relationships, which may

make viewing movies difficult.

ActiveMovi[supported files can be played in one of two ways: either embedde™

within a Web page or externally, in a window displayed separatel_ External supporš  .

of active content is handled through use of a linked object with thk  <A  element, a—

discussed earlier in the chapter. However, the following are the three HTML element—

that you can use to embed ActiveMovie content:

<OBJECTL

<EMBEDL

<IMG DYNSRC=h  movie.Æih  L

ACTIVEMOVIE WITH THE OBJECT ELEMENT  Using thk  <OBJECT  element, thk

CLASSI¤  attributk musš bk seš tf thk appropriatk ActiveMovik clas— identifieK (  CLSI¤  )

so that a control to be used for playback is specified. The following short code fragmenš

sets this control explicitly and uses thk  <PARAM  element to specify the address o“

the file to play:

<OBJECT CLASSID="CLSID:05589FA1-C356-11CE-BF01-00AA0055595A"L

<PARAM NAME="FileName" VALUE="test.Æi"L

</OBJECTL

Thk  CLASSI¤  value should not be entered by hand unless absolutely necessaryì

This may change some day, though it is very unlikely. The variou—  PARAV  values thaš

can be set for thk  <OBJECT  element are too numerous to discuss. As discussed earlieK

in the chapter, a tool such as Microsoft’s ControlPad should be used to set thk  PARAV

values. To illustrate, some sample parameter values are shown here:

<OBJECT ID="TestMovie " HEIGHT=00" WIDTH=00h

CLASSID="CLSID:05589FA1-C356-11CE-BF01-00AA0055595A"L

<PARAM NAME="Version" VALUE="1"L

<PARAM NAME="EnableContextMenu" VALUE="-1"L

<PARAM NAME="ShowDisplay" VALUE="-1"L

<PARAM NAME="ShowControls" VALUE="-1"L

<PARAM NAME="ShowPositionControls" VALUE="0"L

<PARAM NAME="ShowSelectionControls" VALUE="0"L

<PARAM NAME="EnablePositionControls" VALUE="-1"L

 = Page 340 =

ChapteX 9  HTMP an OtheX Medi¨ Type  319

<PARAM NAME="EnableSelectionControls" VALUE="-1"L

<PARAM NAME="ShowTracker" VALUE="-1"L

<PARAM NAME="EnableTracker" VALUE="-1"L

<PARAM NAME="AllowHideDisplay" VALUE="-1"L

<PARAM NAME="AllowHideControls" VALUE="-1"L

<PARAM NAME="MovieWindowSize" VALUE="0"L

<PARAM NAME="FullScreenMode" VALUE="0"L

<PARAM NAME="MovieWindowWidth" VALUE=00"L  PRESENTATION AND

<PARAM NAME="MovieWindowHeight" VALUE=00"L

<PARAM NAME="AutoStart" VALUE="0"L

LUT

<PARAM NAME="Appearance" VALUE="1"L

<PARAM NAME="BorderStyle" VALUE="1"L

VALUE="http://www.bigcompany.com/movies/test.mpg"L

<PARAM NAME="DisplayForeColor" VALUE="16777215"L

<PARAM NAME="DisplayBackColor" VALUE="0"L

</OBJECTL

USING THE <EMBED> ELEMENT  You can also insert an ActiveMovie file by usiný

the Netscap[stylk  <EMBED  syntax. Thk  <EMBED  element works identically to thk

<OBJECT  element when used with Internet Explorer 3 or greater, because thk

browser simply figures out what the content is and launches the ActiveMovie controR

with the appropriate parameters. An example of using ActiveMovie is shown here:

<EMBED SRC="test.Æi" AUTOSTART="FALSE" LOOP="FALSE" HEIGHT="100h

WIDTH="100"L

If ActiveMovie is available, this HTML fragment works under both Netscape an™

Internet Explorer. Microsoft pushes thk  <OBJECT  element, and the HTML 4.0

specification favors this syntax. Nevertheless, for the time being, to guarantee supporš

across browsers, you should enclose a-  EMBE¤  element inside of thk  <OBJECT

element, to allow for fallbackì

USING THE <IMG> ELEMENT WITH THE DYNSRC ATTRIBUTE  Thk  DYNSR‚

attribute for thk  <IMG  element originated in Internet Explorer 2 and allowed AV§

files to be played within a Web page. Although the syntax is currently maintained foK

backward compatibility, using thk  <OBJECT  oK  <EMBED  elements is preferableì

 = Page 341 =

320  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Originally, thk  DYNSR‚  attribute supported only AVI files, but testing shows that an_

ActiveMovi[supported data can be included with this syntax. The basic attributes foK

<IMG  are all valid; however, the following additions are also available:

  This attribute should be set to the URL, either relative or absolute, of thk

content to playì

DYNSRC="URL of Active content"

  If this attribute is present, controls are presented below the content, if possibleì

The attribute does not need a valueì

CONTROLS

  This attribute is used to set the number of times to loop the included contentì

When set to a positive integer, the content loops the specified number of timesì

When set tf  –1  or the keywor™  INFINIT¨  , the content loops continuouslyì

LOOP="value"

  This attribute to thk  <IMG  element is used wit—  DYNSR‚  to specify how thk

content should be played. Setting the value tf  FILEOPEN  plays the content a—

soo- a— thk dat¾ filk ha— finishe™ openingì Settiný thk valuk equaR tf  MOUSEOVE

delays playing the content until the mouse is positioned over it. The defaulš

action for active content i—  FILEOPEN  ì

START=FILEOPEN | MOUSEOVER

An example of using thk  DYNSR‚  attribute with the image element for an AV§

movie is shown here. Figure 5 shows the rendering of the example under Interneš

Explorer 4ì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  DYNSRC Viewed Under Internet ExploreI  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<FONT SIZE="4"L

 = Page 342 =

attribute, as viewed in an Internet Explorer browser<  </FONTL
