VSPACE=0"L

</BODYL

</HTMLL

PRESENTATION AND

In terms of browser support, it is difficult to come up with a best bet for simplk

LUT

Web video. Netscape 3 and Internet Explorer both support AVI in their Window—

incarnations, but Macintosh users don’t even get a consolation prize. For QuickTime,

Internet Explorer and Netscape for Windows users without QuickTime installed o-

their operating systems are left out in the cold. AVI apparently might be less of ¾

problem, but the size and synchronization quality of AVI video files makes the formaš

far from ideal. In some sense, you probably should stick with a video format such a—

RealVideo, given its wide acceptance and streaming approachì

Figurs 9-58  DYNSRC  under Internet Explore

 = Page 343 =

32p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Other Video Format“

Like their audio compatriots, proprietary video formats offer one thing that man_

standard digital video formats lack: the possibility of truly streaming data. RemembeK

that a 28.8Kbps modem user receives approximately 2K of data per second. If onk

secon™ o“ videf an™ soun™ coul™ bk represente™ i- 2K, an™ thaš dat¾ coul™ bk delivere™

to the end user in time to play it, the video could effectively “stream” over the Internetì

Still, a few potential drawbacks exist to streaming audio. First, to compress video faK

enough for streaming, you have to sacrifice a certain degree of quality. Second, thk

Internet protocols themselves do not readily support the requirements of streaming, a—

discussed in the section “Audio File Formats and Compression,” earlier in this chapterì

Thk mai- streaminý videf formaš i— RealNetworks’ RealVidef (http://www.real.com)ì

Like its audio counterpart, this technology uses different attributes with thk  <EMBED

an™  <OBJECT  elements to support RealAudio’s own video protocol. Although mosš

video formats share common attributes, such a—  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  , make sure tf

check the appropriate site for information about the particular syntax to support ¾

proprietary video format. Fortunately, RealNetworks provides a production tool thaš

should insert most of the syntax to handle videoì

While proprietary formats may offer many benefits with respect to streaming oK

image quality, page authors should carefully consider the lack of builâin supporš

before rushing out to use a new technology. Choosing the wrong technology coul™

limit the audience that is able to view the content in the pageì

Like audio, the future of video on the Internet ultimately lies in integration. Peoplk

wilR resisš downloadiný dozen— o“ pluin— foK numerou— dat¾ formatsì The_ prefeK singlk

technologie— thaš integratk intf onk wholk presentation, an™ QuickTimk an™ ActiveMovik

show how this can be done. Furthermore, Macromedia supports a variety of extras foK

Shockwave, and integrating video into a presentation should also be possibleì

Eve- wit— betteK integratio- o“ videf intf ¾ WeD page, compressio- an™ performanck

guarantees will be the key points—unless the bandwidth problem is resolved. Mork

exotic compression technologies, such as fractal or wavelet video compression, wilR

certainly become more commonplace as people struggle to stream the smallest files tf

users and provide the closest semblance to the holy grail of Web TV. The Internet,

however, is a difficult place to broadcast information. With single sites as video strea“

sources, latency will make streaming to distant users impossible, regardless of hou

much compression is used. Unless a wide range of video and audio mirror services ark

deployed, allowing European users the same access to video clips as users in Nort—

America or Asia, rea_time broadcasting of video on the Internet will remain restricte™

to a select fewì

Other Binary Format“

Besides audio and video, many other data objects can be inserted into a Web page. Thk

most common binary object besides those discussed in this chapter are Adobe Acrobaš

files, which are cros-platform documents, and Macromedia Shockwave and Flash files,

 = Page 344 =

ChapteX 9  HTMP an OtheX Medi¨ Type  32

which are complex multimedia files. Both of these technologies can be included in ¾

Web page by using either thk  <EMBED  syntax popularized by Netscape or thk

<OBJECT  syntax to reference an ActiveX control. Thk  <EMBED  syntax is the safesš

untiR  <OBJECT  is finally cleared up as the standard way to include a file. Of course,

thk  <OBJECT  element syntax enables authors to include a-  <EMBED  element tf

provide backward compatibility for browsers that don’t yet supporš  <OBJECT  ì

Fortunately, obtaining canned scripts is becoming easier, which can provide HTML

markup for all the various browser, pluin, and control situationsì

PRESENTATION AND

Flass

LUT

One of the most popular new media formats on the Internet is Macromedia’s Flas—

(http://www.macromedia.com). The Flash format is a powerful vecto§base™

animation format that includes sound and interactivity. One of the nicest things abouš

the format is that it is very bandwidth friendlyì

Creating a Flash file requires using Macromedia’s Flash tool. After you assemblk

the animation, you can save it in the form of a SWF file and reference it from a WeD

page. To reference a Flash file, you can use thk  <EMBED  syntax to use a Netscapk

pluin, as shown in this example:

<EMBED SRC="test.swf" swLøeConnect="FALSE" WIDTH="‚0h

HEIGHT=40" QUALITY="autohigh" BGCOLOR="#FFFFFFh

TYPE="application/x-shockwÆe-flashh

PLUGINSPAGE="http://www.macromedia.com/shockwÆe/downloadX

index.cgi?P1_Prod_Version=ShockwÆeFlash"L

<NOEMBEDL

<IMG SRC="test.gif" HEIGHT=50" WIDTH="‚0"L

</NOEMBEDL

You also can use thk  <OBJECT  syntax to reference an ActiveX control, as follows:

<OBJECT classid="clsid:27CDB6E-AE6D-11cf-96B8-444553540000h

codebase="http://actøe.macromedia.com/flash2/cabsX

swflash.cab#version=3,0,0,0h

ID="test" WIDTH="‚0" HEIGHT=40"L

<PARAM NAME="movie" VALUE="test.swf"L

<PARAM NAME="quality" VALUE="autohigh"L

<PARAM NAME="bgcolor" VALUE="#FFFFFF"L

<IMG SRC="test.gif" WIDTH="‚0" HEIGHT=40"L

</OBJECTL

 = Page 345 =

32  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

You can even use a-  <APPLET  tag to reference a Java version of the Flash player,

as shown here:

<APPLET CODE="Flash.class" ARCHIVE="Flash.jar" WIDTH="‚0h

HEIGHT=40"L

<APPLET CODE="Flash.class" ARCHIVE="Flash.zip" WIDTH="‚0h

HEIGHT=40"L

<PARAM NAME="cabbase" VALUE="Flash.cab"> ');

<PARAM NAME="movie" VALUE="test.swf"> ');

<PARAM NAME="quality" VALUE=autohigh> ');

</APPLETL

Alternative renderings may be provided, and you can logically assume that form—

can be combined to support any situation. Because of the complexity of doing this,

Macromedia has created a tool called AfterShock, which outputs the appropriatk

HTML syntax and JavaScript code to ensure that the Flash file is properly supported i-

most every situation. A brief discussion of this is presented in Chapter 15, in the sectio-

“Cros-Platform Support with PluIns and ActiveX Controls.” A rendering of a Flas—

file in action is shown in Figure 6ì

Figurs 9-68  Flash animation in progres9

 = Page 346 =

ChapteX 9  HTMP an OtheX Medi¨ Type  32

Before Flash, the Macromedia Director format, in a compressed form called Shockwav—

for Director, was very popular. The biggest problem with Director-built animations wax

that they tended to be very large. While Shockwave for Director files (.dcr) still exisP

online, they are most appropriate for complex multimedia applications rather than th—

simple animations and presentations that Flash is often used for. Naming confusion doex

exist and people seem to use Shockwave and Flash interchangeably at times. They ar—

actually different technologies, though they are merging as time passes.

If you are interested in adding animation to your Web pages, you should check  PRESENTATION AND

into Flash, at http://www.macromedia.com/flash. Now that many browsers such a—

Netscape are shipping with the Flash format, use of this technology should skyrocketì

LUT

Acroba

Adobe’s Acrobat technology is one approach to the distribution of electroni´

documentation. Originally proposed to help implement the mythical ideal of thk

paperless office, Acrobat has now matured into a product with uses both on and off thk

Web. Adobe Acrobat provides the capability to deliver an electronic document to a-

end user without requiring the reader to have the authoring environment to open thk

file. Visually, Acrobat preserves the exact look and feel of the document, both onscree-

an™ i- printì FoK desig™oriente™ WeD publishers, Acrobaš provide— ¾ highl_ motivatiný

alternative to HTML that easily surpasses HTML’s relatively simplistic and imprecisk

layout features, as shown in Figure 7ì

Acrobat files are created by using a combination of traditional text authoring tool—

(word processors and desktop publishing software) and special Acrobat authoriný

software (Adobe Exchange or Distiller). The files are then saved in a file format aptl_

name™  Portable Document Format¨ PDF  oK  . PDF files are small, sel´contained document—

that can be transported in a variety of ways: via disk, CD-ROM, or network. The en™

user then reads the files by using special Adobe Acrobat Reader software. Thus, by it—

very nature, Acrobat reader technology must be cros-platform. Acrobat ReadeK

software is currently available for the following operating systems: Microsoft Window—

3.1, Windows 95, and Windows NT; Macintosh; Linux; Sun Microsystems’ Sun SPARC

Solaris and Sun SPARC SuƒS; HewletâPackard’s HKUX; Silicon Graphic’s IRIX;

IBM’s AIX and OS/2; and Digital’s VMSì

With regard to HTML, inserting an Acrobat file in a page is a choice betwee-

linking to the document with thk  <A  element or using thk  <EMBED  oK  <OBJECT

element to insert the document inline. The format of thk  <EMBED  element is ver_

straightforward, as shown by the following HTML fragment:

<EMBED SRC="spec.pdf" ALIGN="LEFT HSPACE=0" HEIGHT="300h

VSPACE=0" WIDTH="480"L

The only thing to worry about is how thk  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  attributes ark

handled with the Acrobat Reader. Be careful not to use widths smaller than aroun™

 = Page 347 =

32‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 9-78  Sample Acrobat documend

480 pixels; otherwise, some of the controls on the reader will be chopped off. It seem—

like the controls should be settable with attributes or even eliminated, but any supporš

for that appears to be undocumented. For more information about Acrobat and mork

details on how Acrobat might be included in a Web page, visit Adobe’s Web sitk

(http://www.adobe.com)ì

Chapte7 1h

Style Sheet

32—

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 349 =

328  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

TML is a poor language for page formatting, but this isn’t a failing of thk

technology. As mentioned throughout this book, HTML elements are noš

supposed to be used to represent layout. Even so, people often use HTML as ¾

õ

visual design environment. They tend to think visually, rather than organizationally,

when building Web pages. Why? Well, not very many choices were available in thk

past. Everybody wanted the same thing—a high degree of control over the layout o“

their Web pages. Until recently, this control required using tables, HTML tricks, an™

images for layout; or embedding a binary form, such as Acrobat, in a page. Thesk

solutions generally were unsatisfactory, howeverì

A better solution is emerging. Finally, style sheets, in the form o“  Cascading Styl—

Sheets (CSS)  , are available in the major browsers. Style sheets offer what designers havk

been clamoring for over the years: more control over layout. Arguably, style sheets ark

the best approach for creating attractive pages. Although style sheets are still relativel_

new, they are likely to become the dominant way to format Web pages in the neaK

future. Netscape and Microsoft Internet Explorer fall short in some areas of CSS1 (thk

first specification) support, but both browsers seem to be trending toward improve™

support. Another browser, Opera 3.5 (http://www.operasoftware.com/), alread_

approaches full CSS1 compliance. As you’ll see in this chapter, designers should begi-

transitioning away from HTML layout, which relies heavily on tables, and towar™

using style sheets. Furthermore, CSS2, the newest style sheet specification, is laying thk

groundwork for expanded media possibilities for Web pages. Although CSS2 isn’š

supported by many browsers yet, it will be soon, so this chapter discusses some of it—

more interesting features. The chapter ends with a section that covers some proprietar_

style sheet properties introduced by Microsoftì

The Rise of Styls

Basically, stylk sheet— separatk thk structurk o“ ¾ documenš fro“ it— presentationì

Dividiný layouš an™ presentatio- ha— man_ theoreticaR benefits; mosš importantly, iš ca-

providk foK flexiblk document— thaš displa_ equall_ welR acros— man_ type— o“ outpuš

devicesì I- general, We~base™ stylk sheet— contai- informatio- thaš describe— hou

document— ark presented, whetheK o- ¾ computeK monitor, i- print, oK perhap— eve-

pronounce™ b_ ¾ speecubase™ syste“ foK thk visuall_ impairedì Although, i- somk

ways, thi— doesn’š soun™ muc— differenš fro“ whaš man_ peoplk consideK tf bk thk

functio- o“ HTML, i- fact, iš i— fundamentall_ differenš tha- thk intende™ functio-

o“ HTMLì

As early as 1993, people have been interested in adding more layout control tf

HTML. Many approaches have been discussed and many continue to be used. A—

mentioned earlier, these approaches include misuse of HTML tags and embedde™

binary object formats (such as Adobe’s Acrobat). Because of the theoretical benefits o“

style sheets, they have been the favorite solution of the standards bodies. However,

work on a style sheet standard for the Web didn’t begin until Bert Bos of the Worl™

 = Page 350 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  329

Wide Web Consortium (W3C) wrote a charter to do so in 1995. Eventually, Hkon Lie,

also of the W3C, introduced a proposal for cascading style sheets; in December 1996,

this proposal became the W3C’s recommendation of Cascading Style Sheets Level Ç

(CSS1). The cascading style sheet approach of the W3C provides a chain of precedence,

so that local style may override global style, and a document creator’s style might eve-

override reader stylesì

But cascading isn’t the most interesting aspect of CSS1. These newly introduce™

style rules move a step closer toward device independence, and reduce reliance o-

proprietary HTML elements and tricks to force layout. As previously discussed, man_

PRESENTATION AND

of these HTML layout tags and tricks are not supported across the multitude o“

browsers. The motivation of style sheets to divide the semantic meaning of a page fro“

LUT

its physical presentation may seem a bit grandiose, but style sheets are gaininý

acceptance rapidly. The greater degree of layout control than was previously possiblk

is the main reason that Web developers may start to use style sheets. For example, stylk

sheets can be used to create a paragraph with a hal´inch margin, 100 pixels betwee-

lines, and text rendered in 4point green Impact font. Try doing that in HTMLì

Style sheets might sound wonderful, but the fact remains that they still aren’š

widely supported. Internet Explorer 3 and 4, Netscape 4, and later versions of bot—

browsers all support CSS—based style sheets to some degree, but no widely use™

browser supports all aspects of the W3C CSS definition. And now the W3C ha—

finalized the CSS Level 2 (CSS2) specification, which incorporates many of the feature—

introduced by browser vendors—notably positioning features—and introduces neu

features to support aural processing of styles and printing features. Other than outsidk

positioning, most of CSS2 is unsupported in any 4ì generation browser (althoug—  x

forthcoming 5ì -generation browsers probably will include more CSS2 support)ì  x

To further complicate matters, more than one type of style sheet exists. Man_

industry pundits support a type of sheet known a—  Document Style Semantics an

Specification Language (DSSSL)  , developed by the SGML community. The most recenš

addition i—  Extensible Style Languag— (XSL)  , an industry proposal based on DSSSL thaš

uses Extensible Markup Language (XML) syntax. XSL provides mor[complex stylk

manipulation, but is more complicated to use than CSS1. Whether XSL will achievk

industry acceptance is an open questionì

Fortunately, despite industry confusion and the browser vendors’ slow adoption o“

style sheets, you can take advantage of what style sheets offer without causiný

problems for browsers that are not “style aware.”

Style Sheet Basic“

CSS1 style sheets rely on an underlying markup structure, such as HTML. They are noš

a replacement for HTML. Without a binding to an element, a style really doesn’t mea-

anything. The purpose of a style sheet is to create a presentation for a particulaK

 = Page 351 =

330  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

element or set of elements. Binding an element to a style specification is very simple; iš

consists of an element, followed by its associated style information within curly braces:

element   {style specification}

Suppose that you want to bind a style rule to thk  <H1  element so that a 2poinš

Impact font is always used. The following rule would result in the desired display:

H1   {font-family: Impact;

font-size:   28pt}

In general, a style specification or style sheet is simply a collection o“  rulex  . Thesk

rules include ¾  selector—  an HTML element, ¾  CLASS  name, or a-  I¤  value—which i—

bound to a stylk  property  such a—  font-family  , followed by a colon and the value(s) foK

that style property. Multiple style rules may be included in a style specification b_

separating the rules with semicolons. You can also use many shorthand notations an™

grouping rules that are available, as discussed in “Advanced Style Rules: ContextuaR

Selection, Grouping, and Inheritance,” later in this chapter. Style sheets alone df

nothing; first, you must bind the rule to a tag(s) or class of HTML objects. Currently,

more than 50 properties are specified under CSS1 that affect the presentation of a-

HTML document, and more than 50 more properties are defined under CSS2ì

Unfortunately, not all of them are supported consistently across the major browsersì

Even worse, most of the newer style properties defined by CSS2 are not supported b_

any browser. The full CSS1 specification can be found at the following address:

http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-CSS1ì

The style sheet information itself is not HTML. Style information may be include

within an HTML document or outside it, but it isn’t necessarily subject to the sam—

rules as HTML pages. Many of the basic ideas do apply. Like HTML, style sheet rulex

are case-insensitive, except for the aspects of the rule that are outside the control of th—

style sheet language; these aspects include font family names (such as Britannic Bold)

and(RLs (such as http://www.bigcompany.com/Staff/thomas.htm), both of which may

be case-sensitive.

Adding Style to a Documen

Stylk informatio- ma_ Dk include™ i- a- HTML documenš i- an_ onk o“ threk basi´ ways:

  Use an outside style sheet, either by importing it or by linking to itì

  Embed a documenâwide style in thk  <HEAD  element of the documentì

  Provide an inline style exactly where the style needs to be appliedì

Eac— o“ thesk stylk sheeš approache— ha— it— ow- pro— an™ cons, a— liste™ i- Tablk 10-1ì

 = Page 352 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  33h

Sheet“  Document-Wide Styls  Inline Styls

Pro—  *Can set style foK  *Can control style for ¾  *Can control style tf

many document—  document in one plack  a single characteK

with one style sheeš  *No additional downloa™ instanck

time for style informatio-  *Overrides an_

external oK

document style—

*Need to reapply stylk

Con—  *Require extr¾  *Need to reappl_  LUT

download time foK  information for otheK  style informatio-

the style sheet,  document—  throughout thk

which may dela_  document an™

page renderiný  outside document—

*Bound too closely tf

HTML—difficult tf

updatk

Tabls 10-18  Comparison of Style Sheet Approache9

Linking to a Style Shee

An external style sheet is simply a plain text file containing the style specifications foK

HTML tags or classes. The extension indicating that the document provides style sheeš

information is .css, for Cascading Style Sheetsì

The following CSS1 style rules might be found in a file called corpstyle.css, whic—

defines a corporate style sheet for a large Web site:

BODY         {font: 10pt;

font-family: Serif;

color: black;

background: white}

H1           {font: 24pt;

font-family: Sans-Serif;

color: black}

 = Page 353 =

33p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

H2           {font: 16pt;

font-family: Sans-Serif;

color: black}

P            {text-indent: 0in;

margin-left:S0px;

margin-right:S0px}

A:link:      {color: blue;

text-decoration: none}

A:visited:   {color: red;

text-decoration: none}

A:active:    {color:red;

text-decoration: none}

.important   {background: yellow;

font-weight: extra-bold}

#note        {background: orange}

An HTML file that uses this style sheet could reference it by using thk  <LINK  taý

within thk  <HEAD  element of the document. Recall from Chapter 4 that thk  <LINK

element isn’t exclusive to style sheets and has a variety of possible relationship setting—

that can be set with thk  REL  attribute. The following is an example of how style sheeš

linking is used:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Style Sheet Linking Exampl4  </TITLEL

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="corpstyle.css" MEDIA="screenh

TYPE="text/css"L

</HEADL

<BODYL

...Content affected by style sheet..<

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 354 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  33

In this example, the relationship for thk  <LINK  element as indicated by thk  REL

attribute is set to bk  STYLESHEE  ; then, thk  HREF  attribute is used to indicate thk

URL of the style sheet to use. In this case, the style sheet resides in the same director_

as the referencing file and is known a—  corpstyle.cs—  . However, a remote style sheeš

could also be referenced by using a URL, such as http://www.bigcompany.com/

styles/tesâstyle1.css. Note that linking to an external style sheet has the same problem—

as linking to an external object insofar as the object may no longer be available or thk

speed of acquiring that object may inhibit performance of the pageì

Thk  MEDIG  attribute is used under CSS2 to provide an indication of which medi¾

PRESENTATION AND

the style sheet should apply to. This attribute enables the page designer to define onk

style for computer screens, one for print, and perhaps one for personal digitaR

LUT

assistants (PDAs). For example, a document could include two links, one for scree-

and one for print, as shown here:

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="screenstyle.css" MEDIA="screenh

TYPE="text/css"L

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="printstyle.css" MEDIA="printh

TYPE="text/css"L

Multiple values may also be set for the attribute. These should be separated b_

commas, to show that the style may apply to many media forms—for example,

MEDIA="screen,print"  . Currently, thk  MEDIG  attribute isn’t widely understood b_

browsers. For a discussion of media types defined by CSS2, see “CSS2: New Featurk

Summary,” later in this chapterì

The last thing to note in the linked style sheet example is the use of thk  TYP¨

attribute in thk  <LINK  element, which is set to the MIME typk  "text/css"  . This valuk

indicates that the linked style sheet is a cascading style sheet, but another form of stylk

sheet certainly could be linked. A style sheet type may be defined both inline an™

document wide. To avoid having to use thk  TYP¨  attribute, you may want to set ¾

default style sheet language in thk  <HEAD  element of the document by using thk

<META  element, as shown here:

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" Content="text/css"L

As it stands, by default, most browsers assume that CSS1 is being used; thk  TYP¨

setting may have little effect, regardless of how it is appliedì

Embedding and Importing Style Sheet“

The second way to include an external style sheet is to embed it. When you embed ¾

style sheet, you write the style rules directly within the HTML document. You coul™

 = Page 355 =

33  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

separate the style rules into another file and then import these rules, much as a-  includ—

file is used in a programming language such as C. However, imported style sheets ark

not supported consistently by browsers and are merely shorthand for pulling in all o“

the style information without typing it directlyì

Documenâwide style is a very easy way to begin using style sheets. It involve—

using thk  <STYLE  element found within thk  <HEAD  element of an HTML

document. You enclose the style rules within thk  <STYLE  an™  </STYLE  tag pair an™

place this pair within the head section of the HTML document. Because multiple form—

of style sheets may be included (beyond the standard CSS format), you should stilR

include thk  TYP¨  attribute to indicate which format of style sheet you are using,

regardless of the browser’s support for other style sheet technologies. You can havk

multiple occurrences of thk  <STYLE  element within the head of the document, an™

you may even import some styles, link to some style rules, and specify some style—

directly. Dividing style information into multiple sections and forms may be ver_

useful, but a way must exist to determine which style rules apply. This is the idea o“

the cascade, which is discussed in more detail later in the chapterì

One concern when including style sheets within an HTML document is that not alR

browsers understand style information. To avoid problems, comment out the stylk

information by using an HTML comment, such a—  <’- ’-  , so that the comments aren’š

displayed onscreen or misinterpreted by older browsers. A complete example of ¾

documenâwide style sheet, including hiding rules from older browsers, is shown here:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Document-Wide Style Sheet?  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css" MEDIA="PRINT"L

<!-p

BODY   {background: white;

margin-left: 1in;

margin-right: 1.5in}

H1     {font-size:p4pt;

font-family: sans-serif;

color: red;

text-align: center}

P      {font-size: 12pt;

font-family: Serif;

text-indent: 0.5in;

color: black}

--L

 = Page 356 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  33

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

...Content affected by style sheet..<

</BODYL

</HTMLL

PRESENTATION AND

Importing a style into a document is another way to use a documenâwide stylk

LUT

rather than provide the style directly. The idea is similar to linking. An external stylk

sheet is referenced; but, in this case, the reference is similar to a macro expansion inlineì

The syntax for the rule for importing a style sheet i—  @import  followed by the URL o“

the style sheet to include. This rule must be included within thk  <STYLE  element; iš

has no meaning outside that element, as compared to the linked style sheet. A-

example of how to import a style sheet is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Final//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Imported Style Sheet?  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p

@import "http://www.bigcompany.com/styles/corpstyle.css";

@import "docstyle.css";

H1   {font-size:p4pt;

color: red;

text-align: center} /* local rule‚

that may override import *X

--L

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

...Content affected by style sheet..<

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Although imported style sheets may seem to provide a great advantage foK

organizing style information, their use currently is limited by the fact that none of thk

browsers support this form of style sheet access. Page designers should stick to thk

<LINK  form of accessing external style sheets until this form has more supportì

 = Page 357 =

33‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Using Inline Styls

Beyon™ usiný ¾ stylk sheeš foK thk wholk document, yo¾ ca- ad™ stylk informatio- righš

dow- šf thk singlk elementì Thk simplesš wa_ šf ad™ stylk information, buš noš necessaril_

thk best, i— tf ad™ stylk rule— tf thk particulaK HTML elementì Here’— hou iš worksì

Supposk yo¾ wanš tf seš onk particulaK  <H1  taý tf rendeK i- 4point, green, AriaR fontì

Yo¾ coul™ appl_ thaš stylk tf alR  <H1  elements, oK tf ¾ clas— o“ the“ (discusse™ i- thk nexš

section), b_ applyiný ¾ documenâwidk styleì O- thk otheK hand, yo¾ coul™ appl_ thk stylk

tf onl_ thk taý i- question; thi— i— donk wit— thk  STYL¨  attribute, whic— ca- bk use™ withi-

nearl_ an_ HTML elementì FoK example, thk followiný examplk show— hou stylk rule—

coul™ bk applie™ tf ¾ particulaK  <H1  element:

<H1 STYLE="font-size: 48pt; font-family: Arial; color: green"L  CSS1

TesM  </H1L

This sort of style information doesn’t need to be hidden from a browser that isn’š

styl[sheet–aware, because browsers ignore any attributes that they don’t understandì

By using inline style, you can easily apply a style to a certain section or division of ¾

document by using thk  <DIV  element. Setting a twkparagraph portion of ¾

document to have a yellow background with bold, black text is fairly simple, as show-

here:

<DIV STYLE="background: yellow; font-weight: bold; color: black"L

<PL  Style sheets separate the structure of a document from it?

presentation. Dividing layout and presentation has manh

theoretical benefits and can provide for flexible document?

that display equally well on large graphically rich system?

and palmtop computers<  </PL

<PL  This is another paragraph describing the wonderful benefits o¨

style sheets<  </PL

</DIVL

If you want to provide style information solely for a few words, or even a feu

letters, the best approach is to use thk  <SPAN  element. As a block element, thk

<DIV  element works well to surround other block elements, such as paragraphs; but,

when setting a localized style within a paragraph,  <SPAN  is the correct element tf

bind style information. For example, notice hou  <SPAN  is used here to call attentio-

to a particular section of text:

<PL  Calling ouM  <SPAN STYLE="background: yellow; font-weight: bold;

color: black"L  special sections of texM  </SPANL  isn’t hard wit—

SPAN<  </PL

 = Page 358 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  33

Although putting style inline with the elements may seem like the best way to geš

started with style sheets, it isn’t; instead, you can add style to a particular set o“

elements or even to a single, unique occurrence of ¾  <P  elementì

Using Classes and ID“

In the previous examples, the style rules were bound to a particular element oK

included directly within the tag in the form of an attribute. While inlining style seem—

easy, it gives up much of the benefit of separating the structure of the document fro“

the style. But without inline styles, how can a particular style be applied to onk  PRESENTATION AND

occurrence of thk  <H1  element, or to only a few particulaK  <H1  elements? Thk

solutions to these problems are thk  CLASS  an™  I¤  attributesì

LUT

As discussed in Chapter 4, you can name a particular tag with thk  I¤  attribute sf

that it can be made a destination for a link. For example,

<H1 ID="FirstHeading"L  Welcome to Big Company, Inc<  </H1L

assigns a name of "  FirstHeading  " to thk  <H1  element so that it can be referenced fro“

an anchor element:

<A HREF="#FirstHeading"L  Go to Heading 1  </AL

Thk  I¤  attribute is common to nearly all HTML elementsì  I¤  an™  CLASS  should bk

available to most HTML elements, except for a few, such a—  <HTML <HEAD  ,  , an™

<BODY  . Style sheets can also usk  I¤  values as selectors for the style rules, enabliný

you to affect a particular element with a rule without creating an inline style for it. Thk

following markup shows how a green background is applied to thk  <P  element wit—

thk  I¤  value o“  "SecondParagraph"  , while no style is applied to the other paragraph:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  ID Style Sheet Exampl4  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

#SecondParagraph   {background: green}

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<PL  This is the first paragraph<  </PL

<P ID="SecondParagraph"L  This is the second paragrap—  </PL

 = Page 359 =

338  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<PL  This is the third paragraph<  </PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Because almost every element can have a-  I¤  attribute, the style informatio-

doesn’t need to be put within the tag. To write a style rule for a-  I¤  value, simpl_

include a rule with the name of thk  I¤  , preceded by a pound symbol, as the selector foK

the rule. For example, to create a simple rule for an element with a-  I¤  value o“

FirstHeading  , use the following syntax:

#FirstHeading   {color: blue}

The only worry that a page designer might have with using thk  I¤  attribute is thk

idea of naming, because ever_  I¤  value must be unique. So, how can a style be applie™

to some occurrence of an element, but not to others? In the preceding markup example,

how can the same style be applied to the first and thir™  <P  elements but not thk

second? The answer is simple: use a class ruleì

Thk  CLASS  attribute is referenced throughout the book when discussing the syntax

of various elements, because it defines the name of the class to which a particulaK

element belongsì  CLASS  values don’t have to be unique. Many elements can bk

members of the same class; in fact, elements don’t even have to be of the same type tf

be in a common class. The idea of usiný  CLASS  is illustrated here:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  ID Style Sheet Exampl4  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

.important   {background: yellow}

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 CLASS="important"L  Exampl4  </H1L

<P CLASS="important"L  This is the first paragraph<  </PL

<PL  This is the second paragraph<  </PL

<P CLASS="important"L  This is the third paragraph<  </PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 360 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  339

This example has three elements, each of which has it—  CLASS  attribute set tf

important  . According to the style sheet information, all members of thk  important

class, as indicated by the period, have a yellow background color. Writing rules foK

classes is easy: simply specify the class name, with a period before it as the selector:

.main-item   {font-size: 150%}

Other variations on class rules are possible. For example, setting alR  <H1  element—

important  PRESENTATION AND

of the clas—  to have a background of orange could be written like this:

H1.important   {background: orange}  LUT

Classes can be used to reduce significantly the number of style rules necessary in ¾

document. Other forms, such as contextual selection, grouping, and inheritance, whic—

are described next, may also be useful in certain situationsì

Advanced Style Rules: Contextual Selection,Grouping,

and Inheritancs

While thk  CLASS  an™  I¤  attributes provide a great deal of flexibility for creating stylk

rules, many other types of rules of equal value exist. For example, it might be useful tf

specify that alR  <STRONG  elements that occur within ¾  <P  element get treated in ¾

certain way, as compared to the same elements occurring elsewhere within thk

document. To create such a rule, the concept o“  contextual selectioc  must be usedì

Contextual selectors are created by showing the order in which the attributes must bk

nested for the rule to be applied:

P STRONG   {background: yellow}

This rule would set all occurrences of thk  <STRONG  element within ¾  <P

element to have a yellow background. Other occurrences o“  <STRONG  might noš

necessarily have the yellow background, because potential issues of inheritance ma_

creep inì

HTML documents have an implicit structure. They all have a-  <HTML  elementì

Within this element lie thk  <HEAD  an™  <BODY  elements, which might contain thk

<TITLE  an™  <P  elements, respectively. The structure of the document look—

somewhat like a family tree. For example, the document shown here would have ¾

parse tree, as shown in Figure 10-1:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Test Fil4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

 = Page 361 =

340  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<BODYL

<H1L  TesM  </H1L

<PL  This is :  <BL  TesM  </B>.</PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

In the example parse tree, note how thk  <B  element is enclosed within thk  <P

element, which is in thk  <BODY  , which is in thk  <HTML  element. What happens i“

you set a style rule to thk  <P  element? Wouldn’t this rule also apply to thk  <B

element? Sometimes it would; this is the idea of inheritance. Not all items inherit, so bk

careful when making any assumptions about inheritanceì

In some cases, applying similar rules to several different elements may be mork

useful than rewriting the rule for each separate element or creating a special groupiný

class. In such a situation, you can provide a shorthand notation known a—  elemenP

Figurs 10-18  Simple parse tree to show inheritancP

 = Page 362 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  34h

groupinv  . If you wanš  <H1 <H2  ,  , an™  <H3  to have the same basic background an™

color, you could apply the following rule:

H1, H2, H3   {background: yellow; color: black}

If it turns out that each particular heading should have a different size, you ca-

represent that by adding other rules:

PRESENTATION AND

H1   {font-size: 200%}

H2   {font-size: 150%}

H3   {font-size: 125%}  LUT

When the grouping rule and the other rules are encountered, they are combinedì

The resulting rules create the whole style. But, what happens in the followiný

situation?

H1, H2, H3   {background: yellow; color: black}

H1           {background: green}

What’s the background color for thk  <H1  element supposed to be, green oK

yellow? Some might say green because it is second. But what happens if the rules ark

swapped? This idea, called thk  cascad—  , is the key to powerful style sheet rulesì

The general idea of the cascade, in effect, is that it provides a system to sort ouš

which rules apply to a document that has many style sheets. For example, a documenš

may include a linked style sheet, embedded style definition, and inline stylk

information for a particular element. It may even include a special style definitio-

assigned by the user in his or her browser. With all of these different style rules in thk

document, one rule—perhaps a compound rule—eventually takes precedence. UndeK

CSS, the browser’s style is the least important, the user’s style is next, and thk

designer’s specified style is the most important. From a designer’s point of view, thi—

seems appropriate. Beyond this basic priority scheme, within the document itself,

inline styles, such as those set with ¾  STYL¨  attribute, take precedence over documenš

styles, which take precedence over linked or included styles. Essentially, the closer tf

the element, the more priority the style hasì

Thk cascadk concept, combine™ wit— thk ide¾ o“ inheritance, make— stylk sheet— ver_

flexibleì Imagink thaš yo¾ nee™ tf seš ¾ corporat[widk stylk i- onk documenš an™ linkiš

tf ever_ filk i- ¾ WeD site, excepš foK onk particulaK documenš thaš require— somk speciaR

changesì Wh_ redf thk corporatk stylk whe- ¾ locaR stylk ca- bk adde™ tf takk

precedenck oveK thk globaR style? However, alR o“ thi— theoriziný abouš thk cascadk

concepš isn’š reall_ necessary, becausk alR thaš yo¾ nee™ tf knou ca- bk reveale™ simpl_

b_ usiný stylk sheetsì Thus, thk nexš sectio- provide— a- examplk thaš yo¾ ca- followì

 = Page 363 =

34p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Style Sheet Exampls

The example shown here uses two forms of style: document wide and inline. Thk

example also illustrates the use of thk  CLASS  an™  I¤  attributes. Most of the propertie—

should make sense, particularly after seeing the rendering. If you don’t get it, don’š

worry; basic CSS properties and examples are covered later in the chapterì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Simple CSS Exampl4  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p

BODY           {background: black}

DIV.PAGE       {background: #FFD040;

color: black;

margin: 50px 10px 50px 10px;

padding: 10px 10px;

width: 100%;

height: 100%}

H1             {font-size:p4pt;

font-family: Comic Sans Ms, Cursøe;

text-align: center}

.black {color: black; background: white}

.white {color: white; background: black}

P              {font-family: Arial, Sans-serif;

font-size: 16pt;

line-height:p00%;

text-align: justify;

text-indent:p0px;}

.style         {color: blue; font-family: Arial;

font-style: oblique}

.size          {font-size: x-large}

#letterspace   {letter-spacing: 15pt}

--L

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<PL

of Web pages with greater precision. Style sheets can be used tB  PRESENTATION AND

Style Sheet Propertie“

The basic idea o“  how  rules are formed in style sheets was discussed earlier in thi—

chapter (refer to “Style Sheet Basics”), but whaš  ar—  the various properties that can bk

set? CSS1 defines more than 50 different properties and values, and the browseK

vendors are busy inventing new ones all the time. This section covers the standar™

CSS1 properties, which should work in all browsers. Although the_  shoul  work, somk

properties may not work in your browser. Although CSS1 promises a lot mork

flexibility than HTML, you still have the issues regarding lack of support acros—

browsers and minor rendering differencesì

Font Propertie“

CSS1 provides numerous fonâoriented properties to set the family, style, size, an™

variations of the font used within a Web page. Beyond font properties, you also ca-

combine these rules with rules for color, background, margin, and spacing to create ¾

variety of interesting typographic effectsì

font-famil

Thk  font-family  property is used to set the font family that is used to render text. Thk

font-family  property may be set to a specific font, such as Arial, or to a generic family,

such as sans serif. You have to quote any font family names that contain white space,

such a—  "Britannic Bold"  , and you may have to capitalize font values for a matchì

According to the CSS1 specification, the following generic families should bk

available on all browsers that support CSS1:

  Serif (e.g., Times)

  San-serif (e.g., Helvetica)

  Cursive (e.g., Zap´Chancery)

  Fantasy (e.g., Western)

  Monospace (e.g., Courier)

Like thk  <FONT  element, when setting thk  font-family  , you can provide ¾

prioritized list of names, separated by commas, that will be checked in orderì

Remember to always provide a backup generic font family at the end of thk

font-family  list in case the user’s browser doesn’t support the fonts suggestedì

To set a documenâwide font, use a rule such as the following:

BODY   {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, Sans-serif}

 = Page 366 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  34

The end of this chapter discusses how downloadable fonts are handled with stylk

sheets and includes a discussion of other important font properties, as well as ¾

complete exampleì

font-sizs

Thk  font-siz2  property is used to set the relative or physical size of the font used. Thk

value for the property may be a value that is mapped to a physical point size or tf

a relative word describing the size. Physical poinâsize values includk  xx-smal“  ,

x-smal“ smal“ mediu… larg2 x-larg2  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  xx-larg2  , or a relative word such a—  large(  PRESENTATION AND

oK  smalle(  . Physical sizes also may include examples, such a—  48pt 2c…  ,  , oK  .25in  ì

Percentage values, such a—  150%  , are also valid for relative sizing; negative percentage—

LUT

or point sizes are not allowed. A few example rules are shown here:

P        {font-size: 18pt}

STRONG   {font-size: larger}

H1       {font-size: 200%}

One suggestion with thk  font-siz2  property is to avoid setting point sizes, whe-

possible, because users who can’t see well may have a hard time adjusting sizeì

On certain monitors, a 10-point font might look fine; but, on others, it might bk

microscopic. If you use exact point size, remember thaš  larg2  often is better as far a—

readability is concernedì

font-styls

Thk  font-styl2  property is used to specif_  norma“ itali8  ,  , oK  obliqu2  font style for thk

font being used. A few examples are shown here:

H1       {font-style: oblique}

.first   {font-style: italic}

.plain   {font-style: normal}

Don’t try to override HTML elements with this property. Setting a rule whereb_

thk  <B  element has an italic rendering may not work. When it does, it makes foK

confusing markupì

font-weigh

Thk  font-weight  property selects the weight, or darkness, of the font. Values for thk

property range fro“  100  tf  900  , in increments of 100. Keywords are also supported,

 = Page 367 =

34‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

includiný  bold bolde(  ,  , an™  lighte(  , which are used to set relative weights. Somk

browsers may also provide keywords such a—  extra-light light demi-light mediu…  ,  ,  ,  ,

demi-bold bold  ,  , an™  extra-bold  , which correspond to thk  100  tf  900  values. Becausk

font families also includk  bold  values, and the meaning within them varies, thk

numeric scheme is preferred. A few examples are shown here:

STRONG     {font-weight:   bolder}

H1         {font-weight:   900}

.special   {font-weight:   extra-bold}

Typically, the valuk  bold  is the same a—  700  , while thk  norma“  font value i—  400  ì

font-varian

Thk  font-variant  property is used to select a variation of the specified (or default) fonš

family. The only current variants supported with this property ark  small-cap—  , whic—

displays as small uppercase letters, an™  norma“  , which doesn’t do anything. A simplk

rule is shown here:

EM   {font-variant: small-caps}

fon

Thk  font  property provides a concise way to specify all of the font properties with onk

style rule. One attribute that is included withi-  font  i—  line-height  , which specifies thk

distance between two lines of text. Each font attribute can be indicated on the line,

separated by spaces, except foK  line-height  , which is used wit—  font-siz2  and separate™

by a slash. You can use as few or as many font rules in this shorthand notation as yo¾

want. The general form of the font rule is shown here:

font: font-style font-variant font-weight font-size/line-heighM

font-familh

The following is an example of using a compact font rule:

P   {font:italic small-caps 600 18pt/24pt "Arial, Helvetica"}

The shorthand notation does not require all of the properties, so the next example i—

just as valid as the complete notation:

P   {font: italic 18pt/24pt}

 = Page 368 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  34

Two other properties,  text-transfor…  an™  text-decoration  , also affect type, so the_

are discussed next, before a complete example is presentedì

text-decoratio

Thk  text-decoration  property is used to define an effect on text. The standard values foK

this property includk  blink line-throug— overlin2 underlin2  ,  ,  ,  , an™  non2  . The meaniný

of these values is obvious, except foK  overlin2  , which creates a line above text. Thk

following examples show possible uses for this property:

PRESENTATION AND

.struck        {text-decoration: line-through}

SPAN.special   {text-decoration: blink}  LUT

H1             {text-decoration: overline}

A              {text-decoration: none}

#author        {text-decoration: underline}

As the fourth example shows, thk  text-decoration  property often is used with thk

<A  element and its associated pseudoclasses, which includk  A:link A:activ2  ,  , an™

A:visited  . Make sure to note the colon in the pseudoclass. The following example set—

unselected links to be underlined, turns off the underlining during the click, and puts ¾

line through alreadÇvisited links:

A:link      {text-decoration: underline}

A:active    {text-decoration: none}

A:visited   {text-decoration: line-through}

Using grouping, or just applying the rule to thk  <A  element, itself, might be mork

appropriate if the same style is to be applied to all states of a link. For example,

A:link, A:active, A:visited   {text-decoration: none}

text-transform

Thk  text-transfor…  property determines the capitalization of the text that it affects. Thk

possible values for this property ark  capitaliz2 uppercas2 lowercase,  ,  ,  an™  non2  . Notk

that the valuk  capitaliz2  may result in capitalizing every word. Here are some possiblk

uses of thk  text-transfor…  property:

P        {text-transform: capitalize}

.upper   {text-transform: uppercase}

.lower   {text-transform: lower}

 = Page 369 =

348  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The following is a complete style sheet example that uses all of the font rules, a—

well a—  text-transfor…  an™  text-decoration  :

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  CSS Font Attributes Exampl4  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p

BODY            {font-size: 14pt}

.serif          {font-family: serif}

.sans-serif     {font-family: sans-serif}

.cursøe        {font-family: cursøe}

.fantasy        {font-family: fantasy}

.comic          {font-family: Comic Sans MS}

.xx-small       {font-size: xx-small}

.x-small        {font-size: x-small}

.small          {font-size: small}

.medium         {font-size: medium}

.large          {font-size: large}

.x-large        {font-size: x-large}

.xx-large       {font-size: xx-large}

.smaller        {font-size: smaller}

.larger         {font-size: larger}

.points         {font-size: 18pt}

.percentage     {font-size:p00%}

.italic         {font-style: italic}

.oblique        {font-style: oblique}

.weight         {font-weight: 900}

.smallcaps      {font'ariant: small-caps}

.uppercase      {text-transform: uppercase}

.lowercase      {text-transform: lowercase}

.capitalize     {text-transform: capitalize}

.underline      {text-decoration: underline}

.blink          {text-decoration: blink}

.line-through   {text-decoration: line-through}

.overline       {text-decoration: overline}

--L

</STYLEL

<xL  Font Familh  </xL

The next bit of text is transformed  <SPAN CLASS="lowercase"L  tB

all lowercase<  </SPAN><BRL

<SPAN CLASS="capitalize"L  This text is all capitalized. It doesn'M

do what you think, does it?  </SPAN><BRL

<xL  Text DecoratioY  </xL

<BR><BRL

<BR><BRL

This text should b4  <SPAN CLASS="overline"L  overline<  </SPAN><BR><BRL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 371 =

350  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The rendering of the font and text example is shown in Figure 10-3. Note that smalR

differences still exist between Netscape and Microsoft style sheet implementationsì

Downloadable fonts and other changes to font support under style sheets ark

discussed later in this chapter. The next section covers colors and backgroundsì

Color and Background Propertie“

CSS1 supports a variety of properties that can be used to control the colors an™

backgrounds in a document. With style sheets, you can create arbitrary regions wit—

different background colors and images. In the past, such designs were difficult tf

accomplish without turning to tables or proprietary HTML extensionsì

CSS1 style sheets support three basic forms of color specifications:

  Color name—  The suggested keyword colors supported by browsers are a seš

PRESENTATION AND

of 16 color names taken from the Windows VGA palette. The colors includk

Aqu Black Blu2 Fuchsi Gray Green Lim2 Maroon Navy Oliv2 Purpl2  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

Red Silve( Tea“ Whit2  ,  ,  ,  , an™  Yellof  . These are the same predefined color—  LUT

from the HTML specificationì

  Hexadecimal value—  Support for the standard, six-digit color for“  #RRGGBB

as used with thk  <FONT  an™  <BODY  elements. A shortened, thre[digiš

color form, in which R, G, and B are hex digits, is also supported under CSS, buš

currently is an uncommon form of color specification and thus isn’t suggestedì

  RGB value—  The RGB format is also specified in the for“  rgb (R,G,B)  , whereb_

the values for R, G, and B range from 0 to 255. This format should be ver_

familiar to users of Adobe Photoshop. Currently, most browsers don’t supporš

thk  rgb (R,G,B)  color format, so use it with cautionì

colo5

CSS supports thk  colo(  property, which is used to set the text color. Its use is illustrate™

in the following examples:

BODY    {color: green}

H1      {color: #FF0088}

.fun    {color: #0f0}

#test   {color: rgb(0,255,0)}

background-colo5

Thk  background-colo(  property sets an element’s background color. The default valuk

i—  non2  , which allows any underlying content to show through. This state is alsf

specified by the keywor™  transparent  . Thk  background-colo(  property is often used i-

conjunction with thk  colo(  property that sets text color. With block elements,

background-colo(  colors content an™  padding¨  the space between an element’s content—

and its margins. With inline elements,  background-colo(  colors a box that wraps wit—

 = Page 373 =

35p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

the element if it occurs over multiple lines. This property takes colors in the samk

format as thk  colo(  property. A few example rules are shown here:

P       {background-color: yellow}

BODY    {background-color: #0000FF}

.fun    {background-color: #F00}

#test   {background-color: rgb(0,0,0)}

The second example is particularly interesting, because it sets the background coloK

for the entire document. Given this capability, thk  BGCOLO  attribute of thk

<BODY  element isn’t neededì

background-imags

Thk  background-imag2  property associates a background image with an element. I“

the image contains transparent regions, underlying content shows through. To prevenš

this, designers often use thk  background-imag2  property in conjunction with thk

background-colo(  property. The color is rendered beneath the image and provides a-

opaque background. Thk  background-imag2  property requires a URL to thk

appropriate image to use as a background. Images that can be used as background—

include whatever the browser supports for thk  BACKGROUN¤  attribute of thk

<BODY  element, typically GIF and JPEG. A few examples are shown here, includiný

some that work in conjunction with thk  background-colo(  property:

B         {background-image: url(donut-tile.gif);

background-color: white}

BODY      {background-image: url(funtile.gif)}

.brick    {background-image: url(brick.gif)}

#prison   {background-image: url(bars.gif)}

Notice that you can set a background for a small element, such a—  <B  , just as easily a—

you can for the whole document, by applying the rule to thk  <BODY  elementì

background-repea

Thk  background-repeat  property determines how background images tile in cases i-

which they are smaller than the canvas space used by their associated elements. Thk

default value i—  repeat  , which causes the image to tile in the horizontal and verticaR

dimensions. A value o“  repeat-x  for the property limits tiling to the horizontaR

dimension. Thk  repeat-y  value behaves similarly for the vertical dimension. Thk

no-repeat  value prevents the image from tilingì

 = Page 374 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  35

P      {background-image: url(donut-tile.gif);

background-repeat: repeat-x}

BODY   {background-image: url(donut-tile.gif);

background-repeat: no-repeat}

By using th—  background-repeat  property, you can avoid some of the undesirable tilinv

effects from HTML-based backgrounds. As discussed in Chapter 6, designers often musP

resort to making very wide or tall background tiles so that users won’t notice the repeat.

Because the direction o  repeat  can be controlled, designers can now use much smalle(  PRESENTATION AND

background tiles.

LUT

The second example may present an issue of what happens when the user scroll—

the screen: should the background be fixed or scroll off screen? It turns out that thi—

behavior is specified by the next property,  background-attachment  ì

background-attachmen

Thk  background-attachment  property determines whether a background image shoul™

scroll like the element content with which it is associated scrolls, or whether the imagk

should stay fixed on the screen while the content scrolls. The default value i—  scrol“  ì

The alternative value,  fixed  , can implement a watermark effect, similar to thk

proprietary attributk  BGPROPERTIES  of thk  <BODY  element that was introduce™

by Microsoft. An example of how a watermark effect might be used is shown here:

BODY   {background-image:url(logo.gif);

background-attachment: fixed}

background-positio

Thk  background-position  property specifies how a background image, not a color, i—

positioned within the canvas space used by its element. Three ways exist to specify ¾

position:

  The tošleft corner of the image can be specified as an absolute distanceì

  The position can be specified as a percentage along the horizontal and verticaR

dimensionsì

  The position can be specified with keywords to describe the horizontal an™

vertical dimensions. The keywords for the horizontal dimension ark  left cente(  ,  ,

an™  right  . The keywords for the vertical dimension ark  top cente(  ,  , an™  botto…  ì

When keywords are used, the default for an unspecified dimension is assume™

to bk  cente(  ì

 = Page 375 =

35  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The first example shows how to specify the tošleft corner of the background b_

using an absolute distance:

P   {background-image:url(picture.gif);

background-position: 10px 10px}

Remember that this distance is relative to the element and not to the document as ¾

whole, unless, of course, the property is being set for thk  <BODY  elementì

The next example shows how to specify a background image position by usiný

percentage values along the horizontal and vertical dimensions:

P   {background-image:url(picture.gif);

background-position: 20%Y0%}

If you forget to specify one percentage value, the other value is assumed to bk  50%  ì

Specifying an image position by using keywords is an easy way to do simplk

placement of an image. When you set a value, the keyword pairs have the followiný

meanings:

Keyword Pai5  Horizontal Positio  Vertical Positio

top left  0%  0%

top cente(  50%  0%

top right  100%  0%

center left  0%  50%

center cente(  50%  50%

center right  100%  50%

bottom left  0%  100%

bottom cente(  50%  100%

bottom right  100%  100%

An example of using keywords to position a background image is shown here:

BODY   {background-image: url(picture.gif);

background-position: center center}

Remember that if only one keyword is set, the second keyword defaults tf  cente(  ì

Thus, in the preceding example, the keywor™  cente(  was needed only onceì

 = Page 376 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  35

backgroun

Thk  background  property is a comprehensive property that allows any or all of the specifi´

background properties to be set at once, not unlike the shorthan™  font  property. Propert_

order does not matter. Any property not specified uses the default value. A few example—

are shown here:

P         {background: white url(picture.gif) repeat-y center}

BODY      {background: url(tile.jpg) top center fixed}

PRESENTATION AND

.bricks   {background: repeat-y top top url(bricks.gif)}

LUT

A complete example of all of the background properties in cascading style sheets i—

shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  CSS Background Attributes Exampl4  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p

P   {background: yellow url(logo.gif) repeat-y }

--L

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<PL  This is a paragraph of text. The left side will probably be hard tB

the background color. This is more text just to illustrate the idea<

This is even more text. This is more text just to illustrate the idea<

This is even more text. This is more text just to illustrate the idea<

35‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Notice that multiple background types with a variety of elements may be included. A

similar layout is possible under pure HTML, but the require™  <TABLE  elemenš

would be somewhat complicated. A rendering of the background style sheet examplk

is shown in Figure 10-4ì

Text Propertie“

Text properties are used to affect the spacing and layout of text inline, namely, the texš

within block elements such as paragraphs. The basic properties enable the pagk

designer to set indentation, word spacing, letter spacing, spacing between lines, an™

horizontal and vertical text alignment. Although these would seem to be very usefuR

properties, they currently aren’t well supported in browsersì

When you manipulate text and other objects with a style sheet, you often musš

specify a length or size. CSS1 supports a variety of measurement forms. For fonts, thk

most familiar form of measurement is probably points ( ). The CSS1 specification alsf  pt

supports measurements such as inches ( ), centimeters (  in  c…  ), and millimeters (  m…  ), a—

Figurs 10-48  Rendering of background propertie9

 = Page 378 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  35

well as picas (  p8  ), the em measurement (  e…  ), the ex unit (  x-height  ), and (under certai-

measurement situations), pixels (  px  ). In other cases, relative measurements, such a—

150%  , may be specified. Page designers who are used to electronic layout tools wilR

probably stick to the measurements most familiar to them, such as points or pixelsì

Currently, the major browsers have only limited support, if any, for measurementx

usinv  em  o(  x-height  .

word-spacing  PRESENTATION AND

Thk  word-spacing  property specifies the amount of space between words. The defaulš

value,  norma“  , uses the browser’s worÙspacing default. Designers are free to specif_  LUT

the distance between words in a variety of measurements, including inches ( ),  in

centimeters (  c…  ), millimeters (  m…  ), points ( ), picas (  pt  p8  ), the em (  e…  ) measurement,

and pixels (  px  ). A few examples are shown here:

P      {word-spacing: 1em}

BODY   {word-spacing: 10pt}

At the time of this writing, neither of the major browsers supports thk

word-spacing  property. Page designers should check to make sure this property work—

in their target audience’s browser(s) before relying on this propertyì

letter-spacing

Thk  letter-spacing  property specifies the amount of space between letters. The defaulš

value,  norma“  , uses the browser’s lette§spacing default. Like thk  word-spacing

property, a variety of measurements may be used to set word spacing, from pixels tf

em values. A few examples of this property are shown here:

P       {letter-spacing: 0.2em}

BODY    {letter-spacing: 2px}

.wide   {letter-spacing: 10pt}

#Fun    {letter-spacing: 2cm}

vertical-alig

Thk  vertical-align  property controls the vertical positioning of text and images wit—

respect to the baseline currently in effect. The possible values for thk  vertical-align

property includk  baselin2 sub supe( top text-top middl2 botto… text-botto…  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™

percentage values. Compare these values with thk  ALIGN  attribute for thk  <IMG

element, as well as alignment options for table cells, and things should begin to makk

sense. The flexibility of style sheets enables you to set element values on individuaR

 = Page 379 =

358  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

characters. When not specified, the default value o“  vertical-align  i—  baselin2  . Thk

following are a few examples:

P              {vertical-align: text-top}

.superscript   {vertical-align: super; font-size: smaller}

.subscript     {vertical-align: sub; font-size: 75%}

Notice in the example hou  vertical-align  can be used with other properties to create a-

interesting contextual class, likk  .superscript  ì

text-alig

Thk  text-align  property determines how text in a block-level element, such as thk  <P

element, is horizontally aligned. The allowed values for this property ark  left right  ,  ,

cente(  , an™  justify  . The default value for the property i—  left  . This property should acš

similar to most of thk  ALIGN  attributes, which are available on certain block-leveR

elements in HTML. Be aware that justification of a block element may be ver_

noticeable when the font is very large, and may show the added spaces. A feu

examples are shown here:

P          {text-align: justify}

DIV        {text-align: center}

.goright   {text-align: right}

text-inden

Thk  text-indent  property sets the indentation for text in the first line of a block-leveR

element. Its value can be given either as a length value (  .5c… 15px 12pt  ,  ,  , and so on) oK

as a percentage of the width of the block, such a—  10%  . The default value for thk

property i— , which indicates no indentation. A few examples of hou  0  text-indent

might be used are shown here:

P         {text-indent: 2em}

P.heavy   {text-indent:S0px}

One interesting effect is the use of negative values to create a hanging indent,

wherein the text within the block element expands outside of the block. The followiný

rule creates a paragraph with a yellow background, in which the first line of text start—

left of the text:

P   {text-indent: -10px; background: yellow}

 = Page 380 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  359

Combining the hanging indent with a large first letter for the paragraph creates a-

interesting effectì

line-heigh

Thk  line-height  propert_ set— thk heighš betwee- line— i- ¾ block-leveR element, suc— a— ¾

paragraphì Thk basi´ ide¾ i— tf seš thk link spacing, know- mork appropriatel_ a—  leadinv  ì

Thk valuk o“ thk attributk ma_ bk specifie™ a— thk numbeK o“ line— ( ), ¾ lengt— (  1.4  14pt  ), oK

a— ¾ percentagk o“ thk link heighš (  200%  )ì So, doublk spaciný coul™ bk writte- a—

PRESENTATION AND

P.double   {line-height: 2}

LUT

as well a—

P.double2   {line-height: 200%}

Other examples of usiný  line-height  are shown here:

P          {font-size: 12pt; line-height: 18pt}

P.carson   {font-size: 24pt;   line-height: 6pt}

Notice in the second example how thk  line-height  property is much smaller than thk

font-siz2  property. A browser generally should render the text on top of the other text,

creating a harÙtkread, but potentially “cool” effectì

A complete example showing the HTML and cascading style sheet markup for texš

properties is shown here:

Box Propertie“

Block-level elements, such as thk  <P  element, can be thought of as occupyiný

rectangular boxes on the screen. Three aspects of these boxes can be controlled wit—

style properties. The box properties that can be controlled include the following:

  Margin propertie—  Determine the distance between edges of an element’—

box and the edges of adjacent elementsì

  Border propertie—  Determine the visual characteristics of a bordeK

surrounding an element’s edgesì

  Padding propertie—  Determine the distance inside an element between it—

edges and its actual contentì

  Height, width, and positioning propertie—  Determine the size and positio-

of the box that the element createsì

 = Page 383 =

36p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 10-58  Rendering of text properties under Internet Explorer 4Yleft) anP

Netscape Navigator 4Yright)

The box properties are equivalent to attributes such a—  BORDE HEIGH  ,  , an™

WIDTh  when used with block elements such a—  <IMG  , but the box propertie—

provide even more power than is available under standard HTMLì

Margin Propertie“

FouK margi- propertie— ark availablk tf seš individuall_ eac— o“ a- element’— fouK marginsì

A fift— margi- propert_ allow— alR o“ thk margin— tf bk seš togetherì IndividuaR margin— foK

¾ blockelemenš ca- bk seš b_ usiný  margin-top margin-right margin-botto…  ,  ,  ,f K

margin-left  propertiesì Thk value— foK thk margin— shoul™ bk ¾ lengt— (suc— a— oK  15pt

2e…  ), ¾ percentagk valuk o“ thk blockelement’— widt— (suc— a— ), oK thk valuk  20%  autG  ,

whic— attempt— tf figurk ouš thk appropriatk margi- automatically:

BODY      {margin-top: 20px;

margin-bottom: 20px;

margin-left: 30px;

margin-left:S0px}

 = Page 384 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  36

P         {margin-bottom: 20mm}

DIV.fun   {margin-left: 1cm; margin-right: 1cm}

One interesting use of margin properties is to set negative margin values. O“

course, negative margins may clip the content of the block element in the browseK

window, if you aren’t careful. Try an example such a—

PRESENTATION AND

P   {margin-left: -2cm; background: green}

LUT

to get an idea of how negative margins workì

The last few examples show that you can set one or many margins. To make settiný

multiple margins even easier, a shorthand notation is available that enables pagk

designers to set all of the margins at once. Using thk  margin  property, one to fouK

values can be assigned to affect the block element margins. If a single value is specified,

it is applied to all four margins. For example,

P   {margin: 1cm}

sets all of the margins equal to 1.5 cm. If multiple values are specified, they are applie™

in clockwise order: first the top margin, followed by (in order) the right, bottom, an™

left margins. For example,

P   {margin: 10px,Spx, 15px,Spx}

sets the top margin to 10 pixels, the right to 5 pixels, the bottom to 15 pixels, and thk

left to 5 pixels. If only two or three values are specified in the rule, the missing value—

are determined from the opposite sides. For example,

P   {margin: 10px,Spx}

sets the top margin to 10 pixels and the right margin to 5 pixels. The opposite sides ark

then set accordingly, making the bottom margin 10 pixels and the left margin 5 pixelsì

A completk examplk usiný thk margi- propertie— i— show- hereì Notick thaš thk

examplk use— onk negativk marginì Thk backgroun™ coloK make— iš easieK tf sek thk effectì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

 = Page 385 =

36  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<TITLEL  CSS MargiY Exampl4  </TITLEL

<STYLc TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p

#ONc  {background: yellow;

margin: 1cm 1cm;

}

#TWL  {background: orange;

margin-top: 1cm;

margin-bottom: 1cm;

margin-right: .5cm;

margin-left: -10px;

}

#BIGCHAR  {background: red;

color: white;

font-size: 28pt;

font-family: Impact;

}

--L

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<F ID="ONE"L  Thi? i? : paragrap— o¨ texM thaM ha? margin? seM foI

al¤ side? tB 1 cm< Thi? i? jusM dummh texM tB show th4 effect? o¨

th4 margins< Thi? i? jusM dummh texM tB show th4 effect? o¨ th4 margins<  </PL

<F ID="TWO"><SPAN ID="BIGCHAR"L </SPANL    hi? i? anotheI paragrap— thaM ha?

margins< Thi? i? jusM dummh texM tB show th4 effecM o¨ th4

The rending of the cascading style sheet margin example under Internet Explorer 4

is shown in Figure 10-6ì

Border Propertie“

Element— ma_ Dk completel_ oK partiall_ surrounde™ b_ border— place™ betwee-

theiK margin— an™ theiK paddingì Thk bordeK propertie— controR thk edge— o“ block

element— b_ settiný whetheK the_ shoul™ havk ¾ border—whaš thk border— look

like—theiK width, theiK color, an™ sf onì Border— ark suppose™ tf work wit— bot—

block-leveR an™ inlink elements; yo¾ may, however, sek browser— automaticall_  PRESENTATION AND

converš element— wit— border— tf blockelement— b_ addiný precediný an™

followiný carriagk returnsì

LUT

 = Page 387 =

36‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

border-styls  Thk  border-styl2  property is used to set the appearance of the bordersì

The default value for the property i—  non2  , which means no border is drawn,

regardless of any other setting. The values foK  border-styl2  includk

Valus  Intended Rendering

dotted  A dotted bordeK

dashed  A dasheÙline bordeK

solid  A normal soliÙline bordeK

doubl2  A doubl[line bordeK

groov2  An etched bordeK

ridg2  An extruded bordeK

inset  An inset border, making an object look like it is set into the pagk

outset  A beveled border, making an object look raise™

A few examples o“  border-styl2  rules are shown here:

H1        {border-style: solid}

P.boxed   {border-style: double}

.button   {border-style: outset}

Thk  border-styl2  property sets the borders for each of the sides of the elementì

Individual border styles can be controlled wit—  border-top-styl2 border-bottom-styl2  ,  ,

border-left-styl2  , an™  border-right-styl2  . Thk  border-styl2  property can also act as ¾

shorthand notation and may take up to four values starting from top, right, bottom,

and then left. Like thk  margin  property, when less than four values are set, thk

opposite sides are set automatically. To set double borders on the top and bottom, usk

either of the following rules:

P       {border-style: double none}

P.one   {border-style: double none double none}

P.two   {border-top-style: double;

border-bottom-style: double;

border-left-style: none;

border-right-style: none}

 = Page 388 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  36

border-widts  Numerous properties are used to set the width of borders. FouK

propertiesfsetfthk widt— foK specifi´ borders:  border-top-widt— border-right-widt—  ,  ,

border-bottom-widt—  , an™  border-left-widt—  ì SimilaK tf thk  border-styl2  property, thk

border-widt—  propert_ sets all four borders at once and takes from one to four valuesì

Multiple values are applied to borders in a clockwise order: top, right, bottom, left. I“

only two or three values are used, the missing values are determined from the oppositk

sides, just as with margins and border stylesì

Width can be specified by using the keyword—  thin mediu…  ,  , an™  thick  as value—

indicating the size of the border, or by using an absolute measurement such as 10

PRESENTATION AND

pixels. The following examples illustrate how border widths can be set:

LUT

P                {border-style: solid; border-width: 10px}

P.double         {border-style: double; border-width: thick}

P.thickandthin   {border-style: solid; border-width: thick thin}

.fun             {border-style: double none; border-width: thick}

border-colo5  Borders may be assigned a color by using thk  border-colo(  propertyì

Color values are specified by using either a supported color name or a numeric RGB

specification. Thk  border-colo(  property sets all four borders and takes from one tf

four values. Multiple values are applied to borders in a clockwise order: top, right,

bottom, left. If only two or three values are used, the missing values are determine™

from the opposite sides. As with border widths and styles, you can use a property foK

eac— border’— coloK b_ usiný  border-top-colo( border-right-colo( border-bottom-colo(  ,  ,  ,

an™  border-left-colo(  . The following examples illustrate the basic ways to set ¾

border’s colors:

P       {border-style: solid; border-color: green}

P.all   {border-style: solid; border-top-color: green;

border-right-color: #FF0000;

border-bottom-color: yellow;

border-left-color: blue}

border shorthan  Several border properties allow any combination of width, color,

and style information to be set in a single property. Thk  border-top border-right  ,  ,

border-botto…  , an™  border-left  properties support this for their respective borders. FoK

example, to set the top border or paragraph elements to be red, doubl[line style, an™

20 pixels thick, usk

P   {border-top: double 20px red}

 = Page 389 =

368  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The order of the property values to set the style, width, and color is arbitrary, buš

according to the specification, designers should probably set the style, and then thk

width, followed by the color. Multiple properties can be combined in one rule to set thk

borders differently, as shown in the following example:

#RainbowBox   {background: yellow;

border-top: solid 20px red;

border-right: double 10px blue;

border-bottom: solid 20px green;

border-left: dashed 10px orange}

Besides a shorthand notation for each individual border side, you can use ¾

shorthand notation for all sides by using thk  borde(  property. For example, to set alR

borders of a paragraph to be red, doubl[line style, and 20 pixels thick, usk

P   {border: double 20px red}

Note that it is impossible to set the individual border sides with this shorthan™

notation. The actual properties to set the various borders must be used, such a—

border-top  or, even more specifically,  border-top-styl2  ì

The following brief example shows all of the border properties used so far. Notick

that both compact and explicit notations are used in the exampleì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p

border-style: solid;

border-width: 5px;

padding: 10px 10px

}

border-style: double;

border-width: medium;

}

border-color: red green purple blue;

Padding Propertie“

The space between an element’s border and its content can be specified by using thk

padding properties. An element’s four padding regions can be set by using thk

padding-top padding-right padding-botto…  ,  ,  , an™  padding-left  properties. As wit—

borders and margins, you can use a shorthand notation property, calle™  padding  , to seš

the padding for all sides at once. This example illustrates some basic uses of paddiný

properties:

DIV   {padding-top: 1cm}

P     {border-style: solid;

padding-left: 20mm;

padding-right:S0mm}

 = Page 391 =

370  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 10-78  CSS border properties rendered under Internet Explorer 4

The shorthand notation propert_  padding  allows a single property assignment tf

specify all four padding regions. It can take from one to four values. A single value i—

applied to all four padding areas. Multiple values are applied to padding regions in ¾

clockwise order: top, right, bottom, left. If only two or three values are used, thk

missing values are determined from the opposite sides. So,

DIV   {border-style: solid; padding: 1cm}

sets a region with a solid border, but with contents padded 1 cm from the border on alR

sides. The following sets padding on the top and bottom to 2 mm and the right and lefš

to 4 mm for all paragraphs:

P   {padding: 2mmYmm}

 = Page 392 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  37h

An example showing padding and borders to help you better understand paddiný

values is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<TITLEL  CSS Padding Exampl4  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p  PRESENTATION AND

#ONE     {background: yellow;

border-style: double;

LUT

border-width: medium;

padding-left: 1cm;

padding-right: .5cm;

}

#TWO     {background: yellow;

border-style: double;

border-width: medium;

padding-top: 1cm;

padding-bottom: 1cm;

}

#THREE   {background: yellow;

border-style: double;

border-width: medium;

padding: 1cm 1cm;

margin: .5cm 4cm;

}

--L

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

right,but not on the top and bottom<  </PL

top and bottom<  </PL

 = Page 393 =

37p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf
