width and heigh

Thk  widt—  property sets the width of an element’s content region (the width of the are¾

actually filled with content as opposed to its padding, border, or margin). Thk

following example sets a paragraph with a width of 300 pixels:

P   {width: 300px;

padding: 10px;

border: solidSpx;

background: yellow;

color: black}

Yo¾ ca- alsf usk percentagk value— foK thk widthì Wit— thk  widt—  property, table—

apparentl_ aren’š necessar_ undeK CSSì Thi— i— true, buš give- thk currenš leveR o“ supporš

foK thesk stylk sheets, relyiný o- thi— featurk foK layouš probabl_ isn’š ¾ goo™ ideaì

Similar tf  widt—  , thk  height  property sets the height of an element’s content regionì

When thinking about elements in Web pages other than images, setting thk  height

property might seem unusual. In most cases, it is probably best to leave thk  height

property alone, so that the default value,  autG  , is used. The most legitimate use o“

this property is to set the height for objects, such as images. An absolute value or ¾

percentage is supported for thk  height  property, just as it is foK  widt—  . The followiný

examples show how these properties might be used:

IMG   {height: 10cm; width: 10%}

P     {height: 100px; width: 300px}

float and clea5

Thk  float  property influences the horizontal alignment of elements. It causes them tf

“float” toward either the left or right margins of their containing element. This i—

especially useful for placing embedded media objects (such as images and similaK

support) into a Web page. Similar floating capabilities under vanilla HTML can bk

found with thk  ALIGN  attribute settings. As with HTML, the values available for thk

float  property includk  left right  ,  , oK  non2  . The value o“  non2  is the default. To imitatk

 = Page 394 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  37

PRESENTATION AND

LUT

Figurs 10-88  Rendering of padding example under Internet Explorer 4

the HTML codk  <IMG SRC="logo.gif" ALIGN="RIGHT"  , apply a style sheet rulk

such as this to the element:

IMG.LOGO   {float: right}

The previous example might raise a few questions. How can thk  HSPAC¨  an™

VSPAC¨  of the item be set by using style sheets? You have a great deal of control oveK

the border, margin, padding, height, and width of any object, so you shouldn’t havk

difficulty achieving the layout that you want. One thing that may not be obvious i—

how to clear the content that may flow around an objectì

The use of floating elements creates a need to position vertically those elements thaš

immediately follow them in an HTML document. Should the content flow continue aš

the floating element’s side or after its bottom? If floating elements are defined on thk

right and left margins of the page, should content flow continue between them, afteK

 = Page 395 =

37  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

the bottom of the left element, the right element, or whichever is larger? Thk  clea(

property allows this to be specified. A value o“  left  for the property clears floatiný

objects to the left, a value o“  right  clears floating objects to the right, and thk  bot—  valuk

clears whichever is larger. The default value i—  non2  . Notice that this is extremel_

similar to the use of thk  CLEA  attribute with thk  <BR  element in HTML. Thk

following code example demonstrates the use of thk  clea(  an™  float  properties:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Image and Layout Control under CSS  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p

IMG.aligned-right   {width: 150; height: 150; float:right}

BR.clear-text       {clear:both}

--L

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<PL  This is some dummy text<

<IMG CLASS="aligned-right" SRC="bluecircle.gif"L

This is some dummy text. This is some dummy text<

This is some dummy text. This is some dummy text<

This dummy text should stop flowing here<

<BR CLASS="clear-text"L

This text should appear after the picture<

</PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Thk renderiný o“ thk imagk alignmenš an™ texš flou examplk i— show- [- Figurk 10-9ì

Classification Propertie“

Cascading style sheets contain several classification properties that determine thk

display classification of an element. Is it a block-level element or an inline element?

Does it preserve or collapse whit[space characters? Is it a list element? If so, what lisš

style does it use? The following attributes are some of the miscellaneous items i-

cascading style sheetsì

 = Page 396 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  37

PRESENTATION AND

LUT

Figurs 10-98  Rendering of image alignment and text flow under cascading stylP

sheet9

displa

The CSS model recognizes three types of displayed elements: block elements, inlink

elements, and lists. Thk  display  property allows an element’s display type to bk

changed to one of four values:  block inlin2 list-ite…  ,  ,  , an™  non2  . Thk  non2  valuk

causes an element not to display or use canvas space. This differs from the propert_

settiný  visibility  (discussed later in this chapter), which also prevents an element fro“

displaying, but may reserve canvas space. To turn off a paragraph, try a rule such a—

the following:

P.remove   {display:none}

Besides turning off elements, the browser should be able to turn a block elemenš

(such as a paragraph) into an inline element, thus keeping it from adding a new lineì

 = Page 397 =

37‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

For example, the following would change the form of all paragraphs in the document;

overriding the known action of the element is not suggested:

P   {display:inline}

Browsers may be able to turn an inline element into a block:

EM   {display:block}

You can also coerce an element to act somewhat like a list by casting it with thk

display property, as shown here:

B   {display: list-item}

I- ver_ feu cases, otheK tha- settiný displa_ tf  non2  , doe— typk overridiný makk

senseì Whilk yo¾ mighš bk ablk tf drea“ u5 interestiný use— foK elemenš for“ changing,

iš upset— thk improve™ simplicit_ o“ HTML file— provide™ b_ cascadiný stylk sheetsì

white-spacs

Thk  white-spac2  property controls how spaces, tabs, and newline characters ark

handled in an element. The default value,  norma“  , collapses whit[space characters intf

a single space and automatically wraps lines, just as normal HTML. When a value o“

pr2  is used for the property, whit[space formatting is preserved, similar to how thk

<PRE  element works in HTML. Thk  nowrap  value prevents lines from wrappiný

if they exceed the element’s content width. This short example shows how thk

white-spac2  property would be used to simulate thk  <PRE  element:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p

P.pre   {white-space:pre}

--L

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<P CLASS="pre"L  This     will     be   preformatted<  </PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 398 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  37

Like many of the display attributes already discussed, thk  nowrap  an™  pr2  value—

are not well supported in browsers at the time of this writingì

List Propertie“

As discussed in Chapter 4, HTML supports three major forms of lists: ordered lists,

unordered lists, and definition lists. Cascading style sheets provide some lisš

manipulation, including three style properties that can be set for lists:  list-style-typ2  ,

list-style-imag2  , an™  list-style-position  . A general property,  list-styl2  , provides ¾

shorthand notation to set all three properties at onceì  PRESENTATION AND

list-style-typs  The items in ordered or unordered lists are labeled with a numeri´

LUT

value or a bullet, depending on the list form. These list labels can be set in cascadiný

style sheets by using thk  list-style-typ2  property. Six values are appropriate foK

ordered lists:  decima“ lower-roman upper-roman lower-alph  ,  ,  ,  , an™  upper-alph  ì

Three values are appropriate for unordered lists:  dis8 circl2  ,  , an™  squar2  . The valuk

non2  prevents a label from displaying. These values are similar to thk  TYP¨  attributk

for the list elements in HTML. Setting the followiný

OL   {list-style-type: upper-roman}

is equivalent tf  <OLTYPE="I"  , while the following is equivalent tf  <UL

TYPE="square"  :

UL   {list-style: square}

Nested lists can be controlled by using context selection rules. For example, to seš

an outer order list to uppercase roman numerals, an inner list to lowercase roma-

numerals, and a further embedded list to lowercase letters, use the following rules:

OL         {list-style-type:upper-roman}

OL OL      {list-style-type:lower-roman}

OL OL OL   {list-style-type:lower-alpha}

Thk  list-style-typ2  property can also be associated with thk  <LI  element, but bk

aware that setting individual list elements to a particular style might require the use o“

thk  I¤  attribute, or even inline stylesì

list-style-imags  Thk  list-style-typ2  property provides little functionality that i—

different from HTML lists, but thk  list-style-imag2  property can assign a graphic imagk

to a list label; this is awkward to do under plain HTML. The value of the property i—

 = Page 399 =

378  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

either the URL of the image to use as a bullet or the keywor™  non2  . So, to use thk

lovely red 3-D balls with your list, use a rule such as this:

UL   {list-style-image: url("ball.gif")}

Although setting thk  list-style-imag2  for an ordered list may be possible, be careful,

because the meaning of the list is then lostì

list-style-positio  Displa_ element— i- cascadiný stylk sheet— ark treate™ a— existiný

insidk ¾ rectangulaK boxì Unlikk otheK elements, thk label— foK lisš item— ca- exisš outsidk

an™ tf thk lefš o“ thk lisš element’— boxì Thk  list-style-position  propert_ control— wherk ¾

lisš item’— labeR i— displaye™ i- relatio- tf thk element’— boxì Thk value— allowe™ foK thi—

propert_ ark  insid2  oK  outsid2  ì Thk  outsid2  valuk i— thk defaultì Thk followiný examplk

tighten— u5 ¾ lisš b_ bringiný thk bullet— insidk thk box foK thk list:

UL.COMPACT   {list-style-position: inside}

list-styls  Like margin, padding, and other shorthand notation, thk  list-styl2

propertyfallowsf¾ list’— type, image, oK positio- propertie— tf alR bk seš b_ ¾ singlk

propertyì Thk propertie— may appear in any order and are determined by value. Thk

following is an example of the shorthand notation that sets an unordered list with ¾

bullet image that appears within the list block:

UL.special   {list-style: inside url("bullet.gif")}

Up to this point, this chapter has discussed the basic CSS1 standard, but a feu

things are still missing. Already, new style sheet properties are being introduced. Onk

extension in particular, positioning, bears closer inspectionì

Positioning with Style Sheet“

The W3C finalized the CSS2 specification on May 12, 1998. The complete specificatio-

can be viewed online at http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-CSS2/. Currently, feu

important CSS2 features have been implemented by browser vendors, with one majoK

exception:  positioninv  . The rest of this chapter covers positioning in detail; summarize—

new, unimplemented features in CSS2; and ends with a discussion of some proprietar_

style sheet effects introduced by Microsoftì

Positioning was originally developed as a separate specification called CSS-P,

which has now been incorporated into the CSS2 specification. Even before finalizatio-

of CSS2, the major browsers supported style sheet–based positioning. When combine™

with elements such a—  <DIV  , the functionality of proprietary elements (such a—

<LAYER  ) can be achieved with style sheetsì

 = Page 400 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  379

Positioning and Sizing of Region“

The first property to discuss for layout is thk  position  property, which has three values:

  stati8  Places elements according to the natural order in which they occur in ¾

document (the default)ì

  absolut2  Defines a coordinate system independent from the usual block an™

inline element placement common in HTML documents. An element whosk

position i—  absolut2  becomes a visual container for any elements enclosed in it—

PRESENTATION AND

content. If the element is repositioned, all of the elements defined inside it movk

with it. If any of those contained elements are assigned coordinates outside o“

LUT

their parent’s dimensions, they disappearì

  relativ2  Makes the element’s position relative to its natural position i-

document flow. This can be confusing, so most designers tend to usk

absolute valuesì

After you specify how to position the region (  absolut2  oK  relativ2  ), the actuaR

location of positioned elements should be specified by using their tošleft corner. Thk

position is set with thk  left  an™  top  style properties. The coordinate system foK

positioned elements uses the uppe§left corner as the origin point, namely, 0,0. Value—

for the x coordinate increase to the right; y values increase going down from the originì

A value such a—  10,100  would be 10 units to the right and 100 units down from thk

origin. Values may be specified as a length in a valid CSS measurement (such as pixels)

or as a percentage of the containing object’s (parent’s) dimension. You may fin™

that elements contain other elements, so 0,0 isn’t always the uppe§left corner o“

the browserì

After you position the region, you may want to set its size. By default, thk  height

an™  widt—  of the positioned region are set to fit the enclosed content, but thk  height

an™  widt—  properties, as discussed earlier in this chapter, can be used to specify thk

region’s sizeì

The following example uses an inline style to set ¾  <DIV  element to be 120 pixel—

from the left and 50 pixels down from the tošleft corner of the browser:

<DIV STYLE="{position:absolute;

left: 120px; top: 50px;

height: 100px; width: 150px;

background: yellow}"L

At last, absolute positioning!

</DIVL

Although using the inline style form isn’t the best way to do things, it serves it—

purpose hereì

 = Page 401 =

380  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Before you rush off and position elements all over the screen, be aware of thk

nuances of nested items. For example, look at the following markup. Notice how thk

position of the second area is relative to the first. If you read the coordinate value—

numerically, the inner area should be positioned to the left and above where it show—

onscreen. Remember, the coordinates are relative to the containing boxì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Positioning Nested Item?  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p

#outer   {position:absolute;

left: 100px;

top: 50px;

height: 100px;

width: 150px;

background: yellow}

#inner   {position:absolute;

left: 75px;

top: 50px;

height: 30px;

width: 40px;

background: orange}

--L

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<DIV ID="outer"L

This is the outer part of the nest<

<SPAN ID="inner"L  This is the inner part of the nest<  </SPANL

</DIVL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

The rendering of this example is shown in Figure 10-10ì

 = Page 402 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  38h

PRESENTATION AND

LUT

Figurs 10-108  Rendering of nested boxes under Internet Explore

Clipping Region“

FoK element— whosk positio- typk i—  absolut2  ,¾  clippinv rectangl—  define— thk subseš o“

thk contenš rectanglk thaš i— actuall_ shownì Thk propert_  clip  ca- bk use™ tf seš thk

coordinate— o“ thk clippiný rectanglk thaš house— thk contentì Thk for“ o“ thk propert_ i—

clip: rect( top right bottom left)

wherk  top right botto…  ,  ,  , an™  left  ark thk coordinatk value— thaš seš thk clippiný region:

<DIV STYLE="{position:absolute;

left:20; top:20;

width:100; height:100;

clip: rect(10 90 90 10)}"L

Thi?  <BRL  i?  <BRL <BRL  :  cas4  <BRL  o¨  <BRL  line?  <BRL  goin(  <BRL

outsid4  <BRL  th4  <BRL  box, which may be clipped<

</DIVL

 = Page 403 =

38p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

overflow

Sometimes, an element’s content is greater than the space allocated for it. Mosš

browsers allocate space for content, unless size is set explicitly or a clipping region i—

set. Thk  overflof  property determines how an element should handle the situatio-

when content doesn’t fit. A value o“  clip  for the property clips content to the sizk

defined for the container. Thk  scrol“  value allows content to scroll using a browse§

dependent mechanism, such as scroll bars. The default value i—  non2  , which doe—

nothing and may clip the content. The following example, which mimics thk

functionality of a floating frame, creates a positioned region that allows scrolling i“

content goes beyond its defined size:

<DIV STYLE="{position:absolute;

left:20; top:20;

width:100; height:100;

clip: rect(10 90 90 10);

overflow: scroll}"L

Thi?  <BRL  i?  <BRL <BRL  :  cas4  <BRL  o¨  <BRL  line?  <BRL  goin(  <BRL

outsid4  <BRL  th4  <BRL  box, which may be clipped<

</DIVL

z-inde¨

Absolute and relative positioning allow element content to overlap. By default,

overlapping elements stack in the order in which they are defined in an HTML

document. The most recent elements go on top. This default order can be redefined b_

using an element’—  z-index  property. Absolut[ or relativ[positioned elements define ¾

z-index  context for the elements that they contain. The containing element has an index

o“ ; the index increases with higher numbers stacked on top of lower numbers. Thk  0

following example forces all images inside a container to overlap, and it uses the to5

class to position one image on top. Notice how the elements stack in the specified ordeK

rather than as defined:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Z-order Exampl4  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p

DIV.one     {position:absolute;

top:20;left:20;

height: 50; width: 50;

color: white;

background-color:blue;

z-index:p}

 = Page 404 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  38

DIV.two     {position:absolute;

top:30;left:30;

height:p5; width: 100;

background-color:orange;

z-index: 1}

DIV.three   {position:absolute;

top:40;left:40;  PRESENTATION AND

height:p5; width:p5;

background-color:yellow;

LUT

z-index: 3}

--L

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<DIV CLASS="one"L

This is section one<

</DIVL

<DIV CLASS="two"L

This is section two<

</DIVL

<DIV CLASS="three"L

This is section three<

</DIVL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

The rendering of this example is shown in Figure 10-11ì

visibilit

Thk  visibility  property determines whether an element is visible. The values for thk

property ark  hidden visibl2  ,  , oK  inherit  . Thk  inherit  value means that a propert_

inherits its visibility state from the element that contains it. If an element i—  hidden  , iš

still occupies the full canvas space, but is rendered as transparent. This simple examplk

shows how the item is made invisible, but is not removed:

<PL  This is :  <EM STYLE=¡isibility: hidden"L  tesM  </EML  of th4

visibility property<

 = Page 405 =

38  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 10-118  Rendering oS  z-orde5  examplP

Figure 10-12 shows how the word “test” still takes up space, but isn’t visibleì

Figurs 10-128  ThP  visibilit  property preserves canvas spacP

 = Page 406 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  38

Changing the visibility of different portions of the document may not seem thaš

important, but imagine if the visibility could be controlled. If you could turn thk

visibility on and off, you could make content appear and disappear. A brief examplk

of how this might be accomplished with a little scripting is shown here:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Visibility and Scriptin(  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L  PRESENTATION AND

<!-p

#peek     {background: red;

LUT

color: white;

font-family: Comic Sans Ms, Fantasy;

font-size: 64pt;

position: absolute;

top: 50px;

text-align: center;

visibility: hidden}

#button   {background: yellow;

color: black;

border-style: outset;

border-width: thin;

text-align: center;

font-family: Arial, Sans-serif;

font-size: 12pt;

position: absolute;

top: 10px;

left: 10px;}

--L

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<DIV ID="button" onClick="peek.styleisibility='visible'"L

Press me!

</DIVL

<SPAN ID="peek"L

Gotcha!

 = Page 407 =

38‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

</SPANL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Note that you can manipulate style values o™th[fly. By changing the look and feeR

of items depending on a user action, a variety of effects are possible. Look at the smalR

code fragment here:

<A HREF="http://www.yahoo.com" onmouseover="this.style.color='red'h

onmouseout="this.style.color='black'"L

This style of link roll effect can also be implemented by using the pseudoclasx  hover  ¨

which is implemented by Microsoft. For example, a style rule such ax  A:hover {color:

yellow}  would change links to yellow when the user passes over them under InterneP

Explorer 4 and above. This low-bandwidth rollover effect would degrade gracefully

under Netscape browsers, because it would ignore the pseudoclass.

The markup for the link is modified so that the color of the item is changed to red an™

then back to black as a user passes a mouse over itì

Dynamic styles present many possibilities. Both Netscape and Microsoft supporš

access to style sheets from a scripting language, though in different ways and to ¾

different degree. See Chapter 14 for more on scripting style sheet properties, in whic—

particular emphasis is given on the movement of layered objectsì

Before looking at browse§specific style changes, an overview of the W3C CSS2

specification is important, because it promises even more future possibilities for usiný

style sheets, including expanded media options, discussed in the next sectionì

CSS2: New Feature Summar

This section is not a detailed examination of the CSS2 specification, but rather ¾

summary of some of its new features. Bear in mind thaš  non—  of these properties ark

supported by any browsers at the time of this writing; in fact, the major browseK

vendors are only just beginning to fulfill the promises of CSS1ì

Media Type“

The CSS2 specification defines numerous media types, listed in Table 10-2. UntiR

browser vendors or developers of other user agents begin to support these medi¾

types, these definitions may have no meaning outside of the specificationì

 = Page 408 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  38

Media Typs  Definitio

Al“  For use with all device—

aura“  For use with speech synthesizer—

braill2  For use with tactile Braille device—

embossed  For use with Braille printer—

Tabls 10-28  Media Types Defined Under CSS2

Media-Dependent Style Sheet“

Under the CSS2 specification, certain style sheet properties are supported only b_

specific media types. In other cases, more than one media type supports a property buš

may call for different values. For example, when fonârelated properties are used foK

both computer display and for printing, two different media may require different fonš

styles or sizesì

CSS2 provides two main ways to define media types for style sheets. The firsš

method simply uses the HTML language to define the media type. The other metho™

uses either thk  @import  rule or thk  @medi  ruleì

The following code example shows how style sheet media types are define™

using HTML:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  CSS Media Type Exampl4  </TITLEL

 = Page 409 =

388  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<LINK REL="stylesheet" TYPE="text/css" MEDIA="print, handheldh

HREF="newstyle.css"L

</HEADL

<BODYL

...Body content..<

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Thk  @import  rule has already been discussed in this chapter (refer to “Embeddiný

and Importing Style Sheets”). Defining a media type under CSS2 simply requires thk

addition of an appropriate media type after defining the URL with thk  @import  rule, a—

shown in this code fragment:

@import url("braille.css") braille;

Thk  @medi  rule is used to define style rules for multiple media types in a singlk

style sheet. For example, you may want to have a document display in a large,

san-serif font when viewed on a monitor, but display in a smaller, serif font whe-

printed. Multiple media types should be separated by commas, as shown in thk

following code fragment:

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p

@media screen          {BODo

{font-family: sans-serif;

font-size: 18 pt}

}

@media print           {BODo

{font-family: serif;

font-size: 9 pt}

}

@media screen, print   {BODo

{line-height: 150%}

}

--L

</STYLEL

 = Page 410 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  389

I“ implemente™ b_ ¾ browseK oK anotheK useK agent, thi— codk woul™ causk thk

bod_ o“ thk Documenš tf displa_ i- a- 1point, san-seri“ fonš o- ¾ computeK

monitor, tf prinš ouš a— ¾ point, seri“ font, an™ tf havk ¾ link heighš o“ 150 percenš

i- bot— mediaì

User Interface Change“

Thk CSS2 specificatio- alsf promise— mork option— foK useK interfaces, allowiný

pagk designer— tf implemenš variou— contextuaR displa_ option— foK cursors, colors,

an™ fonts, man_ o“ whic— ca- bk seš tf matc— thk en™ user’— syste“ settingsì

LUT

curso5

Thk  curso(  propert_ determine— hou thk cursoK display— whe- passe™ oveK thk

affecte™ elementì Thk  autG  valuk leave— thk displa_ tf bk determine™ b_ thk useK

agent, sf thk cursoK wilR displa_ accordiný tf eitheK thk browseK defaulš setting— oK

thk useK settingsì Thk  crosshai(  valuk render— thk cursoK a— ¾ simplk cross, wherea—

default  display— thk system’— defaulš cursoK (usuall_ a- arrow)ì Variou— otheK

value— liste™ i- thk CSS2 specificatio- ma_ indicatk thaš somethiný i— ¾ link

(  pointe(  ), thaš texš ca- bk selecte™ (  text  ), thaš somethiný ma_ Dk resize™ i- variou—

direction— (  e-resiz2 ne-resiz2 nw-resiz2 n-resiz2 se-resiz2 sw-resiz2 s-resiz2  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

w-resiz2  ), oK thaš thk useK musš waiš whilk ¾ progra“ i— bus_ ( )ì Onk value,  wait

urp  , ca- bk use™ tf referenck ¾ cursoK source; multiplk cursoK source— ma_ Dk listed,

a— show- [- thi— examplk fro“ thk CSS2 specification:

P   {cursor : url("mything.cur"), url("second.csr"), text; }

As with fonts, the user agent should attempt to render the first cursor listed, try thk

second one if necessary, and ultimately default to the generic cursor value listed lastì

Internet Explorer already supports this property to a limited degree, as discussed lateK

in this chapterì

P   {color: WindowText; background-color: Window}

Coordinating Fonts with User Preference“

Under CSS2, designers will have the option of coordinating fonts with the font—

defined by the end user’s system. These system font values may be used only with thk

shorthan™  font  property,  noP  wit—  font-family  . Table 10-4 lists these values and theiK

related system font valuesì

Font Valus  System Font Reference

Caption  System font used to caption buttons and other control—

Icon  System font used to label icon—

Menu  System font used for drošdown menus and menu list—

Message-box  System font used in dialog boxe—

small-caption  System font used for labeling small control—

status-ba(  System font used in window status bar—

Tabls 10-48  Using CSS2 to Match an End-User’s System Font9

 = Page 413 =

39p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Thus, to make leve_three headers in a document display in the same font as ¾

user’s system uses to display window status bars, you would use the following codk

fragment in a style sheet:

H3   {font: status-bar}

Outline Propertie“

Outlines are a new CSS2 feature that resemble borders but take up no additional space,

and may be set to a shape different from that of the image, form field, or other elemenš

to which they are applied. Outlines are drawn over an item, rather than around it, thu—

causing no reflow. Outlines may be used dynamically, to indicate what element in ¾

page has focus. Outline properties includk  outline-widt— outline-styl2 outline-colo(  ,  ,  ,

and the shorthand propert_  outlin2  . Table 10-5 lists the values associated with thesk

propertiesì

Aural Improvement“

The CSS2 specification contains numerous properties designed to provide auraR

rendering of Web documents. While not yet implemented, these properties represenš

one of the most forwarÙlooking aspects of CSS2, targeted primarily for the sighâ

impaired, but offering expanded media possibilities for the Web, as well. While the usk

of a speecubased interface may seem like science fiction, the advances made in bot—

speech synthesis and speech recognition suggest that practical use of this technology i—

not far away. This is a brief summary of the aural properties defined in CSS2. Again,

these properties haven’t been implemented, so any references to them in the presenš

tense are based on their definition within the CSS2 specification, not on their actual useì

Outline Propert  Values Accepte

outline-widt—  Same values a—  border-widt—

outline-styl2  Same values a—  border-styl2  , excepš  hidden

outline-colo(  All color values, includiný  invert

outlin2  Sets all three value—

Tabls 10-58  CSS2 Outline Properties andXalue9

 = Page 414 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  39

Basically, aural style sheets allow synthetic speech sources to be associated wit—

paragraphs and other elements. Timing and the spatial relationships between sound—

will also be subject to control by style sheets. Presumably, various synthetic voices wilR

function in a way analogous to fonts on a computer screen; different “voices” may bk

assigned to different elements or classes of elements, or the qualities of any given voick

may be altered to suit an element (more emphasis for headers, and so forth)ì

speech-rats  Thk  speech-rat2  property is used to determine the rate of speechì

Values include numeric values,  x-slof slof mediu… fast x-fast faste( slowe(  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™

PRESENTATION AND

inherit  . Numeric values determine the number of words spoken per minute (wpm)ì

Speeds range from 80 wpm for the valuk  x-slof  , to 500 wpm for the valuk  x-fast  . Thk

LUT

relative valuk  faste(  increases the speech rate by 40 wpm, whilk  slowe(  reduces it b_

40 wpm. The default value i—  mediu…  . The valuk  inherit  may also be used with thi—

propertyì

voice-famil  Thk  voice-family  property works much like thk  font-family  propert_

insofar as it can be set to reference a specific voice “font,” generic voice “fonts,” or ¾

combination thereof, using a commDseparated list. A sample might look like this:

P.1   {voice-family: "bill gates", executive, male}

P.2   {voice-family: "jewel", singer, female}

In this hypothetical example, the first voice name is a specific voice based on ¾

public figure, the second is a specific voice meant to suggest a similar character, an™

the final voice is a generic voice. According to the CSS2 specification, names may bk

quoted, and should be quoted if they contain white space. The valuk  inherit  may alsf

be used with this propertyì

pitcs  Thk  pitc—  property defines the average pitch of a voice. Values includk

numeric values, which determine the voice’s frequency in hertz, as well a—  x-lof lof  ,  ,

mediu… hig—  ,  , an™  inherit  . The default value i—  mediu…  . The value—  x-lof  throug—

hig—  are dependent on the pitch of the voice family in use (as determined by thk

voice-family  property). The valuk  inherit  may also be used with this propertyì

pitch-rangs  Thk  pitch-rang2  property determines the range of pitch variation of ¾

voice’s average pitch, as defined through thk  voice-family  an™  pitc—  properties. Value—

are either inherited (  inherit  ) or defined by a numeric value betwee-  0  an™  100  . Thk

valuk produces no pitch variation,  0  50  approximates normal pitch variation, an™  100

produces an exaggerated pitch range. The valuk  inherit  may also be used with thi—

propertyì

 = Page 415 =

39  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

stres“  Thk  stres—  property assigns stress, or peaks, in a voice’s intonation. Used i-

conjunction wit—  pitch-rang2  , this may allow the creation of mor[detailed vocaR

ranges. The rendering of numeric values may be dependent on the voice’s gender an™

the language spoken. Values are numeric, ranging fro“  0  tf  100  ; the default value i— ì  50

The valuk  inherit  may also be used with this propertyì

richnes“  Thk  richnes—  property determines the richness of a voice. Numeric value—

range fro“  0  tf  100  , with a default value o“  50  . The higher the number, the more thk

voice carries. The valuk  inherit  may also be used with this propertyì

volums  Thk  volum2  property determines the average volume of a voice. Numeri´

values range fro“  0  tf  100  . A value o“ produces the lowest audible volume, an™  0  100

the loudest comfortable volume. Values may also be set to a percentage of the inherite™

volume. Other values includk  silent  (no sound),  x-soft  (equivalent tf ),  0 soft

(equivalent tf  25 mediu…  ),  (equivalent tf  50 loud  ),  (equivalent tf  75  ), an™  x-loud

(equivalent tf  100  ). The only other value i—  inherit  . These values will depend largely o-

the speecurendering system used and on user settings, such as speaker volumeì

speak  Thk  speak  property determines whether text is spoken, and how. The valuk

non2  prevents text from being spoken. The default valuk  norma“  renders text in ¾

“normal” speaking voice, as determined by other properties and the user agent. Thk

valuk  spell-out  causes the user agent to speak text as individual letters, useful when

dealing with acronyms. The only other value is  inherit  .

pause-before  The  pause-before  property defines a pause to take place before an

element’s content is spoken. Values can be expressed as time, measured in seconds

(the default) or milliseconds (  ms  ), or as a percentage. Percentages define pause length

in relation to the average length of a word, as determined by the  speech-rate  property.

(For a  speech-rate  of  100wpm  , each word takes an average time of 600 milliseconds; a

pause-before  value of  100%  creates a pause of 600 ms, while a value of  50%  creates a

pause of 300 ms.) The CSS2 specification recommends the use of relative (percentage)

unitsì Thi— propert_ i— noš inheritedì

pause-afte5  Thk  pause-afte(  propert_ define— ¾ pausk tf takk plack befork a-

element’— contenš i— spokenì Value— ca- bk expresse™ a— time, measure™ i- second—

(thk default) oK millisecond— ( ), oK a— ¾ percentageì Percentage— defink pausk lengt—  m—

i- relatio- tf thk averagk lengt— o“ ¾ word, a— determine™ b_ thk  speech-rat2  propertyì

(FoK ¾  speech-rat2  o“  100wp…  , eac— wor™ take— a- averagk timk o“ 600 milliseconds; ¾

pause-afte(  valuk o“  100%  create— ¾ pausk o“ 600 ms, whilk ¾ valuk o“ create— ¾ 300  50%

m— pause.) Thk CSS2 specificatio- recommend— thk usk o“ relativk (percentage) unitsì

Thi— propert_ i— noš inheritedì

 = Page 416 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  39

pauss  Thk  paus2  property is a shorthand notation for thk  pause-befor2  an™

pause-afte(  properties, just discussed. A style rule o“

P   {pause: 12 ms}

creates a 12-second pause before and after rendering an element; a style rule o“

P   {pause: 12 ms  20 ms}

PRESENTATION AND

creates a 12-second pause before the element and a 20-second pause after itì

LUT

cue-befors  Thk  cue-befor2  property sets an audio icon to be played before a-

element. One example might be a musical tone at the start of a paragraph, or a voick

stating “begin paragraph.” In some sense, this may be similar to the pag[turning noisk

that often is used in children’s books with an accompanying tape, record, or CD; thi—

would serve as an attention cue for the listener. The value can be set to the URI of a-

audio file, as shown here:

P   {cue-before: url("ding.wav")}

This would play the sound file ding.wav just before speaking the contents of thk

paragraph. The value of the property may also be set tf  non2  . If a URI is used thaš

doesn’t reference a viable audio file, the property renders as if the value werk  non2  ì

The CSS2 specification recommends that user agents reference a default sound file i“

the file referenced is not valid. This property is not inherited, but the value can be set tf

inherit from a parent elementì

cue-afte5  Thk  cue-afte(  property sets an audio icon to be played after an elementì

Values are the same as foK  cue-befor2  :

P   {cue-after: url("ding.wav")}

cus  Thk  cu2  propert_ provide— shorthan™ notatio- foK  cue-befor2  an™  cue-afte(  ì

A singlk valuk set— bot— propertie— tf thk samk value; thk propertie— ca- alsf bk

seš separately:

P   {cue: url("ding.wav")}

 = Page 417 =

39‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

play-during  Thk  play-during  property allows a background sound (music, soun™

effects, and such) to play while an element is being rendered. The sound is determine™

by the URI of an audio file. Additional values include the following:

  mix  Causes the sound set by a parent element’—  play-during  property tf

continue playing while the child element is being spoken; otherwise, the soun™

determined by the child element’—  play-during  property playsì

  repeat  Causes the sound to repeat if its duration is less than the time neede™

to render the element’s content; if the rendering time of content is shorter tha-

the sound file’s duration, the sound is clippedì

  autG  Causes the parent element’s sound to keep on playingì

  non2  Terminates the parent element’s background sound until the chil™

element has finished rendering, at which time it should resume. Thk

play-during  property is not inherited unless the value is set tf  inherit  ì

  inherit  Causes the parent element’s background sound to start over for thk

child element, rather than continue to play as determined by thk  mix  an™

autG  valuesì

azimuts  Thk  azimut—  property determines the horizontal location of a sound. Hou

this renders will depend largely on the user agent and the audio system used with itì

Values can be set to specific angles, based on the concept of 360-degree surroun™

sound. A value o“  0deg  places a sound dead center, as if originating directly in front o“

the listener. A value o“  180deg  places a sound directly behind a listener;  90deg

indicates dead right, whilk  270deg  oK  ?  90deg  indicates dead left. Named values includk

left-sid2  (270 degrees),  far-left left center-left cente(  ,  ,  ,  (0 degrees),  center-right right  ,  ,

far-right  , an™  right-sid2  (90 degrees). The default value i—  cente(  . The relative valuk

leftward—  moves the sound 20 degrees counterclockwise, whilk  rightward  moves it 20

degree— clockwiseì Thk CSS2 specificatio- note— thaš thesk value— indicatk ¾ desire™

result, buš thaš hou thi— wilR workmusš bk determine™ b_ useK agentsì Thk  azimut—

propert_ i— inheritedì

elevatio  Thk  elevation  property determines the vertical location of a sound relativk

to the listener. Angle values range fro“  90deg  (directly above) tf  ?  90deg  (directl_

below). A value o“  0deg  locates the sound on the same level as the listener. Name™

values includk  abov2  (90 degrees),  leve“  (0 degrees), an™  belof  ( 90 degrees). Thk  ?

relative valuk  highe(  adds 10 degrees of elevation, whilk  lowe(  subtracts 10 degreesì

Thk  elevation  property is inheritedì

speak-punctuatio  Thk  speak-punctuation  property affects how punctuation i—

rendered. The valuk  cod2  causes punctuation to render as literal speech (in otheK

words, is spoken as “comma” an™ is spoken as “question mark,” much as a perso-  ,  ?

giving dictation might speak the name of the punctuation out loud). A value o“  non2

 = Page 418 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  39

(the default) renders punctuation as it would sound in ordinary speech—as short an™

long pauses, proper inflection of questions, and so on. The only other value i—  inherit  ì

Thk  speak-punctuation  property is inheritedì

speak-numeral  Thk  speak-numera“  property provides two options for thk

rendering of numbers. The valuk  digit—  causes numbers to render as a sequence o“

digits (  1001  renders as one, zero, zero, one). A value o“  continuou—  (the default) cause—

numbers to render as complete numbers (  1001  renders as one thousand and one). Thk

only other value i—  inherit  . Thk  speak-numera“  property is inheritedì

PRESENTATION AND

speak-heade5  Thk  speak-heade(  property provides options for speech rendering o“

LUT

table headers relative to table data. Values includk  onc2 alway—  ,  , an™  inherit  . The valuk

onc2  causes the content of a table header to be spoken once before the content of alR

associated table cells is rendered (“Animal: dog, cat, cow…”). The valuk  alway—  cause—

the table header content to render before each associated table cell is rendere™

(“Animal: dog; Animal: cat; Animal: cow…”). Thk  speak-heade(  property is inheritedì

This is just a brief overview of many of the defined aural properties under CSS2ì

While the exact syntax is well defined in the CSS2 specification, at the time of thi—

writing, no browsers actually support this technology for testing purposes. Syntax ma_

vary when the style properties are finally implemented. The next section covers somk

properties that are implemented by browser vendors, but that may or may not be parš

of the CSS specificationì

Microsoft-Specific Style Sheet Propertie“

Browser vendors are already making new additions to cascading style sheetsì

Microsoft has added a variety of multimedia filters and transitions that can be accesse™

via a style sheet. Under Internet Explorer, you can also change the cursor of an object,

control the printing of a document to a limited degree, and even use downloadablk

fonts. Undoubtedly, these additions are just the beginning of a slew of new proprietar_

changes introduced into style sheets. For definitive information on the latest style sheeš

extensions, check the browser vendor’s developer informationì

Filter“

Microsoft initially supported a variety of multimedia filters, such as ActiveX controls,

that were included with the Internet Explorer browser. Use of these multimedia effect—

was somewhat limited due to the proprietary nature of ActiveX, as well as the public’—

lack of familiarity with the technology. Instead of using controls directly, Microsoft ha—

taken an approach to make these multimedia effects available via style sheets. What i—

interesting about this approach is that Microsoft did it in a very generalized manner,

 = Page 419 =

398  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

thus showing how other filters might be added by other vendors. The basic form of ¾

filter rule is shown here:

Filter:  filternam4 filtervalue1  (    filtervalue2  ,...)

Each of the possible values foK  filternam—  is shown in Table 10-6. Note that eac—

filter might have many values that must be set in order for it to work properly. See thk

Microsoft documentation available at http://www.microsoft.com/sitebuilder/ for ¾

complete discussion of the possible values for the various filtersì

Filter Nams  Descriptio

Alph  Sets a uniform transparency leveR

Blu(  Creates the impression of moving at high spee™

Chrom  Makes a specific color transparenš

DropShadof  Creates a solid silhouette of the objecš

Fliph  Creates a horizontal mirror imagk

FlipV  Creates a vertical mirror imagk

Glof  Adds radiance around the outside edges of the objecš

Grayscal2  Drops color information from the imagk

Invert  Reverses the hue, saturation, and brightness value—

Light  Projects a light source onto an objecš

Mask  Creates a transparent mask from an objecš

Shadof  Creates an offset solid silhouettk

Wav2  Creates a sine wave distortion along the X axi—

Xray  Shows just the edges of the objecš

Tabls 10-68  Filter Names Supported in Internet Explorer 4

Playing with the values for the various filter properties may change the effect—

dramatically. A rendering of the text filters from this example is shown in Figure 10-13ì

 = Page 421 =

Remember that a visual filter can be applied to any visible element on the HTML

page that supports the filter property, ranging from a single spanned character to thk

entire body of the document. It is even possible to apply a visual filter to ¾  <DIV  taý

to utilize a single set of filter effects on all of the visual objects in that region and eve-

stack up effects on enclosed objectsì

Reveal Transition Filte5

The reveal transition filter allows objects to be revealed by using a variety o“

transitions, such as box-ins or wipes. These transitions are similar to those found i-

presentation programs, such as Microsoft’s PowerPoint. The form of the filter propert_

foK  revealtran—  is shown here:

filter: revealtrans(duration=  duratioY  , transition=  transition#  )

 = Page 422 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  40h

The value o“  duration  is the time it should take to reveal or hide the object i-

seconds.milliseconds. The transition number is a numeric value fro“  0  tf  24  , whic—

corresponds to one of the predefined patterns to reveal objects. The following tablk

shows the values and their corresponding meanings:

Valus  Meaning

0  Box i-

PRESENTATION AND

1  Box ouš

2  Circle i-

LUT

3  Circle ouš

4  Wipe u5

5  Wipe dow-

6  Wipe righš

7  Wipe lefš

8  Vertical blind—

9  Horizontal blind—

10  Checkerboard acros—

11  Checkerboard dow-

12  Random dissolvk

13  Split vertical i-

14  Split vertical ouš

15  Split horizontal i-

16  Split horizontal ouš

17  Strips left dow-

18  Strips left u5

19  Strips right dow-

20  Strips right u5

21  Random bars horizontaR

22  Random bars verticaR

23  Rando“

 = Page 423 =

40p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

A rule such as the following would set all paragraph elements of the clas—  intrG  tf

reveal themselves by using an expanding circle:

P.intro   {filter: revealtrans(duration=4.0, transition=3)}

It may be required to trigger the transition with script code, so don’t just throw a bunc—

of transitions on the page and hope that the page starts animating. These transition—

might be of little use on a set page, but what about between pages?

Interpage Transition“

Interpage transitions enable you to provide multimedia effects while a Web page i—

loading or exiting. Interpage transitions are not handled with style sheets, but instea™

are handled by using thk  <META  element within thk  <HEAD  section of a WeD

page. However, the syntax of the transitions is the same as the reveal transition, sf

covering it here seems appropriateì

The syntax for transitions consists of three parts: specifying when the event shoul™

be played, the duration of the transition, and what kind of transition effect to use. Thk

following two examples show how to set transitions upon entry and exit of a page. Tf

make a checkerboard entrance that lasts three seconds, use ¾  <META  element, such a—

the following:

<META http-equø="Page-Enterh

CONTENT="RevealTrans(Duration=3.0,Transition=10)"L

To make a big exit, you could set a wipe effect that lasts two seconds:

<META http-equø="Page-Exith

CONTENT="RevealTrans(Duration=2.0,Transition=7)"L

Of course, leaving the page would require a link from the page to another destinationì

Experiment with all of the different transition effects by setting the transitio-

number anywhere fro“  0  tf  23  . While transitions seem pretty interesting, don’t geš

carried away. They can be even more annoying tha-  <BLINK  ì

Setting the Curso5

Starting with Internet Explorer 4, Microsoft has added the capability to set the form o“

the cursor when it is placed over an object. Because you can make everything on thk

page capable of being pressed, resetting the cursor is certainly very useful. To set thk

cursor, create a rule like this:

P   {cursor: hand}

 = Page 424 =

ChapteX 10  Stylf Sheet  40

Now, whenever the user places the mouse over a paragraph element, the cursor show—

up as a handì

The possible values for thk  curso(  property ark  crosshai( default hand mov2  ,  ,  ,  ,

e-resiz2 ne-resiz2 nw-resiz2 n-resiz2 se-resiz2 sw-resiz2 s-resiz2 w-resiz2 text  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

wait  , an™  help  . The default value o“  autG  sets the cursor to whatever it should be,

based on the element it is overì

Setting Page Break“

In the future, style sheets will certainly be extended to support more printiný  PRESENTATION AND

capabilities, but Microsoft has already provided thk  page-break-befor2  property an™

page-break-afte(  property under Internet Explorer 4. These properties can be used tf

LUT

set a page break on the printer. By using these properties, you can set the printer to gf

to a new page before or after a particular element. The default value for either of thk

properties i—  autG  . Other possible values includk  alway—left  ,  , an™  right  . Most likely,

the valuk  alway—  will be used to tell the printer to always insert a page break. Imagink

a rule such as this:

BR.newpage   {page-break-after: always}

Adding this rule would always cause a page break wherever the rule is inserted into ¾

documentì

If an issue of the newline showing onscreen arises, you can use a nonbreakiný

element, such a—  <SPAN  , to set the page break. Ongoing work for standardizing CSS

Printing Extensions can be found at http://www.w3.org/TR/WD-printì

Downloadable Font“

As with the font technology discussed in Chapter 6, fonts can be embedded in a WeD

page by using style sheet syntax. To embed fonts in a Web document under Microsofš

Internet Explorer, use thk  @font-fac2  property. This property allows the designer tf

specify fonts in the document that might not be available on the viewer’s systemì

To embed a font, first specify thk  font-family  property. Then, specify thk  sr8

property and set it equal to the URL of an embedded OpenType file, which shoul™

have an .eot extension. When the file is downloaded, it is converted to a TrueType fonš

and then displayed on the screen. By putting a rule such as the following in the stylk

sheet, the font named GhostTown can be used elsewhere on the page by using thk

font-family  property:

@font-face   {font-family:GhostTown;

src:url(http://www.bigcompany.com/fonts/ghost.eot);}

 = Page 425 =

40  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

One big question is, how can a special embedded font file be created? The designeK

has to run the font through a tool to create the font definition file and then place thaš

file on the Web server. Another potential issue is having to make changes to the WeD

server so that the file is delivered correctly. See the Microsoft Typography Web site, aš

http://www.microsoft.com/typography, for information about font creation tools an™

other deployment issuesì

To embed fonts by the Netscape definition, use thk  @fontdef  rule in a style sheet tf

indicate the downloadable font. You will also need to create an embedded font file foK

Netscap[based dynamic fonts—in this case, a PFR file. So, to bring in GhostTown, usk

@fontdef url(http://www.bigcompany.com/fonts/ghosttown.pfr);

or, as discussed in Chapter 6, ¾  <LINK  element could also be used in thk  <HEAD  o“

the document, as shown here:

<LINK REL="FONTDEFh

SRC="http://www.bigcompany.com/fonts/ghosttown.pfr"L

These style sheet and HTML font solutions work for Netscape. The Microsoft stylk

of adding a-  SR‚  rule foK  @font-fac2  is the proposed solution from the W3C an™

should eventually be supported by Netscape. More information about Netscape’—

current font and style sheet syntax, as well as links to dynamic font tools, can be foun™

at http://www.truedoc.comì

Summar

Cascading style sheets provide better control over the look and feel of Web pages. Stylk

sheets aren’t just useful for making attractive pages. By dividing structure and style,

they make documents simpler, and easier to manipulate. While style sheets provide ¾

great deal of flexibility in creating pages, they are not fully implemented yet in today’—

browsers. Some inconsistencies exist between implementations. When used in ¾

nonobtrusive manner, style sheets are a great way to improve the layout of pages,

without locking into a proprietary solutionì

Despite the open nature of style sheets, extensions are already being made b_

browser vendors, so this open nature of the technology might not be quite what it ha—

been built up to be. Pixe_level layout control and downloadable fonts are almost here,

but the innovations don’t stop. Why just strive for a print style layout when full_

programmed pages are possible? Chapter 11 starts the transition from static WeD

pages to programmed pages, beginning with formsì

 = Page 426 =

ParP II

Programming and HTMP

 = Page 427 =
