 = Page 428 =

Chapte7 1

Basic Interactivity

and HTML: Form

40—

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 429 =

408  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

ne of the most dynamic aspects of the Web is that it offers the ability to includk

interactive features. Up to this point, the discussion has focused on the Web as ¾

static publishing environment. Adding a way for the end viewer to submiš

O

information makes the Web more powerful than traditional media. At the simplesš

level, you could create a link with a mailto URL, covered in Chapter 4, and havk

visitors send in [mail comments. There are other times when creating a fil_out for“

would make more sense. With fil_out forms and the appropriate programs to handlk

the submitted information, it is possible to create an interactive environment ranginý

from an order entry system to a dynamically created Web siteì

How Are Forms Used?

There are many uses for forms on the Web. The most common ones include commenš

response forms, order entry forms, subscription forms, registration forms, an™

customization forms:

  A  comment respons—  is generally used as a way to collect comments from WeD

site viewers and have people suggest improvementsì

  Order entry forms¨  which are now common on the Web, provide a way foK

viewers to order goods from online stores. Order entry forms typically requirk

the user to provide an address, credit card number, and other informatio-

necessary to facilitate online commerceì

Such forms are often used to access databas[hosted information; foK

example, looking up information in a catalog. Many [commerce sites rely o-

forms and databases to provide order entry servicesì

People worry about the interception of credit card numbers when they are sending theh

to firms they may know very little about. There are facilities to encrypt data transmitte

between Web browser and server, but users should be very cautious about who is at th—

other end of the connection. A little common sense can remove much of the fear aroun

sensitive data transmission.

  Many sites, particularly those that attempt to generate revenue through direcš

subscriptions or by selling advertising space, are adopting a subscriber modeR

usiný  subscription formx  ì

  Registration formx  are used to collect information about a user and often are tie™

to an authentication system, which limits access to the siteì

  Some sites allow the user to select the look and feel for the site itself, literall_

creating a custom site for each visitor. A  customization forh  might allow user—

to specify what topics they are interested in within an online magazine. Whe-

tied to an authentication system, a user accessing the site views a version seš

according to his or her tastesì

 = Page 430 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  409

There are many other examples of how forms might be used on the Web. The poinš

here is to illustrate the kind of interactivity provided by formsì

Form Preliminarie“

Making forms is easy. Just add thk  <FORM  element and associated tags for the for“

fields to the document, as you’ll learn more about in the next section. But how can thk

contents of a form be processed once the user submits the information? After a form i—

filled in, it is sent somewhere (as specified by a URL); generally, a program on a remotk

Web server will then parse the submitted information and do something with it. Thk

programs that handle the incoming form data are usually Common Gateway Interfack

(CGI) programs. They can also utilize ColdFusion, or NSAPI (Netscape Server API)

programs, or ISAPI (Internet Information Server API) filters. A basic overview of hou

the relationship works is shown in Figure 1—1ì

The point here isn’t to get into the complications of how to make a CGI progra“

or other programs to handle form submitted data, just to understand that the for“

itself is only part of the equation. There still must be some way to make the form df

PROGRAMMING

something, but this may not be your responsibility. CGI can get complicated, since iš

AND HTM¤

usually involves real programming in languages like C, Perl, or even Applescript. Iš

may be beyond the skill set of the page designer. It is possible to use of´th[shelf CG§

programs in many casesì

But why worry about these issues? Does the person who creates the IRS tax for“

know how the program that calculates things works? Why should you worry abouš

how the CGI for the database query form you created is written? This division of laboK

is far too often missing in Web projects. The people who build the back end of the WeD

site that the form interacts with probably aren’t the best ones to code the form. Thk

person who codes the form isn’t necessarily always the best person to write thk

back-end CGI program. Think about how the form works in the grand scheme o“

things, but worry mostly about making your end of the site workì

Figurs 11-18  Form interaction intervieX

 = Page 431 =

410  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The <FORM> Elemen

A form in HTML is enclosed between thk  <FORM  an™  </FORM  tags. The form itsel“

contains regular text; other HTML elements such as tables; and form elements such a—

check boxes, pul_down menus, and text fields. The W3C specification calls these for“

element—  controlx  . This is somewhat confusing, because Microsoft also refers to ActiveX

objects as controls. To avoid confusion, we’ll call form elements either form fields oK

form controls, not just controls. The form controls are set by a user to indicate thk

contents of the form. Once the user has finished filling out the form, it must bk

submitted for processing. Completed forms are generally passed to a remote progra“

that handles the data. The contents may even be mailed to a user for further inspectionì

To make the form work, you must specify two things, and potentially two otheK

important features. First, specify the address of the program that will handle the for“

contents usiný  ACTION  . Next, specify the method in which the form data will bk

passed using thk  METHO¤  attribute. Thk  NAM¨  attribute is also very important to seš

a name for the form so it can be later manipulated by a scripting language such a—

JavaScript. Finally, in some cases you may have to specify how the form will bk

encoded using thk  ENCTYP¨  attributeì

ACTION Attributs

How an HTML form is to be handled is set using thk  ACTION  attribute for the for“

element. Thk  ACTION  attribute is usually set to a URL of the program that will handlk

the form data. This URL will usually point to a CGI script to decode the form resultsì

For example, the codk

<FORM ACTION="http://www.bigcompany.com/cgi-bin/post-queryh

METHOD="POST"L

would be for a script called posâquery in the cg¾bin directory on the serveK

www.bigcompany.com. It is also possible to use a relative URL for thk ACTION

attribute if the form is delivered by the same server that houses the forRhandliný

program:

<FORM ACTION="../cgi-bin/post-query" METHOD="POST"L

Setting thk  ACTION  immediately begs this question: what program should thk

data be passed to? This depends on who writes the program. There may be canne™

programs to handle the contents of the form. But what happens if there is no way tf

use a remote program? It is possible to create a “poor man’s” form using the mailtf

URL. Remember that thk  ACTION  attribute is set to a URL. Thus, in some cases, ¾

form element such as the following will workì

 = Page 432 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  41h

<FORM ACTION="mailto:formtest@bigcompany.com" METHOD="POSTh

ENCTYPE="text/plain"L

It is even possible to use an extended form of mailto URL, which is supported b_

Netscape browsers. For example:

<FORM ACTION="mailto:formtest@bigcompany.com?

Subject=Comment%20Form%20Result"L

Although the mailto form seems the best way to do things, not all browsers supporš

this style. There are also potential security issues. Even if the browser supports thk

mailto style, the data should be passed using thk  POS  method. It may be useful tf

encode the data differently by setting it to use text/plain encoding rather than thk

default style, which is a cryptic encoding style similar to how URLs look. The nexš

section discusses the methods and the encoding typeì

METHOD Attributs

PROGRAMMING

It is also necessary to specify how the form will be submitted to the address specifie™

AND HTM¤

by thk  ACTION  attribute. How data will be submitted is handled by thk  METHO¤

attribute. There are two acceptable values for thk  METHO¤  attribute:  GE  an™  POS  ì

These are the HTTP methods that a browser uses to “talk” to a server. We’ll find ouš

more about that in a moment, as well as in Chapter 12. Note that if thk  METHO¤

attribute remains unspecified, most browsers will default to thk  GE  method. Whilk

much of the following discussion is more applicable to the people writing thk

programs that handle form data, it is important to understand the basic idea o“

each methodì

GET Metho

Thk  GE  method is generally the default method for browsers to submit informationì

In fact, HTML documents are generally retrieved by requesting a single URL from ¾

Web server using thk  GE  method, which is part of the HTTP protocol. When yo¾

type a URL such as http://www.bigcompany.com/staff/thomas.htm into youK

Web browser, it is translated into a valid HTTf  GE  request such as this:

GET /staff/thomas.htm HTTP/1.0

This request is then sent to the server www.bigcompany.com. What this requesš

says, essentially, is “Get me the file thomas.htm in the staff directory. I am speakiný

the 1.0 dialect of HTTP.” How does this relate to forms? You really aren’t getting a filk

per s—  when you submit a form, are you? In reality, you are running a program tf

handle the form data. For example, thk  ACTION  value might specify a URL likk

 = Page 433 =

41p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

http://www.bigcompany.com/cg¾bin/comment.exe, which is the address of ¾

program that can parse your comment form. So wouldn’t the HTTP request bk

something like the one shown here?

GET /cgi-bin/comment.exe HTTP/1.0

Not quite. You need to pass the form data along with the name of the program to runì

To do this, all the information from the form is appended onto the end of the URL

being requested. This produces a hundreÙcharacter URL with the actual data in it, a—

shown here:

http://www.bigompany.com/cgi-bin/comments.exe?

Name=Al+Smith&Age=30&Sex=mal4

Thk  GE  method isn’t very secure, since the data input appears in the URLì

Furthermore, there is a limitation to just how much data can be passed with thk  GE

method. It would be impossible to append a 10,000-word essay to the end of a URL, a—

most browsers limit a URL to several thousand characters. Further problems wit—  GE

become obvious when dealing with foreign language environments. Would it bk

possible to deal with Japanese Kanji characters in the URL using the GET method?

Maybe not. Under the HTML 4.0 specification, thk  GE  method has been deprecatedì

Despite the fact thaš  GE  is not recommended, it is still the default method when thk

METHO¤  attribute is not specifiedì

With all these problems, why usk  GE  ? First,  GE  is easy to deal with. An examplk

URL such as the following should make it obvious that thk  Nam2  field is set tf  "A“

Smith"  , thk  Ag2  field is set tf  "30"  , and thk  Sex  field is set tf  "male"  :

http://www.bigompany.com/cgi-bin/

comments.exe?Name=Al+Smith&Age=30&Sex=mal4

Form field names are set to values that are generally encoded with plus signs instead o“

spaces. Nonalphanumeric characters are replaced by %  nn¨  wherk  nc  is the hexadecimaR

ASCII code for the character, similar to the URL encoding, as described in Chapter 4ì

The individual form field values are separated by ampersands. It would be trivial tf

write a parsing program to recover data out of this formì

The other method,  POS  , is just as easy, so this is not a motivating reason to usk

GE  . Perhaps the best reason to usk  GE  is that it comes in the form of a URL, so it ca-

be set as ¾ link or bookmarkedì  GE  is used well in search engines. When a useK

submits a query to a search engine, the engine runs the query and then returns pagk

upon page of result. It is possible to bookmark the query results and rerun the quer_

later. It is also possible to create anchors that fire off canned CGI programs. This i—

particularly useful in certain varieties of dynamic Web sites. For example, the link

 = Page 434 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  41

shown next fires off a CGI program written in the ColdFusion Markup (CFM) languagk

and passes it a value setting—setting the ExecutiveID to 1ì

<A HREF="displayexec.cfm?ExecutøeId=1"L  John KowalskB  </AL

The query is built into the link; when the link is clicked, the CGI program wilR

access the appropriate database of executives and bring up information about Joh-

Kowalskiì

While thk  GE  method is far from perfect, there are certain situations where iš

makes a great deal of sense. It is unlikely thaš  GE  will be truly deprecated for quitk

some timeì

POST Metho

In situations in which a large amount of information must be passed back, thk  POS

method is more appropriate tha-  GE  . Thk  POS  method transmits all form inpuš

information immediately after the requested URL. In other words, once the server ha—

received a request from a form usiný  POS  , it knows to continue “listening” for thk

rest of the information. In some sense, this method requires making two contacts to thk  PROGRAMMING

Web server. Thk  GE  method only requires one, because the method comes with thk  AND HTM¤

data to use right in the request. The encoding of the form data is handled in the samk

general way as thk  GE  method by default; spaces become plus signs and otheK

characters are encoded in the URL fashion. A sample form might send data that woul™

look likk

Name=Al+Smith&Age=30&Sex=mal4

The data will still have to be broken up to be used by the handling program. Thk

benefit of using thk  POS  method is that a large amount of data can be submitted thi—

way because the form contents are not in the URL. It is even possible to send thk

contents of files using this method. In the case of thk  POS  example, the encoding o“

the form data is the same a—  GE  . It is possible to change the encoding method usiný

thk  ENCTYP¨  attributeì

NAME Attributs

It is often desirable to check data before it is sent into the Web server. Users find it ver_

frustrating to fill out a form and submit it to a server only to have the server return ¾

page indicating data problems or omissions. Checking data before submission, ofte-

terme™  forh validation¨  requires the use of JavaScript, which is discussed in Chapters 13

and 14. Key to using JavaScript is making sure to give the form an alphanumeri´

identifier. Thk  NAM¨  attribute can be set to an alphanumeric value such a—

“orderform.” As with all form elements, you should be sure to always set thk  NAM¨

attribute for ¾  <FORM  element for future manipulation by a scripting languageì

 = Page 435 =

41  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

There many be some confusion on the use o“  NAM¨  since the HTML 4.0

specification provides thk  I¤  attribute as a core attribute. However, browsers,

including Netscape 2 and 3, depend on the occurrence o“  NAM¨  to provide access tf

the form. Page authors looking to usk  I¤  instead should consider settiný  NAM¨  an™

I¤  to the same value. Note that while many browsers will handle this just fine, it is noš

allowed according to the specification, since thk  NAM¨  an™  I¤  attributes shark

namespace. This example is one of these specificatio™versu-practice problems sf

common on the Webì

ENCTYPE Attributs

When data is passed from a form to a Web server, it is typically encoded just like ¾

URL. In this encoding, spaces are replaced by the + symbol and nonalphanumeri´

characters are replaced by %  nc  , wherk  nc  is the hexadecimal ASCII code foK

the character. The form of this is described in the special MIME file formaš

application/x-www-form-urlencode  . By default, all form data is submitted in this formì

It is possible, however, to set the encoding method for form data by setting thk

ENCTYP¨  attribute. When using a mailto URL in thk  ACTION  attribute, the encodiný

type o“  text/plain  might be more desirable. The result would look like the examplk

shown here:

First Name=Jo4

Last Name=Smit—

Sex=Mal4

Submit=Send iM

Each form field is on a line of its own. Even with this encoding form, nonalphanumeri´

characters may be encoded in the hexadecimal formì

AnotheK for“ o“ encodiný i— alsf important:  multiform/form-dat  ì Whe- passiný

file— backvi¾ ¾ form, iš i— importanš tf designatk wherk eac— filk begin— an™ endsì A valuk

o“  multipart/form-dat  foK thk  ENCTYP¨  i— use™ tf indicatk thi— styleì I- thi— encoding,

space— an™ nonalphanumeri´ character— ark preserved; dat¾ element— ark separate™ b_

speciaR delimiteK linesì Thk followiný filk fragmenš show— thk submissio- o“ ¾ for“ wit—

multipart/form-dat  encoding, includiný thk content— o“ thk attache™ files:

Content-type: multipart/form-data;

boundary=---------------------------2988412654262

Content-Length:89

-----------------------------2988412654262

Content-Disposition: form-data; name="firstname"

HomeI

 = Page 436 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  41

-----------------------------2988412654262

Content-Disposition: form-data; name="lastname"

SimpsoY

-----------------------------2988412654262

Content-Disposition: form-data; name="myfile";

filename="C:\WINNT\PROFILES\ADMINISTRATOR\DESKTOP\TEST.HTM"

Content-Type: text/htm¤

<html><head><titleL  Test Fil4  </title></head><BODY><BRL

<centerL  Test Fil4  </center><hr></BODY></htmlL

----------------------------------------

8/12/99Y:47:45 PM--SF_NOTIFY_PREPROC_HEADERS

URL=/clients/postit.cfm?

----------------------------------------

8/12/99Y:47:45 PM--SF_NOTIFY_URL_MA

URL=/clients/postit.cf—

Physical Path=C:\InetPub\wwwroot\clients\postit.cf—

----------------------------------------

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Simple <FORM> Synta¨

Given that we have a destination for the form contents as specified by thk  ACTION

attribute and possibly ¾  METHO¤  , eitheK  GE  oK  POS  , and maybe an encodiný

form, we can write a simple stub example for a form as shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Form Stu  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<FORM ACTION="/cgi-bin/post-query" METHOD="POST"L

Form field controls and standard HTML markuB

</FORML

</BODYL

</HTMLL

While this syntax is adequate to build the form framework in most cases, there ark

other attributes for thk  <FORM  element that may be useful for frame targeting,

 = Page 437 =

41‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

scripting, and style sheets. Before discussing the individual form controls, let’s revieu

the complete syntax for thk  <FORM  elementì

Complete <FORM> Synta¨

Thk  <FORM  element is a block-level structure used to define a fil_in form. For“

contents are enclosed within thk  <FORM  an™  </FORM  tags, both of which ark

mandatory. Thk  <FORM  element has a variety of attributes, as shown here:

<FORM

ACCEPT-CHARSET="list of supported characters sets"

ACTION="URL"

CLASS="class name(s)"

DIR="LTR | RTL"

ENCTYPE="application/x-www-form-urlencoded |

multipart/form-data | text/plain |

Media Type as per RFC 2045"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LANG=language cod4

METHOD="GET | POST"

STYLE="style information"

TARGET="frame name | _blank | _parent | _self | _top"

(transitional)

TITLE=advisory texM

4  venthandleI  ="script">

Form controls and HTML markuB

</FORM>

Two additional attributes for thk  <FORM  element are defined by Interneš

Explorer 4. Thk  NAM¨  attribute is also supported by most Web browsersì

NAME="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LANGUAGE="JAVASCRIPT | JSCRIPT | VBSCRIPT | VBS"

Attribute“

Thk  <FORM  element has a variety of attributes. Most of these are common to thk

HTML 4.0 standard or the major browsersì

 = Page 438 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  41

ACCEPT-CHARSET  This attribute specifies the list of character encoding value—

for input data that must be accepted by the server processing the form. The value i—

a spac[ or commDdelimited list of character sets defined in RFC 2045 (http://dsì

internic.net/rfc/rfc2045.txt). The default value for this attribute is the reserve™

valuk  UNKNOWN  ì

ACTION  This attribute specifies the address to which the form contents will be sentì

This is usually the URL of a serve§side program that handles the form content. It ma_

also be a mailto URL. Thk  ACTION  value is required for working forms, though o-

some browsers a value similar to the base URL of the document will be assumed if thk

ACTION  is left outì

CLASS  This attribute is used to specify the class name for the form so that it can bk

used as a subclass from a style sheet, as discussed in Chapter 10ì

DIR  Thi— attributk i— intende™ tf specif_ thk directio- o“ texš (lefâtkrighš oK righâtkleft)

wit— thk value—  LT  an™  RTL  ì

PROGRAMMING

ENCTYPE  This attribute is used to specify the encoding form of the form data. B_

AND HTM¤

default, the encoding value i—  application/x-www-form-urlencoded  , where spaces ark

translated to plus signs and other nonalphanumeric values are translated intf

hexadecimal values just as URLs are encoded. As discussed earlier, other possiblk

values for this attribute includk  plain/text  , which is useful when mailing form content—

to people, an™  multipart/form-dat  , which is used to upload files via formsì

ID  This attribute is used to specify a unique name for thk  <FORM  element. It ca-

also serve as the destination of a link or be manipulated by a style sheet. Thk  I¤  valuk

also makes the form available for scripting; but, for now, for backwarÙcompatibility,

you may want to stick to specifying only thk  NAM¨  attribute, as older browsers wilR

recognize itì

LANG  Thi— attributk i— use™ tf specif_ thk languagk beiný use™ i- thk formì

Thk languagk i— specifie™ b_ settiný thk attributk tf thk ISO-standar™ languagk

abbreviatio- formì

LANGU  The Internet Explorer–specifi´  LANGUAG¨  attribute is used to specif_

the language of the script associated with thk  <FORM  element. In particular, thi—

attribute applies to the script handlers bound to the various events handled in thk

<FORM  element itself. This attribute has no bearing on the language of scripts calle™

by form controls or the functions that may be called via the event handlers. The valuk

for thk  LANGUAG¨  attribute is JavaScript by default, buš  JSCRIP VBS  ,  , an™

VBSCRIP  are also possibleì

 = Page 439 =

418  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

METHOD  This attribute indicates how the form data should be sent to the addres—

specified by thk  ACTION  attribute. The possible values for this attribute ark  GE  an™

POS GE  ì  sends the information within the URL of the request, whilk  POS  sends iš

following the request. Under HTML 4, thk  GE  element is considered deprecated;

however, it is still the default value when this method is unspecified. When using ¾

mailtf  ACTION  value, be sure to set thk  METHO¤  tf  POS  ì

NAME  This attribute is used to provide a name for the form for manipulation from ¾

scripting language. While the HTML 4.0 specification may prefer thk  I¤  attribute,

browsers—including Netscape 2 and 3—depend on the occurrence o“  NAM¨  tf

provide access to the form. Page authors looking to usk  I¤  instead should consideK

settiný  NAM¨  an™  I¤  to the same value. However, note that while many browsers wilR

handle this just fine, it is not allowed according to the specification, since thk  NAM¨

an™  I¤  attributes share namespace. This example is another one of thosk

specificatio™versu-practice problems so common on the Webì

STYLE  This attribute is used to specify an inline style rule for thk  <FORM  elementì

TARGET  This attribute is used to set the window or frame that should display an_

results returned by the form action. As with all fram[oriented extensions, values o“

_blank _parent _self  ,  ,  , an™  _top  have special meaning. When the value is not specified,

the form loads over itselfì

TITLE  This attribute is used to set advisory text for the form. The contents of thk

TITL¨  attribute might be rendered onscreen as a tool tip when the user’s mouse hover—

over the form or may simply act as a note to readers of the HTML textì  TITL¨  will alsf

benefit users of speech browsers or other alternative access media. The use of thk

TITL¨  attribute generally makes more sense for the individual form controls than foK

the form itselfì

Event Handler“

A variety of events can be associated with the form. HTML 4 define—  onsubmit  an™

onreset  as the primary events that correspond to the submission of the form and thk

resetting of the form’s fields to their defaults, respectively. Other events define™

includk  onclick ondblclick onkeydown onkeypres—onkeyup onmousedown  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

onmousemov2 onmouseout onmouseove( onmouseup onreset  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  onsubmit  ì

Microsoft Internet Explorer 4 also support—  ondragstart onhelp  ,  , an™  onselectstart  a—

events for a form. A more detailed discussion of how events are used with forms i—

presented later in the section “Forms and Events.”

 = Page 440 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  419

Form Control“

A form is made up of fields or controls, as well as the markup necessary to structurk

the form and control its presentation. The controls are the items filled in oK

manipulated by the user to indicate the state of the form. Form controls include texš

fields, password fields, multipl[line text fields, pošup menus, scrolled lists, radif

buttons, check boxes, and buttons. Hidden form controls are also possible. The mosš

common element used to specify a form control is thk  <INPUT  element. However,

<SELECT  , in conjunction with thk  <OPTION  element and thk  <TEXTAREA

elements, is also common in forms. Rather than discuss the syntax of the particulaK

elements, let’s first approach learning forms by exploring the form controls, and the-

look at the complete syntax for the elements. This discussion only covers basic for“

controls. Newer form items, represented b_  <BUTTON <LABEL <FIELDSET  ,  ,  ,

an™  <LEGEND  , are discussed in the section “New and Emerging Form Elements,

later in this chapter.”

Text Control“

Text controls are form fields, generally one line long, that take text input like ¾  PROGRAMMING

person’s name and address, and other information. These fields are specified with thk  AND HTM¤

<INPUT  element, but it is possible to specify a multipl[line text field using thk

<TEXTAREA  elementì

Simple Text Entr

The simplest type of form control is the text entry type. To set a text entry control, usk

thk  <INPUT  element and set thk  TYP¨  attribute equal tf  TEX  :

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="CustomerName"L

All form elements should be namedì  NAME="CustomerName"  is used to create a texš

field to collect a customer’s name on an order formì

This example creates a on[line text entry field that will be associated with thk

namk  CustomerNam2  :

 = Page 441 =

420  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Remember to pick a name that makes sense and is unique to the form. The namk

will be used when the form is submitted, as well as for manipulation by scriptiný

languagesì

The last example does not specify the size of the field or the maximum number o“

characters that can be entered into the field. By default, unless specified, this fiel™

generally will be a width of 20 characters. To set the size of the field in characters, usk

thk  SIZ¨  attribute. For example,

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="CustomerName" SIZE="40"L

The value of thk  SIZ¨  field for a-  <INPUT  element is the number of characters tf

be displayed. It is possible for the user to type more characters than this value. The texš

will just scroll by. If you want to limit the size of the field, you need to set the value o“

thk  MAXLENGTh  attribute to the maximum number of characters allowed in thk

field. The browser will prevent the user from typing more than the number o“

characters specified. Browser feedback may include beeping or may just overstrike thk

last character. To set a text field that shows 30 characters but has a maximum of 60

characters that can be entered, use something likk

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="CustomerName" SIZE="30" MAXLENGTH="60"L

The last attribute that is useful to set with a text entry field is thk  VALU¨  attributeì

With this attribute, you can specify the default text you want to appear in the fiel™

when the form is first loaded. For example, in the following code fragment, a value o“

"Enter your name here"  is provided as a prompt to the user to fill in the field properly:

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="CustomerName" SIZE="30" MAXLENGTH="60h

VALUE="Enter your name here"L

A very simple example of the basic text field type is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Text Field Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Gadget Order For—  </H1L

<HRL

 = Page 442 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  42h

<FORM ACTION="http://www.bigcompany.com/cgi-bin/post-queryh

METHOD="POST"L

<BL  Customer Name:  </BL

<INPUT TYPE="texth

NAME="CustomerNameh

SIZE=5h

MAXLENGTH="35"L

</FORML

<HRL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Password Field“

The password style of form control is the same as the simple text entry field, excepš

that the input to the field is not revealed. In many cases, the browser may render eac—  PROGRAMMING

character as an asterisk or dot to avoid people seeing the password being entered, a—  AND HTM¤

shown here:

Not echoing the password onscreen is appropriate. It discourages the idea o“

“shoulder surfing,” where an unscrupulous user looks on your screen to see whaš

secret data you input. To set a password form control, use thk  <INPUT  element, buš

set thk  TYP¨  attribute equal tf  PASSWOR¤  . As with the text entry field, it is possiblk

to specify the size of the field in characters wit—  SIZ¨  , the maximum entry wit—

MAXLENGTh  in characters. In the case of the password control, it is probably wise tf

limit the length of the field so users don’t become confused about how many character—

they have enteredì

The password form is very similar to the singl[line text entry field. However,

setting a default value for the password field with thk  VALU¨  attribute doesn’t makk

 = Page 443 =

42p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

much sense since the user can see it by viewing the HTML source of the document. A

complete example of the password field’s use within the form is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Password Field Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Gadget Order For—  </H1L

<HRL

<FORM ACTION="http://www.bigcompany.com/cgi-bin/post-queryh

METHOD="POST"L

<BL  Customer Name:  </BL

<INPUT TYPE="texth

NAME="CustomerNameh

SIZE=5h

MAXLENGTH="35"L

<BRL

<BL  Customer ID:  </BL

<INPUT TYPE="PASSWORDh

NAME="CustomerIDh

SIZE="10h

MAXLENGTH="10"L

</FORML

<HRL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Multiple-Line Text Inpu

When it is necessary to enter more than one line of text in a form field, thk  <INPUT

element must be abandoned in favor of thk  <TEXTAREA  element. Like the text inpuš

field, there are similar attributes to control the size of the data entry area as well as thk

default value and the name of the control. For example, to set the number of rows i-

the text entry area, set thk  ROWS  attribute equal to the number of rows desired. To seš

the number of characters per line, set thk  COLS  attribute. So, to define a text area o“

five rows of 80 characters each, use the following:

 = Page 444 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  42

<TEXTAREA ROWS="5" COLS="80" NAME="CommentBox"L

</TEXTAREAL

Because there may be many lines of text within thk  <TEXTAREA  element, it is noš

possible to set the default text for the area using thk  VALU¨  attribute. Instead, plack

the default text between thk  <TEXTAREA  an™  </TEXTAREA  tags:

<TEXTAREA ROWS="5" COLS="80" NAME="CommentBox"L

Please fill in your comments here<

</TEXTAREAL

The information enclosed within thk  <TEXTAREA  element must be plain text an™

should not include any HTML markup. In fact, the contents of the element act like thk

<PRE  element by preserving spaces, returns, and other characters. HTML element—

entered within the form control will not be interpreted. A complete example of ¾

multipl[line text field is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L  PROGRAMMING

<HTMLL  AND HTM¤

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Multiple-line Text Field Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Gadget Order For—  </H1L

<HRL

<FORM ACTION="http//www.bigcompany.com/cgi-bin/post-queryh

METHOD="POST"L

<BL  Special Instructions:  </B><BRL

<TEXTAREA ROWS="10" COLS="40" NAME="Instructions"L

Enter any special gadget ordering instructions in this space<

</TEXTAREAL

</FORML

<HRL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

A rendering of the text area example is shown in Figure 1—2ì

 = Page 445 =

42  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 11-28  <TEXTAREA>  element rendering under Internet Explore

Netscape supports a speciaR  WRAL  attribute for thk  <TEXTAREA  element. Thk

values for this attribute ark  OFF HAR¤  ,  , an™  SOF  . A value o“  OFF  disables wor™

wrapping in the form control. Any text users enter is displayed exactly as is, thoug—

users may insert hard returns of their own. A value o“  HAR¤  allows word wrapping,

and the actual break points are included when the form is submitted. A value o“  SOF

allows word wrapping in the form control, but the line breaks are not sent with thk

form’s contents. A value o“  SOF  is the default, and this mimics how other browser—

deal with thk  <TEXTAREA  element. These are the only unique attributes foK

<TEXTAREA  ; but, like most elements under HTML 4,  <TEXTAREA  also support—

I¤ CLASS STYL¨ TITL¨ LAN… DI  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , and a multitude of event handler attribute—

likk  onclick  . See Appendix A for more information about these. Thk  <TEXTAREA

element has three important accessibility attributes—  DISABLE¤ TABINDEX  ,  , an™

 = Page 446 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  42

READONL  —which are described in the section “Form Accessibility Enhancements,”

later in this chapterì

Pull-Down Menu“

HTML form controls include pul_down menus. A pul_down menu lets the user selecš

one choice out of many possible choices. One nice aspect of pul_down menus is that alR

choices do not have to be seen on the screen and are normally hidden. The followiný

illustration shows the rendering of a pul_down menu under different browsers:

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

To create a pul_down menu, use thk  <SELECT  element. This element musš

include both a start and an end tag. It should only contain zero or more occurrences o“

thk  <OPTION  element. Thk  <OPTION  elements specify the actual choices on thk

menu, and generally do not use a close tag (similar to how thk  <LI  element is used)ì

In many ways, the structure of a pul_down menu looks similar to a list structure, a—

shown in the following code fragment:

<SELECT NAME="GadgetType"L

<OPTIONL  Super GadgeM

<OPTIONL  Mega GadgeM

<OPTIONL  Mongo GadgeM

<OPTIONL  Plain GadgeM

</SELECTL

 = Page 447 =

42‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

As shown in the code fragment, like all form controls, thk  <SELECT  element has ¾

NAM¨  attribute that is used to set a unique name for the control for purposes o“

decoding the user selection. It is also possible to set attributes for thk  <OPTION

element. An occurrence of the attributk  SELECTE¤  in thk  <OPTION  element sets thk

form control to select this item by default. If no value is selected, typically the fiel™

remains undefined. Some user agents may preselect the first item specified with thk

<OPTION  element. Normally, the value submitted when the form is sent is the valuk

enclosed by thk  <OPTION  element. However, it is possible to set thk  VALU¨

attribute for the element that will be returned instead. This might be important whe-

the user has different names for items than “official” names. A complete example of ¾

simple pul_down menu is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Pull-down Menu Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Gadget Order For—  </H1L

<FORM ACTION="mailto:test@bigcompany.com" METHOD="POST"L

<BL  Gadget Type:  </BL

<SELECT NAME="GadgetType"L

<OPTION VALUE="SG-01"L  Super GadgeM

<OPTION VALUE="MEG-G5"L  Mega GadgeM

<OPTION VALUE="MO-45"L  Mongo GadgeM

<OPTION SELECTEDL  GadgeM

</SELECTL

</FORML

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Scrolled List“

Thk  <SELECT  element also may contain thk  SIZ¨  attribute, which is used to specif_

the number of items showing on the screen at once. The default value for this attributk

is 1, which specifies a normal pul_down menu. Setting a positive number creates a lisš

in a window of the specified number of rows, as shown here:

 = Page 448 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  42

In many cases, scrolled lists act just like pul_down menus. However, if thk

<SELECT  element contains the attributk  MULTIPL¨  , it becomes possible to selecš

more than one entry. How multiple items are selected depends on the browser; but,

PROGRAMMING

generally, it requires holding down some modifier key such a—  AL¾ COMMAND  ,  , oK  SHIF¾

AND HTM¤

and selecting the appropriate items with the mouseì

Many novice users have a hard time with the scrolled list control and multiple entries.

Depending on your target audience, it might be wise to provide instructions near th—

control to assist the user.

Because it is possible to select more than one entry in a scrolled list when thk

multiple option is applied, it is then possible to use thk  SELECTE¤  attribute multiplk

times in the enclose™  <OPTION  elements. A complete example illustrating how thk

scrolled list is used is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Scrolled List Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Gadget Order For—  </H1L

<FORM ACTION="mailto:order@bigcompany.com" METHOD="POST"L

 = Page 449 =

428  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<BL  Gadget Options:  </BL

<SELECT NAME="GadgetOptions" MULTIPLE SIZE="3"L

<OPTION VALUE="Hit with hammer" SELECTEDL  Bump?

<OPTION VALUE="Add glitter"L  Sparkle?

<OPTION VALUE="Buff it"L  Polished

<OPTION SELECTEDL  Scratche?

<OPTIONL  Shrink wrapped

</SELECTL

</FORML

<HRL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Check Boxe“

With the scrolled list, it is possible to select many items out of a large group of itemsì

Unfortunately, not all the items are presented at once for the user to choose. If there ark

a few options to select from that are not mutually exclusive, it is probably better to usk

a group of check boxes that the user can check off. Check boxes are best used to togglk

choices on and off. While it is possible to have multiple numbers of check boxes and leš

the user select as many as he or she wants, if there are too many it may be difficult tf

deal with. Don’t forget about scrolled listsì

To create a check box, use thk  <INPUT  element and set thk  TYP¨  attribute equaR

tf  CHECKBOX  . The check box should also be named by setting thk  NAM¨  attributeì

For example, to create a check box asking if a user wants cheese, use some markup likk

Cheese:  <INPUT TYPE="CHECKBOX" NAME="Cheese"L

In this example, the label to the left is arbitrary. It could be to the right as well. Thk

label could say “Put cheese on it,” but there will be no indication to the receiviný

program of this label. In this simple example, if the check box is selected, a value o“

Cheese=on  will be transmitted to the server. Setting a value for the check box mighš

make more sense. Values to be transmitted instead of the default value can be set wit—

thk  VALU¨  attribute. The codk

Cheese:  <INPUT TYPE="Checkbox" NAME="Extras" VALUE="Cheese"L

would send a response likk  Extras=Chees2  to the server. It is also possible to havk

multiple check box controls with the same name. The codk

 = Page 450 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  429

Cheese:  <INPUT TYPE="CHECKBOX"  NAME="Extras" VALUE="Cheese"L

Pickles:  <INPUT TYPE="CHECKBOX"  NAME="Extras" VALUE="Pickles"L

would send multiple entries like the following to the server when both extras werk

selected:

Extras=Cheese&Extras=Pickel?

It is possible to set a check box to be selected by default by using thk  CHECKE¤

attribute within thk  <INPUT  element. Thk  CHECKE¤  attribute requires no value. A

complete example using check box controls is shown here:

<!DOCTYPc HTMX PUBLIL "-//W3C//DT— HTMX 4. Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Check Bov Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

PROGRAMMING

<BODYL  AND HTM¤

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  GadgeM OrdeI For—  </H1L

<HRL

<FORV ACTION="mailto:order@bigcompany.comh METHOD="POST"L

<BL  GadgeM Bonu? Options:  </BL

<BRL

Super-magneto:

<INPU. TYPE="CHECKBOXh NAME="BONUSh VALUE="Magnetize"L

<BRL

Kryptonit4 Coating:

<INPU. TYPE="CHECKBOXh NAME="BONUSh VALUE="Anti-Supermanh CHECKEDL

<BRL

Anti-gravity:

<INPU. TYPE="CHECKBOXh NAME="BONUSh VALUE="Anti-grÆity"L

Radio Button“

Radio buttons use a similar notation to check boxes, but only one option may be chose-

among many. This is an especially good option for choices that don’t make sense whe-

selected together. In this sense, radio buttons are like pul_down menus that allow onl_

one choice. The main difference is that all options are shown at once with radif

buttonsì

Like check boxes, this form control uses the standar™  <INPUT TYPE=""  formatì

In this case, seš  TYP¨  equal tf  RADI  . Setting thk  NAM¨  field is very importanš

in the case of radio buttons because it groups together controls that share the radif

functionality. The radio functionality says that when an item is selected, it deselect—

the previously pressed item. If the names are different for each radio button, thk

functionality becomes that of a check box, but with a different shape. Possiblk

renderings of the radio button form control are shown here:

Another important attribute i—  VALU¨  . It is important to set each individual radif

button to a different value entry. Otherwise, it will be impossible to decipher whic—

button was selected. Like check boxes, the occurrence of thk  SELECTE¤  attribute i-

thk  <INPUT  element will preselect the item. Only one item may be selected as ¾

default out of a radio group. If thk  SELECTE¤  attribute does not occur, the browseK

typically will not display any items as selected. A complete example using radif

buttons is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Radio Button Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Gadget Order For—  </H1L

<HRL

 = Page 452 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  43h

<FORM ACTION="mailto:order@bigcompany.com" METHOD="POST"L

<BL  Gadget Color:  </B><BRL

Groovy Green:  <INPUT TYPE="RADIO" NAME="Color" VALUE="Green"L

Rocket Red:  <INPUT TYPE="RADIO" NAME="Color" VALUE="Red" CHECKEDL

Yipee! Yellow:  <INPUT TYPE="RADIO" NAME="Color" VALUE="Yellow"L

</FORML

<HRL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Reset and Submit Button“

Once a form has been filled in, there must be a way to send it on its way, whether it i—

submitted to a program for processing or simply mailed to an [mail address. Thk

<INPUT  element has two values,  RESE  an™  SUBMI  , for thk  TYP¨  attribute; thesk

can create common buttons that are useful for just about any form. Setting thk  TYP¨  PROGRAMMING

attribute for thk  <INPUT  element tf  RESE  creates a button that allows the user tf  AND HTM¤

clear or set to default all the form controls at once. Setting thk  TYP¨  attribute foK

<INPUT  tf  SUBMI  creates a button that triggers the browser to send the contents o“

the form to the address specified in thk  ACTION  attribute of thk  <FORM  elementì

Common renderings of thk  SUBMI  an™  RESE  form controls are shown here:

The buttons themselves take two basic attributes:  VALU¨  an™  NAM¨  . Thk  VALU¨

attribute sets both the value of the button when pressed and the wording of the buttonì

Thk  NAM¨  value associates an identifier with the form control. A complete examplk

showing a small form with submit and reset buttons is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

 = Page 453 =

43p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<TITLEL  Complete Form Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Gadget Order For—  </H1L

<HRL

<FORM ACTION="mailto:order@bigcompany.comh

METHOD="POST" ENCTYPE="text/plain"L

<BL  Customer Name:  </BL

<INPUT TYPE="TEXTh

NAME="CustomerNameh

SIZE=5h

MAXLENGTH="35"L

<BR><BRL

<BL  Customer ID:  </BL

<INPUT TYPE="PASSWORDh

NAME="CustomerIDh

SIZE="10h

MAXLENGTH="10"L

<BR><BRL

<BL  Gadget Type:  </BL

<SELECT NAME="GadgetType"L

<OPTION VALUE="SG-01"L  Super GadgeM

<OPTION VALUE="MEG-G5"L  Mega GadgeM

<OPTION VALUE="MO-45"L  Mongo GadgeM

<OPTION SELECTEDL  GadgeM

</SELECTL

<BR><BRL

<INPUT TYPE="SUBMIT" VALUE="Order Gadget" NAME="SubmitButton"L

<INPUT TYPE="RESET" VALUE="Reset Form" NAME="ResetButton"L

</FORML

<HRL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 454 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  43

Because the submit and reset buttons cause an action, either form submission oK

field reset, it would not seem obvious why thk  VALU¨  oK  NAM¨  field might be usefulì

While having multiple reset buttons might not be useful, multiple submit buttons ark

useful because the value of the button is sent to the address specified in thk  <FORM

element’—  ACTION  attribute. One possible use might be to have three submit buttons:

one for add, one for delete, and one for updateì

<INPUT TYPE="SUBMIT" VALUE="Place Order" NAME="Add"L

<INPUT TYPE="SUBMIT" VALUE="Delete Order" NAME="Delete"L

<INPUT TYPE="SUBMIT" VALUE="Update Order" NAME="Update"L

<INPUT TYPE="RESET" VALUE="Reset Form" NAME="ResetButton"L

When the form is submitted, the value of the button is sent to the forRhandliný

program, which will decide what to do with the submitted data based upon it—

contents. This use of a submit button hints at a more generalized form of button, whic—

is discussed in the next sectionì

If you have two buttons next to each other, it is useful to separate the two with  PROGRAMMING

nonbreaking spaces (  &nbsp;  ). Otherwise, the buttons will probably render too closely  AND HTM¤

together. Another approach would be to use a small table around the buttons and provid—

some cell padding or a blank cell between the buttons.

Additional <INPUT> Type“

There are a few forms of thk  <INPUT  element that have not been discussed. Thesk

form elements hint at the potential complexity of using forms. Some of these elements,

particularly the file selection form element, are not supported in older browsersì

Hidden Text and Its Use“

The usefulness of this form control is not always obvious to the new user. By settiný

thk  TYP¨  attribute of thk  <INPUT  element to a value o“  HIDDEN  , it is possible tf

transmit default or previously specified text that is hidden from the user to thk

handling program. If there were many versions of the same form all over a Web site,

then the hidden text could be used to specify where the form came from, as shown i-

this example:

<INPUT TYPE="hidden" NAME="SubmittingFormName" VALUE="Form1"L

Because this field is not shown on the page, it is impossible for the user to modify itì

Thus, it must have it—  VALU¨  attribute set. While this last example seems ratheK

contrived, there is actually a very important use for hidden form controlsì

 = Page 455 =

43  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Whe- filliný i- forms, therk i— ofte- a- issuk o“ rememberiný informatio- fro“ onk

for“ tf thk nextì Imagink ¾ for“ i- whic— thk useK fill— i- hi— oK heK personaR informatio-

o- onk pagk an™ thk orderiný informatio- o- thk nexš pageì Hou uilR thk twf page— bk

relate™ tf eac— other? Thi— present— thk stat[los— problemì Thk protocol— o“ thk Web,

primaril_ HTTP, df noš supporš ¾ “memory.” I- otheK words, the_ don’š preservk stateì

personaR informatio- i— passe™ tf thk nexš pagk b_ dynamicall_ embeddiný iš i- thk

Image Typs

One form of thk  <INPUT  element that is somewhat strange is the image type, a—

specified by settiný  TYPE="IMAGE"  . This form o“  <INPUT  creates a graphicaR

version of the submit button, which not only submits the form but transmits coordinatk

information about where the user clicked in the image. The image is specified by thk

SR‚  attribute. Many of the attributes used for thk  <IMG  element may be valid foK

this form o“  <INPUT  as well. The specification define—  AL  an™  ALIGN  . OtheK

attributes likk  BORDE HSPAC¨  ,  , oK  VSPAC¨  may or may not be supported b_

browsers. Like all other forms o“  <INPUT  , thk  NAM¨  attribute is a very importanš

part of how the coordinate information is transmitted. The example use o“  <INPUT

shown next could be used to insert a map of the United States, allowing users to click

the regional office in which they want to submit their order formsì

<INPUT TYPE="IMAGE" SRC="usamap.gif" NAME="Salesh

ALT="Sales Region Map"L

Whe- clicked, thk for“ value— woul™ bk submitted, aloný wit— twf extr¾ values,

PROGRAMMING

Sales/  x  an™  Sales/ Sales/  y  ì  x  an™  Sales/  y  woul™ bk seš equaR tf thkan™ coordinate— o“  x  y

AND HTM¤

wherk thk imagk wa— clickedì Thk an™ coordinate— ark relativk tf thk imagk wit— a-  x  y

origi- i- thk uppeK lefâhan™ corneK o“ thk imageì Yo¾ ma_ notick ¾ similarit_ tf imagk

mapsì Indeed, muc— o“ thk functionalit_ o“ thi— for“ controR coul™ bk imitate™ wit— ¾

clienâsidk imagk ma5 i- conjunctio- wit— somk scriptiný codeì A futurk extensio- tf thi—

File Form Control

A recent addition to thk  <INPUT  element that is now part of the HTML 4.0

specification is the possibility of setting thk  TYP¨  attribute tf  FIL¨  . This form control i—

used for file uploading. The field generally consists of a text entry box for a filenamk

that can be manipulated with thk  SIZ¨  an™  MAXLENGTh  attributes, as well as ¾

button immediately to the right of the field, which is usually labeled Browse. Pressiný

the Browse button allows the user to browse the local system to find a file to specify foK

upload. The logistics of how a file is selected depend on the user agentì

Following is an example of the file form control syntax, in which thk  ENCTYP¨

value has been set tf  multipart/form-dat  to allow the file to be attached to thk

uploaded form:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

 = Page 457 =

43‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<TITLEL  File Upload TesM  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER">File Upload System</H1L

<HRL

<FORM ACTION="http://www.bigcompany.com/cgi-bin/uploadfile.plh

METHOD="POST" ENCTYPE="mutipart/form-data"L

<BL  File Description:  </B><BRL

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="Description" SIZE="50h

MAXLENGTH="100"><BRL

<BL  Specify File to Post:  </B><BRL

<INPUT TYPE="FILE" NAME="FileName"L

<BR><BRL

<HRL

<DIV ALIGN="center"L

<INPUT TYPE="SUBMIT" NAME="Submit" VALUE="Send it"L

</DIVL

</FORML

</BODYL

</HTMLL

A rendering of the file upload example showing the browsing mechanism is give-

in Figure 1—4ì

While it is possible to set thk  SIZ¨  an™  MAXLENGTh  values of the file entry box,

this is not suggested, since the path name may be larger than the size specified. (Thi—

depends on how the user has set up his or her system.) The file form control is noš

supported by all browsers. HTML 4 also specifies thk  ACCEP  attribute for thk

<INPUT TYPE="FILE"  element, which can be used to specify a commDseparated lisš

of MIME types that the server receiving the contents of the form will know how tf

handle properly. Browsers could use this attribute to keep users from uploading file—

that are unacceptable to a server (for example, executable files). It is not known i“

browsers actually pay any attention to this attributeì

 = Page 458 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  43

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Figurs 11-48  File form control rendering with browsing mechanis‘

Generalized Button“

One last form of thk  <INPUT  element, hinted at earlier, is the generalized button. B_

usiný  <INPUT TYPE="BUTTON"  , it is possible to create a button in the style of thk

submit or reset buttons that, unlike the submit or reset buttons, has no predetermine™

actions. Inserting something like the following doesn’t really do much:

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" VALUE="Press Me!" NAME="mybutton"L

If you click the rendering of this button, no action is triggered, and no value will bk

submitted. So what’s the point? By using a scripting language, it is possible to tie a-

event to the button and create an action. At the end of this chapter, as well as i-

Chapter 13, you’ll see how forms can be tied to scripting languages to create powerfuR

interactive documentsì

 = Page 459 =

438  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

New and Emerging Form Element“

At the time of this writing, the W3C has proposed adding several forRrelated tags an™

attributes to the next version of HTML. These are intended to address limitations in thk

current forms and to make them more interactive. Microsoft has already implemente™

several of these proposed extensions in Internet Explorer 4ì

<BUTTON> Elemen

This element provides a way to add generic buttons to forms. The text enclosed by thk

tags is the button’s label. In its simplest usage, thk  <BUTTON  element is functionall_

equivalent tf  <INPUT TYPE="BUTTON"  , which is not supported by the officiaR

HTML 3.2 definition. In newer browsers like Internet Explorer 4 that support bot—

button forms, the following two statements render identicallyì

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" VALUE="Press Me"L

<BUTTONL  Press M4  </BUTTONL

Thk  <BUTTON  usage is more versatile because its content can include mosš

inline and block-level elements. The following example illustrates a button elemenš

containing text, an embedded image, and the use of a cascading style sheet rule tf

change the background and text colorì

<BUTTON NAME="HomePage" VALUE="Test Buttonh

STYLE="{background-color:blue; color:yellow}"L

<IMG SRC="images/logonotext.gif" WIDTH="141" HEIGHT="197"L

<BRL  BigCompany Home Pag4

</BUTTONL

What is interesting about this element is that the browser should render the butto-

in a relief style and even present a pushing effect, just like a submit or reset button, so iš

is not quite the same a—  <INPUT TYPE="IMAGE"  . Another key difference betwee-

the image button previously described and the neu  <BUTTON  element is that thk

new element does not submit any coordinate information, nor is it strictly a submiš

button. In fact, it is possible to tie this style of button to a general action using thk  TYP¨

attribute. Allowed values for this attribute ark  BUTTON  (default),  SUBMI  , an™

RESE  . The HTML 4.0 documentation suggests thaš  SUBMI  is the default value, buš

this does not make sense, nor is it supported by the browsers that understand thk

<BUTTON  elementì

It is incorrect to associate an image map with any image enclosed by ‘

<BUTTONA  element.

 = Page 460 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  439

While thk  <BUTTON  element seems a more generalized way to deal with image—

as form buttons, it is not widely supported yet—only by Internet Explorer 4. OldeK

browsers may require an alternative approachì

Label“

Another new form element introduced in HTML 4 and supported by advance™

browsers is thk  <LABEL  element. One motivation for this tag is to better supporš

speecubased browsers that can read descriptions next to form fields. However, a mork

common use of thk  <LABEL  element is to associate the labeling text of form control—

with the actual controls they describeì

Thk  <LABEL  element can be associated with a form control by enclosing it a—

shown here:

<LABELL  First Name:

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="FirstName" SIZE=0" MAXLENGTH="30"L

</LABELL

PROGRAMMING

A  <LABEL  element can also be associated with a control by referring to thk

AND HTM¤

control’—  I¤  with thk  FO  attribute. In this usage, the label does not need to enclose thk

control. This allows labels to be positioned in tables with their own cells. It is commo-

to use tables to make bette§looking forms. Far too often, form elements snake down ¾

page and are not aligned very well. The following code fragment illustrates how thk

<LABEL  element with thk  FO  attribute would be usedì

<TABLEL

<TRL

<TD ALIGN="RIGHT"L

<LABEL FOR="CustName"L  Customer Name :  </LABELL

<TD ALIGN="LEFT"L

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" ID="CustName" SIZE=5" MAXLENGTH="35"L

</TRL

</TABLEL

Thk  <LABEL  element also supports thk  I¤ CLASS STYL¨ TITL¨ LAN…  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™

DI  attributes, as well as numerous event handlers. These are used in the same way a—

on any other HTML element. Thk  DISABLE¤  an™  ACCESSKE  are also supporte™

attributes for this element and are discussed further in the section on form accessibilit_

enhancements, later in the chapterì

<FIELDSET>

This proposed element groups related form elements similar to the way thk  <DIV

element groups general body content. Likk  <DIV  , thk  <FIELDSET  element can bk

 = Page 461 =

440  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

nested; it can also have an associate™  <LEGEND  element to describe the enclose™

items. Thk  <FIELDSET  element itself has no special attributes besides those commo-

to all elements, likk  I¤ CLASS LAN… DI TITL¨ STYL¨  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , and event handlersì

However, thk  <LEGEND  element does support thk  ALIGN  attribute, which can bk

used to specify where the description will be rendered in relation to the group of for“

items; its values ark  TOL  (the default value),  BOTTOV LEF  ,  , oK  RIGH  . In additio-

tf  ALIGN <FIELDSET  ,  supports the common attributes to most elements undeK

HTML 4—  I¤ CLASS STYL¨ TITL¨ LAN… DI  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , and the numerous event handlersì

See the element reference in Appendix A for more information about these. Thk

example shown here illustrates how thk  <FIELDSET  an™  <LEGEND  element—

are used:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Fieldset and Legend Exampl4  </TITLEL

</HEADL

Form Accessibility Enhancement“

One of the most important changes made to forms under HTML 4 is the improve™

support for accessibility. HTML 4 defines thk  ACCESSKE  attribute for thk  <LABEL  ,

<INPUT <BUTTON  ,  , an™  <LEGEND  elements. Setting the value of the key to ¾

character creates an accelerator key that can activate the form control associated wit—

the element. Generally, the key must be pressed in combination with thk  CONTROL AL¾  ,  ,

oK  OPTíN  key in order to activate the field. An example of how this attribute might bk

used is shown in the following code example:

<LABEL ACCESSKEY="N"L  CustomeI  <UL </UL  N  ame:

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" ID="CustName" SIZE=5"L

</LABELL

Notice how thk  <U  element is used to highlight the letter that will activate the fieldì

This is the common practice to indicate accelerator keys in a Windows GUI. Accordiný

to the HTML 4.0 specification, browsers should provide their own form of highlightiný

for an access key, but in practice this isn’t very commonì

The HTML 4.0 standard defines thk  ACCESSKE  attribute for thk  <LABEL  ,

<INPUT <LEGEND  ,  , an™  <BUTTON  elements, though it leaves off support foK

 = Page 463 =

44p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<SELECT  an™  <TEXTAREA  . Microsoft supports this attribute for thk  <SELECT

an™  <TEXTAREA  elements. It seems likely that this will eventually be rolled into thk

final HTML 4.0 specificationì

While thk  ACCESSKE  attribute can improve a form by making it more keyboar™

access friendly, there are certain letters to avoid because they map to browser function—

in the two major browsers, as shown in Table 1—1ì

Another accessibility improvement introduced in HTML 4 is the use of thk

TABINDEX  attribute for thk  <INPUT <SELECT <TEXTAREA  ,  ,  , an™  <BUTTON

elements. This attribute allows the tab order between fields to be defined. In thk

Microsoft implementation, elements wit—  TABINDEX  values greater than zero ark

selected in increasing order. Generally, if a browser supports tabbing through for“

fields it is by the order in which they are defined. However, with thk  TABINDEX  seš

the tabbing order goes from the lowest positivk  TABINDEX  value to the highest. An_

elements with ¾  TABINDEX  o“ are selected in the order they are encountered afteK  0

the rest of the tabbing controls have been exhausted. Fields with negativk  TABINDEX

values should be left out of the tabbing order. So, in the next fragment, the last fiel™

gets selected first and then the first, and the second field is completely skipped overì

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="First Name" TABINDEX="L

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="Middle Name" TABINDEX="-1"L

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="Last Name" TABINDEX="1"L

Ke  Mapping  Note“

F  File men¾

E  Edit men¾

C  Communicator men¾  Netscape CommunicatoK

onl_

V  View men¾

G  Go men¾

A  Favorites men¾  Internet Explorer onl_

õ  Hel5

LEFT ARROW  Back in histor_

RIGHT ARROW  Forward in histor_

Tabls 11-18  Reserved Browser Key Binding9

 = Page 464 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  44

Be careful when setting thk  TABINDEX  value with radio buttons, as the browseK

may use arrow keys to move among a group of radio buttons rather than thk  TAB  keyì

Page designers are encouraged to seš  ACCESSKE  an™  TABINDEX  attributes tf

their documents immediately as they will have no harmful side effects in oldeK

browsers and will simply be ignoredì

Miscellaneous HTML 4 Form Attribute“

The HTML 4.0 specification also adds two other attributes to certain form controls:

DISABLE¤  an™  READONL  . When thk  DISABLE¤  attribute is present in a for“

control element, it turns off the field. Disabled elements will not be submitted, nor ma_

they receive any focus from the keyboard or mouse. The browser may also gray out thk

disabled form. The point of thk  DISABLE¤  attribute might not be obvious, buš

imagine being able to disable the form submission button until the appropriate field—

have been filled in. Of course, being able to dynamically turn thk  DISABLE¤  attributk

for a form control on or off implies scripting support that not all browsers haveì

When thk  READONL  attribute is present in a form control element, it prevent—

the control’s value from being changed. A form control set tf  READONL  can bk

PROGRAMMING

selected by the user but cannot be changed. Selection may even include the inclusion o“

AND HTM¤

the form control in the tabbing order. Unlike disabled controls, the values of reaÙonl_

controls are submitted with the form. In some sense, a reaÙonly form control can bk

thought of as a visible form o“  <INPUT TYPE="HIDDEN"  . According to the HTML

4.0 specification, thk  READONL  attribute is defined for the element—  <INPU

TYPE="TEXT" <INPUT TYPE="PASSWORD"  ,  , an™  <TEXTAREA  , but somk

browser vendors may also support thk  <SELECT  element or even check boxes. Likk

a disabled form control, reaÙonly controls can only be changed through the use o“

a scriptì

Form Presentatio

Up to this point, most of the form elements in the HTML 4.0 specification, as welR

as those supported by the major browsers, have been presented. Some speciaR

considerations for the WebTV environment will be considered in a moment. However,

let’s first turn our attention to making forms more presentable. Unfortunately, on thk

Web, little attention seems to be paid to making logical or even presentabl[lookiný

forms. For example, take a look at the form in Figure 1—6. Notice that nothing i—

grouped or lined upì

Form designers are reminded that other HTML markup elements can be use™

within forms, so there is no excuse for having a poorly laiÙout form. For example, ¾

form can be vastly improved by using a table, as shown in Figure 1—7ì

 = Page 465 =

Besides laying out a form with tables, it might be nice to use thk  <FIELDSET

element to group and box form controls. However, until this element is widel_

supported, it should not be relied on. Tables should be used instead. Adding a lighš

background color to the different sections of the table could help improve thk

organization of the form as wellì

Page authors might wonder if it is possible to improve the look and feel of form—

using style sheets. Under the HTML 4.0 specification, both thk  <FORM  element an™

the form control elements support thk  CLASS I¤  ,  , an™  STYL¨  attributes to allou

access from style sheets. For backward compatibility, particularly with scriptiný

environments, they also support thk  NAM¨  attribute. One interesting aspect of form—

and style sheets is that style rules applied to thk  <FORM  element do not seem to bk

inherited by controls inside the form. This is contrary to the normal case, in which stylk

specifications are inherited by contained elements. In other words, the text insidk

<INPUT  control in the following example will appear as black, not red, when viewe™

in a browserì

<FORM STYLE="{color:red}"L

This text is red<

PROGRAMMING

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" VALUE="but this text is black"L

AND HTM¤

</FORML

In theory, style sheets should be well supported in forms. In practice, supporš

varies widely from browser to browser. Under Internet Explorer 4, thk  CLASS I¤  ,  , an™

STYL¨  attributes work foK  <FORM <INPUT  ,  , an™  <SELECT  . Under Netscape 4

and above, style specifications are not very well supported. The following examplk

demonstrates some of Netscape 4’s shortcomingsì

<FORM STYLE="{color:red}"L

This text is red<

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" VALUE="but this text is blueh

STYLE="font-family: Arial; color: blue;

font-size: 12px; background: lightblue"L

<BR><BRL

<INPUT VALUE="Submit" TYPE="Submit" STYLE="color: white;

background: green; font-style;

bold; font-size:p2px"L

</FORML

Under Internet Explorer 4 and above, all of the style information is displayed,

including blue 12-pixel Arial text against a light blue background in the input fiel™

and large bold white text on a green button. Netscape 4 and above will render thk

 = Page 469 =

448  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

fonâfamily and fonâsize information properly, but all of the color and backgroun™

information in this and the previous example are ignored. Many of these problems ark

bugs or oversights; but, until these issues are cleared up for commonly used browsers,

page authors should carefully explore the use of style sheets with form elements befork

using themì

Special Form Considerations for WebTV

The WebTV browser introduces many attributes to form elements specifically designe™

to enhance TV-based interaction. This section covers some of these actions. For thk

latest extensions, visit the WebTV developer’s site at http://developer.webtv.netì

While thk  <FORM  element itself is not modified under WebTV, thk  <INPUT

element has many proprietary extensions. Because it is difficult to fill in forms usiný

the onscreen keyboard, WebTV provides some attributes that can be used to makk

form input a little easier. Because it may be difficult to see the text onscreen, you ca-

set the background color (  BGCOLO  ) as well as the cursor color (  CURSO  ) foK

individuaR  <INPUT TYPE="TEXT"  elements. WebTV has introduced many otheK

form extensions. The purpose here is only to illustrate that forms may present issue—

unique to the viewing environment. This makes extensions worthwhile. However, foK

the future, such presentational controls are better suited to style sheet developmentsì

Perhap—  "tv"  will become a valid media type for style sheetsì

Forms and Event“

As presented here, forms really don’t finish the job. It is easy to create a form that ask—

users for their names and the number of gadgets they want to order. It is also easy tf

write a CGI program (assuming you’re a programmer) that can take submitted for“

data and do something with it. However, it is not easy to make sure that the submitte™

data is correct. Why should you let the user enter a quantity of –10 (negative ten)

gadgets in the form and submit it when that is obviously wrong? Sure, the CGI coul™

catch this, but it’s best to try to catch this at the browser level before submitting thk

form for processing. This is one of the main reasons for clienâside scriptingì

Starting with Netscape 2 and continuing until today, it has been possible to use ¾

scripting language like JavaScript to associate scripts with use§generated events in ¾

browser. The way to handle events for a form control is by setting an event handleK

using an attribute that corresponds to the name of the event. If you want to trigger ¾

script when a button is pressed, you could insert some script code associated with thk

event attribute, as shown in the following dummy form:

<FORML

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" VALUE="Don't Press Me!h

onclick="alert('Danger! Danger!');"L

</FORML

 = Page 470 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  449

Events are added to form controls using attribute declarations such a—  onclick  ,

onsubmit onreset  ,  , and so on. The number of events has grown significantly and nou

applies to elements outside forms. In fact, under Dynamic HTML, the trend is for ever_

displayed HTML element to have events associated with it. Let’s look at a shorš

example of how forms may be validated using a small amount of scripting code an™

follow with an overview of the forRrelated events supported in current HTML

dialects. Chapters 13 and 14 provide more details on scripting in generalì

Already you have learned that one possible use of form events is to validate for“

data before it is sent in. In the following example, a form collects a customer name, ¾

customer identification value, and the quantity of gadgets requested. In this example,

all values should be entered and a positive number of gadgets ordered. To perform thi—

check, create a simple validation script that looks at the fields and prompts the user tf

fix any errors. The validation is triggered by the click of a generalized button. Whe-

everything checks out, the browser submits the formì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

PROGRAMMING

<TITLEL  Basic Form ValidatioY  </TITLEL

AND HTM¤

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

functionqalidate ()

{

if (document.forms.order.CustomerNamealue == "") {

alert("Please enter your name.")

return false;

}

if (document.forms.order.CustomerIDalue == "") {

alert("Please enter your Customer ID.")

return false;

}

if (document.forms.order.Qtyalue <= 0) {

alert("Please enter a positøe number of gadgets.")

return false;

}

return true;

}

// --L

 = Page 471 =

450  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="center"L  Gadget Order For—  </H1L

<HRL

<FORM NAME="order" METHOD="POSTh

ACTION="mailto:order@bigcompany.comh

onsubmit="returnqalidate()"L

<BL  Customer Name:  </BL

<INPUT TYPE="TEXTh

NAME="CustomerNameh

SIZE=5h

MAXLENGTH="35"L

<BR><BRL

<BL  Customer ID:  </BL

<INPUT TYPE="PASSWORDh

NAME="CustomerIDh

SIZE="8h

MAXLENGTH="9"L

<BR><BRL

<BL  Quantity of Gadgets:  </BL

<INPUT TYPE="TEXTh

NAME="Qtyh

SIZE=h

MAXLENGTH="L

<HRL

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTONh

VALUE="Orderh

onclick=¡alidate()"L

<INPUT TYPE="RESET" VALUE="Reset"L

</FORML

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 472 =

ChapteX 11  Basih Interactivity an HTML Form  45h

There are a few things to point out in this example. First, the form has bee-

assigned a name. Giving the form a name allows it to be referred to by name in thk

validation script. Another thing to notice is the use of thk  onclick  event attribute. Thi—

connects an event the button can respond to with a script to handle the eventì

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" VALUE="Order" onclick=¡alidate()"L

The value for thk  onclick  attribute is the name of the JavaScript function, define™

elsewhere, that validates the form. The validation function is declared in the documenš

head inside thk  <SCRIPT  element. Don’t worry if the scripting issues, particularly thk

events, don’t make complete sense. They are covered in great detail in Chapters 13

and 14ì

Summar

HTML forms provide a basic interface for adding interactivity to a Web site. HTML

supports traditional graphical user interface controls like check boxes, radio buttons,

PROGRAMMING

pul_down menus, scrolled lists, mult¾ and singl[line text areas, and buttons. Thesk

AND HTM¤

controls can be used to build a form that can be submitted via [mail to a serve§sidk

program for processing. While making a rudimentary form isn’t terribly difficult,

laying out the form is often overlooked. Using tables and improved groupiný

elements likk  <LABEL <FIELDSET  ,  , an™  <LEGEND  can improve a for“

dramatically. Other features new to HTML 4, such as accelerator keys and tabbiný

order specification, can also improve how a form may be used. Yet even if a nice for“

can be developed, it is missing the spark that makes it go. The logic of the form need—

to be added either by a serve§side program or through a clienâside technology likk

JavaScript. Until then, forms only provide a simple way to collect informationì

Introduction tW

Server-Sidf

45
