 = Page 475 =

45  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

he last chapter hinted at the move from static Web pages to a more dynami´

paradigm. The Web is undergoing a shift from a pag[oriented view of the worl™

to a more prograRoriented view. Although there is increased focus on thk

¾

programmed elements of a Web page, this doesn’t mean that HTML is going away an_

time soon. Knowing how to author wel_formed HTML documents may become mork

important than ever with the rise of Dynamic HTML. Yet, even before the rise o“

clienâside technologies, HTML has intersected with programming ideas. Serve§sidk

computing on the Web has often had an HTML flavor to it, particularly whe-

serve§side includes and parsed HTML solutions like Microsoft’s Active Server Page—

(ASP) or Allaire’s ColdFusion are involved. These technologies blur the lines betwee-

HTML and programming, because they appear in the form of special markup tags thaš

include information or perform programming tasksì These topics may not seem to bk

part of HTML and are not official in the standards sense, but they do illustrate hou

programming and HTML interactì

This chapter will examine the general concept of the programmed Web site an™

some of the technologies that can be used on the server side to add interactivity tf

Web pages. The next two chapters will continue the discussion, but with a focus o-

clienâside scripting technologies and object technologies, respectivelyì

Overview of Client/Server Programming

on the We—

When it comes right down to it, the Web is just a form of client/server interaction. WeD

browsers make requests of Web servers to do some processing or to return a file that i—

sent back and displayed in the browser. This basic idea is shown in Figure 12-1ì

In this basic printeÙpage idea of the Web, a Web server acts as a file server thaš

delivers HTML files to a Web browser. As shown in the last chapter, thinking about thk

Web as a digital paper medium is somewhat limiting and does not take advantage o“

the potential of interactivityì

The most basic form of interactivity on the Web, beyond link selection, is usiný

fil_out forms that are handled by programs, typically Common Gateway Interfack

(CGI) applications, running on a Web server. The way a user interacts with ¾

CGìbased Web site is easy to describe. First, the user requests a dynamic page or fill—

out a form to perform a task, such as ordering a product. The request is sent to the WeD

server, which runs the CGI program, which then outputs information to return to thk

Web browser, as shown in Figure 12-2ì

In this sense, the Web can be used to run programs on a remote server, which the-

returns a result. When described this way, the Web begins to look more and more like ¾

client/server application environmentì

 = Page 476 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  45

Figurs 12-18  Graphic representation of client/server relationshi—

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Thk diagra“ i- Figurk 12-2 suggest— twf questionsì First,wherk shoul™ thk computiný

happen? An™ second, usiný whaš technology? O- thk earl_ Web, thk browseK tende™ tf df

ver_ littlk computingì Iš wa— solel_ responsiblk foK renderinýf pages on the screen. Now,

with the rise of clienâside technologies like Java, ActiveX, JavaScript, and DHTML, it i—

possible to perform a great deal of computation from within the browser. Put all thk

pressure on the server, and it might bog down, or the user might get frustrated wit—

poor responsiveness. Doing most of the computing on the client might cause problem—

with compatibility, since it’s difficult to know what kinds of clients are out thereì

Figurs 12-28  Overview of basic CGI interactivitV

 = Page 477 =

45‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Security may also be a problem. The best solution is a mixture: some things are betteK

suited for the client; some are better suited for the serverì

As discussed in Chapter 11, it makes sense to use JavaScript to check the contents o“

a form before it is submitted to a CGI program, rather than have the CGI progra“

check the data. However, you would still want to check the data at the server side foK

users who are running older clients or who have turned off clienâside scripting. Thing—

can go wrong, and users don’t always have the best browser with all the right settingsì

And, of course, you would still want to check whether a malicious user has deliberatel_

sent the CGI bad data. A developer who wants to build a We~based application musš

choose where to host the logic of the program (client side or server side) and whic—

technology should be used to do it. The decision isn’t always obvious, as illustrated b_

the numerous choices in Table 12-1ì

What’s interesting about the numerous technologies available for WeD

programming is that developers often focus solely on one tool or one side of thk

equation (client or server) rather than thinking about how the applications they ark

trying to build are going to work. This chapter will look at the server side of thk

equation; subsequent chapters will focus on the client sideì

Client Sids  Server Sids

Helper—  CGI program—

Pluin—  NSAPI/ISAPI program—

Activ[X control—  Serve§side scriptiný

Java applet—  Serve§side include—

Scripting language—  Active Server page—

JavaScripš  Serve§side JavaScript (LiveWire)

VBScripš  Database middlewark

Dynamic HTML  ColdFusio-

Tabls 12-18  Web Programming Technology Choice9

 = Page 478 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  45

Server-Side Programming

When adding interactivity to a Web page, it often makes sense to add all functionalit_

on the server side. There are two basic reasons for doing this. First, the server side i—

the only part of the equation that can be completely controlled. If we only rely on thk

browser to render HTML pages, life is simple. If we assume users have JavaScript,

Java, or a particular pluin, things become less predictable. Why is this, given thaš

most modern browsers come with many of these technologies? There are too man_

variables and too many bugs. Users often turn off support for Java, JavaScript, oK

ActiveX due to fear of security breaches. Even when turned on, these technologies ark

often far from robust. For example, JavaScript comes in two basic flavors, Microsofš

and Netscape, and has more than three versions running on at least four majoK

operating systems (Mac, Windows 3.1, 95/NT, and UNIX). Each of thesk

implementations has some subtle and noâsksubtle differences, including featurk

disparity and bugs. It is no wonder we would want to move computation to the server,

where these issues are more controllableì

The second reason that serve§side computation makes sense is that the server i—

where much of the data required actually “lives.” Consider a database. A commo-

PROGRAMMING

requirement of the Web is to act as a front end to access a database. Imagine a Web sitk

AND HTM¤

where the user wants to query a system to see if a particular product is available. A

form could be developed for the user to submit the query. The contents of the for“

could be passed to a program on a Web server, which would parse the form data an™

produce a database query. Such a program is calle™  middlewar—  , because it sits betwee-

the back-end database server and the clienâaccessible Web server. A CGI program i—

one form of middleware. After the database completes the query, the result is passe™

back to the middleware, which formats the result as an HTML page and passes thk

result back to the browser. The Web server acts as the coordinator for this wholk

process, including interacting with and possibly even starting the middleware. Thi—

process is illustrated in Figure 12-3ì

One potential downside to adding interactivity via serve§side programs should bk

mentioned: too much reliance on the server. In the last examples, the browser wa—

relatively simple, because the computation took place almost entirely on the serveK

side. The client browser was only responsible for rendering the entry form and thk

resulting pages. Choosing the appropriate approach to deal with a problem likk

database access is beyond the scope of this book, but remember that there can bk

disadvantages to putting all the computing responsibility on the server—namely,

speed and scalability. For now, our discussion turns to the approaches to serve§base™

interactivity and how it intersects with HTMLì

 = Page 479 =

458  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 12-38  Database access via the We

CommonGateway Interface (CGI)

Probably the most common way to add interactivity to a Web page is through a CG§

programì  Common Gateway Interface (CGI)  is a protocol standard that specifies hou

information can be passed from a Web page via a Web server, to a program, and back

from the program to a browser in the proper format. Many people confuse the progra“

that does this with the CGI protocol. In reality, the program is just a program. It jusš

happens to be a CGI program since it was written to pass information back and fort—

using the CGI specificationì

The following steps summarize how CGI interacts with a form:

1ì The user submits a formì

2ì The form is sent to the server and eventually to the CGI program, using thk

following steps:

aì The server determines if the request is a document or program request b_

examining execution settings and pathì

bì The server locates the program (in the cg¾bin directory on the server oK

elsewhere) and determines if the program can be executedì

´ì Thk serveK start— thk progra“ an™ prepare— thk data, an™ an_ extr¾ informatio-

fro“ thk environment, tf bk senš tf thk progra“ fro“ thk for“ fieldsì

dì The program runsì

kì Thk serveK wait— foK thk progra“ tf produck outpuš (optional) an™ the- passe—

backthk properl_ formatte™ resulš tf thk clienš or, potentially, a- erroK messageì

3ì The CGI program processes the data and responds to the serverì

4ì The Web server passes the CGI response back to the clientì

 = Page 480 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  459

Server launching of the program (step 2c) is operating system–dependent and may

require starting a new process.

It is possible to create anything, including games, with CGI; but complex tasks ark

often limited by the state problem. The common uses of CGI includk

  Form processiný

  Database acces—

  Counter—

  Custom document generatio-

  Browse§specific page deliver_

  Banner ad serviný

  Guest book and authenticatio-

  Threaded discussio-

  Game—

PROGRAMMING

Understanding how CGI works requires an understanding of how the HTTf  AND HTM¤

protocol works. The only magic behind CGI is knowing how to read data in and writk

data out to talk to a Web browser. Writing data out is the easiest. The key to writiný

data out for Web browsers is understanding the headers so the browser knows what iš

is getting, namely, MIME types. MIME stands foK  Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensioc  ì

The MIME content type of a file tells a browser how to process itì

The following example, which shows how a Web browser and a Web serveK

communicate, should help us better understand exactly what CGI programs doì

You can access a Web server directly by using a telnet program to literally log in tf

the TCP service port for HTTP. To do this, use a telnet program to access a Web serveK

and set the port number to 80. In UNIX, you might typk

telnet www.bigcompany.com 80

This could also be performed via Windows 95/NT, which has telnet built into it. Jusš

make sure to set the port value to 80ì

Once connected to the Web server, type in the proper HTTP request. A simplk

request would bk

GET / HTTP/1.0

Then pres—  ENTER  twice to send a blank line, without which the operation won’t workì

 = Page 481 =

460  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Once the server processes the request, the result should look something like thk

listing shown here:

HTTP/1.0 200 OK

Date:    Monday, 01-January-99 09:00:00 GM

Server:  NCSA/1.3.1

MIME-version: 1.0

Content-type: text/htm¤

Content-length: 1200

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Sample HTML DocumenM  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

...content..<

</BODYL

If a Web browser were reading this data stream, it would read thk  Content-typ2  lineì

The browser would then determine what to do with the data. Browsers have ¾

mapping that takes a MIME type and then determines what to do with it. Figure 12-4

shows the mapping file from Netscape Navigator 3’s helper applicationì

Notice in the preceding code that the contenâtype i—  text/htm“  . This has the actio-

of a browser, which would render the HTML within the browser window. RemembeK

that Web servers can serve just about any type of data and pass that data to a plui-

or helper, or query the user to save the fileì

CGI Outpu

Given that you have now seen the manual execution of an HTTP request, what i—

important to the Web browser? The simple answer is the MIME type and its associate™

data. In most cases, the pages being delivered are HTML based, so the MIME typk

should bk  text/htm“  and any HTML you want on your screen. With this idea in mind, iš

should be easy to write a CGI program that fakes an HTML page. To do this, you nee™

to print out the MIME type indicatio-  Content-type: text/htm“  , followed by a series o“

HTML codes. The following small Perl program shows how this might be done. An_

language, including C, Pascal, or BASIC, could also be used to make such an exampleì

 = Page 482 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  46h

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Figurs 12-48  Sample MIME mapping dialog box under Netscape 3

#!/usr/bin/perl# Note the path to perl may vary<

# Really simple CGI progra—

#

print "Content-type: text/html\n\n"

print "<HTML>\n<HEAD><TITLE>First CGI</TITLE></HEAD>\n"

print "<BODY>\n<H1>I was created by a CG

program!</H1>\n</BODY>\n</HTML>"

 = Page 483 =

46p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

If this example were typed and set to run on a Per_capable Web server, it could bk

accessed directly by a user to print out the simple page shown in Figure 12-5. To sek

the program in action, try the URL http://www.htmlref.com/cg¾bin/firstcgi.plì

In summary: To create a document on the fly, you have to print a group of headersì

Make sure to do this in the correct format. Other than that, the rest of the program i—

up to you. This section only covers getting information from the server, which is jusš

half of the CGI equation. The following section discusses getting information to youK

programì

Passing Information to a CGI Program:

Environment Variable“

In order to get information into a CGI program, you generally need to use a form. Thk

CGI program itself can actually read some information from the HTTP request and thk

local environment. This information can be used in conjunction with form data tf

understand the environment the program is running. Environment variables ark

actually very valuable. They can be used to help the CGI program decide what kind o“

pages to prepare. A list of most of the common CGI environment variables is provide™

in Table 12-2ì

Figurs 12-58  Output of simple CGI progra‘

server; for example, CGI/1.1ì

running the CGI programì

name and version number of the software—foK

example, Netscap[Commerce/1.12ì

The Perl code for the result in Figure 12-6 is shown here:

#!/usr/bin/per¤

&print_HTTP_header;

&print_head;

&print_body;

&print_tail;

 = Page 486 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  46

# print the HTTP Content-type headeI

sub print_HTTP_header {

print "Content-type: text/html\n\n";

}

#Print the start of the HTML fil4

sub print_head {

print <<END;

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  CGI Environment Variable?  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  Environment Variable?  </H1L

PROGRAMMING

<HRL

AND HTM¤

END

}

#Loop through the environment variabl4

#associative array and print out its values<

sub print_body {

foreach $variable (sort keys %ENV) {

print "  <BL  $variable:  </BL  $ENV{$variable}  <BRL  \n";

}

}

#Print the close of the HTML fil4

sub print_tail {

print <<END;

</BODYL

</HTMLL

END

}

 = Page 487 =

46‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Notice that the code is written to make the printing of the appropriate headers, thk

start of the HTML file, the results, and the close of the file more straightforwardì

Code libraries, which do much of the work of CGI, are commonly availableì

Browser Sensing with CGY

At first glance, the environment variables might not seem very useful. When use™

properly, however, they are indispensable. One of the most important uses of CGI is tf

sense the browser being used so that customized pages can be delivered for differenš

browser types. Using a small program, it would be possible to sense a user’s browseK

type and redirect him or her automatically to another pageì

Figurs 12-68  CGI environment variables examplP

 = Page 488 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  46

To make browser sensing work, the server may have to be configured to run the CG‚

program automatically. This may just require putting a file called index.cgi in the rooP

directory or performing some similar renaming.

Here is how browser sensing works. The CGI environment variable calle™

HTTP_USER_AGEN  is read in by the CGI program using a simple call availablk

from a Perl CGI library. Once the value is set, a set of conditions determines whic—

page to send, depending on the browser accessing the page. In the following example,

the file netscapehome.htm is sent if the browser is Netscape 3 or above. If the browseK

is Microsoft Internet Explorer 3 or above, the file mshome.htm is sent. Otherwise, thk

file home.htm is sentì

#!/usr/local/bin/per¤

require '/usr/local/ns-home/cgi-bin/cgi-lib.pl';

# pulls in special library for easy reading o¨

# environment variable?  PROGRAMMING

&ReadParse;  AND HTM¤

$agent = $ENV{'HTTP_USER_AGENT'};

if ($agent =~ /Mozilla\/3.0|Mozilla\/4.0/i) {

$file = "netscapehome.htm";

}

if ($agent =~ /MSIE 3.0|MSIEY.0/i) {

$file = "mshome.htm";

}

else {

$file = "home.htm";

}

print "Location: http://www.bigcompany.com/$file", "\n\n";

What’— interestiný i— thaš thi— filk wa— use™ tf sorš ouš whaš for“ o“ animatio- coul™

bk usedì Thk peoplk whf receive™ thk mshome.ht“ filk coul™ rea™ Macromedi¾ Flas—

files, Netscapk 3 an™ 4 user— coul™ usk JavaScripš rolloveK animations, an™ everyonk whf

coul™ df neitheK receive™ ¾ stati´ pageì Whe- ¾ sitk i— donk well, therk isn’š a- entranck

pagk thaš say— “Clickherk foK Netscape” an™ “Clickherk foK otheK browsers.” Thing— jusš

work, becausk thk sitk ha— browse§awark pagesì O“ course, onk hugk proble“ wit— thi—

ide¾ i— haviný tf kee5 differenš file— foK thk samk pageì Parse™ HTML, a— discusse™ lateK

i- thk chapter, ma_ offeK ¾ betteK solutio- tf browse§awark pagesì

 = Page 489 =

468  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Passing Information to a CGI Program: Form DatC

Forms are a good way to collect user input such as a survey result or a comment. The_

can also start database queries or launch programs. Creating HTML forms wa—

discussed in Chapter 11. For a quick refresher on how HTML forms are used, take ¾

look at the following example:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Final//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Meet and GreeM  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  Welcome to CGI!  </H1L

<HRL

<FORM METHOD="POSTh

ACTION="http://www.pint.com/cgi-bin/helloworld.pl"L

<BL  What's your nam4  ?</BL

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="user_name" SIZE=5"L

<BR><BRL

<INPUT TYPE="SUBMIT" VALUE="Hi I am..."L

<INPUT TYPE="RESET" VALUE="RESET"L

</FORML

</BODYL

</HTMLL

If this example is typed and run, it will greet the user by whatever name he or shk

types in. Thk  <FORM  element is the key to this example, because it has an action tf

perform (as indicated by thk  ACTION  attribute when the form is submitted). Thk

action is to launch a CGI program indicated by the URL value of thk  ACTION

attribute. Thk  <FORM  element also has an attribute,  METHO¤  , which indicates hou

information will be passed to the receiving CGI program. There are two basic method—

to pass data in via a form:  GE  an™  POS GE  ì  appends information on the end of thk

submitting URL, so the URL accessed in the previous example might be something likk

http://www.pint.com/cgi-bin/hello.pl?user_name=Joe+Smit—

 = Page 490 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  469

The data sent will be encoded. Long strings may havk  +  oK  %  nn  hex-encode™

values. Name/value pairs will be separated by ampersands. (The format o“

URL-encoded data is discussed in Chapter 11.) The problem with thk  GE  method i—

that, besides being ugly, it is limited to the amount of data that can be easily sent inì

GE  does have two advantages: it is easy to understand and provides the possibilit_

for canned queries. The more common approach for larger forms is to use thk  POS

method, which sends the form data as a separate data stream—in other words, ¾

file—to the server. The data stream (essentially a file) consists of many lines, such a—

name=Joe%20Smit—  . These lines can be parsed by the receiving program for lateK

processing. Given how data is encoded, a skilled programmer could easily determink

how to parse data and access the values. The following simple helloworld.pl examplk

shows how this might be done in a brute force manner that does no error checking:

#! /usr/bin/per¤

# Print the HTTP header?

print "Content-type: text/html\n";

PROGRAMMING

print "\n";

AND HTM¤

read (STDIN, $GN_QUERY, $ENV{CONTENT_LENGTH});

# This statement will split data into different field?

@QUERY_LIST = split( /&/, $GN_QUERY);

foreach $item (@QUERY_LIST) {

# First convert plus signs into space?

$item =~ s/\+/ /g;

# Now convert $nn encoded data to character?

$item =~ s/%(..)/pack("c",hex($1))/ge;

# Now put the result into the QueryArrah

$loc=index($item,"=");

$param=substr($item, 0, $loc);

$value=substr($item, $loc+1);

$QUERY_ARRAY{$param} .= $value;

}

 = Page 491 =

470  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

# Now get the users nam4

$name = "$QUERY_ARRAY{user_name}";

# Print Return HTML

print "<HTML><HEAD><TITLE>Hello</TITLE></HEAD>\n<BODY>\n";

print "<H1>Hello $name. Welcome to CGI!</H1>\n";

print "</BODY></HTML>";

Writing CGI Program“

The previous examples might seem to suggest that writing CGI programs is trivialì

This is true if data is only to be read in and written out. In fact, this part of CGI is sf

mechanical that page designers are encouraged not to attempt to parse the dat¾

themselves. There are many scripting libraries available for Perl. These include cgi´

(http://www.boutell.com/cgic/) foK ANS§ programs, cgi++ (http://www.webthing.com/

cgiplusplus/) for C++, and CGI.pm (http://stein.cshl.org/WWW/software/CGI/

cgi_docs.html) foK PerR 5ì Thesk libraries, an™ other— availablk o- thk Internet, makk thk

readiný o“ environmenš variable— an™ parsiný o“ encode™ for“ dat¾ ¾ simplk processì

¾—k ™ifficult part of CGI isn’t the input and output of data. It is the logic of the codk

itself. Given that the CGI program can be written in nearly any language, WeD

programmers might wonder what language to use. Performance, Web suitability, an™

string handling are important criteria for selecting a language for CGI authoringì

Performancewise, compiled CGI programs typically will have better performance tha-

interpreted programs written in a scripting language like Perl. However, it is probabl_

easier to write a simple CGI in a scripting language like Perl or AppleScript than to usk

C or C++ì

Some programming languages may have better interfaces to Web servers an™

HTTP than others. For example, Perl has a great number of CGI libraries and operatiný

system facilities readily available. Because much of CGI is about reading and writiný

text data, ease of string handling may also be a big consideration in selecting thk

language. The bottom line is that scripting language choice mainly depends on thk

server the script must run on and the programmer’s preference. It is even possible tf

use an old version of FORTRAN or some obscure language to write a CGI program,

though it would be easier to pick a language that works well with the Web server an™

use it to access some other program. CGI lives up to its name as a gatewayì

Table 12-3 lists the common languages for CGI coding based on the Web server’—

operating system. Notice that Perl is common to most of the platforms due to its ease o“

use and lonstanding use on the Webì

 = Page 492 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  47h

Web Server Operating System  Common CGI Language“

UNIX  Perl, C, C++, Java, Shell scripš

languages (csh, ksh, sh), Pytho-

Window—  Visual Basic, C, C++, PerR

Macintos—  AppleScript, Perl, C, C++

Tabls 12-38  Common CGI Language Choice9

Don’t rush around and get ready to code your own form handlers. Consider hou

many other people in the world need to access a database or [mail a form. Given thesk

common needs, it may be better to borrow or buy a canned CGI solution than to buil™

a new oneì

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Buying or Borrowing CGI Program“

Most CGI programs are similar to one another. There are a great deal of shareware,

freeware, or commercial packages available to do most of the common Web tasksì

Matt’s Script Archive (http://www.worldwidemart.com/scripts) and the CG§

Resource Index (http://www.cg¾resources.com) are good places to start looking foK

these. There are many scripts for form handling, bulletin boards, counters, an™

countless other things available for free on the Internet. There are also compile™

commercial CGI programs made to perform a particular task. Site developers are urge™

to consider the cost of developing custom solutions versus buying premade solutions,

particularly when time is an important consideration in building the siteì

NSAPI/ISAPY

One serious problem with CGI programs is their slowness. There are two reasons wh_

CGI programs can be slow. The first is that the launch of the CGI program by the WeD

server can be slow. Once launched, the program may run relatively slowly, because iš

is written in an interpreted language like Perl. Solving the second problem is easy:

simply rewrite the program in a compiled language like C. Performance should quickl_

improve. What about the launch problem? One approach would be to prelaunch thk

main CGI program so that it is running all the time and have smaller CGI program—

launch when needed. While this would help, the server would still have tf

 = Page 493 =

47p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

communicate with an external program, which might be time consuming. If speed is o“

the essence, migrating the functionality of the CGI program into the server is requiredì

This is the idea behind the Netscape Server Application Programming Interfack

(NSAPI) and the Internet Server Application Programming Interface (ISAPI)ì

In short, NSAPI and ISAPI programs are like pluins for a server. A program,

typically written in C or C++, that conforms to the NSAPI/ISAPI can be plugged intf

the server to add functionality to the system. Obviously, writing such a solution i—

much more difficult than writing a simple CGI program. There are other drawbacks a—

well. For example, a misbehaving ISAPI/NSAPI program may bring a whole serveK

down. Developers who write an application programming interface (API)–base™

solution may also be stuck using a particular server platform, while CGI programs ark

generally portable from server to server. Regardless of their drawbacks, NSAPI/ISAP§

programs have the advantage of speed and the ability to share data across sessions an™

users very easily. With this power, many thirÙparty developers have created serveK

extensions to allow fast and easy database access, threaded discussion capability, an™

many other features. While most developers are about as likely to use NSAPI or ISAP§

programs as they are to write browser pluins, the technology has enabled thk

creation of serve§side parsing technology, which is useful to almost every Web pagk

developerì

Parsed HTML Solutions: Server-Side Scripting

CGI and NSAPI/ISAPI programs are beyond the technical understanding of some WeD

page developers. However, adding interactivity to a site does not always have to bk

difficult. Another form of serve§based programming, generically terme™  parsed HTM?  ,

provides much of the sophistication of general CGI with the ease of HTML. The idea o“

parsed HTML is simple. First, code a page using standard HTML. Then add speciaR

new elements or directives to indicate what to do in particular cases. Imagine if yo¾

wanted to print out different HTML headings for Netscape users, Microsoft Interneš

Explorer, and other browser users. Using parsed HTML, you might put statements in ¾

parsed HTML language in your file, like this:

$if browser = Netscap4

<H1><BLINKL  Hey Netscape User!  </BLINK></H1L

$else if browser = IE

<MARQUEEL  Hey Microsoft User!  </MARQUEEL

$els4

<H1L  Hey User!  </H1L

$endi¨

 = Page 494 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  47

To indicate that the file is a special parsed HTML file, end its name with the extensio-

.parsedhtml. Next, configure the server to parse and execute the special statement—

you have added to the file. In this case, the server will then output only the HTML,

depending on the particular browser being used. An overview of parsed HTML

solutions is shown in Figure 12-7ì

While parsed HTML solutions are very easy for people to deal with, they can puš

an excessive load on the server. Use them wisely. The next few sections describe threk

common parsed HTML technologies used on the Web: serve§side includes (SSI),

ColdFusion, and Active Server Pages (ASP)ì

Server-Side Includes (SSIs)

Serve§side includes are the simplest form of parsed HTML. SSIs are short directive—

you can embed in an HTML document to indicate files to be read and included in thk

final output. This might be useful if the designer wants to make one file with footeK

information, such as an address and copyright, and then append it to all page—

dynamically. To do this, create a file called footer.htm and then include it dynamicall_

using SSI. The contents of footer.htm might look something like this:

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

<HR NOSHADEL

<CENTERL

<FONT SIZE="-1"L

Copyright 1997 Big Companh  <BRL

2105 Garnet Ave, Suite E, San Diego, CA 92109  </FONTL

Figurs 12-78  Overview of parsed HTML solution9

 = Page 495 =

47  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

To include this file in another file, you would need an SSI directive like this:

<!--#include file="footer.htm" --L

Notice that this is just a special form of an HTML comment with a-  #includ2  comman™

and a parameter file, which is set to the file you want to include. To indicate to thk

server that the page contains SSI commands, use the .shtml extension. If the server i—

properly configured, it should pick up the file and execute it before sending the resultì

Besides including external files, SSI can also be used to show the results o“

programs, including CGI programs. Thus, it can provide a way to query databases an™

make a page counter, among other things. The simple example that follows shows hou

thk  echG  SSI command can be used to access the environment variables to which CG§

programs have accessì

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<BODYL

<x ALIGN="CENTER"L  Welcom4  <!--#echoqar="REMOTE_HOST" --L

to my serveI  <!--#echoqar="SERVER_NAME" --></xL

<HRL

You are usin(  <!--#echoqar="HTTP_USER_AGENT" --L  <

</BODYL

</HTMLL

One possible result of this example is shown in Figure 12-8. Remember that youK

result will be different since the page is dynamically generated and must be run from ¾

server with SSI turned onì

The environment variables that are accessible from SSI are similar to those that ca-

be accessed by any CGI program. They also include the variables listed in Table 12-4ì

Besides inserting CGI environment variable values, it is also possible to use SSI tf

embed the results of a CGI program into an HTML document by using the EXEC CG§

command. For example, it would be possible to add a simple page counter to an HTML

 = Page 496 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  47

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Figurs 12-88  SSI output under Internet Explore

Variable Nams  Descriptio

DATE_GM  This value references the current server local date,

same a—  DATE_LOCAL  , but in Greenwich mean timeì

This variable is subject to formatting from thk

CONFI…  SSI commandì

DATE_LOCAL  The current date, local time zone. Subject to formattiný

from thk  CONFI…  SSI commandì

Tabls 12-48  SSI-AvailableXariables Potentially Outside the CGI Sed

 = Page 497 =

47‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Variable Nams  Descriptio

DOCUMENT_NAM¨  The variable holds the current filenameì

DOCUMENT_URI  The variable contains the virtual path to the currenš

document—for example, /about/bigcompany/

contact.shtmlì

LAST_MODIFIE¤  The last modification date of the current documentì

This variable is subject to the date formatting set b_

thk  CONFI…  SSI commandì

QUERY_STRING_  This variable contains the “unescaped” version of an_

UNESCAPE¤  search query (  GE  ) sent by the browser. Any speciaR

characters are escaped using the \ characterì

Tabls 12-48  SSI-AvailableXariables Potentially Outside the CGI Sed  (continued)

document by using an SSI command to execute the counter program and display it—

results in the page. Assuming there were a program called counter.cgi in the cg¾bi-

directory on the server, you could use a simple SSI statement like the following to ad™

the page count:

<!--#exec cgi="cgi-bin/counter.cgi"--L

In general, SSI consists of a special comment form that indicates the SSI command,

as well as any parameters to modify the command in the general format, as follows:

<!-- #command parameter=value --L

Following are some of the common SSI commands and their associated parametersì

ECHO

PARAMETERS  VA

DESCRIPTION  Used to insert the values of special SSI variables and environmenš

variables into the pageì

 = Page 498 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  47

<!--#ECHO VAR="REMOTE_HOST"--L

INCLUDE

PARAMETERS  FIL¨ VIRTUAL  ,

DESCRIPTION  Used to insert the contents of a document into the current file. Thi—

pathname of the file can be either relative or virtual. Relative files paths are relative tf

the current directory, while virtual filenames may access other directories using the ../

directory style or an absolute pathì

<!--#INCLUDE FILE="footer.htm"--L

<!--#INCLUDE VIRTUAL="../templates/footer.htm"--L

FSIZE

PARAMETERS  FIL¨

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

DESCRIPTION  Inserts the size of a given fileì

<!--#FSIZE FILE="index.htm"--L

FLASTMOD

PARAMETERS  FIL¨

DESCRIPTION  Inserts the last modification date of a given fileì

<!--#FLASTMOD FILE="index.htm"--L

EXEC

PARAMETERS  CM¤ CGI  ,

DESCRIPTION  Allows you to execute external programs, either an application o-

the host or a CGI programì

<!--#EXEC CMD="/usr/bin/ls"--L

<!--#EXEC CGIi="cgi-bin/counter.cgi"--L

 = Page 499 =

478  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

CONFq

PARAMETERS  ERRMS…  =  string¨  SIZEFM  = byte— | abbrev,  TIMEFM  =  formaP strinv

DESCRIPTION  Allows you to configure SSI output options for error output, file sizk

output, and data output. The value foK  ERRMS…  is simply a string value for the erroK

messageì  SIZEFM  may be set to bytes or abbrev, whilk  TIMEFM  can be set to ¾

UNIX date format string in the form compatible with the strftime libraryì

<!--#CONFIG ERRMSG="[SSI Statement Failed!]"--L

<!--#CONFIG SIZEFMT="bytes"--L

<!--#CONFIG TIMEFM="%A %b %d %j"--L

Depending on the server, there may be more SSI statements, includiný  ODB‚  an™

EMAIL  , which are used to access a database and send [mail, respectively. Thesk

commands are the ones most common across most SSìcapable serversì

While SSI looks appealing, it has two potential problems: security and performanceì

SSI’s security problem is mainly due to the EXEC command, which can be used tf

execute a program on the server. With this command, security breaches are possibleì

For example, it might be possible to insert a command to launch a remote session. Eve-

if security isn’t a big issue, depending on how SSI and the Web server are configured,

the executing command may have a great deal of permissions and be able to removk

values. Web administrators are advised to limit use of this SSI commandì

The other problem with SSI, performance, is typical with any parsed HTML

solution. Because all SSI files have to be parsed, they may cause a performance hitì

If a site has serious performance requirements, parsed HTML solutions may bk

inappropriate. Fortunately, it is possible to limit parsed HTML or mix it with standar™

HTML by having only certain files, for example those ending in .shtml, parsed by thk

server. When used in a limited fashion, SSI can provide powerful features that ark

within the technical ability of any HTML writer. However, SSI is limited. Pagk

designers may find other parsed HTML solutions, such as ColdFusion or ASP, mork

appropriateì

ColdFusio

One of the most popular serve§parsed HTML solutions is Allaire’s ColdFusio-

(http://www.allaire.com). ColdFusion is a complete Web application developmenš

tool that allows developers to create dynamic databas[driven Web site application—

with an easÇtkuse, serve§side markup language similar to HTML. Getting starte™

with ColdFusion requires learning a few new markup tags that look like HTML buš

make up what is called ColdFusion Markup Language (CFML). Since one of it—

primary functions is database access, ColdFusion uses the Open Database Connectivit_

 = Page 500 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  479

(ODBC) standard to connect to popular database servers like Microsoft SQL Server,

Access, Sybase, Oracle, and others. ColdFusion is not dependent on a particulaK

database or Web server, and it works well on a variety of Windows Nf an™

Unix-based servers. While ColdFusion is not a W3C defined standard, it is widel_

used. It is presented here to illustrate an example of parsed HTML and to show hou

HTML might be used to interact with a databaseì

Web applications built with ColdFusion use dynamic pages composed of a mixturk

of CFML and HTML markup. When the page is requested, the ColdFusion applicatio-

running on the server preprocesses the page, interacts with a database or otheK

serve§side technologies, and returns a dynamically generated HTML page. It i—

probably better to refer to ColdFusion–enabled pages as templates since the actuaR

page output variesì

Using CFM¤

Here is how to use CFML to select and output data in a dynamic Web page. Thi—

section will show how to use a number of CFML tags to query data from a database,

take the results of the query, and populate a Web pageì

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Database Overview

A database is simply a collection of data that is organized in a regular fashion, typicall_

in the form of a table. Imagine you want to create a Web site to post the various joD

openings in your company. The first thing you need to do is to decide whaš

information is relevant: position number, job title, location, brief description, hiriný

manager, and posting date. This information could be organized in the form of ¾

database table, called Positions, as shown in Table 12-5ì

Tabls 12-58  Simple Database Table Called Position9  (continued)

The example is populated with some simple data, but how can the data be retrieve™

to be displayed in a Web page automatically?

Selecting the DatC

The first step is to define a database query using Structured Query Language (SQL)ì

SQL is the language used to retrieve or modify data from the tables in a database. Thk

language is relatively simple, at least as far as mastering the basics. If you werk

interested in making a query to the database table called Positions, you would use ¾

SQL statement likk

SELECT * FROM Position?

 = Page 502 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  48h

This query simply says to select all items indicated by the wildcard ( ) in the tablk  *

called Positions. If you just want to list all the positions in Austin, you could qualify thk

query by adding ¾  WHER¨  modifier, indicating you only want entries for which thk

location is Austinì

SELECT * FROM Positions WHERE Location="Austin"

Using thk  WHER¨  modifier, it is possible to create complex queries. For example,

you could query all jobs in Austin, or in Los Angeles, for which the position i—

Game Testerì

SELECT *

FROM Position?

WHERE ((Location="Austin" OR

(Location="Los Angeles") AND

(Position="Game Tester"))

PROGRAMMING

This brief discussion should reveal the flavor of SQL. While the basic language i—

AND HTM¤

simple, queries can be more complicated. A full discussion of SQL is well beyond thk

scope of this book. For sake of this discussion, only simple queries are used in thk

examplesì

In order to pull data out of the database, write a SQL query, and then place iš

within ¾  <CFQUERY  element. The following example illustrates the use o“

<CFQUERY  . A select SQL query calle™  ListJob—  , as specified by thk  NAM¨  attribute,

will query a database and retrieve all the records in the Positions table. The syntax foK

this example is shown hereì

<CFQUERY NAME="ListJobsh

DATASOURCE="CompanyDataBase"L

SELECT * FROM Position?

</CFQUERYL

Notice that thk  DATASOURC¨  attribute is set equal to CompanyDataBase, which i—

the ODBC data source that contains a database called Company, which contains thk

Positions table from which data is pulledì

 = Page 503 =

48p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) is a standardized way to access data from ‘

variety of different databases. ODBC provides a layer of abstraction that protects th—

developer from having to learn the particulars of a specific database system. To query th—

Positions table, your server might connect to a simple Microsoft Access database or ‘

powerful Oracle system. In order to access a database, a developer needs to set up ac

ODBC data source. This requires that developer to select an ODBC driver, name th—

data source, and configure any specific settings for the database. A complete discussioc

of how to set up ODBC drivers and configure data sources can be found in th—

documentation for ColdFusion.

Beside—  NAM¨  an™  DATASOURC¨  , thk  <CFQUERY  element has a variety o“

attributes, as described in Table 12-6ì

Attributs  Descriptio

NAM¨  Required. This attribute is used to assign a name to thk

SQL query. The name is used later in the template tf

reference the query resultsì

DATASOURC¨  Required. This attribute is used to specify the name of thk

ODBC data source that will be used to access thk

databaseì

MAXROWS  Optional. This attribute is used to specify the maximu“

number of rows as a positive integer number that shoul™

be returned by the query. More output rows beyond thi—

value will be droppedì

USERNAM¨  Optional. Since many databases have login features, thi—

attribute is used to set the username to access the dat¾

source. This attribute overrides the default settings in thk

ColdFusion Administratorì

PASSWOR¤  Optional. This attribute is used to set the passwor™

associated for the username that will access the databaseì

This value overrides the default settings in thk

ColdFusion Administratorì

TIMEOU  Optional. This attribute can be set to a time, i-

milliseconds, for a query to successfully execute. Querie—

that take longer than this value will failì

DEBU…  Optional. When present, this attribute turns on thk

tracing and debugging features for the fileì

Tabls 12-68  <CFQUERY>  Attribute SummarV

 = Page 504 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  48

Outputing the DatC

Using thk  <CFOUTPUT  element, it is possible to display the data retrieved from ¾

previously define™  <CFQUERY  element. For example, in order to output the quer_

called ListJobs, you would use a code fragment, as shown here:

<CFOUPUT QUERY="ListJobs"L

<HR NOSHADE><BRL

Position Number: #PostionNum#  <BR><BRL

Title: #JobTitle#  <BR><BRL

Location: #Location#  <BR><BRL

Description: #Description#

</CFOUPUTL

Notice the use of thk symbols throughout this code fragment. These values are use™  #

to delimit the areas in which you wish to place the data from the database. FoK

PROGRAMMING

example,  #PositionNum#  will be populated with data from the colum-  PositionNu…  ,

AND HTM¤

whilk  #JobTitle#  will get the values for thk  JobTitl2  column in the database. Notick

also that normal HTML markup can be used within the queryì

The primary attribute for thk  <CFOUTPUT  element i—  QUER  , but there ark

numerous other attributes, as shown in Table 12-7ì

Attributs  Descriptio

QUER  Required. This is set to the name of thk  <CFQUERY  thaš

will be used to query the databaseì

MAXROWS  Optional. This attribute is used to specify the maximu“

number of rows in the query: a positive integer, whic—

should be displayedì

GROUL  Optional. This attribute is used to group output and i—

useful for nested reportingì

STARTROW  Optional. This attribute is used to specify an integer rou

from which to start output; for example, setting thi—

attribute to 5 would start the output with the fifth rou

returned by the queryì

Tabls 12-78  <CFOUTPUT>  Attribute SummarV

 = Page 505 =

48  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

By putting both thk  <CFQUERY  and thk  <CFOUTPUT  elements together in ¾

complete CFML template file, which you could call example1.cfm, and putting this o-

a server that understands ColdFusion, you could create a dynamically generated pageì

A complete listing showing the two primary ColdFusion elements is shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<!-- SQL statement to select jobs Æailable from the database--L

<CFQUERY NAME="ListJobs" DATASOURCE="CompanyDataBase"L

SELECT * FROM Position?

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Big Company Job Listing?  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<x ALIGN="center"L  Big Company Job Listing?  </xL

<HRL

<CFOUTPUT QUERY="ListJobs"L

<HR NOSHADE><BRL

Position Number: #PositionNum#  <BR><BRL

</CFOUTPUTL

Big Company, Inc<

</HTMLL

application would work equally well under Internet Explorer, Lynx, WebTV, or an_

other browserì

Conditional Statement“

When creating dynamic pages, things don’t always work out as expected. Whaš

happens, for example, if there are no jobs in the database to print out? Should the useK

get a blank page or one that says “Sorry, no jobs available?” ColdFusion provides ¾

number of facilities to take care of just such problems. Using thk  <CFIF  element,

simple comparison conditions can be added to the page and simple applications can bk

built. The basic syntax for thk  <CFIF  element is shown hereì

 = Page 507 =

48‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<CFIF  expressioY  >

HTML and CFML tag?

<CFELSE>

HTML and FML tag?

</CFIF>

An expression is a comparison condition. For example,  IS NOT ""  would be a-

expression to see if something is not set. Sf

<CFIF ListJobs.PostionNum IS NOT ""L

Print the query here<

</CFIFL

would only do the section “Print the query here.” if thk  PostionNu…  field were noš

empty. Note that, as shown in this example, thk  <CFELSE  element is optionalì

The expression used in thk  <CFIF  element can be complex and may consist of onk

or many of the operators shown in Table 12-8ì

Operato5  Descriptio

IS  Performs a cas[insensitive comparison of twf

values and return—  TRU¨  if the values are identicaR

IS NO  oK  NEQ  Performs the opposite function of thk  IS  operatoK

returniný  TRU¨  only if the values are not equaR

CONTAINS  Performs a check to determine if the value on the lefš

of the operator is contained in the value on the righš

of the operator and return—  TRU¨  if it i—

DOES NOT CONTAIN  Opposite of thk  CONTAINS  operatoK

Tabls 12-88  <CFIF>  Operators SummarV

 = Page 508 =

Operato5  Descriptio

GREATER THAN  oK  G  Checks whether the value on the left is greater tha-

the value on the right and return—  TRU¨  if it i—

LESS THAN  o(  L  Checks whether the value on the left is less than thk

value on the right and return—  TRU¨  if it i—

GREATER THAN O  Checks whether the value on the left is greater tha-

EQUAL T  oK  GT¨  or equal to the value on the right and return—  TRU¨

if it i—

LESS THAN OR EQUAL  Checks whether the value on the left is less than oK

T  oK  LT¨  equal to the value on the right and return—  TRU¨  i“

it i—

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Using the conditional capabilities provided by thk  <CFIF  element, it is possible tf

create an improved example that checks whether the table has open positions. If not, iš

prints out a statement indicating that no jobs are available, as shown here:

<!-- SQL statement to select jobs Æailable from the database--L

<CFQUERY NAME="ListJobs" DATASOURCE="CompanyDataBase"L

SELECT * FROM Position?

</CFQUERYL

<CFIF ListJobs.PositionNumber IS NOT ""L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Big Company Job Listing?  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<x ALIGN="CENTER"L  Big Company Job Listing?  </xL

<HRL

 = Page 509 =

488  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<CFOUTPUT QUERY="ListJobs"L

<ULL

<HR NOSHADE><BRL

Position Number: #PositionNum#  <BR><BRL

Title: #JobTitle#  <BR><BRL

Location: #Location#  <BR><BRL

Description: #Description#

</ULL

</CFOUTPUTL

<HRL

<ADDRESSL

Big Company, Inc<

</ADDRESSL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

<CFELSEL

<CFLOCATION URL="nojobs.htm"L

</CFIFL

Thk  <CFIF  statement in this example checks to see if thk  PositionNu…  field i—

empty in the database. If the field is not empty, then it proceeds to populate the WeD

page. If the field is empty, it redirects to a page called nojobs.htm, which indicates thaš

there are no positions currently available at the companyì

CFML Summar

It should be obvious from the examples presented that ColdFusion can be used tf

create dynamic Web pages. When using conditional operators, as well as other CFML

elements that can be used to loop or set variables, it is even possible to creatk

ful_fledged applications with ColdFusion. ColdFusion and other HTML-like,

serve§parsed languages are great, because they are relatively easy to get started withì

There are fewer than two dozen CFML elements to learn. Some of these provide ver_

powerful features like file upload, cookie manipulation, file inclusion, automati´

HTML table creation, and mailing. A brief summary of the CFML elements available i-

ColdFusion is presented in Table 12-9ì

The previous discussion is just a sample of what ColdFusion can do. It is onl_

meant to illustrate what a serve§side HTML language can do. For more detaile™

 = Page 510 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  489

Elemen  Descriptio

<CFABORT  Aborts the processing of the CFML application oK

template at the specified locatio-

<CFAPPLICATION  Defines the CFML application name and activates thk

client variable—

<CFCOL  Defines a table column header, including setting widt—

and alignment of the colum-

<CFCONTENT  Defines the content type and the name of the file to bk

uploaded from the applicatio-

<CFCOOKIE  Defines and sets a cookie, which can be used tf

preserve state informatio-

<CFERROR  Customizes HTML error page—

<CFFILE  Allows the developer to define fil[handling task—

within the CFML applicatio-  PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

<CFHEADER  Generates HTTP headers in the application, which ma_

be useful to avoid having the page be cache™

<CFIF  Creates a conditional expression that is useful foK

catching error conditions or setting up more outpuš

logi´

<CFINCLUDE  Includes a ColdFusion template file in the applicatio-

(useful for keeping routines in separate files)

<CFINSERT  Inserts records into an ODBC databaseì

<CFLOCATION  Opens a ColdFusion template or HTML file (most ofte-

used for redirection of output)

<CFLOOP  “Loops” or repeats a set of instructions or display—

conditional outpuš

<CFMAIL  Sends SMTP [mail from the CFML applicatio-

<CFOUTPUT  Displays the results of a database query as specified b_

thk  <CFQUERY  elemenš

<CFPARAM  Assigns a parameter an initial valuk

Tabls 12-98  CFML Language SummarV

 = Page 511 =

490  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Elemen  Descriptio

<CFQUERY  Passes a SQL statement, typically a query to a-

ODBC-connected databask

<CFREPORT  Embeds a report from Crystal Reports into the pagk

<CFSET  Defines a variable within the CFML application that ca-

be accessed later using ¾  <CFIF  or similar construcš

<CFTABLE  Builds a quick HTML table to hold the output of ¾

quer_

<CFUPDATE  Updates records in an ODBC data sourck

Tabls 12-98  CFML Language SummarV  (continued)

information on the syntax of ColdFusion, as well as examples of its use, see thk

ColdFusion Language Reference at Allaire’s Web site (http://www.allaire.com). Whilk

ColdFusion is somewhat tag oriented, there are other serve§side parsed HTML

solutions, such as Microsoft’s ASP, that may provide more scripting style functionalityì

Active Server Pages (ASP)

Microsoft’s ASP is a serve§side scripting environment primarily for the Microsofš

Internet Information Server (IIS) Web server, although thirÙparty vendors havk

recently ported ASP to other Web servers, such as the Netscape Enterprise serverì

Using ASP, it is possible to combine HTML, scripting code, and serve§side ActiveX

components to create dynamic Web applications. The ability to write scripts i-

standard scripting languages such as VBScript, JavaScript, and other scriptiný

languages such as Perl, enables developers to create applications with almost any typk

of functionality. This makes the ASP approach to serve§side scripting very generalize™

for a broad range of applications. Serve§side scripts can also access serve§side object—

in the form of ActiveX controls for a variety of functions, such as database access vi¾

ODBC. Like other parsed HTML solutions, an ASKenabled page is parsed by the WeD

server to generate the dynamic HTML that is sent to the Web browser. This means thaš

ASKenabled pages work equally well on every browserì

 = Page 512 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  49h

Creating ASP Page“

To get started using ASP, the developer needs to have a working knowledge of HTML,

as well as knowledge of a scripting language like VBScript or JavaScript. Files create™

for ASP have an .asp file extension. When an ASKenabled server sees a file with suc—

an extension, it will execute it before delivering it to the user. For example, the simplk

VBScript embedded into the file shown here is used to display the current date on ¾

Web page dynamically:

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="VBScript" RUNAT="Seer"L

</SCRIPTL

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  ASP Display Date Exampl4  </TITLEL

<HEADL

<BODYL

<H1L  Welcome to News of the Dah  </H1L

PROGRAMMING

<% = date %L

AND HTM¤

<PL

Today the stock of a major software companh  <BRL  reached an all tim4

high, making the bigcompany.com's CEO  <BRL  the world's first and

only trillionaire<  <BRL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Thk  <SCRIPT  element is used to indicate the primary scripting language beiný

employed. This element also tells the Web server to execute the script code on thk

server rather than the client with thk  RUNA  attribute. This can be abbreviated a—

<@ LANGUAGE =  script_languageA  .  Notice how thk  <% %  is used to delimit thk

script code that is run. ASP is a generalized technology. It can be used to do whatever ¾

user dreams up. Since people commonly want to do things on the Web like access ¾

database, it has been enhanced to do this wellì

DATABASE ACCESS IN ASV  In the following discussion, ASP will be used tf

access the Positions database described earlier in the chapter. While this coul™

probably be done more easily using ColdFusion, the point here is to introduce the ide¾

of object access from ASP. The first step in this example is to create an instance of thk

 = Page 513 =

49p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

database component by adding the following line to an ASP file, which might bk

named example.aspì

<OBJECT RUNAT="Seer" ID="Connh

PROGID="ADODB.Connection"></OBJECTL

This statement creates an instance of a database access object calle™  Conn  that can bk

used with a serve§side scriptì

Later on, the file will open a connection to the database and execute a SQL

command to select job positions and return a set of records. The small code fragmenš

shown next does this. The code is enclosed withi-  <%  an™  %  so that the server know—

to execute this rather than display it on the screenì

<%

Conn.Open Session("ConnectionString")

SQL = "SELECT * FROM Positionsh

Set RS = Conn.Execute(SQL)

Do While Not RS.EOF

%L

The code between thk  <%  %  statements is VBScript, which is interpreted b_

the Web server when this page is requested. The Do While statement is a standar™

VBScript looping statement, which is used here to loop through the record set until a-

end of file (EOF) marker is reached, signifying the end of the records. While loopiný

through each record, the output is displayed in the context of regular HTML code, suc—

as displaying the Job Department field in a table cell:

<TDL

<%= RS("JobDepartment")%L

</TDL

Putting this all together in a file called example.asp provides a complete ASf

database access example:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 3¨ Final//EN"L

<OBJECT RUNAT="Seer" ID="Connh

PROGID="ADODB.Connection"></OBJECTL

<%@ LANGUAGE = VBScript %L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Open Position?  </TITLEL

</HEADL

 = Page 514 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  49

<BODYL

<x ALIGN="CENTER"L  Open Position?  </xL

<BR><BRL

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="1" CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="4"L

<TRL

<THL  Position NumbeI  </THL

<THL  LocatioY  </THL

<THL  DescriptioY  </THL

<THL  Hiring ManageI  </THL

Fro“ thi— example, yo¾ ca- sek thk advantage— o“ ASf foK generatiný dynami´ pagesì Thk

¾ databask acces— objectì Thk dynamicall_ create™ pagk i— builš fro“ ¾ combinatio- o“

dat¾ fro“ ¾ database, iš hint— aš thk generalize™ poweK o“ ASPì Activk ServeK Page— ark

usefuR foK creatiný application— ratheK tha- jusš dynami´ pagesì Wit— ASP, iš i— possiblk tf

determink thk user’— browser, kee5 track o“ thk user’— progres— throug— ¾ seš o“ pages, an™

managk alR thk dat¾ thaš i— passe™ backan™ fort— fro“ thk useK (includiný cook ie— an™ for“

fields)ì Thk ke_ tf thi— poweK i— thk serve§sidk object— provide™ wit— ASPì

Built-In ASP Object“

What makes ASP so powerful is that the technology includes five builâin objects foK

global use:

  Applicatio-

  Requesš

  Responsk

  ServeK

  Sessio-

 = Page 516 =

ChapteX 12  Introductio‘ tW Server-Sidf Programmin‚  49

The application object is used to share common information within an applicationì

An example would be a page counter. You can store the number of times a page ha—

been accessed and use this object to display it on the page. The application objecš

supports locking, since multiple users may be using the Web application at the samk

time and could possibly corrupt dataì

The request object is used to get information from the user, including form data,

cookies, or standard HTTP request variables such as browser type (user agent). Thk

request object contains collections of information that can be used in scripts. Thk

request object supports the following collections:

  ClientCertificat2  The values of fields stored in the client certificate thaš

is sent in the HTTP requesš

  Cookie—  The values of cookies sent in the HTTP requesš

  For…  The values of the fields sent from a form submissio-

  QueryString  The values of the variables sent in an HTTP query striný

  ServerVariable—  HTTP server information, such as server name, type,

and versio-

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

The response object is used to send information to the user. It could be used to seš

the type of content to be sent to a browser, such as HTML; Word files; or other formats,

such as graphics. It could also send and retrieve cookie values to a client to determink

user preferences for creating customized pagesì

The server object provides access to server methods and properties, includiný

setting how long a script should run and asking for serve§side objects, such a—

database objectsì

The session object, one of the most useful objects, is used to store information for ¾

particular user session. This means that information is maintained as the user jump—

from page to page, thus preserving state. The basic property for this object sets an ID

for the session while the events deal with the start or end of a sessionì

A generalized language like VBScript or JavaScript, combined with serve§sidk

objects to do common tasks like maintaining user state, makes complex serve§sidk

applications possible. Many other technologies, such as Netscape’s LiveWire with it—

serve§side JavaScript, take a similar approach. When it comes right down to it, thk

differences between ColdFusion and ASP are somewhat cosmetic. Programmers ma_

find ASP comfortable, while skilled HTML authors may find ColdFusion mork

suitable. The choice of any serve§side technology should be a logical process ratheK

than a blind acceptance of a single vendor’s solutionì

This discussion introduces ASP and is by no means complete. It illustrates ¾

mucugeneralized method of parsed HTML that utilizes the power of popular scriptiný

languages and access to serve§side objects with common and powerful functions, suc—

as database access and session tracking. Complete information on ASP can be found o-

the Microsoft Internet Information Server Web site (http://www.microsoft.com/iis/)

or in the ASP Roadmap documentation that is included when ASP is installed on ¾

Web serverì

 = Page 517 =

49‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Summar

Serve§side programming is one way to add interactivity to a Web page. CGI is thk

traditional way to do this. Writing a CGI program isn’t difficult if you use libraries,

but the price to pay for ease is often speed. Because so many CGI programs ark

very similar, some are rewritten as faster serve§side pluins called NSAPI or ISAP§

programs. While these types of server modules tend to be beyond most developers, it i—

easy to buy one to solve a common problem like database access. Some server engine—

now support a form of serve§side scripting known generically as parsed HTMLì

Parsed HTML solutions such as SSIs, ColdFusion, and ASP provide an easy way foK

HTML authors to add functionality to Web pages. While serve§side technologie—

provide a great deal of power for the Web developer, they are only half the picture. It i—

also possible to add interactivity using a clienâside technology like JavaScript or Javaì

The next two chapters discuss these technologies and their intersection with HTMLì

 = Page 518 =

Chapte7 10

Introduction tW

Scripting and HTMP

49—

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 519 =

498  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

dding interactivity to a Web site is not limited to serve§side programs. Thk

client side of the Web, the browser, can generally execute code in the form o“

scripting or embedded programmed objects. For HTML writers, the easiest wa_

A

to begin adding dynamic aspects to a Web page is through clienâside scripting, usiný

JavaScript or VBScript. This chapter discusses the intersection between scripting an™

HTML, but does not attempt to teach scripting techniques in depth. The idea o“

scripting requires the page designer to think more carefully about how the user wilR

interact with the page. If scripting is not used carefully, errors may creep in and causk

problems for the viewerì

As it stands now, scripting languages such as JavaScript are often relegated to smalR

embellishments such as the ubiquitous rollover button. However, Dynamic HTML

(DHTML) and the Document Object Model (DOM) show how the idea of a page ma_

change forever because of clienâside scripting (discussed in Chapter 14). Beyond thesk

new dynamic features, scripting has an even bigger role to play on a Web pageì

Whereas HTML may provide the structure, scripting may act as the glue, providing ¾

link between static content and user actions, and between various embedded object—

(discussed in Chapter 15)ì

The Purpose of Scripting

How do Web scripting languages relate to ful_fledged Web programming language—

such as Java? In general, scripting languages are used in small doses, for specific tasksì

Scripting has a very limited domain. Some people use scripting languages for task—

such as loan calculators. Such simple tasks illustrate basic features of the scriptiný

language. The basic uses of scripting includk

  Form validatio-

  Page embellishment, including rollover buttons and animatio-

  Dynamic page generatio-

  Interobject communication “glue”

HTML developers tend to be comfortable with scripting languages, because the_

can simply enter script commands into the HTML file along with the text markup. I-

fact, some developers simply cut and paste scripts to add scrolling marquees, dialoý

boxes, and other customized features to their pages. This form of quick embellishmenš

comes at a cost. If testing is not rigorous, serious problems—even crashes—may cree5

in. With the rise of so many scripting languages, such as JavaScript versions 1, 1.1, 1.2,

1.3, and various versions of JScript (Microsoft's interpretation of JavaScript), bugs ark

becoming more common. Hopefully, the rise of ECMAScript, a standardized form o“

JavaScript, may help solve some of these problems. Beyond compatibility issues,

scripting occasionally has some security problems, mostly related to browseK

implementation bugs. Some more cautious users may even turn off scripš

 = Page 520 =

ChapteX 13  Introductio‘ tW Scriptin‚ an HTMP  499

interpretation in their browsers, potentially causing the page to render improperly. I“

scripting makes sense for your site, you must choose between JavaScript and VBScriptì

JavaScrip

JavaScript is a scripting language developed by Netscape. Microsoft also support—

JavaScript in the form of JScript, a clone language used in Internet Explorer. Thk

language was turned over to the international standards bod_  European Compute(

Manufacturers Association (ECMA)  , which announced during the summer of 1997 thk

approval of ECMA-262, or ECMAScript, as a cros-platform Internet standard foK

scripting. Browser vendors will comply with the specification but will still use thk

commonly recognized JavaScript nameì

At the time of this writing, neither Netscape nor Internet Explorer fully supporP

ECMAScript—quite a few “gaps” in implementation still exist. Opera is the only

browser currently supporting ECMAScript in full.

PROGRAMMING

As a scripting language, JavaScript is meant to be easy to use, noncompile™

AND HTM¤

(interpreted), and useful in small chunks. This sets it apart from Java and otheK

languages that might be used on the Internet, which tend to be compiled and relativel_

hard to master for the nonprogrammer. The syntax of JavaScript is somewhat like C oK

Java with Per_style regular expression handling, and the language has basic objecâ

oriented capabilities. JavaScript is not, however, a true objecâoriented programminý

language, and it retains features (such as weak typing) that are common to simplk

scripting languagesì

JavaScript is useful for small jobs, such as checking form data; adding small bits o“

HTML code to a page o™th[fly; and performing browse§, tim[, and use§specifi´

computation. JavaScript is also a powerful means of controlling events in browser—

and accessing the DOM for programming DHTML, which is discussed in the nexš

chapter. An important potential function of JavaScript is to act as the glue betwee-

different technologies, such as pluins, Java applets, and HTML pages. An examplk

of JavaScript code being used to greet the user is shown here; a rendering of the scripš

in action is shown in Figure 13-1:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  First JavaScript Exampl4  </TITLEL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

 = Page 521 =

500  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

function Greet()

{

alert("Hello user! Welcome to JÆaScript.");

}

//--L

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  First JavaScript Exampl4  </H1L

<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"L

<FORML

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" VALUE="Press Me" onclick="Greet()"L

</FORML

</DIVL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

This is a simple example of how JavaScript may be included in an HTML file. Thk

form button triggers the function calle™  Greet()  , which greets the user. The evenš

handler attributk  onclick  is used to tie the HTML to the JavaScript that is contained i-

the head of the document within thk  <SCRIPT  element. While this example is ver_

easy, remember that it is also a trivial example; this is a real programming languagk

that has many nuances. During its short lifetime, JavaScript has undergone man_

changes. Not all browsers support it to the same degree, if at all. JavaScript has a feu

major dialects, including JavaScript 1 (Netscape 2ì ), JavaScript 1.1 (Netscape 3ì ), an™  x  x

JavaScript 1.2 (Netscape 4ì ). JScript in Internet Explorer 3 is approximately equivalenš  x

to JavaScript 1; it doesn’t support JavaScript 1.1 features, such as dynamic imagk

replacement. Internet Explorer 4 appears to support JavaScript 1.1, but with a richeK

objecš modelì Finally, therk i— thk ECMAScripš standard, thk latesš variatio- o“ JavaScriptì

Table 13-1 shows the JavaScript versions supported by different browsersì

For more information on JavaScript, visit Netscape's developer site, located aš

http://developer.netscape.com/. Information about Microsoft's implementation o“

JavaScript, called JScript, can be found at http://msdn.microsoft.com/scripting/ì

VBScrip

Visual Basic Scripting Edition, generally called VBScript, is a subset of the populaK

Visual Basic language. Because of its Visual Basic heritage, VBScript is somewhat mork

well defined and seems to have a more stable specification than JavaScript. VBScript i—

less prevalent than JavaScript on the Internet, largely because VBScript is full_

supported only in Internet Explorer 3 and above. The language can be used to providk

the same functionality as JavaScript and is just as capable as accessing the variou—

objects that compose a Web page (termed a browser'—  Document Object Model  ). Avoi™

trying to use VBScript as a cros-platform scripting solution. Used with ActiveX

controls in a more controllable environment, such as an intranet, VBScript might just bk

what the Microsofâoriented developer needs. When dealing with ActiveX control—

(discussed in Chapter 14), VBScript may provide more functionality. The following is ¾

sample of VBScript to give you a flavor of its syntax; this example has the samk

functionality as the JavaScript example given previously:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  VBSscript Exampl4  </TITLEL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="VBScript"L

<!-p

Sub Greet_onclick

MsgBox "Hello user! Welcome to VBScript.h

End Sub

'--L

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  First VBScript Exampl4  </H1L

<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"L

<FORML

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" VALUE="Press Me" NAME="Greet"L

</FORML

</DIVL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 524 =

ChapteX 13  Introductio‘ tW Scriptin‚ an HTMP  50

This is a simple example of how VBScript may be included in an HTML file. Iš

produces a rendering similar to the one shown in Figure 13-2ì

As in the first example, the form button named Greet triggers an alert box thaš

greets the user. Notice that rather than using an explicit HTML attribute such a—

onclick  , as was used in the JavaScript example, the VBScript example names thk

subroutine in a certain way to associate it with the button event, in this cask

Greet_onclick  ì

Other subtle differences in VBScript include the use of thk  MsgBox  function tf

create the alert window, as well as other syntactical differences, such as use o“

parentheses. Readers familiar with Visual Basic should find this example very easy,

because this language is just a subset of Visual Basic proper. Unfortunately, as ¾

clienâside technology, VBScript is not very useful, other than for use on an intranetì

Because it is limited to Internet Explorer, relying on VBScript locks out all Netscapk

users, which is unacceptable for a public Web site. Because of this, VBScript is ofte-

limited to being used within a Microsofâoriented intranet or on the server side, in thk

form of Active Server Page code (as discussed in Chapter 12). No significant discussio-

of VBScript occurs during this clienâside discussion. However, readers interested i-

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Figurs 13-28  VBScript says HellH
