50  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

more information about the syntax of VBScript, as well as examples, are encouraged tf

visit Microsoft's VBScript site (http://msdn.microsoft.com/scripting/)ì

Including Scripts in an HTML Documen

As suggested by the last two examples, the main way to include in a Web page script—

written in any language is primarily with thk  <SCRIPT  element. Thk  <SCRIPT

element is used to delimit the script code; anything that is found within this element i—

treated as a script, not HTML, by a scriptincapable browser. This is an importanš

statement for HTML writers to ponder. Script code tends to be sensitive to returns an™

capitalization, whereas HTML is not. The HTML rules that you know and love may noš

be valid once you are within thk  <SCRIPT  elementì

While the contents of thk  <SCRIPT  element may be very complex, the syntax o“

the element is relatively simple. Thk  <SCRIPT  element has only three majoK

attributes, as shown in Table 13-2ì

Attribute Nams  Possible Value(s)  Descriptio

LANGUAG¨  JavaScript  The value of this attribute i—

Jscript  used to specify the scriptiný

VBS  language being used. The twf

VBScript  major possibilities ark

JavaScript or VBScriptì

SR‚  A URL  This attribute is used tf

indicate the URL of a file thaš

contains an external scripš

to loadì

TYP¨  application/x-javascript  *  Indicates the MIME type of thk

text/javascript  script to runì

text/vbscript

*Thk  TYP¨  value o“  application/x-javascript  is not encouraged, although it is commo-

for older browsers that support JavaScriptì

Tabls 13-28  <SCRIPT>  Element Attribute9

 = Page 526 =

ChapteX 13  Introductio‘ tW Scriptin‚ an HTMP  50

The actual script to execute should be placed between thk  <SCRIPT  an™

</SCRIPT  tags, as shown here:

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

Script goes here<

</SCRIPTL

Remember that what is between these tags is script, not HTML markup. A ver_

different syntax may be involved, depending on the scripting language usedì

Thk  <SCRIPT  element can be used multiple times in thk  <HEAD  , as well as i-

thk  <BODY  element. Because HTML pages are read sequentially, a lot of scriptiný

code may appear in the head section of a document. Much of this script code could bk

terme™  deferred scripP  , because it may be read in the head but not executed until later i-

the script. This script code can be called later by immediate scripts or by use§actio-

scripts within the body of the HTML document. The type of script that tends to go intf

thk  <HEAD  element is similar to a function or procedure definition, as shown in thk

following example:

PROGRAMMING

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L  AND HTM¤

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

function AlertTest( ){

alert("Danger JÆaScript ahead!");

}

// --L

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

<BODYL

HTML tags that eventually may trigger JavaScript code in head

</BODYL

</HTMLL

As previously stated, thk  <SCRIPT  element may also occur in thk  <BODY

element. Generally, it is used to create immediate scripts that are executed as soon a—

 = Page 527 =

50‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

the browser reads them. For example, the following markup includes JavaScript codk

that adds the document modification time automatically to the end of the document:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Immediate ScripM  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  Big Company, Inc<  </H1L

<HRL

<PL  Interesting text goes here<  </PL

<HRL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

document.write("Last updated on: "+document.lastModified);

//--L

</SCRIPTL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Besides using thk  <SCRIPT  element, you can also embed script code directly intf

HTML tags. Typically, scripts for handling use§triggered events are the common wa_

that scripts are referenced outside thk  <SCRIPT  element. HTML elements generall_

have special attributes, called —  cript handlers¨  for particular user events. For example, ¾

click event to a button is handled by a speciaR  onclick  event. While HTML attribute—

tend to be written in uppercase, event handlers are often written in mixed case oK

lowercase, to distinguish the fact that the handler is concerned with scripting, as show-

in the following example using thk  <INPUT  element:

<FORML

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" NAME="TestButton" VALUE="Don't push me!h

onclick="AlertTest()"L

</FORML

By combining deferred scripts with use§triggered events, you can make dynami´

documents. The following example presents a button that, when clicked, opens a smalR

 = Page 528 =

ChapteX 13  Introductio‘ tW Scriptin‚ an HTMP  50

alert dialog box by using JavaScript (which is the same as the first example presente™

in the chapter):

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

Function AlertTest( ) {

alert("Danger! JÆaScript ahead! ");

}

// --L

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"L

PROGRAMMING

<FORML

AND HTM¤

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" NAME="TestButtonh

VALUE="Don't push me!" onclick="AlertTest()"L

</FORML

</DIVL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

In summary, the following are the primary ways that you can add JavaScript codk

to an HTML document:

  To the head of the document, within thk  <SCRIPT  elemenš

  To the body of a document, within thk  <SCRIPT  elemenš

  Within the elements themselves, as values of event handler attributes such a—

onclick

Two more ways exist to add JavaScript code to an HTML document. The first wa_

involves a URL scripting pseudoprotocol. Netscape browsers introduced the use of ¾

new URL style in the form o“  javascript:  , which can be used with links. For example,

 = Page 529 =

508  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<A HREF='jÆascript:alert("Danger! JÆaScript ahead!")'L  ScripM

me!  </AL

creates a link that, when clicked, executes the specified JavaScript code. Interneš

Explorer also supports this style. The other, very uncommon way to add JavaScripš

code to a Web page is with a character entity. (Remember that usiný  &copy;  woul™

include a copyright symbol.) JavaScript code can be inserted inside of a special entity o“

the for“  &{javascript code};  . The JavaScript code must be included within braces; iš

may even call functions or perform numerous statements. This entity form can only bk

used as an attribute value. This style could be used as a form of macro in Netscape 4 oK

Internet Explorer 4 pages. Imagine inserting in the head of the document a bunch o“

identifiers for colors and font style, and then referencing them by name later, as show-

in the following example:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Entity ScripM  </TITLEL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

textColor='green';

//--L

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<FONT COLOR=&{textColor;};L  This should be green<  </FONTL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

This example would probably be better handled by a style sheet, but it is presente™

here solely to show how the entity script style works. The entity and pseudkURL stylk

for adding JavaScript is specific to this particular scripting language. As more scriptiný

languages are used online, other ways to add script to a page may very well arise. FoK

now, the two standard ways are in the form of thk  <SCRIPT  element and as values o“

the attribute event handlers for individual elements such a—  onclick  , which is discusse™

in greater detail later in the chapter (see “Script Events and HTML”)ì

Specifying the Scripting Languags

By default, most browsers assume that the script language being used is JavaScriptì

Thk  LANGUAG¨  attribute can be used to specify other languages, including VBScripš

 = Page 530 =

ChapteX 13  Introductio‘ tW Scriptin‚ an HTMP  509

and many others. The HTML 4.0 specification deprecates thk  LANGUAG¨  attribute i-

favor of thk  TYP¨  attribute. Thk  TYP¨  attribute is used to indicate the MIME type o“

the script to run; for example,  text/javascript  . This indication of scripting dialect is noš

often used; it may not provide the flexibility o“  LANGUAG¨  ì

Not all versions of JavaScript support the same features. The object relied upon b_

animated buttons wasn’t available until JavaScript 1.1; it causes errors in oldeK

browsers if it isn’t accounted for. Thk  LANGUAG¨  attribute can be used to indicatk

the version of JavaScript being used. The attribute can be set tf  JavaScript1.1  oK

JavaScript1.2  , rather than simpl_  JavaScript  . Only browsers that understand thk

particular dialect of JavaScript will execute the enclosed script code. With thi—

idea, you can make a fal_through situation with multiple versions of similar code,

as shown here:

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

Simple versioY

</SCRIPTL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript1.1"L

PROGRAMMING

Netscape 3

AND HTM¤

</SCRIPTL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript1¨"L

Netscape?

</SCRIPTL

One final way exists to indicate a scripting language: use thk  <META  element i-

thk  <HEAD  . For example,

<META http-equøv="Content-Script-Type" content="text/jÆascript"L

sets the default scripting language for the whole document to JavaScript, unles—

overridden by a local occurrence of thk  LANGUAG¨  attribute. A Web server may alsf

be configured to issue such a headerì

External Script“

You also can place the script code in a separate file and specify that file by using thk

SR‚  attribute that specifies the URL of the script to include. For example,

<SCRIPT SRC="http://www.bigcompany.com/scripts/myscript.js"L

</SCRIPTL

loads a script called myscript.js, specified by the URL for thk  SR‚  attributeì

 = Page 531 =

510  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

When including an external script in a page by setting thk  SR‚  attribute, thk

LANGUAG¨  attribute may not be used. While JavaScript is assumed anyway, the filk

extension of the file is used by the Web server to specify the scripting language. Thk

Web server should map the extension to the appropriate MIME type—in this case,

application/x-javascript  —so that the browser receiving the file knows what to do wit—

it. Older servers may require a MIME type that is configured to allow remote inclusio-

of script filesì

One major advantage of external scripts is that a browser may cache the script fil—

locally. If the same script code is used over and over again, the files that reference iP

would require only the simpl—  <SCRIPTA  statement and would be able to reuse th—

cached copy. Considering how much script code is inserted in many pages, this coul

improve site efficiency.

Scripting and Non-Script-Aware Browser“

One advantage to referencing external script files is that it provides compatibility foK

older, no™JavaScripâaware browsers. A browser simply ignores any tags that iš

doesn’t understand, so nothing happens when an older browser reads ¾  <SCRIPT

element that uses a-  SR‚  attribute. If the script is used inline, as shown here, oldeK

browsers that don't understand JavaScript will display the statemenš  alert ("I am 

Script.");  onscreen instead of executing it:

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

alert("I am a script.");

</SCRIPTL

To improve compatibility with no™JavaScripâaware browsers, scripting codk

should be commented out. In JavaScript, this would be accomplished as shown here:

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

alert("I am a script.");

//--L

</SCRIPTL

Notice how the HTML comment starts the exclusion of JavaScript, buš  //’-  is used tf

close the comment. This is because JavaScript interprets lines wit— as comments an™  /

does not attempt to run a comman™  -’  as a commandì

Commenting out VBScript code is similar, requiring only a simple comment, a—

shown here:

 = Page 532 =

ChapteX 13  Introductio‘ tW Scriptin‚ an HTMP  51h

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="VBScript"L

<!-p

MsgBox "Hello World!", 0, "h

' --L

</SCRIPTL

Other languages may have different commenting styles for hiding the script codk

from the no™scripâaware browserì

<NOSCRIPT>

Like other extensions to HTML, thk  <SCRIPT  element supports a special element tf

deal with browsers that don't execute a script. Thk  <NOSCRIPT  element is used tf

enclose alternative text and markup for browsers that don't interpret a scriptì

Furthermore, users can turn off support for a scripting language in their browsersì

Thk  <NOSCRIPT  content renders onscreen, as shown in the following example,

if the user has turned off scripting support or is using a browser that doesn'š

understand JavaScript:

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  JavaScript and NOSCRIP  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

document.write('<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  JavaScript is ON  </H1>');

//--L

</SCRIPTL

<NOSCRIPTL

<BL  Please turn on JavaScript if you have it and reload thi?

page!  </BL

</NOSCRIPTL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 533 =

51p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Although this example works, some confusion currently exists between thk

specification and current browser actions in relation tf  <NOSCRIPT  when thk

language is not understood. According to the HTML 4.0 specification, browsers shoul™

evaluate the content i-  <NOSCRIPT  when the scripting language used earlier in thk

<SCRIPT  statement is not understood. In the case of the imaginary language name™

BozoScript, the browser should evaluate the content i-  <NOSCRIPT  in the marku5

shown here:

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="BozoScript"L

This is bozo language<

</SCRIPTL

<NOSCRIPTL

I don't understand BozoScript<

</NOSCRIPTL

Unfortunately, this is not how browsers act in all cases. In fact, browsers ma_

ignore thk  <NOSCRIPT  statement in this case. Furthermore,  <NOSCRIPT  has ¾

major problem when you consider that multiple occurrences of thk  <SCRIPT  elemenš

can occur in a document. This raises an important question: whic—  <NOSCRIPT

occurrence matches whic—  <SCRIPT  ? The natural assumption is that the firsš

<NOSCRIPT  element following a particulaK  <SCRIPT  element would match thaš

<SCRIPT  element; but is this, or should this, be the way things work?

Script Events and HTM¤

Earlier in this chapter, the section “Including Scripts in an HTML Document”

mentioned that script code could be added to HTML documents through speciaR

attributes calle™  event handlerx  . What are events? Events occur as the result of a useK

action or, potentially, an external event, such as a page loading. Examples of event—

include a user clicking a button, pressing a key, moving a window, or even simpl_

moving the mouse around the screen. HTML provides a way to bind a script to thk

occurrence of a particular event, through a-  event handler attribut—  . This is the namk

of the event, prefixed by the wor™ ; for example,  oc  onclick  . The following code show—

how thk  onclick  event handler attribute is used to bind some script to a button click

occurrence:

<FORML

<BUTTON onclick='alert("Hey this is JÆaScript")' VALUE="Press Me"L

</FORML

 = Page 534 =

ChapteX 13  Introductio‘ tW Scriptin‚ an HTMP  51

Under HTML 4, event handler attributes can be added to quite a number of HTML

elements. In practice, event handler attributes are most commonly associated wit—

form controls specified by thk  <INPUT <SELECT <TEXTAREA  ,  ,  , an™

<BUTTON  elements, though this is changing with the rise of DHTML. As Table 13-3

shows, HTML 4 defines a wide range of events for nearly all the elementsì

The core event model according to HTML 4 include—  onclick ondblclick  ,  ,

onkeydown onkeypres—onkeyup onmousedown onmousemov2 onmouseout  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

onmouseove(  , an™  onmouseup  . These core events are defined for nearly all HTML

elements in which the element is displayed onscreen. As used in Table 13-3, thk

expression “Most elements” is meant to include the following:

<A  <CAPTION  <DIR

<ACRONYM  <CENTER  <DIV

Obviously, certain structuring or miscellaneous elements do not make any sense foK

events. Under the HTML 4.0 specification, these include the following elements:  PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

<APPLET  <HTML

<BASE  <IFRAME

<HEAD

The HTML 4.0 specification indicates thaP  <APPLETA  an  <FONTA  do not take th—

core events. However, some browsers do define events for them.

Certain elements under HTML 4 have their own special events outside this cork

event model. For example, thk  <BODY  an™  <FRAMESET  elements have an evenš

for loading and unloading pages, so both elements also have thk  onload  an™  onunload

event attributes. In the case of thk  <FRAMESET  element, the load and unload event—

don't fire until all the frames have been loaded or unloaded, respectively. Thk

<FORM  element itself also has two special events that are typically triggered whe-

the user clicks the submit or reset button. These events ark  onsubmit  an™  onreset  . O“

course, with scripting, these events may fire for other reasons. Last, the primary for“

 = Page 537 =

51‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

element types under HTML 4 ark  <BUTTON <INPUT <LABEL <SELECT  ,  ,  ,  , an™

<TEXTAREA  . For text fields set with thk  <INPUT  element, you can catch the focu—

and blur events wit—  onfocu—  an™  onblu(  . These events fire when the user accesses thk

field and moves on to another one. You can also watch for the select event wit—

onselect  , which is triggered when a user selects some text, as well as the change evenš

(  onchang2  ), which is triggered when a field's value changes and loses focusì

The following markup illustrates simple use of the HTML 4 event attributes wit—

form elements and links:

You may encounter problems with th—  onfocus  demo under some versions of Netscape¨

because it may not release the focus event. This does not occur under all versions of th—

browser and, hopefully, will be fixed in the version that you are testing under.

While the example events should work equally well under Internet Explorer 4 an™

Netscape 4 browsers, the extent to which the events can be used in various element—

varies from browser to browser. For example, thk  onclick  handler is defined for nearl_

all elements, includiný  <B <SPAN  ,  , and eve-  <HR  . However, only Interneš

Explorer 4 and above currently support markup such as the following:

<B onclick='alert("You clicked the bold text")'L  Click her4  </BL

As of the time of this writing, Netscape does not provide as rich an event or objecš

model as the HTML 4.0 specification defines, but future versions such as 5 promise tf

support the full HTML 4 event model. Interestingly, both the browser—  dX  supporš

other events not in the current specificationì

Extended Event Model“

While HTML 4 specifies numerous events, Netscape and Internet Explorer supporš

many more events. Some of the events, such a—  onabort  , have been around sinck

Netscape 3 and are well understood. Thk  onabort  handler fires when a downloa™

of an image is not completed:

<IMG SRC="reallybigimportantimage.gifh

onabort='alert("Please reload page")'L

Other events, such as the numerous data binding events, are not nearly as welR

understood, and are supported only in Internet Explorer 4. Table 13-4 lists thesk

extended events, as well as their compatibilityì

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

As shown here, events currently vary from browser to browser. How these event—

can be captured also varies. Netscape currently supports a concept calle™  evenP

capturinv  , while Microsoft support—  event bubblinv  . The basic idea of event bubbling i—

that an event “bubbles up” through the document structure, starting from where iš

occurred. If a user clicks ¾  <B  element, it may be passed up to an enclosiný  <P

element, and then to thk  <BODY  element, and then disappear. Netscape takes thk

opposite approach, offering the event first to the highesâlevel structure and then o-

down. Such differences make coding cros-platform scripts somewhat difficultì

Furthermore, the extent of elements that support particular events is changing rapidlyì

Only some elements under Netscape can respond to events, but this will probabl_

change quicklyì

Internet Explorer 5 Event Preview

At the time of this writing, Internet Explorer 5 is nearing release stage. This browseK

introduces even more events for JavaScript. Notably, IE 5 introduces events dealiný

with the transfer of data within a page and from other applications by using the cut,

copy, and paste functions of a browser or application. These event handlers, which ark

fairly sel´explanatory, includk  oncopy onbeforecopy oncut onbeforecut onpast2  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

an™  onbeforepast2  . IE 5 also provides a rich model for drag and drop, with evenš

handlers foK  ondrag ondragend ondragente( ondragleav2 ondragove(  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  ondrop  ì

 = Page 547 =

52‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Internet Explorer 5 also introduces the ability to sense printing using the evenš

handler—  onafterprint  an™  onbeforeprint  . These may be useful to change the style of ¾

page or its content before printingì

One potentially useful new event handler for Internet Explorer 5 i—  oncontextmenu  ,

which can be triggered when a user trys to bring up the context menu for an objectì

This is generally invoked by a right mouse click by the user. Imagine having a WeD

interface in which the user could right click objects to trigger pošup menus. With thk

addition of these events to the existing proprietary and standard events, Web interface—

are nearly as rich as any modern graphical user interface environment. However, tf

guarantee compatibility, page authors should consider staying with events associate™

with form controls, as defined in the HTML 4.0 specificationì

Error Handler“

One interesting event handler that warrants special consideration i—  onerro(  . A-

onerro(  event handler executes scripting code when an error (typically a scriptiný

error) occurs while loading a document. The benefit to thk  onerro(  handler is that yo¾

can use it to turn off the annoying and often numerous error messages that may pesteK

a user when reading a misbehaving script. When used properly, you might eve-

provide the user with a simple feedback message, instructing the user what to do tf

rectify the problem, or even how to report the bug. To display the entire error messagk

in JavaScript and replace it, seš  window.onerro(  to the name of your special erroK

handler. Make sure to retur-  tru2  to suppress any normal scripting alerts. Thk

following example shows this idea in use:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Error HandleI  </TITLEL

<SCRIPT Language="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

window.onerror=displaySorry

function displaySorry(message, url, line)

{

var msg="There has been a scripting error.\nh

msg +="Please contact bugs@bigcompany.com\n";

msg +="Reference file: " + url

alert(msg);

return true;

}

//--L

 = Page 548 =

ChapteX 13  Introductio‘ tW Scriptin‚ an HTMP  52

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<SCRIPTL

bad script code;

</SCRIPTL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

The preceding “bad script code” will invoke a dialog box, as shown here:

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Many sites would benefit from adding such facilities to their pages to suppress an™

help clean up the numerous scripting errors that occurì

Because of the confusion of JavaScript error messages, starting with version 4.5, th—

Netscape browser suppresses most messages to a separate console.

Microsoft Event-Handling Extension“

Typically, event handlers are specified as attributes for the particular element wit—

which the event is associated. For example,

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" onclick="script"L

However, Microsoft also supports a different form of event handler, first in thk

form of an extension to thk  <SCRIPT  element, and second as a naming convention foK

VBScript. Under Internet Explorer, thk  <SCRIPT  element also has a-  EVEN  and ¾

FO  attribute. Thk  EVEN  attribute is used to define a particular event that should bk

 = Page 549 =

528  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

reacted to. Thk  FO  attribute is used to define the name or ID of the element that thk

event is tied to. Notice in the following example how thk  FO  attribute is associate™

with the particular button named myButton, and thk  EVEN  attribute is used tf

specify the event to respond to—in this case,  onclick  :

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Microsoft Alternate Event For—  </TITLEL

<SCRIPT FOR="myButton" EVENT="onclick" LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

alert("I've been clicked!");

//--L

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<FORML

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" NAME="myButton" VALUE="Click me"L

</FORML

</BODYL

</HTMLL

This form o“  <SCRIPT  handler is specific to Microsoft and will either ru-

incorrectly or even cause errors with Netscape browsers. Using VBScript, this style i—

very common. VBScript also supports a naming convention style for event handling:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Microsoft Alternate Event For—  </TITLEL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="VBScript"L

<!-p

Sub myButton_onclick

msgBox "I've been clicked!h

End Sub

'--L

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

 = Page 550 =

ChapteX 13  Introductio‘ tW Scriptin‚ an HTMP  529

<BODYL

<FORML

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" NAME="myButton" VALUE="Click me"L

</FORML

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Notice that the name of the subroutine has the event handler name in it and require—

no hooks into HTML. In some sense, this is the cleanest way to integrate scripts wit—

HTML, but JavaScript does not support this style of event handling. The extension—

introduced by Microsoft for event handling should be avoided, except when trying tf

access ActiveX controls, which tend to require thk  FO EVEN  /  style for JScript or thk

VBScript naming ideaì

Form Validation in JavaScrip  PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

So far, this chapter has looked at very simple changes to pages, such as writing out thk

last modification date of a page dynamically or creating a button that greets the userì

The basic examples are meant only to show the intersection of JavaScript with HTMLì

However, before moving on to more advanced forms of scripting, it is important tf

look at a very useful application of JavaScript—form validationì

Form validatioc  is the process of checking the validity of use§supplied data in a-

HTML form before it is submitted to a serve§side program, such as a CGI program. B_

prevalidating data before it is sent to a server, you can avoid a lot of user frustratio-

and reduce communication time between the Web browser and the serverì

The key to checking form data is naming the various form fields. Take a look at thk

example HTML markup shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Reading a Form Field  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<FORM NAME="myform" ACTION="cgi-bin/dosomething.pl" METHOD="POST"L

<BL  Name:  </BL

 = Page 551 =

530  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

INPU. TYPE="TEXTh NAME="usernameh SIZE=5h MAXLENGTH=5"><BR><BRL

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" VALUE="CHECK NAMEh

oclick="alert('You entered '+document.myform.usernamealue)"L

</FORML

</BODYL

</HTMLL

This example has a form name™  myfor…  and a text field name™  usernam2  insidk

the form. In both cases, the names were set by using thk  NAM¨  attribute, which i—

being phased out in HTML 4 in favor o“  I¤  . For backward compatibility,  NAM¨  wilR

always be used in this book for form validation. Next, notice that thk  onclick  evenš

handler creates an alert that reference—  document.myform.username.valu2  . This smalR

piece of JavaScript references the form name™  myfor…  in the current document; it—

field calle™  usernam2  ; and, finally, that object’s value property. So, if you run thk

simple example, you can see that reading the contents of any field that a user may filR

out is easyì

Under newer browsers, you may be able to use simply  username.valu¨  o(

myform.username.valu¨  . Be very careful, because although this will work under th—

latest browsers, older JavaScript-aware browsers such as Netscape Navigator 2 and 3

will fail. It would be ironic if your code to keep the user from making errors ended up

causing a different form of frustration. Remember, it is always best to reference you(

object explicitly so it will work in all situations.

Suppose that you want to make sure that the user enters something in each texš

field before submitting a form. Checking the contents of the field, as shown in thi—

example, is fairly easyì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Reading a Form Field  </TITLEL

<SCRIPTL

<!-p

functionqalidate()

{

if (document.myform.usernamealue == "")

alert('Please enter your name');

 = Page 552 =

ChapteX 13  Introductio‘ tW Scriptin‚ an HTMP  53h

else

alert('You entered '+document.myform.usernamealue)

}

// --L

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<FORM NAME="myform" ACTION="cgi-bin/dosomething.pl" METHOD="POST"L

<BL  Name:  </BL

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="username" SIZE=5h

MAXLENGTH=5"><BR><BRL

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTONh

VALUE="CHECK NAMEh

onclick=¡alidate()"L

</FORML

</BODYL

PROGRAMMING

</HTMLL

AND HTM¤

In this example, the functio-  validate()  is called and the contents of the fiel™

usernam2  is checked to see whether it is blank or contains information. If the fiel™

is left blank when the user clicks the button, the user is told to complete the field;

otherwise, the data entered is printed in the alert box. By making some simplk

modifications to the preceding example, you can change the button to a submiš

button and have the validation functio-  validate()  return ¾  tru2  oK  fals2  value tf

indicate whether the form submission is allowed to continue, as shown here:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Reading a Form Field  </TITLEL

<SCRIPTL

<!-p

functionqalidate()

{

if (document.myform.usernamealue == "")

{

 = Page 553 =

53p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

alert('Please ente you name');

retur false;

}

else

{

alert('Thank‚ fo you submissio '+document.myform.usernamealue);

retur true;

}

}

/X --L

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<FORV NAME="myformh ACTION="cgi-bin/dosomething.plh

METHOD="POSTh onSubmit="retur validate()"L

<BL  Name:  </BL

<INPU. TYPE="TEXTh NAME="usernameh SIZE=5h

MAXLENGTH=5"><BR><BRL

<INPU. TYPE="SUBMITh VALUE="CHECK NAME"L

</FORML

</BODYL

</HTMLL

This example uses the HTML event handler attributk  onsubmit  , which is triggere™

when the user clicks the submit button. The submission will occur unless the evenš

returns ¾  fals2  value. Notice how the validation functio-  validate()  returns ¾  tru2  oK

fals2  value, based upon the user's input. Expanding this example to check more field—

is not difficult, as was shown in the larger example at the end of Chapter 11ì

Another approach to form field validation is to catch errors as users move from field tX

field. By using th—  onblur  attribute, you can sense when a user has deselected a fiel

and is trying to select another field. Be careful: many users may be annoyed by forh

validation usinv  onblur  , and it may not even always work, because of bugs ic

JavaScript implementations.

The previous discussion is meant to serve only as a basic introduction to thk

concept of form validation. Even if you are an experienced programmer, it is noš

suggested that you go out and attempt to create your own validation scripts foK

 = Page 554 =

ChapteX 13  Introductio‘ tW Scriptin‚ an HTMP  53

[mail addresses, credit card numbers, ZIP codes, and so on. Many libraries alread_

exist that perform these tasks; these libraries are available from JavaScript archive site—

such as http://www.javascripts.com; http://javascript.internet.com; and Netscape'—

original form validation library, located at the following address:

http://developer.netscape.com/docs/examples/javascript/formval/overview.htmR

Form validation is only one example of how JavaScript may be useful in a WeD

page. The next chapter looks at how to embellish pages by using JavaScript an™

focuses on the idea of DHTML, which enables you to manipulate the very element—

of your pageì

Summar

Clienâside technologies have their place in a Web site. The evolution of scriptiný

technologies has of´loaded some of the processing that traditionally occurred on thk

server. For example, validating form field entries by using JavaScript or VBScript o-

the client makes more sense than relegating this processing to the server. Integratiný

PROGRAMMING

scripts into a Web page comes in two major forms: within thk  <SCRIPT  element an™

AND HTM¤

as event handlers in the form of HTML attributes. By using JavaScript or VBScript,

you can create simple interface changes or even perform useful tasks such as for“

validation. The intersection between HTML and scripting was originally very distinct;

but, as the next chapter explains, a script now can be used to modify the very element—

in a page by accessing the Document Object Model. When combining this approach tf

scripting Web pages with improved page layout facilities, such as style sheets, you ca-

make your pages come alive with interaction and movement: thus, DHTML is bornì

 = Page 555 =

Thispbbintentional8yleftPlank‘

 = Page 556 =

Chapte7 18

DynamihHTMP(DHTML)

53P

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 557 =

53‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

he previous chapter discussed how scripting languages such as JavaScript coul™

be added to HTML documents. One of the only reasonable application—

discussed was form validation. However, many Web developers are mork

¾

interested in making their buttons light up or making their pages come alive wit—

movement. This chapter discusses the idea of Dynamic HTML, or DHTML, which i—

the popular expression to describe interactive HTML pages. We’ll look at how to makk

rollover buttons and even how to animate positioned layers on a page. However,

before diving into the effects, it is important to understand what DHTML is all aboutì

You’ll see that entire Web pages, right down to the individual HTML elements an™

their content, soon will become changeable through a scripting language. Truk

Dynamic HTML won’t just be about moving the content around the screen, buš

changing it dynamically based on user desiresì

Dynamic HTML and the Documen

Object Model

Dynami´ HTML (DHTML) i— noš abouš neu tag— oK attribute— thaš ca- animatk pagesì

Dynami´ HTML actuall_ extend— thk currenš seš o“ HTML elements, an™ ¾ feu otheK thing—

likk stylk sheeš properties, b_ allowiný the“ tf bk accesse™ an™ modifie™ b_ ¾ scriptiný

languagk likk JavaScripš oK VBScriptì Dynami´ facilitie— ca- bk adde™ b_ exposiný tag— tf ¾

scriptiný language; thi— allow— page— tf comk alivk wit— movemenš an™ interactivityì Thk

tag— i- ¾ pagk ark accesse™ throug— thk Documenš Objecš ModeR (DOM)ì

Every Web document is made up of a variety of elements likk  <B <IMG  ,  , an™

<FORM  . Browsers read pages in a regular fashion because they understand thk

extent of the objects that are possible in a page. A page might be composed of threk

image elements, two paragraphs, an unordered list, and the text within these elementsì

The DOM describes each document as a collection of individual objects like images,

paragraphs, and forms, all the way down to the individual characters. Each particulaK

object may have properties associated with it, typically in the form of HTML attributesì

For example, the paragraph element has an alignment attribute that may be set to left,

right, or center. In the object model, this attribute is called a property of the object. A-

object may have methods that are associated with it, and events that may occur an™

affect it. An image tag may have a-  onmouseove(  event that is triggered when a useK

places the cursor over the image. A form may have a submit method that can be use™

to trigger the submission of the form and its contents to a serve§based CGI programì

Thk besš wa_ tf explai- thk DOM i— wit— a- exampleì Lookaš thi— simplk HTML file:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Big Companh  </TITLEL

</HEADL

 = Page 558 =

ChapteX 14  Dynamih HTMP (DHTML)  53

<BODY BGCOLOR="white"L

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  Big Companh  </H1L

<HRL

<P ID="para1"L  This is a paragraph of text<  </PL

<ULL

<LI><A HREF="about.htm"L  AbouM  </AL

<LI><A HREF="products.htm"L  Product?  </AL

</ULL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

This file could be modeled as a parse tree, as shown in Figure 14-1. The structure™

breakdown of HTML elements and how they enclose one another should be familiaK

even from the first chapter of this bookì

PROGRAMMING

The concept of the Document Object Model is that there is a rigid structure define™

AND HTM¤

to access the various HTML elements and text items that make up a document. Thi—

model starts from the browser window itself. A typical window contains either ¾

document or a collection of frames (basically windows) that in turn contain documentsì

Within a document is a collection of HTML elements. Some of these HTML elements,

particularly forms, contain even more HTML elements, and some may contain textì

The key to accessing the elements in a document is to understand the hierarchy an™

make sure to name the various elements in the page using either thk  I¤  or thk  NAM¨

Figurs 14-18  Parse tree for example HTML filP

 = Page 559 =

538  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

attribute. In the previous example, you may want to address the first paragraph o“

text, which happens to have thk  I¤  o“  para1  . It could be referenced under Interneš

Explorer 4 or above using a JavaScript identifier likk  window.document.all['para1']  ,

document.all['para1']  , or simpl_  para1  . Sinck  para1  refers to ¾  <P  element, you ma_

want to manipulate its attributes (for example, thk  ALIGN  attribute). Adding the wor™

align  to any of the object references previously mentioned, in the for“  para1.align  ,

should give us access to the value of this attribute. The following example, whic—

works currently only under Internet Explorer 4 or above, shows how you coul™

manipulate the alignment of the paragraph dynamicallyì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  The Dynamic Paragrap—  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODY BGCOLOR="white"L

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  The Dynamic Paragrap—  </H1L

<HRL

<P ID="para1"L  I am a dynamic paragraph. Watch me dance!  </PL

<HRL

<SPAN onClick="para1.align='right'"L  [ Shift Right ]  </SPANL

<SPAN onClick="para1.align='left'"L  [ Shift Left ]  </SPANL

<SPAN onClick="para1.align='center'"L  [ Shift Center ]  </SPANL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

§- thk previou— example, ever_ timk thk useK click— f- thk spanne™ text, thk actuaR valuk

o“ thk  ALIGN  attributk foK thk  <P  taý i— manipulatedì O“ course, i“ yo¾ vieu thk sourck o“

thk pagk yo¾ won’š notick anything, buš thi— i— basicall_ whaš i— happeningì Notk thaš thk

lasš examplk wilR noš workundeK Netscapk 4ì  x  –generatio- browsersì Thk difference—

betwee- thk twf browsers’ approac— tf Dynami´ HTML wilR bk discusse™ shortlyì

The DOM can be complex, but what it can do is impressive—without alway—

requiring a great deal of work. Developers may use the object model to find an imagk

on a page and replace it with another image when a user rolls a cursor over it. Suc—

rollovers, or animated buttons, are already common on the Web. In conjunction wit—

scripting, the DOM can also animate a page by moving objects around, set up a-

expanding tree structure to navigate a site, or create a complex application like a gamk

or database front end. To seasoned JavaScript programmers, many of these ideas mighš

not sound so new. They’ve been around in a limited form since Netscape 2. Beginniný

 = Page 560 =

ChapteX 14  Dynamih HTMP (DHTML)  539

with that release, JavaScript provided an object model that allowed access to man_

parts of a Web page, including anchors, form elements, and images. True Dynami´

HTML, however, takes the idea much further. It gets right down to the actual text,

styles, tags, and scripts within a page, making the whole page modifiableì

Thk DOM i— thk cork componenš o“ bot— browseK vendors’ ide¾ o“ Dynami´ HTMLì

A— define™ b_ thk Worl™ Widk WeD Consortiu“ (http://www.w3.org/pub/WWW/

MarkUp/DOM/), DOM i— ¾ “platforf an™ languag[neutraR interfack thaš wilR allou

program— an™ script— tf dynamicall_ acces— an™ updatk thk content, structure, an™ stylk

o“ documents.” Thk WeD standard— bod_ ha— alread_ release™ thk LeveR Ç specificatio- o“

thk DOM thaš include— thk syntax foK accessiný pagk elementsì Aš thk timk o“ thk writiný

o“ thi— book, thk browseK vendor— havk gonk faK beyon™ thk definitio- o“ thk currenš

DOM i- somk area— buš stilR lacksupporš foK somk o“ it— basi´ featuresì

The definition of Dynamic HTML as a DOM isn’t precisely what is meant b_

DHTML in the commercial arena. There, DHTML can include style sheets, absolutk

positioning, multimedia effects, database access facilities, dynamic fonts, an™

potentially any other thing that can make a page dynamic. This is where the confusio-

about Dynamic HTML arises. Netscape and Microsoft have the same basic idea abouš

the DOM, and both companies are working jointly with the W3C to develop ¾

PROGRAMMING

standard; but when it comes down to specific details, DHTML varies (ofte-

AND HTM¤

significantly) between the two leading browser vendors. This can cause trouble foK

designers looking to create cros-platform dynamic pagesì

Object Model“

Since Netscape 2, the browser, window, document, and document contents—forms,

images, links, and so on—have been modeled as a collection of objects. This i—

generically referred to as a-  object model  or, more precisely, the Document Object ModeR

(DOM). Both of the major browsers support the DOM idea, but each has differenš

naming conventions and a different degree of exposure. For example, in Netscape 3,

only particular items—form elements—are accessible for scripting. Figure 14-2

illustrates the object model for Netscape 3 and Internet Explorer 3ì

Objects in the Netscape 3 object hierarchy provide access not only to page element—

like links, anchors, frames, and forms, but to things like the browser’s name, history,

pluins, and Java classes associated with the current windowì

With the introduction of Netscape 4, more elements, such as layers, are accessibleì

Under Internet Explorer 4, all page elements are scriptable, and it is obvious thaš

Netscape will soon follow suit, making the entire page modifiable. Figure 14-3 show—

an expanded object model. Note that many of the items in this model are available onl_

under one browser or anotherì

Once the objects that make up a page are accessible, there are certain changes thaš

must be made to HTML documents, particularly concerning correct markup an™

naming of elementsì

 = Page 561 =

540  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 14-28  Object model for Netscape 3–generation browser9

 = Page 562 =

ChapteX 14  Dynamih HTMP (DHTML)  54h

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Figurs 14-38  Expanded object model for Netscape 4–generation browser9

 = Page 563 =

54p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

HTML and Scripting Acces“

While the DOM specifies a model for all the objects and HTML elements that make ¾

Web page, they need to be named properly to allow scripting languages to easily rea™

and manipulate them. The basic way to attach a unique identifier to an HTML elemenš

under HTML 4 is by using thk  I¤  attribute. Thk  I¤  attribute is associated with nearl_

every elementì

The point of thk  I¤  attribute is to bind a unique identifier to the element. To name ¾

particular enclosed bolded piece of texš  SuperImportant  , you could use the marku5

shown here:

<B ID="SuperImportant"L  This is very important<  </BL

Naming is very important. Authors are encouraged to adopt a consistent naminý

style and to avoid using potentially confusing names that include the names of HTML

elements themselves. For example,  button  does not make a very good name, and ma_

interfere with scripting language accessì

NAME Attributs

Before HTML 4, thk  NAM¨  attribute was often used to expose items to scripting. FoK

backward compatibility, thk  NAM¨  attribute is commonly defined foK  <A  ,

<APPLET <BUTTON <EMBED <FORM <FRAME <IFRAME <IMG  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

<INPUT <OBJECT <MAP <SELECT  ,  ,  ,  , an™  <TEXTAREA  . The HTML 4.0

specification does not support all of these. In particular,  <FORM  an™  <IMG  ark

missing, an™  <OBJECT  has a different meaning. Notice that the occurrence of thk

NAM¨  attribute corresponds closely to the Netscape 3 object modelì

Both  <METAA  an  <PARAMA  support attributes calle  NAMJ  , but these have totally

different meanings than script access.

Page developers must be careful to usk  NAM¨  where necessary to ensurk

backward compatibility with older browsers. Earlier browsers will not recognize thk

I¤  attribute, so usk  NAM¨  as well. However, a—  NAM¨  an™  I¤  share the samk

namespace, you must not use the same value for both. A—  I¤  is not cas[sensitive,

values differentiated only by case are not allowed. For example,  <A NAME="link1"

ID="LINK1"  is not legal. If the names clash, what happens remains unclear; somk

browsers may ignore the second occurrence, while others may disable script accessì

Another consideration when adding scripting to a page is whether the HTML i—

well formed. Simple things such as crossed elements, as shown here,

<B><IL  TesM  </B></IL

 = Page 564 =

ChapteX 14  Dynamih HTMP (DHTML)  54

may cause a problem with a scripting language. This has to do with the manipulatio-

of the text within the elements. Page authors should consider it dangerous tf

manipulate poorly formed markup with scripts; according to the HTML 4.0

specification, the results are unpredictableì

When HTML documents are well formed, scripting languages such as JavaScripš

and VBScript can be used to read and manipulate the various objects in a page. DOM

defines a special set of reserved names that use this notation to allow scriptiný

languages like JavaScript to refer to entities in the browser and the document,

including form elements. The basic notation uses a series of object and property name—

separated by dots. To access the form defined b_

<FORM NAME="myform"L

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="username"L

</FORML

with a scripting language, use eitheK  window.document.myfor…  or simpl_

document.myfor…  . The field and its value can be accessed in a similar fashion. Tf

access the text field, usk  document.myform.usernam2  . To access the actual value of thk  PROGRAMMING

usernam2  field, access thk  valu2  property usiný  document.myform.username.valu2  ì  AND HTM¤

Note that, as shown previously, it may also be possible to use a shorthand notatio-

such a—  myform.username.valu2  , as supported under Internet Explorerì

This simple naming style can be used to access the properties of the various object—

that make up the document. The following example, similar to those in the last chapter,

shows the concept in action as the contents of a form field are accessed and displaye™

dynamically in an alert window:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Meet and GreeM  </TITLEL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

function sayHello()

{

theirname=document.myform.usernamealue;

if (theirname !="")

alert("Hello "+theirname+"!");

else

alert("Don't be shy.");

}

// --L

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

 = Page 565 =

54  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<BODYL

<FORM ACTION="mailto: info@bigcompany.comh

METHOD="POST" NAME="myform"L

<BL  What's your name?  </BL

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="username" SIZE=0"> <BR><BRL

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" VALUE="Greet" onclick='sayHello()'L

</BODYL

</HTMLL

One potential problem to overcome with naming document objects is thk  NAM¨

an™  I¤  namespace conflict. Older browsers only understan™  NAM¨  , while thk

specification encourage—  I¤  . A likely approach would be simply to set thk  NAM¨  an™

I¤  attributes to be the same values as those shown here:

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="username" ID="username"L

According to the specification, this approach is not supposed to work becausk

NAM¨  an™  I¤  share the namespace, creating a conflict. In practice, browsers don’š

seem to care. Scripting could be used to deal with different names for the same object,

but that introduces needless complexity. The simple solution is to usk  NAM¨  on alR

elements that support it an™  I¤  on the new elementsì

Besides accessing the properties of various document objects, it is also occasionall_

possible to trigger actions calle™  methodx  . An example of a method would be to submiš

a form. In the last example,  document.myform.submit()  would submit the form to thk

address specified by thk  ACTION  attribute for thk  <FORM  elementì

The previous example only scratches the surface of the DOM. It is possible to refeK

to forms and form elements without assigning them a name using an array notationì

Forms can be referred to with a forms array that includes a number beginning at 0ì

Elements within a form can be referred to with an elements array that includes ¾

number beginning at 0. The previous example contains only one form and onk

field, so the syntax  document.forms[0].elements[0].valu2  is the same a—

document.myform.username.valu2  . Note that it is better to name elements ratheK

than to access them via their position in a page, since any additions or movemenš

of the HTML elements within the page may potentially break the scriptì

It is also possible, in some cases, to update the contents of certain elements such a—

form fields. The following example code shows how this might be done:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Meet and Greet 2  </TITLEL

 = Page 566 =

ChapteX 14  Dynamih HTMP (DHTML)  54

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

function sayHello()

{

theirname = document.myform.usernamealue;

if (theirname != "")

document.myform.responsealue="Hello "+theirname+"!";

else

document.myform.responsealue="Don't be shy.";

}

// --L

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

<BODYL

PROGRAMMING

<FORM NAME="myform"L

AND HTM¤

<BL  What's your name?  </BL

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="username" SIZE=0"> <BR><BRL

<B>Greeting:</BL

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" NAME="response" SIZE="40"> <BR><BRL

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" VALUE="Greet" onclick='sayHello()'L

</BODYL

</HTMLL

You may have noted the use o  NAMJ  rather thac  Ir  in this example.(nfortunately¨

with form elements, browser support is inconsistent with th—  Ir  attribute and may

cause errors. Try switching ouP  NAMJ  fo(  Ir  if you are using a 5. –generatioc  x

browser, and you should get the same result.

Under Netscape 3 and 4 and Internet Explorer 3, only some objects in a page ark

changeable, notably form elements. Starting with Internet Explorer 4, everything in ¾

page can be modified right down to the very text and markup itself. This is the reaR

idea of Dynamic HTML. Look at the following markup:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Simple DHTML for IE4  </TITLEL

<BR><BR><BRL

<SPAN onclick="bold1.innerText='Click me'"L  [ Chang4 texM back ]  </SPANL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Notice that thk  <B  element is name™  bold1  . This is later referenced by thk  <SPAN

element. Furthermore, notice that the actual text is changed when the user clicks on thk

text regions. It is obvious that this form of DHTML is very powerful, particularly whe-

you consider that it can also be used to control style sheetsì

Script Interaction with Style Sheet“

Both Netscape and Microsoft support scripting access for style sheets. Of course, thk

variations between the two browsers are significant. Currently, Microsoft and Netscapk

differ on how style sheets can be accessed and the degree to which they can bk

manipulated. For example, under Netscape 4 the only style sheet properties that can bk

changed after the document has loaded are the absolute positioning propertie—  left  ,

top z-index  ,  , an™  visibility  ì

Microsoft has shown the extent to which style sheets can be manipulated vi¾

scripting language. It is assumed that Netscape 5ì –generation browsers will supporš  x

such manipulation as well. The following code fragment shows how events can be tie™

with style changes to make text that changes to red when the mouse is over it:

<A HREF="http://www.yahoo.comh

onmouseover='this.style.color="#FF0000"'

onmouseout='this.style.color="#0000FF"'L  Yahoo!  </AL

The special scripting keywor™  thi—  is a shortcut reference to the current element, but a-

I¤  attribute could be used just as well, as shown here:

<A HREF="http://wwwyahoocomh

ID="yahoolinkh

onmouseover='yahoolink.style.color="red";

yahoolink.style.fontSize="larger"'

 = Page 568 =

ChapteX 14  Dynamih HTMP (DHTML)  54

onmouseout='yahoolink.style.color="blue";

yahoolink.style.fontSize="smaller"'

STYLE="color: blue"L

Yahoo!  </AL

It is also possible to use multiple style sheet rules, as presented in Chapter 10. In thk

last example, the size and color of the text are changed when the mouse rolls over itì

Using positioning, style sheets, and scripting, it is possible to make some very dynami´

pages with little effort, as you will see in the next two sectionsì

Rollover Button“

The preceding examples demonstrate how scripting can be used to manipulate the look

of a link as a user rolls over it. A feature available since Netscape calle™  dynami

buttons¨  commonly calle™  rollover buttons¨  is one of the first common examples o“

PROGRAMMING

dynamic page manipulation using JavaScript, although it predates DHTML. We wilR

AND HTM¤

first explore traditional JavaScript rollovers and then take a look at their mork

advanced DHTML cousinsì

A  rollover buttoc  is a button that becomes active when the user positions the mousk

over it. The button may also have a special activation state when it is pressed. To creatk

a rollover button, you will first need at least two, perhaps even three images, tf

represent each of the button’s states—inactive, active, and unavailable. A sample set o“

rollover images is shown here:

In order to add this rollover image to the page, simply use thk  <IMG  tag likk

another image. The idea is to swap the image out when the mouse passes over thk

image and switch back to the original image when the mouse leaves the image. B_

literally swapping the value of thk  SR‚  attribute, you can achieve the rollover effectì

This is in essence what the following script, which should work in Netscape 3 an™

Internet Explorer 4, would do:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  RolloveI  </TITLEL

 = Page 569 =

548  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

/* Check to ensure rollovers work *X

if (document.images)

{

/* preload the images *X

buttonoff = new Image();

buttonoff.src = "buttonoff.gif";

buttonon = new Image();

buttonon.src = "buttonon.gif";

}

function On(imageName)

{

if (document.images)

{

document[imageName].src = eval(imageName+"on.src");

}

}

function Off(imageName)

{

if (document.images)

{

document[imageName].src = eval(imageName+"off.src");

}

}

// --L

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  Rollover FuY  </H1L

<HRL

<A HREF="http://www.yahoo.com" onmouseover="On('button')h

onmouseout = "Off('button')"L

<IMG SRC="buttonoff.gif" NAME="button" WIDTH="90" HEIGHT=0h

BORDER="0"></AL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

 = Page 570 =

ChapteX 14  Dynamih HTMP (DHTML)  549

Let’s take a look at how the code works. The first section of the JavaScript checks tf

make sure the browser supports the images part of the Document Object Model. Thi—

capability is necessary to make the rollover buttons work. If the browser supports thi—

feature, the images are loaded in and assigned names. Once the page is loaded, thk

user can move the mouse over the image. The link, as indicated by thk  <A  element,

has two event handlers: one for the mouse passing over the image (  onmouseove(  ) an™

one for the mouse leaving the image (  onmouseout  ). These handlers call thk  On()  an™

Off()  functions, respectively. Thk  On()  function simply sets thk  SR‚  of thk  <IMG

element to the name of the image passed to it and append—  on.sr8  , which changes thk

image to the on state. Thk  Off()  function does the opposite by setting thk  SR‚  equal tf

the image name wit—  off.sr8  appended to it. The key to adding more images is thk

names. For example, if you wanted to add another button calle™  button1.gif  , yo¾

would add the following code to thk  <SCRIPT  element within the firsš  if  statement,

button1off = new Image();

button1off.src = "button1off.gif";

button1on = new Image();

buttonon1.src = "button1on.gif";

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

and the following code later on in the document:

<A HREF="URL to load " onmouseover="On('button1')h

onmouseout = "Off('button1')"L

<IMG SRC="buttonoff1.gif" NAME="button1" WIDTH="90h

HEIGHT=0" BORDER="0"></AL

Because rollovers are so common on Web sites, there are many sites, such a—

http://www.webreference.com/javascript, that offer rollover tutorials. Tools such a—

Macromedia’s Dreamweaver can create the code instantly when they are provide™

with two imagesì

Style Sheet–Based Rollover“

One potential downside to imag[based rollovers is that you need numerous image—

for every single button on a page. If you have a menu with nine choices, you may fin™

you are downloading 18 images for a twkstate button or even 27 images for ¾

thre[state button. The number of images can certainly affect download time, so yo¾

may desire to find a way to create interesting text buttons without graphics using stylk

sheets. The following code illustrates how we can set the color and size of a link as ¾

mouse rolls on and off the link under Internet Explorer. It is possible to create a clunk_

version of this that works in Netscape, but they should eventually support this form o“

rollover in a future browserì

 = Page 571 =

550  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  CSS Rollover 1  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p

A        {color: blue;}

.over    {color: red; font-size: larger}

--L

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<A HREF="http://www.yahoo.com" onmouseover="this.className='over'h

onmouseout="this.className=''"L  Visit Yahoo!  </AL

<BR><BRL

<A HREF="http://www.excite.com" onmouseover="this.className='over'h

onmouseout="this.className=''"L  Visit Excit4  </AL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Because text rollovers on links are so common, Microsoft even introduced a speciaR

pseudoclass for thk  <A  element calle™  hove(  . This pseudoclass, as well as thk  activ2

class, is now part of the CSS2 specification and is illustrated in this simple example,

which works in Internet Explorer 4 and beyond:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  CSS2 Text Rollover?  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p

A:link       {color: blue}     /* uØisited link *X

A:visited    {color: purple}   /*qisited link   *X

A:hover      {color: red}      /* mouse hovers   *X

A:actøe     {color: yellow}   /* actøe link    *X

--L

</STYLEL

</HEADL

ChapteX 14  Dynamih HTMP (DHTML)  55h

<BODYL

<A HREF="http://www.yahoo.com"L  Visit YahoB  !</AL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

There are many other forms of rollovers that are possible using DHTML and stylk

sheets. One interesting approach is the use of image map rollovers. The concept here i—

to make a solid button bar of all of´state and a solid button bar of all o™state, an™

place the o™state bar behind the of´state bar using style sheet positioning. Then yo¾

can write JavaScript code to reveal a portion of the covered image as the user rolls oveK

the button bar. The advantage to this approach is that it avoids having to downloa™

multiple images for every state of every button. This lo“bandwidth rollover approac—

and others are detailed at many sites about DHTML and JavaScript, including this one:

http://www.webreference.com/dhtml and http://www.webreference.com/j—

AND HTM¤

Moving Objects with DHTM¤

One of the unfortunate aspects of DHTML is that it is not supported in the same wa_

across browsers. Many of the preceding examples work only under Internet Explorer 4

or above. However, one area in which the browsers are very similar in their support i—

in the positioning of regions using style sheets and in the visibility of these regionsì

Both browsers support the movement of regions after load time as well as settiný

visibility of regions. With these rudimentary features, it is possible to create a variety o“

interesting animation and page effects, as illustrated in the following simple exampleì

As discussed in Chapter 10, objects can be positioned using style sheets. To positio-

a simple graphic with an explosion and the wor™  DHTM?  on it, use some markup likk

this:

<DIV ID="dhtml" STYLE="position:absolute; width:200px;

height:115px; z-index:1; left: 100px; top: 50px"L

<IMG SRC="dhtml.gif" WIDTH=75" HEIGHT="175"L

</DIVL

Moving the object is a little more difficult. The basic idea is to change thk  left  an™

top  properties of thk  <DIV  element by a set number of pixels every so often. The basi´

problem is that Netscape and Microsoft reference the object in their object model—

 = Page 573 =

55p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

differently. It is easy enough to detect what browser object model is in effect by usiný

some JavaScript code such as this:

var NS4 = (document.layers) ? 1 : 0;

var IE4 = (document.all) ? 1 : 0;

Basically, this code sets a variable calle™  NS4  tf  1  (true) if thk  document.layer—  objecš

exists, as this is something unique to Netscape, an™ (false) otherwise. The variablk  0

IE4  is set to true ( ) or false ( ) based on the existence of thk  1  0  document.al“  structureì

Once the browser is determined, you can then execute different code based on whic—

browser is being used. This code can be messy, so it is nicer to abstract away thk

difference by creating yet another way to reference the various properties of ¾

positioned region. Many libraries for doing this exist on the Webì

The following example modifies code from the Web Reference animation librar_

and provides a simple animation; the code has been simplified for readability and tf

provide only the necessary featuresì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  DHTML AnimatioY  </TITLEL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

var NS4 = (document.layers) ? 1 : 0;

var IE4 = (document.all) ? 1 : 0;

function AnimationObject(elementid)

{

this.element = (NS4) ? document[elementid] :

document.all[elementid].style;

this.actøe = 0;

this.timer = null;

this.path = null;

this.num = null;

this.name = elementid + "Var";

eval(this.name + " = this");

this.animate = Animate;

this.step = Step;

this.left = Left;

this.top = Top;

this.MoveTo = MoveTo;

this.SlideBy = SlideBy;

 = Page 574 =

ChapteX 14  Dynamih HTMP (DHTML)  55

this.SlideTo = SlideTo;

}

function Animate(inteal)

{

if (this.actøe)

return;

this.num = 0;

this.actøe = 1;

this.timer = setInteal(this.name + ".step()", inteal);

}

function Step()

{

this.MoveTo(this.path[this.num].x, this.path[this.num].y);

if (this.num >= this.path.length - 1)

{

PROGRAMMING

clearInteal(this.timer);

AND HTM¤

this.actøe = 0;

if (this.statement)

eval (this.statement);

}

else

{

this.num++;

}

}

/* Returns the left coordinate *X

function Left()

{

return (NS4) ? this.element.left : this.element.pixelLeft;

}

/* Returns the top coordinate *X

function Top()

{

return (NS4) ? this.element.top : this.element.pixelTop;

}

 = Page 575 =

55  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

/* Move element to x,y position *X

function MoveTo(x, y)

{

this.element.left = x;

this.element.top = y;

}

/* Slide the element by changex pixels on x axis, changey pixels o

y axis, using a time inteal specified by inteal in pixel step‚

specified by steps *X

function SlideBy(changex, changey, steps, inteal)

{

var startx = this.left();

var starty = this.top();

var finalx = startx + changex;

var finaly = starty + changey;

this.SlideTo(finalx, finaly, steps, inteal);

}

/* Slide the element to a particular point set by finalx and finaly i

increments of steps pixels with an inteal specified by inteal *X

function SlideTo(finalx, finaly, steps, inteal)

{

var startx = this.left();

var starty = this.top();

var changex = finalx - startx;

var changey = finaly - starty;

var stepx = changex / steps;

var stepy = changey / steps;

var steparray = new Array();

for (var i = 0; i < steps; i++)

{

 = Page 576 =

ChapteX 14  Dynamih HTMP (DHTML)  55

startx += stepx;

starty += stepy;

steparray[i] = new position(startx, starty);

}

this.path = steparray;

this.animate(inteal);

}

/* Return the position as an integerqalue *X

function position(x, y)

{

this.x = Math.round(x);

this.y = Math.round(y);

}

//--L

</SCRIPTL

PROGRAMMING

</HEADL

AND HTM¤

<BODY BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF" L

<DIV ID="dhtml" STYLE="position:absolute; width:200px; height:115px;

z-index:1; left: 100px; top: 50px"L

<IMG SRC="dhtml.gif" WIDTH=75" HEIGHT="175"L

</DIVL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-p

dhtmllayer = new AnimationObject("dhtml");

dhtmllayer.SlideBy(100, 150, 99, 50);

Before and after renderings of this example are shown in Figure 14-4ì

If you are an experienced programmer, this code won’t seem that difficult, buš

others might find it impossible to understand. It turns out that even using codk

libraries isn’t the best way to animate a page. Many companies have already release™

products that can be used to create DHTML animation easily. Probably the mosš

popular of these is Macromedia’s Dreamweaver, shown in Figure 14-5ì

Dreamweaver can generate the JavaScript to make your animation run with littlk

fuss and is even good at rollover buttons. Unless you plan to learn to program, using ¾

tool is a good ideaì

 = Page 578 =

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Figurs 14-58  Dreamweaver, a popular DHTML edito

Ramifications of DHTM¤

DHTML raises the requirements for Web developers significantly. First, to usk

DHTML, you need to make sure your pages are coded properly in HTML. Since yo¾

have been reading this book, you have a huge head start, because you have bee-

quoting attributes, naming elements, and generating your HTML in a structure™

fashion. Second, you need to understand style sheets. This isn’t terribly difficult eitherì

Third, you need to understand JavaScript very well. JavaScript isn’t a difficulš

language; but when all is said and done, those who know fundamental programminý

produce much better code than those who learn programming for the first time wit—

 = Page 579 =

558  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

JavaScript. It is sad to see just how many Web scripts don’t exhibit fundamental codiný

techniques, such as variable hiding, modularity, and even simple commenting an™

logical variable naming. It’s no wonder script code breaks all the time. Finally, yo¾

need to understand the Document Object Model. This isn’t difficult either, particularl_

if you think about HTML in a structured manner. If you consider all of the things yo¾

need to know to create a DHTML page, you realize that creating a DHTML page i—

much more complicated than creating a static HTML page. With DHTML, we havk

definitely moved from a page paradigm to a program paradigm, and with that come—

new complications. For example, testing becomes paramount. You can’t assume youK

page is correct just because it looks correct; the page has to be tested under numerou—

conditions, including displaying it under different browsers and other conditions. Thk

bottom line is that DHTML changes Web design so that there is much more emphasi—

on JavaScript, and you need to be sure you understand this technology just as well a—

you understand HTMLì

Summar

Script code can be used to modify elements within a page by accessing the Documenš

Object Model (DOM), particularly when the HTML is well formed and named usiný

thk  I¤  attribute. Modeling the document as a collection of objects has been done sinck

Netscape 2; but under DHTML, modeling has been taken to a new extreme. Nou

browsers such as Internet Explorer 4 can be used to manipulate anything on a WeD

page from simple text elements, such a—  <B  , to style sheets, to even the very text of thk

page itself. DHTML shows where clienâside computing is headed, but this poweK

comes at a price. For the moment, the standard DOM as specified by the W3C isn’š

consistently supported by browser vendors, so defensive programming techniques an™

major amounts of testing are required when building scripâfilled Web pages. If thk

page designer takes proper steps, client scripting does not have to be relegated tf

simple embellishments. It should be considered the “glue” that is used to bin™

elements of a Web page together, including embedded binary objectsì

 = Page 580 =

Chapte7 1@

Client-Sidf

Programming and HTMP

55

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 581 =

560  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

he last chapter discussed how scripting elements can be added to HTML pagesì

Scripts can manipulate a variety of form elements, and, in the case of Dynami´

HTML, the page elements themselves. Scripts are also used to access embedde™

¾

binary objects. As discussed in Chapter 9, embedded objects can be used to bring neu

media types, such as sounds and movies, to the Web. They can also be used to ad™

small executable programs to a page. Binary objects come in many forms, includiný

Netscape pluins, Java applets, and ActiveX controls. Each of these requires speciaR

HTML elements. In the future, all included media types will eventually be added wit—

thk  <OBJECT  element. Until objects are standardized, however, it is useful tf

understand each individual technology and how it might intersect with HTMLì

Scripting, Programming, and Object“

You might wonder why this chapter is separate from the last two. With both script—

and embedded objects, the interactivity takes place on the client side. What’s thk

difference? Why distinguish between scripting and objects? Remember the point o“

Web clienâside scripting—small bits of interpreted code used to add a bit o“

functionality to a page or fill the gaps in an application. Scripting i—  noP  necessarily a—

complex or general as programming, though it often seems like it is. Programming i—

more generalized than scripting; programming enables you to create just abouš

anything that you can imagine, though it tends to be more complex in some sense tha-

scripting. Think about checking the data fields of a form; you need only a few lines o“

code to make sure the fields are filled. Now consider trying to create somethiný

sophisticated, such as a We~based, résumé-handling system that can sort throug—

thousands of submissions a day. This takes more than a few lines of code, and shoul™

probably be programmed in a language such as Java, C/C++, or Visual Basicì

Scripting generally isn’t powerful enough to build full applications, but it can bk

useful in tying things together. As you build your Web application, you may decide tf

build the logic entirely on the server, in the form of a Common Gateway Interfack

(CGI) program, or you may use a clienâside technology (Java applets or ActiveX

controls). If you choose a clienâside technology, you’ll probably build the Web page—

with a combination of HTML, scripting, and embedded programming objects such a—

ActiveX controls, Netscape pluins, or Java applets. Building objects is not trivial. Iš

can require significant knowledge of programming. You may be able to string togetheK

premade objects, generically calle™  componentx  , by using HTML and either JavaScripš

or VBScript. Consequently, for most casual Web page designers, putting together ¾

custom object probably isn’t necessary. This chapter discusses each of the objecš

technologies, as well as how such objects can be inserted into a Web pageì

 = Page 582 =

ChapteX 15  Client-Sidf Programmin‚ an HTMP  56h

Plug-In“

Pluins were introduced by Netscape in Navigator 2 and above and supported b_

Internet Explorer 3. They address the communication and integration issues thaš

plagued helper applicationsì  Plug-inx  are small helper programs (components) that ru-

within the context of the browser itself. The pluin approach of extending a browser’—

features has its drawbacks, however. Users must locate and download pluins, instalR

them, and even restart their browsers. Many users find this rather complicatedì

Netscape 4 offers some installation relief with somewhat sel´installing pluins an™

other features, but pluins remain troublesome. To further combat this problem, man_

of the most commonly requested pluins, such as Macromedia’s Flash, are beiný

included as a standard feature with Netscape browsers. However, even if installatio-

were not such a problem, unfortunately, pluins are not available on every machine;

an executable program, oK  binary¨  must be created for each particular operating systemì

Because of this machin[specific approach, many pluins only work on Windows 95

and NT. A decreasing number of pluins work on Windows 3.1, Macintosh, or UNIXì

Finally, each pluin installed on a system is a persistent extension to the browser, an™

takes up memory and disk spaceì

PROGRAMMING

¾—k benefiš o“ pluin— i— thaš the_ ca- bk welR integrate™ intf WeD pagesì The_ ma_

AND HTM¤

bk include™ b_ usiný thk HTML element—  <EMBED  oK  <OBJECT  ì Typically, thk

<EMBED  syntax i— used, buš thk  <OBJECT  syntax i— thk preferre™ metho™ an™ wilR

eventuall_ supplanš  <EMBED  completelyì I- general, thk  <EMBED  elemenš take— a-

attribute— ofte- ark use™ tf indicatk thk pixeR dimension— o“ thk include™ object, i“

welcome.av[ thaš ca- bk viewe™ b_ thk Netscapk LiveVidef plui- (generall_ installe™

<EMBED SRC="welcome.Æi" HEIGHT="100" WIDTH="100"L

Thk  <EMBED  element displays the pluin (in this case a movie) as part of thk

HTML document in a rectangular area of the page (shown in Figure 15-1)ì

Although pluins can appear anywhere in a Web page, special limitations apply tf

pluins within ¾  <LAYER  element. Pluins use the main window, and usuall_

appear on top of all other contentì

A browser may have many pluins installed. To check which pluins are installe™

in Netscape, the user may enter a strange URL, such a—  about:plugin—  , or look undeK

the browser’s Help menu for an entry that reads “About Pluins.” The browser wilR

show a list of pluins that are installed, the associated MIME type that will invokk

each pluin, and information as to whether that pluin is enabled. Figure 15-2 show—

an example of the pluins information pageì

<EMBED> Synta¨

The primary way to load pluins for Netscape 2 and 3 and Internet Explorer 3 and i—

to use the HTML elemenš  <EMBED  , which is not part of the HTML 4.0 specificationì

It would be preferable to use thk  <OBJECT  element, which is part of the specification,

buš  <OBJECT  works only under Internet Explorer 3 and above, and Netscape 4 an™

above. For backward compatibility, you may have to use both forms, as shown later i-

this chapter. The general syntax of thk  <EMBED  element can be found in the elemenš

reference in Appendix Aì

The most important attribute for thk  <EMBED  element is probabl_  SR‚  , which i—

set to the URL of the data object that is to be passed to the pluin and embedded in thk

page. The browser generally determines the MIME type of the file—and thus thk

pluin to pass the data to—by the filename suffix. For example, a file such as test1.dcK

would be mapped to a MIME type of application/x-director and passed to ¾

Shockwave for Director pluin. In some cases, however, the pluin to use with ¾

particulaK  <EMBED  tag is not obvious. The pluin may not need to use a-  SR‚

attribute if it reads all of its data at run time or doesn’t need any external data; if nf

SR‚  attribute exists, how do you determine the proper pluin? The best way tf

PROGRAMMING

indicate the pluin is to use thk  TYP¨  attribute and set it to the MIME type, whic—

AND HTM¤

then uses the appropriate pluin. Don’t use thk  TYP¨  attribute to override a MIME

type or avoid using file extensions. In the following markup fragment, the file name™

mysteryfile has no filename suffix:

<EMBED SRC="mysteryfile" TYPE="application/x-director"L

Although ¾  TYP¨  attribute is used, this won’t work, because the server will sen™

the file with a contenâtype indication of plain/text or application/octeâstream, an™

the browser will attempt to handle it accordingly. Instead, the file should be name™

correctly. In general, you shouldn’t need thk  TYP¨  attribute if thk  SR‚  attribute can bk

used to infer the type. The use o“  TYP¨  is mandatory if thk  SR‚  is not setì

Because pluins are rectangular, embedded objects, similar to images, thk

<EMBED  element has many of the same attributes as thk  <IMG  element:

  ALIGN  Use to align the object relative to the page and allow text to flou

around the object. To achieve the desired text layout, you may have to use thk

<BR  element with thk  CLEA  attributeì

  HSPAC¨  an™  VSPAC¨  Use to set the buffer region, in pixels, between thk

embedded object and the surrounding textì

  BORDE  Use to set a border for the pluin, in pixels. As with images, settiný

this attribute to zero may be useful when using the embedded object as a linkì

  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  Use to set the vertical and horizontal size of thk

embedded object, typically in pixels, although you may express them a—

percentage values. Thk  UNITS  attribute also can be used to define the unit o“

 = Page 585 =

56  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

measuremenš foK thesk attributesì  UNITS  ha— ¾ pixeR value, b_ default, buš ¾ valuk

o“  EN  ca- bk use™ tf indicatk thaš hal“ thk poinš sizk shoul™ bk use™ a— thk

measuremenš unitì Value— foK  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  shoul™ alway— bk set, unles—

thk  HIDDEN  attributk i— usedì Settiný thk  HIDDEN  attributk tf  TRU¨  i- thk

<EMBED  elemenš cause— thk plui- tf bk hidde- an™ override— an_  HEIGH

an™  WIDTh  settings, a— welR a— an_ effecš thk objecš ma_ havk o- layoutì

AnotheK i-teresting attribute for thk  <EMBED  element i—  PALETT¨  , whic—

indicates the color palette for the pluin to use. By default, the pluin uses thk

background palette, but you can alternatively use the foreground color palette b_

setting the attribute tf  FOREGROUN¤  . Setting this value properly may avoid thk

annoying color shifting that occurs under Windows environments with limited coloK

support when switching between applications that use different color palettesì
