Attributes for Installation of Plug-in“

Users often have a difficult time installing pluins. Under Netscape 2, pluins ofte-

had to be found and installed manually. Users could visit the Pluin Plaza aš

Browserwatch (http://www.browserwatch.com), for example, and install the pluin—

that interested them. These pluins often came with installation scripts; a few require™

users to copy the pluin manually to the appropriate directory. The directory, usuall_

found in the same directory as the browser application itself, was name™  plug-in—  . O-

the UNIX system, however, the directory could be set by using the environmenš

variable NPX_PLUGIN_PATH, which defaulted to /usr/local/netscape/plugins,

~/netscape/plugins. This path could be different than where the browser applicatio-

was installedì

Having users figure out for themselves which pluin to install manually isn’t thk

best solution. You can set thk  PLUGINSPAG¨  attribute equal to a URL that indicate—

the instructions for installing the pluin. This way, if the browser encounters a-

<EMBED  element that it can’t handle, it visits the specified page and provide—

information on how to download and install the pluin. Starting with Netscape 4,

however, this attribute automatically points to a special Netscape pluin finder pageì

 = Page 586 =

ChapteX 15  Client-Sidf Programmin‚ an HTMP  56

The Netscape 4 browser release also simplifies the pluin installation process b_

introducing the JAR Installation Manager (JIM), which is used to install Java Archivk

files (JARs). JAR files are a collection of files, including pluins, that can bk

automatically downloaded and installed. Set thk  PLUGINURL  attribute for thk

<EMBED  element to the URL of a JAR file containing the pluin that is needed. If thk

user doesn’t have the appropriate pluin already installed, the browser invokes JIM

with the specified JAR file and begins the download and installation process. The useK

has control over this process. The downloaded objects may be signed—a type o“

authentication—to help users avoid downloading malicious code. Figure 15-3 shows ¾

sample JIM window under Netscape 4ì

In Netscape 4 and above, thk  PLUGINURL  attribute takes precedence oveK

PLUGINSPAG¨  . Usiný  PLUGINURL  rather tha-  PLUGINSPAG¨  is recommendedì

If neither attribute is used, the Netscape browser defaults to a pluin finder pageì

Although the JIM provides a great deal of help in dealing with pluins, it is ver_

specific to Netscape. Microsoft’s Internet Explorer does support thk  <EMBED

element, so any benefits of the JIM will not be experienced by Internet Explorer usersì

<NOEMBED>

Figurs 15-38  JIM window under Netscape 4

yo¾ tf providk somk alternativk texš oK markeÙu5 contentì I- thk followiný shorš

example, a- AV§ videf i— embedde™ i- thk pageì Thk  <NOEMBED  elemenš

contain— a- image, whic— i- tur- ha— a- alternativk texš readiný seš wit— thk  AL

attributeì Notk hou thk examplk degrade— fro“ ¾ ver_ sophisticate™ settiný alR thk

wa_ dow- šf ¾ texâonl_ environment:

<NOEMBEDL

<IMG SRC="welcome.gif" ALT="Welcome to Big Company, Inc."L

</NOEMBEDL

One potential problem with thk  <NOEMBED  approach occurs when a browseK

supports pluins but lacks the specific pluin to deal with the included binary objectì

In this case, the user is presented with a broken puzzl[piece icon or a similar icon, an™

then is directed to a page to download the missing pluin. You should set thk

PLUGINURL  oK  PLUGINSPAG¨  attribute to start the user on the process of gettiný

the pluin needed to view the contentì

<OBJECT> Syntax for Plug-In“

Starting with Netscape 4, thk  <OBJECT  element can be used to include a variety o“

object types in a Web page, including Netscape pluins. Like thk  <EMBED  element,

thk  <OBJECT  element’s attributes determine the type of object to include, as well a—

the type and location of the pluin. Thk  <OBJECT  element supports alternativk

representations, if the browser isn’t capable of supporting the object. Thk  <EMBED

element that currently is used for pluins does not handle this well, although it doe—

provide thk  <NOEMBED  syntax. The following is the syntax o“  <OBJECT  as iš

relates to thk  <EMBED  element (a more generalized discussion of thk  <OBJECT

element is presented in “ActiveX Controls,” later in this chapter):

<OBJEC

DATA="URL of Object's Data"

ALIGN="LEFT | RIGHT | TOP | BOTTOM | MIDDLE"

CODEBASE="URL"

CLASSID="URL of plug-in to download"

HEIGHT="pixels"

ID="Unique Identifier"

TYPE="MIME Type"

WIDTH="pixels">

Alternative HTML representation her4

</OBJECT>

 = Page 588 =

ChapteX 15  Client-Sidf Programmin‚ an HTMP  56

For the complete syntax of thk  <OBJECT  element, refer to the element reference i-

Appendix Aì

Thk  DATG  attribute represents the URL of the object’s data and is equivalent to thk

SR‚  attribute o“  <EMBED  . Like thk  <EMBED  element, thk  TYP¨  attribute represent—

the MIME type of the object’s data. This may sometimes be inferred from the value o“

thk  DATG  attribute. Thk  CODEBAS¨  attribute, which is similar to thk  PLUGINSPAG¨

attribute, represents the URL of the pluin. Thk  CLASSI¤  attribute is used to specif_

the URL to use to install the pluin, by using the JIM. If nf  CLASSI¤  attribute i—

specified and the object can’t be handled, the object is ignored, and any nested HTML i—

displayed. Thk  I¤  attribute is used to set the name of the object for scripting. If thk

browser can’t handle the type, or can’t determine the type, it can’t embed the objectì

Subsequent HTML is parsed as normal. The following is an example of using thk

LiveAudio pluin under Netscape 4 with thk  <OBJECT  syntax:

<OBJECT DATA="click.wÆ" TYPE="audio/wÆ" HEIGHT="60" WIDTH="14  "

AUTOSTART="FALSE"L

<BL  Sorry, no LiveAudio installed..<  </BL

</OBJECTL

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Page authors should avoid referencing pluins with thk  <OBJECT  element,

because compatibility issues with Microsoft Internet Explorer may ariseì

Scripting and Plug-In“

Pluins can be accessed from a scripting language. Each pluin in a document can bk

referenced in Netscape’s version of JavaScript as an element of thk  embeds[]  collection,

which is part of the document object. Thk  NAM¨  attribute should be set to a uniquk

identifier, so that the pluin can be accessed easily by name from a scripting languageì

Internet Explorer and Netscape 4 prefer the use of thk  I¤  attribute; the pluin may noš

work well with thk  NAM¨  attribute. For backward compatibility with Netscape 3ì –  x

generation browsers, thk  NAM¨  attribute should be used whenever possible. A-

example of how a pluin is named is shown here:

<EMBED SRC="welcome.Æi" NAME="WelcomeMovie" HEIGHT="100h

WIDTH="100"L

This example gives the LiveVideo pluin the name WelcomeMovie. After the pluin i—

named, it can be accessed from JavaScript a—  document.WelcomeMovi2  . If it is thk

second pluin on the page, it could also be referenced a—  document.embeds[1]  . Wh_

noš  document.embeds[2]  ? Ordered arrays in JavaScript start numbering at zero; sf

document.embeds[0]  references the first pluin,  document.embeds[1]  references thk

second pluin, and so onì

 = Page 589 =

568  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Under Netscape 3 and 4 and Internet Explorer 4, you can determine which pluin—

are available in the browser by using thk  plugins[]  collection, which is part of thk

navigator object in JavaScript. The following markup displays the pluins that ark

installed in a Netscape browser:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Print Plug-in?  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<x ALIGN="CENTER"L  Plug-ins Installed  </xL

<HRL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

if (navigator.appName == "Microsoft Internet Explorer")

document.write("Plug-ins[] collection not supported under IE");

els4

{

num_plugins = navigator.plugins.length;

for (count=0; count < num_plugins; count++)

document.write(navigator.plugins[count].name + "  <BRL  ");

}

</SCRIPTL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Note that this example will not display the pluins under Internet Explorer,

because that browser doesn’t support the samk  plugins[]  collection. Under Netscape,

however, you can use some simple i´then logic to determine which HTML to use if ¾

particular pluin is loaded in the browserì

After you name an occurrence of a pluin in a page, you may be able tf

manipulate the pluin’s actions even after you load the page. Netscape browsers,

starting with the 3ì generation, include a technology calle™  x  LiveConnecP  that enable—

JavaScript to communicate with Java applets and pluins. However, only thosk

pluins written to support LiveConnect can be manipulated by using LiveConnectì

Netscape’s LiveAudio, as presented in Chapter 9, does support LiveConnect. Usiný

LiveAudio in conjunction with LiveConnect, audikenhanced buttons can be createdì

The next simple example shows how the link could play a short sound when thk

mouse passes over it. This example could easily be extended to create animate™

buttons with synchronized sounds by using LiveConnectì

 = Page 590 =

ChapteX 15  Client-Sidf Programmin‚ an HTMP  569

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Audio Link  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<EMBED SRC="click.wÆ" HIDDEN="TRUE" AUTOSTART="FALSE"L

<A HREF="http://www.yahoo.comh

onmouseover="document.embeds[0].play(false)"L  Yahoo!  </AL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

The preceding example is very specific to Netscape. The implementation of LiveConnecP

is buggy and may not work under all versions of Navigator.

Tyiný togetheK pluin— b_ usiný ¾ scriptiný languagk i- conjunctio- wit—

LiveConnecš hint— aš thk poweK o“ suc— componenš model— a— Netscape’— pluinsì

AND HTM¤

Java Applet“

Sun Microsystems’ Java technology (http://www.javasoft.com) is an attractive,

revolutionary approach to cros-platform, Interneâbased development. Java promise—

a platforRneutral development language that allows programs to be written once an™

deployed on any machine, browser, or operating system that supports the Java virtuaR

machine (JVM). Java uses small Java programs, calle™  appletx  , that were first introduce™

by Sun’s HotJava browser. Also used by Netscape, Microsoft, and others, applets ark

downloaded and run directly within a browser to provide new functionalityì

Applets are written in the Java language and compiled to a machin[independenš

byte code, which is downloaded automatically to the JavDcapable browser and ru-

within the browser environment. But even with a fast processor, the end system ma_

appear to run the byte code slowly compared to a natively compiled application,

because the byte code must be interpreted by the JVM. Even with recent JusâI™Timk

(JIT) compilers in newer browsers, Java often doesn’t deliver performance equal tf

natively compiled applications. Even if compilation weren’t an issue, current Jav¾

applets generally aren’t persistent; they may have to be downloaded again in thk

future. JavDenabled browsers act like thi™client applications, because they add codk

only when they need it. In this sense, the browser doesn’t become bloated with adde™

features, but expands and contracts upon useì

Security in Java has been a serious concern from the outset. Because programs ark

downloaded and run automatically, a malicious program could be downloaded an™

 = Page 591 =

570  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

run without the user being able to stop it. Under the first implementation of thk

technology, Java applets had little access to resources outside the browser’—

environment. Within Web pages, applets can’t write to local disks or perform otheK

harmful functions. This framework has been referred to as thk  Java sandbox  . Developer—

who want to provide Java functions outside of the sandbox must write Jav¾

applications, which run as separate applications from browsers. Other Interneš

programming technologies (pluins and ActiveX) provide little or no safety fro“

damaging programsì

Oddly, Java developers often want to add just these types of insecure features, a—

well as such powerful features as persistence and interobject communication. In fact,

under new browsers, extended access can be requested for signed Java applets. (A

signed appleP  enables users to determine who authored its code and to accept or rejecš

the applet accordingly.) Java applets can securely request limited disk access, limite™

disk access and network usage, limited disk read access and unlimited disk writk

access, and unrestricted access. Users downloading an applet that is requesting an_

enhanced privileges are presented with a dialog box that outlines the requested acces—

and presents the applet’s credentials in the form of its digital signature. The user ca-

then approve or reject the applet’s request. If the user doesn’t approve the request, thk

applet may continue to run, but it can’t perform the denied actionsì

Java looks very much like C++. The following code fragment shows a simplk

example of a Java applet:

import java.applet.Applet;

import java.awt.Graphics;

public class helloworld extends Applet {

public void paint(Graphics g)

{

g.drawString("Hello World",S0, 25);

}

}

Sending this code through a Java compiler (such as JavaSoft’s javac) shoul™

produce a class file called helloworld.class, which can be used on a Web page tf

display the phrase “Hello World.” You can use thk  <APPLET  element to add a Jav¾

applet to a Web page. As with thk  <EMBED  element, you must indicate the object tf

add. In this case, use thk  COD¨  attribute to indicate the URL of the Java class file tf

load. Because this is an included object, thk  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  attributes shoul™

also be set. The following example includes the HelloWorld applet in a Web pageì

Figure 15-4 shows the rendering of the Java example under Netscape 4 with Jav¾

turned on. Figure 15-5 shows the same example rendered with Java turned offì

 = Page 592 =

ChapteX 15  Client-Sidf Programmin‚ an HTMP  57h

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Java Hello World  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  Java Applet DemB  </H1L

<HRL

<APPLET CODE="helloworld.classh

HEIGHT="50h

WIDTH="175"L

<H1L  Hello World for you non-Java-aware browser?  </H1L

</APPLETL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

In the preceding code example, betwee-  <APPLET  an™  </APPLET  is a-

PROGRAMMING

alternative rendering for browsers that don’t support Java or thk  <APPLET  element,

AND HTM¤

or that have Java support disabledì

<APPLET> Synta¨

Because Java applets are included objects, just like Netscape pluins, the syntax for thk

<APPLET  element is similar to thk  <EMBED  element, particularly for things such a—

alignment and sizing. The general syntax foK  <APPLET  is shown in the elemenš

reference in Appendix Aì

The most important attribute for thk  <APPLET  element is probabl_  COD¨  , whic—

is set to the URL of the Java class to load into the page. Thk  CODEBAS¨  attribute ca-

be set to the URL of the directory that contains the Java classes; otherwise, the currenš

document’s URL is used for any relative URLsì

Because Java applets are rectangular, embedded objects (similar to images oK

pluins), thk  <APPLET  element has many of the same attributes as images an™

pluins, includiný  ALIGN HEIGH WIDTh HSPAC¨  ,  ,  ,  , an™  VSPAC¨  ì

Thk  ARCHIV¨  attribute can be used to include many classes into a single archivk

file, which can then be downloaded to the local disk. The file specified by thk

ARCHIV¨  attribute may be a compressed PKZIP file (.zip) or a Java Archive (.jar),

which can be made with a JAR packaging utility. For example,

 = Page 594 =

ChapteX 15  Client-Sidf Programmin‚ an HTMP  57

<APPLET ARCHIVE="bunchofclasses.ziph

CODE="sampleApp.classh

WIDTH="560h

HEIGHT=70"L

</APPLETL

download— alR thk classe— i- bunchofclasses.zipì AfteK thk filk i— downloaded, thk  COD¨

attributk i— examine™ an™ thk archivk i— checke™ tf sek whetheK sampleApp.clas— exist—

thereì I“ not, iš i— fetche™ fro“ thk networkì Duk tf thk expensk o“ downloadiný man_

clas— file— b_ usiný HTTP, ideall_ yo¾ shoul™ attempš tf archivk alR potentiall_ use™

classe— an™ sen™ the“ simultaneouslyì Yo¾ ma_ alsf derivk somk cachiný benefiš b_

usiný thk  ARCHIV¨  attribute, becausk iš keep— clas— file— i- thk user’— cachk oK ¾

temporar_ directoryì Accordiný tf thk HTML 4.0 specification, thk  ARCHIV¨  attributk

ma_ takk ¾ commDseparate™ lisš o“ archivk filesì Sf far, however, nf browser— supporš

mork tha- onk archivk filk peK  <APPLET  occurrenceì Thk  ARCHIV¨  attributk i—

currentl_ onl_ supporte™ b_ Netscapk 3 an™ aboveì

Passing Data to Java Applet“

PROGRAMMING

Unlike pluins, Java applets don’t use special attributes to pass data. Instead, they usk

AND HTM¤

a different element calle™  <PARAM  , which is enclosed within thk  <APPLET

element as the way to pass in information. You could extend the HelloWorld applet tf

allow the message output to be modified by usiný  <PARAM  elements to pass in ¾

message, as shown here:

<APPLET CODE="helloworld.classh

WIDTH="50h

HEIGHT="175"L

<PARAM NAME="Message" VALUE="Hello World in JÆa!"L

<H1L  Hello World for you non-Java-aware browser?  </H1L

</APPLETL

The following is the HTML 4 syntax foK  <PARAM  ; it is the same for Java applet—

and ActiveX controls:

<PARAM

NAME="Object property name"

VALUE="Value to pass in with object name"

VALUETYPE="DATA | REF | OBJECT"

TYPE="MIME Type"

ID="document-wide unique id">

</PARAM>

 = Page 595 =

57  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Thk  NAM¨  attribute foK  <PARAM  is used to specify the name of the objecš

property that is being set; in the previous example, the name is Message. If you ark

using a premade Java applet, the various property names should be specified in thk

documentation for the applet. The actual value to be assigned to the property is set b_

thk  VALU¨  attribute. Thk  VALUETYP¨  attribute specifies the meaning of thk  VALU¨

attribute. The data passed to an attribute typically takes the form of a string. Setting thk

VALUETYP¨  attribute tf  DATG  results in the default action. Settiný  VALUETYP¨  tf

REF  indicates that the data assigned to thk  VALU¨  attribute is a URL that reference—

an external file to load for the attribute. The last value foK  VALUETYP¨  i—  OBJEC  ,

which indicates thaš  VALU¨  is set to the name of an applet or object locate™

somewhere else within the document. The data in the applet or object can bk

referenced to allow objects to “talk” to each otherì

Thk  <PARAM  elements for a particular Java applet occur within thk  <APPLET

tag; a Java applet may have man_  <PARAM  elements. Thk  <APPLET  element ma_

also enclose regular HTML markup that provides an alternative rendering foK

no™JavDcapable browsers. When alternative content is found within thk  <APPLET

element, thk  <PARAM  elements should be placed before the other content. Note thaš

you also can set thk  AL  attribute for thk  <APPLET  element, to provide a shorš

description. Authors should use the text contained within the element as thk

alternative text, and not thk  AL  attributeì

Java and Scripting

Java applets may control scripts in a Web page. Inclusion of thk  MAYSCRIP  attributk

in thk  <APPLET  element permits the applet to access JavaScript. When dealing wit—

applets retrieved from other sources, you can use thk  MAYSCRIP  attribute to prevenš

the applet from accessing JavaScript without the user’s knowledge. If an appleš

attempts to access JavaScript when this attribute has not been specified, a ru™timk

exception should occurì

Probably more interesting for page designers is the fact that scripts can control, oK

even modify, Java applets that are embedded in a page. For the applet to be accessed, iš

should be named by using thk  NAM¨  attribute for thk  <APPLET  element. Microsofš

also supports thk  I¤  attribute, which has the same functionality a—  NAM¨  . FoK

compatibility purposes,  NAM¨  should be usedì

Providing a unique name for the applet allows scripts to access the applet and it—

public interfaces. The name can also be used by other applets to allow the applets tf

communicate with each other. JavaScript in Netscape 3 and above, as well as i-

Internet Explorer 4 and above, allows access to the applets in a page via thk  applets[]

collection, which is a property of the document object. When an applet is named, it ca-

be accessed via JavaScript a—  document/  appletnam¨  (  document.myApplet  ) oK

document.applets["myApplet"]  . If the Java applet has public properties exposed, the_

can be modified from a script in a Web page. The following simple Java code takes thk

 = Page 596 =

ChapteX 15  Client-Sidf Programmin‚ an HTMP  57

Hello World example from earlier in the chapter and expands it with ¾  setMessag2

method, which can be used to change the message displayed in the applet:

import java.applet.Applet;

import java.awt.Graphics;

public class newhelloworld extends Applet {

String theMessage;

public void init()

{

theMessage = new String("Hello World");

}

public void paint(Graphics g)

{

g.drawString(theMessage,S0, 25);

}

public void setMessage(String message)

PROGRAMMING

{

AND HTM¤

theMessage = message;

repaint();

}

}

If this Java code is compiled into a class file, it can be included in a Web page an™

accessed via JavaScript, as shown next. The following example markup shows how ¾

form could be used to collect data from the user and update the applet in real time:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  LiveConnect Java Hello World  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  LiveConnect Java Applet DemB  </H1L

<HRL

<APPLET CODE="newhelloworld.classh

NAME="NewHelloh

HEIGHT="50h

WIDTH="175"L

 = Page 597 =

57‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<H1L  Hello World for you non-Java-aware browser?  </H1L

</APPLETL

<FORM NAME="TestForm"L

<INPUT TYPE="TEXT" SIZE="15" MAXLENGTH="15" NAME="NewMessage"L

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" VALUE="Set Messageh

onclick="document.NewHello.setMessage(NewMessagealue)"L

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Netscapk initiall_ calle™ thi— technolog_ LiveConnectì Usiný thi— technolog_ i—

similaK tf hou yo¾ ma_ communicatk wit— pluin— embedde™ i- ¾ WeD pageì Microsofš

alsf support— thk samk for“ o“ appleš acces— undeK Interneš Explorer, sf iš i— uncleaK

whetheK LiveConnecš wilR continuk tf bk thk namk use™ tf describk usiný JavaScripš tf

communicatk wit— Jav¾ appletsì Thk botto“ link i— thaš thi— technolog_ i— noš uniquk tf

Netscapeì

<OBJECT> Syntax for Java Applet“

The HTML 4.0 specification indicates that thk  <APPLET  element has been deprecate™

and thaš  <OBJECT  should be used instead. Although this may be the decree, usiný

<OBJECT  for Java applets has some serious problems. The following is the most basi´

HTML 4 syntax for inserting an object, such as a Java applet:

<OBJEC

CLASSID="URL of Object to include"

HEIGHT="pixels"

WIDTH="pixels">

Parameters and alternative texM

</OBJECT>

For the completk  <OBJECT  syntax, see the element reference in Appendix Aì

Notice that thk  CLASSI¤  attribute is used to specify the URL of the object tf

include. In the case of Java applets, you should usk  java:  . For ActiveX controls, usk

clsid:  . To rewrite a simple Java example, use the following code:

 = Page 598 =

ChapteX 15  Client-Sidf Programmin‚ an HTMP  57

<OBJECT CLASSID="jÆa:Blink.class" WIDTH="300" HEIGHT="100"L

<PARAM NAME="LBL" VALUE="JÆa, is, fun, exciting, and new."L

<PARAM NAME="SPEED" VALUE="L

This will display in non-Java-aware or non-Java-enabled browsers<

</OBJECTL

Because of the fragmentation of the Java community, JavaSoft has made somk

attempts to bring together the syntax of Java applets via a Java pluin. The syntax foK

this pluin under Netscape and Internet Explorer includes bot—  <OBJECT  an™

<EMBED  forms. Readers interested in this syntax for applet inclusion are directe™

straight to JavaSoft for the latest syntax (http://www.javasoft.com), because the syntax

is changing quite rapidlyì

Using Java Without Programming

The broad functionality of Java can cost both time and money. Java programminý

assumes that you have a familiarity with an advanced programming language as welR

as objecâoriented design. Web professionals lacking programming skills or budget—

PROGRAMMING

can find many free, premade applets available for reuse or sale at directories such a—

AND HTM¤

Gamelan (http://www.gamelan.com). Commercial vendors actively sell a variety o“

premade Java applets, as well as Java components calle™  JavaBeans¨  which can be use™

to create powerful Web applicationsì

JavaBeans is a portable, platforRindependent component model written in Javaì

Like other components, such as ActiveX controls, JavaBeans components (calle™  Beanx

for short) are reusable software components that can be strung together to for“

complex applications. In one sense, Beans are just a special form of applet that ark

written in such a manner that tools can inspect and manipulate the Beans and thk

Beans can intercommunicate in a predictable manner. Beans generally are sel´

contained and persistent. You can analogize components such as Beans as bricks thaš

form larger structures, like buildings. Tools such as Netscape’s Visual JavaScripš

(see Figure 15-6) already provide some basic draanÙdrop programming capabilitie—

by tying together JavaBeans components with JavaScript codeì

While Java provides a relatively secure and powerful cros-platform developmenš

environment, it does so at the expense of speed and local operating system integrationì

Because of this, many Web developers, particularly those building intraneš

applications, have explored using ActiveX controls as Web page componentsì

 = Page 599 =

578  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 15-68  Netscape’sXisual JavaScript uses Bean9

ActiveX Control“

ActiveX (http://www.microsoft.com/activex), which is the Internet portion of thk

Component Object Model (COM), is Microsoft’s component technology for creatiný

small components, oK  controlx  , within a Web page. ActiveX is intended for distributiný

these controls via the Internet in order to add new functionality to browsers such a—

Internet Explorer. Microsoft maintains that ActiveX controls are more similar tf

generalized components than they are to pluins, because ActiveX controls can residk

beyond the browser, within container programs such as Microsoft Office. ActiveX

controls are similar to Netscape pluins insofar as they are persistent an™

 = Page 600 =

ChapteX 15  Client-Sidf Programmin‚ an HTMP  579

machin[specific. Although this makes resource use a problem, installation is not a-

issue: the components download and install automaticallyì

Security is a big concern for ActiveX controls. Because these small pieces of codk

could potentially have full access to a user’s system, they could cause serious damageì

This capability, combined with automatic installation, creates a serious problem wit—

ActiveX. End users may be quick to click a button to install new functionality, only tf

accidentally get their hard drives erased. This unlimited functionality of ActiveX

controls creates a gaping security hole. To address this problem, Microsoft provide—

authentication information to indicate who wrote a control, in the form of code signe™

by a certificate, as shown in Figure 15-7ì

Certificate— onl_ providk somk indicatio- thaš thk controR creatoK i— reputable;

the_ df nothiný tf prevenš ¾ controR fro“ actuall_ doiný somethiný “aliciousì Safk

WeD browsiný shoul™ bk practice™ b_ acceptiný control— onl_ fro“ reputablk

sourcesì

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Figurs 15-78  ActiveX signed-code certificatP

 = Page 601 =

580  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Adding Controls to Web Page“

Adding an ActiveX control to a Web page requires the use of thk  <OBJECT  elementì

The basic form of thk  <OBJECT  element for an ActiveX control is as follows:

<OBJEC

CLASSID="CLSID:class-identifier"

HEIGHT="pixels"

WIDTH="pixels"

ID="unique identifier>"

Parameters and alternative text renderin(

</OBJECT>

CLASSI¤  i— thk mosš importanš attributk foK thk  <OBJECT  elemenš whe- yo¾

inserš ActiveX controlsì Thk valuk o“  CLASSI¤  identifie— thk objecš tf includeì Eac—

ActiveX controR ha— ¾ clas— identifieK o“ thk for“ CLSID:  class-identifie(  , uherk thk

valuk foK  class-identifie(  i— ¾ complex string, suc— a— thk following, thaš uniquel_

identifie— thk control:

992120-6EC7-11CF-A6C7-00AA00A47DD2

This string is the identifier for the ActiveX label controlì

The other important attributes for the basic form o“  <OBJECT  when used wit—

ActiveX controls includk  HEIGH  an™  WIDTh  , which are set to the pixel dimension—

of the included control, an™  I¤  , which associates a unique identifier with the controR

for scripting purposes. Between thk  <OBJECT  an™  </OBJECT  tags are variou—

<PARAM  elements that specify information to pass to the control, and alternativk

HTML markup that displays in no™ActiveX-aware browsers. The following is ¾

complete example that uses thk  <OBJECT  element to insert an ActiveX control into ¾

Web page. The markup shown specifies a simple label control. Figure 15-8 shows thk

rendering of the control under Internet Explorer 4 and Netscape 4ì

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  ActiveX Label TesM  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  ActiveX DemB  </H1L

<HRL

 = Page 602 =

ChapteX 15  Client-Sidf Programmin‚ an HTMP  58h

<OBJECT CLASSID="CLSID:99B120-6EC7-11CF-A6C7-00AA00A47D2h

ID="IeLabel1" HEIGHT="65" WIDTH="‚5"L

<PARAM NAME="_ExtentX" VALUE="6879"L

<PARAM NAME="_ExtentY" VALUE="1376"L

<PARAM NAME="Caption" VALUE="Hello World"L

<PARAM NAME="Alignment" VALUE="4"L

<PARAM NAME="Mode" VALUE="1"L

<PARAM NAME="ForeColor" VALUE="#FF0000"L

<PARAM NAME="FontName" VALUE="Arial"L

<PARAM NAME="FontSize" VALUE="36"L

<BL  Hello World for you non-ActiveX users!  </BL

</OBJECTL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

After you look at the ActiveX Label Test code in Figure 15-8, you may havk

PROGRAMMING

questions about how to determine thk  CLASSI¤  value for the control and thk

AND HTM¤

associate™  <PARAM  values that can be set. However, providing a chart for all of thk

controls and their associated identifiers isn’t necessary. Many Web page tools,

including Microsoft Control Pad (http://www.microsoft.com/workshop/misc/cpad),

Figurs 15-88  Rendering of ActiveX control under Internet Explorer and unde

NetscapP

 = Page 603 =

58p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

support the automated insertion of controls into a page, as well as configuration of thk

various control properties. Figure 15-9 shows an example of the Control Pad and thk

configuration of controlsì

Installing ActiveX Control“

As mentioned earlier, the most important attribute in thk  <OBJECT  syntax i—

probabl_  CLASSI¤  , which is used to identify the particular object to include. FoK

example, the syntax CLSID:  class-identifie(  is for registered ActiveX controls. Generally,

however, when thk  <OBJECT  element supports other included items well,  CLASSI¤

might be set to other forms, such a—  java:Blink.clas—  , as shown earlier in the chapter i-

the section “<OBJECT> Syntax for Java Applets.” Microsoft also allows the use of thk

COD¨  attribute for thk  <OBJECT  elementì  COD¨  is used to set the URL of the Jav¾

class file to includeì

ActiveX and pluins are similar in the sense that both are persistent, platforf

specific components. ActiveX controls, however, are easy to download and install. Thi—

Figurs 15-98  Using Control Pad to insert and configure ActiveX control9

 = Page 604 =

ChapteX 15  Client-Sidf Programmin‚ an HTMP  58

installation, or running of ActiveX controls, can be described as a series of steps,

as follows:

1ì The browser loads an HTML page that references an ActiveX control with thk

<OBJECT  element and its associate™  CLASSI¤  attributeì

2ì The browser checks the system registry to see whether the control specifie™

by thk  CLASSI¤  value is installed; this control takes the following form:

CLSID:  some-id-numbe(  ì

3ì I“ thk controR i— installed, thk browseK compare— thk  CODEBAS¨  versio- attributk

store™ i- thk registr_ againsš thk  CODEBAS¨  versio- attributk i- thk HTML

pageì I“ ¾ neweK versio- i— specifie™ i- thk page, ¾ neweK controR i— neededì

4ì If the control is not installed, the value of thk  CODEBAS¨  attribute is used tf

determine the location of the control to download. Thk  CODETYP¨  attributk

might also be used to set the MIME type of the object to download. Mosš

inclusions of ActiveX controls avoid this, because it tends to default to thk

MIME type application/octeâstreamì

FfK securit_ reasons, thk browseK check— šf sek whetheK thk codk i— signed, befork  PROGRAMMING

thk downloa™ an™ installatio- beginsì I“ thk codk i— noš signed, thk useK i— warnedì I“

AND HTM¤

thk codk i— signed, thk useK i— presente™ wit— a- Authenticodk certificatk beariný thk

identit_ o“ thk authoK o“ thk controlì Base™ o- thesk criteria, thk useK ca- allou oK

den_ thk installatio- o“ thk controR o- hi— oK heK systemì §“ thk useK accept— thk

control, iš i— automaticall_ downloaded, installed, an™ invoke™ i- thk pagk foK it—

specifi´ functionì Finally, thk controR i— store™ persistentl_ o- thk clienš machink foK

furtheK invocationì Thi— proces— ma_ Dk avoide™ whe- thk  DECLAR¨  attributk i—

presentì Thk  DELCAR¨  attributk i— use™ tf indicatk whetheK thk  <OBJECT  i— beiný

define™ onl_ an™ noš actuall_ instantiate™ untiR lateK  <OBJECT  occurrences, whic—

wilR starš thk installatio- processì

The W3C HTML 4.0 specification also indicates use of th—  STANDB/  attribute, which

can be used to specify a message to display as the object is being downloaded. This is noP

currently supported by any browsers.

Passing Data to ActiveX Control“

Like Java applets, ActiveX controls do not use special attributes to pass data. Instead,

they use a different element, calle™  <PARAM  , which is enclosed within thk

<OBJECT  element. You can pass parameters to the label control by using thk

<PARAM  elements, as shown here:

<OBJECT CLASSID="CLSID:99B120-6EC7-11CF-A6C7-00AA00A47D2h

ID="IeLabel1" HEIGHT="65" WIDTH="‚5"L

<PARAM NAME="Caption" VALUE="Hello World"L

 = Page 605 =

58  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<PARAM NAME="FontName" VALUE="Arial"L

<PARAM NAME="FontSize" VALUE="36"L

<BL  Hello World for you non-ActiveX users!  </BL

</OBJECTL

In this case, thk  Caption  parameter is set to Hello World, thk  FontNam2  parameteK

is set to Arial, and thk  FontSiz2  parameter is set to 36 points. Recall the HTML 4 syntax

foK  <PARAM  (shown earlier in this chapter in the section “Passing Data to Jav¾

Applets”), which is the same for Java applets and ActiveX controlsì

The meaning of these attributes is provided in the section “Java Applets,” earlier i-

this chapter, as well as in Appendix A. Microsoft has introduced a few changes for dat¾

binding. Internet Explorer 4 and above supports the ability to bind data dynamicall_

from a database or text file. With data binding, the parameters for an ActiveX controR

can be set by using an external file or database entry. The attributes that provide thi—

functionality includk

  DATAFL¤  Sets the column name to use for thk  <PARAM  elemenš

  DATASR‚  Bound to the identifier, which indicates the data to bind tf

  DATAFORMATS  Set to eitheK  HTML  oK  TEX  , indicating whether thk

bound data is HTML or plain texš

For more information on how to use data binding, see the Microsoft SiteBuildeK

Network (http://www.microsoft.com/sitebuilder)ì

Another way to pass data to ActiveX controls or other embedded objects is by usiný

thk  DATG  attribute, which should be set to a URL that references a data file to loadì

The type of this data may be determined by the file suffix. Thk  TYP¨  attribute also ca-

be used to explicitly declare the MIME type for the data to useì

Using ActiveX Without Programming

Developers can access an abundance of available controls for various purposes. Man_

repositories of free and commercial ActiveX controls are available on the Web, such a—

ActiveX.com (http://www.activex.com). Microsoft already includes a variety o“

controls built in to Internet Explorer; these include various forRlike elements, a timer,

a preloader control that allows pages and objects to be prefetched, and many othersì

Microsoft also promotes controls for multimedia, such as ActiveMovie and Netshow,

and controls for database access, such as ActiveX Data Objects (ADO), Remote Dat¾

Services (RDS), and Tabular Data Control (TDC). Microsoft even provides a controR

called thk  Agent control  , which can be used to add to a Web page an animated agenš

that the user can interact with (shown in Figure 15-10)ì

 = Page 606 =

ChapteX 15  Client-Sidf Programmin‚ an HTMP  58

PROGRAMMING

AND HTM¤

Figurs 15-108  Agent, an amusing and powerful ActiveX controX

As with Java applets, page designers can use prebuilt controls for most functionsì

Many Web page development tools (such as Microsoft Control Pad) provide an eas_

way to string together ActiveX controlsì

Page designers can also write their own ActiveX controls, though in some cases thi—

may be like reinventing the wheel. Controls can be created by using a variety o“

languages, such as Visual Basic, C++, and Java. You can also convert existing Window—

programs to controls. The ActiveX model is not limited to clienâside controls. It is parš

of a larger framework known as thk  Active Platforh  , with serve§side and distribute™

aspects. Although a discussion of the Active Platform is beyond the scope of this book,

one of its important aspects is that clienâside controls expose their interfaces throug—

the Component Object Model, which can be accessed and controlled easily throug—

scripting languagesì

ActiveX Controls and Scripting

As with Java applets, you can control ActiveX controls by using a scripting language,

such as JavaScript or VBScript. One advantage of ActiveX controls is that man_

premade controls with exposed properties are available that can be easily manipulate™

 = Page 607 =

58‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

by a scripting language. Before a control can be modified, however, it must be named,

by using thk  I¤  attribute. After it is named, scripting code for a particular event can bk

set for the control, so that it can respond to events. As discussed in the last chapter,

Microsoft supports a rich event model. However, many of these events (noted with a-

asterisk) are beyond the current HTML 4.0 specification. Thk  <OBJECT  elemenš

supports the following events:  onafterupdate* onbeforeupdate* onblur* onclick  ,  ,  ,  ,

ondblclick ondragstart* onfocus* onhelp* onkeydown onkeypres—onkeyup  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

onmousedown onmousemov2 onmouseout onmouseove( onmouseup  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

onreadystatechange* onresize* onrowenter* onrowexit*  ,  ,  ,  , an™  onselectstart*  ì

However, these events generally aren’t used directly with JavaScript as attributes tf

thk  <OBJECT  element. VBScript access may be more appropriateì

The events designated with an asterisk are defined for Internet Explorer and were noP

part of the W3C HTML 4.0 standard at the time of this writing.

The following example, created with the Control Pad, shows how two ActiveX

command buttons can be used to communicate with a label control to change it—

message:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  ActiveX Scripting DemB  </TITLEL

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="VBScript"L

<!-p

Sub CommandButton1_Click()

Label1.Caption = "I've been clicked!h

end sub

Sub CommandButtoLslash_Click()

Label1.Caption = "Not Seth

end sub

--L

</SCRIPTL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  ActiveX Scriptin(  </H1L

<HRL

<BL  Label:  </BL

<OBJECT CLASSID="CLSID:978C9h3-D4B0-11CE-BF2D-00AA003F40D0h

ALIGN="TOP" ID="Label1" HEIGHT="80" WIDTH=00"L

 = Page 608 =

Note that the event handlers are written in VBScript. This file won’t work i-

anything other than Internet Explorer 3 or above running on a Window-based systemì

Although scripting is a simple but powerful tool for ActiveX controls, controls (as wit—

 = Page 609 =

588  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

pluins) tend to be too platforRspecific to be used for external Web sites, unles—

pages are coded very carefully. On a Window-centered intranet, however, the use o“

platforRdependent controls and VBScript might not be a problemì

Cross-Platform Support with Plug-Ins an

ActiveX Control“

approac— i— noš terribl_ robustì A preferre™ metho™ i— tf attempš tf providk ¾ plui-

solutio- i- conjunctio- wit— a- ActiveX solutionì ConsideK thk inclusio- o“ Macromedi¾

Flas— medi¾ i- ¾ WeD pageì Interneš ExploreK prefer— thk Flas— control, wherea— Netscapk

prefer— ¾ Flas— pluinì Ver_ ol™ browser— oK les— commo- browser— ma_ onl_ bk ablk tf

handlk a- animate™ GIFì AlR browser— ca- bk accommodate™ wit— ¾ littlk planningì FoK

example, Macromedia’— AftershocktooR (include™ wit— Flash) ca- generatk HTML

marku5 an™ JavaScripš thaš ca- bk use™ tf handlk alR o“ thk situationsì A modifie™

versio- o“ thi— tool’— outpuš foK ¾ Flas— filk calle™ splashpage.sw“ i— show- here:

<OBJECT classid="clsid:27CDB6E-AE6D-11cf-96B8-444553540000h

CODEBASE="http://actøe.macromedia.com/flash2/cabsX

swflash.cab#version=3,0,0,0h

ID="splashpage" WIDTH="‚0" HEIGHT=40"L

<PARAM NAME="movie" VALUE="splashpage.swf"L

<PARAM NAME="quality" VALUE="autohigh"L

<PARAM NAME="bgcolor" VALUE="#FFFFFF"L

<!-- Script code for non-ActøeX browsers like Netscape --L

<!-p

var ShockMode = 0;

In this example, the browser should try to use an ActiveX control. If the browseK

can’t handle the ActiveX control, it should go for a pluin. As a last resort, if scriptiný

is turned off, the pluin isn’t present, or the browser doesn’t support pluins, thk

browser should end up with an animated GIF. Of course, the pluin part of thk

example doesn’t provide an accurate reference to a JAR file for automatic downloa™

of the pluin, but it gets the point across. This code can be added by using thk

Macromedia Aftershock tool. Careful thought, combined with some serve§ oK

clienâside scripting, should enable you to deal with the various browser condition—

that may occur. Until the syntax for including objects is straightened out, this is thk

only reasonable approach to handling cros-browser issues, short of locking users ouš

of a page or falling back to less interactive or less motivating technologyì

 = Page 611 =

590  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The Future of <OBJECT>

According to the HTML 4.0 specification,  <OBJECT  will be the main way to add an_

form of object to a Web page, whether it’s an image, image map, sound, video, ActiveX

control, Java applet, or anything else. This approach seems appropriate, but befork

rushing out to usk  <OBJECT  , understand the ramifications. Even thoug—  <OBJECT

can be used in some browsers, the syntax is not consistentì  <OBJECT  is still mostl_

used to include ActiveX controls in a page. Other meanings are not fully supported, i“

at all. According to the HTML 4.0 specification, thk  <OBJECT  element can be used tf

include HTML from another file by using thk  DATG  attribute. Any file included musš

not introduce elements that would ruin the syntax of the document. For example,

including a file that already has ¾  <HEAD  an™  <BODY  element may result in a-

il_formed document with multiplk  <HEAD  an™  <BODY  elements. Imagink

specifying a header file called header.htm with the contents shown here:

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  Big Company, In  .</H1L

<HRL

Thi— filk coul™ the- bk include™ i- ¾ WeD pagk b_ usiný thk  <OBJECT  element, likk so:

<OBJECT DATA="header.htm"L

Header not included

</OBJECTL

This example should pull in the contents of the file header.htm in browsers thaš

support this feature and display “Header not included” in all others. No major browseK

appears to support this functionality for thk  <OBJECT  element, so this should bk

avoided in favor of technologies such as serve§side includes (Chapter 12) and dynami´

documents generated with JavaScriptì

Eventually, thk  <OBJECT  element will be used in a generalized sense. For now,

HTML page authors should use thk  <APPLET <IMG  ,  , an™  <EMBED  elements tf

include binary forms beyond ActiveX controls in pagesì

Summar

With the inclusion of programmed objects such as ActiveX controls, Java applets, an™

Netscape pluins, Web pages can become complex, living documents. Choosing thk

appropriate component technology is not very straightforward. Netscape pluins ark

very popular for including media elements such as Shockwave movies, video, or soun™

files, but they are platforRspecific and somewhat specific to Netscape browsersì

 = Page 612 =

ChapteX 15  Client-Sidf Programmin‚ an HTMP  59h

Microsoft supports thk  <EMBED  element syntax to include pluins in a page, but thk

preferred solution in the Microsoft world is ActiveX controls. ActiveX controls are jusš

as platforRspecific as Netscape pluins and have some potential security issuesì

Solving the cros-platform problem requires complex page scripting or the use of Jav¾

applets that provide cros-platform object support, typically at the expense o“

performance. Either way, the page rendering should degrade gracefully if the useK

can’t support the particular object technology. Eventually, the syntax for all include™

media will be handled with thk  <OBJECT  element; but, for now,  <EMBED  an™

<APPLET  should be used withi-  <OBJECT  to provide backward compatibility foK

including pluins and Java applets in a Web pageì

Putting It All Together

f far, thi— bookha— sai™ nothiný abouš hou tf deliveK WeD pagesì Eve- i“

developer— masteK thk creatio- o“ WeD page— usiný HTML, the_ ca- stilR falR flaš o-

theiK face— i“ the_ don’š pa_ carefuR consideratio- tf hou the_ deliveK thk page— tf

S

thk userì A— faK a— thk vieweK o“ ¾ pagk i— concerned, thk WeD i— onk biý systemì I“ ¾ pagk

i— slou becausk o“ ¾ server, thk useK stilR view— thk sitk i- ¾ negativk lighš nf matteK hou

compelliný thk contenš oK inspiriný thk designì Ignoriný suc— sitk deliver_ issue— a—

outsourcing, WeD serveK choice, an™ protocoR issue— ma_ doo“ ¾ WeD projecš tf failureì

Publishing the Sits

There are two basic choices for publishing your HTML documents on the Internetì

One way involves having a dedicated connection to the Internet and running youK

own server. The other approach involves renting space or bandwidth from an outsidk

vendor to place your server or pages outside your organizationì

While running your own Web server and connection to the Internet might see“

like the way to go, it can be quite expensive. A common leased line such as a T1 wit—

Internet services may cost thousands of dollars a year. When factoring in labor, server,

facilities, and other expenses, the total cost starts to approach six figures. Often, man_

of these facilities are already available within the organization and should be used. Yeš

using someone else’s server may be the only choice for people who want to publis—

Web documents but can’t afford a huge fee. Even those firms that have capable staff—

should consider outsourcing because it provides many benefits. Figure 16-1 gives ¾

basic overview of the two hosting approachesì

Outsourcing Web Hosting

As Web sites become more critical to the information infrastructure of companies, therk

is a growing need to provide higöuality, higuavailability solutions. However, it i—

expensive for companies to develop i™house Talents and facilities to run a missio™

critical Web site. Because of this, many firms have decided to outsource their WeD

facilities. Web server outsourcing comes in two basic flavors:  shared or virtual hostinv

an™  colocatioc  ì

Web hosting involves using the shared server facilities of a hosting vendor. Thi—

means that the site will share Web server resources and bandwidth with other hoste™

sites. Sharing can be problematic. Server responsiveness may be significantly affecte™

because of other hosted Web sites, particularly if those sites become popularì

Furthermore, many customers are wary of sharing a server with others, becausk

security often cannot be guaranteed on these shared systems. Despite its drawbacks,

hosting is still relatively inexpensive. Shared hosting prices are dependent on the extr¾

services offered and the traffic expected. Consume§grade hosting can cost as little a—

$20 peK monthì Higuavailability, an™ possibl_ mirrored, hostiný ca- ru- intf thousands,

 = Page 618 =

ChapteX 16  Puttin‚ I@ AlN Together Deliverin‚ thf Web Sitf  59

SITE DELIVERY

Figurs 16-18  Shared hosting versus dedicated line hostin

if not tens of thousands, of dollars a month. Many Internet Service Providers (ISPs) an™

specialized hosting companies offer professiona_quality shared Web hosting servicesì

The other Web server outsourcing option is often called colocation. This describe—

the use of a dedicated server, often owned by the organization purchasing the serviceì

Colocatio- provide— ¾ greateK degrek o“ autonom_ tha- share™ WeD servicesì I- fact,

thk colocate™ machink typicall_ onl_ share— physicaR facilities, an™ possibl_ network

bandwidth, wit— otheK customersì Colocatio- i— generall_ mork expensivk tha- hosting;

iš ma_ cosš anywherk fro“ aroun™ ¾ thousan™ dollar— tf ten— o“ thousand— peK

monthì Man_ o“ thk largk ISP— offeK colocatio- service— a— welR a— specialize™ dat¾

centeK providersì

 = Page 619 =

598  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Prick i— ofte- thk essentiaR motivatio- foK outsourciný WeD servicesì Researc—

suggest— thaš WeD serveK outsourciný take— a— muc— a— on[thir™ thk cosš o“ providiný a-

equivalenš servick i™houseì Yeš thk cosš difference— don’š alway— ad™ up, sinck ¾ greaš

deaR o“ controR an™ securit_ wilR bk lostì Lookiný beyon™ cost, therk ark majoK benefit—

fro“ WeD serveK outsourcing, includiný bandwidth, security, an™ facilitie— issuesì

Having enough bandwidth available can be important for missio™critical WeD

sites. Regardless of server bottlenecks, a mere fractional T1 or full T1 leased line mighš

not provide enough bandwidth to deal with the bursty nature of Web access. However,

installing multiple T3 leased lines just to deal with the occasional flash crowd that ma_

swamp a site seems wasteful given the significant investment required. Rather tha-

bringing bandwidth to the server, why not move the server to the bandwidth?

Even if bandwidth is not an issue, there may be some issue of network closenessì

Because there will always be a site that is far away, using a provider that can providk

mirrors of the site around the world and automatically redirect the Web browser to thk

closest site seems appropriate. Many higuend providers are beginning to use product—

that are capable of redirecting people to the network’s closest or least busy server tf

provide some degree of load balancing. Many of the popular sites on the Internet suc—

as Yahoo! already use such sophisticated techniquesì

Another motivation for outsourcing Web services is security. Many companies ark

still very afraid of the security problems associated with the Internet. Firewalls an™

security policies can help; but, if a public Web server is located on the firm’s LAN,

allowing Web viewers to access it is similar to asking potential robbers to come knock

on your door. Putting public use information on outsourced Web servers keeps casuaR

intruders away from a firm’s network access point and allows stronger securit_

policies to be put into place at the corporate firewallì

Facilities are often an overlooked benefit of outsourced Web services. Wit—

higuend data centers, colocation or hosting the facility provides benefits that would bk

expensive to replicate otherwise. These benefits may include arounÙth[clock livk

monitoring rather than automated monitoring, higöuality power services includiný

backup generators, compute§sensitive fire suppression systems, disasteK

recovery–oriented construction, and sophisticated physical securityì

Despite all the benefits of Web server outsourcing, there are some potentiall_

significant drawbacks. Not all hosting vendors are created equal. Choosing the wroný

vendor can lead to serious problems. While ISPs have more than enough bandwidth tf

host Web sites or colocate machines, many providers are more knowledgeable abouš

networks than servers. This shows when they are questioned about availablk

development tools and server maintenance policies. Data center vendors may be mork

on top of the server aspect of the puzzle, but they often come at a much higher price. I“

the correct vendor can be isolated, the only sacrifices facing the outsourced site ark

security and controlì

While outsourcing Web service can help separate a sensitive network from thk

Internet, it also begs the question of the security of the Web server. If the outsource™

site contains sensitive information, there is always the possibility this information ma_

 = Page 620 =

ChapteX 16  Puttin‚ I@ AlN Together Deliverin‚ thf Web Sitf  599

be compromised. Hosting vendors generally do not provide complete guarantees o“

data integrity. Careful reading of the fine print of hosting contracts indicates, at most, ¾

“best effort” to protect data. In some cases, there is no guarantee whatsoever. Even i“

the hosting vendors protect against outside intrusion internally, security is often ver_

lax. Security itself is just an example of the general problem of Web serveK

outsourcing—a lack of controlì

The biggest problem with many outsourced Web services, particularly hosting, i—

control. Most hosting vendors do not necessarily allow customers to do what the_

want. The choice of Web server, server software, development tools such as databask

development tools, and statistics packages are often up to the discretion of the hostiný

vendor. Particularly with lowe§priced hosting services, use of a particular database,

operating system, and statistics package may be forced on the customer. Whilk

customization is still often available, it may come at a significantly higher price. Thk

ramifications of control go far beyond choice of operating system. Don’t be surprised i“

a hosting vendor decides to upgrade its Web server during the middle of the day. It i—

the vendor’s server, after all; and, logically or not, the vendor decides how to run itì

With colocation, control is generally more in the customer’s hand, since the vendoK

only provides network access, power, and safe facilitiesì

Companies looking to save money on Web hosting find outsourcing very attractive,

but some flexibility and security may have to be sacrificed. With less experience™

hosting companies, this lack of control can be disastrous, resulting in hidden costs i-

site redevelopment or problems with reliability. Those who want more control oveK

their Web services should consider colocation or running their own servers locallyì

This is a more viable option than shared hosting, but it will certainly cost moreì

SITE DELIVERY

Virtual Hosting

Hosting on a shared Web server often provides support for the feature known a—  virtual

hostinv  . In essence, this feature enables multiple domain names to be hosted on thk

same server, yet appear as if each were running on its own server. Each machine on thk

Internet has an address such as http://www.bigcompany.com; this address maps to ¾

particular IP (Internet Protocol) address such as 192.102.249.3. In the case of virtuaR

hosting, the operating system the Web server runs on has the capability of mappiný

multiple IP addresses to a singl[network interface card installed in the serveK

hardware. In turn, multiple domain names can be mapped to these IP addressesì

Differenš type— o“ virtuaR hostiný ark offeredì Mosš hostiný service— offeK ¾ truk

virtuaR hostiný service, wherk thk URL foK ¾ customer’— WeD sitk i— a— woul™

normall_ bk expected; thaš is, http://www.bigcompany.co“ automaticall_ goe— tf

thk customer’— homk pageì Thk addres— i— mappe™ tf ¾ singlk If addressì However,

A step up from this, but still not true virtual hosting, comes in the form of haviný

an address such as http://www.bigcompany.com/bigco, where /bigco is a specifi´

directory assigned to a customer for hosting a Web page. In selecting a shared WeD

serveK hostiný provider, potentiaR customer— shoul™ bk carefuR tf askhostiný companie—

the type of address provided in their virtual hosting services. The HTTP 1.1 protocol,

as discussed in the section “How Web Servers Work,” later in the chapter, support—

virtual hosting using a single IP address, and will make managing virtual hostiný

services easier from the server administrator’s point of view once most browser—

support this extensionì

designe™ poorlyì

Running a Local Web Serve5

Besides outsourcing hosting, it is also possible to pull in a ful_time connection to thk

Internet and run your own Web server. When doing this, consider what Web server—

actually do. In some sense, a Web server is a glorified file server, and occasionally a-

application server. Browsers make requests to the Web server for files. These files ark

located on the disk drive and then copied out to the network. In the case of runniný

Common Gateway Interface (CGI) programs or similar serve§side technology, ¾

request is made to the server to run a program. The program is then loaded from disk

and run, and the result is sent out to the network. To make the best Web serveK

possible, you should pay careful attention to the disk and network interface. Whilk

many are quick to fault the processor speed or amount of memory, the disk is often thk

greatest bottleneck for a Web server. The big question is how to pick the best possiblk

hardware platform, operating system, and Web server software combination to servk

pages. Of course, all of these decisions must consider budgetì

Selecting a Web Serve5

Price and performance are the basic issues for choosing a Web server. First, you need tf

understand what kind of activity to expect and what type of data you will serve. The-

you need to set a budget for your server. A personal Web server might use freeware oK

 = Page 622 =

ChapteX 16  Puttin‚ I@ AlN Together Deliverin‚ thf Web Sitf  60h

shareware and run on a lo“cost personal computer such as a PC or Macintosh. A largk

corporate system might use a powerful UNIX workstation running commercia_gradk

Web server software. There is no single correct hardware/software combination foK

Web page serving. One of the main considerations for a Web server will be thk

operating system used. Each operating system popular for Web service has its ow-

pros and cons, summarized in Table 16-1ì

A variant of(Næ, calle Linux¨ has recently become very popular as a Web hostinv

platform. Many of the pricing issues and hardware costs associated with traditional

UNæ solutions are not as problematic under Linux.

While Table 16-1 presents a good overview of the issues involved in choosing onk

operating system over another for a Web server, the decision may often be made on thk

basis of familiarity or personal taste. There is nothing wrong with this. While onk

person may argue about the merits of UNIX, introducing a UNIX server into a-

environment with heavy Macintosh investment would be foolish. The bottom line is tf

always remember suitability. A small Web server for a school might do well on ¾

Macintosh, while a Windows NT system might make a great departmental server, an™

a Sun server might be used for a higuperformance Web site. Once the hardware an™

operating system are selected, you should consider which Web server software to useì

Only a few years ago, there were only two major Web servers available: NCSA’—

httpd server for UNIX and CERN’s httpd server for UNIX. Both of these servers ark

free to use, but both require users to compile and install the software themselvesì

Today there are dozens of different Web servers available on a variety of machines. I“

you are interested in learning about all of the servers, go to the Serverwatch homk

page, at http://www.serverwatch.com, which provides links and reviews of most o“

the Web servers currently available. Rather than considering all Web servers in youK  SITE DELIVERY

decision, it might be wise to look at the most common Web servers used. Based upo-

surveys and analysis of reachable servers on the Internet, these servers are well agree™

upon, though their exact market percentage is a topic of hot debateì

These are the major Web servers:

  Apachk

  Microsoft’s IIS

  Netscape Web server—

  WebSitk

  WebStaK

These popular Web servers are discussed in the following sections. This should b_

no means be considered as approval of these products, just a synopsis of each producš

and some of its known issuesì

Apache (http://www.apache.org)

A descendant of NCSA’s httpd server, Apache is probably the first or second mosš

popular Web server on the Internet. Apache’s popularity stems from the fact that it i—

free and fast. It is also very powerful, supporting features such as HTTP 1.1, extende™

serve§side includes (SSIs), a module architecture similar to NSAPI/ISAPI, an™

numerous free modules that perform functions such as serve§based Perl interpretatio-

or interpretation of parsed HTML. However, Apache is not for everyone. The mai-

issuk wit— Apachk i— thaš iš isn’š ¾ commerciaR packageì Whilk therk i— generall_ supporš

available on the Internet, many firms may be hesitant to run their missio™criticaR

systems on a use§supported product. However, as with operating systems such a—

Linux, various third parties offer commercial support for Apacheì

Another potential limiting factor for Apache is that the system currently is mainl_

for UNIX, although a port to Windows 95/Windows NT was recently developed. Thi—

may limit the use of Apache to higuuse external and noâfo§profit Web sites ratheK

than intranets. Last, Apache might require modification of configuration files or eve-

compilation in order to install. If you like to tinker, have a UNIX system, and don’š

have a lot of money, then Apache might just be for you. You’ll be in good company:

some of the largest Web sites on the Internet swear by this productì

For Web trivia buffs, the name Apache is derived from the description of the software ax

a patched version of NCSA. Think “a patchy NCSA server.”

Microsoft Internet Information Serve5

(http://www.microsoft.com/iis)

IIS is Microsoft’s server for Windows NT. Windows 95 also supports a similar buš

much less powerful version of IIS called the Personal Web Server (PWS). While PWS  SITE DELIVERY

is certainly popular, of the two, most organizations favor IIS. One very importanš

aspect of IIS is that it is very tightly integrated with the Windows NT environmentì

Unfortunately, being so Windows NT specific is also considered one of the problem—

with IIS. Because of hardware and clustering issues, it hasn’t proved quite as scalablk

a— somk UNIX-base™ serversì Wit— neu Microsofš clusteriný technologie— an™ integratio-

with a transaction processor, this scalability problem is likely to change. For an intraneš

environment, particularly one with heavy Microsoft investment, it is difficult to beaš

the services offered by IIS—particularly its integration with other Microsoft product—

such as the SQL-Server database system. The price for IIS is currently a big selliný

point for the software: it’s freeì

Netscape Web Servers (http://home.netscape.com/servers)

Netscape has a growing line of Web servers, ranging from its FastTrack system tf

its Enterprise server. Netscape Web servers run on most major variants of UNIX

(Solaris, SuƒS, AIX, HKUX, Digital UNIX, and IRIX), as well as Windows 95 an™

Windows NT. The systems are advanced, supporting hooks with databases, contenš

 = Page 625 =

60  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

management, HTTP 1.1, and a variety of other features. Netscape has attempted tf

make the software more commercial grade, including We~based installation an™

administration. The only gripe people tend to make about these servers is that the_

sometimes perform sluggishly. Otherwise, if you are in a cros-platform environment,

consider using Netscape servers. Netscape Web software is available for evaluation,

but it is commercial and requires paymentì

WebSite (http://website.ora.com)

A very easÇtkuse Web server for Window 95 and Windows NT, O’Reilly’s WebSitk

is one of the only robust Web servers available for Windows 95. Though it lacks thk

performance of Netscape or Microsoft servers running on more powerful systems,

WebSite is considered one of the easiest servers to install and administer. Furthermore,

the system provides many nice development features such as integration with Col™

Fusion, advanced SSI, and special APIs for server extensions. For intranets or sites thaš

don’t need the performance of Windows NT or UNIX, WebSite is a great choiceì

WebStar (http://www.starnine.com)

The most popular Web server for the Macintosh was originally based on MacHTTPDì

WebStar integrates well with the Macintosh. It supports AppleScript and otheK

Macintosuspecific tools and ideas such as automatic binhexing of files. The syste“

supports UNIX-style CGI programs, a Java virtual machine for serve§side Java, an™

extended SSI. The performance of WebStar often leaves much to be desired, thoug—

claims have been made that this has been improved. WebStar is probably more tha-

adequate for intranets or small Web sitesì

In the Web server software discussion, people often don’t consider that differenš

packages will have different performance characteristics. Using the same hardware,

one Web server software package may far outperform another. When planning to buil™

a Web server, start either from the hardware and build up, or from the particulaK

software and build down, picking the best possible hardware. If you make goo™

software and hardware choices, the performance of the site can be significantl_

improved. However, be sure to base your builÙout on requirements. It is alway—

possible to design your Web server to handle a certain number of users or request—

per second or minuteì

How Web Servers Work

Whe- iš come— tf thk physicaR proces— o“ publishiný documents, thk mai- issue— ark

whetheK tf ru- youK ow- serveK oK tf hosš elsewherk i- conjunctio- wit— WeD serveK

softwark an™ hardwareì A- understandiný o“ hou WeD server— df theiK joD i— importanš

tf understandiný potentiaR bottleneck— an™ lead— tf a- i™dept— understandiný o“ hou

thk WeD worksì I- somk sense, alR thaš ¾ WeD serveK doe— i— liste- foK request— fro“

browser— or, a— the_ ark calle™ mork generically,  use( agentx  ì Onck thk serveK receive— ¾

 = Page 626 =

ChapteX 16  Puttin‚ I@ AlN Together Deliverin‚ thf Web Sitf  60

request, typicall_ tf deliveK ¾ file, iš determine— i“ iš shoul™ df itì I“ so, iš copie— thk filk

fro“ thk diskouš tf thk network ì §- somk cases, thk useK agenš ma_ askthk serveK tf

executk ¾ program, buš thk ide¾ i— thk same: eventually, somk dat¾ i— transmitte™ backtf

thk browseK foK displayì Thi— discussio- betwee- thk useK agent, typicall_ ¾ WeD

browser, an™ thk serveK take— plack usiný thk HTTf protocolì

HTTV

The Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) is the basic underlying applicatio™leveR

protocol used to facilitate the transmission of data to and from a Web server. HTTf

provides a simple, fast way to specify the interaction between client and server. Thk

protocol actually defines how a client must ask for data from the server and how thk

server returns it. HTTP does not specify how the data is actually transferred; this is u5

to lowe§level network protocols such as TCPì

The first version of HTTP, known as version 0.9, was used as early as 1990. Thk

current version of HTTP 1, as defined by RFC 1945, is supported by most servers an™

clients (Web browsers). However, HTTP 1 does not properly handle the effects o“

hierarchical proxies and caching, or provide features to facilitate virtual hosts. Mork

important, HTTP 1 has significant performance problems due to the opening an™

closing of many connections for a single Web pageì

HTTP 1.1 solves many of these problems. It is currently supported by newer,

version 4–generation Web browsers as well as servers. There are still many limitation—

to HTTP, however. It is used increasingly in applications that need more sophisticate™

features, including distributed authoring, collaboration, and remote procedure callsì

The Protocol Extension Protocol (PEP) is a proposed extension to HTTP designed tf

address the tension between browser, server, and proxy vendor enhancemenš

agreements and public specifications. PEP allows the software to introduce neu

SITE DELIVERY

protocols during communication, negotiate protocols or content, or even switc—

between protocols o™th[fly. For now, such protocols are still in development. Thi—

discussion will deal with HTTP 1 and 1.1ì

The process of a Web browser or other user agent such as a Web spider or roboš

requesting a document from a web—or, more correctly, an HTTP server—is simple an™

has been discussed throughout the book. The overall process is diagrammed i-

Figure 16-2ì

In Figure 16-2, the user first requests a document from a Web server by specifyiný

the URL of the document desiredì

During this step, a domain name lookup may occur, which translates a machine nam—

such as www.bigcompany.com to an underlying IP address such as 192.102.249.3. If th—

domain name lookup fails, an error message such as “No such host” or “The server doex

not have a DNS entry” will be returned. Certain assumptions, such as the defaulP

service port to access for HTTP requests (80), may also be made. This is transparent tX

the user, who simply uses a(RL to access a page.

 = Page 627 =

60‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 16-28  Overview of Web client/server relationshi—

 = Page 628 =

ChapteX 16  Puttin‚ I@ AlN Together Deliverin‚ thf Web Sitf  60

The browser then forms the proper HTTP request and sends the request to thk

server residing at the address specified by the URL. A typical HTTP request consists o“

HTTP-Method Identifier HTTP-versioY

<Optional additional request headersL

In this example, thk HTTKMethod would bk  GE  oK  POS  . An identifier mighš

correspond to the file desired (for example,  /reports/latest.htm“  ), and the HTTKversio-

indicates the dialect of HTTP being used (for example,  HTTP/1.0  )ì

If a user requests a document with the URL http://www.bigcompany.com/

reports/lastest.html, the browser might generate a request such as the one show-

here to retrieve the object from the server:

GET /reports/latest.html HTTP/1.0

If-Modified-Since: Tuesday, 12-Aug-99 01:39:39 GMT;

Referer: http://www.bigcompany.com/reports/index.htm¤

Connection: Keep-Aliv4

User-Agent: Mozilla/4.02 [en] (X11; I; SunOSS suhm)

Accept: image/gif, image/x-xbitmap, image/jpeg, image/pjpeg, */*

Accept-Language: eY

Accept-Charset: iso-8859-1,*,utf-8

People often ask why the complete URL is not shown in the request. It isn’š

necessary in most cases, except when using a proxy server. The use of a relative URL

in the header is adequate. The server knows where it is; it just needs to know whaš

document to get from its own file tree. In the case of using a proxy server, whic—

SITE DELIVERY

requests a document on behalf of a browser, a full URL is passed to it that is later madk

relative by the proxy. Besides the simplk  GE  method, there are various other method—

specified in HTTP. Not all are commonly used. Table 16-2 provides a summary of thk

HTTP 1.1 request methodsì

Withi- a- HTTf request, therk i— ¾ variet_ o“ optionaR field— foK creatiný ¾ completk

requestì Thk commo- field— an™ a- examplk foK eac— ark show- i- thk followiný sectionsì

Accept:  MIME-typs MIME-subtyps  /

anythiný i— accepted; however, iš i— possiblk tf indicatk particulaK contenš type— suc—

a—  image/jpeg  sf thk serveK ca- makk ¾ decisio- o- whaš tf returnì Thi— facilit_ coul™

suc— a— lasš modificatio- data, buš doe— noš retur- thk actuaR objecš

OPTIONS  Returns information about the capabilities supported by a serveK

if no location is specified, or the possible methods that can bk

applied to the specified objecš

POS  Sends information to the address indicated by the identifier;

generally used to transmit information from a form using thk

METHOD="POST"  attribute of thk  <FORM  element to ¾

serve§based CGI progra“

PU  Sends data to the server and writes it to the address specified b_

the identifier overwriting previous content; in basic form, can bk

used for file uploa™

DELET¨  Removes the file specified by the identifier; generally disallowe™

TRAC¨  Provides diagnostic information by allowing the client to sek

what is being received on the serveK

This field indicates the character set that is accepted by the browser, such as ASCII oK

Accept-language:  languags

This field lists the languages preferred by the browser and could be used by the serveK

to pass back the appropriate language dataì

Accept-Language: eY

Authorization:  authorization-scheme authorization-datC

This field is typically used to indicate the userid and “encrypted” password if the useK

is returning authorization informationì

Authorization: user joeblow:testpas?

Content-length:  byte“

This field gives the length in bytes of the message being sent to the server, if anyì

Remember that the browser may upload or pass data using thk  PU  oK  POS  methodì

Content-length: 1805

SITE DELIVERY

Content-type:  MIME-typs MIME-subtyps  /

This field indicates the MIME type of a message being sent to a server, if any. The valuk

of this field would be particularly important in the case of file uploadì

Content-type: text/plaiY

Date:  date-tims

This field indicates the date and time in Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) that a requesš

was made. GMT time is mandatory for time consistency, given the worldwide naturk

of the Webì

Date: Thursday, 15-Jan-99 01:39:39 GM

610  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

reasons, this request header often is not sentì

From: joe@bigcompany.co—

Hos

This field indicates the host and port of the server to which the request is being madeì

Host: www.bigcompany.co—

If-Modified-Since:  date-tims

This field indicates file freshness to improve the efficiency of thk  GE  method. Whe-

used in conjunction with ¾  GE  request for a particular file, the requested file i—

checked to see if it has been modified since the time specified in the field. If the file ha—

not been modified, a “Not Modified” code (304) is sent to the client so a cached versio-

of the document can be used; otherwise, the file is returned normallyì

If-Modified-Since: Thursday, 15-Jan-99 01:39:39 GM

If-Match:  selector-string

Thi— fiel™ make— ¾ requesš conditionall_ onl_ i“ thk item— “atc— somk selectoK valuk

passe™ inì Imagink onl_ usiný  POS  tf ad™ dat¾ onck iš ha— bee- move™ tf ¾ filk

calle™ olddataì

If-Match: "olddata"

If-None-Match:  selector-string

Thi— fiel™ doe— thk oppositk o“  If-Matc—  ì Thk metho™ i— conditionaR onl_ i“ thk selectoK

doe— noš matc— anythingì Thi— mighš bk usefuR foK preventiný overwrite— o“ existiný filesì

If-None-Match: "newfile"

If-Range:  selecto5

I“ ¾ clienš ha— ¾ partiaR cop_ o“ a- objecš i- it— cachk an™ wishe— tf havk a- uštkdatk cop_ o“

thk entirk objecš there, iš coul™ usk thk  Rang2  requesš headeK wit— thi— conditionaR  If-Rang2

modifieK tf updatk thk fileì Modificatio- selectio- ca- takk plack o- timk ¾— uellì

If-Range: Thursday, 15-Jan-99 01:39:39 GMT;

 = Page 632 =

ChapteX 16  Puttin‚ I@ AlN Together Deliverin‚ thf Web Sitf  61h

If-Unmodified-Sincs

This field makes a conditional method. If the requested file has not been modified sinck

the specified time, the server should perform the requested method; otherwise, thk

method should failì

If-Unmodified-Since: Thursday, 15-Jan-99 01:39:39 GM

Max-Forwards:  intege5

This field is used with thk  TRAC¨  method to limit the number of proxies or gateway—

that can forward the request. This would be useful to determine failures if a requesš

moves through many proxies before reaching the final serverì

Max-Forwards: 6

MIME-version:  version-numbe5

This field indicates the MIME protocol version, understood by the browser, that thk

server should use when fulfilling requestsì

MIME-Version: 1.0

Proxy-Authorization:  authorization informatio

Thi— fiel™ allow— thk clienš tf identif_ itsel“ oK thk useK tf ¾ prox_ thaš

require— authenticationì

SITE DELIVERY

Proxy-Authorization: joeblow: testpass; Realm: Al¤

Pragma: “  erver-directivs

This field passes information to a server; for example, this field can be used to inform ¾

caching proxy server to fetch a fresh copy of a pageì

Pragma: no-cach4

Range:  byte-rangs

This field requests a particular range of a file such as a certain number of bytesì

The example shows a request for the last 500 bytes of a fileì

Range: bytes=-500

 = Page 633 =

61p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Referrer:  UR¤

This field indicates the URL of the document from which the request originates (i-

other words, the linking document). This value may be empty if the user has entere™

the URL directly rather than by following a linkì

Referrer: http://www.bigcompany.com/reports/index.htm¤

User-Agent:  agent-cods

This field indicates the type of browser making the requestì

User-Agent: Mozilla/3.0 (Windows 95; Internet Explorer)

Note that all of these request headers seem very familiar. They constitute the samk

environment variables that you can access from within a CGI program. Now it shoul™

be clear how this information is obtainedì

AfteK receiviný ¾ request, thk WeD serveK attempt— šf 5roces— thk requestì Thk

resulš o“ thk requesš i— indicate™ b_ ¾ serveK statu— link thaš contain— ¾ responsk code,

foK example, thk eve§populaK “Noš Found” (404)ì Thk serveK responsk statu— link

take— thi— form:

HTTP-version Status-code Reason-Strin(

For a successful query, a status line might read as follows:

HTTP/1.0   200   OK

while in case of error the status line might rea™

HTTP/1.0  Y04   Not Found

The status codes for the emerging HTTP 1.1 standard are listed in Table 16-3ì

After the status line, the server responds with information about itself and the dat¾

being returned. There are various selected response headers, but the most importanš

indicates the type of data in the form of a MIME-type and subtype that will bk

returned. Like request headers, many of these codes are optional and depend on thk

status of the requestì

 = Page 634 =

ChapteX 16  Puttin‚ I@ AlN Together Deliverin‚ thf Web Sitf  61

Status Cods  Reason String  Descriptio

Informational Codes (Process Continues After This)

100  Continuk  An interim response issued by the serveK

that indicates the request is in progres—

but has not been rejected or acceptedì

HTTP 1.1ì

be used to initiate a rea_time protocolì
