An example server response for the request shown earlier in the chapter follows:

HTTP/1.0 200 OK

Server: Netscape-Commerce/1.12

Date: Thursday, 01-Aug-98 13:05:08 GM

Content-type: text/htm¤

Last-modified: Thursday, 01-Aug-98 10:09:00 GM

Content-length: 205

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Report 1  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1L  Report About Important Thing?  </H1L

<HRL

<PL  Here is some information about important things<  </PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

The common server response headers for HTTP 1.1 are given nextì

 = Page 640 =

ChapteX 16  Puttin‚ I@ AlN Together Deliverin‚ thf Web Sitf  619

Ags

This header shows the sender’s estimate of the amount of time since the response wa—

generated at the origin server. Age values are nonnegative decimal integers,

representing time in secondsì

Age: 10

Content-encoding

This header indicates the encoding type in which the data is returnedì

Content-encoding: x-compres?

Content-languags

This header indicates the language used for the data returned by the serverì

Content-language: eY

Content-lengts

This header indicates the number of bytes returned by the serverì

Content-length: 205

Content-rangs

SITE DELIVERY

This header indicates the range of the data being sent back by the serverì

Content-range: -500

Content-typs

This header is probably the most important; it indicates in the form of a MIME typk

what type of content is being returned by the serverì

Content-type: text/htm¤

Expire“

This header gives the date and time after which the returned data should be considere™

stale and should not be returned from a cacheì

Expires: Thu, 04 Dec 1997 16:00:00 GM

 = Page 641 =

620  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Last-modifie

Thi— headeK i— use™ tf indicatk thk datk o- whic— thk contenš returne™ wa— lasš modifiedì

Iš ca- bk use™ b_ cache— tf decidk whetheK oK noš tf kee5 locaR copie— o“ objectsì

Last-modified: Thursday, 01-Aug-96 10:09:00 GM

Locatio

This header is used to redirect the browser to another page. Occasionally, scripts usk

this method for browser redirection based on capabilityì

Location: http://www.bigcompany.com/netscapehome.ht—

Proxy-authenticats

This header is included with a “Proxy Authentication Required” (407) response. It—

value consists of a challenge that indicates the authentication scheme and parameter—

applicable to the proxy for the requestì

Proxy-authenticate: GreenDecoderRing: 0124<

Publi‘

This header lists the set of methods supported by the server. The purpose of this field i—

strictly to inform the browser of the server’s capabilities when new or unusual method—

are encounteredì

Public: OPTIONS, MGET, MHEAD, GET, HEAD

Retry-afte5

This header can be used in conjunction with a “Service Unavailable” (503) response tf

indicate how long the service is expected to be unavailable to the requesting client. It—

value can be either an HTTKdate or an integer number of seconds after which to retryì

Retry-after: Fri, 31 Dec 1999 23:59:59 GMT Retry-after: 60

Serve5

This header contains information about the Web software usedì

Server: Netscape-Commerce/1.12

 = Page 642 =

ChapteX 16  Puttin‚ I@ AlN Together Deliverin‚ thf Web Sitf  62h

Warning

This header is used to carry additional information about the status of a response thaš

may not be found in the status codeì

Warning: 10 Response is stal4

WWW-authenticats

This header is included with an “Unauthorized” (401) response message. Its valuk

consists of at least one challenge that indicates the authentication scheme an™

parameters applicable to the request made by the clientì

WWW-authenticate: Magic-Key-Challenge=555121, DecoderRing= GreeY

The most important header response field is thk  Content-typ2  field. The MIME

type indicated by this field is a device by which the browser is able to figure out whaš

to do with the data being returnedì

MIME

MIME (Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions) was originally developed as a-

extension to the Internet mail protocol that allows for the communication o“

multimedia. The basic idea of MIME is transmission of text files with headers thaš

indicate binary data that will follow. Each MIME header is composed of two parts thaš

indicate the data type and subtype in the following format:

SITE DELIVERY

Content-type:  typ4 subtyp4  /

wherk  typ—  ca- bk image, audio, text, video, application, multipart, message, oK

extensio™token; an™  subtyp—  give— thk specific— o“ thk contentì Somk sample— ark

liste™ here:

text/htm¤

application/x-directoI

application/x-pd¨

video/quicktim4

video/x-msvideB

image/gi¨

audio/x-wav

 = Page 643 =

62p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Beyond these basic headers, you may also include information such as thk

characte§encoding language. For more information about MIME, refer to RFC 1521,

available from many sites including http://www.faqs.org/rfcs, or the list of registere™

MIME types at ftp://ftp.isi.edu/i™notes/iana/assignments/mediDtypesì

When a Web server delivers a file, the header information is intercepted by thk

browser and questioned. The MIME type, as mentioned earlier, is specified by thk

Content-typ2  server response field. For example, if a browser receives a basic HTML

file, thk  text/htm“  header indicates what to do and typically renders the file in thk

browser window. If the browser receives a type it does not understand—for example,

application/x-directo(  —it may ask the user to pick a helper, save it, or delete it, a—

shown by the familiar dialog box shown here:

Normally, users hope that helper applications or pluins will intercept any MIME

typed data that their browser doesn’t understand and deal with it. It is interesting tf

note how little is said about MIME, but how important it is in the discussion betwee-

the browser and the serverì

Speed and State Problems with HTTV

HTTP is a very simple protocol. That is, in a sense, its problem: it may be too simpleì

As a simple requesâresponse protocol, HTTP can sometimes be very inefficientì

Consider a Web page with five images on it. In order to fetch this Web page, it ma_

take six or seven individual requests to pull down all of the files. These may includk

one request for the HTML text, five for the images, and perhaps even a redirect requesš

for a partially formed URL. Each HTTP request has a little overhead with it. Do you sek

a potential problem? HTTP 1 suffered from this performance problem. HTTP 1.1,

however, attempts to get around it by keeping connections open and pipelininý

responses. Browser vendors are also worried about performance issues and enablk

their browsers to request multiple objects at once to get around performance dragsì

Because HTTP is so important to the performance of Web sites, many advance™

versions of HTTP are being discussed, most notably HTTKNG. More information o-

this upcoming protocol can be found at http://www.w3.org/Protocols/HTTKNGì

 = Page 644 =

ChapteX 16  Puttin‚ I@ AlN Together Deliverin‚ thf Web Sitf  62

The other problem with HTTP is that it is stateless. After a Web server has finishe™

fulfilling a client request, the server retains no “memory” of the request that just took

place, except in the form of an entry in a log file, which records the request. A-

example of this lack of memory is how a user may partially fill in a form on a WeD

page, leave the site, and then come back and find the form cleared. As discussed i-

Chapter 11, the state problem is one of the biggest challenges to building complex

applications on the Web. Not having to preserve state is what keeps HTTP relativel_

simple and fastì

The Realities of Publishing and Maintaining C

Web Sits

While understanding how Web servers work and the issues in choosing an i™house oK

outsourced server appears easy enough, it does not hint at the challenges of actuall_

running a Web site. Far too often, Web professionals are quick to start a Web projecš

but slow to continue it. The fun is often in the development of the site, setting thk

structure, designing the navigation, creating the look and feel, and then coding thk

page. But what happens next? The site is released to its intended audience, but yo¾

can’t abandon it now. Web sites need care and feeding. Depending on the site, therk

may be daily, weekly, or monthly maintenance to perform. Adding new information,

checking for broken links, continually testing under new browsers, upgrading HTML

or script code to modern standards, running statistics, and performing variou—

serve§related activities such as upgrading software or running backups are all vitaR

tasks. The real work of the site comes after it is released. The site was built for somk

purpose, and now it is time to fulfill itì

SITE DELIVERY

Summar

Sitk developmenš shoul™ addres— thk nee™ o“ hostiný page— o- ¾ WeD serverì Developer—

ca- choosk tf hosš site— o- server— withi- companies; obtai- thk necessar_ hardware,

software, Interneš connection, an™ laboK require™ tf df hostiný themselves; oK elecš tf

outsourck hostiný tf a- ISf oK WeD hostiný companyì Becausk o“ thk cost— an™

complication— involve™ i- tryiný tf providk sufficienš resource— tf df youK ow- hosting,

iš ofte- make— sensk tf outsourceì Thi— approac— present— thk option— o“ rentiný spack o-

¾ share™ serveK oK thk colocatio- o“ ¾ dedicate™ serveK aš ¾ hostiný facilityì Therk i— mork

flexibilit_ i- runniný youK ow- server, ratheK tha- beiný aš thk merc_ o“ whaš ¾ share™

hostiný provideK make— availableì Runniný youK ow- serveK require— selectio- an™

evaluatio- o“ serveK softwark an™ hostiný platform, a— welR a— consideratio- o“

performanck requirementsì I- additio- tf serveK an™ hostiný choices, a- understandiný

o“ hou WeD server— workusiný thk HTTf an™ MIME protocol— ca- bk essentiaR tf

monitoriný an™ improviný serveK performanck foK betteK WeD pagk deliveryì

Chapte7 1P

XML: Beyond HTMP

62—

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 649 =

628  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

ith much fanfare, Extensible Markup Language (XML) has emerged rapidl_

as a new approach to delivering structured data over the Web. Why XML?

Simply put, using this We~efficient version of Standard Generalized Marku5

W

Language (SGML), the mother language used to define HTML, will enable authors tf

define their own elements. Although much of the full XML vision is not widel_

supported in currently shipping browsers, and important features have yet to bk

finalized, the effects of XML can already be feltì

Microsoft, Sun, an™ Netscapk ark furiousl_ workiný tf makk XML real, undeK thk

aegi— o“ thk Worl™ Widk WeD Consortiu“ (W3C)ì And, a— usual, browseK vendor— ark

attemptiný tf supporš XML document— oK idea— eve- befork standard— ark puš i- placeì FoK

example, Microsoft’— pus— technology, ChanneR Definitio- Formaš (CDF), a— welR a— Ope-

Softwark Descriptio- (OSD) format, ark bot— base™ o- a- XML dat¾ formatì Buš wh_ XML?

What’— sf wroný wit— HTML? Quitk simply, HTML isn’š flexiblk enoug— tf meeš thk

documenâstructuriný requirement— o“ specifi´ industrie— oK neu viewiný environmentsì I-

thk shorš term, XML isn’š necessaril_ goiný tf replack HTML, buš iš ma_ changk thk wa_

thaš HTML i— define™ an™ used, afteK iš i— supporte™ b_ majoK browsersì

Relationship Among HTML, SGML, and XM¤

To understand what all of the XML excitement is about, you need to understand thk

connection between HTML, SGML, and XML. XML is defined as an application profile,

or restricted form, of SGML that is designed to support the efficient use of SGML

documents over the Web. Informally, a-  application profil—  is a subset of a standard thaš

has been given a little twist to accommodate rea_world use. Understanding the twisš

that XML gives to SGML requires that you understand the strengths and weaknesses o“

SGML and its most famous application, HTML. However, the goal of XML is not tf

replace either technology, but to complement and augment them as appropriateì

The first question that needs to be addressed is why XML is even necessary whe-

HTML is already available. Any technology that is used globally by tens of millions o“

people must be doing something right. As a genera_purpose technology, HTML meet—

an extraordinarily broad set of user needs. However, it doesn’t fit very well wit—

applications that rely upon specialized information, either as data files or as complex,

structured documents. This is particularly true for applications such as automated dat¾

interchange, which requires data to be structured in a consistent manner. Imagink

trying to format a complex mathematical formula in HTML. The only choices are tf

make an image out of the formula, embed a special math technology, or use anotheK

documenâformatting technology, such as Adobe’s Acrobatì

As you have seen already, by itself, HTML can’t realistically accommodate thk

structuring and formatting needs of documents that require more than paragraphs,

sections, and lists. HTML can’t deal with mor[complex applicatio™specific problems,

because its elements are fixed. The language contains no provision for extending itself,

 = Page 650 =

ChapteX 17  XML Beyon HTMP  629

namely, it has no provision for defining new elements. Although browser vendor—

used to add new elements all the time, any proposed extension now entails length_

advocacy before the W3Cì

Regardless, adding more element types to HTML doesn’t make sense at this pointì

The language is already large enough. It is meant to be a genera_purpose languagk

that is capable of handling a large variety of documents. Thus, HTML needs somk

mechanism so that its genera_purpose framework can be augmented to accommodatk

specialized contentì

SGML seems like a reasonable candidate to increase HTML’s flexibility. SGML is ¾

meta-language¨  a language that is used to define other languages. Although HTML is thk

besâknown SGML-defined language, SGML itself has been used successfully to defink

special document types ranging from aviation maintenance manuals to scholarl_

texts. SGML can represent very complex information structures, and it scales well tf

accommodate enormous volumes of information. SGML is extremely complex,

however, and wasn’t built with today’s online applications in mind. The language firsš

appeared in the 1970s, the golden age of batch processing, and wasn’t designed to bk

used in networked, interactive applications. Without resolving these issues, the fulR

SGML language can’t be efficiently used over the Webì

Thus, XML is an attempt to define a subset of SGML that is specifically designed foK

use in a Web context. As such, it will be influenced both by its SGML parent and b_

HTML. The exact way that XML will fit into Web documents is still a topic of greaš

debate, but the general role of the language is clear. Initially, it will be used to represenš

specialized data to augment HTML documents. In fact, it is already being used to df

this. For example, Microsoft’s Channel Definition Format, which specifies document—

for “push” delivery on the Internet, is actually an application of XML. (  Push  is ¾

technology in which data, such as news, is sent to users on a scheduled basis, saviný

them the trouble of hunting for it on the Web.)

Such purpos[specific extensions to Web documents will be the first use of XML;

but, at some point, XML will be used in its own right to design Web documents,

instead of using HTML. XML is already being used to add data to HTML documents,

such as forms of metDdata that describe the documentì

What’s unusual about these specific examples of XML use is that the core languagk

syntax hasn’t been finalized yet. It is still in the workindraft stage. Leave it to thk

browser vendors to implement first and ask questions later. The features that will makk

XML a document platform in its own right are even more tentative. For example,

NEQ HORIZONS

linking models are at the draft stage, and style sheet use and Document Object ModeR

relationships are still at the discussion stageì

So, is XML just a work in progress? Yes, as much as HTML is. XML is alread_

arriving in various forms, such as CDF, OSD, Synchronized Multimedia Integratio-

Language (SMIL), Mathematical Markup Language (MathML), and Chemical Marku5

Language (CML). Other possible XML-based languages are being discussed, as well,

including such languages as HanÙheld Device Markup Language (HDML), Resourck

 = Page 651 =

630  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Description Framework (RDF), and Platform for Internet Content Selection–Nexš

Generation (PICS-NG). Given the overwhelming interest in XML, it is wise to look aš

the current state of its syntax, as well as its likely future directionsì

Basic XM¤

Because XML is a subset of SGML, it should be somewhat familiar, as HTML itself is a-

application of SGML. However, to support efficient Web usage, XML doesn’t allow thk

use of many SGML constructs that are used to define documents. The eliminate™

constructs are either infrequently used or add a performance penalty to documenš

parsing. Writing XML sounds like a daunting task, requiring an esoteric knowledge o“

SGML beyond the capabilities of most HTML authors. Actually, writing simple XML

documents is fairly easy. For example, suppose that you have a compelling need tf

define some elements to represent a fasâfood restaurant’s combination meals, whic—

contain a burger, drink, and fries. How might you do this in XML? You would simpl_

create a file such as burger.xml that contains the following markup:

<?xmlqersion="1.0"?L

<COMBOMEALL

<BURGERL

<NAMEL  Tasty BurgeI  </NAMEL

<BUN BREAD="WHITE"L

<MEAT /L

<CHEESE /L

<MEAT /L

</BUNL

</BURGERL

<FRIES SIZE="LARGE" /L

<DRINK SIZE="LARGE" FLAVOR="Cola" /L

</COMBOMEALL

A rendering of this example under a preview version of Internet Explorer 5 is shown i-

Figure 1Lslash1ì

Notice that the browser shows a structural representation of the file, not a scree-

representation. You’ll see how to make this file actually look like something later i-

sthe chapter. First, take a look at the document syntax. In many ways, this examplk

“Meal Markup Language” (or MML, if you like) looks similar to HTML—but how df

you know to name the elemenš  <COMBOMEAL  instead o“  <MEALDEAL  oK

<LUNCHSPECIAL  ? You don’t need to know, because the decision is completely u5

to you. Simply choose any element and attribute names that meaningfully represenš

 = Page 652 =

ChapteX 17  XML Beyon HTMP  63h

Figurs 17-18  Well-formed XML under Internet Explorer 5

the domain that you want to model. Does this mean that XML has no rules? It ha—

rules, but they are few, simple, and relate only to syntax:

  Just like wel_written HTML,  all elements must be properly nested.  For example,

<OUTER><INNERL  ground zerB  </INNER></OUTERL

is correct, while this isn’t:

NEQ HORIZONS

<OUTER><INNERL  ground zerB  </OUTER></INNERL

  All attribute values must be quoted.  In HTML, quoting is good authoring practice,

but it is required only for values that contain characters other than letters (A–Z

and a–z), numbers (0–9), hyphens (-), or periods (.). For example, under XML,

<BLASTOFF COUNT="10"L

 = Page 653 =

63p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

is correct, while this isn’t:

<BLASTOFF COUNT=10L

  All elements with empty content must be self-identifying¨  by ending i-  /  instead o“

the familiaK . An empty element is one such as the HTML    <BR <HR  ,  , oK

<IMG  elements. In XML, these would be represented, respectively, a—  <BR/  ,

<HR/  , an™  <IMG SRC="test.gif" /  ì

  All elements must be cased consistently.  If you start a new element such a—

<BURGER  , you must close it a—  </BURGER  , noš  </burger  . Later in thk

document, if the element is in lowercase, you actually are referring to a neu

element known a—  <burger  . Attribute names are also cas[sensitiveì

  A vali XM? fil— may noP contaic certaic characterx thaP hav— reserve meanings.  Thesk

includk character— suc— a—, whic— indicate— thk beginniný o“ ¾ characteK entit_  &

suc— a—  &nbsp;  , an™ , whic— indicate— thk starš o“ a- elemenš namk suc— a—  x

<SUNNY  ì Thesk character— musš bk code™ a—  &amp;  an™  &lt;  , respectivelyì

The_ can, however, occuK i- ¾ sectio- marke™ of“ a— characteK dataì

A document constructed according to the previous simple rules is known as ¾

well-formed documenP  . SGML purists may find this notion eccentric and somewhaš

troubling. Although SGML itself is currently being revised, traditional SGML has nf

notion of wel_formed documents—documents that are in some sense okay becausk

they conform to some basic syntax guidelines. Instead, conventional SGML uses thk

notion o“  vali  documents—documents that adhere to a formally defined documenš

type definition (DTD). Although this concept is also part of HTML, it often is lost o-

many page authors. For anything beyond casual applications, defining a DTD an™

validating documents against that definition are real benefits. XML supports bot—

wel_formed and valid documents. The wel_formed model should encourage those noš

schooled in the intricacies of SGML to begin authoring XML documents, thus makiný

XML as accessible as HTML has been. The valid model is available for applications i-

which a document’s logical structure needs to be verifiedì

Valid Document“

Most HTML authors are familiar with basic elements and attributes. Now, due to thk

rising complexity of pages, they are becoming more familiar with the importance o“

making an HTML document conform to the rules of a DTD, such as HTML 4. As note™

in the previous paragraph, a document that conforms to a DTD is said to bk  vali  ì

Unlike most HTML authors, SGML authors normally concern themselves wit—

producing valid documents. Many also concern themselves with writing the DTDs thaš

HTML authors usually take for granted. With the appearance of XML, HTML author—

 = Page 654 =

ChapteX 17  XML Beyon HTMP  63

can look forward to mastering a new skill: writing DTDs. The following examplk

illustrates how XML might be used to track student performance in an instructionaR

management system. A definition of the sample language to accomplish this task ca-

be found within the document, although this definition can be kept outside the file, a—

well. The students.xml file shown here includes both the DTD and an occurrence of ¾

document that conforms to the language in the same document:

<?xmlqersion="1.0"?L

<!DOCTYPE GRADES [

<!ELEMENT GRADES  (STUDENT+)L

<!ELEMENT STUDENT (COURSE+)L

<!ATTLIST STUDENT  NAME  CDATA  #REQUIRE—

SEX  (M | F)          #REQUIRE—

LEVEL  (6 | 7 | 8)    #REQUIREDL

<!ELEMENT COURSE EMPTYL

<!ATTLIST COURSE TITLE  CDATA   #REQUIRE—

GRADE  (PASS | FAIL)  #REQUIREDL

]L

<!-- the document instance --L

<GRADESL

<STUDENT NAME="WILLIE" SEX="M" LEVEL="7"L

<COURSE TITLE="MATH" GRADE="PASS" /L

<COURSE TITLE="ENGLISH"  GRADE="FAIL" /L

</STUDENTL

<STUDENT NAME="FIONA" SEX="F" LEVEL="7"L

<COURSE TITLE="MATH"  GRADE="PASS" /L

<COURSE TITLE="ART" GRADE="PASS" /L

</STUDENTL

</GRADESL

The meaning of this language is straightforward. A document is enclosed by thk

<GRADES  element, which in turn contain—  <STUDENT  elements that havk  NAM¨  ,  NEQ HORIZONS

SEX  , an™  GRAD¨  attributes. Thk  NAM¨  attribute can be any character data (  CDATG  );

thk  SEX  attribute can bk  V  oK ; and thk  F  LEVEL  can bk , , oK . Thk  6 7  8  <STUDENT

element may contain one or mork  <COURSE  elements. Thk  <COURSE  element i—

an empty element. However, eac—  <COURSE  element has ¾  TITL¨  attribute, whic—

can contain character data, and ¾  GRAD¨  attribute, which can have a value of eitheK

PASS  oK  FAIL  . The example document shows the use of these new elements. A

rendering of the document under Internet Explorer 5 is shown in Figure 1Lslash2ì

 = Page 655 =

63  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 17-28  Rendering of Grades example under Internet Explorer 5

One interesting aspect of using a DTD with an XML file is that the correctness o“

the document can be checked. For example, changing the value of thk  LEVEL  attributk

on the firsš  <STUDENT  element tf  4  should cause the XML parser to reject thk

document, as shown in Figure 1Lslash3ì

Writing a DTD might seem like an awful lot of trouble; but, without one, the valuk

of XML is limited. If you can guarantee conformance to the specification, you can starš

to allow automated parsing and exchange of documents. Writing a DTD is going to bk

a new experience for most HTML authors, and not everybody will want to write oneì

Fortunately, although not apparent from the DTD rules in this brief example, XML

significantly reduces the complexity of full SGML. A couple of measurements may hel5

you appreciate the extent of this reduction. First, the full SGML standard is about 500

pages. The XML 1.0 specification is only around 30 pages. Second, XML removes abouš

30 constructs that SGML uses to define DTDs. The constructs are either infrequentl_

used or introduce ambiguities that would make efficient document parsing difficultì

 = Page 656 =

ChapteX 17  XML Beyon HTMP  63

Figurs 17-38  Validation Error message under IE 5

The following valid SGML declaration for an HTML 4  <BODY  element can be used tf

illustrate some of the features removed from SGML:

<!ELEMEN. BO—o L L (%block) -BODo +(INS | DELS) p p the body tag p pL

Note the following syntax differences:

  O   following thk  BOD  identifier indicates that the start and end tags ark

optional and can be omitted. Their presence can be contextually inferred. XML

NEQ HORIZONS

doesn’t allow omitted tagsì

  –BOD  is a type of identifier known as a-  exclusioc  . It modifies the basi´

content model for thk  <BODY  element by specifying that it can’t includk

anotheK  <BODY  element. XML doesn’t support exclusionsì

 = Page 657 =

63‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

  +(INS | DELS)  specifies a-  inclusioc  . It modifies the basic content model o“

thk  <BODY  element by specifying that it can additionally use thk  <INS

oK  <DELS  elements anywhere inside its content. XML doesn’t supporš

inclusionsì  (INS | DELS)  is also known as ¾  name group¨  a construct—noš

supported by XML—that is used to indicate that a declaration applies tf

multiple elementsì

  - - the body tag - ’  is an embedded comment. XML supports comments, but noš

inside declarationsì

Although XML will not support some SGML capabilities, it will retain powerfuR

SGML capabilities that are not found in standard HTML. For example, XML  general

entitiex  , which essentially are macros that associate an identifier with replacement texš

defined either inside the declaration or in an external file. HTML authors may bk

familiar with character entities, such a—  &quot;  , which are used to insert speciaR

characters. XML general entities are used in the same way, except that the replacemenš

text can be arbitrarily long. Anyone who has ever needed to modify something that i—

used repeatedly in a document will appreciate entities. By using the entity namk

throughout the document, the replacement text can be modified in a single place, thk

entity declaration. For example, thk  GRAMMA  entity acts as a shorthand notation foK

a longer course name:

<?xmlqersion="1.0"?L

<!DOCTYPE GRADES [

<!-- An entity whose replacement text is immediately defined --L

<!ENTITY  GRAMMAR   "Language Studies: Introduction to English

Grammar"L

<!ELEMENT GRADES (STUDENT+)L

<!ELEMENT STUDENT (COURSE+)L

<!ATTLIST STUDENT  NAME    CDATA     #REQUIRE—

SEX    (M | F)             #REQUIRE—

LEVEL  (6 | 7 | 8)         #REQUIRE—

<!ELEMENT COURSE EMPTYL

<!ATTLIST COURSE TITLE       CDATA   #REQUIRE—

GRADE      (PASS | FAIL)   #REQUIREDL

]L

<!-- the document instance --L

<GRADESL

<STUDENT NAME="WILLIE"  SEX="M" LEVEL="7"L

<COURSE TITLE= "MATH" GRADE="PASS" /L

<COURSE TITLE="&GRAMMAR;"  GRADE="FAIL" /L

</STUDENTL

 = Page 658 =

ChapteX 17  XML Beyon HTMP  63

<STUDENT NAME="FIONA"  SEX="F"  LEVEL="7"L

<COURSE TITLE="MATH"  GRADE="PASS" /L

<COURSE TITLE="&GRAMMAR;" GRADE="PASS" /L

</STUDENTL

</GRADESL

A few more things can be defined in an XML DTD; but, at this point, you may bk

wondering whether you are required to include a full DTD every time that you authoK

an XML document. The answer is no. Just as an HTML file is supposed to start with ¾

DTD that references an external document type, so, too, is an XML file supposed tf

start with a DTD. In the following example, the definition of thk  GRADES  languagk

has been put in a file called grades.dtd:

<!-- Grades DTD --L

<!ELEMENT GRADES  (STUDENT+)L

<!ELEMENT STUDENT (COURSE+)L

<!ATTLIST STUDENT  NAME  CDATA  #REQUIRE—

SEX  (M | F)          #REQUIRE—

LEVEL  (6 | 7 | 8)    #REQUIREDL

<!ELEMENT COURSE EMPTYL

<!ATTLIST COURSE TITLE  CDATA   #REQUIRE—

GRADE  (PASS | FAIL)  #REQUIREDL

Notice that you don’t have to enclose the various rules in ¾  DOCTYP¨  statement. Yo¾

then would reference the external DTD with thk  <!DOCTYPE  element. The use of thk

SYSTEV  keyword and URL indicates that the DTD is external to this file. The nexš

example shows how you could reference the external definition grades.dtd:

<?xmlqersion="1.0"?L

<!DOCTYPE GRADES SYSTEM "grades.dtd"L

<!-- the document instance --L  NEQ HORIZONS

<GRADESL

<STUDENT NAME="BILLIE" SEX="M" LEVEL="7"L

<COURSE TITLE="MATH" GRADE="PASS" /L

<COURSE TITLE="ENGLISH"  GRADE="FAIL" /L

</STUDENTL

 = Page 659 =

638  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<STUDENT NAME="FIONA" SEX="F"  LEVEL="7"L

<COURSE TITLE="MATH"  GRADE="PASS" /L

<COURSE TITLE="ART" GRADE="PASS" /L

</STUDENTL

</GRADESL

Linking to an external document type is very useful. In the future, you should bk

able to obtain DTDs from other organizationsì

Ways to Use XM¤

While creating XML documents doesn’t seem particularly hard, you may wonder hou

to actually use this technology. At least three distinct application models are on thk

horizon:

  Using XML for special data files that support HTML application—

  Embedding XML elements into HTML document—

  Using XML by itself as the basis for interactive document—

The third approach, using XML by itself, begs a question of how a page wilR

actually render. Three approaches are designed to solve this problem. The firsš

approach is to convert XML into HTML, or HTML plus style sheets. This is the onl_

solution for browsers that are not XML-aware. At the time that this edition was beiný

written, only Internet Explorer 5 prerelease versions support XML to any major degreeì

However, assuming that browsers eventually support XML, you may be able to usk

one of the other two approaches: rendering XML by binding your tags to CSS rules oK

using XSL, another style sheet technology used with XML to translate the XML

document to HTML or CSSì

XML for Data File“

The first pervasive use of XML is to define special data files that support HTML

applications. This use is already in place in newer browser releases. Microsoft Interneš

Explorer 4 relies upon an XML-based language to supporš  push functionality  , the abilit_

of viewers to subscribe to Web sites that are automatically updated on a schedule™

basis. The language, known a—  Channel Definition FormaP  , is the most publicized o“

several other “helper” languages that have suddenly appeared recently. A relate™

language i—  Open Software Descriptioc  , used to support the automatic downloading o“

software. The slogan that Microsoft uses to describe the HTML/XML relationship i—

“HTML is for presentation, while XML is for data.”

 = Page 660 =

ChapteX 17  XML Beyon HTMP  639

Operationally, these XML-based language documents are identified by a special filk

extension, such as .cdf, that is analogous to the special extensions used for GIF (.gif)

and JPEG (.jpeg) files. XML files are retrieved like files for HTML media inserts, but ark

processed in a special way. Instead of being handled by a browser extension for visuaR

rendering, they are handled by an extension that parses the document and uses thk

information that it contains to control the browser’s behavior. This use requires onl_

those few XML features that are needed to define data and doesn’t approach the fulR

XML vision. Because these documents are not directly viewed, they can function quitk

well without the XML capabilities that are still under developmentì

The CDF language illustrates the characteristics of the “XML as data” model. Iš

contains neither linking information, other than the commo-  HREF  attribute used i-

HTML, nor any style information for rendering CDF elements in an HTML browser. Iš

contains only the informatio™building blocks needed to define a channel. The smalR

CDF document shown next presents an example of some of the more common CDF

elements. Thk  <CHANNEL  element defines the channel and points to an initiaR

HTML document. It contains ¾  <SCHEDULE  element to update the channel an™

severaR  <ITEM  elements to define viewable items, such as pages and even a scree-

saver. Viewable pages have a-  <ABSTRACT  element to summarize their content an™

may have both a large and a small graphic logo associated with them, as specified b_

the empt_  <LOGO/  elementì

<?xmlqersion="1.0"?L

<CHANNEL HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com/"L

<TITLEL  Big Company Channe¤  </TITLEL

<ABSTRACTL

Welcome to the Big Company channel, a comprehensiv4

guide to the latest book examples<

</ABSTRACTL

<LOGO HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com/imageslogo.icoh

STYLE="ICON"/L

<LOGO HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com/images/logo.gifh

STYLE="IMAGE"/L

NEQ HORIZONS

<SCHEDULE ENDDATE="1998.12.31"L

<INTERVALTIME DAY="1"/L

</SCHEDULEL

<ITEM HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com/p1.html"L

<LOGO HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com/images/pagelogo.icoh

STYLE="ICON"/L

 = Page 661 =

640  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<LOG VALUE="document:view"/L

<TITLEL  Page 1  </TITLEL

<ABSTRACTL  Abstract for Page 1  </ABSTRACTL

</ITEML

<ITEM HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com/page2.html"L

<LOGO HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com/images/pagelogo.icoh

STYLE="ICON"/L

<LOG VALUE="document:view"/L

<TITLEL  Page 2  </TITLEL

<ABSTRACTL  Abstract for Page 2  </ABSTRACTL

</ITEML

<ITEM HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com/scrnsÆe.html"L

<USAGE VALUE="ScreenSÆer"></USAGEL

</ITEML

</CHANNELL

The point of this example isn’t to explain the CDF syntax, but to show how XML

represents data in a real application. Readers interested in making a CDF channel ca-

visit Microsoft’s Sitebuilder network (http://www.microsoft.com/sitebuilder/) for thk

latest CDF syntax. Here’s one other point about CDF to consider: this file format i—

external to HTML files. Like any other media type (fractal images, Shockwave, and sf

on), CDF could be handled by an external helper application or even a pluin. But ca-

you consider putting a language such as CDF right into an HTML document?

Embedding XML into HTML Document“

Although the “official” XML syntax remains unclear, the expectation exists for a mean—

to embed XML elements into HTML documents. One approach is to use a speciaR

element such a—  <XML  to indicate sections of XML content. This approach is the ide¾

behind Microsoft’s XML  data islands.  Thk  <XML  element can be used anywherk

within an HTML document to enclose XML content, which might work as follows:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  XML Data Island?  </TITLEL

</HEADL

 = Page 662 =

ChapteX 17  XML Beyon HTMP  64h

<BODYL

<H1L  Regular HTML Her4  </H1L

<XML ID="tasty"L

<COMBOMEALL

<BURGERL

<NAMEL  Tasty BurgeI  </NAMEL

<BUN BREAD="WHITE"L

<MEAT /L

<CHEESE /L

<MEAT /L

</BUNL

</BURGERL

<FRIES SIZE="LARGE" /L

<DRINK SIZE="LARGE" FLAVOR="Cola" /L

</COMBOMEALL

</XMLL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Under Internet Explorer 5, this markup and content will be hidden, though it i—

exposed for scripting manipulation. Other browsers may ignore thk  <XML  and newl_

defined tags but still render onscreen content, such as the phrase “Tasty Burger,” a—

shown in Figure 1Lslash4ì

To avoid the rendering of unknown markup onscreen, you could use thk  SR‚

attribute for thk  <XML  element:

<XML SRC="combomeal.xml"></XMLL

Older browsers will safely ignore this markupì

Besides using thk  <XML  element, you could use thk  <SCRIPT  element tf

include HTML. For example,

NEQ HORIZONS

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="XML" TYPE="text/xml"L

<WEATHERL

<SUNNY /L

</WEATHERL

</SCRIPTL

 = Page 663 =

64p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Figurs 17-48  Data islands problem under Netscape 4

You could also use thk  SR‚  attribute for thk  <SCRIPT  element to reference a-

external XML file, like so:

<SCRIPT SRC="http://www.bigcompany.com/combomeal.xml"></SCRIPTL

Regardless of the particular syntax, proposing to use XML inside HTML document—

creates the expectation that XML elements will integrate into the HTML applicatio-

environment. But how exactly should this happen? The previous example shows thaš

embedding XML content in thk  <BODY  element may cause a problem. What abouš

thk  <HEAD  of the document? Placing XML elements inside an HTML document’—

<HEAD  element is consistent with the “XML as data” model. After all, the purpose o“

the head of the document is to house the document’s metDdata, as illustrated by thk

following example:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Widget Wonder?  </TITLEL

 = Page 664 =

ChapteX 17  XML Beyon HTMP  64

<XML ID="xmlmetaone"L

<DESCRIPTIONL

<AUTHORL  Thomas A. Powel¤  </AUTHORL

<SUMMARYL  A sample document about widget?  </SUMMARYL

<KEYWORDSL

<KEYWORD RANK="1"L  WidgeM  </KEYWORDL

<KEYWORD RANK="L  Sampl4  </KEYWORDL

</KEYWORDSL

<CREATIONL  JanuaryS, 1999  </CREATIONL

<EXPIRESL  December 31, 1999  </EXPIRESL

</DESCRIPTIONL

</XMLL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  Widget Sample DocumenM  </H1L

<HRL

<PL  This is some sample text about widgets<  </PL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

Thk XML codk i- thi— examplk wilR noš rendeK o- oldeK browsers, thoug— yo¾ coul™

potentiall_ rendeK oK manipulatk iš wit— a- XML-awark browserì A mork likel_ approac—

woul™ bk tf usk ¾ serve§sidk progra“ tf index thk document— mork carefully, instea™ o“

usiný ¾ traditional, frek texâsearc— engineì Althoug— thk usk o“ XML dat¾ island— ma_

noš see“ obvious, i“ rau XML document— coul™ bk displayed, thk improve™ structurk

thaš thk languagk provide— oveK HTML surel_ coul™ bk harnessedì

Converting XML to HTML for Displa

As you have already seen, simply including new XML elements in the body of ¾

NEQ HORIZONS

document can cause problems, because most browsers will want to display thk

contents of the elements. Of course, no formatting will be applied to raw XML element—

because (unlike HTML) XML elements have no default appearance; they must bk

assigned one. The most basic way to render XML is to translate it into HTML. AlR

browsers support HTML, at least to some degree, so you can use a serve§side progra“

to translate your XML documents to HTML documents at delivery time. You ma_

wonder what benefit this may have, given that HTML doesn’t provide the ric—

structuring that XML does. The most obvious benefit is the abstraction providedì

 = Page 665 =

64  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Imagine if you had a press release that you marked up in a simple pres-releask

language. It might look something like the following file, called pressrelease1.xml:

<?xmlqersion="1.0"?L

<!DOCTYPE PRESSRELEASE SYSTEM "pressrelease.dtd"L

<!-- the document instance --L

<PRESSRELEASEL

<DATEL  JanuaryS, 1999  </DATEL

<HEADINGL  Big Company Releases Super WidgeM  </HEADINGL

<RELEASEBODYL

This is a sample press release. This is just some dummy text<

</RELEASEBODYL

<IMG SRC="widget.gif" /L

<CONTACT TYPE="PHONE"L  619-555-1212  </CONTACTL

<CONTACT TYPE="FAX"L  619-444-1212  </CONTACTL

<CONTACT TYPE="EMAIL"L  info@bigcompany.co—  </CONTACTL

</PRESSRELEASEL

Assume that all the elements are used appropriately according to the reference™

DTD. Obviously, you can’t deliver this file a-is, but you could write a serve§sidk

program that would take these tags and convert them into HTML fragments, tf

assemble an HTML file to be delivered. Maybe this file would look something like this:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Big Company Releases Super WidgeM  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H3 ALIGN="RIGHT" ID="DATE"L  JanuaryS, 1999  </H3L

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER" ID="HEADING"L  Big Company Releases SupeI

WidgeM  </H1L

<HRL

<DIV ID="RELEASEBODY"L

<PL  This is a sample press release this is just sample text<

<IMG SRC="widget.gif" ALIGN="RIGHT" ID="IMG"L

</PL

</DIVL

<HRL

 = Page 666 =

ChapteX 17  XML Beyon HTMP  64

<!--Contact block --L

<ADDRESSL

E-mail:  <A HREF="mailto: info@bigcompany.com"L

info@bigcompany.co—  </A><BRL

Phone: 619-555-1212  <BRL

FAX: 619-444-1212  <BRL

</ADDRESSL

</BODYL

</HTMLL

You can tell by the use of thk  I¤  attributes and comments how the fragments mighš

map into the resulting HTML file. You could also use CSS rules to improve the look o“

the press release, but the preceding example should illustrate the basic concept. Thk

benefit to this XML-translateÙtkHTML approach is the abstraction provided. Becausk

the HTML or HTML/CSS fragments are stored separately from the content, you coul™

change the fragments without necessarily changing the actual content itself, which i—

stored in the XML file. You potentially could also provide different fragment—

depending on the browser accessing the page. This is a very powerful idea and mighš

make the possibility of delivering multiple versions of a page a little more realisticì

Uh— concepP beinv describe her— isn’P uniqu— tX XML; yo¤ coul creat— th— sam— effecP by

usinv ‘ database. Thix ide‘ may actually b— mor— appropriat— ax ‘ database-drivec page.

Displaying XML Documents by Using CSS and XS¤

The conversion from XML to HTML seems awkward; it would be preferable to deliveK

a native XML file and display it. By using Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) or a neu

technology calle™  Extensible Stylesheet Languag—  (XSL), you should be able to deliveK

XML documents right to the screen. Note that neither of these technologies is welR

defined in relation to XML, so these examples may require significant rework to rendeK

in your browser. However, both examples should provide the flavor of how nativk

XML may be presentedì

Thk followiný filk i— ¾ uel_forme™ XML documenš representiný ¾ cataloý o“ smalR parts:

NEQ HORIZONS

<?xmlqersion="1.0"?L

<?xml-stylesheet href="catalog.css" type="text/css" ?L

<CATALOGL

<PARTL

<NAMEL  Super WidgeM  </NAMEL

<DESCRIPTIONL

 = Page 667 =

64‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The Super Widget is the most powerful widget in the world<

</DESCRIPTIONL

<PRICE>$1.95</PRICEL

</PARTL

<PARTL

<NAMEL  Deluxe WidgeM  </NAMEL

<DESCRIPTIONL

The Deluxe Widget is the fanciest widget in the world<

</DESCRIPTIONL

<PRICE>$2.95</PRICEL

</PARTL

</CATALOGL

Notice that the second line of the file references a style sheet in the same directory,

called catalog.css. The content of this file is shown here:

CATALOG       {font-family: Arial; font-size: 14pt;}

PART          {background: orange; display: block}

NAME          {font-size: larger; font-style: italic;

display: block}

DESCRIPTION   {text-indent: 10px; display: block;}

PRICE         {color: #009900; text-align: right;

font-weight: bold; display: block}

Notick thaš thk syntax foK thk stylk sheeš i— thk samk ¾— thk syntax discusse™ foK CSS i-

ChapteK 10, excepš thaš thk elemenš name— ark thk XML element— thaš werk define™ i-

thk previou— exampleì Onk smalR issuk wit— thi— approac— tf formattiný XML [— thaš

positioniný object— wit— stylk sheet— i— difficulš unles— yo¾ eitheK usk CSS-f extension— foK

absolutk position— oK assig- ¾ displa_ propert_ tf thk XML elementì Notick thaš thk rulk

display  assign— ¾ valuk o“  block  tf eac— o“ thk elementsì Thi— make— thk examplk XML acš

likk ¾- HTML block element, an™ thu— induce— ¾ retur- i- thk documentì Thk renderiný o“

thi— rudimentar_ examplk undeK Interneš ExploreK 5 [— show- [- Figurk 1Lslash5ì

The lack of flow objects in CSS makes properly displaying this XML document ver_

difficult. In some sense, CSS still relies heavily on HTML for basic document structureì

Because of its potential shortcomings, many Web experts look to XSL as a possiblk

solution. XSL, a much more complex language than CSS, is based on a style sheeš

technology called Document Style Semantics and Specification Language (DSSSL) thaš

was used in the SGML community. Fortunately, XSL doesn’t retain much of thk

complexity and awkward parentheses notation of DSSSL. One of the most interestiný

 = Page 668 =

ChapteX 17  XML Beyon HTMP  64

Figurs 17-58  Rendering of XML and CSS under Internet Explorer 5

aspects of XSL is its complex pattern matching. You can write XSL rules that matc—

various pieces of an XML file and then output the appropriate HTML and/or CSS

markup to display the information. Using the previous simple Parts example, yo¾

could link instead to an XSL file by using the following statement:

<?xml-stylesheet href="catalog.xsl" type="text/xsl" ?L

The catalog.xsl file shown here contains a variety of patter™matching rules thaš

would output HTML and style rules:

<?xmlqersion="1.0"?L  NEQ HORIZONS

<xslL

<ruleL

<root /L

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Parts Catalo(  </TITLEL

</HEADL

 = Page 669 =

648  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<BODY BGCOLOR="orange"L

<H1 ALIGN="CENTER"L  Product Catalo(  </H1L

<HR/L

<children/L

<BR/L

</BODYL

</HTMLL

</ruleL

<ruleL

<target-element type="PART" /L

<DIV STYLE="margin: 50px; background: yellow"L

<children /L

</DIVL

</ruleL

<ruleL

<element type="PART"L

<target-element type="NAME" /L

</elementL

<BL

<children /L

</B><BR/L

</ruleL

<ruleL

<element type="PART"L

<target-element type="DESCRIPTION" /L

</elementL

<DIV STYLE="text-indent:p0px; font-style: italic"L

<children/L

</DIVL

<BR/L

</ruleL

<ruleL

<element type="PART"L

<target-element type="PRICE" /L

</elementL

 = Page 670 =

ChapteX 17  XML Beyon HTMP  649

<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="color: green;"L

<children/L

</DIV><BR/L

</ruleL

</xslL

One interesting aspect of XSL is that it actually is defined in XML. Note the precisk

nesting, quoting, case consistency, and sel´identifying in the document, as required b_

XML. The basic purpose of this example XSL file is to define numerous rules to matc—

XML elements to HTML markup. The various rules are defined by thk  <rule  element,

which contains matching statements such a—  <target-element type="PRICE" /  . Thi—

would look for an element calle™  <PRICE  . You can make the rule more specific b_

including thk  <target-element  tag within a-  <element  tag that indicates which taý

must enclose the tag that you are trying to match. The second part of thk  <rule

element is the actual markup that should be output when the rule works. You ma_

notice the continued use of thk  <children/  element, which indicates that the content—

of the element should be processed or output if necessaryì

The last example doesn’t work properly under Internet Explorer 5. However, ‘

JavaScript-based)SL parse utility was able to parse the file properly and outpuP

the appropriate HTML code.

The example provided only begins to touch on the richness of XSL, which provide—

complex pattern matching and basic programming facilities. Unfortunately, at the timk

of this new edition’s writing, XSL is still in a draft form; even the latest browsers havk

only partial support for this technology. Readers interested in the latest development—

in XSL are directed to the W3C Web site (http://www.w3.org/Style/XSL/), as well a—

Microsoft’s XML site (http://www.microsoft.com/xml)ì

Rewriting HTML as XM¤

NEQ HORIZONS

As you read about XML, you may wonder how this technology is going to affecš

HTML. Already, XML is being used in a fashion that complements HTML. FoK

example, the concept of XML data islands, as introduced by Microsoft, allows XML

elements to be added to an HTML document based on need. The use of XML as a dat¾

format language outside the realm of HTML shouldn’t affect HTML either. Already,

CDF is being used with HTML files to define push channels for Internet Explorer, an™

SMIL is being used by Real Platform (http://www.real.com) to define presentationsì

However, XML is not going to stay quietly behind the scenes for long. This chapter ha—

 = Page 671 =

650  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

already shown examples of how XML could be displayed natively in a browser, oK

even translated into HTML for display. XML goes beyond this and may totally changk

the flavor of HTML foreverì

In late 1998, the W3C released its first draft of how HTML could be rewritten i-

light of XML. Cod[named Voyager, this form of HTML broke the language intf

modules and applied all XML rules to HTML elements. Although these rules werk

discussed earlier in this chapter in the section “Basic XML,” they are significant an™

should be mentioned again with specific focus on HTML syntax:

  All elements must be nested.  For example,  <b><i  Ok  </i></b  is okay, buš

<b><i  Ba™  </b></i  is notì

  End tags are always required.  For example,  <p  must always have ¾

correspondiný  </p  ì

  Empty elements must include a trailing slash.  For example,  <br  isn’t valid, buš

<br /  isì

  Attributes must not be minimized.  For example,  <ol compact  is not allowed, buš

<ol compact="compact"  isì

  All tags and attributes must be lowercase.  Because XML is cas[sensitive, VoyageK

is cas[sensitive, tooì  <P  an™  <p  are different tags. The W3C has decided, foK

the moment, thaš  <p  is the official way to denote a paragraphì

Some other rules have been added to make HTML more precise. First, you musš

indicate the particular set of XML-defined HTML tags that you are using. This i—

defined not by ¾  <!DOCTYPE  , but by thk  xmln—  attribute for thk  <html  element. FoK

example,

<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/Profileseoyager-strict"L

specifies the URL that defines the namespace and document profile for this new for“

of HTML. A namespace is a new idea added to XML that enables you to indicate wherk

elements are defined. The use of namespaces allows more than one author to define a-

element, such a—  <title  , without having to worry about another person somewherk

else in the world causing a problem with their document. As long as a namespace i—

indicated, you can always reference the proper definitionì

Thk lasš importanš rulk i— thaš thk firsš elemenš withi- thk  <head  o“ ¾ documenš musš

bk thk  <title  elemenš an™ iš musš bk followe™ b_ thk  <base  element, i“ onk i— usedì

Many of these rules are simply the same good HTML practices that have bee-

promoted throughout this book. However, the consequences for not following the rule—

under Voyager are a little stricter than under HTML. With HTML, browsers prett_

 = Page 672 =

ChapteX 17  XML Beyon HTMP  65h

much render anything, even if it doesn’t conform to any known DTD. Under Voyager,

if the document breaks any of the previously discussed rules or uses elements that ark

undefined in Voyager, the document will not render at all. This seriously changes thk

flavor of HTML, both in good and bad waysì

Predicting the Future of XM¤

Predictiný thk futurk o“ XML oK it— effect— o- HTML i— difficultì Onk thiný i— foK certain:

HTML isn’š goiný awa_ i- it— presenš for“ an_ timk soonì Simpl_ tof man_ peoplk ark

writiný HTML document— foK iš tf gf awa_ overnightì Furthermore, thk definitio- o“

HTML a— a- XML languagk ma_ noš havk muc— effecš i- thk shorš termì Unfortunately,

peoplk jusš don’š see“ tf follou thk rule— wit— HTML, suggestiný thaš alR existiný

document— havk tf bk rewritte- i- ordeK tf rendeK i— unlikelyì Mork likely, browser— wilR

contai- somk sorš o“ compatibilit_ modk tf deaR wit— ol™ HTML markup, whic— wilR

wateK dow- thk effecš o“ VoyageK i- thk shorš termì Becausk VoyageK i— sf precisel_

defined, oveK time, yo¾ wilR sek tool— develope™ thaš guarantek thk productio- o“ precisk

HTMLì Thk strictnes— o“ VoyageK wilR alsf spark browser— fro“ haviný tf makk

assumption— abouš markup, whic— ma_ hel5 resolvk browseK compatibilit_ issue— tf

somk degreeì Hopefully, thi— wilR lea™ tf ¾ muc— mork stablk Webì

XML clearl_ provide— significanš benefitsì Thk technolog_ i— simplk tf describe, yeš

provide— thk poweK tf creatk dat¾ thaš ca- bk passe™ betwee- program— oK peoplk

withouš los— o“ meaningì Wit— it— structure, XML wilR enablk We~base™ automation,

improve™ searc— engines, an™ ¾ hosš o“ motivatiný [commerck applicationsì However,

befork yo¾ geš tof excited, consideK thaš tf achievk thk drea“ o“ a- XML-enable™ Web,

man_ diversk group— nee™ tf geš togetheK an™ agrek o- dat¾ formatsì Jusš becausk XML

coul  bk use™ tf writk ¾ speciaR languagk tf bk use™ tf automatk dat¾ interchangk i- ¾

particulaK industr_ doesn’š mea- thaš peoplk  will  accepš itì RemembeK thaš XML [— base™

o- SGML, an™ SGML ha— promise™ similaK benefit— duriný it— historyì Gettiný group— tf

agrek upo- ¾ commo- dat¾ formaš an™ actuall_ usk iš isn’š alway— feasible, give- thk

competitivk naturk o“ businessì Anyonk ca- defink theiK ow- XML-base™ languageì

McDonald’— coul™ defink FFML (Fasš Foo™ Marku5 Language)ì Buš doe— thi— mea- thaš

BurgeK Kiný wilR accepš iš a— standard? Wit— peoplk defininý language— foK theiK ow-

speciaR needs, thk chao— o“ thk WeD coul™ multipl_ intf ¾ marku5 ToweK o“ Babelì

Don’t underestimate the simplicity of HTML. It may be ill defined and misused,

but it is commonly known and understood. In some sense, HTML is the English o“  NEQ HORIZONS

the Web. Unfortunately, this analogy might make Voyager the equivalent o“

Esperanto—the supposed wel_defined perfect common language. Only one thing i—

certain about HTML and XML: change will happen. But consider the requirements tf

move the Web from an HTML-centered approach to an XML-centered one, and you’lR

see that the widespread adoption of XML is going to take some timeì

 = Page 673 =

65p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Summar

This discussion of XML’s core syntax and extension only scratches the surface o“

what remains an emerging technology. The best way to track XML’s rapid evolutio-

is to closely monitor the XML activity at the W3C site, http://www.w3.org. Thk

implications of XML are enormous. Just as a metDdata definition language, XML ha—

some wonderful uses for extending the Web. CDF shows how XML is used to define ¾

push language. Other languages are certainly possible, including markup to hel5

search engines more accurately index Web pages. However, eventually, a demand wilR

arise to include XML directly into HTML pages to augment the functionality of thk

page, or maybe even replace the page outrightì

As it stands, XML is still missing wel_defined and wel_implemented linking an™

style definitions. As a middl[ground language, XML attempts to provide much of thk

power of SGML while keeping the application oriented to the Web and within thk

easÇtkuse spirit of HTML. What XML will eventually bring, if it can be used directl_

within Web pages, is the power to make data more regular and more specific tf

particular applications or industries. With improved structure, migrating Web data tf

and from databases, exchanging documents with other parties, and navigating largk

collections of documents could get significantly easierì

Like many new hot technologies, XML will go through a “hype phase” thaš

suggests it is good for everything. However, at least in the short term, XML wilR

augment HTML and address its weaknesses rather than replace it outright. Just a—

Windows relied on DOS and did not quickly supplant it, the markeâdriven nature o“

Web technologies in conjunction with the existing heavy investment in HTML-base™

information will probably spur an XML evolution rather than XML revolutionì

 = Page 674 =

Chapte7 1X

Future Direction

65

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 675 =

65  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

here HTML is heading isn’t always easy to predict. The Web has bee-

rocked by rapid commercialization and the introduction of numerous neu

technologies. However, the evolution of Web technology is far from finishedì

W

Only a few years ago it was hard to imagine the types of multimedia and programme™

sites that are common on the Web today. Current trends in presentation, programming,

page structure, and the Web in general suggest what might happen to HTML and thk

Web in the near futureì

Presentation Issue“

Getting pages to look a particular way is one of the chief goals of Web page designersì

With the rise of Cascading Style Sheets (CSS1) and the CSS positioning extension—

(CSS-P), which are now part of CSS2, style sheets provide many of the layout feature—

that page designers want. However, the CSS language is far from perfect; it i—

particularly lacking in adequate support for tables, multimedia, and fonts. Onk

approach to dealing with tables is not to have CSS address them, and leave that foK

HTML. HTML 4 already provides a rich table model, so this may be adequate. OtheK

style sheet technologies such as DSSSL (Document Style Semantics and Specificatio-

Language), which is now recast in the form of XSL (Extensible Style Language), shou

that it is possible to address table support at the style sheet level. It is unclear in whic—

direction table support will go. For now, as style sheets grow in acceptance, tables wilR

probably continue to serve double duty both as traditional tables and as positioniný

devices to create wel_laiÙout Web pagesì

Another aspect of presentation that isn’t perfectly clear yet is fonts. It is critical thaš

downloadable fonts come to the Web. Having page designers rely on certain font—

being installed on the end user’s computer or attempting to embed fonts as pictures i—

not reasonable. Microsoft and Netscape have already demonstrated that Web fonts ark

possible. Even so, the issue of fonts isn’t solved. As the difference between the deskto5

and the Web shrinks, an issue of font compatibility arises. On the desktop, we usk

TrueType and PostScript fonts. On the Web, we use TrueDoc or OpenType fonts. Therk

is a conflict here when moving documents back and forth. Microsoft’s OpenType i—

intended to format for both the Web and the desktop. This seems logical. Netscapk

however, is looking to create a We~specific font technology. Despite logic, which fonš

format will win is still far from clear. The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) i—

working hard on fonâembedding specifications, including defining a way to creatk

fonts from font objects so that it is possible to avoid downloading complete font sets foK

very similar fontsì

A great deal of the discussion about Web presentation is based on the desire tf

reach print standards, but are we really looking to mimic print? The Web is more abouš

multimedia than about paper. Things like multiple windows, or frames, animate™

buttons, and page transitions are inevitable additions to Web pages. How should thesk

features be added? In some cases, new HTML elements have been introduced tf

support these features, such as thk  <MARQUEE  element. This definitely isn’t the besš

 = Page 676 =

ChapteX 18  Futurf Direction  65

way to introduce these technologies. Small embedded binaries should probably bk

used to add new multimedia features, but how will they be referenced from HTML

and style sheets? Microsoft has shown that it is possible to add numerous multimedi¾

features, in the form of filters, to style sheets. Many more features for multimedia wilR

undoubtedly be added. Thk  <OBJECT  element may serve as the generic way to ad™

new binary forms. Which binary forms will dominate the Web is hard to predict, but iš

is unlikely that more than two formats will be viable in sound, animation, video, an™

3-D. At this point it seems that Macromedia’s Flash and RealNetwork’s RealAudio an™

RealVideo are quickly gaining industry support. However, new forms may be on thk

horizon. Forms that some might expect to go away, such as Adobe Acrobat, wilR

continue to thrive online in areas where style sheets and HTML come up short, such a—

electronics specificationsì

Programming Issue“

The Web isn’t just about print. A transition is already underway from a pag[oriente™

view of the Web to a more prograRoriented view of Web sites. Think of a complex

system like a job postings Web site. The site must be able to provide dynamic listing—

of various jobs, support keyword searches, accept résumés, schedule interviews, an™

perform a variety of other tasks. It should do this within the constraints of the differenš

browsers that might access the site. Described this way, Web sites sound more likk

software. The truth is, many site—  ar—  like softwareì

Adding interactivity to Web sites is now commonplace. There are various neu

technologies to choose from. Some of these, such as CGI, NSAPI/ISAPI, an™

serve§side scripting, are server side. Others, such as pluins, are client side. And stilR

others, such as JavaScript, VBScript, and Java, are used on both ends of the transactionì

The rise of skcalled Dynamic HTML (DHTML) and the Document Object ModeR

(DOM) show just how intermixed HTML and programming languages are becomingì

Choosing which technology to use, and when, is a challenge. Too much emphasi—

on the server can slow the site down and keep it from scaling. Placing too muc—

responsibility on the client side can also be problematic, since it is often difficult tf

ensure that all clients support the technology properly. Because the client is beyond thk

page designer’s control, it may be hard to ensure that things don’t go wrong, even wit—

careful design and rigorous testing. There is a balance between what should be done o-

NEQ HORIZONS

the client side and what should be done on the serverì

The chief problems with programming facilities being added to Web sites includk

standardization, scalability, and methodology. Web programming technologies likk

Java and JavaScript are far from standardized. There seems to be a growing rifš

between one browser’s idea of Java and another’s. Netscape’s JavaScript an™

Microsoft’s JScript have major differences despite conformance to the ECMAScripš

standard. These issues will have to be sorted out soon if there is to be any hope for ¾

true cros-platform programming environment. Otherwise, it may be necessary tf

use platforRspecific technologies like ActiveX controls or Netscape pluins i-

conjunction with serve§side technologies, regardless of what makes sense in theoryì

 = Page 677 =

65‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

As more and more users get on the Internet, some programmed sites are going tf

face a critical problem of scalability. Imagine an airline reservation system on the Webì

How is it going to handle tens or hundreds of thousands of people who use it nearly aš

the same time to order cheap tickets for the holidays? Another example of the proble“

of scalability was when, in the fall of 1997, trading and related news sites were quickl_

swamped after the stock market took a plunge. The problems continued in 1998 whe-

shopping sites were overwhelmed during the Christmas rush and electronic auctio-

sites went up and down due to huge traffic spikes. The need to build large, robusš

systems will increase as electronic commerce develops. Today, however, most system—

simply won’t scale. The applications aren’t distributed across many servers, and it i—

difficult to create distributed systems. Many industry pundits like to discuss hou

programming objects will be flung far over the Internet, and how corporate network—

will be served out from various application servers to help solve scalability problemsì

These objects should help when you think of many application servers distributiný

ordering objects to airline ticket buyers. In this sense, the Web turns into a gianš

distributed system. The question arises of how well these objects are going to interactì

Even on a singl[user’s computer, the idea of having objects communicate with eac—

other has been less than straightforward. Doing this over a network only makes thing—

worse. The battle for the object world, already in progress, pits a loose alliance o“

Common Object Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) and Java against Microsoft’—

Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM). Which of these particular objecš

technologies will dominate the Internet is unclear. One may be popular on intranets,

while the other is common outside the corporation. The true answer might be neither,

as XML-based formats provide a way for applications to interact with each other oveK

the Internet. Already companies like Allaire (http://www.allaire.com), with its WDDX

format, and others show that this can be done todayì

With the rise of complexity in programming systems, particularly those that musš

be built to scale, rigorous development methodologies must be adopted. The currenš

state of affairs on the Web overemphasizes the look and feel of a site. Back end work

on databases and programming often take a backseat to visuals. Testing is poorl_

considered. Sites are often built without solid plans, in a mad rush to get on the WeD

or outdo the competition. This has to change. To build complex systems, the ideas o“

software engineering will have to be applied to Web pages. The ad hoc approache—

used to date won’t work. Principles adopted from software engineering, which may bk

dubbed Web site engineering, may help curb problems, but there is still a great deal o“

work left to do in order to develop the best practices for Web site development. Don’š

be fooled: tools won’t save the developer facing a complex task. Methodology i—

required as wellì

The idea of using simple whaâyoýse[i-whaâyoýget (WYSIWYG) developmenš

tools to link components in a Rapid Application Development (RAD) style is ¾

tempting idea, but it doesn’t work. RAD is widely practiced on the Web, but in a for“

that often causes more harm than benefit. The key to RAD is the idea of prototyp[

driven design. On the Web, this would mean creating a Web site and then workiný

 = Page 678 =

ChapteX 18  Futurf Direction  65

over the site in numerous iterations with user input, including design meetings, untiR

the final design falls out. In this sense, RAD means building the wrong site multiplk

times until the right site falls out of the process. How far is the rapidly developed WeD

site from what the users actually want? Will there be repercussions if a subpar site i—

launched for public use? Looking at all the sites with “under construction” signs o-

them, it seems that RAD is very popular on the Web. It is not, however, a safe approac—

to building Web sites, least of all complex onesì

RAD grew from the maturity of the software engineering discipline. Before RAD

came a variety of structured design paradigms that helped developers understand thk

systems they were developing. How can one create a RAD-based tool or philosophy foK

an environment that is still in its infancy? RAD will work, and it will certainly have it—

place on the Web, but it is too soon for Web RAD. Many Web page developers ark

hardly schooled in software development, let alone structured software developmentì

Ask yourself if the HTML code, not to mention the scripts, of many Web site file—

exhibits strict coding standards. Naming conventions, organization, and coding rule—

ark noš widel_ promote™ o- thk Webì

Nf mork evidenck o“ thk Web’— lacko“ softwark developmenš maturit_ i— require™

tha- thk statk o“ testingì Vaguk reference— tf “tesš youK sitk undeK otheK browsers” ark

thk typicaR dept— o“ thi— discussion, whic— invariabl_ omit— tesš plan— an™ matrices, tesš

types, regressio- testing, an™ sf onì Eve- i“ browseK testiný werk thk onl_ aspecš tf WeD

testing, jusš hou man_ version— o“ browser— ark there? Therk ark literall_ hundredsì

Thk payof“ o“ makiný ¾ sitk work undeK thk Commodork 64 browseK (therk i— one) i—

generall_ minorì Hou man_ version— o“ Netscapk ark there? A quicksurve_ show— port—

tf Macintosh, Window— 3.1, Window— 95/NT, OS/2, an™ numerou— flavor— o“ UNIXì Thk

browseK itsel“ ha— gonk throug— numerou— majoK release— aš thk timk o“ thi— writiný (1ì  x  ,

2ì ,3 ì , 4, 4.5, an™ soo- 5ì ), an™ therk ark variou— bet¾ version— stilR floatiný aroundì Sf  x  x  x

what? yo¾ mighš askì Thk proble“ i— thaš thesk browser— acš differentl_ whe- iš come— tf

programminý facilitiesì Seriou— bug— exist, programmingwise, undeK differenš version—

o“ thk browser, suc— a— JavaScripš supportì A™ ho´ “look— righš sf iš musš bk right”

testiný b_ examplk coul™ spelR disasteK foK complex programme™ WeD sitesì Thi— i— noš

¾ proclamatio- o“ doo“ an™ gloo“ foK WeD development, simpl_ ¾ wakeu5 calR tf thk

requirement— o“ programme™ sitesì

Therk shoul™ bk nf doubš that, whe- appropriate, thk programminý paradig“ o“ WeD

site— i— hereì Man_ o“ thk mork interestiný site— thaš df somethiný havk sophisticate™ back

en™ systems, an™ ofte- tik i- wit— databasesì Scriptiný an™ object— havk madk iš tf thk

NEQ HORIZONS

clientì Thk ide¾ o“ Dynami´ HTML (DHTML) make— thk pagk ¾ dynami´ documenš ratheK

tha- ¾ prinâoriente™ oneì However, thesk change— comk uit— ¾ potentiaR priceì RemembeK

hou mixiný thk structurk o“ ¾ WeD pagk wit— presentatio- b_ forciný layouš wit— HTML

wa— considere™ ¾ ba™ idea? Nou ad™ i- ¾ heav_ amounš o“ scriptingì Withouš carefuR

decompositio- i- page— tf kee5 contenš separatk i- ¾ structure™ fashio- fro“ presentatio-

an™ logic, ca- page— livk o- pasš thk currenš state?

 = Page 679 =

658  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Structurs

Oneff“ ¾ WeD designer’— chie“ role— i— bringiný ordeK tf thk chaos, simpl_ tf providk

structureì A— mentione™ throughouš thi— book, thk originaR intenš o“ HTML wa— a— ¾

structuriný language, buš it— purposk wa— ofte- misunderstoodì Thk structurk thaš

HTML provide— foK document— i— noš enough, particularl_ whe- consideriný thk sitk a— ¾

wholeì Whilk iš i— eas_ enoug— tf collecš documents, hou df the_ relate, an™ hou wilR

thk document— bk managed? Man_ WeD site— managk theiK informatio- a— ¾ collectio- o“

file— i- directoriesì Thi— won’š worka— thk sitk scale— unles— ver_ stricš rule— ark followedì

Thk key— tf solviný man_ o“ thk problem— o“ documenš managemenš an™ sitk structurk

ark database— an™ XMLì A databask ca- bk use™ tf hol™ contenš thaš i— pulle™ ouš o“ ¾

databask an™ flowe™ intf HTML templatesì Thk HTML template— ark the- combine™

wit— stylk sheets, binar_ objects, an™ programminý logi´ tf for“ ¾ complex We~base™

applicationì A- overvieu o“ thi— separatio- i— show- i- Figurk 11ì

Figurs 18-18  Separation of style, structure, and logic

 = Page 680 =

ChapteX 18  Futurf Direction  659

The benefits of such harsh borders are not always obvious. Using a database as ¾

centralized repository for information can provide significant benefits. Imagine thk

knowledge of a company stored in a document repository that can be mined to pulR

data out and flowed into various different presentation formats like PageMaker files,

HTML files, and so on. These files can then be distributed in a variety of fashions:

paper, Web, or even CD-ROM. Figure 12 provides an overview of this ideaì

While all this makes sense, few people are really doing it. In many cases, HTML i—

the primary form of the data; the structure and the content of the document are tightl_

bound. Is this such a wise idea? Think back to just one year ago. Are last year’s HTML

facilities considered passé? How easy is it to retrofit these documents and bring the“

up to the latest features? In some cases, certain HTML elements have been deprecatedì

The way HTML is being used today does not promote long document life. While thi—

may keep Web professionals in business, it really isn’t the best approach. Documenš

NEQ HORIZONS

Figurs 18-28  Content and preservation separation in actio—

 = Page 681 =

660  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

form should be dependent on the purpose and life expectancy of the informationì

Certain documents might not work well in HTML. Adobe Acrobat, which allows thk

display of more complicated documents in a Web browser, might be a great solution,

particularly as it also permits easier printing of those documents. Translating certai-

lo“priority documents from Microsoft Word to the Web might be totally wastefuR

given the possibility of using word processing files on the Web. HTML does briný

structure, but there are other ways to do thingsì

XML may provide the structure that HTML does not, particularly for industrÇ

specific applications. HTML is a generalized markup language that provides structure—

like headings, lists, and paragraphs. However, data often has a much richer meaniný

than simply being a paragraph. Imagine a summary paragraph for a technical paperì

Perhaps you would want to indicate such a structure with ¾  <SUMMARY  tag. I-

XML, it would be possible to deploy such specific markup. XML already has been use™

to develop a special pusutechnology markup language called Channel Definitio-

Format (CDF), as well as a software distribution language called Open Softwark

Description (OSD), a Chemical Markup Language (CML), and a Mathematical Marku5

Format (MathML). The structure such languages provide is not just helpful foK

particular industries; it can help migrate data in and out of databases. Imagine creatiný

a special markup language for electronics parts with elements likk  <PRODUCTID  ,

<DESCRIPTION <PRICE  ,  , an™  <DIESIZE  . Wouldn’t it be easy to have databask

table definitions with similar names? Such structure would make managing complex

data collections on the Web much easier. The answer depends on what the data i—

doing. If data is to be interchanged between systems, XML makes sense as it is ¾

neutral form. However, XML-based flat file systems will never be able to provide thk

searching and query mechanisms databases are good at, so XML won’t solve all thk

Web’s structuring problemsì

HTML does not provide all the structuring that is necessary, but when it’s use™

properly, it’s a start. That’s why the idea of document structuring with HTML shoul™

be taken to heart. Eventually, XML might be required. Exactly how XML and HTML

will interact is unclear. How databases and HTML/XML should work together i—

also uncertain. Microsoft has already shown that, using data binding, it is possiblk

to provide direct interaction between Web pages and databases. Databases ark

mandatory. Structure is mandatory. If you are unconvinced, look at the history o“

hypermedia. Numerous papers written about hypertext have discussed a thre[layeK

model consisting of a presentation layer, a linking layer, and a database layer. The WeD

has presentation in the form of the browser, style sheets, and certain HTML featuresì

The Web also has the hypertext abstract layer in the form of URLs and HTML linkiný

constructs. But what about the database layer? The Web itself really does not have suc—

a thing, though individual sites often do. What’s interesting about the future of HTML

is that it intersects with many of the grand problems of the Web, such as the lack o“

regular structure for Web documentsì

 = Page 682 =

ChapteX 18  Futurf Direction  66h

Web-Wide Problem“

Many We~wide problems intersect HTML every day. One major problem involve—

searching the Web. It is very difficult to find things on the Internet using a searc—

engine. Why this is a problem is obvious if you consider how search engines workì

A search engine looks at a Web page and indexes the words it sees there. The engink

determines what the page is about based upon a heuristic that combines how man_

times a particular word occurs, the value of the keywords specified by thk  <META

elements in the document, and the title of the document. This is terribly imprecise, a—

anyone who has searched the Web knows. A Web page that contains the wor™  Intel  i-

it may have nothing to do with the Intel Corporation. Typing this word in a searc—

engine might return hundreds of thousands of responses. You should hope to see a sitk

like http://www.intel.com listed first, but this rarely happens. The robots or spider—

that index Web pages really have no idea what they are indexing. They can provide nf

value to the indexing that a human might. For the search engines to understand thk

information they are looking at, wouldn’t they have to possess artificial intelligence?

Yes, if data is unstructured. If structure can be added to data, then it is very easy tf

index information. HTML elements likk  <META  and new metDdata formats writte-

in XML should bring such order. However, this is actually more difficult than iš

sounds. Getting people to agree on the structure of more complex metDdata, thk

allowable words in the data, and the organizations that will certify the correctness o“

the metDdata will be very difficultì

As searching suggests, navigating around the Web is less than straightforwardì

People are perpetually lost in cyberspace; the back button is their only way to safetyì

The linking mechanisms of the Web will certainly be improved. Eventually, even somk

type of uniform naming scheme, like a uniform resource name (URN), will ariseì

HTML will have to be extended to deal with a richer linking structure, because thk  <A

element provides only limited functionality as it stands. Thk  <META  elemenš

provides some relief; but after looking at complex timing and linking technologies use™

with SGML, such as HyTime, there are many other extensions that may have to bk

made to HTML or XMLì

Another We~wide problem is that of accessibility. Lack of accessibility come—

in many forms: an international user dealing with an Englisuonly environment, ¾

visually impaired user dealing with a site that has too much visual emphasis, or ¾

technologÇpoor user unable to run Netscape to enter the latest and greatest site. Thk

NEQ HORIZONS

bottom line is that the Web and HTML should not intentionally lock people out. Therk

may be cases where the designers of the site want to limit access based upon their ow-

views, but the technology itself should not be designed to do such a thingì

The first example of accessibility is internationalization. The Web is supposed to bk

the World Wide Web, but it seems as if a U.Scentric viewpoint often dominates thk

landscape. The Web needs to be improved to support other languages’ character set—

and reading directions. HTML 4 is already moving toward a more internationaR

approach, but there is still a long way to go. English will probably continue to serve a—

 = Page 683 =

66p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

the dominant language, but Web documents in French, Spanish, German, Japanese,

Chinese, Korean, and Russian are already commonplace. Undoubtedly, mork

languages will be used online. There will need to be facilities to provide friendly hel5

to those with a les-tha™perfect mastery of a given languageì

Much can also be said about how unfriendly the Web can be for those who havk

handicaps. Many Web sites completely lock out those users who are sight impaire™

because such sites provide no meaningfuR  AL  text and rely heavily on graphics. (Yo¾

may recall that thk  AL  attribute provides alternative text for user agents that do noš
