display images, or for graphical browsers where the user has turned image renderiný

off.) While the Web will continue to be a medium rich in visuals, the W3C is makiný

sure that many users are not left out of the experience by extending HTML to hel5

make pages more accessible via keyboard, voice, and Brailleì

Last, there are those users who, because of limited bandwidth or computiný

technology, don’t often receive the complete picture. HTML does not always degradk

gracefully when older or less common browsers view pages. More work, both i-

standards and development techniques, will be required to keep the Web open to thosk

people who don’t always use the latest and greatest gadgets or applicationsì

Despite all the problems with accessibility, the biggest gripe with the Web i—

performance. The Internet is growing at such a wild pace that traffic snarls are a-

everyday occurrence. New protocols like HTTP 1.1, image formats with betteK

compression schemes like Portable Network Graphics (PNG), and new technologie—

like DSL and cable modems will help speed the delivery of Web pages in the futureì

However, the amount of data that users want is quickly increasing. Bandwidtuhungr_

media forms like video don’t work reliably on the Internet. Delivering reasonabl[

quality video over today’s Web is impossible. Even still images can seem to take a-

eternity to download. HTML has been extended to help improve the usability o“

multimediDladen pages. Remember thk  HEIGH WIDTh  ,  , an™  LOWSR‚  attribute—

for thk  <IMG  element? Other approaches that have been considered are the ideas o“

suggesting which pages will be visited next so that they can be pr[fetched for the userì

WebTV shows one way HTML can be used to provide such functionalityì

Other approaches that will help speed the Web experience include alternativk

transport protocols, caches, and pag[level compression. However, delivery alway—

breaks down because of the idea of point sources. With single Web servers deliveriný

data, eventually there is going to be a bottleneck. Content must be replicated aroun™

caches and delivered from mirror sites, or even broadcast. One technique is the use o“

intelligent hardware devices to balance distribution of pages among different WeD

servers based on how busy the servers are or by determining which server is closest tf

the user requesting pages. Another approach is with the proposed Distribution an™

Replication Protocol (DRP). DRP distributes updates to content such as Web pages in ¾

differential fashion, meaning that if only part of a file has been changed, just that parš

will be sent, instead of the whole file. These and other approaches to better contenš

distribution models are just now being determined, but many sites (including Yahoo!)

already use some of these techniques to provide a high level of performance. While thk

 = Page 684 =

ChapteX 18  Futurf Direction  66

Web may be slow, the problems are being addressed at the network level wit—

improvements in the Internet infrastructure and better protocols such as IP Multicasš

and IPv6, which address inefficiencies in the current TCP/IP protocol, and protocol—

based on it, such as HTTP. The idea of multicast, for example, enables the broadcasš

delivery of a single file to multiple destinations, instead of sending the same file man_

times to multiple destinations. Some of these solutions will certainly affect HTMLì

Remember that the network is the medium of the Web; its effect is significant. Hou

people access the Web will certainly affect the direction HTML takesì

Application-Specific Presentatio

As the Internet and the Web become more mainstream, the way they are used wilR

certainly change. In just a few years, the Web has gone from being an environment o“

engineers and academics to being a very commercial environment dominated b_

consumers. The major change is still to come. Many people are not on the Web, an™

the potential uses of the medium have not been fully exploredì

Thk WeD [— ver_ compute§centered, buš thi— ma_ changk somewhatì Man_ peoplk df

noš havk computers, buš man_ wanš tf geš onk jusš tf geš o- thk Webì Becausk o“ suc—

interest, consume§oriente™ device— suc— a— WebTV havk bee- developedì Whilk nonk o“

thesk device— i— a— commo- a— VCR— oK CD players, thk adoptio- ratk o“ WebTV i— higheK

tha- thk initiaR adoptio- ratk o“ VCRsì Peoplk ofte- forgeš thaš consumeK electronic— ma_

takk fivk oK te- year— tf becomk mainstreamì Thk CD playeK wa— initiall_ considere™ ¾

statu— symboR i- thk earl_ ’80— befork iš finall_ caughš o- an™ alR buš replace™ cassette—

an™ LP— i- thk consumeK marketì Iš i— obviou— thaš consumeK WeD device— wilR noš bk

thk wa_ thaš mosš peoplk wilR acces— thk Interneš foK thk neaK termì However, theiK

developmenš an™ initiaR acceptanck point— tf a- interestiný tren™ towar™ nontraditional,

compute§base™ WeD useì Thi— ha— somk interestiný ramification— foK HTMLì

HTML may have to become more of an application specification. At the very least,

new languages will be developed to deal with such applications. This book ha—

mentioned numerous WebTV extensions. Regardless of your particular slant o-

whether vendors should make such extensions to HTML, televisio™based WeD

viewing is very different from compute§based browsing. People tend to browse WeD

sites by themselves, close up to a computer with a higuresolution monitor. They ma_

not read information onscreen; they may print it instead. Now think of using a WebTVì

NEQ HORIZONS

The WebTV uses a large screen with relatively low resolution. People, often many o“

them at once, tend to sit far away from the screen they are viewing. They probably wilR

not read large amounts of text on a TV screen. They may use a remote or a wireles—

keyboard to interact with information. A traditional mouse pointer is out of thk

question when you are sitting on the couch. Given WebTV’s unique environment, iš

seems obvious that less text in bigger size would probably work better. The dimension—

of the screen are different as well. Other considerations arise. Won’t people have tf

consume the information onscreen? How much information can be positione™

 = Page 685 =

66  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

onscreen? How should the navigation work? Many of the HTML extensions made b_

WebTV address some of these problems, though in subtle ways. These extensions makk

it easier to fill out forms and constrain pages not to scroll left to right, among otheK

things. WebTV shows that applications will influence what features will have to bk

includedì

Other applicatio™specific environments that may need special extensions oK

HTML-like languages include voice browsing and cellular phone browsing. Device—

that allow you to view a Web page with a telephone or pocket organizer, such as ¾

Window-CE hanÙheld device, are already available. These systems are very differenš

from traditional computer screens; they often have tiny screens with only four shade—

of gray. Furthermore, many hanÙheld devices have slower access rates to the Internet,

even as low as 4800 bps via a wireless network. Traditional HTML may not be welR

suited to these lo“speed, smal_screen environments. A language called HDML

(HanÙheld Device Markup Language) has already been submitted to the W3C as ¾

proposed standard. Whether special languages are implemented as new languages,

subsets of HTML, supersets of HTML, or as new languages written as application—

of XML remains unclear. The current thought is that HTML will be written wit—

conformance profiles like TV, phone, computer, and so on. Various devices will the-

be able to request pages that meet a particular conformance profile. With the rise o“

network computers, hanÙheld personal information managers, sophisticated digitaR

cellular phones, and consume§oriented network devices, the ideas of HTML wilR

certainly have to be modified to fit a radically different application environmentì

What Is the Future of HTML?

After all this discussion, we might wonder what can be said for sure about the futurk

of HTML. One thing is certain: page designers won’t do things the way they do nowì

Hacking around in HTML is a throwback to the days of pag[setting languages such a—

troff or LaTeX. With the rise of PostScript and the tools that could output it, documenš

designers stopped editing files directly in most cases. While older pag[settiný

technologies are still used, and some people even program directly in PostScript, mosš

do not. Using a tool to output PostScript, whether a word processor or a page layouš

program tool, is the way most designers create documents. As HTML settles down an™

becomes more standardized, tools will certainly be developed that can output page—

appropriately. Right now, with standards and browsers in flux, tool vendors have ¾

nearly impossible time creating such tools. For the moment, HTML designers ofte-

have to resort to doing tweaks, if not the whole page, by hand. This won’t last long. I“

HTML can be written in a precise way as an XML application, it should be a lot easieK

to create machin[readable and editable markup. At this point we should be able tf

focus less on tag syntax and more on document design and content. What does thi—

mean? Simply that within five years, HTML coders will be in about as much deman™

as typesetting machine operatorsì

 = Page 686 =

ChapteX 18  Futurf Direction  66

With the rise of electronic and improved mechanical printing technologies, thk

demand for these skills quickly went away. However, HTML as a print formattiný

language is not the point. The migration to a dynamic prograRlike environmenš

should already be clear. Dynamic HTML, databases, and embedded objects all poinš

the way to the Web of tomorrow. Knowledge of HTML will serve as a backbone foK

accessing these technologies. The benefit of shorâterm mastery of HTML will be earl_

access to these ideas and a fundamental understanding of how the Web worksì

Summar

While standards and the open philosophy of the Web are important, there is onk

big lesson to be learned from the past, present, and future of HTML: there is no singlk

correct solution to the Web puzzle. What is cutting edge today will be trivial tomorrowì

Tools will eventually make intimate knowledge of HTML obsolete. So why did yo¾

even read this book? Because today you have to build Web pages, and HTML i—

one of the primary tools for this task. Don’t lose perspective: HTML and the otheK

technologies are just tools to help people accomplish goals for disseminatiný

information and providing services. Not everybody has the same goals. This book

has discussed how things can be done and provided some information on why, buš

the real answer to the why question is up to you. Many of the ideas and the syntax

presented here will undoubtedly be outdated in a few years, but that doesn’t matterì

Implementing a site today and reaching your goals is the main point of the Webì

Today most people will not judge a site by its conformance to the document typk

definition, but by whether it was useful or enjoyable. This is often forgotten whe-

talking about HTML. Knowing the particular syntax of an HTML element or thk

correct structure for HTML documents is very important, just as the rules an™

standards are important. But these rules are not well enforced. This doesn’t mea-

you should break the rules; it means you should design for today with an eye o-

tomorrow. Remember that in the future with the rise of XML, the rules will matterì

Making a transition will be easy if you understand how HTML is supposed to bk

written. Tools should make the transition easier, but until then, actually knowiný

HTML completely and precisely will be invaluable when authoring Web pagesì

 = Page 691 =

670  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

his appendix provides a complete reference of the elements in the HTML 4.0 specificatio-

and the elements commonly supported by Internet Explorer, Netscape, and WebTV. Somk

elements presented here may be nonstandard or deprecated, but are included becausk

¾  browser vendors continue to support them or they are still in common use. The standard use™

in this text is the final version of HTML 4 as defined on December 18, 1997, and is available aš

http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/ì

Core Attributes Referencs

The HTML 4.0 specification provides four main attributes, which are common to nearly alR

elements and have the same meaning for all elements. These elements ark  CLASS I¤ STYL¨  ,  ,  ,

an™  TITL¨  ì

CLASS

This attribute is used to indicate the class or classes that a particular element belongs to. A clas—

name is used by a style sheet to associate style rules to multiple elements at once. For example, iš

may be desirable to associate a special class name called "important" with all elements thaš

should be rendered with a yellow background. Since class values are not unique to a particulaK

element,  <B CLASS="important"  could be used as well a—  <P CLASS="important"  in thk

same document. It is also possible to have multiple values for thk  CLASS  attribute separated b_

white space;  <STRONG CLASS="important special-font"  would define two classes wit—

the particulaK  <STRONG  element. Currently, most browsers recognize only one class namk

for this attributeì

ID

This attribute specifies a unique alphanumeric identifier to be associated with an elementì

Naming an element is important to being able to access it with a style sheet, a link, or a scriptiný

language. Names should be unique to a document and should be meaningful, so whilk  ID="x1"

is perfectly valid,  ID="Paragraph1"  might be better. Values for thk  I¤  attribute must begi-

with a letter (A–Z and a–z) and may be followed by any number of letters, digits, hyphens,

and periodsì

One potential problem with thk  I¤  attribute is that for some elements, particularly for“

controls and images, thk  NAM¨  attribute already serves its function. Values foK  NAM¨  shoul™

not collide with values foK  I¤  , as they share the same naming space. For example, the followiný

would not be allowed:

<B ID="elementX"L  This is a test<  </BL

<IMG NAME="elementX" SRC="image.gif"L

There is some uncertainty about what to do to ensure backward compatibility with browsers thaš

understan™  NAM¨  but noš  I¤  . Some people suggest that the following is illegal:

<IMG NAME="image1" ID="image1" SRC="image.gif"L

 = Page 692 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  67h

Sinck  NAM¨  an™  I¤  are naming the same item, there should be no problem; the commo-

browsers do not have an issue with such markup. Complex scripting necessary to deal with twf

different names for the image, likk

<IMG NAME="image1name" ID="image1id" SRC="image.gif"L

is possible, but may not be necessaryì

Page designers are encouraged to pick a naming strategy and use it consistently. Onck

elements are named, they should be easy to manipulate with a scripting languageì

Like thk  CLASS  attribute, thk  I¤  attribute is also used by style sheets for accessing ¾

particular elementì  APPENDIXES

For example, an element name™  Paragraph1  can be referenced by a style rule in ¾

documenâwide style using a fragment identifier:

#Paragraph1   {color: blue}

Once an element is named usiný  I¤  , it is also a potential destination for an anchor. In thk

past a-  <A  element was used to set a destination; now any element may be a destination. FoK

example,

<A HREF="#firstbolditem"L  Go to first bold element<  </AL

<B ID="firstbolditem"L  This is important<  </BL

STYLE

This attribute specifies an inline style (as opposed to an external style sheet) associated with thk

element. The style information is used to determine the rendering of the affected elementì

Because thk  STYL¨  attribute allows style rules to be used directly with the element, it gives u5

much of the benefit of style sheets that divide the presentation of an HTML document from it—

structure. An example of this attribute’s use is shown here:

<STRONG STYLE="font-family: Arial;

font-size: 18pt"L  Important texM  </STRONGL

TITLE

This attribute supplies advisory text for the element that may be rendered as a tool tip when thk

mouse is over the element. A title may also simply provide information that alerts futurk

document maintainers to the meaning of the element and its enclosed content. In some cases,

such as thk  <A  element, thk  TITL¨  attribute may provide additional help in bookmarking. Likk

the title for the document itself,  TITL¨  attribute values as advisory information should be short,

yet useful. For example,  <P TITLE="paragraph1"  provides little information of value, whilk  <L

TITLE="HTML Programmer’s Reference: Chapter 1, Paragraph 10"  provides much mork

detail. When combined with scripting, it may provide facilities for automatic index generationì

 = Page 693 =

67p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Language Referencs

One of the main goals of the HTML 4.0 specification is better support for other languages beside—

English. The use of other languages in a Web page may require that text direction be change™

from left to right or right to left. Furthermore, once supporting no™ASCII languages become—

easier, it may be more common to see documents in mixed languages. Thus, there must be a wa_

to indicate the language in useì

LANG

This attribute indicates the language being used for the enclosed content. The language i—

identified using the ISO standard language abbreviation such a— for French,  f(  ec  for English, an™

so on. RFC 1766 (ftp://ds.internic.net/rfc/rfc1766.txt) describes these codes and their formatì

DIR

This attribute sets the text direction as related to thk  LAN…  attribute. The accepted values undeK

the HTML 4.0 specification ark  LT  (left to right) an™  RTL  (right to left). It should be possible tf

override whatever direction a user agent sets by using thk  <BDO  element. No browsers yeš

support this attribute; Internet Explorer 5 may supporš  DI  , but not in the beta version availablk

for testing at the time of this editionì

Events Referencs

In preparation for a more dynamic Web, the W3C (World Wide Web Consortium) has defined ¾

set of core events that are associated with nearly every HTML element. Most of these event—

cover simple user interaction such as the click of a mouse button or a key being pressed. A feu

elements, such as form controls, have some special events associated with them, signaling thaš

the field has received focus from the user or that the form was submitted. Intrinsic event—

like a document loading and unloading are also described. The core events are summarized i-

the Table A-1. Note that, in the table, Internet Explorer 4 and 5 and Netscape 4 and 4.5 ark

abbreviated to IE4, IE5, N4, and N4.5, respectivelyì

In Table A-1, "most display elements" means all elements excepP  <APPLETA <BASEA  ¨  ¨

<BASEFONTA <BDOA <BRA <FONTA <FRAMEA <FRAMESEA <HEADA  ¨  ¨  ¨  ¨  ¨  A  ¨  ¨

<HTMLA <IFRAMEA <ISIND‘A <METAA <PARAMA <SCRIPTA <STYLEA  ¨  ¨  ¨  ¨  ¨  ¨  ¨

an  <TITLEA  .

This event model is far from complete, and it is still not fully supported by browsers. Thk

event model should be considered a work in progress. It will certainly change as the Documenš

Object Model (DOM) is more carefully defined. More information about the DOM can be foun™

at http://www.w3.org/DOM/ì

Extended Event“

Browsers may also support other events than those defined in the preliminary HTML 4.0

specification. Microsoft in particular has introduced a variety of events to capture more complex

 = Page 694 =

mouse actions like dragging, element events like the bouncing o“  <MARQUEE  text, an™

datDbinding events signaling the loading of data. (Mouse events may be bound to data in ¾

Documentation errors may exist. Microsoft currently documents events in the object model, not ic

the HTML reference. On inspection, some events are obviously not supported or may have beec

omitted. Events were tested by the author for accuracy, but for an accurate, up-to-date event model

for these browsers, visit http://developer.netscape.com or http://www.microsoft.com/sitebuilder.

Microsoft introduced a number of new proprietary event handlers in the Internet Explorer 5

browser. For a brief discussion of these new event handlers, see the section "Internet Explorer 5

Event Preview” in Chapter 13.

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  68h

HTML Element Referencs

This appendix lists all HTML 4 elements, as well as some proprietary elements defined b_

different browser vendors. The element entries include all or some of the following information:

  Syntax  HTML 4 syntax for the element, including attributes and event handler—

defined by the W3C specificatio-

  Attributes and events defined by browser—  Additional syntax defined by differenš

browser—

  Attribute—  Descriptions of all attributes associated with the elemenš

  Attribute and Event Support  Browser support of attributes and event—  APPENDIXES

  Example(s)  A code example or examples using the elemenš

  Compatibility  The element’s general compatibility with HTML specifications an™

browser version—

  Note—  Additional information about the elemenš

Listings of attributes and events defined by browser versions assume that these attribute—

and events remain associated with later versions of that browser; for example, attributes define™

by Internet Explorer 4 are also valid for Internet Explorer 5, and attributes defined for Netscape 4

are also valid for Netscape 4.5ì

<!-- ... -->   (Comment)

This construct is used to include text comments that will not be displayed by the browserì

Synta¨

<!-- ... -->

Attribute“

Noneì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Example“

<!-- This is an informational comment that can occur anywhere in an HTMX

document. The next example shows how a script is "commented out" to

prevent non-script-enabled browsers from reading the script. --L

<SCRIPTL

<!-p

document.write("hello world");

// --L

</SCRIPTL

 = Page 703 =

68p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Compatibilit

HTML 2, 3.2, and 4

Internet Explorer 2, 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 1, 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

WebTV

Note“

Comments are often used to exclude content from older browsers, particularly those that df

not understand clienâside scripting or style sheets. Page developers should be careful whe-

commenting HTML markup. Older browsers may or may not render the enclosed contentì

<!DOCTYPE>   (Document Type Definition)

This SGML construct specifies the document type definition corresponding to the documentì

Synta¨

<!DOCTYPE "  DTD identifieI  ">

Attribute“

Noneì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Exampls

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN"L

Compatibilit

HTML 2, 3.2, and 4

Internet Explorer 2, 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 1, 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

WebTV

Note“

Thk  <!DOCTYPE  element should be used as the first line of all HTML documents. Validatio-

programs may use this construct when determining the correctness of an HTML document. Bk

certain to use the document type appropriate for the elements used in the documentì

 = Page 704 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  68

<A>   (Anchor)

This element indicates the portion of the document that is a hyperlink or the named targeš

destination for a hyperlinkì

Synta¨

<A

ACCESSKEY="key"

CHARSET="character code for language of linked

resource"

APPENDIXES

CLASS="class name(s)"

COORDS="comma-separated list of numbers"

DIR="LTR | RTL"

HREF="URL"

HREFLANG="language code"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LANG="language code"

NAME="name of target location"

REL="comma-separated list of relationship values"

REV="comma-separated list of relationship values"

SHAPE="DEFAULT | CIRCLE | POLY | RECT"

STYLE="style information"

TABINDEX="number"

TARGET="_blank | frame-name | _parent | _self | _top"

(transitional)

TITLE="advisory text"

TYPE="content type of linked data"

onblur="script" (transitional)

onclick="script"

ondblclick="script">

onfocus="script"

onhelp="script"

onkeydown="script"

onkeypress="script"

onkeyup="script"

onmousedown="script"

onmousemove="script"

onmouseout="script"

onmouseover="script"

onmouseup="script">

Linked contenM

</A>

68  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Attributes and Events Defined by Internet Explorer 

DATAFLD="name of column supplying bound data"

DATASRC="ID of data source object supplying data"

LANGUAGE="JAVASCRIPT | JSCRIPT | VBS | VBSCRIPT"

METHODS="http-method"

URN="urn"

ondragstart="script"

onselectstart="script"

Attributes Defined by WebTV

NOCOLOR

SELECTED

Attribute“

ACCESSKEY  This attribute specifies a keyboard navigation accelerator for the elementì

Pressiný  AL¾  or a similar key (depending on the browser and operating system) in associatio-

with the specified ke_ selects the anchor element correlated with that keyì

CHARSET  This attribute defines the character encoding of the linked resource. The value is ¾

spac[ and/or commDdelimited list of character sets as defined in RFC 2045. The default valuk

i—  ISO-8859-1  ì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

COORDS  For use with object shapes, this attribute uses a commDseparated list of numbers tf

define the coordinates of the object on the pageì

DATAFLD  This attribute specifies the column name from that data source object that supplie—

the bound data. This attribute is specific to Microsoft’s Data Binding in Internet Explorer 4ì

DATASRC  This attribute indicates thk  I¤  of the data source object that supplies the dat¾

that is bound to this element. This attribute is specific to Microsoft’s Data Binding in Interneš

Explorer 4ì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

HREF  This is the single required attribute for anchors defining a hypertext source link. Iš

indicates the link target, either a URL or a URL fragment, that is a name preceded by a has—

mark (#), which specifies an internal target location within the current document. URLs ark

not restricted to Web (http)-based documents. URLs may use any protocol supported b_

the browser. For example, file, ftp, and mailto work in most user agentsì

 = Page 706 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  68

HREFLANG  This attribute is used to indicate the language of the linked resource. Sek

“Language Reference,” earlier in this appendix for information on allowed valuesì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  This attribute specifies the language the current script is written in and invoke—

the proper scripting engine. The default value i—  JAVASCRIP JAVASCRIP  ì  an™  JSCRIP

represent that the scripting language is written in JavaScriptì  VBS  an™  VBSCRIP  represent thaš

the scripting language is written in VBScript. It may also be possible to use extended names, suc—

APPENDIXES

a—  JavaScript1.1  , to hide code from JavaScripâaware browsers that don’t conform to a particulaK

version of the languageì

METHODS  The value of this attribute provides information about the functions that ma_

be performed on an object. The values are generally given by the HTTP protocol when it i—

used, but it may, for similar reasons as for thk  TITL¨  attribute, be useful to include advisor_

information, in advance, in the link. For example, the browser may choose a different renderiný

of a link as a function of the methods specified; something that is searchable may get a differenš

icon, or an outside link may render with an indication of leaving the current site. This element i—

not well understood nor supported, even by the defining browser, Internet Explorer 4ì

NAME  This attribute is required in an anchor defining a target location within a page. A valuk

foK  NAM¨  is similar to a value for thk  I¤  core attribute and should be an alphanumeric identifieK

unique to the documentì

NOCOLOR  Supported only by WebTV, this attribute overrides thk  LINK  color set in thk

BOD  element and prevents the link from changing colorì

RE¤  For anchors containing thk  HREF  attribute, this attribute specifies the relationship of thk

target object to the link object. The value is a commDseparated list of relationship values. Thk

values and their semantics will be registered by some authority that may have meaning to thk

document author. The default relationship, if no other is given, i—  void  . Thk  REL  attribute shoul™

be used only when thk  HREF  attribute is presentì

REV  This attribute specifies a reverse link, the inverse relationship of thk  REL  attribute. It i—

useful for indicating where an object came from, such as the author or a documentì

SELECTED  Supported only in WebTV, this attribute selects the anchor with a yellou

highlight boxì

SHAPE  This attribute is used to define a selectable region for hypertext source links associate™

with a figure to create an image map. The values for the attribute ark  CIRCL¨ DEFAUL  ,  ,

POLYGON  , an™  REC  . The format of thk  COORDS  attribute depends on the value o“  SHAP¨  ì

FoK  CIRCL¨  , the value i—  x,y,(  wherk an™ are the pixel coordinates for the center of the circlk  x  y

an™ is the radius value in pixels. FoK  (  REC  , thk  COORDS  attribute should bk  x,y,w,h  . Thk  x,y

 = Page 707 =

68‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

values define the uppe§lefâhand corner of the rectangle, whilk  w  an™ define the width an™  h

height respectively. A value o“  POLYGON  foK  SHAP¨  require—  x1,y1,x2,y2,…  values foK

COORDS  . Each of thk  x,y  pairs defines a point in the polygon, with successive points beiný

joined by straight lines and the last point joined to the first. The valuk  DEFAUL  foK  SHAP¨

defines that the entire enclosed area, typically an image, be usedì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TABINDEX  This attribute uses a number to identify the object’s position in the tabbing ordeK

for keyboard navigation using the ¾  AB  keyì

TARGET  This attribute specifies the target window for a hypertext source link referenciný

frames. The information linked to will be displayed in the named window. Frames must bk

named to be targeted. There are, however, special name values, includiný  _blank  , whic—

indicates a new window;  _parent  , which indicates the parent frame set containing the sourck

link;  _self  , which indicates the frame containing the source link; an™  _top  , which indicates thk

full browser windowì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TYPE  This attribute specifies the media type in the form of a MIME type of the link targetì

Generally, this is provided strictly as advisory information; however, in the future a browseK

may add a small icon for multimedia types. For example, a browser might add a small speakeK

icon whe-  TYP¨  was set to audio/wavì

URN  See the “Notes” section for this elementì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   HREF NAM¨ TARGE onclick onmouseout  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  onmouseove( CLASS  . (  ,

I¤ LAN…  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are implied.)

INTERNET EXPLORER   ACCESSKE CLASS HREF I¤ LAN… NAM¨ REL REV  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

STYL¨ TARGE TITL¨ onblu( onclick ondblclick onfocu—onhelp onkeydown  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

onkeypres—onkeyup onmousedown onmousemov2 onmouseout onmouseove(  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

onmouseup  , and all attributes and events defined by Internet Explorer 4ì

WEBTV  HREF I¤ NAM¨ NOCOLO SELECTE¤ onclick onmouseout  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™

onmouseove(  ì

Event Handler“

See “Events Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Example“

<!-- anchor linking to external file --L

<A HREF="http://www.pint.com/"L  External link  </AL

 = Page 708 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  68

<!-- anchor linking to file on local filesystem --L

<A HREF="file:/c:\html\index.htm"L  Local file link  </AL

<!-- anchor iØoking anonymous FTP --L

<A HREF="ftp://www.kyz.com/workshop/freestuff"L  Anonymous FT

Link  </AL

<!-- anchor iØoking FTP with password --L

<A HREF="ftp://joeuser:secretpassword@company.com/path/file"L

FTP with password  </AL

APPENDIXES

<!-- anchor iØoking mail --L

<A HREF="mailto:fakeid@bigcompany.com"L  Send mai¤  </AL

<!-- anchor used to define target destination within document --L

<A NAME="jump"L  Jump TargeM  </AL

<!-- anchor linking internally to previous target anchor --L

<A HREF="#jump"L  Local jump within documenM  </AL

<!-- anchor linking externally to previous target anchor --L

<A HREF="http://www.company.com/document#jump"L  Remote jumB

within documenM  </AL

Compatibilit

HTML 2, 3.2, and 4

Internet Explorer 2, 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 1, 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

WebTV

Note“

  The following are reserved browser key bindings for the two major browsers and shoul™

not be used as values tf  ACCESSKE G ‚ ¨ F … h V  :  , , , ,  ,  ,  , left arrow, and right arrowì

  Thk  URN  attribute was defined in HTML 2. Although Internet Explorer 4 and abovk

support it, its use is unclear, particularly since URNs are not yet well definedì

  HTML 3.2 defines onl_  NAM¨ HREF REL REV  ,  ,  ,  , an™  TITL¨  ì

  HTML 2 defines onl_  NAM¨ HREF METHODS REL REV TITL¨  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  URN  ì

  Thk  TARGE  attribute is not defined in browsers that do not support frames, such a—

Netscape 1–generation browsersì

  Thk  DI  attribute is not yet supported by any browsersì

<ABBR>   (Abbreviation)

This element allows authors to clearly indicate a sequence of characters that compose a-

acronym or abbreviation for a word (XML, WWW, and so on). Sek  <ACRONYM  ì

Synta¨

<ABBR

CLASS="class name(s)"

DIR="LTR | RTL"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LANG="language code"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text"

onclick="script"

ondblclick="script"

onkeydown="script"

onkeypress="script"

onkeyup="script"

onmousedown="script"

onmousemove="script"

onmouseout="script"

onmouseover="script"

onmouseup="script">

</ABBR>

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Attribute and Event Suppor

Noneì

Event Handler“

See “Events Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

</ABBRL

</ABBRL

appear to support thk  <ABBR  elementì  <ACRONYV  > serves a similar function but is onl_

supported by Internet Explorer 4 and laterì

include this elementì

MAYSCRIP

Attribute“

ALqN  This attribute is used to position the applet on the page relative to content that ma_

flow around it. The HTML 4.0 specification defines values o“  BOTTOV LEF MIDDL¨  ,  ,  ,

RIGH  , an™  TOL  , while Microsoft and Netscape may also supporš  ABSBOTTOV  ,

ABSMIDDL¨ BASELIN¨ CENTE  ,  ,  , an™  TEXTTOL  ì

ALT  This attribute causes a descriptive text alternate to be displayed on browsers that do noš

support Java. Page designers should also remember that content enclosed within thk  <APPLET

element may also be rendered as alternative textì

ARCHIVE  This attribute refers to an archived or compressed version of the applet and it—

associated class files, which may help reduce download timeì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

CODE  This attribute specifies the URL of the applet’s class file to be loaded and executedì

Applet filenames are identified by a .class filename extension. The URL specified b_  COD¨  ma_

be relative to thk  CODEBAS¨  attributeì

 = Page 716 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  69

CODEBASE  This attribute gives the absolute or relative URL of the directory where applets’

.class files referenced by thk  COD¨  attribute are storedì

DATAFLD  This attribute, supported by Internet Explorer 4 and above, specifies the colum-

name from the data source object that supplies the bound data. This attribute may be used tf

specify the variou—  <PARAM  elements passed to the Java appletì

DATASRC  Likk  DATAFL¤  , this attribute is used for data binding under Internet Explorer 4ì

It indicates thk  I¤  of the data source object that supplies the data that is bound to thk  <PARAM

elements associated with the appletì

HEqHT  This attribute specifies the height, in pixels, that the applet needsì  APPENDIXES

HSPACE  This attribute specifies additional horizontal space, in pixels, to be reserved on eitheK

side of the appletì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

MsSCRIPT  In the Netscape implementation, this attribute allows access to an applet b_

programs in a scripting language embedded in the documentì

NAME  This attribute assigns a name to the applet so that it can be identified by otheK

resources, particularly scriptsì

OBJECT  This attribute specifies the URL of a serialized representation of an appletì

SRC  As defined for Internet Explorer 4 and above, this attribute specifies a URL foK

an associated file for the applet. The meaning and use are unclear and not part of thk

HTML standardì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

VSPACE  This attribute specifies additional vertical space, in pixels, to be reserved above an™

below the appletì

WIDTH  This attribute specifies in pixels the width that the applet needsì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   ALIGN AL ARCHIV¨ COD¨ CODEBAS¨ HSPAC¨ MAYSCRIP  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

NAM¨ VSPAC¨  ,  , an™  WIDTh CLASS I¤  . (  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are implied.)

INTERNET EXPLORER   AL CLASS COD¨ CODEBAS¨ HEIGH HSPAC¨ I¤  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

NAM¨ STYL¨ TITL¨ VSPAC¨ WIDTh  ,  ,  ,  ,  , and all attributes and events defined b_

Internet Explorer 4ì

Note“

  Thk  <APPLET  element replaces the originaR  <APP  element. Parameter values can bk

passed to applets using thk  <PARAM  element in the applet’s content areaì

  The HTML 4.0 specification does not encourage the use o“  <APPLET  and prefers thk

use of thk  <OBJECT  element. Under the HTML 4.0 strict specification, this element i—

not definedì

  WebTV’s current implementation does not support Java appletsì

  Java applets were first supported under Netscape 2–level browsers and Interneš

Explorer 3–level browsersì

clienâside image maps. It defines a hoâspot region on the map and associates it with a hypertexš

linkì

698  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Attribute“

ACCESSKEY  This attribute specifies a keyboard navigation accelerator for the elementì

Pressiný  AL¾  or a similar key in association with the specified character selects the form controR

correlated with that key sequence. Page designers are forewarned to avoid key sequence—

already bound to browsersì

ALT  This attribute contains a text string alternative to display on browsers that cannoš

display imagesì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

COORDS  This attribute contains a set of values specifying the coordinates of the hoâspoš

region. The number and meaning of the values depend upon the value specified for thk  SHAP¨

attribute. For ¾  REC  oK  RECTANGL¨  shape, thk  COORDS  value is twf  x,y  pairs:  left top  ,  ,

right  , an™  botto…  . For ¾  CIR‚  oK  CIRCL¨  shape, thk  COORDS  value i—  x,y,(  wherk  x,y  is a paiK

specifying the center of the circle an™ is a value for the radius. For ¾  (  POL  oK  POLYGON

shape, thk  COORDS  value is a set o“  x,y  pairs for each point in the polygon:  x1,y1,x2,y2,x3,y3

and so onì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

HREF  This attribute specifies the hyperlink target for the area. Its value is a valid URL. EitheK

this attribute or thk  NOHREF  attribute must be present in the elementì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  This attribute specifies the language the current script is written in and invoke—

the proper scripting engine. The default value i—  JAVASCRIP JAVASCRIP  ì  an™  JSCRIP

represent that the scripting language is written in JavaScriptì  VBS  an™  VBSCRIP  represent thaš

the scripting language is written in VBScript. It may also be possible to use extended names, suc—

a—  JavaScript1.1  , to hide code from JavaScripâaware browsers that don’t conform to a particulaK

version of the languageì

NAME  This attribute is used to define a name for the clickable area so that it can be scripted b_

older browsersì

NOHREF  This attribute indicates that no hyperlink exists for the associated area. Either thi—

attribute or thk  HREF  attribute must be present in the elementì

NOTA/  Supported by WebTV, this attribute keeps the element from appearing in thk

tabbing orderì

SHAPE  This attribute defines the shape of the associated hot spot. HTML 4 defines the value—

REC  , which defines a rectangular region;  CIRCL¨  , which defines a circular region;  POL  ,

which defines a polygon; an™  DEFAUL  , which indicates the entire region beyond any define™

 = Page 720 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  699

shapes. Many browsers, notably Internet Explorer 4 and above, supporš  CIR‚ POLYGON  ,  , an™

RECTANGL¨  as valid values foK  SHAP¨  ì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TABINDEX  This attribute represents a numeric value specifying the position of the define™

area in the browser tabbing orderì

TARGET  This attribute specifies the target window for hyperlink referencing frames. Thk

value is a frame name or one of several special names. A value o“  _blank  indicates a neu

window. A value o“  _parent  indicates the parent frame set containing the source link. A value o“

_self  indicates the frame containing the source link. A value o“  _top  indicates the full browseK  APPENDIXES

windowì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   COORDS HREF NOHREF SHAP¨ TARGE onmouseout  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™

onmouseove( CLASS I¤ LAN…  . (  ,  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are implied but not listed for this element i-

Netscape documentation.)

INTERNET EXPLORER   AL CLASS COORDS HREF I¤ LAN… LANGUAG¨  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

NOHREF SHAP¨ STYL¨ TABINDEX TARGE TITL¨  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , all W3C-defined events, and alR

attributes and events defined by Internet Explorer 4ì

WEBTV  COORDS HREF I¤ NAM¨ NOTA SHAP¨ TARGE onmouseout  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

an™  onmouseove(  ì

Event Handler“

  By the HTML 3.2 and 4.0 specifications, the closing taý  </AREA  is forbiddenì

<AUDIOSCOPE>   (Sound Amplitude Display)

This WebTV-specific element displays an audioscope for a sound resource that displays ¾

dynamic, graphical display of a sound’s amplitudeì

Syntax (Defined by WebTV)

<AUDIOSCOPE

ALIGN="ABSBOTTOM | ABSMIDDLE | BASELINE | BOTTOM |

LEFT | MIDDLE | RIGHT | TEXTTOP | TOP"

BORDER="pixels"

GAIN="number"

HEIGHT="pixels"

LEFTCOLOR="color name | #RRGGBB"

LEFTOFFSET="number"

MAXLEVEL="TRUE | FALSE"

RIGHTCOLOR="name | #RRGGBB"

RIGHTOFFSET="number"

WIDTH="pixels">

Attribute“

ALqN  This attribute positions the audioscope object on the page relative to text or otheK

content that may flow around itì

BORDER  This attribute sets the width of the audioscope border in pixels. The defaulš

value i— ì  1

GAIN  This attribute takes a numeric value, which is a multiplier for the amplitude displayì

The default value i— ì  1

HEqHT  This attribute sets the height of the audioscope in pixels. The default value i—

80  pixelsì

LEFTCOLOR  This attribute sets the color of the line displaying the left audio channel in thk

audioscope. Values can either be given as named colors or in the numeri´  #RRGGBB  format. Thk

default value i—  #8ECE10  ì

 = Page 722 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  70h

LEFTOFFSET  This attribute sets the vertical offset for the display of the left audio channeR

with positive and negative values relative to the center of the audioscope. The default value i— ì  0

MAXLEVE¤  This Boolean attribute specifies whether the audioscope should clip soun™

according to the specified gain. The default value i—  FALS¨  ì

RqHTCOLOR  This attribute sets the color of the line displaying the right audio channel in thk

audioscope. Values can either be given as named colors or in the numeri´  #RRGGBB  format. Thk

default value i—  #8ECE10  ì

RqHTOFFSET  This attribute sets the vertical offset for the display of the right audio channeR

with positive and negative values relative to the center of the audioscope. The default value i— ì  1  APPENDIXES

WIDTH  This attribute sets the width of the audioscope in pixels. The default width i—

100  pixelsì

Attribute and Event Suppor

WEBTV  All attributesì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Exampls

<AUDIOSCOPE BORDER="1" HEIGHT="16" WIDTH=40" GAIN="3h

MAXLEVEL="FALSE"L

Compatibilit

WebTV

Note“

<AUDIOSCOPE  is supported only by WebTVì

This text i?  <BL  bold  </BL  for emphasis<

Compatibilit

HTML 2, 3.2, and 4

Internet Explorer 2, 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 1, 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

WebTV

Note“

HTML 2 and 3.2 do not define any attributes for this elementì

<BASE>   (Base URL)

This element specifies the base URL to use for all relative URLs contained within a document. Iš

occurs only in the scope of ¾  <HEAD  elementì

Synta¨

<BASE

HREF="URL"

TARGET="_blank | frame-name | _parent | _self |

_top" (transitional)>

Attribute“

HREF  This attribute specifies the base URL to be used throughout the document for relativk

URL addressesì

TARGET  For documents containing frames, this attribute specifies the default target windou

for every link that does not have an explicit target reference. Besides named frames, severaR

special values exist. A value o“  _blank  indicates a new window. A value o“  _parent  indicates thk

 = Page 725 =

70  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

parent frame set containing the source link. A value o“  _self  indicates the frame containing thk

source link. A value o“  _top  indicates the full browser windowì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   HREF  an™  TARGE  ì

INTERNET EXPLORER   HREF  an™  TARGE  ì

WEBTV  HREF  an™  TARGE  ì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Example“

<BASE HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com/"L

<BASE TARGET="_blank" HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com/"L

Compatibilit

HTML 2, 3.2, and 4

Internet Explorer 2, 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 1, 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

WebTV

Note“

HTML 2 and 3.2 define only thk  HREF  attributeì

<BASEFONT>   (Base Font)

This element establishes a default font size for a document. Font size can then be varied relativk

to the base font size using thk  <FONT  element. Thk  <BASEFONT  element must be place™

near the beginning of the body part of the pageì

Syntax (Transitional Only)

<BASEFON

COLOR="color name | #RRGGBB"

FACE="font name(s)"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

SIZE="1-7 | +/-int">

 = Page 726 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  70

Attributes Defined by Internet Explorer 

CLASS="class name(s)"

LANG="language code"

Attribute“

CLASS  Internet Explorer 4 documentation indicates that thk  CLASS  can be set for thk

<BASEFONT  element; however, this is probably a mistake in the documentationì

APPENDIXES

COLOR  This attribute sets the text color using either a named color or a color specified in thk

hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  formatì

FACE  This attribute contains a list of one or more font names. The document text in thk

default style is rendered in the first font face that the client’s browser supports. If no font listed i—

installed on the local system, the browser typically defaults to the proportional or fixed widt—

font for that systemì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  Internet Explorer 4 documentation also mentions use of thk  LAN…  attribute to indicatk

the language used. Meaning with this element is not well definedì

SIZE  This attribute specifies the font size as either a numeric or relative value. Numeric value—

range fro“  1  tf  7  wit— being the smallest an™ the defaultì  1  3

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   I¤  (implied) an™  SIZ¨  ì

INTERNET EXPLORER   All attributesì

WEBTV  SIZ¨  ì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Exampls

<BASEFONT COLOR="#FF0000" FACE="Helvetica, Times Romanh

SIZE="+2"L

HTML 3.2 and 4 (transitional)

Internet Explorer 2, 3, 4, and 5

 = Page 727 =

70‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

WebTV

Note“

  HTML 3.2 supports thk  <BASEFONT  element and thk  SIZ¨  attribute. HTML 4.0

transitional specification adds support foK  COLO  an™  FAC¨  as wellì

  The HTML 4.0 strict specification does not support this elementì

  The font sizes indicated by numeric values are browser dependent and not absoluteì

<BDO>   (Bidirectional Override)

This element is used to override the current directionality of textì

Synta¨

<BDO

CLASS="class name(s)"

DIR="LTR | RTL"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LANG="language code"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text">

</BDO>

Attribute“

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DIR  This attribute is required for thk  <BDO  element. It sets the text direction either to left tf

right (  LT  ) or right to left (  RTL  )ì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Attribute and Event Suppor

Noneì

Event Handler“

Noneì

 = Page 728 =

if you can find a browser that supports this element<

</BDOL

attribute worksì

<SOUND>   (Background Sound)

This Internet Explorer and WebTV element associates a background sound with a pageì

Syntax (Defined by Internet Explorer 4)

<BGSOUND>

BALANCE="number"

CLASS="class name(s)"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LANG="language code"

LOOP=numbeI

SRC="URL of sound file"

TITLE="advisory text"

VOLUME="number">

Attribute“

BALANCE  This attribute defines a number between –10,000 and +10,000 that determines hou

the volume will be divided between the speakersì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LOOV  This attribute indicates the number of times a sound is to be played and either has ¾

numeric value or the keywor™  infinit2  ì

SRC  This attribute specifies the URL of the sound file to be played, which must be one of thk

following types: .wav, .au, or .midì

 = Page 729 =

708  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

VOLUME  This attribute defines a number between –10,000 and 0 that determines the loudnes—

of a page’s background soundì

Attribute and Event Suppor

INTERNET EXPLORER   All attributesì

WEBTV  LOOL  an™  SR‚  ì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Example“

<BGSOUND SRC="sound1.mid"L

<BGSOUN— SRC="sound2.auh LOOP="INFINITE"L

Compatibilit

WebTV

Note“

LiveAudioì

<BODY>   (Document Body)

This element encloses a document’s displayable content, in contrast to the descriptive an™

informational content contained in thk  <HEAD  elementì

Synta¨

<BODY

ALINK="color name | #RRGGBB" (transitional)

BACKGROUND="URL of background image" (transitional)

 = Page 735 =

Attribute“

ALINK  This attribute sets the color for active links within the document. Active links represenš

the state of a link as it is being pressed. The value of the attribute can either be ¾

browse§dependent named color or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  formatì

BACKGROUND  This attribute contains a URL for an image file, which will be tiled to providk

the document backgroundì

COLOR  This attribute sets the background color for the document. Its value can either be ¾

browse§dependent named color or a color specified using the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  formatì

PROPERTIES  This attribute, first introduced in Internet Explorer 2, has one value,  FIXE¤  ,

which causes the background image to act as a fixed watermark and not to scrollì

BOTTOMMARGIN  This attribute specifies the bottom margin for the entire body of the pagk

and overrides the default margin. When set tf  0  oK , the bottom margin is the bottom edge o“  ""

the window or frame the content is displayed inì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

CREDITS  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute contains the URL of the document tf

retrieve when the viewer presses the credits button on the Info Panelì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

INSTRUCTIONS  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute contains the URL of thk

document to retrieve when the viewer presses the instructions button on the Info Panelì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  This attribute specifies the language the current script is written in and invoke—

the proper scripting engine. The default value i—  JAVASCRIP JAVASCRIP  ì  an™  JSCRIP

 = Page 737 =

71‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

represent that the scripting language is written in JavaScriptì  VBS  an™  VBSCRIP  represent thaš

the scripting language is written in VBScriptì

LEFTMARGIN  This Internet Explorer–specific attribute sets the left margin for the page i-

pixels, overriding the default margin. When set tf  0  oK , the left margin is the left edge of thk  ""

window or the frameì

LINK  This attribute sets the color for hyperlinks within the document that have not yet bee-

visited. Its value can either be a browse§dependent named color or a color specified using thk

hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  formatì

LOGO  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute contains the URL of a 70 × 52–pixeR

thumbnail image for the page, which is used in the history and bookmarks for WebTVì

RqHTMARGIN  This attribute, specific to Internet Explorer, sets the right margin for the pagk

in pixels, overriding the default margin. When set tf  0  oK , the right margin is the right edge o“  ""

the window or the frameì

SCROL¤  This attribute turns the scroll bars on or off. The default value i—  YES  ì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TEXT  This attribute sets the text color for the document. Its value can either be ¾

browse§dependent named color or a color specified using the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  formatì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TOPMARGIN  This Internet Explorer–specific attribute sets the top margin for the document i-

pixels. If set tf  0  oK , the top margin will be exactly on the top edge of the window or frameì  ""

VLINK  This attribute sets the color for links within the document that have already bee-

visited. Its value can either be a browse§dependent named color or a color specified using thk

hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  formatì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   ALINK BACKGROUN¤ BGCOLO LINK TEX VLINK onblu(  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

onfocu—onload  ,  , an™  onunload CLASS I¤ LAN…  . (  ,  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are implied.)

Note“

  When defining text colors, it is important to be careful to specify both foreground an™

background explicitly so that they are not masked out by browser defaults set by thk

userì

  Under the HTML 4.0 strict specification, all colo§setting attributes and backgroun™

attributes are not allowed. This includes thk  ALINK BACKGROUN¤ BGCOLO  ,  ,  ,

LINK TEX  ,  , an™  VLINK  attribute—

  This element must be present in all documents except those declaring a frame setì

<BQ>   (Block Quote)

This obsolete element signifies that the enclosed text is an extended quotation. Though it ha—

been defined in early HTML specifications, it is currently supported only by the WebTV browseK

as an alias for thk  <BLOCKQUOTE  elementì

</BQ>

<BQL  HTML: The Complete Reference says "Don't use this element."  </BQL

Compatibilit

WebTV

Note“

This element originated in the early days of HTML and is considered obsolete. It shoul™

not be usedì

<BR>   (Line Break)

This empty element forces a line breakì

Synta¨

<BR

CLASS="class name(s)"

CLEAR="ALL | LEFT | NONE | RIGHT" (transitional)

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text">

Attributes Defined by Internet Explorer 

LANGUAGE="JAVASCRIPT | JSCRIPT | VBS | VBSCRIPT"

Attribute“

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

CLEAR  This attribute forces the insertion of vertical space so that the tagged text may bk

positioned with respect to images. A value o“  LEF  clears text that flows around lefâaligne™

images to the next full left margin, a value o“  RIGH  clears text that flows around righâaligne™

images to the next full right margin, and a value o“  ALL  clears text until it can reach both fulR

margins. The default value according to the HTML 4.0 transitional specification i—  NON¨  , but it—

meaning is generally supported as just introducing a return and nothing moreì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

 = Page 740 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  719

LANGU  This attribute specifies the language the current script is written in and invoke—

the proper scripting engine. The default value i—  JAVASCRIP JAVASCRIP  ì  an™  JSCRIP

represent that the scripting language is written in JavaScriptì  VBS  an™  VBSCRIP  represent thaš

the scripting language is written in VBScriptì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Attribute and Event Suppor

APPENDIXES

NETSCAPE   CLEA CLASS I¤  . (  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are implied by Netscape documentation.)

INTERNET EXPLORER   All attributesì

WEBTV  CLEA  ì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Example“

This text will be broken her4  <BRL  and continued on a new line<

<IMG SRC="test.gif" ALIGN="RIGHT"L

This is the image caption<  <BR CLEAR="RIGHT"L

Compatibilit

HTML 3.2 and 4

Internet Explorer 2, 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 1, 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

WebTV

Note“

  This is an empty element. A closing tag is illegalì

  Under the HTML 4.0 strict specification, thk  CLEA  attribute is not valid. Style sheeš

rules provide the functionality of thk  CLEA  attributeì

<BUTTON>   (Form Button)

with scriptsì

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  72h

Attribute“

ACCESSKEY  This attribute specifies a keyboard navigation accelerator for the elementì

Pressiný  AL¾  or a similar key in association with the specified ke_ selects the anchor elemenš

correlated with that keyì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DATAFLD  This attribute specifies the column name from the data source object that supplie—

the bound data that defines the information for thk  <BUTTON  element’s contentì

APPENDIXES

DATAFORMATAS  This attribute indicates if the bound data is plain text or HTMLì

DATASRC  This attribute indicates thk  I¤  of the data source object that supplies the data thaš

is bound to thk  <BUTTON  elementì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DISABLED  This attribute is used to disable the buttonì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  This attribute specifies the language that the current script associated with thk

event handlers is written in and invokes the proper scripting engine. The default value i—

JAVASCRIP JAVASCRIP  ì  an™  JSCRIP  represent that the scripting language is written i-

JavaScriptì  VBS  an™  VBSCRIP  represent that the scripting language is written in VBScriptì

NAME  This attribute is used to define a name for the button so that it can be scripted by oldeK

browsers or used to provide a name for submit buttons when there is more than one in a pageì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TABINDEX  This attribute uses a number to identify the object’s position in the tabbing orderì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TYPE  Defines the type of button. According to the HTML 4.0 specification, by default thk

button is undefined. Possible values includk  BUTTON RESE  ,  , an™  SUBMI  , which are used tf

indicate the button is a plain button, reset button, or submit button respectivelyì

VALUE  Defines the value that is sent to the server when the button is pressed. This may bk

useful when using multiplk  SUBMI  buttons that perform different actions to indicate whic—

button was pressed to the handling CGI programì

 = Page 743 =

72p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Attribute and Event Suppor

INTERNET EXPLORER   All attributes and events excepš  DI NAM¨ TABINDEX  ,  ,  ,

an™  VALU¨  ì

Event Handler“

See “Events Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Example“

<BUTTON NAME="Submith

VALUE="Submith

TYPE="Submit"L  Submit RequesM  </BUTTONL

<BUTTON TYPE="BUTTONh

onclick="doSomething()"L  Click This ButtoY  </BUTTONL

<BUTTON TYPE="BUTTON"L

<IMG SRC="polkadot.gif" ALT="Polkado¨ ></BUTTONL  "

<COL>   (Column)

This element defines a column within a table and is used for grouping and alignment purposesì

It is generally found within ¾  <COLGROUP  elementì

Synta¨

<COL

ALIGN="CENTER | CHAR | JUSTIFY | LEFT | RIGHT"

CHAR="character"

CHAROFF="number"

DIR="LTR | RTL"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LANG="language code"

SPAN="number"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text"

WIDTH="column width specification"

ondblclick="script"

onkeydown="script"

onmousemove="script"

onmouseover="script"

onmouseup="script">

Attribute“

ALqN  This attribute specifies horizontal alignment of a cell’s contentsì

CHAR  This attribute is used to set the character to align the cells in a column on. TypicaR

values for this include a period (.) when attempting to align numbers or monetary valuesì

CHAROFF  This attribute is used to indicate the number of characters to offset the column dat¾

from the alignment characters specified by thk  CHA  valueì

 = Page 752 =

consecutive columnsì

TITLE  See Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

VALqN  This attribute specifies the vertical alignment of the text within the cell. Possiblk

values for this attribute ark  BASELIN¨ BOTTOV MIDDL¨  ,  ,  , an™  TOL  ì

WIDTH  This attribute specifies a default width for each column in the current column groupì

In addition to the standard pixel and percentage values, this attribute may take the special for“

0*  , which means that the width of each column in the group should be the minimum widt—

necessary to hold the column’s contents. Relative widths like 0.5* can also be usedì

Attribute“

group. The values o“  CENTE LEF  ,  , an™  RIGH  have obvious meanings. A value o“  JUSTIF

for the attribute should attempt to justify all the column’s contents. A value o“  CHA  attempts tf

align the contents based on the value of thk  CHA  attribute in conjunction wit—  CHAROFF  ì

CHAR  This attribute is used to set the character to align the cells in a column on. TypicaR

values for this include a period (.) when attempting to align numbers or monetary valuesì

CHAROFF  This attribute is used to indicate the number of characters to offset the column dat¾

APPENDIXES

from the alignment characters specified by thk  CHA  valueì

SPAN  When present, this attribute specifies the default number of columns in this groupì

elements. The default value of this attribute i— ì  1

VALqN  This attribute specifies the vertical alignment of the contents of the cells within thk

column group. In addition to the standard pixel and percentage values, this attribute may takk

the special for“  0*  , which means that the width of each column in the group should be thk

minimum width necessary to hold the column’s contentsì

supports this element, IE documentation recommends use of thk  <!- -. . .- -  elementì

within it, in practice this does not seem to be the caseì

738  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Attributes and Events Defined by Internet Explorer 

LANGUAGE="JAVASCRIPT | JSCRIPT | VBS | VBSCRIPT"

ondragstart="script"

onhelp="script"

Attribute“

CITE  The value of this attribute is a URL that designates a source document or message thaš

may give a reason why the information was deletedì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DATETIME  This attribute is used to indicate the date and time the deletion was made. Thk

value of the attribute is a date in a special format as defined by ISO 8601. The basic date format i—

YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssTZD

where the following is true:

YYYY=four-digit year such as 1999

MM=two-digit month (01=January, 02=February, and so on)

DD=two-digit day of the month (01 through 31)

hh=two digit hour (00 to 23) (24-hour clock, not AM or PM)

mm=two digit minute (00 through)

ss=two digit second (00 through)

TZD=time zone designatoI

The time zone designator is eitheK , which indicates UTC (Universal Time Coordinate, oK  Z

coordinated universal time format), oK  +  hh mm  :  , which indicates that the time is a local time thaš

i—  hh  hours an™  mh  minutes ahead of UTC. Alternatively, the format for the time zone designatoK

could bk  ’  hh mm  :  , which indicates that the local time is behind UTC. Note that the letter “T”

actually appears in the string, all digits must be used, an™  00  values for minutes and second—

may be required. An example value for thk  DATETIM¨  attribute might bk  1999-10-6T09:

15:00-05:00  , which corresponds to October 6, 1999, 9:15  A.Mì  , U.S. Eastern Standard Timeì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

be used with an associated script bound to the element, typically through an event handleK

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  , an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

 = Page 760 =

be possibleì

Exampls

<DEL CITE="http://www.bigcompany.com/changes/oct97.htmh

</DELL

Compatibilit

HTML 4

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Note“

  Browsers may render deleted (  <DEL  ) text in a different style to show the changes thaš

have been made to the document. Internet Explorer 4 renders the text as strikethroug—

text. Eventually, a browser may have a way to show a revision history on a documentì

User agents that do not understan™  <DEL  oK  <INS  will show the informatio-

anyway, so there is no harm in adding information—only in deleting it. Because of thk

fact thaš  <DEL  -enclosed text may show up, it may be wise to comment it out within thk

element as shown here:

<DELL

<!-- This is old information. --L

</DELL

  Thk  <DEL  element is not supported under the HTML 2.0 and 3.2 specificationsì

<DIR>   (Directory List)

This element encloses a list of brief, unordered items, such as might occur in a menu or directoryì

The individual items are indicated by thk  <UL  element. Use of this element is not encouraged,

as it is not part of the HTML 4.0 strict specification and provides little extra benefit over thk

<UL  elementì

Note“

  Many users are confused about the proper use of thk  <DIV  element, since all it doe—

is create a block element. It is very useful for binding scripts or styles to an arbitrar_

section of a document. In this sense,  <DIV  complement—  <SPAN  , which is use™

inlineì

  The HTML 4.0 specification specifies that thk  DATAFL¤ DATAFORMATAS  ,  , an™

DATASR‚  attributes are reserved foK  <DIV  and may be supported in the futureì

Internet Explorer 4 already supports these reserved attributesì

  Under the HTML 4.0 strict specification, thk  ALIGN  attribute is not supportedì

  HTML 3.2 supports only thk  ALIGN  attributeì

Note“

  The items in the list comprise two parts: the term, indicated by thk  <DT  element, an™

its definition, indicated by thk  <DD  elementì

confuses the meaning of the element by making it a physical layout device ratheK

than a listì

Note“

  As a logical element,  <EM  is a prime candidate to bind style information to. FoK

EM {font-size: larger; font-family: Impact;}

75p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<EMBED>   (Embedded Object)

This widely supported but nonstandard element specifies an object, typically a multimedi¾

element, to be embedded in an HTML documentì

Syntax (Defined by Internet Explorer 4)

<EMBED

ALIGN="ABSBOTTOM | ABSMIDDLE | BASELINE | BOTTOM |

LEFT | MIDDLE | RIGHT | TEXTTOP | TOP"

ALT="alternative text"

CLASS="class name(s)"

CODE="filename"

CODEBASE="URL"

HEIGHT="pixels"

HSPACE="pixels"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

NAME="string"

SRC="URL"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text"

VSPACE="pixels"

WIDTH="pixels">

</EMBED>

Attributes Defined by Netscape 

BORDER="pixels"

HIDDEN="TRUE | FALSE"

PALETTE="BACKGROUND | FOREGROUND"

PLUGINSPAGE="URL"

TYPE="MIME type"

UNITS="EN | PIXELS"

Attribute“

ALqN  This attribute controls the alignment of adjacent text with respect to the embedde™

object. The default value i—  LEF  ì

ALT  This attribute indicates the text to be displayed if the applet cannot be executedì

BORDER  This attribute specifies the size in pixels of the border around the embedded objectì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

 = Page 774 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  75

CODE  This attribute specifies the name of the file containing the compiled Java class if thk

<EMBED  element is used to include a Java applet. This is a strange alternate form of Jav¾

inclusion documented by Microsoftì

CODEBASE  This specifies the base URL for the pluin or potential applet in the case of thk

alternative form under Internet Explorerì

HEqHT  This attribute sets the height in pixels of the embedded objectì

HIDDEN  If this attribute is set to the valuk  TRU¨  , the embedded object is not visible on thk

page and implicitly has a size of zeroì

APPENDIXES

HSPACE  This attribute specifies in pixels the size of the left and right margin between thk

embedded object and surrounding textì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

NAME  This attribute specifies a name for the embedded object, which can be referenced b_

clienâside programs in an embedded scripting languageì

PALETTE  This attribute is used only on Windows systems to select the color palettk

used for the pluin and may be set tf  BACKGROUN¤  oK  FOREGROUN¤  . The defaulš

i—  BACKGROUN¤  ì

PLUGINSP  This attribute contains the URL of instructions for installing the plui-

required to render the embedded objectì

SRC  This attribute specifies the URL of source content for the embedded objectì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TYPE  This attribute specifies the MIME type of the embedded object. It is used by the browseK

to determine an appropriate pluin for rendering the object. It can be used instead of thk  SR‚

attribute for pluins that have no content or that fetch it dynamicallyì

UNITS  This Netscap[specific attribute is used to set the units for measurement for thk

embedded object either i-  EN  or in the default,  PIXELS  ì

VSPACE  This attribute specifies in pixels the size of the top and bottom margin between thk

embedded object and surrounding textì

WIDTH  This attribute sets the width in pixels of the embedded objectì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   ALIGN (BOTTOV | LEF | RIGH | TOP) HEIGH SR‚ WIDTh  ,  ,  ,  , an™

all Netscap[defined attributes. (  CLASS I¤ LAN…  ,  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are implied.)

 = Page 775 =

75  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

INTERNET EXPLORER   All Microsofâdefined attributes and eventsì

WEBTV  ALIGN (BOTTOV | LEF | RIGH | TOP) BORDE HEIGH HIDDEN  ,  ,  ,  ,

HSPAC¨ NAM¨ SR‚ VSPAC¨  ,  ,  ,  , an™  WIDTh  ì

Event Handler“

See “Events Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Example“

<!-- EMBED without a close tag --L

<EMBED SRC="testmovie.mov" HEIGHT="150" WIDTH="150"L

<NOEMBEDL

<IMG SRC="testgif.gif" HEIGHT="150" WIDTH="150" ALT="Test Image"L

</NOEMBEDL

<!-- EMBED with a close tag --L

<EMBED SRC="testmovie.mov" HEIGHT="150" WIDTH="150"L

<NOEMBEDL

<IMG SRC="testgif.gif" HEIGHT="150" WIDTH="150" ALT="Test Image"L

</NOEMBEDL

</EMBEDL

Compatibilit

Netscape 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

WebTV

Note“

  It is unclear whether or not the close tag foK  <EMBED  is required. Many sites tend noš

to use it, and documentation is not consistent. Some people claim that a close tag i—

required and should surround any alternative content in ¾  <NOEMBED  element;

others do not use a close tag. Since this element should eventually be phased out in favoK

o“  <OBJECT  , this may be a moot issueì

  While WebTV may support thk  <EMBED  element, it can deal only with media type—

the equipment knows how to handle, such as Macromedia Flash or certain standar™

audio files. Other pluins cannot be added to the systemì

  Thk  <EMBED  element is not favored by the W3C and is not part of any official HTML

specification; however, it is very common. The HTML specification says to use thk

<OBJECT  element, which can be used in conjunction with thk  <EMBED  element tf

provide backward compatibilityì

  Embedded objects are multimedia content files of arbitrary type, which are rendered b_

browser pluins. Thk  TYP¨  attribute uses a file’s MIME type to determine a-

appropriate browser pluin. Any attributes not defined are treated as objecâspecifi´

parameters and passed through to the embedded object. Consult the pluin or objecš

documentation to determine these. The standard parameters supported by the Microsofš

implementation ark  HEIGH NAM¨ PALETT¨ SR‚ UNITS  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  WIDTh  ì

 = Page 776 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  75

<FIELDSET>   (Form Field Set)

This element allows form designers to group thematically related controls togetherì

Synta¨

<FIELDSE

CLASS="class name(s)"

DIR="LTR | RTL"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LANG="language code"

APPENDIXES

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text"

onclick="script"

ondblclick="script"

  Grouping controls makes it easier for users to understand the purposes of the control—

documents more accessible to people with disabilitiesì

<FN>   (Footnote)

This WebTV-specific element indicates either a reference to a footnote or the footnote itselfì

Syntax (Defined by WebTV)

<FN

HREF="URL"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier">

</FN>

APPENDIXES

Attribute“

HREF  This attribute contains a URL that references the footnote. Typically the URL is ¾

fragment in the form of the pound sign (#) followed by the name of the footnote anchor. Iš

indicates that the tagged text is a reference to a footnoteì

ID  This attribute contains the name of the footnote anchor. It indicates that the tagged texš

is a footnoteì

Attribute and Event Suppor

WEBTV  HREF  an™  I¤  ì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Exampls

This wonderful idea came fro—  <FN HREF="#smith"L  Smith<  </FNL

<FN ID="smith"L  Smith, Fred, Journal of Really Good Idea?  </FNL

Compatibilit

WebTV

Note“

  Footnotes are implemented as internal links within a document. Use thk  HREF  attributk

to indicate a reference to a footnote. Use thk  I¤  attribute to indicate the footnote itselfì

  Footnotes are not to be used outside the WebTV environment. They are a leftover of thk

failed HTML 3 proposalì

 = Page 779 =

758  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<FONT>   (Font Definition)

This element allows specification of the size, color, and font of the text it encloses. Use of thi—

element is not encouraged as it is not part of the HTML 4.0 strict specification. Style sheet—

provide a cleaner way of providing the same functionality when they are supportedì

Syntax (Transitional Only)

<FON

CLASS="class name(s)"

COLOR="color name | #RRGGBB"

DIR="LTR | RTL"

FACE="font name"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LANG="language code"

SIZE="1 to 7 | +1 to +6 | -1 to -6"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text">

</FONT>

Attribute“

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

COLOR  This attribute sets the text color using either a browse§dependent named color or ¾

APPENDIXES

color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  formatì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

EFFECT  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute renders the tagged text in a special wayì

Thk  RELIEF  value causes the text to appear raised off the page. Thk  EMBOSS  value causes thk

text to appear embossed into the pageì

FACE  This attribute contains a list of one or more font names separated by commas. Thk

user agent looks through the specified font names and renders the text in the first font thaš

is supportedì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  This attribute specifies the language the current script is written in and invoke—

the proper scripting engine. The default value i—  JAVASCRIP JAVASCRIP  ì  an™  JSCRIP

represent that the scripting language is written in JavaScriptì  VBS  an™  VBSCRIP  represent thaš

the scripting language is written in VBScriptì

POINT-SIZE  This Netscape 4–specific attribute specifies the point size of text and is used wit—

downloadable fontsì

SIZE  This attribute specifies the font size as either a numeric or relative value. Numeric value—

range fro“  1  tf  7  wit— being the smallest an™ the default. The relative values, + an™ ,  1  3  ?

increment or decrement the font size relative to the current size. The value for increment oK

decrement should range only fro“  +1  tf  + 6  oK  ?  1  tf  ?  6  ì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TRANSPARENCY  WebTV’s proprietar_  TRANSPARENC  attribute is used to set thk

transparency level of the text. A value o“ indicates the text is opaque; a value o“  0  100  indicate—

text is fully transparent, allowing the background to show through. The default value for thi—

attribute i— ì  0

 = Page 781 =

760  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

WEqHT  Under Netscape 4, this attribute specifies the weight of the font, with a value o“  100

being lightest an™  900  being heaviestì

 = Page 782 =

Media Type as per RFC 2045"

_top" (transitional)
