LANGUAGE="JAVASCRIPT | JSCRIPT | VBS | VBSCRIPT"

NAME="string"

ondragstart="script"

onhelp="script"

onselectstart="script"

Attribute“

ACCEPT-CHARSET  This attribute specifies the list of character encodings for input data thaš

must be accepted by the server processing form. The value is a spac[ or commDdelimited lisš

of character sets as defined in RFC 2045. The default value for this attribute is the reserve™

valuk  UNKNOWN  ì

 = Page 783 =

76p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

ACTION  This attribute contains the URL of the server program, which will process thk

contents of the form. Some browsers may also support a mailto URL, which may mail the result—

to the specified addressì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

ENCTYPE  This attribute indicates how form data should be encoded before being sent to thk

server. The default i—  application/x-www-form-urlencoded  . This encoding replaces blank

characters in the data with a + and all other nonprinting characters with a % followed by thk

character’s ASCII HEX representation. The multipart/forRdata option does not perfor“

character conversion and transfers the information as a compound MIME document. This musš

be used when usiný  <INPUT TYPE="FILE"  . It may also be possible to use another encodiný

like text/plain to avoid any form of hex encoding which may be useful with mailed formsì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  This attribute specifies the language the current script is written in and invoke—

the proper scripting engine. The default value i—  JAVASCRIP JAVASCRIP  ì  an™  JSCRIP

represent that the scripting language is written in JavaScriptì  VBS  an™  VBSCRIP  represent thaš

the scripting language is written in VBScriptì

METHOD  This attribute indicates how form information should be transferred to the serverì

Thk  GE  option appends data to the URL specified by thk  ACTION  attribute. This approac—

gives the best performance, but imposes a size limitation determined by the command link

length supported by the server. Thk  POS  option transfers data using a HTTP post transactionì

This approach is more secure and imposes no data size limitationì

NAME  This attribute specifies a name for the form and can be used by clienâside programs tf

reference form dataì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TARGET  In documents containing frames, this attribute specifies the target frame to displa_

the results of a form submission. In addition to named frames, several special values exist. Thk

_blank  value indicates a new window. Thk  _parent  value indicates the parent frame seš

containing the source link. Thk  _self  value indicates the frame containing the source link. Thk

_top  value indicates the full browser windowì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   ACTION ENCTYP¨ METHO¤ NAM¨ TARGE onreset  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  onsubmit  ì

(  CLASS I¤ LAN…  ,  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are implied.)

 = Page 784 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  76

INTERNET EXPLORER   All attributes and events excepš  ACCEPT-CHARSE  an™  DI  ì

WEBTV  ACTION METHO¤ TARGE onreset  ,  ,  ,  , an™  onsubmit  ì

Event Handler“

See “Events Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Exampls

<FORM ACTION="http://www.bigcompany.com/cgi-bin/processit.exeh

Note“

  Form content is defined using thk  <BUTTON <INPUT <SELECT  ,  ,  , an™

<TEXTAREA  elements as well as other HTML formatting and structuring elementsì

Special grouping elements likk  <FIELDSET <LABEL  ,  , an™  <LEGEND  have bee-

introduced to provide better structuring for forms, but other HTML elements such a—

<DIV  an™  <TABLE  may also be used to improve form layoutì

thk  <FORM  elementì

Attribute“

BORDERCOLOR  This attribute sets the color of the frame’s border using either a named coloK

or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  formatì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DATAFLD  This Internet Explorer attribute specifies the column name from the data sourck

object that supplies the bound dataì

DATASRC  This Internet Explorer attribute indicates thk  I¤  of the data source object thaš

supplies the data that is bound to this elementì

FRAMEBORDER  This attribute determines whether the frame is surrounded by an outline™

thre[dimensional border. The HTML specification prefers the use o“  1  for the frame border o-

an™ for off; most browsers also acknowledge the use o“  0  N  an™  YES  ì

 = Page 786 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  76

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  This attribute specifies the language the current script is written in and invoke—

the proper scripting engine. The default value i—  JAVASCRIP JAVASCRIP  ì  an™  JSCRIP

represent that the scripting language is written in JavaScriptì  VBS  an™  VBSCRIP  represent thaš

the scripting language is written in VBScriptì

LONGDESC  This attribute specifies a URL of a document that contains a long description o“

the frame’s content. This attribute should be used in conjunction with thk  <TITLE  elementì

APPENDIXES

MARGINHEqHT  This attribute sets the height in pixels between the frame’s contents and it—

top and bottom bordersì

MARGINWIDTH  This attribute sets the width in pixels between the frame’s contents and it—

left and right bordersì

NAME  This attribute assigns the frame a name so that it can be the target destination o“

hyperlinks as well as be a possible candidate for manipulation via a scriptì

NORESIZE  This attribute overrides the default ability to resize frames and gives the frame ¾

fixed sizeì

SCROLLING  This attribute determines if the frame has scroll bars. A  YES  value forces scrolR

bars, ¾  N  value prohibits them, and a-  AUT  value lets the browser decide. When noš

specified, the default value o“  AUT  is used. Authors are recommended to leave the value a—

AUT  . If you turn off scrolling and the contents end up being too large for the frame (due tf

rendering differences, window size, etc.), the user will not be able to scroll to see the rest of thk

contents. If you turn scrolling on and the contents all fit in the frame, the scroll bars wilR

needlessly consume screen space. With thk  AUT  value, scroll bars appear only when neededì

SRC  This attribute contains the URL of the contents to be displayed in the frame. If absent,

nothing will be loaded in the frameì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   BORDERCOLO FRAMEBORDE MARGINHEIGH MARGINWIDTh  ,  ,  ,  ,

NAM¨ NORESIZ¨ SCROLLIN…  ,  ,  , an™  SR‚ CLASS I¤ LAN…  . (  ,  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are implied.)

INTERNET EXPLORER   All W3C-defined attributes excepš  LONGDES‚  an™  STYL¨  , an™

all attributes and events defined by Internet Explorer 4. (Note: Internet Explorer 4 supports thk

value—  NORESIZ¨  an™  RESIZ¨  .)

 = Page 787 =

76‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Compatibilit

HTML 4

Internet Explorer 2, 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

WebTV

Note“

  A frame must be declared as part of a frame set as set by thk  <FRAMESET  element,

which specifies the frame’s relationship to other frames on a page. A frame set occurs i-

a special HTML document in which thk  <FRAMESET  element replaces thk  <BODY

element. Another form of frames calle™  independent framex  , oK  floating framex  , is alsf

supported by Microsoft as well as the HTML 4.0 transitional specification. Floatiný

frames can be directly embedded in a document without belonging to a frameset. Thesk

are defined with thk  <IFRAME  elementì

  Numerous browsers do not support frames and require the use of thk  <NOFRAMES

elementì

  Frames introduce potential navigation difficulties; their use should be limited tf

instances where they can be shown to help navigation rather than hinder itì

<FRAMESET>   (Frameset Definition)

This element is used to define the organization of a set of independent window regions know-

a—  framex  as defined by thk  <FRAME  element. This element replaces thk  <BODY  element i-

framing documentsì

Syntax (Transitional Only)

<FRAMESE

CLASS="class name(s)"

COLS="list of columns"

 = Page 788 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  76

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

ROWS="list of rows"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text"

onload="script"

onunload="script">

<FRAME> elements and <NOFRAMES>

</FRAMESET>

Attributes and Events Defined by Internet Explorer 

BORDER="pixels"

onfocus="script"

Attributes Defined by WebTV

BORDER="pixels"

FRAMEBORDER="0 | 1"

Attribute“

BORDER  This attribute sets the width in pixels of frame borders within the frame set. Settiný

BORDER="0"  eliminates all frame borders. This attribute is not defined in the HTML

specification but is widely supportedì

BORDERCOLOR  This attribute sets the color for frame borders within the frame set usiný

either a named color or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  formatì

 = Page 789 =

768  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

COLS  This attribute contains a commDdelimited list, which specifies the number and size o“

columns contained within a set of frames. List items indicate columns, left to right. Column sizk

is specified in three formats, which may be mixed. A column can be assigned a fixed width i-

pixels. It can also be assigned a percentage of the available width, such as 50 percent. Lastly ¾

column can be set to expand to fill the available space by setting the value tf , which act—  *

as a wildcardì

FRAMEBORDER  This attribute controls whether or not frame borders should be displayedì

Netscape support—  N  an™  YES  values. Microsoft use— an™ as well a—  1  0  N  an™  YES  ì

FRAMESPACING  This attribute indicates the space between frames in pixelsì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  This attribute specifies the language the current script is written in and invoke—

the proper scripting engine. The default value i—  JAVASCRIP JAVASCRIP  ì  an™  JSCRIP

represent that the scripting language is written in JavaScriptì  VBS  an™  VBSCRIP  represent thaš

the scripting language is written in VBScriptì

ROWS  This attribute contains a commDdelimited list, which specifies the number and size o“

rows contained within a set of frames. The number of entries in the list indicates the number o“

rows. Row size is specified with the same formats used for columnsì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   BORDE BORDERCOLO COLS FRAMEBORDE ROWS onblu(  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

onfocu—onload  ,  , an™  onunload CLASS I¤ LAN…  . (  ,  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are implied.)

INTERNET EXPLORER   BORDE BORDERCOLO CLASS COLS FRAMEBORDE  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

I¤ LAN… LANGUAG¨ ROWS  ,  ,  ,  , an™  TITL¨  ì

WEBTV  BORDE COLS FRAMEBORDE (0 | 1) FRAMESPACIN… ROWS onload  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

an™  onunload  ì

Event Handler“

See “Events Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

 = Page 790 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  769

Example“

<!-- This example defines a frame set of three columns. The middle colum

is 50 pixels wide. The first and last columns fill the remaining space

The last column takes twice as much space as the first. --L

<FRAMESET COLS="*,50,*"L

<FRAME SRC="column1.htm"L

<FRAME SRC="columLslash.htm"L

<FRAME SRC="column3.htm"L

</FRAMESETL  APPENDIXES

<!-- This example defines a frame set of two columns, one of which isp0%

of the screen, and the other, 80%. --L

<FRAMESET COLS=0%, 80%"L

<FRAME SRC="controls.htm"L

<FRAME SRC="display.htm"L

</FRAMESETL

<!-- This example defines two rows, one of which is 10% of the screen,

and the other, whatever space is left. --L

<FRAMESET ROWS="10%, *"L

<FRAME SRC="adbanner.htm" NAME="ad_frame"L

<FRAME SRC="contents.htm" NAME="content_frame"L

</FRAMESETL

Compatibilit

HTML 4 (transitional)

Internet Explorer 2, 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

WebTV

Note“

  Thk  <FRAMESET  element contains one or mork  <FRAME  elements, which are use™

to indicate the framed contents. Thk  <FRAMESET  element may also contain ¾

<NOFRAMES  element whose contents will be displayed on browsers that do noš

support framesì

 = Page 791 =

770  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

  Thk  <FRAMESET  element replaces thk  <BODY  element in a framing document a—

shown here:

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Collection of Frame?  </TITLEL

</HEADL

<FRAMESET COLS="*,50,*"L

<FRAME SRC="column1.htm" NAME="col1"L

<FRAME SRC="columLslash.htm" NAME="col2"L

<FRAME SRC="column3.htm" NAME="col3"L

</FRAMESETL

</HTMLL

<H1> Through <H6>   (Headings)

These tags implement six levels of document headings;  <H1  is the most prominent, an™  <H6

is the least prominentì

Synta¨

<H1

ALIGN="CENTER | JUSTIFY | LEFT | RIGHT"

(transitional)

CLASS="class name(s)"

DIR="LTR | RTL"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LANG="language code"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text"

onclick="script"

ondblclick="script"

onkeydown="script"

onkeypress="script"

onkeyup="script"

onmousedown="script"

onmousemove="script"

onmouseout="script"

onmouseover="script"

onmouseup="script">

</H1>

Attributes and Events Defined by Internet Explorer 

LANGUAGE="JAVASCRIPT | JSCRIPT | VBS | VBSCRIPT"

ondragstart="script"

onhelp="script"

onselectstart="script"

Attribute“

ALqN  This attribute controls the horizontal alignment of the heading with respect to thk

APPENDIXES

page. The default value i—  LEF  ì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  This attribute specifies the language the current script is written in and invoke—

the proper scripting engine. The default value i—  JAVASCRIP JAVASCRIP  ì  an™  JSCRIP

represent that the scripting language is written in JavaScriptì  VBS  an™  VBSCRIP  represent thaš

the scripting language is written in VBScriptì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   ALIGN CLASS I¤ LAN…  . (  ,  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are implied.)

foK  ALIGN  is not supported.)

WEBTV  ALIGN (CENTE | LEF | RIGHT)  ì

Event Handler“

Exampls

<H1L  This is a Major Document Headin(  </H1L

<x ALIGN="CENTER"L  Second heading, aligned to the centeI  </xL

 = Page 793 =

77p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<H3 ALIGN="RIGHT"L  Third heading, aligned to the righM  </H3L

<H4L  Fourth headin(  </H4L

<H5 STYLE="{font-size:p0pt}"L  Fifth heading with style informatioY  </H5L

<H6L  The smallest headin(  </H6L

Compatibilit

HTML 2, 3.2, and 4

Internet Explorer 2, 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 1, 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

WebTV

Note“

  In most implementations, heading numbers correspond inversely with the six font size—

supported by thk  <FONT  element. For example,  <H1  corresponds tf  <FON

SIZE="6"  . The default font size i— . However, this approach to layout is noš  3

encouraged and page designers should consider using styles to set even relative sizesì

  HTML 3.2 supports only thk  ALIGN  attribute. HTML 2 does not support any attribute—

for headingsì

  The HTML 4.0 strict specification does not include support for thk  ALIGN  attributeì

Style sheets should be used insteadì

<HEAD>   (Document Head)

This element indicates the document head that contains descriptive information about the HTML

document as well as other supplementary information such as style rules or scriptsì

Synta¨

<HEAD

DIR="LTR | RTL"

LANG="language code"

PROFILE="URL">

</HEAD>

Attributes and Events Defined by Internet Explorer 

CLASS="class name(s)"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

TITLE="advisory text"

 = Page 794 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  77

Attribute“

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

PROFILE  This attribute specifies a URL for a metDinformation dictionary. The specifie™

APPENDIXES

profile should indicate the format of allowed metDdata and the potential meaning of the dataì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Attribute and Event Suppor

INTERNET EXPLORER   CLASS I¤  ,  , an™  TITL¨  ì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Exampls

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Big Company Home Pag4  </TITLEL

<BASE HREF="http://www.bigcompany.com"L

<META NAME="Keywords" CONTENT="BigCompany, SuperWidget"L

</HEADL

Compatibilit

HTML 2, 3.2, and 4

Internet Explorer 2, 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 1, 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

WebTV

Note“

  Thk  <HEAD  element must contain ¾  <TITLE  element. It may also contain thk

<BASE <ISINDEX <LINK <META <SCRIPT  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  <STYLE  elementsì

Internet Explorer 4 supports the inclusion of thk  <BASEFONT  element in thk  <HEAD

element, buš  <BASEFONT  has been deprecated under HTML 4ì

  While the HTML 4.0 specification shows support for thk  PROFIL¨  attribute, nf

browsers appear to support itì

 = Page 795 =

77  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

  Internet Explorer 4 defines thk  <BGSOUND  element as another legal elemenš

withi-  <HEAD  ì

  HTML 2 and 3.2 support no attributes for this elementì

<HR>   (Horizontal Rule)

This element is used to insert a horizontal rule to visually separate document sections. Rules ark

usually rendered as a raised or etched lineì

Synta¨

<HR

ALIGN="CENTER | LEFT | RIGHT" (transitional)

CLASS="class name(s)"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

NOSHADE (transitional)

SIZE="pixels" (transitional)

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory information"

WIDTH="percentage | pixels" (transitional)

Attributes Defined by WebTV

INVERTBORDER

Attribute“

ALqN  This attribute controls the horizontal alignment of the rule with respect to the pageì

The default value i—  LEF  ì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

APPENDIXES

COLOR  This attribute sets the rule color using either a named color or a color specified in thk

hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format. This attribute is currently supported only by Internet Explorerì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

INVERTBORDER  This WebTV-specific attribute creates a horizontal rule that appears raised,

as opposed to embossed, on the surface of the pageì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  This attribute specifies the language the current script is written in and invoke—

the proper scripting engine. The default value i—  JAVASCRIP JAVASCRIP  ì  an™  JSCRIP

represent that the scripting language is written in JavaScriptì  VBS  an™  VBSCRIP  represent thaš

the scripting language is written in VBScriptì

NOSHADE  This attribute causes the rule to be rendered as a solid bar without shadingì

SIZE  This attribute indicates the height in pixels of the ruleì

SRC  This attribute specifies a URL for an associated fileì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

WIDTH  This attribute indicates how wide the rule should be specified either in pixels or as ¾

percent of screen width, such as 80 percentì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   ALIGN NOSHAD¨ SIZ¨  ,  ,  , an™  WIDTh CLASS I¤  . (  ,  , an™  STYL¨  ark

implied.)

77‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Event Handler“

See “Events Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Example“

<HR ALIGN="LEFT" NOSHADE SIZE="1" WIDTH="0"L

<HR ALIGN="CENTER" WIDTH="100%" SIZE="3" COLOR="#000000"L

WebTV

Note“

The HTML 4.0 strict specification removes support for thk  ALIGN NOSHAD¨ SIZ¨  ,  ,  , an™

WIDTh  attributes for horizontal rules. These effects are possible using style sheetsì

<HTML>   (HTML Document)

This element identifies a document as containing HTML-tagged contentì

Synta¨

<HTML

DIR="LTR | RTL"

LANG="language code"

VERSION="URL" (transitional)>

</HTML>

Attributes Defined by Internet Explorer 

TITLE="advisory text"

Attribute“

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

 = Page 798 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  77

VERSION  Thk  VERSION  attribute is used to set the URL of the location of the document typk

definition (DTD) that the current document conforms to. The DTD is also specified by thk

<!DOCTYPE  comment. Since few if any browsers support thk  VERSION  attribute, it should bk

used only in conjunction with ¾  <!DOCTYPE  comment and not instead of oneì

Attribute and Event Suppor

INTERNET EXPLORER   LAN…  an™  TITL¨  ì

Event Handler“

Noneì

APPENDIXES

Exampls

<!-- Minimal HTML document --L

<HTMLL

<HEAD><TITLEL  Minimal DocumenM  </TITLE></HEADL

<BODY></BODYL

</HTMLL

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

WebTV

Thk  <HTML  element is the first element in a-  <HTML  document. Except for comments, thk

only tags it directly contains are thk  <HEAD  element followed by either ¾  <BODY  element oK

¾  <FRAMESET  elementì

<IFRAME>   (Floating Frame)

This element indicates a floating frame, an independently controllable content region that can bk

embedded in a pageì

Syntax (Transitional Only)

<IFRAME

ALIGN="BOTTOM | LEFT | MIDDLE | RIGHT | TOP"

CLASS="class name(s)"

FRAMEBORDER="0 | 1"

HEIGHT="percentage | pixels"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LONGDESC="URL of description"

MARGINHEIGHT="pixels"

MARGINWIDTH="pixels"

NAME="string"

SCROLLING="AUTO | NO | YES"

SRC="URL of frame contents"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text"

WIDTH="percentage | pixels">

</IFRAME>

Attributes Defined by Internet Explorer 

ALIGN="ABSBOTTOM | ABSMIDDLE | BASELINE | TEXTTOP"

BORDER="pixels"

BORDERCOLOR="color name | #RRGGBB"

 = Page 801 =

780  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

DATAFLD="name of column supplying bound data"

DATASRC="ID of data source object supplying data"

FRAMEBORDER="No | YES | 0 | 1"

FRAMESPACING="pixels"

HSPACE="pixels"

LANG="language code"

LANGUAGE="JAVASCRIPT | JSCRIPT | VBS | VBSCRIPT"

NORESIZE="noresize | resize"

VSPACE="pixels"

Attribute“

ALqN  This attribute controls the horizontal alignment of the floating frame with respect tf

the page. The default i—  LEF  ì

BORDER  This attribute specifies the thickness of the border in pixelsì

BORDERCOLOR  This attribute specifies the color of the borderì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DATAFLD  This attribute specifies the column name from the data source object that supplie—

the bound dataì

DATASRC  This attribute indicates thk  I¤  of the data source object that supplies the data thaš

is bound to this elementì

FRAMEBORDER  This attribute determines whether the frame is surrounded by a border. Thk

HTML 4.0 specification define— to be off an™ to be on. The default value i— . Internet ExploreK  0  1  1

also defines the value—  N  an™  YES  ì

FRAMESPACING  This attribute creates additional space between the framesì

HEqHT  The attribute sets the floating frame’s height in pixelsì

HSPACE  This attribute specifies margins for the frameì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  This attribute specifies the language the current script is written in and invoke—

the proper scripting engine. The default value i—  JAVASCRIP JAVASCRIP  ì  an™  JSCRIP

represent that the scripting language is written in JavaScriptì  VBS  an™  VBSCRIP  represent thaš

the scripting language is written in VBScriptì

 = Page 802 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  78h

LONGDESC  This attribute specifies a URL of a document which contains a long description o“

the frame’s contents. This may be particularly useful as a complement to thk  <TITLE  elementì

MARGINHEqHT  This attribute sets the height in pixels between the floating frame’s contenš

and its top and bottom bordersì

MARGINWIDTH  This attribute sets the width in pixels between the floating frame’s contenš

and its left and right bordersì

NAME  This attribute assigns the floating frame a name so that it can be the target destinatio-

of hyperlinksì

APPENDIXES

NORESIZE  Whe-  NORESIZ¨  is included, the frame cannot be resized by the userì

SCROLLING  This attribute determines if the frame has scroll bars. A  YES  value forces scrolR

bars; ¾  N  value prohibits themì

SRC  This attribute contains the URL of the content to be displayed in the floating frame. I“

absent, the frame is blankì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

VSPACE  This attribute specifies margins for the frameì

WIDTH  This attribute sets the floating frame’s width in pixelsì

Attribute and Event Suppor

INTERNET EXPLORER   All attributes and events excepš  LONGDES‚  ì

Event Handler“

See “Events Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Exampls

<IFRAME SRC="http://www.bigcompany.com" HEIGHT="150" WIDTH=00h

NAME="FloatingFrame1"L

Sorry, your browser doesn't support inline frames<

</IFRAMEL

Compatibilit

HTML 4 (transitional)

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

 = Page 803 =

78p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Note“

  A floating frame does not need to be declared by thk  <FRAMESET  element as part of ¾

frame setì

  WebTV and Netscape 4 do not support floating framesì

  Under the HTML 4.0 strict specification, thk  <IFRAME  element is not defined. Floatiný

frames may be imitated using thk  <DIV  element and CSS positioning facilitiesì

<ILR>   (Inflow Layer)

This Netscap[specific element allows the definition of overlapping content layers that can bk

positioned, hidden or shown, rendered transparent or opaque, reordered front to back, an™

nested. A-  inflow laye(  is a layer with a relative position that appears where it would naturall_

occur in the document, in contrast to ¾  general laye(  , which may be positioned absolutel_

regardless of its location in a document. The functionality of layers is available using CSS

positioning, and page developers are advised not to use this elementì

Syntax (Defined by Netscape 4)

<ILAYER

ABOVE="layer"

BACKGROUND="URL of image"

BELOW="layer"

BGCOLOR="color name | #RRGGBB"

CLASS="class name(s)"

CLIP="x1, y1, x2, y2"

HEIGHT="percentage | pixels"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LEFT="pixels"

NAME="string"

PAGEX="pixels"

PAGEY="pixels"

SRC="URL of layer contents"

STYLE="style information"

TOP="pixels"

VISIBILITY="HIDE | INHERIT | SHOW"

WIDTH="percentage | pixels"

Z-INDEX="number"

onblur="script"

onfocus="script"

onload="script"

onmouseout="script"

onmouseover="script">

</ILAYER>

 = Page 804 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  78

Attribute“

ABOVE  This attribute contains the name of the layer to be rendered above the current layerì

BACKGROUND  This attribute contains the URL of a background image for the layerì

BELOQ  This attribute contains the name of the layer to be rendered below the current layerì

COLOR  This attribute specifies a layer’s background color. Its value can be either a name™

color or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  formatì

APPENDIXES

CLASS  This attribute specifies the class name(s) for access via a style sheetì

CLIV  This attribute specifies the clipping region or viewable area of the layer. All layer contenš

outside that rectangle will be rendered as transparent. Thk  CLIL  rectangle is defined by twf  x,y

pairs: to5 , lefš , botto“  x  y  x  , and righš . Coordinates are relative to the layer’s origin point,  y  0,0  i-

its tošleft cornerì

HEqHT  This attribute specifies the height of a layer in pixels or percentage valuesì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LEFT  This attribute specifies in pixels the horizontal offset of the layer. The offset is relative tf

its parent layer if it has one or to the left page margin if it does notì

NAME  This attribute assigns the layer a name that can be referenced by programs in ¾

clienâside scripting language. Thk  I¤  attribute can also be usedì

PX  This attribute specifies the horizontal position of the layer relative to thk

browser windowì

PY  This attribute specifies the vertical position of the layer relative to thk

browser windowì

SRC  This attribute is used to set the URL of a file that contains the content to load intf

the layerì

STYLE  This attribute specifies an inline style for the layerì

TOV  This attribute specifies in pixels the top offset of the layer. The offset is relative to it—

parent layer if it has one or the top page margin if it does notì

VISIBILITY  This attribute specifies whether a layer is hidden, shown, or inherits its visibilit_

from the layer that includes itì

WIDTH  This attribute specifies a layer’s width in pixelsì

Z-INDEX  This attribute specifies a layer’s stacking order relative to other layers. Position i—

specified with positive integers, wit— indicating the bottommost layerì  1

 = Page 805 =

78  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   All attributesì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Exampls

<PL  Content comes before<  </PL

<ILAYER NAME="background" BGCOLOR="green"L

<PL  Layered information goes here<  </PL

</ILAYERL

<PL  Content comes after<  </PL

Compatibilit

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Note“

  This element will likely fall out of fashion because of its lack of cros-browseK

compatibility. The functionality o“  <ILAYER  is possible using the positioning feature—

in CSS, and page developers are encouraged not to use this elementì

  Applets, pluins, and other embedded media forms, generically calle™  objects¨  may bk

included in a layer; however, they will float to the top of all other layers even if theiK

containing layer is obscuredì

graphic image, but some implementations support movies and animationsì

Attributes Defined by WebTV

CONTROLS

NAME="unique alphanumeric identifier"

RELOAD="seconds"

SELECTED="x,y pair"

TRANSPARENCY="number (1–100)"

Attribute“

ALqN  This attribute controls the horizontal alignment of the image with respect to the pageì

The default value i—  LEF  . Only the Netscape, Internet Explorer 4, and WebTV implementation—

support thk  ABSBOTTOV ABSMIDDL¨ BASELIN¨  ,  ,  , an™  TEXTTOL  valuesì

ALT  This attribute contains a string to display instead of the image for browsers that cannoš

display imagesì

BORDER  This attribute indicates the width in pixels of the border surrounding the imageì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

CONTROLS  Under Internet Explorer 3 and WebTV, it is possible to set the controls to show b_

placing this attribute in thk  <IMG  element. This attribute does not appear to be supporte™

under Internet Explorer 4, and users are encouraged to use thk  <OBJECT  element to embe™

video for Internet Explorerì

DATAFLD  This attribute specifies the column name from the data source object that supplie—

the bound data to set thk  SR‚  of thk  <IMG  elementì

DATASRC  This attribute indicates thk  I¤  of the data source object that supplies the data thaš

is bound to thi—  <IMG  elementì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DYNSRC  In the Microsoft and WebTV implementations, this attribute indicates the URL of ¾

movie file and is used instead of thk  SR‚  attributeì

HEqHT  This attribute indicates the height in pixels of the imageì

 = Page 808 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  78

HSPACE  This attribute indicates the horizontal space in pixels between the image an™

surrounding textì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

ISMAV  This attribute indicates that the image is a serve§side image map. User mouse action—

over the image are sent to the server for processingì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  This attribute specifies the language the current script is written in and invoke—

the proper scripting engine. The default value i—  JAVASCRIP JAVASCRIP  ì  an™  JSCRIP  APPENDIXES

represent that the scripting language is written in JavaScriptì  VBS  an™  VBSCRIP  represent thaš

the scripting language is written in VBScriptì

LONGDESC  This attribute specifies a URL of a document which contains a long description o“

the image. This attribute is used as a complement to thk  AL  attributeì

LOOV  In the Microsoft implementation, this attribute is used with thk  DYNSR‚  attribute tf

cause a movie to loop. Its value is either a numeric loop count or the keywor™  INFINIT¨  ì

LOWSRC  In the Netscape implementation, this attribute contains the URL of an image to bk

initially loaded. Typically, thk  LOWSR‚  image is a lo“resolution or black-anÙwhite image thaš

provides a quick preview of the image to follow. Once the primary image is loaded, it replace—

thk  LOWSR‚  imageì

NAME  This common attribute is used to bind a name to the image. Older browser—

understand thk  NAM¨  field, and in conjunction with scripting languages it is possible tf

manipulate images by their defined names to create effects such as “rollover” buttons. Thk  I¤

attribute under HTML 4 specifies element identifiers; for backward compatibility,  NAM¨  ma_

still be usedì

RELOAD  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute indicates in seconds how frequently a-

image should be reloadedì

SELECTED  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute indicates the initiaR  x,y  coordinatk

location on the image. The cursor is placed at that location when the image is loaded. It require—

either thk  ISMAL  or thk  USEMAL  attributeì

SRC  This attribute indicates the URL of an image file to be displayedì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

SUPPRESS  This Netscap[specific attribute determines if a placeholder icon will appeaK

during image loading. Values ark  TRU¨  an™  FALS¨ SUPPRESS="TRUE"  ì  will suppress displa_

of the placeholder icon as well as display of an_  AL  information until the image is loadedì

SUPPRESS="FALSE"  will allow the placeholder icon and any tool tips defined by thk  AL

information to display while the image is loading. The default value i—  FALS¨  . If the browser i—

set to not load images automatically, thk  SUPPRESS  attribute is ignoredì

 = Page 809 =

788  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TRANSPARENCY  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute allows the background tf

show through the image. It takes a numeric argument indicating the degree of transparency,

from fully opaque ( ) to fully transparent (  0  100  )ì

USEMAV  This attribute makes the image support clienâside image mapping. Its argument i—

a URL specifying the map file, which associates image regions with hyperlinksì

VSPACE  This attribute indicates the vertical space in pixels between the image an™

surrounding textì

WIDTH  This attribute indicates the width in pixels of the imageì

<INPUT>   (Input Form Control)

This element specifies an input control for a form. The type of input is set by thk  TYP¨  attributk

and may be a variety of different types, including singl[line text field, multiline text field,

password style, check box, radio button, or push buttonì

correlated with that key sequence. Page designers are forewarned to avoid key sequence—

already bound to browsersì

ALqN  With image form controls (  TYPE="IMAGE"  ), this attribute aligns the image wit—

respect to surrounding text. The HTML 4.0 transitional specification define—  BOTTOV LEF  ,  ,

MIDDL¨ RIGH  ,  , an™  TOL  as allowable values. Netscape and Microsoft browsers may alsf

presentatio™specific aspects of HTML, thk  ALIGN  attribute is dropped under the HTML 4.0

browsers. The meaning o“  AL  for forms o“  <INPUT  beyon™  TYPE="INPUT"  is unclearì  APPENDIXES

COLOR  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute specifies the background color of ¾

text form control (  TYPE="TEXT"  ). The value of the attribute can be either a named color or ¾

color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  formatì

BORDERIM  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute allows specification of ¾

graphical border foK  RESE SUBMI  ,  , an™  TEX  controls. Its value is the URL of a .bif (BordeK

Image File) graphics file that specifies the border. Border image files tend to reside in WebTV

ROM; the common values ark  file://ROM/Border/ButtonBorder2.bif  an™  file://ROM/Border

ButtonBorder3.bif  , though other values may be present under later versions of WebTVì

CHECKED  Thi— attribute should be used only for check box (  TYPE="CHECKBOX"  ) and radif

(  TYPE="RADIO"  ) form controls. The presence of this attribute indicates that the control shoul™

be displayed in its checked stateì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

CURSOR  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute sets the cursor color for a text for“

control (  TYPE="TEXT"  ). The attribute’s value is either a named color or a color specified in thk

hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  formatì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DISABLED  This attribute is used to turn off a form control. Elements will not be submitted,

nor may they receive any focus from the keyboard or mouse. Disabled form controls will not bk

part of the tabbing order. The browser may also gray out the form that is disabled, in order tf

indicate to the user that the form control is inactive. This attribute requires no valueì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  In the Microsoft implementation, this attribute specifies the scripting language tf

be used with an associated script bound to the element typically through an event handleK

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

values that include the version of the language used, such a—  JavaScript1.1  , may also be possibleì

 = Page 813 =

79p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

MAXLENGTH  This attribute indicates the maximum content length that can be entered in ¾

text form control (  TYPE="TEXT"  ). The maximum number of characters allowed differs from thk

visible dimension of the form control, which is set with thk  SIZ¨  attributeì

NAME  This attribute allows a form control to be assigned a name so that it can be reference™

by a scripting languageì  NAM¨  is supported by older browsers such as Netscape 2–generatio-

browsers, but the W3C encourages the use of thk  I¤  attribute. For compatibility purposes, bot—

may have to be usedì

READON  This attribute prevents the form control’s value from being changed. For“

controls with this attribute set may receive focus from the user but may not be modifiedì

Since it receives focus, ¾  READONL  form control will be part of the form’s tabbing orderì

Last, the control’s value will be sent on form submission. This attribute can only be use™

wit—  <INPUT  whe-  TYP¨  is set tf  TEX  oK  PASSWOR¤  . The attribute is also used wit—

thk  <TEXTAREA  elementì

SIZE  This attribute indicates the visible dimension, in characters, of a text form controR

(  TYPE="TEXT"  ). This differs from the maximum length of content, which can be entered in ¾

form control set by thk  MAXLENGTh  attributeì

SRC  This attribute is used with image form controls (  TYPE="IMAGE"  ) to specify the URL o“

the image file to loadì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TABINDEX  This attribute takes a numeric value that indicates the position of the form controR

in the tabbing index for the form. Tabbing proceeds from the lowest positivk  TABINDEX  valuk

to the highest. Negative values foK  TABINDEX  will leave the form control out of the tabbiný

order. When tabbing is not explicitly set, the browser may tab through items in the order they ark

encountered. Form controls that are disabled due to the presence of thk  DISABLE¤  attributk

will not be part of the tabbing index, though reaÙonly controls will beì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TYPE  This attribute specifies the type of the form control. A value o“  BUTTON  indicates ¾

genera_purpose button with no wel_defined meaning. However, an action can be associate™

with the button using an event handler attribute, such a—  onclick  . A value o“  CHECKBOX

indicates a check box control. Check box form controls have a checked and nonchecked set, buš

even if these controls are grouped together, they allow a user to select multiple check boxes aš

once. In contrast, a value of RADí indicates a radio button control. When grouped, radif

buttons allow only one of the many choices to be selected at a given timeì

A form control type o“  HIDDEN  indicates a field that is not visible to the viewer but is use™

to store information. A hidden form control is often used to preserve state information betwee-

pages. A value o“  FIL¨  for thk  TYP¨  attribute indicates a control that allows the viewer to uploa™

a file to a server. The filename can be entered in a displayed field, or a user agent may provide ¾

special browse button allowing the user to locate the file. A value o“  IMAG¨  indicates a graphi´

image form control that a user can click on to invoke an associated action. A value o“

PASSWOR¤  for thk  TYP¨  attribute indicates a password entry field. A password field will noš

 = Page 814 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  79

display text entered as it is typed; it may instead show a series of dots. Note that passworÙ

entered data is not transferred to the server in any secure fashion. A value o“  RESE  for thk

TYP¨  attribute is used to insert a button that resets all controls within a form to their defaulš

values. A value o“  SUBMI  inserts a special submission button that, when pressed, sends thk

contents of the form to the location indicated by thk  ACTION  attribute of the enclosiný

<FORM  element. Last, a value o“  TEX  (the default) for thk  TYP¨  attribute indicates ¾

singl[line text input fieldì

USEMAV  This HTML 4 attribute is used to indicate the map file to be associated with a-

image when the form control is set wit—  TYPE="IMAGE"  . The value of the attribute should be ¾

URL of a map file, but will generally be in the form of a URL fragment referencing a map filk

APPENDIXES

within the current fileì

USESTYLE  In the WebTV implementation, the presence of this attribute causes control text tf

be rendered in the default text style for the page. This attribute requires no valueì

VALUE  This attribute has two different uses, depending on the value for thk  TYP¨  attributeì

With data entry controls (  TYPE="TEXT"  an™  TYP¨ "PASSWORD"  =  ), this attribute is used to seš

the default value for the control. When used with check box or radio form controls, this attributk

specifies the return value for the control when it is turned on, rather than the default Boolea-

value submittedì

WIDTH  This WebTV attribute is used to set the size of the form control in pixelsì

Attribute“

CITE  The value of this attribute is a URL that designates a source document or message for thk

information inserted. This attribute is intended to point to information explaining why the texš

was changedì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DATETIME  Thisf¾ttributk i— use™ tf indicatk thk datk an™ timk thk insertio- wa— madeì Thk

valuk o“ thk attributk i— ¾ datk i- ¾ speciaR format, a— define™ b_ ISO 8601ì Thk basi´ datk formaš i—

YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssTZD

where the following is true:

YYYY=four-digit year such as 1999

MM=two-digit month (01=January, 02=February, and so on)

DD=two-digit day of the month (01 through 31)

hh=two-digit hour (00 to 23) (24-hour clock not AM or PM)

mm=two-digit minute (00 to)

ss=two-digit second (00 to)

TZD=time zone designatoI

 = Page 817 =

79‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

¾—k timk zonk designatoK i— eitheK , whic— indicate— UTC (UniversaR Timk Coordinate, oK  Z

coordinate™ universaR timk format), oK :  +  hh mm  , whic— indicate— thaš thk timk i— ¾ locaR timk thaš i—

hh  hour— an™  mh  minute— ahea™ o“ UTCì Alternatively, thk formaš foK thk timk zonk designatoK

coul™ bk  ’  hh mm  :  , whic— indicate— thaš thk locaR timk i— behin™ UTCì Notk thaš thk letteK “T”

actuall_ appear— i- thk string, alR digit— musš bk used, an™value— foK minute— an™ second— ma_  00

bk requiredì A- examplk valuk foK thk  DATETIM¨  attributk mighš bk  1999-10-6T09:15:00-05:00  ,

whic— correspond— tf OctobeK 6, 1999, 9:15  A.Mì  , U.Sì Easter- Standar™ Timeì

Note“

  Browsers may render inserted (  <INS  ) or deleted (  <DEL  ) text in a different style tf

show the changes that have been made to the document. Eventually, a browser ma_

have a way to show a revision history on a document. User agents that do noš

understan™  <DEL  oK  <INS  will show the information anyway, so there is no har“

in adding information, only in deleting itì

  Thk  <INS  element is not supported under the HTML 2 and 3.2 specificationsì

<ISINDEX>   (Index Prompt)

This element indicates that a document has an associated searchable keyword index. When ¾

browser encounters this element, it inserts a query entry field at that point in the document. Thk

viewer can enter query terms to perform a search. This element is deprecated under the stricš

HTML 4 specification and should not be usedì

Syntax (Transitional Only)

<ISINDEX

CLASS="class name(s)"

APPENDIXES

DIR="LTR | RTL"

HREF="URL" (nonstandard but common)

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LANG="language code"

PROMPT="string"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text">

Attributes Defined by Internet Explorer 

LANGUAGE="JAVASCRIPT | JSCRIPT | VBS | VBSCRIPT"

Attribute“

ACTION  This attribute specifies the URL of the query action to be executed when the vieweK

presses thk  ENTER  key. While this attribute is not defined under any HTML specification, it i—

common to many browsers, particularly Internet Explorer 3, which defined itì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

HREF  Thk  HREF  attribute is used with thk  <ISINDEX  element as a way to indicate what thk

search document is. Another approach is to use thk  <BASE  element for the document. Thk

HTML 2 documentation suggests that this is a legal approach and browsers appear to support it;

however, it is poorly documented at bestì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  In the Microsoft implementation, this attribute specifies the scripting languagk

to be used with an associated script bound to the element, typically through an event handleK

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  , an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

values that include the version of the language used, such a—  JavaScript1.1  , may also be possibleì

 = Page 819 =

798  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

PROMPT  This attribute allows a custom query prompt to be defined. The default prompt i—

“This is a searchable index. Enter search keywords.” WebTV does not implement this attributeì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   PROMP CLASS I¤ LAN…  . (  ,  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are implied.)

INTERNET EXPLORER   CLASS I¤ LAN… LANGUAG¨ PROMP  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  STYL¨  ì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Example“

<ISINDEX ACTION="cgi-bin/search" PROMPT="Enter search terms"L

<ISINDEX HREF="cgi-bin/search" PROMPT="Keywords:"L

<BASE HREF="cgi-bin/search"L

<ISINDEX PROMPT="Enter search terms"L

Compatibilit

HTML 2, 3.2, and 4 (transitional)

Internet Explorer 2, 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 1, 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

WebTV

Note“

  As an empty element,  <ISINDEX  requires no closing tagì

  The HTML 3.2 specification only allows thk  PROMP  attribute, while HTML 2 expecte™

a text description to accompany the search fieldì

  Netscape 1.1 originated the use of thk  PROMP  attribute. WebTV does not supporš

this attributeì

  Originally, the W3C intended this element to be used in a document’s header. BrowseK

vendors have relaxed this usage to allow the element in a document’s body. Earl_

implementations did not support thk  ACTION  attribute and used thk  <BASE  elemenš

or a-  HREF  attribute to specify a search function’s URLì

  Older versions of Internet Explorer also support thk  ACTION  attribute, which specifie—

the URL to use for the query rather than relying on the URL set in thk  <BASE  elementì

 = Page 820 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  799

Internet Explorer 4 does not support thk  ACTION DI HREF  ,  ,  , oK  TITL¨  attributesì

Microsoft documentation suggests usiný  <INPUT  instead of this deprecated elementì

<LR>   (Content Layers)

This Netscap[specific element allows the definition of overlapping content layers that can bk

exactly positioned, hidden or shown, rendered transparent or opaque, reordered front to back,

and nested. The functionality of layers is available using CSS positioning facilities; pagk

developers are advised not to use thk  <LAYER  elementì

Syntax (Defined by Netscape 4)

<LAYER

ABOVE="layer name"

BACKGROUND="URL of background image"

BELOW="layer name"

BGCOLOR="color value"

CLASS="class name(s)"

CLIP="clip region coordinates in x1, y1, x2, y2 form"

HEIGHT="percentage | pixels"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LEFT="pixels"

NAME="string"

PAGEX="horizontal pixel position of layer"

PAGEY="vertical pixel position of layer"

SRC="URL of layer's contents"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text"

TOP="pixels"

VISIBILITY="HIDE | INHERIT | SHOW"

WIDTH="percentage | pixels"

Z-INDEX="number"

onblur="script"

onfocus="script"

onload="script"

onmouseout="script"

onmouseover="script">

</LAYER>

 = Page 825 =

80  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Attribute“

ABOVE  This attribute contains the name of the layer (as set with thk  NAM¨  attribute) to bk

rendered directly above the current layerì

BACKGROUND  This attribute contains the URL of a background pattern for the layer. Likk

backgrounds for the document as a whole, the image may tileì

BELOQ  This value of this attribute is the name of the layer to be rendered below thk

current layerì

COLOR  This attribute specifies a layer’s background color. The attribute’s value can bk

either a named color, such a—  red  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, suc—

a—  #FF0000  ì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

CLIV  This attribute clips a layer’s content to a specified rectangle. All layer content outsidk

that rectangle is rendered transparent. Thk  CLIL  rectangle is defined by twf  x,y  pairs thaš

correspond to the to5 , lefš , botto“  x  y  x  , and righš coordinate of the rectangle. The coordinate—  y

are relative to the layer’s origin point,  0,0  in its tošleft corner, and may have nothing to do wit—

the pixel coordinates of the screenì

HEqHT  This attribute is used to set the height of the layer either in pixels or as a percentagk

of the screen or region the layer is contained withinì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LEFT  This attribute specifies in pixels the left offset of the layer. The offset is relative to it—

parent layer, if it has one, or to the left browser margin if it does notì

NAME  This attribute assigns the layer a name that can be referenced by programs in ¾

clienâside scripting language. Thk  I¤  attribute can also be usedì

PX  This attribute is used to set the horizontal pixel position of the layer relative to thk

document window rather than any enclosing layerì

PY  This attribute is used to set the vertical pixel position of the layer relative to thk

document window rather than any enclosing layerì

SRC  This attribute specifies the URL that contains the content to include in the layer. Usiný

this attribute with an empty element is a good way to preserve layouts under older browsersì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TOV  This attribute specifies in pixels the top offset of the layer. The offset is relative to it—

parent layer if it has one, or the top browser margin if it is not enclosed in another layerì

 = Page 826 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  80

VISIBILITY  This attribute specifies whether a layer is hidden (  HIDDEN  ), shown (  SHOW  ), oK

inherits (  INHERITS  ) its visibility from the layer enclosing itì

WIDTH  This attribute specifies a layer’s width in pixels or as a percentage value of thk

enclosing layer or browser widthì

Z-INDEX  This attribute specifies a layer’s stacking order relative to other layers. Position i—

specified with positive integers, with “1” indicating the bottommost layerì

Attribute and Event Suppor

APPENDIXES

NETSCAPE   All attributesì

Event Handler“

See “Events Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Example“

<LAYER NAME="scene" BGCOLOR="#00FFFFL

<LAYER NAME="Shaq" LEFT="100" TOP="100"L

<IMG SRC="shaq.gif"L

</LAYERL

<LAYER NAME="Kobe" LEFT=00" TOP="100h

VISIBLITY="HIDDEN"L

<IMG SRC="bryant.jpg"L

</LAYERL

</LAYERL

<!-- The better way to do layers --L

<LAYER SRC="contents.htm" LEFT=0" TOP=0h

HEIGHT="80%" WIDTH="80%"L

</LAYERL

Compatibilit

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Note“

  This element will likely fall out of fashion because it lacks cros-browser compatibilityì

The functionality o“  <LAYER  is possible using the positioning features in CSS; pagk

developers are encouraged not to use thk  <LAYER  elementì

  Applets, pluins, and other embedded media forms, generically calle™  objects¨  may bk

included in a layer; however, they float to the top of all other layers even if theiK

containing layer is obscuredì

 = Page 827 =

80‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

is also possible to position the legend to the right by setting the attribute tf  RIGH  . Thk

specification define—  BOTTOV  an™  TOL  as well. Microsoft defines the use of thk  CENTE  an™

also defines another attribute,  VALIGN  , to set the vertical alignment separately. Future supporš

foK  VALIGN  is unclear; page designers are encouraged to use only thk  ALIGN  attribute and tf

TYPE  This attribute indicates the bullet type used in unordered lists or the numbering typk

used in ordered lists. For ordered lists, a value o“ indicates lowercase letters,    G  indicate—

uppercase letters, indicates lowercase Roman numerals, indicates uppercase Roman numerals,  p  I

an™ indicates numbers. For unordered lists, values are used to specify bullet types. While thk  1

browser is free to set bullet styles, a value o“  DIS‚  generally specifies a filled circle, a value o“

CIRCL¨  specifies an empty circle, and a value o“ specifies a filled square. Browsers such a—  b

WebTV may include other bullet shapes such as trianglesì

VALUE  This attribute indicates the current number of items in an ordered list, as defined b_

thk  <OL  element. Regardless of the value o“  TYP¨  being used to set Roman numerals or letters,

the only allowed value for this attribute is a number. List items that follow continue numberiný

from the value set. Thk  VALU¨  attribute has no meaning for unordered listsì

attributes, as these functions can be performed with style sheetsì

  While bullet style can be set explicitly, browsers tend to change styles for bullets whe-

<UL  lists are nested. However, ordered lists generally do not change stylk

automatically, nor do they support outline style numbers (1.1, 1.1.1, and so on)ì

  The closing taý  </LI  is optional and is not commonly usedì

<LINK>   (Link to External Files or Set Relationships)

This empty element specifies relationships between the current document and other documentsì

Possible uses for this element include defining a relational framework for navigation and linkiný

the document to a style sheetì

Synta¨

<LINK

CHARSET="charset list from RFC 2045"

 = Page 832 =

SCREEN | other"

REV="relationship value"

Attributes Defined by Internet Explorer 

DISABLED

Attributes Defined by Netscape 

SRC="URL"

Attribute“

CHARSET  This attribute specifies the character set used by the linked document. Allowe™

values for this attribute are character set names, such as EUC-JP, as defined in RFC 2045ì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DISABLED  This Microsofâdefined attribute is used to disable a link relationship. Thk

presence of the attribute is all that is required to remove a linking relationship. In conjunctio-

with scripting, this attribute could be used to turn on and off various style sheet relationshipsì

 = Page 833 =

81p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

HREF  This attribute specifies the URL of the linked resource. A URL may be absolutk

or relativeì

HREFLANG  This attribute is used to indicate the language of the linked resource. Sek

“Language Reference,” earlier in this appendix for information on allowed valuesì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

MEDI  This attribute specifies the destination medium for any linked style information, a—

indicated when thk  REL  attribute is set tf  STYLESHEE  . The value of the attribute may be ¾

single media descriptor such a—  SCREEN  or a commDseparated list. Possible values for thi—

attribute includk  ALL AURAL BRAILL¨ PRIN PROJECTION  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  SCREEN  . Other value—

may also be defined, depending on the browser. Internet Explorer support—  ALL PRIN  ,  , an™

SCREEN  as values for this attributeì

RE¤  This attribute names a relationship between the linked document and the currenš

document. Possible values for this attribute includk  ALTERNAT¨ BOOKMARK CHAPTE  ,  ,  ,

CONTENTS COPYRIGH GLOSSAR HELL INDEX NEX PREV SECTION STAR  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

STYLESHEE  , an™  SUBSECTION  ì

The most common use of this attribute is to specify a link to an external style sheet. Thk  REL

attribute is set tf  STYLESHEE  , and thk  HREF  attribute is set to the URL of an external stylk

sheet to format the page. WebTV also supports the use of the valuk  NEX  foK  REL  to preload thk

next page in a document seriesì

REV  The value of thk  REV  attribute shows the relationship of the current document to thk

linked document, as defined by thk  HREF  attribute. The attribute thus defines the reversk

relationship compared to the value of thk  REL  attribute. Values for thk  REV  attribute are similaK

to the possible values foK  REL  . They may includk  ALTERNAT¨ BOOKMARK CHAPTE  ,  ,  ,

CONTENTS COPYRIGH GLOSSAR HELL INDEX NEX PREV SECTION STAR  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

STYLESHEE  , an™  SUBSECTION  ì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TARGET  The value of thk  TARGE  attribute is used to define the frame or window name thaš

has the defined linking relationship or that will show the rendering of any linked resourceì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TYPE  This attribute is used to define the type of the content linked to. The value of thk

attribute should be a MIME type such a—  text/htm“ text/cs—  ,  , and so on. The common use of thi—

attribute is to define the type of style sheet linked and the most common current value i—  text/cs—  ,

which indicates a Cascading Style Sheet formatì

 = Page 834 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  81

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   REL SR‚  ,  , an™  TYP¨ CLASS I¤ LAN…  . (  ,  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are implied.)

INTERNET EXPLORER   DISABLE¤ HREF I¤ MEDIG (ALL | PRINT | SCREEN) REL  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

REV TITL¨  ,  , an™  TYP¨  ì

WEBTV  HREF  an™  REL  (value=  "NEXT"  )ì

Event Handler“

See “Event Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

APPENDIXES

Example“

<LINK HREF="products.htm" REL="parent"L

<LINK HREF="corpstyle.css" REL="stylesheet" TYPE="text/css" MEDIA="ALL"L

<LINK HREF="nextpagetoload.htm" REL="next"L

Compatibilit

HTML 2, 3.2, and 4

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

WebTV

Note“

  As an empty elemenš  <LINK  has no closing tagì

  Thk  <LINK  element can occur only in thk  <HEAD  element; there may be multiplk

occurrences of the elementì

  HTML 3.2 defines only thk  HREF REL REV  ,  ,  , an™  TITL¨  attributes for thk  <LINK

elementì

  HTML 2 defines thk  HREF METHODS REL REV TITL¨  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  URN  attributes for thk

<LINK  element. Thk  METHODS  an™  URN  attributes were later removed fro“

specificationsì

  The HTML 4.0 specification defines event handlers for thk  <LINK  element, but it i—

unclear how they would be usedì

 = Page 835 =

81  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<LISTING>   (Code Listing)

This deprecated element from HTML 2 is used to indicate a code listing; it is no longer part of thk

HTML standard. Text tends to be rendered in a smaller size within this element. Otherwise, thk

<PRE  element should be used instead o“  <LISTING  to indicate preformatted textì

<LISTING>

Attribute“

ALqN  This WebTV-specific attribute is used to indicate how the marquee should be aligne™

with surrounding text. The alignment values and rendering are similar to other embedde™

objects, such as  images. The default value for this attribute under WebTV i—  LEF  . Microsofš

APPENDIXES

Internet Explorer no longer supports this attributeì

BEHAVIOR  This attribute conšrol— thk movemenš o“ marquek texš acros— thk marqueeì Thk

ALTERNAT¨  optio- cause— texš tf completel_ cros— thk marquek fiel™ i- onk directio- an™ the-

cros— i- thk oppositk directionì A valuk o“  SCROLL  foK thk attributk cause— texš tf wra5 aroun™ an™

starš oveK againì Thi— i— thk defaulš valuk foK ¾ marqueeì A valuk o“  SLID¨  foK thi— attributk cause—

texš tf cros— thk marquek fiel™ an™ sto5 whe- it— leadiný characteK reache— thk oppositk sideì

COLOR  This attribute specifies the marquee’s background color. The value for the attributk

can either be a color name or a color value defined in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  formatì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DATAFLD  This attribute is used to indicate the column name in the data source that is boun™

to thk  <MARQUEE  elementì

DATAFORMATAS  This attribute indicates if the bound data is plain text (  TEX  ) or HTML

(  HTML  ). The data bound wit—  <MARQUEE  is used to set the message that is scrolledì

DATASRC  The value of this attribute is set to an identifier indicating the data source to pulR

data from. Bound data is used to set the message that is scrolled in thk  <MARQUEE  ì

DIRECTION  This attribute specifies the direction in which the marquee should scroll. Thk

default i—  LEF  . Other possible values foK  DIRECTION  includk  DOWN RIGH  ,  , an™  UL  ì

WebTV does not support thk  DOWN  an™  UL  valuesì

HEqHT  This attribute specifies the height of the marquee in pixels or as a percentage o“

the windowì

HSPACE  This attribute indicates the horizontal space in pixels between the marquee an™

surrounding contentì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  In the Microsoft implementation, this attribute specifies the scripting languagk

to be used with an associated script bound to the element, typically through an event handleK

 = Page 841 =

820  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  , an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

values that include the version of the language used, such a—  JavaScript1.1  , may also be possibleì

LOOV  This attribute indicates the number of times the marquee content should loop. B_

default, a marquee loops infinitely unless thk  BEHAVIO  attribute is set tf  SLID¨  . It is alsf

possible to use a value o“  INFINIT¨  oK  ?  1  to set the text to loop indefinitelyì

SCROLLAMOUNT  This attribute specifies the width in pixels between successive displays o“

the scrolling text in the marqueeì

SCROLLDEL“  This attribute specifies the delay in milliseconds between successive display—

of the text in the marqueeì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TRANSPARENCY  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute specifies the marquee’—

degree of transparency. Values range fro“  0  (totally opaque) tf  100  (totally transparent). A valuk

o“  50  is optimized for fast renderingì

TRUESPEED  When this attribute is present, it indicates that thk  SCROLLDELA  valuk

should be honored for its exact value. If the attribute is not present, any values less than 60 ark

rounded up to 60 millisecondsì

VSPACE  This attribute indicates the vertical space in pixels between the marquee an™

surrounding contentì

WIDTH  This attribute specifies the width of the marquee in pixels or as a percentage of thk

enclosing windowì

Attribute and Event Suppor

INTERNET EXPLORER   All Microsofâdefined attributes and eventsì

SCROLLAMOUN SCROLLDELA TRANSPARENC VSPAC¨  ,  ,  ,  , an™  WIDTh  ì (Note:

WebTV supports only thk  LEFT and RIGH  values for thk  DIRECTION  attribute.)

Event Handler“

Thk  <MARQUEE  element has a few unique events. For example, an event is triggered whe-

the text bounces off one side or another on the marquee. This can be caught with thk  onbounc2

event handler attribute. When the text first starts scrolling, the start event fires, which can bk

caught wit—  onstart  ; when the marquee is done, a finish event fires, which can be caught wit—

onfinis—  . The other events are common to HTML 4 elements with Microsoft extensionsì

 = Page 842 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  82h

Example“

<MARQUEE BEHAVIOR="ALTERNATE"L

SPECIAL VALUE !!! This week only !!!

</MARQUEEL

<MARQUEE ID="marquee1" BGCOLOR="RED" DIRECTION="RIGHT" HEIGHT="30h

WIDTH="80%" HSPACE="10" VSPACE="10"L

The super scroller scrolls again!!

More fun than a barrel of &lt;BLINK&gt; elements<

</MARQUEEL  APPENDIXES

<MENU>   (Menu List)

This element is used to indicate a short list of items that might occur in a menu of choicesì

Like the ordered and unordered lists, the individual items in the list are indicated by thk  <LI

element. Most browsers render thk  <MENU  element exactly the same as the unordere™

list, so there is little reason to use it. Under the HTML 4.0 strict specification,  <MENU  is nf

longer supportedì

<META>   (Meta-Information)

This element specifies general information about a document, which can be used in documenš

indexing. It also allows a document to define fields in the HTTP response header when it is senš

from the server. A common use of this element is foK  client-pull  page loading, which allows ¾

document automatically to load another document after a specified delayì

Synta¨

<META

CONTENT="string"

DIR="LTR | RTL"

HTTP-EQUIV="http header string"

LANG="language code"

NAME="name of meta-information"

SCHEME="scheme type">

Attributes Defined by WebTV

URL="url"

 = Page 845 =

82  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Attribute“

CONTENT  This attribute contains the actual metDinformation. The form of the actuaR

metDinformation varies greatly, depending on the value set foK  NAM¨  ì

DIR  This attribute defines the text direction (left to right or right to left) of the content of thk

<META  element, as defined by thk  CONTEN  attributeì

HTTP-EQUIV  Thi— attributk bind— thk metDinformatio- i- thk  CONTEN  attributk tf a- HTTf

responsk headerì I“ thi— attributk i— present, thk  NAM¨  attributk shoul™ noš bk usedì Thk

HTTP-EQUIV  attributk i— ofte- use™ tf creatk ¾ documenš thaš automaticall_ load— anotheK

documenš afteK ¾ seš timeì Thi— i— calle™  client-pull  ì A- examplk o“ ¾ clienâpulR  <META  elemenš i—

<META HTTP-EQUIV="REFRESH" CONTENT="10;URL='nextpage.htm'"L

Note that thk  CONTEN  attribute contains two values. The first is the number of seconds tf

wait, and the second is the identifier URL and the URL to load after the specified timeì

LANG  This attribute is the language code associated with the language used in thk

CONTEN  attributeì

NAME  This attribute associates a name with the metDinformation contained in thk

CONTEN  attribute. If present, thk  HTTP-EQUIV  attribute should not be usedì

SCHEME  The scheme attribute is used to indicate the expected format of the value of thk

CONTEN  attribute. The particular scheme may also be used in conjunction with the metDdat¾

profile as indicated by thk  PROFIL¨  attribute for thk  <HEAD  elementì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   CONTEN HTTP-EQUIV  ,  , an™  NAM¨  ì

INTERNET EXPLORER   All attributes excepš  DI  ì

WEBTV  CONTEN HTTP-EQUIV  ,  , an™  URL  ì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Example“

<!-- Use of the META element to assist in document indexing --L

<META NAME="KEYWORDS" CONTENT="HTML, SCRIPTINGh

SCHEME="Lycos"L

<!-- Use of the META element to implement client-pull to

automatically load a page --L

  Thk  <META  element can occur only in thk  <HEAD  element. It may be define™

  Thk  <META  element is an empty element and does not have a closing tag nor contai-

any contentì

  A common use of thk  <META  element is to set information for indexing tools such a—

function includk  AUTHO DESCRIPTION  ,  , an™  KEYWORDS  ; other attributes ma_

also be possibleì

<MULTICOL>   (Multiple Column Text)

¾hi— Netscap[specifi´ elemenš render— thk enclose™ contenš i- multiplk columnsì Thi— elemenš

shoul™ noš bk use™ i- favoK o“ ¾ table, whic— i— ¾ mork standar™ wa_ tf rendeK multiplk column— o“

Attribute“

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

COLS  This attribute indicates the number of columns in which to display the text. Thk

browser attempts to fill the columns evenlyì

GUTTER  This attribute indicates the width in pixels between the columns. The default valuk

for this attribute i—  10  pixelsì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

WIDTH  This attribute indicates the column width for all columns. The width of each column i—

set in pixels and is equivalent for all columns in the group. When the attribute is not specified,

the width of columns is determined by taking the available window size, subtracting the numbeK

of pixels for the gutter between the columns as specified by thk  GUTTE  attribute, and evenl_

dividing the result by the number of columns in the group as set by thk  COLS  attributeì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   All attributesì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Exampls

<MULTICOL COLS="3" GUTTER=0"L

Put a long piece of text here...<

</MULTICOLL

Note“

  Do not attempt to use images or other embedded media within a multicolumn layout, a—

defined b_  <MULTICOL  ì

  Do not set the number of columns to high or resize the browser window very small, a—

this will cause text to overwrite other linesì

may wrap can be inserted using thk  <WBR  elementì

Alternative content for non-frame-supporting browser?

</NOFRAMES>

Attribute“

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

 = Page 851 =

830  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   CLASS I¤ LAN…  ,  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are impliedì

INTERNET EXPLORER   I¤ STYL¨  ,  , an™  TITL¨  ì

Event Handler“

It is interesting to note that while thk  <NOFRAMES  element does support the common event—

for nearly all HTML 4 elements, their value seems unclear. The only time that content within ¾

<NOFRAMES  could be rendered is on a browser that does not support frames; however,

browsers that do not support frames are unlikely to support an event model or similar featuresì

There might be some possibility with clever scripting to access framed and nonframed content,

but for now the benefit of the events seems unclear. For more information, see “Event—

Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Exampls

<FRAMESET ROWS="100,*"L

<FRAME SRC="controls.htm"L

<FRAME SRC="content.htm"L

<NOFRAMESL

Sorry, this browser does not support frames<

</NOFRAMESL

</FRAMESETL

Compatibilit

HTML 4 (transitional)

Internet Explorer 2, 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

WebTV

Note“

  This element should be used within the scope of thk  <FRAMESE    elementì

  The benefit of events and sophisticated attributes such a—  STYL¨  is unclear for browser—

that would use content withi-  <NOFRAMES    , given that older browsers that don’š

support frames would probably not support these featuresì

<NOSCRIPT>   (No Script Support Content)

This element is used to enclose content that should be rendered on browsers that do not supporš

scripting or that have scripting turned offì

Event Handler“

As defined in the preliminary specification of HTML 4, the benefits of event handlers are noš

very obvious, considering that content within thk  <NOSCRIPT  element assumes the browseK

 = Page 853 =

83p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

does not support scripting, while the script handlers themselves are for browsers that supporš

scripting. These are standard events for nearly all HTML 4 elements. For definitions, see “Event—

Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Exampls

Last Updated:

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JAVASCRIPT"L

<!-- document.writeln(document.lastodified); // --L

</SCRIPTL

<NOSCRIPTL

1999

</NOSCRIPTL

Note“

Improved functionality for thk  <NOSCRIPT  element may come if it is extended to deal wit—

the lack of support for one scripting language or another. Currently, the element is used onl_

to indicate if any scripting is supported or not. It is also useful to “comment out” scriptiný

information so no™scriptinaware browsers will not read itì

<OBJECT>   (Embedded Object)

This element specifies an arbitrary object to be included into an HTML document. Initially, thi—

element was used to insert ActiveX controls, but according to the HTML 4.0 specification, a-

object may be any media object, document, applet, ActiveX control, or even imageì
