83  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Attribute“

ACCESSKEY  This Microsoft attribute specifies a keyboard navigation accelerator for thk

element. Pressiný  AL¾  or a similar key in association with the specified character selects the for“

control correlated with that key sequence. Page designers are forewarned to avoid key sequence—

already bound to browsersì

ALqN  This attribute aligns the object with respect to the surrounding text. The default i—

LEF  . The HTML 4.0 specification define—  BOTTOV MIDDL¨ RIGH  ,  ,  , an™  TOL  as wellì

Browsers may provide an even richer set of alignment values. The behavior of alignment foK

objects is similar to images. Under the strict HTML 4.0 specification, thk  <OBJECT  elemenš

does not support this attributeì

ARCHIVE  This attribute contains a URL for the location of an archive file. An archive file i—

typically used to contain multiple object files to improve the efficiency of accessì

BORDER  This attribute specifies the width of the object’s borders in pixels or as a percentageì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

CLASSID  This attribute contains a URL for an object’s implementation. The URL syntax

depends upon the object’s type. With ActiveX controls, the value of this attribute does noš

appear to be a URL but something of the for“  CLSID: object-i  ; for example,  CLSID:

99B42120-6EC7-11CF-A6C7-00AA00A47DD2  ì

CODE  U-™eK thk ol™ Microsofš implementation, thi— attributk contain— thk URL referenciný ¾

Jav¾ appleš clas— fileì Thk wa_ tf acces— ¾ Jav¾ appleš undeK thk HTML 4.0 specificatio- i— tf usk

<OBJEC CLASSID="javax classname.class"  :  ì Thk pseudf URL  java:  i— use™ tf indicatk ¾ Jav¾

appletì Microsofš Interneš ExploreK 4 an™ beyon™ supporš thi— style, sf  COD¨  shoul™ noš bk usedì

CODEBASE  This attribute contains a URL to use as a relative base to access the objecš

specified by thk  CLASSI¤  attributeì

CODETYPE  ¾hi— attributk specifie— a- object’— MIME typeì Df noš confusk thi— attributk wit—  TYP¨  ,

whic— specifie— thk MIME typk o“ thk dat¾ thk objecš ma_ usk a— define™ b_ thk  DATG  attributeì

DAT  This attribute contains a URL for data required by an objectì

DATAFLD  This attribute is used to indicate the column name in the data source that is boun™

to thk  <OBJECT  elementì

DATASRC  The value of this attribute is set to an identifier indicating the data source tf

pull data fromì

DECLARE  This attribute declares an object without instantiating it. This is useful when thk

object will be a parameter to another objectì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

 = Page 856 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  83

HEqHT  This attribute specifies the height of the object in pixels or as a percentage of thk

enclosing windowì

HSPACE  This attribute indicates the horizontal space in pixels or percentages between thk

object and surrounding contentì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  In the Microsoft implementation, this attribute specifies the scripting languagk

to be used with an associated script bound to the element, typically through an event handleK  APPENDIXES

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  , an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

values that include the version of the language used, such a—  JavaScript1.1  , may also be possibleì

NAME  This attribute under the Microsoft definition defines the name of the control sf

scripting can access it. The HTML 4.0 specification suggests that it is a name for for“

submission, but this meaning is unclear and not supported by browsersì

STAND  This attribute contains a text message to be displayed while the object is loadingì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TABINDEX  This attribute takes a numeric value indicating the position of the object in thk

tabbing index for the document. Tabbing proceeds from the lowest positivk  TABINDEX  value tf

the highest. Negative values foK  TABINDEX  will leave the object out of the tabbing order. Whe-

tabbing is not explicitly set, the browser may tab through items in the order they ark

encounteredì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TYPE  This attribute specifies the MIME type for the object’s data. This is different from thk

CODETYP¨  , which is the MIME type of the object and not the data it usesì

USEMAV  This attribute contains the URL of the image map to be used with the objectì

Typically, the URL is a fragment identifier referencing ¾  <MAP  element somewherk

else within the file. The presence of this attribute indicates that the type of object beiný

included is an imageì

VSPACE  This attribute indicates the vertical space in pixels or percentages between the objecš

and surrounding textì

WIDTH  This attribute specifies the width of the object in pixels or as a percentage of thk

enclosing windowì

Note“

  Under the strict HTML 4.0 specification thk  <OBJECT  element loses most of it—

presentation attributes, includiný  ALIGN BORDE HEIGH HSPAC¨ VSPAC¨  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

an™  WIDTh  . These attributes are replaced by style sheet rulesì

  The HTML 4.0 specification reserves thk  DATAFL¤ DATAFORMATAS  ,  , an™

DATASR‚  attributes for future useì

  Alternative content should be defined within thk  <OBJECT  element after thk

<PARAM  elementsì

  Thk  <OBJECT  element is still mainly used to include binaries in pages. While thk

APPENDIXES

specification defines that it can load in HTML files and create image maps, few, if any,

browsers support thisì

<OL>   (Ordered List)

This element is used to define an ordered or numbered list of items. The numbering style come—

in many forms, including letters, Roman numerals, and regular numerals. The individual item—

within the list are specified b_  <LI  elements included with thk  <OL  elementì

Synta¨

Attribute“

COMPACT  This attribute indicates that the list should be rendered in a compact style. Feu

browsers actually change the rendering of the list regardless of the presence of this attribute. Thk

COMPAC  attribute requires no valueì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  In the Microsoft implementation, this attribute specifies the scripting languagk

to be used with an associated script bound to the element, typically through an event handleK

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  , an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

values that include the version of the language used, such a—  JavaScript1.1  , may also be possibleì

START  This attribute is used to indicate the value to start numbering the individual list item—

from. While the ordering type of list elements may be Roman numerals such as XXXI or letters,

the value o“  STAR  is always represented as a number. To start numbering elements from thk

letter “C,” usk  <OL TYPE="A" START="3"  ì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TYPE  This attribute indicates the numbering type: “a” indicates lowercase letters, “A”

indicates uppercase letters, “i” indicates lowercase Roman numerals, “I” indicates uppercask

Roman numerals, and “1” indicates numbers. Type set in thk  <OL  element is used for the entirk

list unless ¾  TYP¨  attribute is used within an enclose™  <LI  elementì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   ALIGN CLASS I¤ LAN…  . (  ,  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are implied.)

INTERNET EXPLORER   All attributes and events excepš  DI  . (Note: Thk  JUSTIF  valuk

foK  ALIGN  is not supported by Internet Explorer 4.)

APPENDIXES

WEBTV  ALIGN (CENTE | LEF | RIGHT)  ì

Event Handler“

See “Events Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Example“

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"L  A right-aligned paragrap—  </PL

<P ID="Para1" CLASS="defaultParagraphh

TITLE="Introduction Paragraph"L

This is the introductory paragraph for a very long paper about nothing<

</PL

Compatibilit

HTML 2, 3.2, and 4

Internet Explorer 2, 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 1, 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

Web TV

Note“

  Under the strict HTML 4.0 specification thk  ALIGN  attribute is not supportedì

Alignment of text can be accomplished using style sheetsì

  The closing tag for thk  <P  element is optionalì

  As a logical element, empty paragraphs are ignored by browsers, so do not try to usk

multiplk  <P  elements in a row likk  <P><P><P><P  to add blank lines to a Web pageì

This will not work; use thk  <BR  element insteadì

  The HTML 3.2 specification supports only thk  ALIGN  attribute with values o“  CENTE  ,

LEF  , an™  RIGH  ì

  The HTML 2.0 specification supports no attributes for thk  <P  elementì

 = Page 867 =

84‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<PARAM>   (Object Parameter)

This element specifies a parameter to pass to an embedded object using thk  <OBJECT  oK

<APPLET  element. This element should occur only within the scope of one of these elementsì

Synta¨

<PARAM

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

NAME="parameter name"

TYPE="MIME Type"

VALUE="parameter value"

VALUETYPE="DATA | OBJECT | REF">

</PARAM>

Attributes Defined by Internet Explorer 

DATAFLD="column name"

DATAFORMATAS="HTML | TEXT"

DATASRC="data source ID"

Attribute“

DATAFLD  This Internet Explorer–specific attribute is used to indicate the column name in thk

data source that is bound to thk  <PARAM  element’s valueì

DATAFORMATAS  This Internet Explorer–specific attribute indicates if the bound data is plai-

text (  TEX  ) or HTML (  HTML  )ì

DATASRC  The value of this attribute is set to an identifier indicating the data source to pulR

data from. Bound data is used to set the value of the parameters passed to the object or appleš

with which thi—  <PARAM  element is associatedì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

NAME  This attribute contains the parameter’s name. The name of the parameter depends o-

the particular object being inserted into the page, and it is assumed that the object knows how tf

handle the passed data. Do not confuse thk  NAM¨  attribute with thk  NAM¨  attribute used foK

form elements. In the latter case, thk  NAM¨  attribute does not have a similar meaning a—  I¤  , buš

rather specifies the name of the data to be passed to an enclosiný  <OBJECT  elementì

TYPE  When thk  VALUETYP¨  attribute is set tf  REF  , thk  TYP¨  attribute can be used tf

indicate the type of the information to be retrieved. Legal values for this attribute are in the for“

of MIME types such a—  text/htm“  ì

 = Page 868 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  84

VALUE  This attribute contains the parameter’s value. The actual contents of this attributk

depend on the object and the particular parameter being passed in, as determined by thk

NAM¨  attributeì

VALUETYPE  This HTML 4–specific attribute specifies the type of thk  VALU¨  attribute beiný

passed in. Possible values for this attribute includk  DATG OBJEC  ,  , an™  REF  . A value o“  DATG

specifies that the information passed in through thk  VALU¨  parameter should be treated just a—

data. A value o“  REF  indicates that the information being passed in is a URL that indicates wherk

the data to use is located. The information is not retrieved, but the URL is passed to the objecš

which may then retrieve the information if necessary. The last value o“  OBJEC  indicates thaš

the value being passed in is the name of an object as set by it—  I¤  attribute. In practice, thk  DATG

APPENDIXES

attribute is used by defaultì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   NAM¨  an™  VALU¨ I¤  . (  may be implied.)

INTERNET EXPLORER   NAM¨ DATAFL¤ DATAFORMATAS DATASR‚  ,  ,  ,  , an™

VALU¨  ì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Example“

<APPLET CODE="plot.class"L

<PARAM NAME="min" VALUE="5"L

<PARAM NAME="max" VALUE="30"L

<PARAM NAME="ticks" VALUE=".5"L

<PARAM NAME="line-style" VALUE="dotted"L

</APPLETL

<OBJECT CLASSID="clsid:27CDB6E-AE6D-11cf-96B8-444553540000h

CODEBASE="swflash.cab#version=2,0,0,0h

HEIGHT="100" WIDTH="100"L

<PARAM ID="param1" NAME="Movie" VALUE="SplashLogo.swf"L

<PARAM ID="param2" NAME="Play" VALUE="True"L

</OBJECTL

elementì

<PLAINTEXT>   (Plain Text)

This deprecated element from the HTML 2.0 specification renders the enclosed text as plain texš

and forces the browser to ignore any enclosed HTML. Typically, information affected by thk

<PLAINTEXT  element is rendered in monospaced font. This element is no longer part of thk

HTML standardì

Syntax (HTML 2; Deprecated Under HTML 4)

<PLAINTEXT>

the starting tagì

and information can be inserted in a preformatted fashion using thk  <PRE  elementì

<PRE>   (Preformatted Text)

This element is used to indicate that the enclosed text is preformatted, meaning that spaces,

returns, tabs, and other formatting characters are preserved. Browsers do, however,

acknowledge most HTML elements that are found with thk  <PRE  element. Preformatte™

text is generally rendered by the browsers in a monospaced fontì

Synta¨

<PRE

CLASS="class name(s)"

DIR="LTR | RTL"

ID="unique alphanumeric value"

LANG="language code"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text"

WIDTH="number" (transitional)

onclick="script"

ondblclick="script"

onkeydown="script"

onkeypress="script"

onkeyup="script"

onmousedown="script"

onmousemove="script"

onmouseout="script"

onmouseover="script"

onmouseup="script">

</PRE>

Attributes and Events Defined by Internet Explorer 

LANGUAGE="JAVASCRIPT | JSCRIPT | VBS | VBSCRIPT"

ondragstart="script"

onhelp="script"

onselectstart="script"

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  , an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

supported and is dropped under the strict HTML 4.0 specificationì

Compatibilit

WebTV

Note“

  The HTML 4.0 transitional specification states that thk  <APPLET <BASEFONT  ,  ,

<BIG <FONT <IMG <OBJECT <SMALL <SUB  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  <SUP  element—

should not be used within thk  <PRE  element. The strict HTML 4.0 specification state—

 = Page 873 =

85p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

that only thk  <BIG <IMG <OBJECT <SMALL <SUB  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  <SUP  element—

should not be used within thk  <PRE  element. The other excluded elements are missing,

as they are deprecated from the strict specification. While these attributes should not bk

used, it appears that the two most popular browsers render them anywayì

  The strict HTML 4.0 specification drops support for thk  WIDTh  attribute, which wa—

not generally supported anywayì

  The HTML 2.0 and 3.2 specifications support only thk  WIDTh  attribute foK  <PRE  ì

<SCRIPT>   (Scripting)

This element encloses statements in a scripting language for clienâside processing. Scriptiný

statements can either be included inline or loaded from an external file and may be commente™

out to avoid execution by no™scriptinaware browsersì

Synta¨

<SCRIP

CHARSET="character set"

DEFER

EVENT="event name" (reserved)

FOR="element ID" (reserved)

LANGUAGE="scripting language name"

SRC="URL of script code"

TYPE="MIME type">

</SCRIPT>

 = Page 879 =

858  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Attributes Defined by Internet Explorer 

CLASS="class name(s)"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

TITLE="advisory text"

Attribute“

CHARSET  This attribute defines the character encoding of the script. The value is a spac[

and/or commDdelimited list of character sets as defined in RFC 2045. The default value i—

ISO-8859-1  ì

CLASS  This Microsofâdefined attribute does not make much sense given that scripting codk

would not be bound by style sheet rules. Its meaning as defined in the “Core Attribute—

Reference” in this appendix is unclear within the context of thk  <SCRIPT  elementì

DEFER  The presence of this attribute indicates that the browser may defer execution of thk

script enclosed by thk  <SCRIPT  element. In practice, deferring code may be more up to thk

position of thk  <SCRIPT  element or the contents. This attribute was added very late to thk

HTML 4.0 specification and its support is currently minimalì

EVENT  This Microsoft attribute is used to define a particular event that the script should reacš

to. It must be used in conjunction with thk  FO  attribute. Event names are the same as evenš

handler attributes, for example,  onclick ondblclick  ,  , and so onì

FOR  Thk  FO  attribute is used to define the name or ID of the element to which an evenš

defined by thk  EVEN  attribute is related. For example,  <SCRIPT EVENT="onclick"

FOR="button1" LANGUAGE="VBSCRIPT"  defines a VBScript that executes when a click

event is issued for an element name™  button1  ì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  This attribute specifies the scripting language being used. The Netscapk

implementation supports JavaScript. The Microsoft implementation supports JScript (¾

JavaScript clone) as well as VBScript, which can be indicated by eitheK  VBS  oK  VBSCRIP  ì

Other values that include the version of the language used, such a—  JavaScript1.1  an™

JavaScript1.2  , may also be possible and are useful to exclude browsers from executing scripš

code that is not supportedì

SRC  This attribute specifies the URL of a file containing scripting code. Typically, file—

containing JavaScript code have a .js extension, and a server attaches the appropriate MIME type;

if not, thk  TYP¨  attribute may be used to explicitly set the content type of the external script fileì

Thk  LANGUAG¨  attribute may also be helpful in determining thisì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

 = Page 880 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  859

TYPE  This attribute should be set to the MIME type corresponding to the scripting languagk

used. For JavaScript, for example, this would bk  text/javascript  . In practice, thk  LANGUAG¨

attribute is the more common way to indicate which scripting language is in effectì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   LANGUAG¨  an™  SR‚  ì

INTERNET EXPLORER   All attributes and events excepš  CHARSE  an™  DEFE  ì

WEBTV  LANGUAG¨  an™  SR‚  ì

APPENDIXES

Event Handler“

There are no events directly associated with thk  <SCRIPT  element. However, the Microsofš

implementation does allow thk  EVEN  attribute to be used to indicate what event a particulaK

script may be associated withì

Example“

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-- alert("Hello World !!!"); // --L

</SCRIPTL

<!-- code in external file --L

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript1¨" SRC="superrollover.js"L

</SCRIPTL

<SCRIPT FOR="myButton" EVENT="onclickh

LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-- alert("I've been clicked!"); // --L

</SCRIPTL

<FORML

<INPUT TYPE="BUTTON" NAME="myButton" VALUE="Click me"L

</FORML

Compatibilit

HTML 4

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 2, 3, 4, and 4.5

Note“

  It is common practice to “comment out” statements enclosed by thk  <SCRIPT  elementì

Without commenting, scripts are displayed as page content by browsers that do noš

support scripting. The particular comment style may be dependent on the languagk

being used. For example, in JavaScript use the following styleì

 = Page 881 =

860  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="JÆaScript"L

<!-- JÆaScript code here // -p  L

</SCRIPTL

and in VBScript usk

<SCRIPT LANGUAGE="VBSCRIPT"L

<!-- VBScript code here // --L

</SCRIPTL

  The HTML 3.2 specification defined a placeholdeK  <SCRIPT  element, but otherwisk

the element is new to HTML 4ì

  Refer to thk  <NOSCRIPT  element in this appendix to see how content may bk

identified for no™scriptinaware browsersì

<SELECT>   (Selection List)

onmouseup="script">

<OPTION> element?

Attributes and Events Defined by Internet Explorer 

ACCESSKEY="character"  APPENDIXES

Attributes Defined by WebTV

AUTOACTIVATE

BGCOLOR="color name | #RRGGBB"

EXCLUSIVE

SELCOLOR="color name | #RRGGBB"

TEXT="color name | #RRGGBB"

USESTYLE

Attribute“

ACCESSKEY  This Microsoft attribute specifies a keyboard navigation accelerator for thk

element. Pressiný  AL¾  or a similar key in association with the specified character selects the for“

control correlated with that key sequence. Page designers are forewarned to avoid key sequence—

already bound to browsersì

ALqN  This Microsofâspecific attribute controls the alignment of the image with respect tf

the content on the page. The default value i—  LEF  , but other values such a—  ABSBOTTOV  ,

ABSMIDDL¨ BASELIN¨ BOTTOV MIDDL¨ RIGH TEXTTOL  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  TOL  may also bk

supported. The meaning of these values should be similar to inserted objects such as imagesì

 = Page 883 =

86p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

AUTOACTIVATE  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute causes the selection list controR

to immediately activate when the user selects it, allowing the user to quickly use the arrow key—

to move up and down. Without this attribute, the process is a twkstep procedure to select thk

control and then move aroundì

COLOR  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute specifies the background color of thk

selection list. The value for this attribute can be either a named color, such a—  red  , or a coloK

specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #FF0000  ì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DATAFLD  This attribute is used to indicate the column name in the data source that is boun™

to the options in thk  <SELECT  elementì

DATASRC  The value of this attribute is set to an identifier indicating the data source tf

pull data fromì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DISABLED  This attribute is used to turn off a form control so that elements will not bk

submitted, and will not receive any focus from the keyboard or mouse. Disabled form control—

will not be part of the tabbing order. The browser may also gray out the form that is disabled, i-

order to indicate to the user that the form control is inactive. This attribute requires no valueì

EXCLUSIVE  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute prevents duplicate entries in thk

selection list. The attribute requires no valueì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  In the Microsoft implementation, this attribute specifies the scripting languagk

to be used with an associated script bound to the element, typically through an event handleK

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  , an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

values that include the version of the language used, such a—  JavaScript1.1  , may also be possibleì

MULTIPLE  This attribute allows the selection of multiple items in the selection list. Thk

default is singl[item selectionì

NAME  This attribute allows a form control to be assigned a name so that it can be reference™

by a scripting languageì  NAM¨  is supported by older browsers such as Netscape 2-generatio-

browsers, but the W3C encourages the use of thk  I¤  attribute. For compatibility purposes bot—

may have to be usedì

SELCOLOR  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute specifies the background coloK

for selected items. Its value can be either a named color, such a—  green  , or a color specifie™

in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #00FF00  . The default for this attribute in WebTV

i—  #EAEAEG  ì

 = Page 884 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  86

SIZE  This attribute sets the number of visible items in the selection list. When thk  MULTIPL¨

attribute is not present, only one entry should show; however, whe-  MULTIPL¨  is present, thi—

attribute is useful to set the size of the scrolling list boxì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TABINDEX  This attribute takes a numeric value indicating the position of the form control i-

the tabbing index for the form. Tabbing proceeds from the lowest positivk  TABINDEX  value tf

the highest. Negative values foK  TABINDEX  will leave the form control out of the tabbing orderì

When tabbing is not explicitly set, the browser may tab through items in the order they ark

encountered. Form controls that are disabled due to the presence of thk  DISABLE¤  attributk

APPENDIXES

will not be part of the tabbing index, though reaÙonly controls will beì

TEXT  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute specifies the text color for items in the listì

Its value can be either a named color, such a—  blu2  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR

#RRGGBB  format, such a—  #0000FF  ì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

USESTYLE  This WebTV-specific attribute causes text to be rendered in the style in effect foK

the page. The attribute requires no valueì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   MULTIPL¨ NAM¨ SIZ¨ onblu( onchang2  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  onfocu— CLASS I¤  . (  ,  ,

LAN…  , an™  STYL¨  are implied.)

INTERNET EXPLORER   All W3C-defined attributes and events excepš  DI  an™  TITL¨  , an™

all attributes and events defined by Internet Explorer 4ì

USESTYL¨ onblu( onchang2 onfocu—  ,  ,  ,  , an™  onclick  ì

Note“

  Thk  <SMALL  element can be used multiple times to decrease the size of text to ¾

greater degree. Using more than six  <SMALL  elements together doesn’t make sense,

since browsers currently only support relative font sizes from 1 to 7. As style sheet—

become more common, this element may fall out of favorì

  The default base font size for a document is typically 3, although it can be changed wit—

thk  <BASEFONT  elementì

<SPACER>   (Extra Space)

This proprietary element specifies an invisible region for pushing content around a pageì

Syntax (Defined by Netscape 3)

<SPACER

ALIGN="ABSMIDDLE | ABSBOTTOM | BASELINE | BOTTOM |

LEFT | MIDDLE | RIGHT | TEXTTOP | TOP"

HEIGHT="pixels"

SIZE="pixels"

TYPE="BLOCK | HORIZONTAL | VERTICAL"

WIDTH="pixels">

Attribute“

ALqN  This attribute specifies the alignment of the spacer with respect to surrounding textì

It is only used with spacers wit—  TYPE="BLOCK"  . The default value for thk  ALIGN  attributk

i—  BOTTOV  . The meanings of thk  ALIGN  values are similar to those used with thk  <IMG

elementì

HEqHT  This attribute specifies the height of the invisible region in pixels. It is only used wit—

spacers wit—  TYPE="BLOCK"  ì

SIZE  Used wit—  TYPE="BLOCK"  an™  TYPE="HORIZONTAL"  spacers, this attribute sets thk

spacer’s width in pixels. Used with ¾  TYPE="VERTICAL"  spacer, this attribute is used to set thk

spacer’s heightì

TYPE  This attribute indicates the type of invisible region. A  HORIZONTAL  spacer add—

horizontal space between words and objects. A  VERTICAL  spacer is used to add space betwee-

lines. A  BLOCK  spacer defines a genera_purpose positioning rectangle like an invisible imagk

that text may flow aroundì

WIDTH  This attribute is used only with thk  TYPE="BLOCK"  spacer and is used to set thk

width of the region in pixelsì

 = Page 888 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  86

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   All attributesì

WEBTV  All attributesì

Example“

A line of text with twB  <SPACER TYPE="HORIZONTAL" SIZE=0"L  word?

separated by 20 pixels. Here is a line of texM  .<BRL

<SPACER TYPE="VERTICAL" SIZE="50"L  APPENDIXES

Here is another line of text with a large space between the twB

lines<  <SPACER ALIGN="LEFT" TYPE="BLOCK" HEIGHT="100" WIDTH="100"L  Thi?

is a bunch of text that flows around an invisible block region. Yo‚

could have easily performed this layout with a table<

Compatibilit

Netscape 3, 4, and 4.5

WebTV

Note“

  This element should not be used. If the effect of this element is required and style sheet—

cannot be used, an invisible pixel trick may be a more appropriate choice. The invisiblk

pixel trick requires a transparent image, which is then resized with thk  HEIGH  an™

WIDTh  attributes of thk  <IMG  element:

<IMG SRC="pixel.gif" HEIGHT="100" WIDTH="100"L

  This is an empty element; no closing tag is allowedì

the content. As it has no preset or rendering meaning, this is the most useful inline element foK

associating style and script with contentì

<STYLE>   (Style Information)

This element is used to surround style sheet rules for a document. This element should be foun™

only in thk  <HEAD  of a document. Style rules within a document’—  <BODY  element shoul™

be set with the style attribute for a particular elementì

Synta¨

<STYLE

DIR="LTR | RTL"

LANG="language code"

MEDIA="ALL | PRINT | SCREEN | others"

TITLE="advisory text"

TYPE="MIME Type">

</STYLE>

Attributes Defined by Internet Explorer 

DISABLED

 = Page 895 =

87  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Attribute“

DIR  This attribute is used to set the text direction of the title for the style sheet, either left tf

right (  LT  ) or right to left (  RTL  )ì

DISABLED  This Microsofâdefined attribute is used to disable a style sheet. The presence o“

the attribute is all that is required to disable the style sheet. In conjunction with scripting, thi—

attribute could be used to turn on and off various style sheets in a documentì

LANG  The value of this attribute is a language code, like all otheK  LAN…  attributes; however,

this attribute defines the language of thk  TITL¨  attribute rather than the content of the elementì

MEDI  This attribute specifies the destination medium for the style information. The value o“

the attribute may be a single media descriptor such a—  SCREEN  or a commDseparated listì

Possible values for this attribute includk  ALL AURAL BRAILL¨ PRIN PROJECTION  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™

SCREEN  . Other values may also be defined, depending on the browser. Internet ExploreK

support—  ALL PRIN  ,  , an™  SCREEN  as values for this attributeì

TITLE  This attribute associates an informational title with the style sheetì

TYPE  This attribute is used to define the type of style sheet. The value of the attribute shoul™

be the MIME type of the style sheet language used. The most common current value for thi—

attribute i—  text/cs—  , which indicates a Cascading Style Sheet formatì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   TYP¨  ì

INTERNET EXPLORER   DISABLE¤ MEDIG (ALL | PRINT | SCREEN) TITL¨  ,  ,  , an™

TYP¨  ì

Event Handler“

Noneì

Exampls

<HTMLL

<HEADL

<TITLEL  Style Sheet Exampl4  </TITLEL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

<!-p

BODY {background: black; color: white; font: 12pt Helvetica}

H1   {color: red; font: 14pt Impact}

--L

 = Page 896 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  87

</STYLEL

</HEADL

<BODYL

<H1L  A 14-point red Impact heading on a black background  </H1L

Regular body text, which is 12 point white Helvetic:

</BODYL

</HTMLL

APPENDIXES

Compatibilit

Note“

  Style information can also be specified in external style sheets, as defined by thk

<LINK  elementì

  Style information can also be associated with a particular element using thk  STYL¨

attributeì

  Style rules are generally commented out within thk  <STYLE  element to avoi™

interpretation by nonconforming browsersì

Exampls

Here is som4  <SUBL  subscripted  </SUBL  text<

Note“

<SUP>   (Superscript)

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  , an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

<TABLE>   (Table)

This element is used to define a table. Tables are used to organize data as well as to providk

structure for laying out pagesì

Synta¨

<TABLE  APPENDIXES

ALIGN="CENTER | LEFT | RIGHT" (transitional)

BGCOLOR="color name | #RRGGBB" (transitional)

BORDER="pixels"

CELLPADDING="pixels"

CELLSPACING="pixels"

CLASS="class name(s)"

DATAPAGESIZE="number of records to display"

DIR="LTR | RTL"

FRAME="ABOVE | BELOW | BORDER | BOX | HSIDES |

LHS | RHS | VOID | VSIDES"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LANG="language code"

RULES="ALL | COLS | GROUPS | NONE | ROWS"

STYLE="style information"

SUMMARY="summary information"

TITLE="advisory text"

WIDTH="percentage | pixels"

onmouseover="script"

Attributes Defined by WebTV

ALIGN="BLEEDLEFT | BLEEDRIGHT | JUSTIFY"

BACKGROUND="URL of image file"

CELLBORDER="pixels"

GRADANGLE="gradient angle"

GRADCOLOR="color value"

HREF="URL"

HSPACE="pixels"

NAME="string"

NOWRA

TRANSPARENCY="number (0-100)"

VSPACE="pixels"

Attribute“

ALqN  This attribute specifies the alignment of the table with respect to surrounding text. Thk

HTML 4.0 specification define—  CENTE LEF  ,  , an™  RIGH  . WebTV also define—  BLEEDLEF

an™  BLEEDRIGH  , which cause the table to bleed over the right and left margins of the page,

 = Page 902 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  88h

an™  JUSTIF  , which is used to justify the table within the browser window. Some browsers ma_

also support alignment values, such a—  ABSMIDDL¨  , that are common to block objectsì

BACKGROUND  This nonstandard attribute, which is supported by Internet Explorer,

Netscape, and WebTV, specifies the URL of a background image for the table. The image is tile™

if it is smaller than the table dimensions. Netscape displays the background image in each tablk

cell, rather than behind the complete table as Internet Explorer doesì

COLOR  This attribute specifies a background color for a table. Its value can be eitheK

a named color, such a—  red  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, suc—

a—  #FF0000  ì

APPENDIXES

BORDER  This attribute specifies in pixels the width of a table’s borders. A value o“ makes ¾  0

borderless table, which is useful for graphic layoutì

BORDERCOLOR  This attribute, supported by Internet Explorer 4 and Netscape 4, is used tf

set the border color for a table. The attribute should only be used with a positive value for thk

BORDE  attribute. The value of the attribute can be either a named color, such a—  green  , or ¾

color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #00FF00  . Internet Explorer color—

the entire table border, including cell borders; Netscape only colors the outer border of the tableì

BORDERCOLORDARK  This Internet Explorer–specific attribute specifies the darker of twf

border colors used to create a thre[dimensional effect for cell borders. It must be used with thk

BORDE  attribute set to a positive value. The attribute value can be either a named color, suc—

a—  blu2  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #00FF00  ì

BORDERCOLORLqHT  This Internet Explorer–specific attribute specifies the lighter of twf

border colors used to create a thre[dimensional effect for cell borders. It must be used with thk

BORDE  attribute set to a positive value. The attribute value can be either a named color, suc—

a—  red  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #FF0000  ì

CELLBORDER  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute sets the width in pixels of thk

border between table cells. If this value is not present, the default border as specified by thk

BORDE  attribute is usedì

CELLPADDING  This attribute sets the width in pixels between the edge of a cell an™

its contentì

CELLSPACING  This attribute sets the width in pixels between individual cellsì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

COLS  This attribute specifies the number of columns in the table and is used to help quickl_

calculate the size of the table. This attribute was part of the preliminary specification of HTML 4,

but was later dropped. A few browsers, notably Netscape 4, already support itì

DATAPSIZE  The value of this Microsofâspecific attribute is the number of records thaš

can be displayed in the table when data binding is usedì

 = Page 903 =

88p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

DATASRC  The value of this Microsofâspecific attribute is an identifier indicating the dat¾

source to pull data fromì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

FRAME  This attribute specifies which edges of a table are to display a border frame. A valuk

o“  ABOV¨  indicates only the top edge;  BELOW  indicates only the bottom edge; an™  BORDE

an™  BOX  indicate all edges, which is the default when thk  BORDE  attribute is a positivk

integer. A value o“  HSIDES  indicates only the top and bottom edges should be displayed;  LHS

indicates the lefâhand edge should be displayed;  RHS  indicates the righâhand edge should bk

displayed;  VSIDES  indicates the left and right edges should both be displayed; an™  VOI¤

indicates no border should be displayedì

GRADANGLE  Thi— WebTV-specifi´ attributk define— thk gradienš anglk foK ¾ table, ranginý fro“

90 tf 90 degreesì  ?  GRADANGLE="0"  yield— ¾ lefâtkrighš gradient, whilk  GRADANGLE="90"

yield— ¾ toštkbotto“ gradientì Thk beginniný coloK o“ thk gradienš i— define™ b_ thk  BGCOLO

attribute, an™ thk endiný coloK i— define™ b_ thk  GRADCOLO  attributeì

GRADCOLOR  This WebTV-specific attribute defines the end color of a table’s backgroun™

gradient, in conjunction with the gradient angle defined by thk  GRADANGL¨  attribute and thk

starting color defined by thk  BGCOLO  attributeì

HEqHT  For Netscape 4, this attribute allows the author to specify the height of the table i-

pixels. Internet Explorer 4 allows both pixels and percentagesì

HREF  This WebTV-specific attribute is used to make the entire table function as a hyperlink

anchor to the specified URLì

HSPACE  This Netscap[specified attribute indicates the horizontal space in pixels betwee-

the table and surrounding content. This attribute is also supported by WebTV but, oddly, not b_

Internet Explorerì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  In the Microsoft implementation, this attribute specifies the scripting languagk

to be used with an associated script bound to the element, typically through an event handleK

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  , an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

values that include the version of the language used, such a—  JavaScript1.1  , may also be possibleì

NAME  This WebTV attribute is used to assign the table a unique name. It is synonymous wit—

thk  I¤  attributeì

NOWRAV  This WebTV-specific attribute keeps table rows from wrapping if they exten™

beyond the right margin. The attribute requires no valueì

RULES  This attribute controls the display of dividing rules within a table. A value o“  ALL

specifies dividing rules for rows and columns. A value o“  COLS  specifies dividing rules foK

 = Page 904 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  88

columns only. A value o“  GROUPS  specifies horizontal dividing rules between groups of tablk

cells defined by thk  <THEAD <TBODY <TFOOT  ,  ,  , oK  <COLGROUP  elements. A value o“

ROWS  specifies dividing rules for rows only. A value o“  NON¨  indicates no dividing rules an™

is the defaultì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

SUMMARY  This attribute is used to provide a text summary of the table’s purpose an™

structure. This element is used for accessibility, and its presence is important for nonvisuaR

user agentsì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì  APPENDIXES

TRANSPARENCY  This WebTV-specific attribute specifies the degree of transparency of thk

table. Values range fro“  0  (totally opaque) tf  100  (totally transparent). A value o“  50  is optimize™

for fast renderingì

VSPACE  This Netscape attribute indicates the vertical space in pixels between the tablk

and surrounding content. This attribute is also supported by WebTV but, oddly, not b_

Internet Explorerì

WIDTH  This attribute specifies the width of the table either in pixels or as a percentage valuk

of the enclosing windowì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   ALIGN (LEFT | RIGHT) BGCOLO BORDE CELLPADDIN…  ,  ,  ,  ,

CELLSPACIN… COLS HEIGH HSPAC¨ VSPAC¨  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  WIDTh CLASS I¤ LAN…  . (  ,  ,  ,

an™  STYL¨  are implied.)

SUMMAR  , and all attributes and events defined by Internet Explorer 4ì

WEBTV  ALIGN (BLEEDLEFT | BLEEDRIGHT | CENTER | LEFT | RIGHT)  ,

BACKGROUN¤ BGCOLO BORDE CELLPADDIN… CELLSPACIN…  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

GRADANGL¨ GRADCOLO HSPAC¨ I¤ NOWRAL TRANSPARENC  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

an™  WIDTh  ì

Note“

  In addition to displaying tabular data, tables are used to support graphic layout an™

designì

  The HTML 4.0 specification reserves the future use of thk  DATAFL¤  ,

DATAFORMATAS  , an™  DATASR‚  attributes for thk  <TABLE  elementì

  The HTML 3.2 specification defines only thk  ALIGN BORDE CELLPADDIN…  ,  ,  ,

CELLSPACIN…  , an™  WIDTh  attributes for thk  <TABLE  elementì  APPENDIXES

  Thk  COLS  attribute may provide an undesirable result under Netscape, whic—

assumes the size of each column in the table is exactly the sameì

<TBODY>   (Table Body)

This element is used to group the rows within the body of a table so that common alignment an™

style defaults can be set easily for numerous cellsì

Synta¨

<TBODY  ALIGN="CENTER | CHAR | JUSTIFY | LEFT | RIGHT"

CHAR="character"

CHAROFF="offset"

CLASS="class name(s)"

DIR="LTR | RTL"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LANG="language code"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text"

VALIGN="BASELINE | BOTTOM | MIDDLE | TOP"

ondblclick="script"

onkeydown="script"

onkeypress="script"

onkeyup="script"

onmousedown="script"

Attribute“

ALqN  This attribute is used to align the contents of the cells within thk  <TBODY  elementì

Common values ark  CENTE JUSTIF LEF  ,  ,  , an™  RIGH  . The HTML 4.0 specification alsf

defines a value o“  CHA  . Whe-  ALIGN  is set tf  CHA  , the attributk  CHA  must be presenš

and set to the character to which cells should be aligned. A common use of this approach woul™

be to set cells to align on a decimal pointì

COLOR  This attribute specifies a background color for the cells within thk  <TBODY

element. Its value can be either a named color, such a—  red  , or a color specified in thk

hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #FF0000  ì

CHAR  This attribute is used to define the character to which element contents are aligne™

when thk  ALIGN  attribute is set to thk  CHA  valueì

CHAROFF  This attribute contains an offset as a positive or negative integer to align character—

as related to thk  CHA  value. A value o“ , for example, would align characters in a cell twf  2

characters to the right of the character defined by thk  CHA  attributeì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  In the Microsoft implementation, this attribute specifies the scripting languagk

to be used with an associated script bound to the element, typically through an event handleK

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  , an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

values that include the version of the language used, such a—  JavaScript1.1  , may also be possibleì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

 = Page 908 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  88

VALqN  This attribute is used to set the vertical alignment for the table cells with thk

<TBODY  element. HTML 4 define—  BASELIN¨ BOTTOV MIDDL¨  ,  ,  , an™  TOL  . Interneš

Explorer replace—  MIDDL¨  wit—  CENTE  ; the effect should be the sameì

Attribute and Event Suppor

INTERNET EXPLORER   All W3C-defined attributes and events excepš  CHA CHAROFF  ,  ,

an™  DI  . (Note: Internet Explorer 4 does not support thk  CHA  an™  JUSTIF  values foK

ALIGN  , nor thk  MIDDL¨  value foK  VALIGN  .)

Note“

This element is contained by thk  <TABLE  element and contains one or more table rows a—

indicated by thk  <TR  elementì

<TD>   (Table Data)

This element specifies a data cell in a table. The element should occur within a table row, a—

defined by thk  <TR  elementì

Synta¨

<TD

ABBR="abbreviation"

ALIGN="CENTER | JUSTIFY | LEFT | RIGHT"

AXIS="group name"

BGCOLOR="color name | #RRGGBB" (transitional)

CHAROFF="offset"

cells' ID values"

LANG="language code"

NOWRAP (transitional)

Attributes Defined by WebTV

ABSHEIGHT="pixels"

ABSWIDTH="pixels"

BACKGROUND="URL of image file"

GRADANGLE="gradient angle"

GRADCOLOR="color"

MAXLINES="number"

TRANSPARENCY="number (0-100)"

Attribute“

ABBR  The value of this attribute is an abbreviated name for a header cell. This may be usefuR

when attempting to display large tables on small screensì

ABSHEqHT  This WebTV-specific attribute sets the absolute height of a cell in pixels. Contenš

that does not fit within this height is clippedì

 = Page 911 =

890  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

ABSWIDTH  This WebTV-specific attribute sets the absolute width of a cell in pixels. Contenš

that does not fit within this width is clippedì

ALqN  This attribute is used to align the contents of the cells within thk  <TBODY  elementì

Common values ark  CENTE JUSTIF LEF  ,  ,  , an™  RIGH  ì

AXIS  This attribute is used to provide a name for a group of related headersì

BACKGROUND  This nonstandard attribute, which is supported by Internet Explorer,

Netscape and WebTV, specifies the URL of a background image for the table cell. The image i—

tiled if it is smaller than the cell’s dimensionsì

COLOR  This attribute specifies a background color for a table cell. Its value can be eitheK

a named color, such a—  red  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—

#FF0000  . (Netscape Navigator often fails to render a cell with a colored background unless ¾

nonbreaking space, at least, is inserted in the cell.)

BORDERCOLOR  This attribute, supported by Internet Explorer and Netscape, is used to seš

the border color for a table cell. The attribute should only be used with a positive value for thk

BORDE  attribute. The value of the attribute can be either a named color, such a—  green  , or ¾

color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #00FF00  ì

BORDERCOLORDARK  This Internet Explorer–specific attribute specifies the darker of twf

border colors used to create a thre[dimensional effect for a cell’s borders. It must be used wit—

thk  BORDE  attribute set to a positive value. The attribute value can be either a named color,

such a—  blu2  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #00FF00  ì

BORDERCOLORLqHT  This Internet Explorer–specific attribute specifies the lighter of twf

border colors used to create a thre[dimensional effect for a cell’s borders. It must be used wit—

thk  BORDE  attribute set to a positive value. The attribute value can be either a named color,

such a—  red  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #FF0000  ì

CHAR  This attribute is used to define the character to which element contents are aligne™

when thk  ALIGN  attribute is set to thk  CHA  valueì

CHAROFF  This attribute contains an offset as a positive or negative integer to align character—

as related to thk  CHA  value. A value o“ , for example, would align characters in a cell twf  2

characters to the right of the character defined by thk  CHA  attributeì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

COLSPAN  This attribute takes a numeric value that indicates how many columns wide a celR

should be. This is useful to create tables with cells of different widthsì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

GRADANGLE  This WebTV-specific attribute defines the gradient angle for a table cell,

ranging from 90 tf  ?  90 degreesì  GRADANGLE="0"  yields a lefâtkright gradient,

whilk  GRADANGLE="90"  yields a toštkbottom gradient. The beginning color of thk

 = Page 912 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  89h

gradient is defined by thk  BGCOLO  attribute, and the ending color is defined by thk

GRADCOLO  attributeì

GRADCOLOR  This WebTV-specific attribute defines the end color of a table cell’s backgroun™

gradient, in conjunction with the gradient angle defined by thk  GRADANGL¨  attribute and thk

starting color defined by thk  BGCOLO  attributeì

HEADERS  This attribute takes a spac[separated list o“  I¤  values that correspond to thk

header cells related to this cellì

HEqHT  This attribute indicates the height in pixels of the cellì

APPENDIXES

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  In the Microsoft implementation, this attribute specifies the scripting language tf

be used with an associated script bound to the element, typically through an event handleK

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  , an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

values that include the version of the language used, such a—  JavaScript1.1  , may also be possibleì

MAXLINES  This WebTV-specific attribute takes a numeric argument indicating the maximu“

number of content lines to display. Content beyond these lines is clippedì

NOWRAV  This attribute keeps the content within a table cell from automatically wrappingì

ROWSPAN  This attribute takes a numeric value that indicates how many rows high a tablk

cell should span. This attribute is useful in defining tables with cells of different heightsì

SCOPE  This attribute specifies the table cells that the current cell provides header informatio-

for. A value o“  COL  indicates that the cell is a header for the the rest of the column below it. A

value o“  COLGROUL  indicates that the cell is a header for its current column group. A value o“

ROW  indicates that that the cell contains header information for the rest of the row it is in. A

value o“  ROWGROUL  indicates that the cell is a header for its row group. This attribute may bk

used in place of thk  HEADE  attribute and is useful for rendering assistance by nonvisuaR

browsers. This attribute was added very late to the HTML 4.0 specification so support for thi—

attribute is minimalì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TRANSPARENCY  This WebTV-specific attribute specifies the degree of transparency of thk

table cell. Values range fro“  0  (totally opaque) tf  100  (totally transparent). A value o“  50  i—

optimized for fast renderingì

VALqN  This attribute is used to set the vertical alignment for the table cell. HTML 4

define—  BASELIN¨ BOTTOV MIDDL¨  ,  ,  , an™  TOL  . Internet Explorer replace—  MIDDL¨

wit—  CENTE  ; the effect should be the sameì

 = Page 913 =

89p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

WIDTH  This attribute specifies the width of a cell in pixelsì

Attribute and Event Suppor

are implied.)

CHA CHAROFF DI HEADERS  ,  ,  ,  an™  HEIGH  , and all attributes and events defined b_

Internet Explorer 4. (Note: Internet Explorer 4 does not support thk  JUSTIF  value foK  ALIGN  ,

nor thk  MIDDL¨  value foK  VALIGN  .)

Attribute“

ACCESSKEY  This Microsofâspecific attribute specifies a keyboard navigation accelerator foK

the element. Pressiný  AL¾  or a similar key in association with the specified character selects thk

form control correlated with that key sequence. Page designers are forewarned to avoid ke_

sequences already bound to browsersì

 = Page 916 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  89

ALqN  Microsoft defines alignment values for this element. The values for this attributk

should behave similarly to any included object or imageì

ALLCAPS  This WebTV-specific attribute renders all viewe§entered text in capital letters. Thi—

attribute requires no valueì

AUTOACTIVATE  This WebTV-specific attribute causes the text input control to immediatel_

activate. This attribute requires no valueì

AUTOCAPS  This WebTV-specific attribute renders the first letter of all viewe§entered word—

in a capital letter. This attribute requires no valueì

APPENDIXES

COLOR  This WebTV-specific attribute specifies the background color for the text inpuš

area. Its value can be either a named color, such a—  red  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR

#RRGGBB  format, such a—  #FF0000  . The default color for thk  <TEXTAREA  element undeK

WebTV i—  #EAEAEG  ì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

COLS  This attribute sets the width in characters of the text area. The typical default values foK

the size of ¾  <TEXTAREA  element when this attribute is not set i—  20  charactersì

CURSOR  This WebTV-specific attribute is used to indicate the cursor color for the text inpuš

area. Its value can be either a named color, such a—  red  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR

#RRGGBB  format, such a—  #FF0000  . The default value for the cursor color in the WebTV browseK

i—  darkblu2 #3333AG  (  )ì

DATAFLD  This attribute is used to indicate the column name in the data source that is boun™

to the content enclosed by thk  <TEXTAREA  elementì

DATASRC  The value of this attribute is an identifier indicating the data source to pull dat¾

fromì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

DISABLED  This attribute is used to turn off a form control. Elements will not be submitte™

nor may they receive any focus from the keyboard or mouse. Disabled form controls will not bk

part of the tabbing order. The browser may also gray out the form that is disabled, in order tf

indicate to the user that the form control is inactive. This attribute requires no valueì

GROWABLE  This WebTV-specific attribute allows the text input area to expand vertically tf

accommodate extra text entered by the user. This attribute requires no valueì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

 = Page 917 =

89‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

LANGU  In the Microsoft implementation, this attribute specifies the scripting languagk

to be used with an associated script bound to the element, typically through an event handleK

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  , an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

values that include the version of the language used, such a—  JavaScript1.1  , may also be possibleì

NAME  This attribute allows a form control to be assigned a name so that it can be reference™

by a scripting languageì  NAM¨  is supported by older browsers, such as Netscape 2–generatio-

browsers, but the W3C encourages the use of thk  I¤  attribute. For compatibility purposes, bot—

attributes may have to be usedì

NOHARDBREAKS  This WebTV-specific attribute causes a press of thk  ENTER  key to selecš

the next form element rather than causing a line break in the text input area. The attributk

requires no valueì

NOSOFTBREAKS  This attribute removes breaks automatically inserted into the text by link

wrapping when the form is submitted. The attribute requires no valueì

NUMBERS  This WebTV-specific attribute causes the number “1” to be selected in thk

onscreen keyboard in anticipation of the viewer entering a numeric valueì

READON  This attribute prevents the form control’s value from being changed. For“

controls with this attribute set may receive focus from the user but may not be modified. Sinck

they receive focus, ¾  READONL  form control will be part of the form’s tabbing order. Finally,

the control’s value will be sent on form submission. The attribute can only be used wit—

<INPUT  whe-  TYP¨  is set tf  TEX  oK  PASSWOR¤  . The attribute is also used with thk

<TEXTAREA  elementì

ROWS  This attribute sets the number of rows in the text area. The value of the attributk

should be a positive integerì

SHOWKEYBOARD  In the WebTV implementation, this attribute causes the onscree-

keyboard to be displayed when thk  <TEXTAREA  element is selectedì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TABINDEX  This attribute takes a numeric value indicating the position of the form control i-

the tabbing index for the form. Tabbing proceeds from the lowest positivk  TABINDEX  value tf

the highest. Negative values foK  TABINDEX  will leave the form control out of the tabbing orderì

When tabbing is not explicitly set, the browser may tab through items in the order they ark

encountered. Form controls that are disabled due to the presence of thk  DISABLE¤  attributk

will not be part of the tabbing index, though reaÙonly controls will beì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

USESTYLE  This WebTV-specific attribute causes text to be rendered in the style in effect foK

the page. The attribute requires no valueì

WRAV  In Netscape and Microsoft browsers, this attribute controls word wrap behavior. A

value o“  OFF  for the attribute forces thk  <TEXTAREA  not to wrap text, so the viewer musš

 = Page 918 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  89

manually enter line breaks. A value o“  HAR¤  causes word wrap and includes line breaks in texš

submitted to the server. A value o“  SOF  causes word wrap but removes line breaks from texš

submitted to the server. Internet Explorer supports a value o“  PHYSICAL  , which is equivalent tf

Netcape’—  HAR¤  value, and a value o“  VIRTUAL  , which is equivalent to Netscape’—  SOF

value. If thk  WRAL  attribute is not included, text will still wrap under Internet Explorer, buš

under Netscape it will scroll horizontally in the text box. It is always a good idea to include thk

WRAL  attributeì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   COLS NAM¨ ROWS WRAL (HARD | OFF | SOFT) onblu( onchang2  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

APPENDIXES

onfocu—  , an™  onselect CLASS I¤ LAN…  . (  ,  ,  , an™  STYL¨  are implied.)

attributes and events defined by Internet Explorer 4ì

an™  onfocu—  ì

Event Handler“

and set to the character to which cells should be aligned. A common use of this approach woul™

be to set cells to align on a decimal pointì

Attribute“

ABBR  The value of this attribute is an abbreviated name for a header cell. This may be usefuR

when attempting to display large tables on small screensì

ABSHEqHT  This WebTV-specific attribute sets the absolute height of a cell in pixels. Contenš

that does not fit within this height is clippedì

ABSWIDTH  This WebTV-specific attribute sets the absolute width of a cell in pixels. Contenš

that does not fit within this width is clippedì

ALqN  This attribute is used to align the contents of the cells within thk  <TBODY  elementì

Common values ark  CENTE JUSTIF LEF  ,  ,  , an™  RIGH  ì

AXIS  This attribute is used to provide a name for a group of related headersì

BACKGROUND  This nonstandard attribute, which is supported by Internet Explorer,

Netscape and WebTV, specifies the URL of a background image for the table cell. The imagk

is tiled if it is smaller than the cell’s dimensionsì

COLOR  This attribute specifies a background color for a table cell. Its value can bk

either a named color, such as red, or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format,

such a—  #FF0000  ì

BORDERCOLOR  This attribute, supported by Internet Explorer and Netscape, is used to seš

the border color for a table cell. The attribute should only be used with a positive value for thk

BORDE  attribute. The value of the attribute can be either a named color, such a—  green  , or ¾

color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #00FF00  ì

BORDERCOLORDARK  This Internet Explorer–specific attribute specifies the darker of twf

border colors used to create a thre[dimensional effect for a cell’s borders. It must be used wit—

thk  BORDE  attribute set to a positive value. The attribute value can be either a named color,

such a—  blu2  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #00FF00  )ì

BORDERCOLORLqHT  This Internet Explorer–specific attribute specifies the lighter of twf

border colors used to create a thre[dimensional effect for a cell’s borders. It must be used wit—

thk  BORDE  attribute set to a positive value. The attribute value can be either a named color,

such a—  red  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #FF0000  ì

 = Page 924 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  90

CHAR  This attribute is used to define the character to which element contents are aligne™

when thk  ALIGN  attribute is set to thk  CHA  valueì

CHAROFF  This attribute contains an offset as a positive or negative integer to align character—

as related to thk  CHA  value. A value o“ , for example, would align characters in a cell twf  2

characters to the right of the character defined by thk  CHA  attributeì

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

COLSPAN  This attribute takes a numeric value that indicates how many columns wide a celR

should be. This is useful to create tables with cells of different widthsì

APPENDIXES

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

GRADANGLE  This WebTV-specific attribute defines the gradient angle for a tablk

header, ranging from 90 tf  ?  90 degreesì  GRADANGLE="0"  yields a lefâtkright gradient,

whilk  GRADANGLE="90"  yields a toštkbottom gradient. The beginning color of thk

gradient is defined by thk  BGCOLO  attribute, and the ending color is defined by thk

GRADCOLO  attributeì

GRADCOLOR  This WebTV-specific attribute defines the end color of a table header’—

background gradient, in conjunction with the gradient angle defined by thk  GRADANGL¨

attribute and the starting color defined by thk  BGCOLO  attributeì

HEADERS  This attribute takes a spac[separated list o“  I¤  values that correspond to thk

header cells related to this cellì

HEqHT  This attribute indicates the height in pixels of the header cellì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANGU  In the Microsoft implementation, this attribute specifies the scripting languagk

to be used with an associated script bound to the element, typically through an event handleK

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  , an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

values that include the version of the language used, such a—  JavaScript1.1  , may also be possibleì

MAXLINES  This WebTV-specific attribute takes a numeric argument indicating the maximu“

number of content lines to display. Content beyond these lines is clippedì

NOWRAV  This attribute keeps the content within a table header cell from automaticall_

wrappingì

ROWSPAN  This attribute takes a numeric value that indicates how many rows high a tablk

cell should span. This attribute is useful in defining tables with cells of different heightsì

SCOPE  This attribute specifies the table cells that the current cell provides header informatio-

for. A value o“  COL  indicates that the cell is a header for the the rest of the column below it. A

 = Page 925 =

90  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

value o“  COLGROUL  indicates that the cell is a header for its current column group. A value o“

ROW  indicates that that the cell contains header information for the rest of the row it is in. A

value o“  ROWGROUL  indicates that the cell is a header for its row group. This attribute may bk

used in place of thk  HEADE  attribute and is useful for rendering assistance by nonvisuaR

browsers. This attribute was added very late to the HTML 4.0 specification so support for thi—

attribute is minimalì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TRANSPARENCY  This WebTV-specific attribute specifies the degree of transparency of thk

table header. Values range fro“  0  (totally opaque) tf  100  (totally transparent). A value o“  50  i—

optimized for fast renderingì

VALqN  This attribute is used to set the vertical alignment for the table cell. HTML 4 define—

BASELIN¨ BOTTOV MIDDL¨  ,  ,  , an™  TOL  . Internet Explorer further define—  CENTE  , whic—

should act just likk  MIDDL¨  ì

WIDTH  This attribute specifies the width of a header cell in pixelsì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   ALIGN BACKGROUN¤ BGCOLO BORDERCOLO COLSPAN  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

HEIGH NOWRAL ROWSPAN VALIGN  ,  ,  ,  , an™  WIDTh CLASS I¤ LAN…  . (  ,  ,  , an™  STYL¨

are implied.)

INTERNET EXPLORER   ALIGN (CENTER | LEFT | RIGHT) BGCOLO CLASS  ,  ,  ,

COLSPAN I¤ LAN… NOWRAL ROWSPAN STYL¨ TITL¨  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  VALIGN (BASELINE |

BOTTOM | TOP)  , all W3C-defined events, and all attributes and events defined by Interneš

Explorer 4ì

WEBTV  ALIGN (CENTER | LEFT | RIGHT) BGCOLO COLSPAN GRADANGL¨  ,  ,  ,  ,

GRADCOLO NOWRAL ROWSPAN TRANSPARENC VALIGN (BASELINE |  ,  ,  ,  ,

BOTTOM | MIDDLE | TOP)  , an™  WIDTh  ì

Event Handler“

See “Events Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Example“

<TRL

<THL  Name?  </THL

</TRL

APPENDIXES

</TABLEL

<THEAD>   (Table Header)

This element is used to group the rows within the header of a table so that common alignmenš

and style defaults can be set easily for numerous cells. This element may be particularly usefuR

when setting a common head for tables that are dynamically generatedì

Synta¨

<THEAD

ALIGN="CENTER | CHAR | JUSTIFY | LEFT | RIGHT"

CHAR="character"

CHAROFF="offset"

CLASS="class name(s)"

DIR="LTR | RTL"

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

LANG="language code"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text"

VALIGN="CENTER"

ondragstart="script"

onhelp="script"

onselectstart="script"

Attribute“

ALqN  This attribute is used to align the contents of the cells within thk  <THEAD  elementì

Common values ark  CENTE JUSTIF LEF  ,  ,  , an™  RIGH  . The HTML 4.0 specification alsf

defines a value o“  CHA  . Whe-  ALIGN  is set tf  CHA  , the attributk  CHA  must be presenš

and set to the character to which cells should be aligned. A common use of this approach woul™

be to set cells to align on a decimal pointì

COLOR  This attribute specifies a background color for the cells within thk  <THEAD

element. Its value can be either a named color, such a—  red  , or a color specified in thk

hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #FF0000  ì

CHAR  This attribute is used to define the character to which element contents are aligne™

when thk  ALIGN  attribute is set to thk  CHA  valueì

CHAROFF  This attribute contains an offset as a positive or negative integer to align character—

as related to thk  CHA  value. A value o“ , for example, would align characters in a cell twf  2

characters to the right of the character defined by thk  CHA  attributeì

908  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<TITLE>   (Document Title)

This element encloses the title of an HTML document. It must occur within a document’—

<HEAD  element and must be present in all valid documents. Meaningful titles are ver_

important since they are used for bookmarking a page and may be used by search engine—

attempting to index the documentì

Synta¨

<TITLE

DIR="LTR | RTL"

LANG="language code">

</TITLE>

Attributes Defined by Internet Explorer 

ID="unique alphanumeric identifier"

TITLE="advisory text"

Attribute“

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Attribute and Event Suppor

INTERNET EXPLORER   I¤  an™  TITL¨  ì

Event Handler“

Noneì

<HEAD><TITLEL  Big Company: Products: Super WidgeM  </TITLE></HEADL

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  909

Note“

  MeaningfuR name— shoul™ providk informatio- abouš thk documentì A pooK titlk woul™ bk

somethiný likk “M_ Homk Page,” whilk ¾ betteK titlk woul™ bk “Jok Smith’— Homk Page.”

  Older versions of Netscape allowed for multiple occurrences of thk  <TITLE  elementì

When multiplk  <TITLE  elements were encountered, they could be used to simulate a-

animated title bar. This was a bug with the Netscape browser, however, and the effect o“

multiplk  <TITLE  elements no longer worksì

APPENDIXES

  Browsers may be extremely sensitive with thk  <TITLE  element. If the title element i—

malformed or not closed, the page may not even render in the browserì

  The HTML 2.0 and 3.2 specifications define no attributes for thk  <TITLE  elementì

This element specifies a row in a table. The individual cells of the row are defined by thk  <TH

an™  <TD  elementsì

Attribute“

ALqN  This attribute is used to align the contents of the cells within thk  <THEAD  elementì

Common values ark  CENTE JUSTIF LEF  ,  ,  , an™  RIGH  ì

COLOR  This attribute specifies a background color for all the cells in a row. Its value ca-

be either a named color, such a—  red  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format,

such a—  #FF0000  ì

BORDERCOLOR  This attribute, supported by Internet Explorer and Netscape, is used to seš

the border color for table cells in the row. The attribute should only be used with a positive valuk

for thk  BORDE  attribute. The value of the attribute can be either a named color, such a—  green  ,

or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #00FF00  ì

BORDERCOLORDARK  This Internet Explorer–specific attribute specifies the darker of twf

border colors used to create a thre[dimensional effect for the cell’s borders. It must be used wit—

thk  BORDE  attribute set to a positive value. The attribute value can be either a named color,

such a—  blu2  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #00FF00  ì

BORDERCOLORLqHT  This Internet Explorer–specific attribute specifies the lighter of twf

border colors used to create a thre[dimensional effect for a cell’s borders. It must be used wit—

thk  BORDE  attribute set to a positive value. The attribute value can be either a named color,

such a—  red  , or a color specified in the hexadecimaR  #RRGGBB  format, such a—  #FF0000  ì

<UL>   (Unordered List)

This element is used to indicate an unordered list, namely a collection of items that do not have ¾

numerical ordering. The individual items in the list are defined by thk  <LI  element, which is thk

only allowed element withi-  <UL  ì

 = Page 937 =

91‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Attribute“

CLASS  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

COMPACT  This attribute indicates that the list should be rendered in a compact style. Feu

browsers actually change the rendering of the list regardless of the presence of this attribute. Thk

COMPAC  attribute requires no valueì

DIR  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

LANG  See “Language Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

 = Page 938 =

Appendix A  HTMP Elemen@ Referencf  91

LANGU  In the Microsoft implementation, this attribute specifies the scripting languagk

to be used with an associated script bound to the element, typically through an event handleK

attribute. Possible values may includk  JAVASCRIP JSCRIP VBS  ,  ,  , an™  VBSCRIP  . OtheK

values that include the version of the language used, such a—  JavaScript1.1  , may also be possibleì

STYLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TITLE  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

TYPE  Thk  TYP¨  attribute is used to set the bullet style for the list. The values defined undeK

HTML 3.2 and the transitional version of HTML 4 ark  CIRCL¨ DIS‚  ,  , an™  SQUAR¨  . A useK

APPENDIXES

agent may decide to use a different bullet depending on the nesting level of the list unless thk

TYP¨  attribute is used. The WebTV interface also supports ¾  TRIANGL¨  bullet. Thk  TYP¨

attribute is dropped under the strict version of HTML 4, since style sheets can provide richeK

bullet controlì

Attribute and Event Suppor

NETSCAPE   CLASS I¤ LAN… STYL¨  ,  ,  ,  , an™  TYP¨  ì

INTERNET EXPLORER   All attributes and events excepš  COMPAC  an™  DI  ì

WEBTV  TYP¨  ì

Event Handler“

See “Events Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

Example“

<UL COMPACT TITLE="Sushi Short List" TYPE="CIRCLE"L

<LIL  MagurB

<LIL  EbB

<LIL  HamachB

</ULL

<!-- Common but bad example --L

<ULL  Indenting using lists should not be used, though it is common<

Many Web editors generate code laden with nonbreaking spaces and

unordered lists<  </ULL

 = Page 939 =

918  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Note“

  HTML 2 supports only thk  COMPAC  attributeì

  The HTML 3.2 specification support—  COMPAC  an™  TYP¨  ì

  Under the strict HTML 4.0 specification, thk  <UL  element does not support thk

COMPAC  attribute or thk  TYP¨  attribute. Both of these attributes can be safel_

replaced with style rulesì

  Many Web page designers and page development tools use thk  <UL  element to indenš

text. Be aware that the only element that should occur within ¾  <UL  element i—  <LI  ,

according to HTML standards, so such HTML markup does not conform to standardsì

However, this common practice is likely to continueì

<VAR>   (Variable)

This element is used to indicate a variable. Variables are identifiers that occur in a programminý

language or a mathematical expression. The element is logical, though enclosed text is ofte-

rendered in italicsì

Synta¨

<VAR

CLASS="class name(s)"

DIR="LTR | RTL"

ID="unique alphanumeric value"

LANG="language code"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text"

onclick="script"

ondblclick="script"

onkeydown="script"

onkeypress="script"

onkeyup="script"

onmousedown="script"

onmousemove="script"

onmouseout="script"

onmouseover="script"

onmouseup="script">

</VAR>

Attributes and Events Defined by Internet Explorer 

<WBR>   (Word Break)

This nonstandard element is used to indicate a place where a line break can occur if necessaryì

This element is used in conjunction with thk  <NOBR  element, which is used to keep text fro“

 = Page 941 =

920  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

wrapping. When used this way,  <WBR  can be thought of as a soft line break in comparison tf

thk  <BR  element. This element is common to both Netscape and Microsoft implementations,

though it is not part of any HTML standardì

Synta¨

<WBR

CLASS="class name(s)"

ID="unique alphanumeric value"

LANGUAGE="JAVASCRIPT | JSCRIPT | VBS | VBSCRIPT"

STYLE="style information"

TITLE="advisory text">

Note“

  This element was introduced in Netscape 1.1ì

<XML> (XML Data Island)

This proprietary element introduced by Microsoft can be used to embed islands of XML

(Extensible Markup Language) data into HTML documents; this only works under Interneš

Explorer 5. Thk  <XML  element can be used to reference outside data sources using thk  SR‚

attribute, or to surround XML data in the HTML document itselfì

APPENDIXES

Syntax (defined by Internet Explorer 5)

<XML

ID="unique alphanumeric value"

NS="URL of XML namespace"

PREFIX="XML prefix"

SRC="URL of XML data file"

ondataavailable="script"

ondatasetchanged="script"

ondatasetcomplete="script"

onreadystatechange="script"

onrowenter="script"

onrowexit="script">

Embedded XML cod4

</XML>

Attribute“

ID  See “Core Attributes Reference,” earlier in this appendixì

NS  This attribute, still largely theoretical at the time of this writing, references the URL of a-

XML namespaceì

PREFIX  This attribute references the URL of an XML namespace prefix in conjunction wit—

thk  NS  attributeì

SRC  This attribute references an external XML data fileì

Event Handler“

See “Extended Events,” earlier in this appendixì

Attribute and Event Suppor

onreadystatechang2 onrowente(  ,  , an™  onrowexit  ì

 = Page 943 =

92p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Example“

<!-- This code embeds XML data directly into a document

All code between the XML tags is not HTML, but ¤

hypothetical example of XML. --L

<XML ID="tasty"L

<COMBOMEALL

<BURGERL

<NAMEL  Tasty BurgeI  </NAMEL

<BUN BREAD="WHITE"L

<MEAT /L

<CHEESE /L

<MEAT /L

</BUNL

</BURGERL

<FRIES SIZE="LARGE" /L

<DRINK SIZE="LARGE" FLAVOR="Cola" /L

</COMBOMEALL

</XMLL

<!-- This code fragment uses the SRC attribute to

reference an external file containing XML data. --L

<XML SRC="combomeal.xml"></XMLL

  For a more detailed discussion of this element, refer to the section “Embedding XML

into HTML Documents” in Chapter 17ì

<XMP>   (Example)

This deprecated element indicates that the enclosed text is an example. Example text is generall_

rendered in a monospaced font, and the spaces, tabs, and returns are preserved, as with thk

<PRE  element. As thk  <XMP  element is no longer standard, thk  <PRE  oK  <SAMP  element—

should be used insteadì

Syntax (Defined by HTML 2; Deprecated Under HTML 4)

<XMP>

</XMP>
