Appendi 

Style Sheet Referencf

92P

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 947 =

92‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

ascading style sheets, covered in Chapter 10, offer a powerful new tool for WeD

page layout. When used properly, style sheets also separate style fro“

document structure, as was originally intended for HTML. Many of the stylk

C

properties defined by the Cascading Style Sheets 1 (CSS1) specification are supporte™

by major browsers, including Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5, and Netscape Navigator 4

and 4.5. This appendix provides a concise look at style sheet rules, a listing o“

commonly supported CSS1 style properties and their values, and their currenš

compatibility with the major browsers. Testing on a prerelease version of Netscape’—

new browser engine suggests that future Netscape browsers will support a wideK

range of style sheet properties. Cascading Style Sheets 2 (CSS2) positioning properties,

also supported by the most recent browser versions, are included in this appendix. FoK

a more detailed discussion of the CSS2 specification, see Chapter 10ì

Style Sheet Term“

This section defines some basic terms used when working with style sheetsì

Embedded Style“

Documenâwide styles can be embedded in a document’—  <HEAD  element using thk

<STYLE  element. Note that styles should be commented out to avoid interpretatio-

by no™styl[aware browsersì

EXAMPLE

<HEADL

<STYLEL

<!-p

P  {font-size: 14pt; font-face: Times; color: blue;

backgroundcolor: yellow}

EM {font-size: 16pt; color: green}

--L

</STYLEL

<TITLEL  ..<  </TITLE></HEADL

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

 = Page 948 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  92

Inline Style“

APPENDIXES

Styles can be applied directly to elements in the body of a document. Rather than seš

documenâwide values for thk  <H1  element, it is possible to set the style for a-

individual header, as shown here:

EXAMPLE

<H1 STYLE="font-size: 48pt; font-family: Arial;

color: green"L  CSS1 TesM  </H1L

A-  <H1  header elsewhere in the document could be assigned a completely differenš

styleì

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Linked Style“

Style can be contained in an external style sheet linked to a document or a set o“

documents (see Chapter 10), as shown in the following example. Linked informatio-

should be placed inside thk  <HEAD  elementì

EXAMPLE

<LINK REL="stylesheet" TYPE="text/css" HREF="newstyle.css"L

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Imported Style“

Styles can be imported from an external file and expanded in place, similar to a macroì

Importing can be used to include multiple style sheets. An imported style is define™

with thk  <STYLE  element and thk  TYP¨  attribute, followed by the URL for the stylk

sheet, as shown here:

 = Page 949 =

928  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

EXAMPLE

<HEADL

<STYLE TYPE="text/css"L

@import url(newstyle.css)

<TITLEL    </TITLE></HEADL

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 5

Future versions of Netscapk

Selector“

A selector is an HTML element, identifier, or class name associated with a style rule. I-

the following examples,  L  an™  DIV  are the selectorsì

EXAMPLES

P {font-size: 12pt}

DIV {font-family: Courier}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Class Selector“

Multiple classes can be defined for individual elements (selectors). To create a clas—

selector, attach a class name to a selector; separate the selector from the class name wit—

a period. Repeat this with the same selector, but give it a different nameì

EXAMPLE

P.one {font-face: Arial; font-size: 12pt}

P.two {font-face: Verdana; font-size: 14pt}

There are now two different paragraph styles to choose from. Use thk  CLASS

attribute with thk  <P  element to distinguish between them in the body of thk

documentì

 = Page 950 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  929

EXAMPLE

APPENDIXES

<P CLASS="one"L  This is paragraph style one<  </PL

<P CLASS="two"L  This is paragraph style two<  </PL

It is also possible to create stanÙalone class selectors by omitting element namesì

EXAMPLE

.one {font-face: Arial; font-size: 12pt}

.two {font-face: Verdana; font-size: 14pt}

<P CLASS="one"L  This is paragraph style one<  </PL

<P CLASS="two"L  This is paragraph style two<  </PL

<H1 CLASS="two"L  This header will also be style two<  </PL

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Contextual Selector“

Contextual selectors define the display of elements within other specific elements. I-

the following example,  <STRONG  text within ¾  <DIV  element displays as green;

however,  <STRONG  text outside the context of thk  <DIV  element is not affected b_

this style. Note that the contextual selector—  DIV  an™  STRON…  are separated by whitk

space, not by commas. Another way to say this is that ¾  <STRONG  element with ¾

<DIV  ancestor will match this styleì

EXAMPLE

DIV STRONG {color: green}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

ID Selector“

Styles can be assigned independent of elements by creating ID selectors. Create an ID

selector by creating a name preceded by the character # and following it with the stylk

to be associated with that IDì

 = Page 951 =

930  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

EXAMPLE

#stylp3 {font-size: 6pt; font-face: Verdana; font-variant:

small-caps}

In the body of the document, use thk  I¤  attribute to assign the style to an elemenš

or elementsì

EXAMPLE

<P ID="style43"L  This text is hard to read<  </PL

<H1 ID="style43"L  So is the text in this header<  </H1L

ID must be unique. Each value must appear only once in a given document.

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Rule“

Style rules determine the styles to be associated with a selector. Style rules are enclose™

within braces. A rule must include a property (  font-fac2  , in the following example) an™

a value (the font namk  Impact  , in the following example)ì

EXAMPLE

P {font-face: Impact}

Multiple rules can be included within a single style specification, but they must bk

separated by semicolonsì

EXAMPLE

P {font-face: Impact; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 16pt}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

 = Page 952 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  93h

Grouping

APPENDIXES

Selectors and declarations can be grouped together so that all the selectors ark

associated with a particular rule. Note that the listed selectors are separated b_

commasì

EXAMPLE

P, DIV, SPAN {background-color: yellow; font-face: Arial;

color: black; font-size: 14pt}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Inheritancs

In most cases, elements contained within another element inherit the property value—

specified for the parent element, unless those properties are defined differently for thk

nested elements. In the following example, thk  <P  element retains the backgroun™

color and font color defined for thk  <BODY  element; only the font face changesì

EXAMPLE

BODY {background-color: blue; font-face: Courier; color: white}

P    {font-face: Arial}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Pseudoclasse“

Elements can be assigned pseudoclasses to affect their display. There are threk

pseudoclasses:  A:activ2 A:link  ,  , an™  A:visited  ì

A:activs

This property specifies how the text in active links will displayì

 = Page 953 =

93p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

EXAMPLE

A:active {text-decoration: none}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 5

A:link

This property specifies how text in unvisited links will displayì

EXAMPLE

A:link {text-decoration: underline}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

A:visite

This property specifies how text in visited links will displayì

EXAMPLE

A:visited {text-decoration: line-through}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Pseudoelement“

This section discusse—  pseudoelements¨  which affect typographical items, such as the firsš

line of a paragraph, rather tha-  structural elements¨  such as the paragraph (  <P  ) itselfì

first-lette5

This property specifies how the first letter of text in a block-level element will displayì

 = Page 954 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  93

EXAMPLE

APPENDIXES

P:first-letter {font-face: Arial Black; font-size: 25pt}

BROWSER SUPPORT  None currently; probable in future versions of Netscapk

first-lins

This property specifies how the first line of text in a block-level element will displayì

EXAMPLE

P:first-line {font-face: Arial Black; font-size: 150%;

font-weight: bold}

BROWSER SUPPORT  None currently; probable in future versions of Netscapk

Miscellaneou“

This section discusses some miscellaneous terms associated with style sheetsì

/* comments */

Comments can be placed within style sheets. HTML comment syntax (  <!’- comment

-’  ) does not apply. Style sheets use the comment syntax used in C programminý

(  /*comment*  )ì

EXAMPLE

<STYLEL

P {font-face: Courier; font-size: 14pt; font-weight: bold;

background-color: yellow}

/*This style sheet was created at Big Company, Inc<

All rights reserved.*/

</STYLEL

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

 = Page 955 =

93  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

! Importan

This property specifies that a style takes precedence over any different, conflictiný

styles. A style specified as important by an author takes precedence over a rule set b_

an end userì

EXAMPLE

DIV {font-size: 14pt; line-height: 150%; font-family: Aria¤ ! important}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 5

Future versions of Netscapk

Font“

The font properties ark  font-family font-siz2 font-styl2 font-weight font-variant  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

text-transfor… text-decoration  ,  , an™  font  . Thk  font  property can be used as ¾

shorthand notation of font valuesì

EXAMPLE

{font-family: Arial sans-serif; font-size: 18pt; font-style: italic;

font-variant: normal; font-weight: bold; text-decoration: underlin4

text-transform: capitalize;}

font-famil

This property sets the font face for text. It is equivalent to thk  FAC¨  attribute of thk

<FONT  elementì

EXAMPLE

{font-family: "Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"}

Fonts are read in descending order and must be separated by commas. In thk

preceding example, Arial is the primary font and will be displayed by browsers an™

systems with that font. If Arial is not available, Helvetica will be displayed. The finaR

option, the generic font namk  sans-serif  , will be used when no other listed font i—

availableì

 = Page 956 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  93

BROWSER SUPPORT

APPENDIXES

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Name Value“

These values define a specific font family or familiesì

EXAMPLES

{font-family: "Times New Roman"}

{font-family: "Courier"}

{font-family: "Times New Roman, Courier"}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Generic Font Name“

These values can be used to set a final option in a list of fonts, generally to the defaulš

generic font on a user's system. For example,  serif  defaults to Courier on man_

systems. There are five generic font names currently available:  serif sans-serif  ,  ,

cursiv2 fantasy  ,  , an™  monospac2  ì

serif  This value specifies a default serif fontì

EXAMPLES

{font-family: "serif"}

{font-family: "Times New Roman, serif"}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3 (Windows only), 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

sans-serif  This value specifies a default san-serif fontì

EXAMPLES

{font-family: sans-serif}

{font-family: "Arial, sans-serif"}

 = Page 957 =

93‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3 (Windows only), 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

cursivs  This value specifies a default cursive fontì

EXAMPLE

{font-family: cursive}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3 (Windows only), 4, and 5

Future versions of Netscapk

fantas  This value specifies a default fantasy fontì

EXAMPLE

{font-family: fantasy}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3 (Windows only), 4, and 5

Future versions of Netscapk

monospacs  This value specifies a default monospace fontì

EXAMPLE

{font-family: monospace}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

font-sizs

This property sets the font size of text. Options include exact sizes (point, pixel, oK

other values), absolute sizes, relative sizes, and percentagesì

 = Page 958 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  93

EXAMPLE

APPENDIXES

{font-face: Arial; font-size: 18pt}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Exact Font Size Value“

These values set the font size to an exact size in points (pt) or pixels (px)ì

EXAMPLES

{font-size: 12pt}

{font-size: 30px}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Absolute Font Size Value“

These values set the font size to an absolute size. There are seven possible sizes:

xx-smal“ x-smal“ smal“ mediu… larg2 x-larg2  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™ -  xx larg2  ì

EXAMPLE

{font-size: xx-small}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

xx-small  The value sets the font size to the smallest absolute font size, which i—

usually equivalent to one point size smaller than the HTML codk  <FONT SIZE="1"  ì

EXAMPLE

{font-size: xx-small}

 = Page 959 =

938  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

x-small  The value sets the font size to the seconÙsmallest absolute font size, whic—

is equivalent to the HTML codk  <FONT SIZE="1"  ì

EXAMPLE

{font-size: x-small}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

small  This value sets the font size to the third smallest absolute font size, which i—

equivalent to the HTML codk  <FONT SIZE="2"  ì

EXAMPLE

{font-size: small}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

medium  The value sets the font size to the middle absolute font size, which i—

equivalent to the HTML codk  <FONT SIZE="3"  ì

EXAMPLE

{font-size: medium}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

largs  The value sets the font size to the thirÙlargest absolute font size, which i—

equivalent to the HTML codk  <FONT SIZE="4"  ì

 = Page 960 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  939

EXAMPLE

APPENDIXES

{font-size: large}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

x-largs  The value sets the font size to the seconÙlargest absolute font size, which i—

equivalent to the HTML codk  <FONT SIZE="5"  ì

EXAMPLE

{font-size: x-large}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

xx-largs  The value sets the font size to the largest absolute font size, which i—

equivalent to the HTML codk  <FONT SIZE="6"  ì

EXAMPLE

{font-size: xx-large}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Percentage Font Size Value“

These values set the font size to a percentage of the primary font size of a section oK

document. For example, if the font size for thk  <BODY  element were set to 12 points,

and font size for ¾  <P  element inside the body were set to 200 percent, the text insidk

thk  <P  element would display in 24-point type. This could be cleared on inheritanceì

EXAMPLE

{font-size: 75%}

 = Page 961 =

940  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3 (incomplete), 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Relative Font Size Value“

These values define the font size relative to the primary font size of a document oK

sectionì

smalle5  This value sets the font size one point smaller than the primary font size of ¾

section or document. It is equivalent to the HTML codk  <FONT SIZE=-1  ì

EXAMPLE

{font-size: smaller}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

large5  This value sets the font size to one point larger than the primary font size of ¾

section or document. It is equivalent to the HTML codk  <FONT SIZE=+1  ì

{font-size: larger}

throug—  900  )ì

100–900

These values set the weight of the font from lightest (  100  ) to boldest (  900  ) in increment—

of 100. In practice, under Internet Explorer 4 and Netscape 4, the value—  100  throug—

500  display as normal text;  600  throug—  800  display as bold; an™  900  displays as extr¾

bold. Browser support for other values is inconsistent at bestì

EXAMPLE

{font-weight: 600}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5 (Windows only, incomplete)

Netscape 4 and 4.5 (incomplete for Macs)

fon

This property provides a shorthand way to specify all font properties with one stylk

rule. Properties ark  font-family font-size/line-height font-styl2 font-weight  ,  ,  ,  , an™

font-variant  . It is not necessary to include all properties. Thk  line-height  property i—

discussed in the following section, “Text.” Font names consisting of more than onk

word should be placed in quotes. Lists of variant fonts should be separated by comma—

and placed in quotesì

EXAMPLE

{font: normal small-caps bold 12pt/18pM

"Times New Roman, Courier, serif"}

Tex

This section discusses style properties that affect texâlevel elementsì

word-spacing

This property sets the spacing between words. Values can be set in inches ( ),  in

centimeters (  c…  ), millimeters (  m…  ), points ( ), picas (  pt  p8  ), em spaces (  e…  ), or pixel—

(  px  ); or to the default valuk  norma“  ì

EXAMPLES

{font-family: Helvetica; font-size: 12pt; word-spacing: normal}

BROWSER SUPPORT  None currently; probable in future versions of Netscapk

normal

browser’s settingì

EXAMPLE

{font-family: Arial; font-size: 10pt; word-spacing: normal}

 = Page 970 =

Future versions of Netscapk

(  c…  ), millimeters (  m…  ), points ( ), picas, (  pt  p8  ), em spaces (  e…  ), or pixels (  px  )ì

such as a paragraph. Values can be specified as a number of lines, a number of unit—

 = Page 971 =

950  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

(pixels, points, and so on), or a percentage of the font size. This property is generall_

used in conjunction with thk  font-siz2  propertyì

Colors and Background“

This section discusses the style properties that affect backgrounds and variou—

concerns associated with backgrounds, such as color, images, and scrolling, as well a—

the property that affects the color of textì

colo5

This property sets the color of text. Values can be specified as color names, hex value—

in thre[ or six-digit format, or reÙgree™blue (RGB) values (numbers or percentages)ì

For browser support of color values, see the section “Style Sheet Color Values,” later i-

this appendixì

EXAMPLES

{color: yellow}

{color: #FFFF00}

{color: #FF0}

{color: rgb(255,255,0)}

{color: rgb(100%,100%,0%)}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

background-colo5

This property sets an element’s background color. It is often used in conjunction wit—

thk  colo(  property, which sets text color (see the discussion of thk  colo(  property undeK

“color,” later in this appendix). Used with block elements, this property colors contenš

and padding but not margins. The default value,  transparent  , allows any underlyiný

 = Page 976 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  95

content to show through. See “Style Sheet Color Values,” later in this appendix, foK

browser support of color valuesì  APPENDIXES

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

any underlying content to show through, as it does when used with thk  background

propertyì

EXAMPLE

{background-color: transparent}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

This property associates a background image with an element. Underlying contenš

shows through transparent regions in the source image. The background imagk

requires a URL (complete or relative) to link it to the source image (GIF or JPEG). Thk

default value i—  non2  ì

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

background imageì

 = Page 977 =

Netscape 4 and 4.5

nons  This value, which is the default for this property, sets the background so that iš

doesn’t display an image (any underlying content shows through)ì

Netscape 4 and 4.5

canvas space used by their associated elements. It is used in conjunction with thk

no-repeat  ì

background-attachmen

This property sets the background image to scroll or not to scroll with its associate™

element’s content. The default value i—  scrol“  . The alternate value,  fixed  , is intended tf

create a watermark effect similar to the proprietary attribute,  BGPROPERTIES  , of thk

<BODY  element introduced by Microsoftì

 = Page 979 =

958  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

EXAMPLE

associated content, such as textì

EXAMPLE

{background-image: url(yellowpattern.gif);

background-attachment: scroll}

fixe

text, scrollsì

EXAMPLE

background-attachment: fixed}

background-positio

This property determines how a background image is positioned within the canva—

space used by its associated element. The position of the image’s uppe§left corner ca-

be specified as an absolute distance in pixels. It can also be specified as a percentagk

along the horizontal and vertical dimensions. Finally, the position can be specified a—

named values that describe the horizontal and vertical dimensions. The named value—

for the horizontal axis ark  cente( left  ,  , an™  right  ; those for the vertical axis ark  top  ,

cente(  , an™  botto…  . The default value for an unspecified dimension is assumed tf

bk  cente(  ì

 = Page 980 =

APPENDIXES

position for the uppe§left corner of the imageì

horizontal and vertical axesì

background image relative to its parent elementì

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Background Positioning Percentage Value“

These values set the position of the background image as a percentage along thk

horizontal and vertical dimensions. The first percentage value sets horizontaR

placement; the second sets vertical placement. If only one value is specified, the verticaR

placement value defaults tf  50%  . Use of these values in a page with no content can lea™

to problems under Internet Explorer 3. (For example, a value o“  botto…  aligns thk

bottom of the image with the top of the browser window, thus placing it completel_

out of view. This has been corrected in Internet Explorer 4, which displays the imagk

properly at the bottom of the browser window.) If no values are set, the placemenš

defaults to the uppe§left corner of the browser windowì

EXAMPLE

{background url(picture.gif) no-repeat 20%S0%}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Background Positioning Named Value“

These values sets the position of the background image. The value—  top middl2  ,  , an™

botto…  , assign vertical positions;  cente( left  ,  , an™  right  assign horizontal positionsì

Values can be combined as common sense suggests. If no values are set, the placemenš

defaults to the uppe§left corner of the browser windowì

EXAMPLES

{background url(picture.gif) no-repeat top center}

{background url(picture.gif) no-repeat right bottom}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

top  This value sets the position of the background image to the top of its associate™

element. If no other value is set, the tošaligned image defaults to the leftì

 = Page 986 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  96

EXAMPLE

APPENDIXES

{background url(picture.gif) no-repeat top}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

cente5  This value sets the position of the background image to the horizontal centeK

of its associated element. If no other value is set, the cente§aligned image defaults tf

the vertical middleì

EXAMPLE

{background url(picture.gif) no-repeat center}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

middls  This value sets the position of the background image to the vertical middle o“

its associated element. If no other value is set, the middl[aligned image defaults to thk

left. Under Internet Explorer 4,  middl2  works only when assigned a horizontal value;

otherwise, the background image defaults to the upper leftì

EXAMPLE

{background url(picture.gif) no-repeat middle}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

bottom  This value sets the position of the background image to the bottom of it—

associated element. If no other value is set, the bottoRaligned image defaults tf

the leftì

EXAMPLE

{background url(picture.gif) no-repeat bottom}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

lef  This value, which is the default horizontal position for this property, sets thk

position of the background image to the left of its associated elementì

 = Page 987 =

96‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

EXAMPLE

{background url(picture.gif) no-repeat left}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

righ  This value sets the position of the background image to the right of it—

associated elementì

EXAMPLE

{background url(picture.gif) no-repeat right}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Layou

This section discusses style properties that affect the layout of HTML documentsì

Margin“

Style sheets can be used to set margins around an element with thk  margin  propertyì

Margin values can be set to a specific length (  15pt 2e…  ,  , and so on) or to a percentagk

value of the block element’s width. Another value,  autG  , attempts to calculate thk

margin automatically. Thk  autG  value is not supported. Four distinct margins can bk

set separately from one another using the following properties:  margin-top  ,

margin-botto… margin-right,  ,  an™  margin-left  . By itself,  margin  sets a consistenš

margin on all four sides of the affected element. Margins can also be set tf

negative valuesì

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3 (Windows only), 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

margin-top

This property sets an element’s top marginì

EXAMPLE

{margin-top: 15pt}

 = Page 988 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  96

BROWSER SUPPORT

APPENDIXES

Internet Explorer 3 (Windows only), 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

margin-bottom

This property sets an element’s bottom marginì

EXAMPLE

{margin-bottom: 10pt}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3 (Windows only), 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

margin-righ

This property sets an element’s right marginì

EXAMPLE

{margin-right: 15pt}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

margin-lef

This property sets an element’s left marginì

EXAMPLE

{margin-left: 12pt}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

 = Page 989 =

968  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

margi

This property sets all margins for an element. Up to four values can be defined, in thi—

order:  top right botto…  ,  ,  , an™  left  . The valuk  autG  is not currently supported. A singlk

value defines the same margin for all four sidesì

EXAMPLE

{margin: 25pt}

If two values are specified, the first defines the top and bottom margins, while thk

second defines the left and right marginsì

EXAMPLE

{margin: 15pt, 25pt}

If three values are specified, the first defines the top margin, the second defines thk

left and right margins, and the third defines the bottom margin. Note that thk

unspecified margin is inferred from the value defined for its opposite sideì

EXAMPLE

{margin: 25pt,S0pt, 25pt}

Finally, all four margins can be set to different values if desired (  top right botto…  ,  ,  ,

an™  left  , in that order)ì

EXAMPLE

{margin: 15pt, 25pt,S0pt, 10pt}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3 (incomplete), 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Border“

There are five properties for setting the width of borders:  border-top-widt—  ,

border-bottom-widt— border-right-widt— border-left-widt—  ,  ,  , an™  border-widt—  . Thk

first four set the width of specific borders;  border-widt—  is used to set all four. Value—

for border widths can be set in numeric measurements or with the named value—  thin  ,

 = Page 990 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  969

mediu…  , oK  thick  . Border colors and styles can be set with the propertie—  border-colo(

an™  border-styl2  , respectively. The propertie—  border-top border-botto…  ,  ,  APPENDIXES

border-right  , an™  border-left  can be used to set width, style, and color values foK

different sides of a border; thk  borde(  property sets the width, style, and color of alR

sides of an element's borderì

border-top-widts

This property sets the width of an element’s top border. Values can be keywords (  thin  ,

mediu…  , oK  thick  ) and numerical lengthsì

EXAMPLES

{border-top-width: thin}

{border-top-width: 25px}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

border-bottom-widts

(  thin mediu…  ,  , oK  thick  ) and numerical lengthsì

EXAMPLES

{border-bottom-width: medium}

{border-bottom-width: 15px}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

(  thin mediu…  ,  , oK  thick  ) and numerical lengthsì

EXAMPLES

{border-right-width:Y0px}

 = Page 991 =

 = Page 993 =

97p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

Thk  border-styl2  property defines the style of up to four different side of a border,

using the value—  non2 dotted dashed solid doubl2 groov2 ridg2 inset  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  outset  ì

These values are listed, in order, for the top, right, bottom, and left sides. Missiný

values are inferred from the value defined for the opposite sideì

EXAMPLE

{border-style: solid, double, solid, double}

Netscape 4 supports only one value fo(  border-styl¨  .(se of multiple values will creat—

erratic display under that browser.

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 (incomplete)

nons  This value “turns off” the border, even if other border properties havk

been setì

EXAMPLE

{border-style: none}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

dotte  This value defines a dotted border styleì

Padding

The padding properties set the space between an element’s border and its contentì

There are five properties for padding:  padding-top padding-botto… padding-right  ,  ,  ,

padding-left  , an™  padding  . Thk  padding  value sets the padding for all four sides; thk

other four set the padding for specific sides. Values can be specified as specific value—

(pixels, points, and so on) or as a percentage of the element’s overall width. Unlike thk

margin  property, thk  padding  property cannot take negative valuesì

padding-top

This property sets the distance between an element’s top border and the top o“

its contentì

EXAMPLE

{padding-top: 25px}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

padding-bottom

This property sets the distance between an element’s bottom border and the bottom o“

its contentì

EXAMPLE

{padding-bottom: 15px}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

padding-righ

This property sets the distance between an element’s right border and the right side o“

its contentì

 = Page 998 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  97

EXAMPLE

APPENDIXES

{padding-right:Spx}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

padding-lef

This property sets the distance between an element’s left border and the left side o“

its contentì

EXAMPLE

{padding-left: 25px}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

padding

This property sets the distance between an element’s border and its contents. A singlk

value creates equal padding on all sidesì

EXAMPLE

{border-style: solid; padding: 10px}

Up to four values can be used, in the following clockwise order:  top right botto…  ,  ,  ,

an™  left  ì

EXAMPLE

{border-style: solid; padding: 10px 20px 10pxS0px}

Any missing value defaults to the value defined for the side opposite to itì

EXAMPLE

{border-style: solid; padding: 10px 20px 10px}

 = Page 999 =

978  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

widts

This property sets the width of an element’s content region (excluding padding,

border, and margin). The next example sets a paragraph with a width of 400 pixelsì

EXAMPLE

P {width:Y00px; padding: 10px; border: solidSpx}

Percentage values, based on the width of the containing element, can also be usedì

EXAMPLE

P {width: 80%; padding: 10px; border: solidSpx}

Thk  autG  value automatically calculates the width of an element, based on thk

width of the containing element and the size of the contentì

EXAMPLE

P {width: auto; padding: 10px; border: solidSpx}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

heigh

This property sets the height of an element’s content region (excluding padding,

border, and margin). The next example sets a paragraph with a height of 200 pixelsì

EXAMPLE

P {height: 200px; padding: 10px; border: solidSpx}

Percentage values, based on the height of the containing element, can also be usedì

 = Page 1000 =

EXAMPLE

APPENDIXES

P {height: 80%; padding: 10px; border: solidSpx}

Thk  autG  value automatically calculates the height of an element, based on thk

height of the containing element and the size of the contentì

EXAMPLE

P {height: auto; padding: 10px; border: solidSpx}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 5

Future versions of Netscapk

floa

toward the left or right margin of its containing element. Possible values ark  left right  ,  ,

an™  non2  ì

EXAMPLE

Netscape 4 and 4.5

lef

Layers and Positioning

This section discusses style properties that affect layering and positioning of elementsì

positio

This property defines how an element is positioned relative to other elements, usiný

the value—  stati8 absolut2  ,  , an™  relativ2  . Thk  left  an™  top  properties define thk

element’s precise location, using the affected element’s uppe§left corner (0,0) a—

reference. Because elements can contain other elements, 0,0 is not necessarily thk

uppe§left corner of the browserì

EXAMPLE

{position: relative; right: 190px; top: 30px}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 4 and 5

stati‘

This value, which is the default for this property, places elements according to thk

natural order in which they occur in a documentì

EXAMPLE

{position: static; left: 120px; top:S0px}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 4 and 5

absoluts

This value defines a coordinate system independent from other block and inlink

element placement. An element whose position is absolute acts as a visual container foK

any elements enclosed within its content. All elements defined inside it move with itì

Contained elements that are assigned coordinates outside their container’s dimension—

will disappearì

EXAMPLE

{position: absolute; left: 120px; top:S0px}

 = Page 1004 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  98

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 4 and 5

APPENDIXES

relativs

This value positions elements relative to their natural position in document flowì

EXAMPLE

{position: relative; left: 120px; top:S0px}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 4 and 5

lef

This value defines thk (horizontal) coordinate for a positioned element, relative to thk  x

uppe§left corner. Values can be specified as lengths (inches, pixels, and so on), as ¾

percentage of the containing object’s dimensions, or a—  autG  ì

EXAMPLES

{position: absolute; left: 120px; top:S0px}

{position: absolute; left: 30%; top:S0%}

{position: absolute; left: auto; top: auto}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

top

This value defines thk (vertical) coordinate for a positioned element, relative to thk  y

uppe§left corner. Values can be specified as lengths (inches, pixels, and so on), as ¾

percentage of the containing object’s dimensions, or a—  autG  , which lets this propert_

function as determined by the browser or as defined by the parent elementì

EXAMPLES

{position: absolute; left: 100px; top: 150px}

{position: absolute; left:S0%; top: 30%}

{position: absolute; left: auto; top: auto}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

 = Page 1005 =

98  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

widts

This property defines the width of an element. Values can be specified as length—

(positive values only), percentages (relative to the containing element’s width), oK  autG  ,

which defaults to the element’s natural widthì

EXAMPLE

IMG {position: absolute; left: 120px; top:S0px; height: 200px;

width:Y00px}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 4 and 5

heigh

This property defines the height of an element. Values can be specified as length—

(positive values only), percentages (relative to the containing element’s height), or a—

autG  , which defaults to the element’s natural heightì

EXAMPLE

IMG {position: absolute; left: 120px; top:S0px; height: 100px;

width: 150px}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 4 and 5

clip

This property sets the coordinates of the clipping rectangle that houses the content o“

elements set to a position value o“  absolut2  . Coordinate values ark  top right botto…  ,  ,  ,

left  , an™  autG  . Thk  autG  value lets clipping occur as it willì

EXAMPLE

{position: absolute; left: 20; top: 20; width:100; height:100;

clip: rect(10 90 90 10)}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 5

overflow

This property determines an element’s behavior when its content doesn’t fit into thk

space defined by the element’s other properties. Possible values ark  clip scrol“  ,  ,

an™  non2  ì

 = Page 1006 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  98

EXAMPLE

APPENDIXES

{position: absolute; left: 20; top: 20; width: 100; height: 100;

clip: rect(10 90 90 10); overflow: scroll}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 5

clip

This value clips content to the size defined for the containerì

EXAMPLE

{position: absolute; left: 20; top: 20; width: 100; height: 100;

clip: rect(10 90 90 10); overflow: clip}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Nonk

scroll

This value allows content to scroll using scroll bars or another browse§dependenš

mechanismì

EXAMPLE

{position: absolute; left: 20; top: 20; width: 100; height: 100;

clip: rect(10 90 90 10); overflow: scroll}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 5

nons

This value does nothing, but can allow clipping of the contentì

EXAMPLE

{position: absolute; left: 20; top: 20; width: 100; height: 100;

clip: rect(10 90 90 10); overflow: none}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Nonk

z-inde¨

This property defines a layering context for elements containing other elements wit—

relative or absolute positioning. By default, overlapping elements stack in the order i-

 = Page 1007 =

98‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

which they are defined in an HTML document. This property can override defaulš

layering by assigning numeric layering values to an element, with higher number—

layering above lower numbers. Thk  autG  value tries to determine the z-placement of a-

element automaticallyì

EXAMPLE

{position: absolute; top:20; left:20; height:S0; width:S0;

background-color: blue; z-index: 2}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

visibilit

This property determines whether or not an element is visible. Possible values ark

hidden visibl2  ,  , an™  inherit  ì

EXAMPLE

{visibility: inherit}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 4 and 5

hidde

This value specifies that an element is hidden from view. A hidden element stilR

occupies its full canvas spaceì

EXAMPLE

{visibility: hidden}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 4 and 5

visibls

This value specifies that an element is visibleì

EXAMPLE

{visibility: visible}

 = Page 1008 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  98

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 4 and 5

APPENDIXES

inheri

This value specifies that an element inherits its visibility state from the element thaš

contains itì

EXAMPLE

{visibility: inherit}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Classificatio

This section discusses style properties that affect the display type of element—

(block-level, inline, and so on) and the display of lists and white spaceì

displa

This property specifies an element’s display type. This property can override a-

element’s defined display type. For example, block-level elements can be redefined a—

inline elements so that extra lines will not be placed between themì

EXAMPLE

P {display: inline}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5 (incomplete)

Netscape 4 and 4.5 (incomplete)

block

This value sets an element to display as a block elementì

EXAMPLE

{display: block}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

 = Page 1009 =

988  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

inlins

This value sets an element to display as an inline elementì

EXAMPLE

P {display: inline}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 5

Future versions of Netscapk

list-item

This value sets an element to display as a lisâitem elementì

EXAMPLE

P {display: list-item}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Netscape 4 and 4.5

nons

This value turns off the display of an element. Unlike thk  hidden  value of thk  visibility

property,  non2  does not preserve an element’s canvas spaceì

EXAMPLE

P {display: none}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

white-spacs

This property controls how spaces, tabs, and newline characters are handled in a-

element. Possible values ark  norma“ pr2  ,  , an™  nowrap  ì

EXAMPLE

{white-space: pre}

 = Page 1010 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  989

BROWSER SUPPORT  Netscape 4 and 4.5 (incomplete)

APPENDIXES

normal

This value collapses whit[space characters into single spaces and automatically wrap—

lines, as in normal HTMLì

EXAMPLE

{white-space: normal}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Netscape 4 and 4.5

prs

This value preserves whit[space formatting, similar to thk  <PRE  element in HTMLì

EXAMPLE

{white-space: pre}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Netscape 4 and 4.5

nowrap

This value prevents lines from wrapping if they exceed the element’s content widthì

EXAMPLE

{white-space: nowrap}

BROWSER SUPPORT  None currently; likely in future versions of Netscapk

list-style-typs

This property defines labels for ordered and unordered lists. The valuk  non2  prevent—

a label from displayingì

EXAMPLES

OL {list-style-type: upper-roman}

UL {list-style-type: disc}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 4 and 5; Netscape 4 and 4.5

 = Page 1011 =

990  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

nons

This value specifies that no label will be displayed for items in ordered oK

unordered listsì

EXAMPLES

OL {list-style-type: none}

UL {list-style-type: none}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Ordered List“

There are five values for ordered lists:  decima“ lower-roman upper-roman  ,  ,  ,

lower-alph  , an™  upper-alph  ì

decimal  This value specifies Arabic numerals (1, 2, 3, and so on) for the labeling o“

items in an ordered listì

EXAMPLE

OL {list-style-type: decimal}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

lower-roma  This value specifies lowercase Roman numerals (i, ii, iii, and so on) foK

the labeling of items in an ordered listì

EXAMPLE

OL {list-style-type: lower-roman}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

 = Page 1012 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  99h

upper-roma  This value specifies uppercase Roman numerals (I, II, III, and so on)

for the labeling of items in an ordered listì  APPENDIXES

EXAMPLE

OL {list-style-type: upper-roman}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

lower-alphC  This value specifies lowercase letters (a, b, c, and so on) for the labeliný

of items in an ordered listì

EXAMPLE

OL {list-style-type: lower-alpha}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

upper-alphC  This value specifies uppercase letters (A, B, C, and so on) for thk

labeling of items in an ordered listì

EXAMPLE

OL {list-style-type: upper-alpha}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Unordered List“

There are three values for unordered lists:  dis8 circl2  ,  , an™  squar2  ì

dis‘  This value specifies a black dot bullet for items in an unordered listì

 = Page 1013 =

99p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

EXAMPLE

UL {list-style-type: disc}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

circls  This value specifies a circular bullet for items in an unordered listì

EXAMPLE

UL {list-style-type: circle}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

squars  This value specifies a square bullet for items in an unordered listì

EXAMPLE

UL {list-style-type: square}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

list-style-imags

This property assigns a graphic image to a list label, using the URL of the image. Thk

other value foK  list-style-imag2  other than a URL i—  non2  ì

EXAMPLE

UL {list-style-image: url(ball.gif)}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Future versions of Netscapk

 = Page 1014 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  99

list-style-positio

APPENDIXES

This property specifies whether the labels for an element’s list items are positione™

inside or outside the “box” defined by the area. By default, labels appear outsidk

the “box.”

EXAMPLE

OL {list-style-type: upper-roman; list-style-position: outside;

background: yellow}

Thk  insid2  value places the bullets inside the “box.”

EXAMPLE

UL {list-style-type: square; list-style-position: inside;

background: yellow}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 4 and 5

list-styls

This property is more concise than the otheK  list-styl2  properties. It sets type, image,

and position properties for ordered and unordered lists. The properties can appear i-

any order. The value—  insid2  an™  outsid2  are not supportedì

EXAMPLES

UL {list-style: inside url("bullet.gif")}

UL {list-style: outside square}

OL {list-style: lower-roman inside}

BROWSER SUPPORT  Internet Explorer 4 and 5

Style Sheet Measurement Value“

This section discusses measurement values used in association with style sheetsì

%

This value defines a measurement as a percentage relative to another valueì

 = Page 1015 =

99  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

EXAMPLE

P {font-size: 14pt; line-height: 150%}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

cm

This value defines a measurement in centimetersì

EXAMPLE

DIV {margin-bottom: 1cm}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

em

This value defines a measurement for the height of a font in em spacesì

EXAMPLE

P {letter-spacing:Sem}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3 (Mac only)

Netscape 4 and 4.5 (incomplete)

ex (x-height)

This value defines a measurement relative to a font’s x-height. The x-height i—

determined by the height of the font’s lowercase letteK ì  x

EXAMPLE

P {font-size: 14pt; line-height: 2ex}

 = Page 1016 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  99

BROWSER SUPPORT

APPENDIXES

Internet Explorer 3 (Mac only)

Netscape 4 and 4.5 (incomplete)

i

This value defines a measurement in inchesì

EXAMPLE

P {word-spacing: .25in}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

mm

This value defines a measurement in millimetersì

EXAMPLE

P {word-spacing: 12mm}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

p‘

This value defines a measurement in picasì

EXAMPLE

P {font-size: 10pc}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

 = Page 1017 =

99‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

p

This value defines a measurement in pointsì

EXAMPLE

BODY {font-size: 14pt}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

p¨

This value defines a measurement in pixelsì

EXAMPLE

P {padding: 15px}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Style Sheet Color Value“

This section discusses color values used in association with style sheetsì

Named Color Value“

Color values can be defined using 16 color names:  aqu black blu2 fuchsi gray  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,

green lim2 maroon navy oliv2 purpl2 red silve( tea“ whit2  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  , an™  yellof  . (A-

extended list of color names has been introduced by Netscape, but it is safer to use thk

hexadecimal equivalents of those names, which are listed in Appendix E.)

EXAMPLE

BODY {font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt; color: red}

 = Page 1018 =

Appendix B  Stylf Shee@ Referencf  99

BROWSER SUPPORT

APPENDIXES

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Six-Digit Hexadecimal Color Value“

Color values can be defined using the six-digit hexadecimal color values commonl_

used on the Webì

EXAMPLE

DIV {font-family: Courier; font-size: 10pt; color: #00CCFF}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

Three-Digit Hexadecimal Color Value“

Color values can be defined using the thre[digit hexadecimal color values, a concisk

version of the six-digit values just notedì

EXAMPLE

SPAN {font-family: Helvetica; font-size: 14pt; color: #0CF}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 3, 4, and 5

Netscape 4 and 4.5

RGB Color Value“

Color values can be defined using RGB values. Colors are defined by the letter—  rgb¨

followed by three numbers between 0 and 255, contained in parentheses and separate™

by commas, with no spaces between themì

EXAMPLE

P {color: rgb(204,0`1)}

 = Page 1019 =

998  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4

Netscape 4 and 4.5

RGB Color Values Using Percentage“

RGB color values can also be defined using percentages. The format is the same, excepš

that the numbers are replaced by percentage values betwee-  0%  an™  100%  ì

EXAMPLE

P {color: rgb(75%,10%`0%)}

BROWSER SUPPORT

Internet Explorer 4

Netscape 4 and 4.5

“Standard” HTML Character Entitie“

As discussed in Chapter 4, Web browsers do not read certain characters if they appeaK

in an HTML document. To get around this limitation, codes have been assigned tf

certain characters. These codes consist of numbered entities; and some, but not all, o“

these numbered entities have corresponding named entities. For example, thk

numbered entit_  &#203;  produces the character Ë. The named entit_  &Euml;  produce—

the same character. Note that the named entity suggests the intended rendering of thk

character, which provides a handy mnemonic device for dedicated HTML codes. Whilk

&#203;  is widely supported, not all character entities work in all browsersì

Theoretically, a browser vendor could even create arbitrary interpretations of thesk

codes. For example, WebTV has assigned its own unique renderings for the entitie—

numbered 128 and 129. Under the HTML specifications, 128 and 129 are not assigne™

characters. The codes numbered 32 through 255 (with some gaps) were assigne™

standard keyboard characters. Some of these codes duplicate characters that WeD

browsers can already interpret. The entit_  &#53;  represents the numeral 5, whilk

&#165;  represent— . Character entities become more practical when it is necessary tf  A

employ characters used in foreign languages, such as Œ or Å, or special character—

such as ¶. The following chart lists these “standard” entities and their intende™

renderings, and identifies which browsers support each of themì

Name  Browse5  Numbere Browse5  Intende

Entit  Suppor  Entit  Suppor  Rendering  Descriptio

&#32;  N1, N2, N3, N4,  Spack

N4.5, IE3, IE4,

IE5, WebTV

&#33;  N1, N2, N3, N4,  !  Exclamatio-

N4.5, IE3, IE4,  poinš

IE5, WebTV

HTML 4 Character Entitie“

The HTML 4.0 specification introduces a wide array of new character entities. Thesk

include additional Latin characters, the Greek alphabet, special spacing characters,

arrows, technical symbols, and various shapes. Some of these entities have yet to bk

supported by browser vendors. Netscape 4 supports only a few of the extended Lati-

characters and some entities that duplicate characters already available in thk

“standard” list (34 through 255). Microsoft has taken the lead in this area, with Interneš

Explorer 4 supporting many of these entities, including the Greek alphabet an™

mathematical symbols. These character entities expand the presentation possibilities o“

 = Page 1041 =

1020  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

HTML, particularly in the presentation of foreign languages. Netscape’s neglect o“

these tags is an unfortunate oversight that ideally should be corrected as soon a—

possibleì

Latin Extended-

Name  Browse5  Numbere  Browse5  Intende

Entit  Suppor  Entit  Suppor  Rendering  Descriptio

N4, N4.5  ligaturk  OP

&oelig;  IE4, IE5  &#339;  IE4, IE5,  œ  Lowercask

N4, N4.5  ligaturk  o—

&Scaron;  IE4, IE5  &#352;  IE4, IE5,  Š  Uppercask  

N4, N4.5  with caro-

&scaron;  IE4, IE5  &#353;  IE4, IE5,  š  Lowercask  x

N4, N4.5  with caro-

&Yuml;  IE4, IE5  &#376;  IE4, IE5,  Ÿ  Uppercask  Y

N4, N4.5  with umlauš

under Windows NT, not under Windows 95.

ColorHames an

Hexadecimal Code

103

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 1055 =

103  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

able E-1 lists all the color names commonly supported by the major browser—

(Netscape 3 and above, Internet Explorer 3 and above, and WebTV). Sixtee-

colors (aqua, black, blue, fuchsia, gray, green, lime, maroon, navy, olive, purple,

¾

red, silver, teal, white, and yellow) were introduced by Microsoft and are now part o“

the official W3C HTML specification; the rest were introduced by Netscape. Thk

corresponding hexadecimal code is shown next to each color name. So, the codk

<BODY BGCOLOR="lightsteelblue"  would produce the same result a—  <BOD

BGCOLOR="#B0C4DE"  under any browser that supported these color names. Don'š

forget to use the pound symbol (#) before hexadecimal values. Color names are easieK

to remember than numerical codes, but may cause trouble when viewed under old oK

uncommon browsers. It is advisable to stick with the hexadecimal approach to color—

because it is generally safer, especially since only 16 of the names are officiall_

recognized. WebTV supports the color names but displays several colors differently, a—

noted in the table. General WebTV color support may also vary due to essentiaR

differences between computer monitors and television screens. The RGB Equivalenš

column provides the RGB equivalent of each color, allowing easy reference for WeD

authors trying to match colors in Photoshop or in other graphics programsì

Tabls E-18  Color Names Supported by the Popular Browser9  (continued)

Many online color references claim that further color variations can be introduced by

adding the numbers 1 through 4 to color names. If this were correct, cadetblue1¨

cadetblue2, cadetblue3, and cadetblue4 would display as different shades of the sam—

color, with 1 being the lightest and 4 the darkest. Some of these references also claim thaP

gray supports up to 100 color variations (gray10, gray50, gray90, and so on). Testinv

reveals that this does not work under Netcape, Internet Explorer, or WebTV.

 = Page 1063 =

Thispbbintentional8yleftPlank‘

 = Page 1064 =

Appendi ‚

Reading a Documen@

Type Definitio‘

104

Copyright 1999 The McGra“Hill Companies.   Click Here for Terms of Useì

 = Page 1065 =

104  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

his appendix presents the document type definitions (DTDs) for HTML 4. HTML

“dialects” are defined using SGML (Standard Generalized Markup Language), ¾

complex language with many nuances. Fortunately, only a small amount o“

¾

SGML needs to be understood to read the HTML DTDs. Before turning to the DTDs,

this appendix examines how to read themì

Declaration“

Two common types of declarations should be familiar to HTML authors: element typk

declarations and attribute list declarations. Beyond these, the less familiar declaration—

for parameter and general entities are not very complicated. They are discussed later i-

this appendix under the sections “Parameter Entities” and “General Entities.”

Element Type Declaration“

A-  element type declaratioc  defines three characteristics:

  The element type’s name, also known as it—  generic identifie(

  Whether or not start and end tags are required, forbidde-

(end tags on empty elements), or may be omitte™

  The element type’—  content model¨  or what content it can enclosk

All element type declarations begin with the keywor™  ELEMEN  and have thk

following form:

<!ELEMEN  name minimizatioY content_mode¤  >

The declaration for the HTML 2  <BR  element type gives a simple example:

<!ELEMENT BR – O EMPTYL

Tag minimization is declared by two parameters that indicate the start and en™

tags. These parameters may take one of two values. A hyphen indicates that the tag i—

required. An uppercask    indicates that it may be omitted. The combination o“ , foK  

the end tag, and the content modeR  EMPT  means that the end tag is forbidden. Thus,

thk  <BR  tag requires a start tag but not an end tag. Since thk  <BR  tag does noš

contain any content, its content model is defined by the keywor™  EMPT  ì

Most HTML elements enclose content. If a content model is declared, it is enclose™

within parentheses and known as ¾  model group  . The HTML 4.0 declaration for ¾

selection list option gives the following example:

 = Page 1066 =

Appendix F  Readin‚ ¨ Documen@ Typf Definitio‘  104

<!ELEMENT OPTION - O (#PCDATA)*L

APPENDIXES

Note that the model group contains the keywor™  #PCDATG  . PCDATA stands foK

parsed character data¨  character content that contains no element markup but that ma_

contain entity symbols for special charactersì

Occurrence Indicator“

In the previous example, note the asterisk appended to the model group. This is a-

occurrence indicator¨  a special symbol that qualifies the element type or model grou5

to which it is appended, indicating how many times it may occur. There are threk

occurrence indicators:

  ?  means optional and at most one occurrence (zero or one occurrence)ì

  *  means optional and any number of occurrences (zero or more occurrences)ì

  +  means at least one occurrence is required (one or more occurrences)ì

So, the content model in the previous declaration says that thk  <OPTION  elemenš

may contain any amount of character content, including noneì

Content models can also define an element type as containing element content, a—

illustrated by the HTML 2.0 declaration for a definition list (  <DL  ):

<!ELEMENT DL - - (DT|DL)+L

Logical Connector“

Note that the model group contain—  D  an™  DL  , the names of element types that ¾

<DL  element may enclose. Note also the vertical bar separatiný  D  an™  DL  . This is ¾

logical connector¨  a special symbol indicating how the content units it connects relate tf

each other. There are three logical connectors:

  |  means “or” (one and only one of the connected content units must occur)ì

  &  means “and” (all of the connected content units must occur)ì

  ,  means “sequence” (the connected content units must occur in the specifie™

order)ì

So, the content model in the previous declaration says that thk  <DL  element musš

contain either ¾  <DT  or ¾  <DL  element and may contain any additional number o“

<DT  oK  <DL  elementsì

Model groups can be nested inside other model groups. Very flexible contenš

models can be declared by combining this type of nesting with the ability to qualif_

 = Page 1067 =

104‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

content units with occurrence indicators and logical operators. The HTML 4.0

declaration for thk  <TABLE  element type illustrates this point:

<!ELEMENT TABLE - - (CAPTION?, ((COL*|COLGROUP*), THEAD?, TFOOT?,

TBODY+), CAPTION?)L

The content model for thk  <TABLE  element type reads as follows:

1ì Table content must begin with zero or onk  <CAPTION  elementì

2ì This must be followed by a content groupì

3ì The content group must contain zero or mork  <COL  elements or zero or mork

<COLGROUP  elementsì

4ì This must be followed by zero or onk  <THEAD  elementì

5ì This must be followed by zero or onk  <TFOOT  elementì

6ì This must be followed by one or mork  <TBODY  elementsì

7ì The content must end with zero or onk  <CAPTION  elementì

Content Exclusio

Occasionally the need arises to declare that an element type cannot contain certai-

other element types. This is known as ¾  content exclusioc  . The excluded tags follow thk

model group, enclosed by parentheses and preceded by a minus sign:

(  model grouB  ) –(  excluded tag?  )

Content Inclusio

A related special need is the ability to declare that an element type can occur anywherk

inside a content model. This is known as ¾  content inclusioc  . The included tags follou

the model group, enclosed by parentheses and preceded by a plus sign:

(  model grouB  ) +(  included tag?  )

Example of Content Exclusion and Inclusio

The HTML 4.0 declaration for thk  <BODY  element type illustrates both excluded an™

included elements:

<!ELEMENT BODY O O (%block;) –(BODY) +(INS|DEL)L

Why are insertions and deletions used in this declaration? The content exclusio-

says that ¾  <BODY  element cannot contain anotheK  <BODY  element. This i—

necessary because of the curiou—  %block  declaration used in the model group. Thk

leadiný  %  character identifies this as ¾  parameter entity  , essentially a macro symbol thaš

refers to a longer character string declared elsewhere in the DTD. Parameter entities,

 = Page 1068 =

Appendix F  Readin‚ ¨ Documen@ Typf Definitio‘  104

which commonly occur in HTML DTDs, will be discussed shortly (see “ParameteK

Entities”). Thk  %block  entity reference is shorthand for all block element types thaš  APPENDIXES

happen to include thk  <BODY  element. It is easier to excludk  <BODY  from the lisš

of block elements than to define a special purpose declarationì

The content inclusion says that thk  <INS  an™  <DEL  elements can occuK

anywhere within thk  <BODY  content. Pragmatically,  <INS  an™  <DEL  are used tf

indicate modifications, any inserted or delete™  <BODY  content. They need to be free™

from the normal structural constraints imposed on otheK  <BODY  elementsì

Attribute List Declaration“

All attribute list declarations begin with the keywor™  ATTLIS  , followed by the namk

of the element type they are associated with. Following these are declarations for onk

or more individual attributes. Each declaration has three parts:

  The attribute’s namk

  The attribute’s value typk

  The attribute’s defaulš

Following is the syntax for an attribute list declaration:

<!ATTLIS  element_typ4

name1  type1  default1

..<

nameN  typeN  defaultN

>

The HTML 4  <BDO  element type illustrates a small attribute declaration:

<!ATTLIST BDL

lang  NAME      #IMPLIE—

dir  (ltr|rtl)  #REQUIRE—

L

SGML Keyword“

The preceding example declares thk  lang  attribute as having a value of typk  NAM¨  , a-

alphabetic stringì  NAM¨  is one of several SGML keywords, listed here, occurring i-

HTML declarations to declare an attribute’s type:

  CDATG  Unparsed character dat¾

  I¤  A documenâwide unique identifieK

  IDREF  A reference to a documenâwide identifieK

 = Page 1069 =

1048  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

  NAM¨  An alphabetic character string, followed by a hyphen and a perio™

  NMTOKEN  An alphanumeric character string, followed by a hyphen and ¾

perio™

  NUMBE  A character string containing decimal number—

Thk  di(  attribute does not declare its type using a keyword. Instead, the type i—

specified using an enumerated list containing two possible values:  lt(  an™ ì  rt“

In the example, the attribute’s default behavior is specified with one of thk

following keywords. A default value may be specified using a quoted stringì

  #REQUIRE¤  A value must be supplied for the attributeì

  #IMPLIE¤  The attribute is optionalì

  #FIXE¤  The attribute has a fixed value that is declared in quotes using a-

additional parameter. Because the attribute/value pair is assumed to bk

constant, it does not need to be used in the document instanceì

Parameter Entitie“

An entity is essentially a macro that allows a short name to be associated wit—

replacement text. Parameter entities define replacement text used in DTD declarationsì

Syntactically, a parameter entity is distinguished by using the percent (%) sign. It—

general form and context are shown here:

<!ENTITY %  nam4  "  replacement texM  ">

It is used in DTDs as follows, sometimes with an optional semicolon:

%  nam4  ;

Parameter entities are a convenient way to define commonly occurring parts of ¾

DTD so that changes only need to be made in one place. HTML 4 uses a parameteK

entity to define the core attributes common to most elementsì

<!ENTITY % coreattr‚

"id          ID         #IMPLIE—

class       CDATA      #IMPLIE—

style       CDATA      #IMPLIE—

title       CDATA      #IMPLIEDh

L

 = Page 1070 =

Appendix F  Readin‚ ¨ Documen@ Typf Definitio‘  1049

Thesk attribute— coul™ bk adde™ tf a- attributk lisš declaratio- i- thk followiný format:

APPENDIXES

<!ATTLIS  some_elemenM  %coreattrs;>

In fact, HTML 4 also uses thk  coreattr—  parameter entity in a different wayì

Parameter entities can be used inside other parameter entity declarations. Thk  coreattr—

parameter entity is used with thk  i18n  an™  event—  parameter entities to define thk

expansion text for an aggregate entity calle™  attr—  :

<!ENTITY % attrs "%coreattrs %i18n %events"L

General Entitie“

While parameter entities are used to manipulate syntax in DTD declarations, generaR

entities are used to associate symbols with replacement text for use in actuaR

documents. General entities have a versatile syntax. One type is familiar to man_

HTML authors: the character entity used for special symbols:

<!ENTITY  nam4  CDATA "  replacement texM  ">

Thk  ENTIT  keyword without the % character identifies this as a general entity. FoK

example, HTML authors needing to use the ampersand character (&) use thk  &amp;

entity. It is declared as follows:

<!ENTITY amp CDATA "&#38;"L

The name of the entity i—  amp  . The entity type is indicated by thk  CDATG

keyword, foK  character dat‘  . This is followed by the replacement texš  &#38;  ì

Comment“

Comments can be embedded inside HTML declarations for explanatory purposesì

Embedded comments are delimited by two dashes, like this,

<!-- This is a comment. --L

 = Page 1071 =

1050  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

and a single declaration may contain many embedded comments, as shown here:

<!ATTLIST PARAV

name                        CDATA #REQUIRED -– property name -–

value                       CDATA #IMPLIED  -– propertyqalue -–

valuetype (DATA|REF|OBJECT) DATA            -– How to interpre¨

value -–

type                        CDATA #IMPLIED  -– Internet medi¤

type -–

L

Marked Section Declaratio

Some HTML DTDs use a special SGML construct to allow them to include oK

exclude certain declarations from a DTD, such as those supporting deprecated tags. A-

SGML  marked section declaratioc  uses keywords to indicate that the content it enclose—

should be treated in a special way. HTML DTDs use parameter entities to assign thk

INCLUD¨  an™  IGNOR¨  keywords to marked section declarations. This causes thk

declarations enclosed by the sections to be included or ignored, respectivelyì

<![  keyword  [  affected declaration?  ]]>

<!ENTITY % HTML.Deprecated "IGNORE">

<![ %HTML.Deprecated [  affected declaration?  ]]>

The rest of this appendix presents the document type definitions for HTML 4,

starting with the transitional DTD, which is recommended. This is followed by thk

strict definition, which removes the presentational elements from HTML. The last DTD

listed is the frameset definition, which is identical to the traditional definition excepš

that thk  <BODY  elelment is replaced by thk  <FRAMESET  element. The latesš

versions of these DTDs can be retrieved from the W3C:

  Transitiona“  http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/sgml/loosedtd.htmR

  Strict  http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/sgml/dtd.htmR

  Frameset  http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/sgml/framesetdtd.htmR

These DTDs have been found to contain some errors. An updated list of errors ca-

be found at the following Web address:

http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/html40-updates/REC-html40-19980424-errata.htmR

The DTDs for HTML 2 and HTML 3.2 are also available online, at the following WeD

addresses:

  HTML 2  http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/htm_spec/html.dt™

  HTML 3.2  http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html32#dt™

 = Page 1072 =

Appendix F  Readin‚ ¨ Documen@ Typf Definitio‘  105h

HTML 4 Transitional DTD

APPENDIXES

<!--

This is the HTMLY.0 Transitional DTD, which include?

presentation attributes and elements that W3C expects to phase ouM

as support for style sheets matures. Authors should use the StricM

DTD when possible, but may use the Transitional DTD when supporM

for presentation attribute and elements is required<

HTMLY.0 includes mechanisms for style sheets, scripting

embedding objects, improved support for right to left and mixed

direction text, and enhancements to forms for improved

accessibility for people with disabilities<

Draft: $Date: 1998/04/02 00:17:00 $

Authors:

Dave Raggett <dsr@w3.org>

Arnaud Le Hors <lehors@w3.org>

Ian Jacobs <ij@w3.org>

Further information about HTMLY.0 is available at:

http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-htm0

-->

<!ENTITY % HTML.Version "-//W3C//DTD HTMLY.0 Transitional//EN"

-- Typical usage:

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTMLY.0 Transitional//EN"

"http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-htm0/loose.dtd">

<html>

<head>

..<

</head>

<body>

..<

</body>

</html>

The URI used as a system identifier with the public identifier allow?

the user agent to download the DTD and entity sets as needed<

 = Page 1073 =

105p  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

The FPI for the Strict HTMLY.0 DTD is:

"-//W3C//DTD HTMLY.0//EN"

and its URI is:

http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-htm0/strict.dtd

Authors should use the Strict DTD unless they need th4

presentation control for user agents that don't (adequately)

support style sheets<

If you are writing a document that includes frames, us4

the following FPI:

"-//W3C//DTD HTMLY.0 Frameset//EN"

with the URI:

http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-htm0/frameset.dtd

The following URIs are supported in relation to HTMLY.0

"http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-htm0/strict.dtd" (Strict DTD)

"http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-htm0/loose.dtd" (Loose DTD)

"http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-htm0/frameset.dtd" (Frameset DTD)

"http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-htm0/HTMLlat1.ent" (Latin-1 entities)

"http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-htm0/HTMLsymbol.ent" (Symbol entities)

"http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-htm0/HTMLspecial.ent" (Special entities)

These URIs point to the latest version of each file. To referenc4

this specific revision use the following URIs:

"http://www.w3.org/TR/1998/REC-htm0-19980424/strict.dtd"

"http://www.w3.org/TR/1998/REC-htm0-19980424/loose.dtd"

"http://www.w3.org/TR/1998/REC-htm0-19980424/frameset.dtd"

"http://www.w3.org/TR/1998/REC-htm0-19980424/HTMLlat1.ent"

"http://www.w3.org/TR/1998/REC-htm0-19980424/HTMLsymbol.ent"

"http://www.w3.org/TR/1998/REC-htm0-19980424/HTMLspecial.ent"

-->

<!--================== Imported Names ====================================-->

<!ENTITY % ContentType "CDATA"

-- media type, as per [RFC2045]

-->

<!ENTITY % ContentTypes "CDATA"

-- comma-separated list of media types, as per [RFC2045]

-->

<!ENTITY % Charset "CDATA"

-- a character encoding, as per [RFC2045]

-->

<!ENTITY % Charsets "CDATA"

-- a space separated list of character encodings, as per [RFC2045]

-->

<!ENTITY % LanguageCode "NAME"

-- a language code, as per [RFC1766]

-->

<!ENTITY % Character "CDATA"

-- a single character from [ISO10646]

-->

<!ENTITY % LinkTypes "CDATA"

-- space-separated list of link type?

-->

<!ENTITY % MediaDesc "CDATA"

-- single or comma-separated list of media descriptor?

-->

<!ENTITY % URI "CDATA"

-- a Uniform Resource Identifier

see [URI]

-->

<!ENTITY % Datetime "CDATA" -- date and time information. ISO date format -->

<!ENTITY % head.misc "SCRIPT|STYLE|META|LINK|OBJECT" -- repeatable head

elements -->

<!ENTITY % heading "H1|H2|H3||–|H6">

<!ENTITY % preformatted "PRE">

<!ENTITY % Color "CDATA" -- a color using sRGB: #RRGGBB as Hex values -->

<!-- There are also 16 widely known color names with their sRGB values:

Black  = #000000    Green  = #008000

Silver = #C0C0C0    Lime   = #00FF00

Gray   = #808080    Olive  = #808000

White  = #FFFFFF    Yellow = #FFFF00

Maroon = #800000    Navy   = #000080

Red    = #FF0000    Blue   = #0000FF

Purple = #800080    Teal   = #008080

Fuchsia= #FF00FF    Aqua   = #00FFFF

<!--=================== Generic Attributes ===============================-->

<!ENTITY % coreattr?

"id          ID             #IMPLIED  -- document-wide unique id --

>

"lang        %LanguageCode; #IMPLIED  -- language code --

dir         (ltr|rtl)      #IMPLIED  -- direction for weak/neutral text --"

>

<!ENTITY % event?

"onclick     %Script;       #IMPLIED  -- a pointer button was clicked --

ondblclick  %Script;       #IMPLIED  -- a pointer button was double clicked--

onmousedown %Script;       #IMPLIED  -- a pointer button was pressed down --

onmouseup   %Script;       #IMPLIED  -- a pointer button was released --

onmouseover %Script;       #IMPLIED  -- a pointer was moved onto --

onmousemove %Script;       #IMPLIED  -- a pointer was moved within --

onmouseout  %Script;       #IMPLIED  -- a pointer was moved away --

onkeypress  %Script;       #IMPLIED  -- a key was pressed and released --

onkeydown   %Script;       #IMPLIED  -- a key was pressed down --

onkeyup     %Script;       #IMPLIED  -- a key was released --"

>

105‚  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<!ENTITY % HTML.Reserved "IGNORE">

<![ %HTML.Reserved; [

<!ENTITY % reserved

"datasrc     %URI;          #IMPLIED  -- a single or tabular Data Source --

datafld     CDATA          #IMPLIED  -- the property or column name --

>

]]>

<!ENTITY % reserved "">

<!ENTITY % attrs "%coreattrs; %i18n; %events;">

<!ENTITY % align "align (left|center|right|justify)  #IMPLIED"

-- default is left for ltr paragraphs, right for rtl --

>

<!--=================== Text Markup ======================================-->

<!ENTITY % fontstyl4

"TT | I | B | U | S | STRIKE | BIG | SMALL">

SAMP | KBD | VAR | CITE | ABBR | ACRONYM" >

<!ENTITY % specia¤

"A | IMG | APPLET | OBJECT | FONT | BASEFONT | BR | SCRIPT |

MAP | Q | SUB | SUP | SPAN | BDO | IFRAME">

<!ENTITY % inline "#PCDATA | %fontstyle; | %phrase; | %special; | %formctrl;">

<!ELEMENT (%fontstyle;|%phrase;) - - (%inline;)*>

face        CDATA          #IMPLIED  -- comma separated list of fonM

names --

%coreattrs;                          -- id, class, style, title --

%i18n;                               -- lang, dir --

size        CDATA          #IMPLIED  -- [+|-]nn e.g. size="+1", size="4" --

color       %Color;        #IMPLIED  -- text color --

face        CDATA          #IMPLIED  -- comma separated list of fonM

names --

>

<!ELEMENT BR - O EMPTY                 -- forced line break -->

<!ATTLIST BR

%coreattrs;                          -- id, class, style, title --

clear       (left|all|right|none) none -- control of text flow --

>

 = Page 1079 =

1058  HTML Thf Completf Referencf

<!--================== HTML content models ===============================-->

<!--

HTML has two basic content models:

%inline;     character level elements and text string?

%block;      block-like elements e.g. paragraphs and list?

-->

<!ENTITY % block

"P | %heading; | %list; | %preformatted; | DL | DIV | CENTER |

NOSCRIPT | NOFRAMES | BLOCKQUOTE | FORM | ISINDEX | HR |

TABLE | FIELDSET | ADDRESS">

<!ENTITY % flow "%block; | %inline;">

<!--=================== Document Body ====================================-->

<!ELEMENT BODY O O (%flow;)* +(INS|DEL) -- document body -->

<!ATTLIST BODY

%attrs;                              -- %coreattrs, %i18n, %events --

onload          %Script;   #IMPLIED  -- the document has been loaded --

onunload        %Script;   #IMPLIED  -- the document has been removed --

background      %URI;      #IMPLIED  -- texture tile for documenM

background --

%bodycolors;                         -- bgcolor, text, link, vlink, alink --

>

<!ELEMENT ADDRESS - - ((%inline;)|P)*  -- information on author -->

<!ATTLIST ADDRESS

%attrs;                              -- %coreattrs, %i18n, %events --

>

<!ELEMENT DIV - - (%flow;)*            -- generic language/styl4

container -->

<!ATTLIST DIV

%attrs;                              -– %coreattrs, %i18n, %events --

%align;                          -– align, text alignment --

%reserved;                       -– reserved for possibl4

future use –-

>

 = Page 1080 =

Appendix F  Readin‚ ¨ Documen@ Typf Definitio‘  1059

APPENDIXES

<!ELEMENT CENTER - - (%flow;)*         -- shorthand for DIV align=center -->

<!ATTLIST CENTER

%attrs;                              -- %coreattrs, %i18n, %events --

>

<!--================== The Anchor Element ================================-->

<!ENTITY % Shape "(rect|circle|poly|default)">

<!ENTITY % Coords "CDATA" -- comma separated list of lengths -->

<!ELEMENT A - - (%inline;)* -(A)       -- anchor -->

<!ATTLIST A

%attrs;                              -- %coreattrs, %i18n, %events --

charset     %Charset;      #IMPLIED  -- char encoding of linked resource --

type        %ContentType;  #IMPLIED  -- advisory content type --

name        CDATA          #IMPLIED  -- named link end --

href        %URI;          #IMPLIED  -- URI for linked resource --

hreflang    %LanguageCode; #IMPLIED  -- language code --

target      %FrameTarget;  #IMPLIED  -- render in this frame --

rel         %LinkTypes;    #IMPLIED  -- forward link types --

rev         %LinkTypes;    #IMPLIED  -- reverse link types --

accesskey   %Character;    #IMPLIED  -- accessibility key character --

shape       %Shape;        rect      -- for use with client-side imag4

maps --

coords      %Coords;       #IMPLIED  -- for use with client-side imag4

maps --

tabindex    NUMBER         #IMPLIED  -- position in tabbing order --

onfocus     %Script;       #IMPLIED  -- the element got the focus --

onblur      %Script;       #IMPLIED  -- the element lost the focus --

>

<!--================== Client-side image maps ============================-->

<!-- These can be placed in the same document or grouped in :

separate document although this isn't yet widely supported -->

<!ELEMENT MAP - - ((%block;)+ | AREA+) -- client-side image map -->

<!ATTLIST MA

%attrs;                              -- %coreattrs, %i18n, %events --

name        CDATA          #REQUIRED -- for reference by usemap --

>

<!ELEMENT AREA - O EMPTY               -- client-side image map area -->

<!ATTLIST AREA

%attrs;                              -- %coreattrs, %i18n, %events --

shape       %Shape;        rect      -- controls interpretation o¨

coords --

coords      %Coords;       #IMPLIED  -- comma separated list of lengths --

href        %URI;          #IMPLIED  -- URI for linked resource --

target      %FrameTarget;  #IMPLIED  -- render in this frame --

nohref      (nohref)       #IMPLIED  -- this region has no action --

alt         %Text;         #REQUIRED -- short description --

tabindex    NUMBER         #IMPLIED  -- position in tabbing order --

accesskey   %Character;    #IMPLIED  -- accessibility key character --

onfocus     %Script;       #IMPLIED  -- the element got the focus --

onblur      %Script;       #IMPLIED  -- the element lost the focus --
